content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												Aside from optimization issues at launch (then again who doesn't these days?), this game is fantastic.The difficulty is hitting alot of XCOM players in the face, and there seems to be negativity regarding the turn limits. People saying it limits decision making, or forces run and gun. It doesn't. What it does do is remove the old "victory through overwatch" strategy that was so popular (read: OP) in XCOM EU & EW. Yeah, I did it too. Did a run through right before XCOM 2 came out and only lost one soldier. Because I decided to (lazy/didn't care at that point). No challenge at all if you really took your time and especially if had two snipers. Given that this is a guerilla operation in XCOM 2, it is true that your team simply does not have all the time in the world. This does not limit options one bit, rather it punishes mistakes brutally. You do NOT have an extra four turns to screw around on the wrong end of the map "cleaning up" safely. You have to be accomplishing something at all times. You end up having to put people in harm's way, and make decisions that are based on the situation at hand as opposed to being able to armchair general your way through by-the-book and not lose a soul.If you enjoy challenge and learning from failure as you would in a roguelike, buy this game. If you are looking to have your hand held and succeed without breaking a sweat, look elsewhere.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
												GAHHHHHH. So many things to like about XCOM 2 but unfortunately it has one crippling flaw that can literally ruin all gameplay. LOS is still totally broken months after release. Almost every mission I'll get instances of randomly getting shot or grabbed through a wall/floor. In a game where cover and positioning is everything, this is utterly gamebreaking. People do complain a lot that the RNG is broken. Whatever, I don't think so, it sucks sometimes but imo that makes the game more intense and interesting (also kinda more realistic). But for Line of Sight to be broken makes the game a literal luck simulator. Taking cover behind a wall? Trying to stay out of an alien's LOS by flanking around behind walls/cover? Too bad, the enemy saw you through two solid walls and killed Johnny Flanker through said walls. It's hard to explain how crippling this is to the gameplay without actually playing the game, but anyone familiar with any strategy games should understand that LOS is a critical element to playing smart. If it can't be relied upon to be consistent, then you never know if you're putting your soldiers in amazing cover or a killzone. Kinda important distinction there. WIth it being broken, it just doesn't make any sense to even call this a strategy/tactical game...

Most negative reviews talk about performance: MSAA will slice your FPS, turn it off or enable FXAA. There will be a patch soon to optimise it.XCOM is back! You don't wanna read a long review (as you wanna BUY THIS & GO PLAY!) so I'll bullet point:+ Aliens are tough as ****. First non-tutorial mission is like a smack with a baseball bat compared to previous XCOM. That's a good thing, struggle is real.+ Much more aliens, many more "species" to fight.+ You lost the war (right?) so you play on alien ground. If they decide to use other humans against you or call in extra support during battle - they will.+ Maps are auto-generated and there's variety.+ Nice graphics and troop customisation! My army of YouTubers doesn't need to hide their faces in helmets like last time. All of them look authentic. :D+ STORY PULLED ME IN WITHIN FIRST 15 MIN.  My jaw dropped after tutorial. Won't spoil.+ Plenty of references to previous XCOM.+ Tactical global map - build up resistance pockets in different regions to stop aliens from completing their projects against you.+ Nice gun modding (you can add scopes etc. looted from dead aliens).+ You start most missions concealed so you can AMBUSH ALIENS!-/+ A lot of missions are timed. I like it as you've gotta be swift and firm in your decisions but some people find the timer to be too strict.-/+ Unit healing time has been increased.-/+ How will I concentrate on my job for the next two weeks (at least)?-/+ No more air interceptions. Kind of makes sense but I miss it.- Occasional graphical/animation glitches.- Needs a patch to fix the lag when having AA enabled. Even CynicalBrit is getting lag with his Titan SLI.Will update the review if needs be.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
 "Never was so much owed by so many to so few. This was their finest hour." XCOM 2 is a turn-based strategy game developed by the company Firaxis Games with emphasis on tactical combat. Atmosphere & presentation: + The game captures the feel of a resistance force opposing an overwhelming alien occupation. + Excellent soundtrack that keeps the player in the game and sets the mood.+ Detail put into level design and environmental effects is impressive.+ Some fighting mechanics are cinematic, intuitive and entertaining.+ It boasts a healthy variety of equipment, firearms and peripherals.+ Partially destructible environments.+ Interface is minimalist and aesthetically pleasing.+ Offers very high replayability.o Game is not optimized for 4K resolution, causing irregular fps drops.- Quite a few bugs and glitches, ranging from minor clipping issues to enemies shooting through obstacles / walls. [Thanks to Volvox Globator for highlighting these points.]- Occasional in-game slowdowns during certain events, e.g. pause between rounds, calculation of burning effects etc. Combat & gameplay: + The game encourages the player to recruit and build a highly specialised army, and the mechanics put in place for doing so are well-rounded and sophisticated.+ Alien AI behaviour is mostly unpredictable, therefore adding to the title's challenge and replayability.+ Some missions offer a stealth system, allowing the player to scout out the land and enemies before engaging. + Reliable cover system and shooting mechanics, supporting offensive and defensive approaches. + Positioning and taking advantage of terrain are the keys to success.+ Base building and economics add another layer of challenge to the game.+ Broad spectrum of weapon customizations enriches the gameplay.+ For the masochistic hardcore gamers among us, the legendary ‘Ironman’ mode is available.o Learning curve is initially a bit steep, and may deter more casual gamers. In comparison with its predecessor the general level of difficulty is higher. o Missions are rng-based (random number generator), which could result in a lot of timed missions or almost no timed missions. [Thanks to Athena for mentioning this point.] Characters & story: + Campaign playthrough is engaging and provides diversified side quests, with different mission goals and winning conditions. + The narrative is well-delivered, with an even pace and solid character development.+ Extensive customization options for the characters and the possibility to export and import the party setup. + The player is likely to develop emotional attachment to some of the soldiers, increasing the immersion into the game. o Solid voice acting of the entire cast. Summary: XCOM 2 offers a superb strategy experience, which manages to improve the original XCOM formula on every level. Achievements: Estimated time for 100% completion: +100 hoursSingleplayer achievements: 69Multiplayer achievements: 1

content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												Xcom2 is more Xcom. It isn't classic Xcom. Go play openXcom for that!Keep in mind the time of this writing.The bad:Odd pauses, technical issues that interfere directly with gameplay such as:  >Line of sight issues with visibly solid walls (why did the enemy see me through an entire skyscraper... oh no, now I'm unexpectedly being shot through the walls, too), the hacking gameplay menu information being obscured by in-game objects, the rare instance of enemies getting extra actions.Balance issues >Hacking is poorly weighted in favor of failure: The rewards for hacking are often too temporary and too impotent to roll the dice on when the penalties are so incredibly severe.  >Swords are overall too risky to use either and stand only as a backup that, more often than not, complicates things by overextending and often ending up causing a new "pod" to join the battle. >Psionics and Meme Beacons are intensely overpowered. Think "What if ghost grenades were even easier to deploy?" >The AI is still shackled, and this isn't more evident than when you get used to how Sectoids' fearsome psionics are used.The good:The script source is supposedly totally open, and the mod pack is as well. Modding for the game couldn't be any more supported and who can live without Hatsune Miku hair or Stop Wasting My Time.Timers are good. Forcing the player to take action and take *some* risks made for a more interesting game. I found myself moving soldiers completely out of cover in order to commit to attacks I would not have taken in Xcom1.The temptation of MELD, in the previous game, wasn't enough because there was no true penalty for ignoring it other than falling slightly behind in the tech race. Now, you stand to lose soldiers, and all the droppable equipment you outfitted them with.The soldiers are given so much value through equipment and visual customization that losing them almost always hurts.Escaping from some mission types makes for interesting choices as well. I found myself seriously considering taking on some missions, weighing the likelihood of losing soldiers, or the advantage it would earn should it be a success. Eventually recognizing when a mission is unwinnable and running away to fight another day helps write interesting personal stories that aren't just "and we won again easily!" The struggle gives depth.The eh:The game arc is still the same as before: The early and mid game are the most interesting segments of the game. They're the moments where you make tactical sacrifices so that the whole group can survive. They're the moments where you're rooting for a critical to land.The late game is still a victory lap where your abilities match or exceed all the challenges the game throws at you except in being outnumbered.It's still Xcom, so what else can I say?Update: Some elements of this review have fallen out of date due to the recent patch in March.Mimic Beacons were significantly balanced (Made more expensive and will now only waste 1-2 enemy actions instead of nearly a *full enemy turn*).Framerate/graphical performance was significantly improved.

 XCOM 2is a turn-based strategy game where we play as "Commander". As Commander we need to rise resistance and lead rest of XCOM forces to take back our planet from alien occupation. Pros:+ great graphics and animations+ amazing customization options+ steam workshop ( mods )+ random generating levels ( every level/map feels really different )+ almost every sort of enviroments ( forest,swamps,deserts,cities/villages, snow terrains etc. )+ destructable ares ( most of things can be destroyed but not all )+ big variety in enemy units+ high replayability+ great soundtrack+ interesting story+ better soldier classes each with his own unique weapons/items and skill tree+ harder than previous XCOM+ new concealment mechanic ( stealth/ambush )+ more cutscenes+ some interesting and more likeable characters ( compared to previous one ) Cons: - optimization problems- mirror bugs ( examples: shooting through the wall , unbreakable windows/doors etc.)- timed missions/campaign ( there are many mods making it better or just deleting completly so don't worry)- no more interception missions ( interception wasn't  great but new hacking system isn't that good either  ) Overall rating: 9,5/10

content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												There are a lot of things about this game that bug the crap out of me. The timed missions, the Avatar project which basically puts a timer on the campaign itself, the scarcity of elerium cores which makes outfitting your squad kind of hard, the same old six person squad size, the needless delays that make the game seem to grind to a halt at the worst possible times...the list goes on and on...But there is a mod for every one of those complaints. Every. Single. One.For everything about this game I din't like, someone else didn't like it either and made a mod to fix it. Then all of these truly amazing modders came along and created wonderful content that took an already impressively open game and expanded it even further. I have no idea how many mods I am currently subscribed to at this point, but every complaint I had about the game when I first bought it has been addressed by the community and my games are much more diverse due to all of the options unlocked through user created content. I'd also like to add that despite having an absurd number of mods active the game is VERY stable. This many mods on something like Fallout New Vegas? Forget about it.So if you enjoyed XCOM and were on the fence about this one you should consider giving it a try. If there is something you heard about it that made you hesitant about picking it up, wait for it to go on sale. I am glad I bought it, though, and it is even better than the previous iteration.

number of helpful: 177 of 228 people (78%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 18, 2016
												XCOM 2 is a turn based tactical strategy game, releasing on PC in February 2016. The game is a direct sequel to XCOM Enemy Unknown which was released in 2012. XCOM 2 was developed by 2K Games and Firaxis Games. Like the first game, game play is separated into two. A management style simulator of controlling your base, and technologies inside it, whether it be through engineering or scientific research – allowing you to advance certain aspects of your base how you choose. Along with the base management side of the game, there is also a map style function which is where you move your ship around the world to different locations, or hubs of activity. Whilst on the map you will see side missions, your main missions, scrap piles to explore for extra money, along with a plethora of other activities to take part in. The main mechanic in XCOM is of course the tactical squad based game play.  This squad of soldiers can consist of five different classes, which again can be specialized even further by using the skills tree which you earn points in through promoting your squad members. To begin with the classes start out very much the same apart from the weapons that they use. After you have gained a few promotions with the characters you will start to differentiate the classes quite a bit with the abilities they will gain. The actual in game mechanics are very much the same as the previous version of XCOM, but just with general improvements. The game’s cover base system works really well, with some handy UI enhancements that make it easier to see how the cover affects you.  What I wasn’t too keen on was the aiming mechanic. On countless occasions I found myself face-to-face with a foe, and still my percentage chance to hit them with my gun would be around 30%. I know there is always going to be a chance anyone will miss a target, but c’mon, these are trained soldiers in point blank range, it shouldn’t be that low. This became increasingly annoying as you progress through the game onto harder enemies which make a habit of getting up close and personal with you.  Overall I found the game play in XCOM to be really intuitive and very addictive with that “oh one more turn” feel to it. Graphically, XCOM 2 is a really stellar looking title. Absolutely crisp animations of anything that moves, right the way down to the rag doll effect of bodies when they get shot (or blown apart). It just looks so fluid that it feels real. The textures and character models are also really high quality too. Normally in tactical games like this the graphical element is more skinned down on to allow for more focus on the game play but not XCOM 2. It is one of the best looking games to come out in the past 12 months and one that will really challenge your rig if you want to push out max settings.  The voice acting is top notch too; I was a little disappointed that all of the enemies have the same kind of voice, but given that there is plenty of different enemies in the game to begin with, this can be forgiven a bit. I would have liked to have seen a little extra depth used with sound in the game mechanics; there is an element of stealth to the game play, at least at the start of missions. It would have been nice to have some sort of sound meter that would trigger alarms for the enemies if you made too much sound – again just a small improvement which would of made the immersion all that more deeper. The game has varying levels of difficulty for the overall campaign – this of course is down to how hard you want the game to be.  After you have finished one play through of the game you will unlock “Ironman” mode which essentially saves your game after every action you take, meaning you cannot jump back a few saves if you messed something up. You have one chance to succeed and that is it. Given that the side missions in the campaign can make a real impact on how the rest of the game pans out, I see this as a really interesting game mode that has the potential to have endless amounts of replay ability. I have been playing for roughly 15 hours so far and I have just about finished my first play through. I will for sure be trying out the Ironman mode personally to see how hard it really can be. Where you start on the world map, and the in game maps are all randomly generated, so whilst the actual objectives of missions may stay the same, where you carry out those objectives will differ from play through to play through. Technically, I had a couple of issues. The main one being I did get random crashes. A few of these caused my graphics drivers to crash. This stopped when I configured an SLI profile for my two 970s and helped with the overall performance of the game too thankfully.  I was happy enough playing on 1080p given the high quality of the graphics on show to begin with. My rig was not capable of playing at 4k, and to be honest I think you would struggle to find a rig to play any of today’s recent releases on 4k.  Whack you’re AA up to max and you won’t really notice a difference though. XCOM 2 is by far the best game in the series so far; the graphical enhancement of the game, as well as the improvements made on the already core game play mechanics makes this a tactical turn based player’s wet dream. Apart from the technical issues I had, I have struggled to find anything major wrong with this release.  The game’s regular price tag of £34, 99 is the mark of this being a AAA release; the sceptics amongst us will want to wait for this to drop into the sales market but if you are keen to pick up where Enemy Unknown left off, XCOM 2 will definitely keep you entertained for plenty more hours with a greater gaming experience.  Tom's Score Card1) Stay away2) Not Recommended3) Only recommended when on sale4) Recommended5) Highly recommended6) This is a must playIf you found this review helpful, please give it a thumbs up. If you would also like to follow my reviews more easily, be sure to join my group by clicking here.You may also be interested in checking out a PC gaming podcast, be sure to head here.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												Changed review to postive review because I found settings that run the game flawlessly without much sacrifice in visual quality.The fast-paced nature if the game no longer bothers me.I recommend using FXAA, turning Ambient Occlusion and Depth of Field off entirely and putting the Shadows on "Directional Only".  With these settings and everything else turned up to Max, I'm running the game at 1440p with 62-64fps in game constantly, and 120+fps in other areas of the game.EDIT: After the patch, I can now run FXAA, SSAO, Bokeh Depth of Field, and All Shadows and am getting 70-90 fps in game and 120fps on the loading screens!  Could not be happier!!  However, I still prefer to keep AO and DoF off and Shadows on Directional Only as I get over 100fps in game consistently and it never dips below 60fps at any time.  It's worth noting that there seems to also be a bug now where SLI users no longer have cover icons (I use SLI and the game runs about 100% better with it, so it's staying on regardless).  For NVIDIA users, I recommend also going into the NVIDIA Control Panel and turning on Anisotropic Optimization; it gives me about a 25-30 fps boost with little, if any, noticeable drop in visual quality.The gameplay is good, the visuals are superb, and the music and sounds are very well done and sound amazing on surround sound.  I recommend it if you enjoy fast-paced tactics games and killing alien scum.

Posted: July 20, 2016
												I have 400 hours on this game and I love it.I do not recommend it. Don't support a company that takes giant backwards leaps in performance and features. The bugs, crashes, core technical faults, and issues won't be fixed because they can't be fixed. Seeing units through walls as you pass by, a character being unusable until reloading (bad luck if you're not smart enough to make manual ironman backups this far in) because they fell through a roof onto a prop, the objectives being destroyed instantly by fire and environmental-destructive enemies (Andromedon's natural walking behaviour will destroy it if it comes into contact), as well as a myriad of other issues; almost all are inherently part of the games creation and will not be "fixed".I am under the assumption Firaxis's publishers rushed the game out of the door to meet deadlines, because I struggle to believe the developers and entire team(s) thought the game was in a "version ready" state, and not late-beta.

												I've just looked at a whole selection of 2K games here on Steam. The majority of 2K games seem to be full of bugs. I honestly think we, the gamers share some of the blame. Here's what we do guys (and this applies for a lot of other games):1) NEVER pre-order anything. Dumb dumb dumb. This is giving a blank cheque to the devs to do what they like. 2) Don't buy DLC. Especially for games where the DLC represents a lot of stuff that should just be there in the game anyway. They're playing you for fools (and you're giving them your money!) Oh, and while I'm at it, don't pay real money for computer money so you can have a fancy colour gun or new car or new clothes for your character. It's like dressing up little girls' dollies. Dumb Dumb Dumb. Developers are laughing all the way to the bank on that one. 3) Wait a couple of weeks before buying any game. Check out the reviews. Hold out. If everyone rushes in believing the hype (No Man's Sky, anyone?) - then once they've got your money, there's little incentive to improve. No one will listen to me though! lol ;)by the way, I did buy XCom2 and I really liked it. Tiny bit buggy, but I forgave it because I like the franchise. There's lots to like about it. I recommend it :)

content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												Short Version - XCOM: Enemy Unknown and Enemy Within are vastly superior to this game. Go buy them instead, or if you have them and want more Firaxis XCOM, install and play the Long War mod.I wanted to like this game so bad. Hundreds of hours into Enemy Unknown and I was ready and raring to go for the next step. And there are certainly next steps in XCOM 2, the Starting concealment, the changes to Psionics, different enemy types, those were all really good ideas. On the other hand, there's simply too many things that can make your game go sideways through literally no fault of your own. In EU, I usually knew when I made a mistake. Sometimes things go poorly one turn, and that's the way it is, and it usually doesn't happen too often unless you're just committed to riding the bullet train of bad decisions. XCOM 2 just is the bullet train of failure, and there's no brakes on that train.Barring the DLC, the art is slick and totally on point, a really good iteration of Enemy Unknown's style. Tygen is cool, but lacks the personality and interest of Vahlen. He's 24/7 cool as a cucumber, and is just constantly aloof, where Vahlen had a proper forward face, but there were plenty of hints through dialogue that at any given time she was basically 2 seconds away from dissecting the nearest thing to her, living or dead, while singing opera. Lily Shen's interest basically drops right after her introduction, she never develops even though she's got the most opportunity to do so. On top of that, she looks EXACTLY like Jackie Ma from Sleeping Dogs, right down to the hairdo and freckles, so that's wierd. The soldier base models are all basically flat, they have zero silhouette and really wierd proportions. Even though there's more customization, somehow it feels more constrained, and I think it's due to there just being less interesting faces and hairdos available.And, once again (see: Batman: Arkham Knight), XCOM 2 has massive performance issues by trying to ship a "next-gen" game on a decade-old engine. Like Rocksteady, they bolted too many custom tools and rendering software onto Unreal Engine 3, and while Unreal is a fantastic engine, they both were trying to do rendering that the engine was just not meant to do. So, came the litany of "I have a top-end machine and I get 20 FPS" and "Game crashes at launch" on forums, and while I only had catastrophic issues once or twice, the load times and frame chug just inside the Skyranger are simply unforgivable.The story of XCOM losing was a bitter pill to swallow, but it gave a good start to why there's more aliens in the future. But beyond that, the presentation just lacks the same punch as Enemy Unknown. It lacks tension and a sense of urgency, even though that's what XCOM 2 is supposed to be completely centered around. I'll go watch the intro cinematic to Enemy Unknown just to watch it, because it gets me totally jazzed up to save the world. Michael McCann kills it with the music, and that stutter cut with the Skyranger gets me giddier than a schoolgirl to go shoot some aliens. On the other hand,the intro to XCOM 2 has scenes that should arguably be even more intense, but the lackluster directing, the totally midtone soundwork, it all made it feel so.... ordinary. Like blowing up ADVENT checkpoints is just what you do on a Tuesday afternoon. Though, Bradford jumping through a window was pretty sweet.The sense of tedium never goes away, as you're constantly shifting back and forth across zones because everything takes too long. You'll rarely finish one activity before you have to go do a guerilla op, oh did you happen to notice, ADVENT's  putting the boots to some hippies in a commune that happen to be our friends, hey you should go look at this wierd spot we found, oh by the way, you need to go pick up your monthly cheque from this spot because we couldn't be arsed to mail it to you direct, and there's a 3 day processing wait, did you want to sell stuff, well you gotta go fly there too, because apparently there's only ONE Black Market bazaar on the planet.There's a nice balance that Enemy Unknown struck between the Strategy and Tactical layers of their game, The Tactical portion was an overt stress-fest of playing hide-and-seek with bullets, doing Hail Marys behind the tiny log that is your only available cover, and hoping to Sweet Baby Ray's that the Meld canister you're after isn't just a total pod-fest of X-rays. The Strategy layer was much more subtle, and the contrast makes the game actually playable. The Strategy layer gives you time to think, to manage your resources and marshal your thoughts on your game plan. It can be a good 10 minutes before another mission crops up, which is good downtime for the player so they aren't keyed up for too long.XCOM 2 learned nothing from its predecessor. The constantly running around, the Doom Ticker front and center, everything takes too long, and missions pop up with an annoying frequency to how much you can actually get done in the Strategy layer before "Hey, you gotta pop half-way round the world to go save those dirty hippies again" There's really never time to rest in XCOM 2 and it's frankly exhausting even thinking about booting the game up.The last sticking point, and really the final straw for me, is really how screwed the game balance was, and continues to be. Instead of say, fixing the fact that missions play like a round of "Whose Line is it Anyway?", where the shot percentages are made up and the aiming angles don't matter, they decide a good idea is to heavily nerf one of the only options for consistent damage, and taking away the biggest reason you pick Volatile Mix (increased grenade radius). Not even mentioning removing the only means of stopping "Run-n-Gun" Chrysallids and Stun Lancers. And there was obviously decisions that were made akin to those bouts of insanity throughout its development. Tons of enemies have armour (DR in EU) and Shieldbearers can give anyone in a huge radius armour, fine. But they took out Shredder rounds, so the only ways are, Psyhic attacks on non-robotic enemies (which bypasses armour, so the rest of your squad is still stuck in DR hell), an extremely high-level perk for Rangers, and the aforementioned nerfed grenades. Thin Men made a new appearance as the Vipers, and they can strangle you from a distance, great! But, (up until a patch a couple weeks ago, where they can't dodge 100% shots anymore), they have a high chance to straight-up ignore half of incoming damage from any weapon that rolls to hit. Your squad starts most missions Concealed, which allows you to try and get the jump on your enemy by (potentially) setting up kill zones to obliterate a pod before they can shoot back, Awesome! But why is there a 10, or even better, a FIVE (yes, five) turn timer on the mission? It completely nullifies the concept of Concealment and geurilla warfare if your only option to succeed in the mission is to dash forward non-stop until you reach the objective, because you WILL run into a pod, you WILL lose Concealment, and after that, you can't hope to just keep running and expect to win.There's things to like in XCOM 2, but it's just such an unfun, buggy mess.

number of helpful: 199 of 268 people (74%) found this review helpful8 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 17, 2016
 (This review is available in both written and video formats below for your convenience.) 


YouTube™ Video: Analog Reviews: Xcom 2 

			Views: 1,283		

			Join Nathan as he reclaims Earth from the forces of Advent in this review of Xcom 2. Despite being one of our favorite genres, there are far too few turn based tactical games being released these...		

In 2012, Firaxis released Xcom Enemy Unknown which helped breathe new life into the genre and successfully rebooted the classic UFO defense franchise. Now, 4 years later, Xcom 2 hopes to improve on all of the elements of its predecessor.Taking place roughly 20 years after where the first game left off, and in an unusual sense for a sequel, Xcom 2 assumes you failed Enemy Unknown as it now takes place in a dystopian future where the aliens have conquered earth. Rather than defending the planet from UFOs, you’re tasked with bolstering resistance cells across the globe with your mobile, flying fortress; the avenger. This functions in the same way as your underground base from the first title, as you can upgrade it, add new facilities, as well as recruit soldiers while managing research and production.The core concepts are similar to Enemy Unknown and you’re faced with a constant race against the clock since the aliens are developing something called the Avatar project. Certain missions will act to delay the progress of the project, but it's game-over upon its completion. There’s also dark events which can provide random modifiers and buffs to the aliens you encounter. Occasionally you’ll be prompted to complete guerilla missions which allow you to prevent a dark event but you’re unable to stop them all, as you’ll typically have to pick and choose which event is most pressing. The world map functions similarly to Enemy Unknown. You’ll set up a base and will be able to scan the map for certain points of interest. Building radio relays in countries will increase your monthly budget, and continental bonuses make a return, adding some elements of strategy and planning. Upon scanning the map, you’ll frequently be interrupted to go on missions, which are all randomly generated with varying objectives. These objectives range from escorting an NPC, saving civilians, eliminating a target or killing every alien in an area.The turn-based combat is what you’d come to expect from an Xcom game, death is permanent and your soldiers can still possibly miss a point-blank shot which otherwise has a 97% success rate. Stealth has been added, which can allow you to strategically place your soldiers and set up ambushes with overwatch, but a lot of the time you’ll feel rushed as there isn’t much time to complete the objectives in most cases. Taking one extra step is sometimes enough to alert enemies to your presence, so you really have to balance between moving cautiously and completing a mission as fast as possible. That element of randomness can be a detriment, as sometimes a civilian could block a ladder and thus seal off the only way up to a rooftop extraction, or a ridiculous amount of enemies could spawn directly on top of a transmitter you’re otherwise supposed to protect. Which leads to one major issue with Xcom 2, it’s extremely luck based and these random factors can cause you to fail a mission with very little control. You can recover from failed missions, but it does feel a little unfair and can be a major downer for ironman playthroughs in which you only have one save file.The soldier classes feel a lot more fleshed out and distinct from one another as they all kind of blurred together in the previous installment. For example the Ranger is equipped with a sword which can absolutely devastate enemies in melee combat while the specialist has a drone that can hack hostile robotic units or support squad mates from anywhere on the map. The scientists and engineers play more of a role now as well. They’re actually named and can be individually assigned to different projects.Xcom 2 also completely expands on the level of customization, giving a lot more appearance options for your soldiers. You’re also able to modify your soldiers’ weapons with various attachments as well as give them performance enhancing implants. While all of these customization options were quite welcomed, this resulted in some completely broken and overpowered combinations. For example, I had given one of my soldiers a superior repeater which gave him a 15% chance to instantly execute whatever target he was shooting at and as a result I was able to one-shot the hardest enemy in the game. The difficulty in general is kind of spiky, while the game initially starts off as challenging; it quickly becomes too easy upon developing certain technologies. Some better pacing would have greatly alleviated this issue because as it stands, it can switch from being so easy that it’s tedious to frustrating with little warning.At first, there seems to be a greater variety of enemies present in Xcom 2. The majority of enemies you face are Advent troopers, human-like soldiers that support the alien regime, while more familiar aliens such-as sectoids function as lieutenants and are actually a greater threat than the previous games. The other aliens have also evolved over the twenty year gap between Enemy Unknown. Unfortunately you hardly fight them in the latter half of the game as you pretty much always face the same enemies over and over again at that point.I also had some issues with the world map. It gives you so many optional areas to scan for additional supplies and personnel but you’re interrupted every two seconds to take part in another randomly generated mission. There are very few actual story missions, and the random stages can really get tedious in the latter half of the game. There’s also very little rhyme or reason going into the appearance of a stage. You could accept a mission in Africa only for there to be pine trees and snow on the ground, making no sense whatsoever. There are a lot of bugs present in the game as well. From graphical glitches, laggy animations and the odd crash.Xcom 2 promised re-playability with its use of random stages but I would’ve honestly preferred handcrafted levels with more of a narrative. There’s also extra mod support this time around but most of the mods available currently are cosmetic or the odd weapon, which doesn’t really add anything significant to the gameplay.The multiplayer from Enemy Unknown makes an appearance again but it’s even more of a throw-away mode this time around. You’re given even less customization options than before as you’re no longer able to choose the rank and loadout of human soldiers. The turns don’t play out simultaneously and can take an extremely long time as there’s quite a bit of additional lag between them. That combined with crashes and random disconnects make this mode barely playable. The soundtrack is well done and changes to match the mood of the battle as well as the enemies you encounter. Unfortunately, there isn't much variety between tracks and it isn't as memorable as Michael Mccann’s soundtrack from Enemy Unknown who was probably too busy working on Deus Ex Mankind Divided.Ultimately, Xcom 2 makes a very strong first impression but it was all downhill from there though, and towards the end of the game, I couldn’t wait to be done with all the randomly generated filler content. That coupled with an overall lack of pacing made it a bit of a disappointment. It’s an improvement over Enemy Unknown in some areas but a step-back in others. Xcom 2 is by no means a bad game, and will most likely improve with time; I was just expecting a lot more. Pros +	Strong Turn Based Tactical Combat+	Increased Customization Options+	Interesting Premise+	Soldier classes and base management are more refined. Cons -	Repetitive Gameplay and Filler Content-	Numerous Bugs-	Lackluster Multiplayer-	Not enough of an improvement over Enemy UnknownIf you enjoyed this review, please check out our curator page: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/AnalogReviewsOfficial#curationThanks for reading,

content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
												Listen: At its best, XCOM 2 is a great game and if you liked XCOM EU there is a lot you would like here. The good parts are covered in other positive reviews and I mostly agree with them.However, I cannot recommend this game as a $60 release in the state it is in. To be honest, I rarely buy games new at full price because I simply don't make that much money. However, I made an exception for this one because the buzz/preview coverage was very positive and I loved the formula established in EU. They couldn't mess it up THAT much, could they? In my opinion, they didn't and the gameplay experience is mostly great with a few minor quibbles here and there. But even considering that, the technical state this game is in makes me very wary about buying a game at launch ever again. I feel burned.The most noticeable thing is is that the performance is terrible - I SHOULD be able to run it at ultra or high settings at 60fps but am sitting around medium with occasional slowdown. Honestly it's a minor thing because graphics aren't the biggest deal to me, but it is still something that annoys me given everything else. But if it was the only thing? Totally fine.Unfortunately the bugs in this game are terrible. XCOM at it's best is a tight, no nonense strategy game where you make well thought out, in the moment decisions and live with the consequences. Unfortunately, bugs and crashes interrupt game flow and can make going through missions a slog. I currently have had three crashes in the middle of an action where a crash dialog box would pop up but I would be unable to force quit the game or access the task manager, forcing me to force restart my whole computer. Just my luck as every single time that I happened I was in a hectic situation that was going well for me. At that point I would have to go back to the game, load the last autosave and try and recreate the situation I was in before the game crashed. Completely breaks enjoyment of the game. I've gotten past them, but each time it happens make me less excited to return to the game.I've also had instances where I've completely destroyed all of the walls of a lower floor in the hopes it would drop an enemy from above only to have it not happen? My only guess is that if a ladder connects the ground to an upper floor it makes it so I can't destroy that floor, which is not a  bug I guess, but still ridiculous. In that same instance I couldn't target a unit that was behind said ladder despite there being no walls around it and despite the unit not being in any sort of cover. Right now I'm in a mission where I have to neutralize or knock out an advent VIP. There is a sectopod near the VIP, so I send a unit with chain shot up to try and shoot the sectopod. Presumably both the sectopod and the VIP are in my line of sight, but for whatever reason I can't change between targets - even when clicking the yellow (flanked) VIP icon or trying to tab between targets, it targets the sectopod. That would be fine except every times I confirm the shot on the sectopod, my soldier shoots the VIP. Excuse me? I was able to destroy the sectopod in another way, but only after reloading my autosave and trying to puzzle out how to get the game to do what I wanted (and should have) been able to do.In this same mission, I finally kill the enemies, knock out the VIP, and carry him away. However, when I knocked him out he was next to a burning car. NO MATTER HOW FAR I AM AWAY FROM THE CAR, and NO MATTER HOW MANY MORE UNITS ARE CLOSER TO THE VEHICLE, when the car explodes the VIP takes damage and dies. Once again, even my soldiers who are closer to the car than my unit carrying the VIP don't take damage. Only the VIP. There are other bugs and crashes, but none quite as egregious or memorable like the ones above. At this point I would have to reload the mission in a previous state to try and figure out a way to get past this particular bug. I don't want to do that and shouldn't have to, frankly. I'm not into Ironman difficulties but also don't like save scumming to get the outcome I want. In this case I'm savescumming because the game is messing up, which just sucks! At this point I feel like I'm trying to beat the game because I feel obligated, considering how much time I put into it, not because I really want to. And it's a shame because because the gameplay is pretty good and I should WANT to beat it because of how fun it is! But I just never know which mission is going to be the breaking point, where I finally hit a point where my best soldiers die not because of my mishandling but because of the game's mistakes. THAT is problematic and it  makes me not excited to return to this game. And maybe I won't. Who knows. It's been a month now and things aren't really ironed out still. I understand a lot of games ship in various states of disrepair but it shouldn't be like this. Maybe other people can get past these things, and maybe other people won't even come across these issues, but I personally wouldn't recommend buying this game at full retail price until it is patched extensively.EDIT: Since writing this review I have played for about three more hours, finishing the campaing. Despite the last mission being mostly great, my recommendation of this game remains the same. Aside from the regular shoddy performance, there were a few bad spots: once again selected one target only to somehow shoot at another, and two instances of not being able to throw a grenade/other item farther than a few squares away with two different soldiers in different locations. Was able to use other soldiers/skills to give me the result I more or less wanted, but still I am annoyed I wasn't able to do what I WANTED to do. Those things did not invalidate the mission as a whole but still muddied what should have been a great experience.Overall, the game's technical failings are a shame. When firing on all cylinders, this game is fantastic. However, the game's tight flow is too often interrupted by perfomance issues. Given just how IMPORTANT that flow is to making the game enjoyable, it's a damn shame that there are too many instances of you, the player, not being allowed to experience it. You feel like you're hitting a stride, and then all of a sudden a crash or a bug pops up and you stumble through no fault of your own leaving you to deal with the consequences or get back up and try all over again. That just sucks. Whether you just heard of this game in passing and were intrigued or loved Enemy Unknown, I would highly recommend you do NOT buy this game until there is a hefty sale going on or until it is reliably patched. Preferably the latter. This is a game that should be experienced with no technical caveats as the sytems underneath are enjoyable, addicting, and often rewarding. Unfortunately that time is not now. Or who knows? Maybe you won't experience the bugs I have, as some people didn't. Guess you could just roll the dice.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												Having bought this recently, nine months after launch, I am stunned by the amount of glitches. XCOM2 does not feel like a finished game. At this point whenever I load it up, I expect to find a new bug or two.From a carried VIP not registering as alive on EVAC (there is a mod to fix this because the devs apparently could not be bothered?) to graphics glitches like the Make Weapons Available button disappearing, or a soldier's arms disappearing, to a save-breaking bug where the keyboard did nothing after reloading, to line of sight bugs (soldier could not see snake, snake tongue pulled him through solid walls), to getting two mind controlled enemies via lamp post hack instead of one, to Psi Zombies from a Dominated Gatekeeper showing up as lost soldiers on mission end screen. And so on and so forth.Only one of the above has been save-breaking so far, but I will not give a thumbs up to something that just doesn't work right half the time.Having said all that, the premise of the game is still good old XCOM.Good:- Concept of customising soldiers is great.- The guerrilla approach is novel and the turn counters make for good fun, though perhaps are a bit too common.- The gameplay is XCOM when it works. Great stuff.- Lots of nifty weapons and special skills. The skills seem to be better balanced than the original (2012) XCOM, in that you often have to consider your two options at the levelup instead of going for the clearly stronger one.- AWC perks are very cool, though they should be retroactive from the get go, or unlock at the final level if the right one has been passed, or something. 2012 XCOM had the same problem where you had to throw away your original A team because their will ended up inferior to new soldiers.- Shen's Last Gift is a good mission. I have not used the SPARK enough to do it justice, but the concept fits in.Bad:- Bugs. Lots and lots of bugs, glitches and annoying things that aren't working right.- Changing armors resets some customisation options, and sometimes they just bug out and change the props around.- Very slow loading times, slow animations and pauses between turns. Why do I need to press caps lock on a loading screen? Why doesn't the damn thing press it for me?Personal preference:- I found the character models and armors from the 2012 game to look better, more human.- Anarchy's children customisation options (For Digital Deluxe) are mostly glam rock and horror movie props that make no sense in the context of the game. There are a select few exceptions.- The strategy screen has no pause or fast forward buttons and the constant interruptions and holo-globe transitions are very jarring.- I would like to say something about Alien Hunters, but I did the scanning part and the Nest never showed up. Going to go ahead and guess this is another bug.- Swords are inferior to the shotgun, except in very rare and specific conditions.The bottom line in all this is - if you do not own XCOM Enemy Unknown/Within, go buy that instead. If you own that and want more, this is a beta version of a good sequel. I wouldn't pay full price for it.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												The game has many significant improvements over XCOM: Enemy Unknown, including.- A new Character Pool feature which lets you make characters from the main menu, which then can be used in your campaign.- You can now freely move around on the world map, it is now more than just a "scan button."- There are a lot more character customization options, you can now change the color of your weapon, name it, and many more new features.- XCOM 2 provides more of a challenge than XCOM: Enemy Unknown did.- The story is actually pretty good, (in comparison to XCOM: Enemy Unknown.)- The graphics are significantly better.- You can now customize your soldiers names and appearances in multiplayer.- XCOM 2 officially has mod support.Overall, i would definitely recommend this game to anyone that enjoyed XCOM: Enemy Unknown.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												I missed my first shot and I'm on normal difficulty with a 89% chance to hit, plus flanking.WELCOME BACK TO XCOM BABY!!--------EDITS&ADDONS----------20hrs of XCOM BABY later, and I've just dismissed my "Sharpshooter" for several other ragequit misses, including no less than a 97%. I heard he has since been employed on an Imperial Star Destroyer as a Stormtrooper. To make this review "more helpful", I feel I should add that this IS a game worth buying, though missing often (and often you will) can become a real frustration - you find yourself grinning in sweet revenge when the same RNG happens to the Aliens and they miss you from from point blank range.Shooting mechanics aside, the only other issues I've come across since playing are:- *Mission timers (which mods can fix already). Plus, this is a personal preference, it's not a fact that this makes the game worse. I actually enjoyed some of the missions when realising I had 3 turns remaining to act out the impossible. You really think about what skills you have remaining and use every resource possible to inflict the greatest amount of damage while moving forward as fast as you can. All normally works out well... Assuming you hit the target, that is! *ahem**The occasional bug / framerate drop (which will no doubt be patched very soon). Again, this is computer specific and really, I hardly noticed it once I tweaked my settings. I had to lower a few things, but no biggie!That's it. I see no real reason not to buy this game, especially if you liked Enemy Unknown/Within. I'm currently finding myself pinned down at times on Normal. Yes, NORMAL, and I have no Ironman, and I still finish some missions thinking "Wow... How did I get outta that one?!" I can't wait to (hopefully) survive this playthrough and crank up the difficulty to make it even more of a challenge.Good luck fellow Commanders! May your aim be true.And if you miss, channel all that anger, know it happens to the best of us, and tell yourself "That's XCOM BABY!"

number of helpful: 371 of 550 people (67%) found this review helpful22 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Once again steam reviews are plagued by opinionated people who exagerate the "cons" to make it sound far worse than it really is, just because there's some aspects in the game they don't like. I hope I got your attention. Good. Now as many reviewers have said I will say as well. Most negative reviews talk about performance: MSAA will slice your FPS, turn it off or enable FXAA. There will be a patch soon to optimise it.Now that we go that out of the way. X-com 2 is based after the events in X-com 1. You've lost the war, and well.. read the store page for more info. The point is, the game plays like this. You're a resistance cell, not a full fledged world army equipped with the best of everything. Apparently people are down voting because it doesn't play like this. (Get gud?) The biggest complaint apart from optimization is the mission timers in the battles. Most reviews exagerate the mother loving heck out of this as they hate missions which are timed. Fair enough. There IS a mod which removes this already, so if turn timers are not your thing, there you go. If a game is going to have timers for missions, then they need to make sense right? Well in X-com they do. They make perfect sense for the missions which have them. You just broke a highly important VIP to the Aliens out of confinement, you're a resistance cell with limited manpower and resources, of course you're going to have to get the hell out of dodge and fast once you break that guy out. It makes sense no? It's REALISTIC. It's IMMERSIVE.. You know.. those things which people apparently hate in games these days. Setting my own butthurt at societies downfall in terms of gaming aside, the time limit, and how often you run into them is changed depending on difficulty, so if you dont' like timed missions to often, but like them for when they make sense, you can adjust the difficulty level of the game and it will throw less at you. Apart from that, I love how it feels like you are actually a resistance cell in a mobile base. Scavanging for equipment on the battlefield when enemies drop them, selling parts, corpses, and other alien artifacts on the Black Market to get Intel, and buying/trading/selling in Intel on the Black Market to gain goods to fill the holes of research and bad RNG rolls in battles in terms of mods you find, make it feel like you are the aggressors against a superior foe. The stealth system in place for most missions is excellent as well, allowing you to scout out the land and enemies before engaging, and setting up ambushes which could wipe the slate in that area entirely before the aliens have time to respond. There is now a better world map as well, This is where you move your mobile base from region to region, unlock new regions by contacting the resistance cells in that area, and take on side missions to gain supplies, Intel, etc. -----------------Over all the game isn't bad by any means. Some performance issues which should be fixed relatively soon, good immersion, great classic game mechanics from X-com 1.-------------------If you're still wondering about the complaints on this game. There are 2 people on the forums are can articulate points far better than me. There is ALOT of debate on the timers in this game. These are 2 great responses. Martial.lore:The timers are essential. Turtling is not a tactic. The squad isn't trying to find a good picnic spot. XCOM is a guerrilla force that has to make lighting strikes before going back into hiding.This theme is reinforced by every mechanic in the game from the short individual timers on the globe to the reinforcement drops that come when you just desperately want to get everyone to the evac point.Sometimes you just have accept that there was not enough time for your ill-equipped soldiers to complete their objective and stay alive, and sometimes sacrifices have to be made for the greater good.Failure is hard to accept but without the timers the potential for disaster during missions would be missing and the game would not be worthy of the XCOM name.If it didn't upset players complacency and make them furious at how unfair life is then where is the fun in that? Sometimes FTL makes me very angry but it's one of my favorite tactical video games and I am generally very good at playing it.Once I have learned how to succeed with XCOM 2 I imagine that even though they will feel familiar and seem easier to deal with, the timers will still screw up a good plan once in a while and get good people killed.Perish the thought that this were a game in which every move, every action and every decision did not have consequences.Jolly:"It mostly IS blind hate against timers. People complaining without really give it a try, or even trying."Because most of the timers are idiotic, and pretty much all of them are poorly implemented."Um, no. Idiotic? That's opinion and not one I'd agree with. Poorly implemented? It's a countdown on the screen - what do you want, an hourglass? I dancing girl who removes clothes til the "time" is up? WTF.Most of the people complaining can't seem to let go of their old XCOM ways. They want to turtle thru full cover overwatch and lure aliens into easy kills. It's a weak "tactic" that takes advantage of poor AI that suicides into that crap.The timers, which only appear in about half the missions if you actually play the game more than you cry about it, aren't even for entire missions, usually just for objectives. The cause you to move a little fast, to tak risks, take you out of your comfort zone, and they obliterate the cheeseball reliance on overwatch luring.What's sad is that if you actually play the game with an open mind, the timers are no big deal. If you just decide you're going to cry about the timers no matter what, which is ignorant, then you desreve the misery you bring upon yourself.XCOM 2 is a glorious game and a triumph of design. Embrace and love it for everything that it offers, which is a megaton."

content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
												I hate to give this game a negative review. I love Firaxis and I think they make a lot of great games. But I loved the first Xcom they made and I just feel like this doesn't even live up to that standard let alone be a better game. The primary reason I dislike this is that pretty much at every point in the game your on a time limit. In a mission, time limit. On the world screen, time limit. I detest time limits, I want to relax and have fun with a video game. Not feel rushed. At least with the first one it was optional (the meld) in the missions. But here, it's mandatory. Also, I just don't feel strong or like I'm doing a good job in this game at all. It feels like your constantly on the edge of losing. Maybe that works with the story they were trying to create in this game, but it's just not fun. Not for me at least. Not to mention after months of this game being out, there are still performance issues that have yet to be resolved. I'm running on a 970 and I still have bad performance issues. In the end I just think this is worse than Enemy Unknown in just about every way. And I'm really sorry to say that.

												Get the game if it is on sale, otherwise it's not worth the $60 USD asking price (Australian store).The game is still broken months after release:-Frame drops at the start of every mission (and loading main menu).-Buggy animations, such as characters shooting through walls or breaking already broken windows to shoot.-Load times to return to base are still stupidly long, which can be reduced to a few seconds if you hit "caps lock"... no joke just google it.-Line of sight is still broken, enemies can see you through some walls, while other times you can't see enemies that are out in the open.Also don't buy the DLC. content:
Posted: January 16
												I really love the X-Com series.  I remember spending hundreds of hours on the Enemy Unknown and Terror from the Deep as a kid and loving every second of it, even the long and tedious multipart ship terror missions and the alien base missions with tentaculats and Lobstermen behind every corner.  The 2012 remake was a welcome addition to the series despite it being simpler than the original.And I definitely like X-Com2 for the most part.  Unfortunately, I just can't recommend it.To begin with, there are the performance issues.  Random frame drops and stutters should NOT be happening with a GTX 1080, especially during in game cinematics.  Then there's the occasional hang ups on enemy turns.  The AI that usually takes no time to perform actions suddenly takes forever to decide what it wants to do for a turn, and then goes back to normal the next turn.  I still have no idea what causes this as it seems to happen at random times.  Also, there are weirdly long (relatively) load times when you're heading back to your main ship.  It really shouldn't take longer to load the base than it does to load a procedurally generated map but... it does.The RNG is still, and will always be there.  Miss a million shots at 95% chance to hit, fail an 81% hack, get no engineers for the first two months but get 5 scientists, need an acid bomb/grenade but get everything but acid, get a useless (for your build) random skill from AWC, the list goes on and on.  You either deal with it by crying or savescumming.  But it's not part of why I don't recommend the game.The main reason why I don't recommend the game?  The pacing.  I get it.  Timed missions make things more difficult since you have less opportunities, so you gotta make the best choice with what you got.  My problem with it isn't the difficulty as I've been able to consistently finish all the timed missions (without DLC bosses randomly showing up that is).  My problem with it is that it takes away most of your choices on how you want to play the game.  You have a myriad of options on how to bumrush to the objective (relatively) safely, such as smoke bombs, mimic beacons, etc but the fact remains is that you have no choice but to bumrush the objective.  In Enemy Unknown, there was some risk vs reward element there.  You can choose to take the additional risk of rushing to get meld, the reward.  Here, you have no choice but to rush and the worst part is that 80% of the missions have some sort of timer (whether it's a real timer or one civilian dies every turn timer).  Majority of my missions consists of kill first enemy pod asap, destroy wall, and either put specialist behind cover with LoS to objective and hack objective or destroy relay.  Timed missions get a bit harder, as they introduce enemies with more health/armor/abilities, and then significantly easier as your specialist improves to reliably control mechanical units and when you can bring in Psi Ops who can dominate the tougher biological enemies, but it doesn't make the repetitiveness less tedious.The next offensive part about pacing lies in the strategic part of the game.  Want to make contact with a new region?  No problem, just 5 days of scanning.  Except you scan half a day and ALERT, gotta fly off to save an ally VIP.  Spend half a day flying to the mission, do the mission, get that engineer drop that you desperately need, but it unfortunately requires 7 days of scanning. So you scan half a day of that before getting dragged into another mission that you NEED to do to prevent the dark event from adding more points to the avatar project, come back to scan for the engineer, scan a couple hours and ALERT!, your allies are being attacked, if you don't save them, you'll lose the relay tower you spent so many supplies on, so off to save them, and just when you think it's safe to try to scan for that engineer again, ALERT!  Resistance forces have disabled a train full of supplies so you gotta fly over and raid th- MOTHERF****R JUST LET ME F*****G SCAN IN MOTHERF*****G PEACE!!  It's offensive to the point where instead of getting your monthly pay immediately, you have to scan 3 days for it; 3 days that'll most likely turn into a week or more after all the interruptions.And now you have a doomsday timer too, in the form of the avatar project.  Let the bar fill up and you have a set period of time to reduce the bar or it's game over.  So when you're trying to prioritize a path to reducing the avatar project and you get interruptions after interruptions, it gets assinine really quick.And yes, I understand that there are mods that can change the pacing but from my point of view, mods shouldn't be necessary to make the game enjoyable.  Not to mention, updates can easily render mods obsolete, make your modded campaign unplayable, etcAnyways, XCom2 isn't a bad game.  At its core, once you get past the mission timers, the tactical combat is great, the soldier customization has been significantly improved, weapon customization is nice, and certain things are less tedious (like having to manufacture new primary weapons and armor for each new rookie, you have a simpler upgrade system for the most standard stuff), and they actually made explosives super useful (makes the first couple missions on normal way too easy though).  The storyline also isn't bad (still ridiculous at points though) and leaves room to be interpreted whether it ties into the ending of X-Com Bureau or whether it's foreshadowing Terror from the Deep or Micronoids, etc.tl:drI like this game but overall, I can't recommend the intended (unmodded) version to the majority of people as most of the game feels like there's only one way to play (rush objectives because 80% of the missions are timed and prioritize avatar project stuff) and that shouldn't be the case from a series that gave you so much freedom in your methods in prior games.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												Contains a lot of features that I expected in XCOM EU. Overall gameplay is solid&fun so far and comes with a lot of customization. But performs like garbage and they tried to balance the game by adding timers to both missions and the overworld map (can be modded out) and some bugs are literally copied 1:1 from XCOM:EU to XCOM2.  Concept Pros Cons   Graphics Are very slick. Performs horribly compared to what you get. Also it lacks 'pre-generated scenes'. Example returning to the base after a mission has a long loading time which should not be necesary   Relocatable base No more 100% pure rng-reliance on wether or not you can get satellites over every country Alien facilities (=bases) may all spawn very far away from your starting location (rng). But there is a counter to this (Lead on Alien Facility)   Saving System  Is as horrible as it was in XCOM:EU. Even the XCOM from 1994 had a better saving system. Not even the autosave feature is working as I would expect it to. Hopefully we get a mod for this soon   Mod support Mod support is great in XCOM2. Also it does NOT prevent you from getting achievements. I'm getting this feeling that they left out some critical game-features and rely on modders to add them.   RNG (random gen) Reliance on RNG is less compared to XCOM:EU. RNG-reliance is still strong. You still have to use tactics to minimize the chances of losing. But if all the odds happen to be against you, you will simly lose. If you are new to the XCOM-series and can't stand rng-based games. Then this game is not for you.   Stability It is way more stable compared to XCOM EU. It's only the first version so we can expect fixes in the near future Still has quite a lot of bugs & glitches and even a reproducable crash for me. But most of them do not impact gameplay. I also found 2 bugs that were also present (and still are) in XCOM1 EU which is a big thumbs down for me.   Soldier customization It is supported right of the bat along with a premade soldier-pool that contains your saved-soldiers for re-use. Also comes with custom colors, voices, and much more Sadly most of this comes from the 2 DLC which add significantly to the total price   Tedious moments  Can't skip some cinematics. There are quite a lot of these early in the game. Also during combat you sometimes get nagged about objectives while stalling gameplay. Also I have to EVAC my soldiers one by one when they all stand in the zone during a VIP mission? No EVAC-all button? No reload-all? No overwatch-all? Some GUI elements are a bit on the slow side   AI A lot better compared to XCOM:EU and especially a lot more stable. Also soldiers on overwatch no longer all fire overkill-damage on the same enemy Civilians stay near burning cars and let themselves explode. They also do not run from aliens and do not seek cover and do not run towards you. They behave like mindless zombies   Missions Good overal design. You now also start cloaked in most battles instead of getting swarmed by like 20 aliens after moving 1 tile as opposed to XCOM1 EU sometimes Most missions are timed. Personally I hate gameplay that has timelimits everywhere. But perhaps this was required to prevent turtling in a safe spot   Theme Being a rebel now after the aliens took over the world is a refreshing change after so many games in the series Early in the game most enemies look like armored humans. It does not feel as if you are fighting aliens   Overworld The scanning and sidemissions are a nice addition Again a timelimit... AGAIN.... Also game progression here feels too linear. I don't have this feeling like I have total freedom to just go wherever I like. I'm still bound to the story just like in XCOM EU. And not truly much choice in what missions you shall take. There is still no freedom like we had in UFO EU (1994). Also sometimes you get like 3 missions in 4 days. You can't even get to a scanning site. But again you can only have 1 skyranger...   Difficulty  There's still a reverse difficulty curve. And some of the difficulty comes purely from the lack of information (no tech tree, some skills not properly explained, etc.) or the enforced timelimits. For players new to the XCOM-seroes, early game can be a total nightmare. Early game is really hard, while lategame you are an untouchable god.   EVAC Call down custom EVAC points Even though all enemies are dead and no new reinforcements are on their way, you simply can't recover the alien artifacts with you during an EVAC. Also you can't carry alien corpses manually into the skyranger. You could in the 1994 game but not in the 2016 one...   Mech Design We have droids (YES) that can remotely hack and jolt enemies The big MECH's look as if they were designed by Apple. They look nowhere near as cool as the ones from XCOM:EU Yes it has bugs. A selection of the bugs that I encountered:May contain minor spoilershttp://steamcommunity.com/app/268500/discussions/0/412446292775581295/Why still the upvote after all those bugs?- Because ~ 9 out 10 of those bugs either have no impact on gameplay, have obvious workarounds or work in your advantage. Just stay away from ironman mode for the time being. I have seen some bugs that could seriously hurt you in ironman mode.- The game just released, so there is still hope.- Gameplay is still pretty solid and beats most other games of it's genre. It has many flaws I admit but it still comes out on top.- Modders are already jumping in, fixing the game and adding critical features.No I have not forgotten how they left XCOM:EUI never managed to beat ironman-impossible in XCOM:EU due to bugs.1. Once an enemy got stuck and my savegame was ruined forever. They 'fixed' this like this: "if an enemy get's stuck, just skip the entire AI's turn". You call that a fix?2. Another time it bugged out in the final level (FFS) and it wouldn't let me enter the door. They actually fixed this one.3. And the 3rd time I forgot. But I just gave up after this.Also some of the bugs like the game skipping your turn entirely, save-games not loading correctly in battle, AI that teleports at the start of their turn (in plain sight) and also immediately fire right thereafter including sectopods and the like...XCOM:EU was never (properly) fixed. I hope XCOM2 will be handled better.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												Final verdict: Buy it when they've done patching the performance issue, as it's the only main problem I see. Other than that, keep an eye out for this game, the base game is awesome, and there's also a great modding community. I believe this is a game that's already better than EU/EW.Quick review:  Very  awesomeThis sequel improves every aspect of XCOM EU/EW,  I almost forgot I'm not playing a long war. Though, it's true the game need some performance patch.Other than that the performance issue and few random lag, its graphic is great.Sound is great (it manages to catch the atmosphere).Gameplay is very XCOM EU/EW,   though I haven't been playing for a long time, but it's looking good so far. If you've played XCOM EU/EW, I'd reccomend it fully.If you haven't, that depends on your preferable genre, as not everyone prefer a strategy gameA bit of advice for people who haven't played XCOM EU/EW, this game quite relies on RNG, don't expect your 99% hit precentage to hit. Always prepare a strategy in case it misses. Still, that doesn't mean it's 100% pure luck type of game, the strategy layer is deep enough to make up for the RNG.UPDATE: Finished the game.Well, it's kind of confusing now that I've seen all the game has to offer. It's not a bad game by all means, it just really push you to be proactive, which good for most people, not really good for other. The following things is purely my opinion:The good one+The avatar project timer is well timed. Not leaving you too laid back, but not really killing your gameplay.+The timers in missions is sometimes bad, sometimes good, though what really screw me up is the placement of the objective in most mission. (♥♥♥♥ capture mission though). But mostly, it's tight but not too tight.+The enemies are varied, which is good. I don't think it will ever be a bad point.+The costumization is good.+Destructible enviroment. Like, super destructible. This is good.+The mods are awesome already, and we're not even hitting the one week mark.The bad one-Some abilities are useless late game, or at least not as useful as the other one. This is a bad point, as every abilities should be useful until late game, to make a varied gameplay.-The pacing is weird and done too quickly. There should be a few mission with the introduction of new enemies. Instead in early time, I met new enemy in every mission. This is bad for new players who haven't learned anything about the enemies.-♥♥♥♥ codex-The final mission isn't as good as EU/EW. Warning though, this is purely my opinion.-The buying of new weapon and armor is weird. One mission you're underpowered, the next one you're super powered. I don't really like it as there's no transition from one point to another.  The use of experimental stuff is also weird.-The lack of stuff. It's like they only focused on the enemies, instead of the thing we'll be using against it.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2016
												I really, really wish Steam had a 'Mixed' review option. In the sequel to the fantastic reboot, it's now canon that you lost the first war and now XCOM is a resistance cell fighting against the ADVENT Coalition, headed by the enigmatic Elders (Ethereals). While the game has tons of potential, I feel like the devs took all the wrong cues from a certain XCOM mod.My first real complaint is the concealment system that allows you to remain hidden until you 'go loud' and begin actual shooting. However, this seems to accomplish very little, especially when the time limit (another gampelay feature I question) is so stringent, and in some cases, literally impossible. Enemies are also broken as hell, and the game seems to have no grasp of when to introduce new enemies. In the first month alone, you start running into one enemy that can literally sprint halfway across the map and kill your guys in one hit. I'm a Classic Ironman veteran of Enemy Unknown, but here it just seems like enemies were straight-up designed to make you take unavoidable losses. There's no sense of parity; either you ambush and kill all the enemies on the first turn or they WILL kill you in three.And for the game's biggest sin: the strategic map. Instead of a ticking doom meter that you can manage by playing well, there's now the Avatar Project to deal with. And here's the problem: not only does the Avatar project show up way too early, but it progresses way, way too fast. Not only that, but there's *specific missions* you have to accomplish to bring it down, and oftentimes those missions will spawn in places beyond your reach. The whole thing just dangles this time limit above the player's head that they have very little control over, and seeing it tick up every month doesn't bring a sense of urgency likes the devs probably thought it would, it's just damn frustrating. With those negative points up in the air, I should mention the positives:* The combat system is as good as EU's, just suffers from the ridiculous enemy progression/unbalance I mentioned* Much better mod support, including some mods to reduce/remove some of the negative points of the game* SO MUCH CHARACTER CUSTOMIZATION. If you loved XCOM for customizing your soldiers, you'll probably like 2 for this alone.This is a okay, but very flawed sequel. I didn't like this for the same reason I don't like Long War; what the devs consider challenging I just consider tedious and annoying.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												A very good game plagued by questionable design decisions. The most obvious culprit is the mission turn limits. Apparentely this was done because overwatch was too strong and they wanted more fast paced/tense gameplay. Unfortunately it's not well implemented, I don't know if its better on other difficulties but on Ironman/commander you barely have enough time to get from point A to B. This makes lots of abilities and even the sharpshooter class quite useless. Why would I carefuly place my sniper on a roof top to flank the enemy if I know I won't have enough time to get her to the evac point in time? Combine this with some extremely powerful enemies like sectoids that appear early and often and you got yourself a major headache.On the other end of the spectrum the Ranger and Specialist are much stronger for the pace of the game, the specialist being especially crucial in the hacking missions. There are also lots of reports of bad performance, I've been lucky enough not to get any but I also turned down certain performance killing options. But from a game that is supposed to be a pc exclusive and was delayed to make sure it's flawless, it's very dissapointing.On the bright side the graphics and sound are great. Executing a perfect ambush against a group of enemies is extremely satisfying (unfortunately you rarely get the chance to do this because you have to hurry so much.I have no doubt that with a few patches/modding this game will shine and I will have no problem recommending it, but right now (especially with the price tag) I can't do so.TLDR version :+ Great sound and graphics+ Ambushes are very satisfying+ I love the new revamped classes, especially the specialist.+ Still the same heartpumping X-com action.-Mission timers for almost EVERY mission-some very powerful enemies early on with little way to counter them-Performance problemsP.S. I chose the "not recommended" option but I would choose a "neutral" option if there were one. It is not a bad game by any stretch and I feel I might update this to positive if a performance patch comes out soon.
