content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												Yes.  This is gaming.High stakes, dare-to-be-great situations, customizable soldiers, and plenty of explosions and pewpewpew!  The sequel and most recent iteration of the Xcom franchise is not PERFECT, but is a worthy edition and worthy of a playthrough.As the game opens, it is revealed that all the struggle to boot the alien menace off planet was for naught, and the invasion force has insinuated themselves as a mildly sinister "first among equals".Yes, all those hours playing the first game are not part of this narrative.  Get over it.Similar to the formula of the series, you are the direction and driving force of the resistance movement, allocating resources of various types in order to create an irresistable tide of cash, supplies, sentiment, and artillery to send them bug-eyed aliens back where the come from.  The planetwide metagame is familiar, as is the squad-based encounter maps, as you equip your troop carrier with strike teams for defense, or targets of opportunity.Part of the fun of this game was the customization of the individual soldiers as they increase in their individual class-based proficiencies and as your rag-tag resistance movement comes into more potent technology.  Over the course of the game, an individual soldier can go from the equivalent of hitting oogga-boogas on the head with a stick to "Over 9,000" cyberwarriors laying waste to the countryside.   The game fights back by introducing aliens of different strains with different strengths to force changes in squad tactics.The limitations of the game become evident on the first playthrough as the technobabble from your chief science officer can be omitted from the story with a mouse-click and a "Yeah, whatever. What can I blow up now?", and the mission objectives don't have a lot of variety. Overlooking these glaring flaws, the rest of the game is straight-up fun strategy.  Now that the game is no longer a new release, the expansion packs will be added, giving new life to new baddies, and further customization options.  As of this date, I have only played the core, game, but I recommend it VERY highly.XCOM 2: The people of Earth need you, WILL YOU HEED THE CALL?

number of helpful: 142 of 225 people (63%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												An incredible game worthy of full price, something I have not been able to say about the overwhelming majority of AAA (and otherwise) titles these days.  If you are a fan of turn based strategy combat, and a minor basebuilding overworld that involves an early-mid game frantic pace where you juggle resources and make key decisions, Xcom 2 should be right up your alley.It improves on almost every facet of the original, though the base building is a little bare bones in comparison, since the nature of this game is quite different and your mothership is your home base so naturally, there are a lot fewer choices to make.  If you played the first one, you will be right at home, nothing is so vastly different that you won't be able to infer what its role or function is.The story is pretty well done, albeit a little sparse, and towards the end it does feel a little anti-climatic but really Xcom is about having a badass group of marines and the amazing combat.  A gripe many people will have (myself included) will be in regards to the some what questionable RNG that determines the success or failure of your tactics within the game.  When I think of 80-95% chance of success, I think of it as an almost sure thing.  When you miss 4 of those in a row, you begin to really question how accurate the numbers depicted upon the screen are.... but as everyone says Xcom is Xcom, and this is just part of the experience.  You can miss a 95% and you can hit a 20%.  The game isn't without its moments where you'd like to put an axe through your monitor.Unfortunately, there are definitely some performance issues and bugs/glitches with the current game.  The game, as impressive as it looks, is certainly not what you'd expect to push your gaming rig to its limits, yet your frames will drop inexplicably, mini cutscenes will stutter, and overall you will notice some choppiness.  Where as it's not aggregious for me (GTX980 TI, 16 gb RAM, SSD, I74790k), it still is bothersome that this game isn't running flawlessly.There is quite a bit of graphical clipping issues, it seems the engine has trouble dealing with structures, walls, doors, windows, and multi-level buildings.  Often your character will stick his gun through a seemingly solid object, or try to smash out a window that is already smashed, walk through a door, be pulled through a building, shot through solid cover, etc.   Where as it is annoying and takes away from immersion, the game is still so robust, deep, and rewarding that I found myself looking past it.  It's just too damn enjoyable to let those things drag down the experience.One would hope Firaxis is aware and addressing these issues, because once they are fixed, this game is a VERY strong contender for GOTY.   Certainly, this is the best tactical strategy game I've played, and the extensive modding capabilities the game has only means great things when you get guys like the creators of the Long War  working on all manners of new content - for free.All in all, despite the somewhat unforgivable performance issues of a PC-Exclusive, this game is definitely what I would consider a must-buy for anyone who is a fan of the genre.9.5/10

												If you enjoyed any of the previous XCOM games, don't read any further - just play this game!Amazing turn based gameplay. Complex and deep customisation/progression of your squad and base.Graphics are lush. I had it all the way up on ultra on my GTX970 and it played well until there were a lot of characters on screen at once and that's when the close up view of shots/reaction fire slowed down. I used the NVidia recommended settings which dropped a few things down slightly like the anti aliasing and to be honest I can't tell the difference and it runs smooth as f*** now.Some people don't like that some maps have a timer (not always a turn countdown). I didn't like the sound of it before in played and now after 40+ hours I can say it actually makes the game better. It changes up your approach and the gameplay and keeps the game fresh after and makes you the better tactician as you have to fully understand your squad and the battlefield. There is an overarching 'countdown' but it hasn't been a problem, again just adds to the overall game. I haven't completed this game yet but I still give it a 10/10 and name it as my PC game of 2016 so far!Seriously sweet.

												This game has only just begun and I already stopped counting how often it tripped over its own procedural generation of content. Your squad can only carry so much firepower. Even if a 100 % of your shots hit, sometimes a squad simply does not have the firepower (leave alone the staying power) to move from point A to B to C and dispatch everything that happens to spawn along the way within the turn limit set by the game. Further into the game, the glaring line of sight bugs also become very annoying. I don't know how often my sniper shot someoe through walls, floors or ceilings on overwatch. Or how often an alien did it on me. I've had entire firefights with all units on both teams exchanging gunfire right through (yet) intact walls. At this point, the game comes down to save-scumming until you get lucky. Recommendation: hands off for now, XCOM2 is simply broken in its current state.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2016
XCOM 2 XCOM 2 is the sequel to the critically acclaimed Enemy Unknown. Does it surpass its predecessor with flying spaceships or misses with near perfect aim, let's find out:Gameplay:XCOM 2 starts with a story which starts by telling you that you lost the war you waged against the aliens and now it's time to avenge humanity. I personally did not find the story of Enemy Unknown too thrilling, its pacing was abrupt and there were some logic gaps. XCOM 2 has a much better story with brilliant pacing and a very satisfying conclusion. Nearly each battle of XCOM 2 starts off with you planning an ambush for the aliens. The previous hunters are now the hunted. There is a specific turn limit in which you must finish your battles. While I don't like these things in any game, XCOM 2 handles it very well. This turn limit makes you really think out your strategies in advance and instead of just hiding behind some containers, you actually try to fight your enemies, which is a very good thing. The thrill which you achieve when an alien group is trapped completely by your squad and seeing that your plan worked is an tremendous achievement. XCOM 2 is still more of the XCOM you know of, you lead a party which are insanely customizable. You grow a bond with the squad mates you play with and it breaks your heart when one of these squad members die on the battle field. This guerrila warfare can easily go wrong in this game and sometimes you have to withdraw your soldiers from the battlefield to save their lives and in turn lose the battle. XCOM 2 is an improvement upon Enemy Unknown in every regard. There are a number of weapons available on your disposable and the game rewards the player's thinking. The game plays faster and there is a key tactical element called Overwatch introduced in the game which makes things easier to examine and play but it also is a thing that is quite expensive at times. There are your usual things like upgrading and managing you base, your soldier's equipment and such. As I said, there is a huge amount of customization available here.  Each map is a little random every time you play it which makes it much more replayable than the previous one. The randomness also means you can't remember each tactical place and that makes it that much more thrilling. XCOM 2 doesn't stray too much from the familiar formula and you can still miss shots at 95% chance, though it never feels familiar as those cases are really rare. The single player campaign is lengthy and will last you a minimum of 20-25 on hard difficulty. Aside from this, there is a multiplayer mode which lets you play as the aliens. While playing as the aliens is exciting, the multiplayer feature is pretty bare bones. I would recommend playing the multiplayer version against friends to get the most fun out of it. The UI is simple and easy to browse through. The tutorial also does a good job in easing a new player in the game. When it initially launched, XCOM 2 was marred by a multitude of bugs. Now, nearly 10 months later, the game is pretty much fixed. Sure, you may find a couple of glitches here and there but nothing game breaking. On the plus side, the modding community for the game is thriving and it has already produced some really nice ones.VisualsVisually, XCOM 2 looks excellent. While it does not sport photo realistic graphics, it does have gorgeous looking maps and excellent character models. The cutscenes are done brilliantly and the texture is simply amazing. The alien models especially look far much superior to the ones in the original and now look far more diverse now. The maps have a good amount of detail and they look gorgeous especially when the sun is shining. The characters look superb and it's a blast customizing them and seeing them in battle field. Overall, XCOM features striking visuals which are a pleasure to view at.SoundThe sound design of XCOM 2 is done very well. The voices are very well acted and the usual random sounds are heightened to a new level. When you are waiting for a new turn, the slow build up makes it all the more tense. The main soundtrack itself is very good to listen at and helps in building the environment.OverallXCOM 2 is an improvement over Enemy Unknown in every single way. It features excellent combat and a fast paced story. The randomized maps makes it more replayable and there a ton of customization options available to the player. The modding community for this game also looks promising and gives it a bright future. It looks good, plays good and has taken tons of hours of my life. I can't ask more from a game. It is, by far, one of the best strategy games I have ever played.Rating : 95/100

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												I'll start by saying I'm really enjoying this game and don't regret getting it, however I don't reccomend buying it at full price in the state that it's in. If you can get it cheaper then go for it, provided you're a fan of EU/EW. XCOM 2 is more of the same, with a bit of different. There's a lot of good here and a lot of bad, but the bad is fixable, it's just that it shouldn't have been there to begin with.Pros:-The new base management and overworld stuff is pretty fun and in my opinion makes it feel like you're not just sitting and waiting for something to happen. Instead of having to try to manage a bunch of "feal levels", but only being able to affect one at a time, there's only one meter to worry about, and there are multiple ways to manage it. Having to make contact with different countries instead of having to prevent losing them gives you a bit more option as to how you approach things.-The new/updated classes feel a lot more balanced and interesting. Each one having two distinct specializations makes your squad more diverse, however a couple of them do feel underpowered, specifically the scout and combat hacker trees.-The weapon changes make things a lot less tedious in some aspects, but moreso in others. Pistols on the sharpshooter class are fantastic, they're decently powerful and give your sniper a way to fight in close quarters and able to attack/overwatch after moving. Being able to attack or move after reloading is just great, so taking away secondaries on all the other classes doesn't really hurt.Meh:-Turn timers, I know people are so divided on these which is why I put them in meh instead of cons, but I dislike them. I feel that they force you to play a certain way, even if you don't want to. I've had missions where I had to rush through enemies or else I wouldn't make it in time, causing me to risk my soldiers. There are already lots of mods to change how they work, whether it be increasing turns, reducing the amount of missions that use them, or outright getting rid of them.-concealment adds a nice way to setup ambushes, however in most cases it doesn't work out like you think it would. This ties in to turn timers, in that the timers are counting down even while you're trying to set up your ambush. It's just not viable to try to tactically ambush the enemy when you have to get to the evac zone in 8 turns. Also having all enemies suddenly just know where you are when you break concealment can easily lead to you being surrounded if you're not careful.Cons:-Performance issues out the♥♥♥♥♥ Supposed to be patched.-Glitches out the♥♥♥♥♥ Supposed to be patched.-I don't know if it's a glitch or just poor design, but line of sight is just super wonky. I've had enemies attacking me through walls, stun lancers meleeing people through the floor above them, and worst of all, snakes pulling my guys through as many as three walls with no holes or windows in any of them, effectively dooming them.-The difficulty curve is steep. Really steep. Within 5 missions I was fighting against armored enemies that could destroy my cover, incapacitate my troops, and almost kill them in one attack, while I was still researching t2 weapons and armor. Enemies pop up randomly one after another, giving you almost no time to adjust your strategy.-Dodge. If that's not specific enough, most enemies have a chance to dodge, causing you to do greatly reduced damage. I know the discussion of rng has been done to death, but sometimes it feels like they just always dodge.-Your soldiers' wounded level seems to be completely arbitrary. Soldiers that take 10% damage get gravely wounded and are out of the fight for a month to recover 2 hp. I've read of people having soldiers take over 50% damage and only being lightly wounded, but take 2 fall damage and be gravely wounded. Hopefully they can patch the performance and glitches, with that I'd say it's worth it, but until then no. Other than that it's up to you whether these things bother you or not.

number of helpful: 117 of 186 people (63%) found this review helpful33 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												"We are extremely impressed with XCOM 2 project thus far, Firaxis. Your recent results were beyond my expectations... And that is not a statement i make lightly."While i have a small number of grievances here and there, they are fairly minor in comparison. With the recent games Starships and Beyond Earth, i was afraid Firaxis might've lost their touch. Though Beyond Earth was pretty decent, it was no near as fun, deep or satisfying as CiV5. XCOM 2 however restored my faith.Truly, XCOM 2 cranks its predecessor up to 11. As your opponents have grown in power and unpredictability, there's an even stronger reason to fear what potential weapon they might unleash upon you next. However, so have you. Everything feels powerful, dangerous and there's few things as satisfying as scoring a critical hit and watching a 3 meters tall monstrosity get blown away from a shotgun round. Though performance seems to be a littly wonky at times (framerate drops when in the Avenger or when deploying a flashbang grenade), it's been fairly stable for me with no bugs aside from the AI suddenly going idle once. For 16 hours of playtime on a newly released game, that's a pretty good thing in my book.Excellent production values shine everywhere. This is apparent in the smaller details as well, such as the great soundtrack and voice acting, soldier customization and the excellent atmosphere in map design that truly gives you a dystopian feel. Not to mention that XCOM2 has an amazingly badass Workshop. Where The Long War was pretty much the best alternative for the original, there's already a bunch of sweet stuff for you to go on, the game is really built to last on a strong mod community - while still providing a base game that's filled to the brim with content.The only thing, gameplay wise that bothers me is that they've added a turn limit. You must complete the objective before the timer runs out, which is usually pretty tight. Though it gives off a feeling of hurry, anxiety and fear - for a game that's partially built on chance and tactics, it's frustrating and doesn't fit well. Thankfully there are mods in the Workshop that remove or increase the turn limit, of which the latter one i highly recommend using. While this is the biggest issue i have, it can be avoided entirely, so i guess it's not much to bother with.In conclusion, any fan of XCOM or TBS will love it. Hell, i think anyone will enjoy it. And i have some very high hopes for the expansion and modding community. Possible GOTY!Edit: Seems performance issues are something some people are running into. None here, surprisingly, since nearly every game that's currently being released is full of bugs and performance issues. However, in my experience, XCOM 2 runs smoothly and without problems. Still, i would highly recommend taking proper precautions, such as giving the game's bug forum a read before picking up the game.

												If you took XCOM and added a couple of minor bugs, one or two game-breaking bugs, broke some functionality and made interface worse and less user friendly, you would get exactly XCOM2. Another large well-known studio which sells their sh** "AAA" game for very high price (£35). Such things should be classified as fraud.Bad performance and poor stability random FPS drops occasional crashes cut-scenes are playing before graphics are loaded, making first few seconds of it either very ugly or just black screen with sounds after one mission, whenever I open geosphere the game freezes - I had to start the campaign over (with disabled mods and tutorial) in later stages of the campaign, the game occasionally gets stuck while loading a saveBroken and user-unfriendly interface most of the interface pretends to be in-game poor quality hologram device and it is blinking, misaligning etc. Very annoying when e.g. reading research report and the text is moving every few seconds... on some screens there are no back/close buttons, making it impossible to navigate with mouse, you have to use keyboard sometimes you have to click the same button multiple times sometimes when you hover over the button to expand a list and then move mouse pointer onto item on the list, the list disappears so you have to hover over the button again, etc. sometimes in the top right corner the video of the talking chief engineer/scientist is shown... all the time... with no sound/text... there is no indication whether quick save was actually made game save doesn't save the camera position and facing direction, neither soldier selection many of the cutscenes and videos are not shown if tutorial is enabled... or maybe that was due to 3 Long War Studios' mods...? sometimes camera is not following the action - is it enemy's turn and you just hear shots and your soldiers being killed? Sorry, all you will see is a wall (or ceiling or undiscovered part of map)Long loading times and a lot of waiting loading a save (even quick load) takes about 20 seconds returning from mission ("flying back" loading screen) takes a few minutes, a bit shorter when flying to mission with over 100 saved games, it takes over 10 seconds to open the list of saves weird long pauses between soldiers' actions on missions - you soldier has just killed an alien? you have to look at its body for 5 seconds before you can give another order it is impossible to skip soldiers' annimationsFlawed and unpolished gameplay soldiers shooting through walls, without line of sight generally what you see and what actually happens are two different things - so get used to seeing entire burst hitting the enemy accompanied by a popup "missed" items drops? The way it works just su***. Enemies occasionally (like 1 every 10) will drop an item, that you have to pick up within 3 turns because otherwise it will disappear. Soldiers don't need any inventory slots for them, picked up items will be just visible as loot on the summary screen weapons upgrades and soldiers' implants? Cannot be produced, can be acquired only via items drops. And the upgrades once placed in, cannot be taken out, only destroyed items manufacturing is extremely confusing and lacks any explanation about how it actually works. I can manufacture two armors - one of them is a single utility item that I can put in soldier's inventory, the other unlocks entirely new armor (new apperance, 2 utility slots, HP bonus) and is available for every soldier. There is nothing indicating whether what you are working on is a single item, unlocking item (i.e. infinite amount of this item) or a research that will let you manufacture an item if you finish a mission while controlling enemy soldier, its body is not retrieved the same if a controlled enemy is killed - it's body just magically disappears "evasive manoeuvres" in case of imminent UFO interception mean “fly around entire Earth” or “fly to a nearby location and wait for the UFO until it flies around entire Earth and attacks you”And many, many more various bugs...

content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												Everyone who knows me well enough knows that I had a ton of hype for this game, and oh boy was it worth it. However, I'm going full ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ critic here, leaving my love for the franchise aside and will do my best to give a fair review. And as usual, I'll start with the stuff the game doesn't do right. Luckily, there's only three things:First and most important, the difficulty spikes. I'm not sure who tested the game, but he was high as f#cking f#ck. I know XCOM is not known for being easy and forgibing but COME ON, THE EARLY GAME HAS A BIGGER DIFFICULTY SPIKE THAN CORRUPTED PEOPLE ON THE SPANISH GOVERNMENT! Since the second mission (the first one being the tutorial, unless you disabled it), you'll be usually facing with normal and fair enemies like the ADVENT troops AND THEN THE SECTOIDS COME ARROUND. This early on, the Sectoids have MORE HP than your soldiers, have three powerful PSI attacks, and also a Bracelet-Gun they never seem to f#cking use for some reason. And it's not like in XCOM 1 when they could waste their turn to make another Sectoid better or at times cause panic. Here they still have the panic skill, and can also Mind-control AND reanimate dead people into zombies. ON THE SECOND MISSION. If that ain't enough to♥♥♥♥♥♥you off, wait until the game tasks you to "hack" an ADVENT Officer. It's similar to capturing aliens in XCOM 1, but with a LITTLE SURPRISE the game forgot to tell you about: hacking an ADVENT Officer spawns a MID-GAME enemy, which early on will feel like out-right cheating and artificial difficulty. This enemy can TELEPORT AND INSTANTLY FLANK YOU, can cause some sort of Black-Hole which will instantly unload your weapons AND explode for too much damage on the early game on the next turn, has double the HP than any of your soldiers by that moment, AAAAAAAAAAAND will split in half when you injure it. Now you'd think that splitting in half makes it easier to defeat, but no. It doesn't. His clone will usually spawn in the completely direction, and they share no cool-downs. If you're not careful, you'll go from facing one Codex to facing TWO, THREE OR EVEN FOUR CODEX. Sure turning a hard battle into f#cking ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.The second people is one I don't really give a ♥♥♥♥ about, but a ton of people do; Performance. This game is not well optimized. I usually blame games for it, but I must admit it looks good and it's a turn-based game, so playing in low FPS ain't that much of an issue... But I must admit that it got old pretty fast, and the devs yet have to fix most of that, as it took them nearly two weeks to release ONE update. No idea what's going on with that.The third and last problem are the bugs. I haven't played since last week but Oh God I was finding some weird crap. Most of them are LUCKILY only animation errors, but still there's some weird crap out there that will make you either mad or lose it completely. Things like rooms on the ship not loading and literally being see-through as there's LITERALLY NOTHING IN THERE. Things like characters stuck on the wrong animations, now being forced to teleport arround the map and for some reason take 30 seconds to do each action. Things like your character showing as he's on the completely wrong place where he should be. Those are fun. However, thing as having one of your soldiers stuck in mid-air while enemies fire at him, and forced to use EXPLOSIVES to take him down, literally bleeding out, IS NOT FUN AT ALL. There's also weird crap such as pieces of buildings floating all over the places, sh#tting all over gravity, or both XCOM soldiers and aliens dropping through the floor. Things like that make you even wonder if the game was properly beta-tested.That being said though, what do we got left? A seriously good sequel for a seriously good game.Gameplay, ignoring the early game insane spikes, is enjoyable, fun and adds more flavour to a really enjoyable XCOM 1 experience. There's a bigger focus on explosives on this game (as they weren't really that good on the first one), and that goes hand to hand with the mostly completely destructible escenarios.And talking about maps, they're randomized. One time or two they looked similar, but they're always different and that's something I totally love.Customization is not only back, it went Super Saiyan: there are AN INSANE TON of options, and it trully feels amazing.Even better than that though, proper Mod support. And the workshop of Steam already has some fun things on it. Personally I only went so far with customization mods but OH GOD, IS IT FUN TO KILL ALIENS WITH CLASSY TOP HATS AND OVER-SIZED MARIACHI HATS.I haven't played multiplayer yet, so I'll avoid that, but ♥♥♥♥ing hell it was worth the money. And it already has DLC's coming, which I decided to pre-order as I do trust there guys. However, the price tag will scare people off. WAIT for a sale. 50€ ain't cheap at all.Just get ready to miss point-blank shotgun shots. It will happen. That's XCOM, baby!

content:
Posted: April 12, 2016
												If, like me, you played Xcom Enemy Unknown (or its expansion, Enemy Within), you probably remember defeating the aliens who were trying to invade Earth. Unfortunately Commander, there's some bad news.  It turns out that was actually some kind of simulation that the aliens used to understand our tactics, so they could figure out how to beat us.  Earth's citizens have been living under a "peaceful" alien rule for 20 years, and you're now part of an underground resistance force, trying to stop the aliens' secret, sinister plan, before its too late.Just like the previous game, Xcom2 is divided into two distinct areas of gameplay: the base, and the missions. During the base phase you can research new technologies, build better weapons, armours and equipment, recruit and train your soldiers and manage your economy. Missions involve taking a squad of upto 6 soldiers to achieve objectives such as protecting some civilians, stealing some intel, recovering an item or destroying an alien base. Combat is the same turn based style as before.Although Xcom 2 is a good game, it didn't quite excite me as much as the previous game did, and I can't quite put my finger on why. I think it might just be because I've played Enemy Unknown/Within for a combined 122 hours across 5 successful campaigns, so although Xcom 2 is bigger and better, there's also an element of "more of the same".The Good•	Your soldiers have a fantastic range of abilities. I found every class of soldier to be extremely useful.•	Large variety of aliens with unique abilities including mind control, stun, poison, disable weapons, area of effect attacks, shield allies, teleport, clone, shapeshift ... and probably more that I'm forgetting.•	The combination of above two points results in lots of tactical depth. I often spent a few minutes on my turn just analysing the situation and considering all my options.•	You can upgrade your soldiers' weapons with mods recovered during missions that give special abilities, including reloading the weapon without it costing a turn, bigger clip size, a percentage chance to attack multiple times on your turn, and a percentage chance to get an instant kill no matter how much health the alien has (I actually killed the most powerful robotic enemy in one shot thanks to this, which was a really cool moment).•	The campaign is longer than the previous game. It took me 40 hours to finish, compared to 25 for EU/EW.•	More visual customisation options for your soldiers.The Bad•	The story is fairly generic and none of the characters are particularly interesting. It doesn't help that the player character never speaks. If there's another sequel, I'd like to see a bit of Mass Effect style banter in between missions with the guys back at your base, to add a bit of personality.•	Poor technical performance. I saw several examples of the action camera not actually showing me the action because my view was obscured by scenery (walls, trees, etc). I saw countless occasions of both the aliens and my soldiers attacking through solid walls (both shooting and melee). And the framerate stutters horrendously when loading into and out of a mission.•	Frustratingly high number of missions where there is an extremely tight turn limit to achieve the objective. For example, hack a data relay before it shuts down in 8 turns. The data relay is so far away from your starting point that it takes 3 turns to get there moving full distance each turn. And of course there are 2 groups of aliens between you and the objective, which will probably take 2 turns each to kill if you do everything perfectly. These kind of missions feel like there's zero room for error, but at the same time, you just have to rush forward, abandoning any kind of intelligent tactics. The absolute worst missions are when you have to stop the aliens from destroying a data relay, which is on the other side of the map, and the aliens are already shooting it on turn 1.•	"Concealment" is a wasted mechanic. Your squad starts most missions in stealth mode, and the aliens don't attack you until you are "revealed", which happens if you open fire, or enter their line of sight. But its pretty much impossible to stealth an entire mission because there are always aliens next to the objective, and so the few times I tried to sneak past a group of aliens, I actually ended up in a bad situation because when I was inevitably seen, I'd find myself surrounded. I quickly figured out that it was safer to ignore concealment, and just attack immediately.•	There are occasions where you have to choose between 3 missions that have different rewards (and penalties for the ones you ignore), and just like EU/EW, you can still only do 1 mission, even if you have enough healthy soldiers for 2 or more full squads. All those resources, all that fancy tech, and we still can't build a second dropship, or at least capture one of the aliens' dropships?The RecommendationWhilst its not quite as amazing as I hoped, Xcom 2 is still a good game that is worth playing. You'll get good value for money from a full price purchase. If you've never played Xcom before, you don't need to play the previous games first because the story has essentially been reset, so you could start with Xcom 2 without a problem.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												For starters, it is really sad that people are giving Firaxis a free pass with this. I'm a big fan of the XCOM franchise, and I've been hyped for a long time to finally get my hands on XCOM 2.Unfortunately, it seems like Firaxis just tricked us into buying the game with the whole "built with PCs in mind" thing. I'm running the game with a GTX 970, 8gb RAM and an i5 3570. This trio is capable of maxing almost all games released these days, and XCOM 2 is the first game to launch the "completely unplayable games" list.Vsync is locking the game at 30fps, but even disabled it is hard to get past the now removed cap. People can argue that you can turn your settings down to make it "playable", however I cannot find a reason to do that when you spend so much money with a good graphics card. Another big bummer is that the cutscenes are rendered in 30fps. I thought we were way past that when the devs said the game was going to launch exclusively for PC, a platform well known for superior performance in games. For what reason would you lock the cutscenes in 30fps when most gamers want to experience the whole game in 60fps?I will refrain from talking about the gameplay for a while, but from what I could play, it just looks like good old XCOM. I'm going to keep this review updated, I just couldn't give it a thumbs up or let people give their thumbs up and say the game is almost unplayable. The newest Naruto game was released today and people aren't giving Bandai the same free pass for delivering a subpar experience.It feels good to be the commander again, but it definitely doesn't feel good to see the game running in slow motion.

number of helpful: 37 of 50 people (74%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13
												"I feel that this game is as complete as it can be. Sure some things could be better, but I don't think this needs anything added. This is the reason I think that there's no point for waiting a next installement."This is a quote from my short review of Xcom: Enemy Unknown+Enemy Within about 2 years ago. And after playing XCOM 2 it still seems very relevant. XCOM 2 in it's own right is an excellent game, but if you've played EU/EW there's the slight problem of the games being too similar to each other. I for one wanted to revisit EU/EW but instead bought this to satisfy my craving. It ended up being a perfect answer yet it made me wonder constantly that was the upgrade worth the money.I have not played other XCOM games than EU/EW and XCOM2, and therefore my review only concentrates on those two. Played both on veteran difficulty(saving allowed). Played XCOM2 only once, 48 hours on the clock at the time of completion.If you haven't played XCOM at all, the basic idea of the game is that you have two game modes. You build your base and control your resources, that allow you to get better equipment for your soldiers. With those soldiers you go on missions, and those missions gives you different kinds of resrouces. If you fail on either part of the game, it gets more difficult on the other part too. So it's basically very similar to Total War series, in a sense that you have to do Campaign properly to survive battles and do battles properly to survive in the campaign. Although in this game the campaign is real time and the battles are turn-based and you cannot autoplay or skip either. More about the actual gameplay can be found from youtube.I so much want to review this as a recommended game. Yet I cannot recite the major differences of the two since I cannot really remember anymore some of the features in the first one. Most of the features I praised in EU/EW I could praise them here too. The graphics are stylized and fit very well, the atmosphere is still there, the music there to support it, the gameplay is stellar with only few hicups here and there. But essentially you're paying premium for a slightly better game. I could still go and play EU/EW and enjoy it without feeling that I'm playing a much more inferior game. I couldn't think of any downgrades from the previous game so XCOM 2 is a better game than it's predecessor but it also costs more and demands more from hardware.For me the biggest upgrade was the level design and how the new features helped playing the game. The biggest new features are the stealth ability, evacing and the increased amount of timed missions. The first leaves more windows open for better tactics while the latter two forces player to make suboptimal moves. The player is now more in control how he faces his enemies yet having a timer means that there is a constant pressure to do suboptimal moves to avoid problems in the later part of the mission. Evacing forces player to think other than just clearing the map. The endless amount of enemy soldiers mean that one might get overwhelmed if one stays too long in the mission area.Thought I think the game is outstanding I must say one word of criticism that is completely a problem in my personal taste. The game is quite difficult. There is a possibility for losing the campaign, unlike in any other tactical game I have played. You might lose a mission so bad that you cannot recover in campaign screen let a lone in the following missions. This is a feature XCOM is famous of, very similar to quite many roguelikes. The difference here is that the campaign can last really long, took me 48 hours when trying to do(or see) everything. So essentially if you lose, it might be after 20-30 hours of gameplay. I loved playing FTL:Faster Than Light and trying again and again to complete it, ending up 23 hours and maybe 50 runs. But I cannot think of myself actually playing this on harder difficulties so that I would end up playing multiple campaigns and losing most of them. I know the reward is just the greater when there's victory after multiple defeats, but the time consumed is just too much. I must emphasize, this is not something I think as a design flaw but as a feature that doesn't please my personal taste. The campaigns don't vary enough for me to make me want to replay again and again.The game offers 4 difficulties, but since those difficulties affect all aspects of the game, it's usually quite a step to up the ante. The game could really use more options in difficulties, so that players that enjoy challenge in missions could only crank up it in those rather than making everything harder. But essentially it boils to the already mentioned features. The game is an excellent game, with quite unique setting and gameplay. Yet it is very similar to it's predecessor XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Within. If you have already played the first one and crave no more similar XCOM, don't buy this. If you want more XCOM, you have to think if the minor, yet great, upgrades are worth the money.

number of helpful: 48 of 69 people (70%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												I Can't reccommend this for anyone except die hard Xcom fans desperate for more xcom action. If you're interested in Xcom and havent played the originals, and the reboot, AND long war, don't buy. They bumbled this one.The bad:- Baffling gameplay design choices- A huge system hog for seemingly simple graphics- A crappy interface, especially for PC (worse than the last xcom!)The good:- Combat is still very satisfying. But way more bullet spongey     I don't understand the direction they are taking this series. It truely baffles and confuses me. The last game stripped xcom of all of its deepest (some may say complicated) elements, like soldier stats (which made them individually unique), action points, etc. This one continues to remove the things we love, like the (granted, dumbed down) UFO interception system, but on top of that ADDS a ridiculously convoluted geoscape and base system. What the hell were they THINKING?    There are 400 differnt resources. Its like an Iphone game where you get wood and ore and gold, but you gotta pay 5 dollars for the super special pink crystals! Unless of course you want to wait around with your thumb up your♥♥♥♥♥for 48 hours.   You run around the map playing a persistant game of wack a mole. But there is always an obvious choice. There is no STRATEGY in this strategy game.    You get to maticulesly place every scientist and engineer, assigning them to various tasks. Cuz why not add some needless, unfullfilling micromanagement to the game?!  You're never really sure what youre acomplishing and why! I need some intel for this, then gotta reseach that, then make contect with this guy then fly over here and pat my head and rub my belly and WHAT THE ♥♥♥♥! How could you make this such a convoluted MESS, yet still say, "Players are too stupid for action points! Thats too complicated! No more interceptors, its too involved! It needs to be accessable!" Are you KIDDING me?!   Besides the gameplay choices being incomprehensible, I'd like to adress the graphics and interface. Can we please stop with this trend of making everything smaller and smaller, and calling that "graphical improvement?!" Please! The buttons in this game are 2x2 pixels. You need a microscope AND a gyroscope to read the text. Because not only is it impossibly small, they thought it would be a silly goof to add a scrambling effect every 3 seconds while you're trying to read 4 paragraphs of text for every research project!  You can only rotate the map in 90 degree incriments instead of 45 now. Which makes it enranging when you're tring to click the single pixel that lets you move to the spot behind cover instead of the one where your genitals are perfectly lined up with the aliens gun barrel.   WHY can I play fallout 4 without issue and this game drops to 3 FPS on the lowest settings? The graphics look like 2006's Sam and Max, so why does this game require a monster PC?  Speaking of which, the graphical design of this game (and to a lesser extent, the previous one) is lame. Its designed for children. I feel like a dork when I play, because I'm looking at guys with cartoonishly large guns and guile haircuts run around in Anime armor. If thats your thing, thats cool. One day you'll be a grown up too and feel some shame!  All that being said, it feels a lot like the last game, and the combat is satisfying. However, they really upped the bullet spongeyness of enimies and added more needless, pointless, convoluted elements to combat as well, in the form of hacking. Which is COMPLETELY RNG. Thats fun too right? Thats what people love about strategy games. The RNG....  So get it if you've exhasted the previous games. Do not support this kind of decision making otherwise.

YouTube™ Video: XCOM Enemy Unknown - Ready For Battle (Extended 1 Hour Version) / Michael McCann

Reminds me of the Skyrim/Fallout modders. At least with mods, I think this game is a bit more playable.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2016
												Here comes my opinion of XCom2.In Short. Can I recommend it?No. Not at its current state.Iam kind of sad to say this, but this game should have never been release in its state.So, whats wrong with it?I will start with what is right instead.The Good:Since the XCom:EU remake, some changes in compare to the originals from the 90's are realy good.First of, it plays fast, action packed, and is nice to look at.The "just one more turn" feeling is still there, and you never get bored during the missions.The story is ok'ish, not that great but you want to know more and why things happen.Reduction of action points to simple 2 actions per turn leads to a fast paced tactical play, skill and soldier class system feels at the right deep for this fast gameplay.Sadly thats almost all about it.The Bad:-worldmapThe stratetic map has been stripped down even more since XCom:EU. You have almost no choices or alternatives, no options. Without spoilers of some sort, every thing you can do is kind of mandatory. If you dont do the right things, you dont advance...but...you will do it because there isnt anything else to do.In fact, you wouldnt even notice if the worldmap where not existent and this things would be done by the AI for you.-basebuildingIts almost the same here. You have some options of buildings, but they are not optional. You can and must build exactly 1 of the key buildings (you cant build more)Then there are 4 facilities left you can choose to build. 2 are almost irrelevant (did complete it without even building them) and the others are also mandatory to support your base.No real choices, no alternative approaches.-UIHorrible. For a PC exclusive game I was hoping for a very good and fluent UI. Insteat we got a cumbersome bunch of menus, where everytime you want to go to another menu you have to watch animations of zooming in and out for seconds. Soldier customizing is unintuitiv at best, and burred in lots of different layers till you get your dude equiped and colored.Also there is a constant feel of lack of information. To check your current weapon, upgrades and personal stims etc. on one soldier you need to zoom in and out through a bunch of menus. In your squad overview you see fancy 3D models but almost nothing else.Gameplay flow comes to a crawl here.Overall presentation of information is realy bad in almost every part of the game.-missionsThe maps are now random generated, which is cool. The battles have not changed to much from :EU. But the maps are ridiculous bugged regarding line of sight, cover etc. (shooting through walls, meele through roofs etc.)The new stealth mode in some missions is just a nice ice on the cake, but its not well thought out. After the initial stealth the enemies still getting their free movement, autospot you if you spot them etc.Cover is now destructible, which is a good thing, except its to easy and to unpredictable to destroy. I had whole housefronts collapse to dust from swordblows, or fires expand through thin air.-AIThe AI feels implausible. Suicide troops left and right, which you cant take out fast enough in early game, and are too easy later on. Most of the difficult comes from the unpredictable random generator and absurd skills some enmies have. In contrast the lategame feels just like a walk in the park, because your soldiers become also absurd overpowered.So it is a very deadly beatup where you hardly can predict the exact outcome. Luck is a factor here. (even very good players are at times just had more luck then others)Then the enemy behavior is sometimes very predictable, even in unlogic situations. If you study this you can abuse it to cancel some threats completely.-performanceOh my God. I dont even know what causes a turn based game to suck this much at performance at almost every aspect. Loading times, movie frame rate, animations, delay and hickups here and there. Very often complete animation sequences are skipped for no obvious reason so you have to guess what just happened. (talking about you snakeman)The aftermission reportscreen sometimes needs longer to load then the mission itself, at least it feels like this.You can watch how textures get loaded etc. etc. And no, I didnt play it on Max Settings, even with my very good rig.-supportLame. We got 1 patch till today which caused more problems then it solved. Critical flaws are still unadressed.So in conclusion, I had my fun with one playthrough, and i had my frustration. But I cant stand to play another campaign because of the numerous flaws, bugs and the horrendous slow UI animations, constant anoying voice chat from your central and lots of other minor things.XCom 2 could have been a precious gem, but someone forgot to polish it.

number of helpful: 20 of 21 people (95%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 19
												LIke its predecessor, XCOM 2 maintains a feeling of constant pressure -- every decision at every level seems weighty. Each time you move a soldier, every shot taken, each upgrade chosen, every choice at both the tactical and strategic level feels important. Every moment in the game is tense and exciting.Sometimes the random elements of the game can feel unforgiving -- missing a shot that has a 95% chance to hit always feels like you've been robbed, even though you're told explictly that the shot has a 1 in 20 chance of failing -- but sometimes the RNG also blesses you with a squad-saving bit of luck just when you need it.The story doesn't contain any surprises, but is well done. I especially enjoyed the little bits of banter in the Avenger view, especially Shen's quip about the Advent burgers. Art and sound design are both high quality; there's an occasional glitch in animation, but that's something forgivable considering that levels are procedurally generated and contain destructive elements -- every so often, you'll have a camera angle on a character that just looks odd. I mention it only out of completeness; it is rare, and never took away from the enjoyment of the game.Finally, the mod support is excellent -- many people have expanded the interface (everyone should get Overwatch All and Evac All), weapon options, new map options, and of course the Long War 2 project might as well be a completely new game by itself.Between the supurb base game and the excellent mod community, XCOM 2 will give fans of tactical games many hours of enormous fun.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												I loved the first one - played through on hard and enjoyed it. This, however, on easy on the first level, I am struggling. 5 attempts so far and no where close to winning.The aliens seem to have a preternatural ability to hit my soldiers in cover despite when it's my turn they show as having a very low hit point percentage.One of my soldiers has a mele attack, which, when you use unless you kill your foe in one hit, it leaves them standing next to the alien, which then obviously kills you.The very first level has a 'grey' which can raise the dead. This would be fine but it takes at least two full barrages from your soldiers, which means you have to put them into harms to way to kill it before the zombie - which also require two kits to kill - can kill your soldiers. And by the way once you fire, that is that's soldiers turn over.And all this is set against the clock, which means you have to take a lot of risks to get to your objective.I would not recommend this.  I bloody loved the original, but this is terrible IMO. God knows how it got such good reviews.  Games are supposed to be fun and this just isn't.  Oh and the graphics are distinctly average when compared to the previous game.My only hope is that I'm rusty at playing xcom, but on easy, 5 attempts in without getting close, come on!

content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
Firaxis strikes again, with a mostly excellent sequel that hits every note bar one.XCOM 2 is one of those games that gets under your skin. You'll be playing it mentally long after you've finished your session for the evening, you'll be thinking about various strategies long after your first campaign completion too. The fact that this time Firaxis has built modding right into the game client is a real testament to the fact that this XCOM will almost certainly be the one to beat for some time to come, and with it they've made some major steps forward, and a few steps sideways, along with one step backwards. I'll come to that one at the end of the review.Firstly, let's go over the synopsis. The game assumes that most people failed their first campaign in XCOM:EU (or EW), which is probably correct, and thusly, the governments of the world, having lost faith in XCOM decided to go the route of negotiating for peace with the aliens. On the face of it, this approach worked. The "elders" as they're now called, have on the surface - uplifted humanity - by providing improved technology, health and civic benefits that have improved the race as a whole, but it's very much a vision of humanity that's ruled with a velvet glove belying an iron fist. Any dissent results in the said voice taking a quick trip to "re-education" and never being seen again. A good way to imagine it is China circa 2015 but with an even more hawkish stance concerning human rights and you'd not be far off.Humanity that wishes to remain free, lives in isolated clusters at the fringes of society, deprived of any real contact with the world. and resists, albeit ineffectually. XCOM, having gone into hibernation, is suddenly awoken as intelligence brings the commander (you) back into play.Firaxis gets a lot rightSo XCOM is now a resistance movement. This rather neatly solves a lot of the story contrivances of the first game, you have limited resources, your base is a very small, but mobile command HQ that can only deal with a subset of what is going on in the larger world. Your options are now reactive, rather than proactive. The enemy is no longer a passive one either, having an active project that it persues. There's no longer a simple "You lose" condition, now the enemy has a "They win" condition that they're going after. This puts active pressure on the player to keep advancing and expanding all the while.Meanwhile, the tactical layer has had an awful lot of quality of life improvements, with classes now feeling a lot more distinct, and offering a lot more "play" in the 2-AP system that has become a hallmark of the XCOM series reboot. There's now ways to bend, and in some cases, thoroughly break the rules in your favour. The same goes for the aliens, who pretty much right away get the ability to mind control your soldiers, which makes for fun times.It's not always sweetness and light though...The game isn't -entirely- without faults, there's still numerous bugs and camera glitches (though they're a lot less than the previous game), and unless you have a real monster of a rig, be prepared to scale the graphics back a bit, because whilst the game looks a fair bit prettier, it seems that Firaxis didn't do that great a job of optimising the code, so the game munches resources at a fairly terrifying clip. If you CAN max out the settings mind, it does look awfully pretty, and you can end up with a great looking game when you're fighting the aliens, so it does reward with the eye candy.Other glitches I've seen include melee attacks through solid walls and closed doors (really -.-) and some pretty amazing instances where the camera decides the one place to be is inside an object, thus clipping everything and rendering the screen opaque for a fair while.The random elephant in the room...However, the big issue is as ever, the RNG. XCOM 2 uses a "pre-generated" set of rolls over the course of a fight, so imagine a long list of dice rolls prepared at the beginning, as each shot is taken, it checks against the list, ticks off a number, and moves to the next. I've tested extensively against multiple scenarios to isolate this, and have managed to confirm that the current system does not roll independently nor does the seed regenerate with a save reload. This is likely done to prevent save scumming, but unfortunately it also means that the game is robbed of a lot of the actual strategic improvisation that is actually supposed to exist, because it reduces the game to something of a puzzle game, once you understand HOW the pre-RNG system works, you can essentially reload saves to maneuver around it.It's a design choice, and it's a bad one. Again, likely to prevent save-scumming, which is a legitimate tactic in and of itself, but it essentially makes a game based on making estimates and percentage shots less about good judgment and more about working out what number is on the list. An option to have the game actively re-randomise rolls on -each- shot would be extremely welcome, and currently the only mod available simply forces the game to move to the next tickbox on the list.Closing thoughtsXCOM 2 is a great game. It could be legitimately excellent, were it not for the terrible issues with the pseudo RNG that is as far from actual randomness as one could get. When someone actually figures out a mod that corrects this, it'll be the first thing I recommend everyone downloads so we get the XCOM experience we deserve, that said, the rest of the package is so complete and tightly tuned that this game still warrants my highest rating even in spite of this issue.Firaxis, if you're listening - Regenerate the seed on each roll check, make this an option as a priority yo. Strategy gamers deserve this.Verdict : Essential

Posted: May 15, 2016
												XCOM 2 proves why the series is the best of its genre, although the fans have mixed feelings about it the truth is this game has been far improved compared to XCOM EU. As there is no perfect game, this one also has its flaws but in my humble opinion they are more at technical area, more explanations below.Pros:-Greatly improved inventory with many new gears = much more possibilities in the battlefield-More detailed environment and more destructible-Epic songs-Many new enemies forcing different means to kill them-"Timed" missions making real the feel of urgency of the setting of the game (controversial for many but for me it was a good decision)-New mechanics such as "concealment" where in some missions you have the possibility to set up ambushes to unaware enemies-Improved Headquarters gameplay, contact finding etc-Good variety of skills and its actually useful to lean to one side or another when training soldiers to a class-Story so far is keeping me very interested, totally fits in the setting and makes me want to kick aliens♥♥♥♥♥br>Cons:-The game runs fine, until certain point (some specific missions) where FPS goes down to 20 or so and you need to restart it, as if it is not managing memory well, loading everything and not unloading as you've done (for reference: max settings @ GTX970, I7 4790k, 32gb ram)-On Alien actions, sometimes it takes too long to catch up that you need to wait 5 seconds + for actions to take place, doesn't affect gameplay at all, just annoys-some minor bugs on enemy actions display, doesn't break the game againwell, that's it if you have any questions send me, I strongly recommend this game for fans and for those who like the genre

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												I'm done.While I was looking forward to the sequal this game apparantly is designed to break you before you even get out of the tutorial stage. It was clearly designed for those who have played Enemy Unknown on Classic and have their game down to a science. It is VERY newcomer unfriendly.I was happily enjoying the game until it started hitting me with missions while was in the VERY LONG process of trying to accomplish any of the supply pickups. I hadn't even made contact with my first new outpost when the game started hitting me with different alien types that started shredding me apart with myself unable to counter attack with nothing but a squad of nothing but rookies, and very low ranking specialists.Almost ALL the missions are on timers requiring you to play VERY AGGRESSILY in order to feel as though you're accomplishing anything. Anyone who's played XCOM will tell you that playing with that level of aggression with low level specialists and rookies is pure suicide. Failing the objectives will cause a swift decline in your ability to fight back effectively ending your game before you even make it out of the tutorial stage.Speaking of the Tutorial Stage. I feel as though Firaxes was trying to push too much too quickly. I was quickly beaten and destroyed on my very first mission when they brought in a Sectoid. My rookies were unprepared to combat such a high level enemy (on the very first mission no less) with their woefully underdeveloped weapons and armor. If anything the aliens represent a mid-game threat and their number rapidly increase to the point where you're facing down packs of mid-game enemies and you haven't even completed your first major objective when the game gets done hand holding you.A lot of the missions I tried to ignore in favor of picking up more supplies but the game kept telling me "No. This is a high priority mission. You shouldn't skip this." With each one throwing a new objective at me. I hadn't even had time to catch my breath and consider how to accomplish the last objective better before I had a new feature to contend with. Again I feel that Firaxes is rushing the progressing trying to show me all the cool new stuff they've done. "Oh look at this new alien! See what it can do! Look at this new objective! You've never done this before have you? Look a new way to play!" Dear god can I just catch my breath and consider how my last mission went first?Enemy Unknown (and Enemy Within) were much better at letting you get comfortable before throwing something new at you. You were just uncomfortable enough until you got toward the endgame and you were a much more equal footting. XCOM 2 is dedicated to smashing you flat until a mountain of new feature after new feature until you finally lose or just give up out of sheer frustration.I get they wanted to make it like a resistance game where you were hounded at every turn but this game dooms you from the start. And I was playing on Normal Mode. It felt like playing on Classic from Enemy Unknown.It's fun for all of about 3 hours. Then the inability to pick up resources because of constantly running missions demanding your attention because they have some new feature to show you cause you to hit a brick wall very quickly."Oh but Adhock that the point of the game! You have to make the hard choices!"What hard choices? The choice of ether losing the game because of the inability to stop alien progression while I'm trying to ensure I'm relatively stocked up enough to advance my gear or let myself get smashed flat trying to keep the aliens from advancing their endgame causing me to loose all my soldier with the inability to gear them or get more because I'm too poor?It's a lose-lose situation ether way. It takes too long to get supplies and they hit with higher tier enemies that should be saved for further in the game. I was expecting to clash with Advent Basic soldiers much like EU Sectoid until I made myself enough of a pain the aliens would respond in force with their bigger and badder units.Apparantly ADVENT doesn't have enough troops that the aliens feel the need to come out swinging harder then they should instead of letting ADVENT troops do their jobs before taking matters into their own hands when you prove too tough for them. Look at a lot of the gameplay videos. Most of the spawns are basic ADVENT soldiers and their counterparts with perhaps one to two aliens per map. I'm getting hammered with four or five aliens right out the starting gate. And don't even get me started on concealment. The mission that finally broke me my soldiers were boxed in by civilans and the act of trying to get past them cause me to drop concealment on my first move and there were too many aliens to punch through. I lost the mission entirely as the overaggressive push required to reach the objective in time caused me to lose half my squad. When the time ran out the aliens finished off the other bedragged half.Which effectively dropped me to only two or three soldiers left unable to field another unit. Because the timers to gain supplies were too long and I kept taking missions I was unable to get more soldiers. Game over.Save your money. Wait until the modders even the playing field for the early game. Right now it's clear that you have to mod to even survive the tutorial. Because it sure as hell isn't balanced in the early game to where it feels unbalanced but you have a chance.This is unbalanced with intent to break you before you even hit the play button.Do not buy the game.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												Edited - 14 July 2016Xcom 2 is awsome but i like Xcom more.This is pretty much how I felt the last time I started playing XCOM, way back in 2012, but I’d liken the game more to XCOM’s “Enemy Within” expansion in 2013. A comprehensive update to the gameplay, customization, and flow of the original, “Enemy Within” made XCOM the game it should have been at launch.XCOM 2 is better. Not only are customization options far more varied even than the expanded XCOM, the game is simply deeper, more challenging, and more fun in almost every way. Still, it’s not without its problems. Lets take a look at the Good, The Bad, and The Insulting of Firaxis’ ambitious sequel.The Good-Customization- I have way too much fun customizing my soldiers. This was severely lacking in XCOM, massively expanded in “Enemy Within” and has reached critical mass in XCOM 2. If you like customization options, they are here in abundance, from language and voice options, to props like sunglasses and baseball caps, to facial hair and scars. When a soldier reaches a certain rank, even more options are opened upEnemy Variety- Enemy variety is almost overwhelming at times. You learn to tread carefully and start making a kill-priority list very early onMore Tactical- Alongside the increased enemy variety is an increased sense of panic at the rest of the challenges. Whether that’s rescuing civilians, blowing up an enemy base, or getting to an enemy data bank before it self-destructs, there’s often some sort of primary or secondary objective that makes your life even harderFeatures- Adding to the tactical flavor are some new game features. Often you start the map out in Concealment mode, and can move through the map unseen by the aliens. This allows you to set up masterful ambushes and take out multiple bogies in one fell swoop.Swords - Using swords is awesome. Every game should have swords.The Scenario Makes Way More Sense- Here we had a global effort to fight back against an alien horde, and we were barely able to fund it. And why were so few soldiers taking on these missions? This time around you lead an underground resistance to the aliens and their global domination organization ADVENT. Having limited resources and a small, elite squad makes way more sense.More Strategic Depth- Alongside more tactical missions, your base of operations and world-map are now way more complex. There’s a consequence for every action, too, which means you’ll probably screw up a lot. Or at least, I screw up a lot, or I think I do.The Bad- It’s All A Bit Too Much - You can barely get one thing done without being interrupted a bazillion times by all the various projects you have going, by new missions popping up, or new resource collecting timers going off. Even when you get through a month and the powers-that-be send you your supplies, you have to go spend a few days picking them up. During that time any number of horrible things can happen, and all the while the ADVENT clock is ticking, leading toward some new calamity.Frankly, it’s just too much going on at once to be enjoyable at times. There’s almost no breathing room, even in the very beginning, and it’s very easy to slid into chaos.Mental Distress- Let me give example for you: I’ve got my four squad mates lined up just right to take out some bad guys. A dudes is in Overwatch, and the girl I have shooting has an 87% chance of success. Then she misses. My Overwatch dudes miss. Everyone misses and the enemies flank me. One of my squad mates gets hit by an alien with a sword, knocks them unconscious, so they’re out of the game. Then two of my squaddies panic and shoot wildly at nothing. Then a Sectoid takes over the mind of my fourth soldier and I’m out. I can’t do anything. There was nothing I could have done any better, either. I set it all up perfectly. I had a good chance of landing a shot and then taking out at least a couple of the aliens with Overwatch. But because half my squad panicked, one was knocked out, and the other got mind-controlled, I had no options left.(After this incidence i took a 3 hours nap)The Insulting-Repetition- In missions where you have to save civilians, you’re going to lose a bunch of them no matter how good you are. Aliens start picking them off instantly, and it’s a race just to grab the bare minimum. But each time the aliens kill someone, your right-hand man “Central” pops up on the screen to chastise you. “We cant afford to loose too many civilians, Commander!” he intones, or something like that. Many times over. The game pauses while he says his bit, which is really irritating. Stuff like this happens throughout the game. It’s repetitive, slow, and annoying. You should at least be able to play while the NPC’s are dressing you down for being a pathetic loser.(Whenever Central pops in, I AM LIKE, DUDE STOP IT, I AM YOUR ****ING COMMANDER)Bugs And GlitchesMy character fall of a building and KIA. One time the game just went black. Sometimes animation freezes for an agonizingly long time when Overwatch is triggered, ETCs.It’s top of the class when it comes to turn-based tactical gameplay, and I honestly can’t get enough.

Posted: February 17, 2016
												XCOM 2 improves on EU in almost every way. The core gameplay is of course very simmilar but all of the changes lead to a much fresher feeling game. The classes each feel uniquely powerful and, for better or for worse, almost all of the enemies from EU have been buffed. Things like the buffs from hacking (speed boosts, invulnerability, etc.) add an enjoyable amount of manuverability in basic combat.However,This game runs like utter trash. It's an absolute slideshow while navigating between the ship and the map. Load times are sluggish and painful. Bugs are very frequent and as a result anyone who wants to play iron man with the chance that their campaign could break at any moment is a crazy person. When they finally whip out the carnuba wax and finish polishing their game I can reccomend it. Until then hands off.EDIT-Specs-OS:       Win 10CPU:     i5 4570 3.2 GHzRam:     8 GB DDR3GPU:     GTX 770The in game settings were a custom set somewhere below medium. Ambient Occlusion, AA and the extras were all disabled. From that alone transitions would occasionally slow to <1FPS while generally being <7FPS.For anyone still interested I would highly reccomend following this guide. 


Essential improvements (Skip intros, fix stuttering, multi monitor support, resolutions past 1080p) 
A Guide for XCOM 2
By: reyqune

			How to Skip intos, fix stuttering, add multi monitor support, play at resolutions higher than 1080p. If you know any other essential improvements, please add a comment and i'll and those to the guide.		


With an emphasis on adjusting poolsize (my VRAM cache was a useless default value of 10MB) and threadedshadercompilethreshold to values that actually reflect your system. FPS is now generally 60 while dipping down to 25 for some transitions.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												Yes, I know, I know I haven't played the game for two centuries, so I'm not allowed to talk about it in public yet. Much less write a review.I'm giving it a negative review, because all the issues that were raised in reviews haven't been addressed for the launch copy:* The frame rates drops constantly (my pc is more than good enough to run it) almost constantly from the start of a mission to the end. So much so that it is sometimes impossible to keep up with.* The camera angles are awful at times, grenades explode off screen before they are due to, walls block the sight entirely, sometimes the alien's move is just a black screen so you have no idea what is going on. You can literally lose a soldier and have no way of knowing how.* There are excessive short pauses for no reason after actions and during some actions (seemingly at random). * Sometimes a person's body will be facing the exact opposite direction to where they are shooting.As well as that, a large number of missions have arbitrary turn limits, which are punishingly short. They only give you enough time to complete a mission comfortably if you rush most of the time. And rely on purely run and gun tactics. It removes any chance or opportunity to actually use strategy and tactics. Most of these issues will hopefully be addressed with hotfix patches, and working with the graphics card companies to get out some optimised drivers ASAP. But that doesn't excuse the game being released in this state. If this is the standard quality of a game at launch then this is the last game I'll ever pre-order.We need to make sure companies know this isn't acceptable or tolerated, or it will just keep happening *Looks at Bethesda*.I HIGHLY recommend waiting until the performance issues and bugs have been patched before purchasing. Once all the performance problems and bugs have been resolved, and there are plenty of mods to allow people to tweat the turn limit system, this will be an absolutely superb and very worthy sequel to X-Com.P.S. Fan(atic) boys please get your tongues out of the♥♥♥♥♥♥of Firaxis Games (more like Fixathis Game). Having it in there makes it harder for the aliens to probe them!P.P.S. the bug testing and QA for this game must have been hilarious: "Are the snakes supposed to be able to grab people through walls?""Why do my soldiers keep dropping through the floor as they move?"  "Is it normal for everyone to be shooting through walls with bullets, when the wall is right in front of them?"  "Why did my character appear on a different part of the map when the snake grabbed me?"  "Are there supposed to be constant pauses before and after every action?""Why does this game run like Crysis 2 on a Gameboy?"  "Is it normal for the screen to go black during the enemy moves time?""Why are the voices telling me important things constantly cut off?""Is it normal for a soldier to have their body face the opposite direction when they shoot?""Why are there such long pauses when the enemy does something?""Is it normal for a soldier who has been knocked unconscious to die instantly for no reason?""Are units supposed to have melee combat against each other from two different floors of a building?""Why are you releasing the game when it clearly needs at least another month of work?""What are you doing!? Where are you taking me!? no, No, NOOOOO"P.P.P.S The one thing I do have to give them credit for is creating a game that has both an 'anti-addiction' and 'anti-piracy' mechanism built into the game.The 'anti-addiction' works by having levels that are so hilariously impossible - due to objectives being destroyed before you can secure the area, or having to take on a whole army whilst getting from A to B in 12 moves' that you'll find yourself literally saying "oh f*** this s***" or "oh f*** off" or my current favourite "stupid f***ing game!" that you'll rage quit from a single player game, and not want to go anywhere near it for at least a day. It's impossible for even the most perverse and self hating sadist to be addicted to.As for the 'anti-piracy', all it takes is for a would-be pirate to read just a few honest reviews of this game (so none of the mainsteam ones then), or to watch someone play it for five minutes, and they'll realise they don't want anything to do with it, and wouldn't even take it for free.

												XCOM2 is just as enjoyable as 1 was a few years ago. There are multiple things which I feel are missing or not as polished as I have wished, considering the success of these releases, however, if the game remained as it is at the time of the review (Shen's gift DLC released), it will still offer a compelling experience. In the end, the pacing of the action and the improvements to the tactical battles, plus wanting to get more of the story it's what gives me confidence to recommend it. I've played so far on Veteran (completed the game surprisingly fast, 30 battles after starting, with the highest soldier rank Captain), on Legendary (plus some mods for extra content, which is badly needed and this will take me a lot of time to finish). There are multiple issues that are worth discussing, but others did a good job at explaining them (story, silly animation issues similar to those of the previous release, DLC stuff, performance, many others). But they don't make a significant dent into the experience, overall. At least not for me.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Performance can be an issue but everything else in the game is an improvement [imo] on the original it is easily recommended; blood, sweat and tears- and i'm only 9hrs into the game- aplenty as you attempt to nurture a fledgling guerrilla force into a truly global resistance network. XCOM2 perfectly captures that feel of 'hit-and-run' partisan style warfare you would expect after twenty years of alien occupation and it is a refreshing change of style and pace over the slow 'overwatch' creep of the first in the series. Blood: your's or their's, the combat is a mix of satisfying ambushes (thanks to the excellent 'concealment' mechanic), frantic tactical movement and complete RNG failure [see Tears].Sweat: as the turn counter ticks down, you'll attempt to navigate the quickest and most effective route to the primary objective engaging in tense and at times frustrating [see Blood] firefights against alien pods after an initial ambush seeking every tactical advantage you can.Tears: your soldiers, veterans and rookies alike, lovingly crafted and kitted out in the excellent customisation/loudout screens, will die. Retirement isn't an option.
