Posted: June 13, 2016
												I'll name off the obvious first:-horrible performance, I have to turn almost everything off or low to medium settings on a GTX970, still get frame drops below 30-very long load times, on a freaking 4x PCI-E SSD-frequent crashes-timers on missions makes the whole concealment aspect hard to pull off since you have to haul butt with Central Command constantly yelling at you that your time is running outNow for an awesome game, I can put up with most of this stuff, but it wasn't until reading some additional reviews that I could really pinpoint my main gripe with the game.It is way to busy.  In EU/EW, you had 10 days roughly to get stuff done at home base.  Not only did this give you a mental break from what (towards the end game) can be intense battles, but more importantly it gave you time to do stuff.There is an extreme tedium with XCOM 2 where you have a mission every 3-4 days and it takes forever to get anything accomplished, which means you're basically playing the same 3 flavors of a mission over and over again without any kind of new, exciting aspect other than upgrading your squad.Maybe I am just playing it wrong, but I kinda wanted some form of advanced technology after 27 hours of gameplay.I love XCOM EU/EW, best TBS game in the last decade at least.  XCOM 2 has a lot of promise, but bad performance, crashes, ridiculous load times, and the overarching feeling of tedium to get anything done kills it for me.

												The game looks like a lot of fun. Sadly, I can't play it, and I can't recommend that you purchase it in its current state. After playing through the first part of the tutorial, I am currently incapable of visiting the base due to a bug. Restarting the game and reloading the save have not fixed this. Attempting to start a new game (because redoing 15 minutes of tutorial isn't going to kill me) results in a complete game freeze. Uninstalling and reinstalling have not fixed this issue.Performance-wise, the game runs at about 30 fps on my rig, which is comprised of a GTX 980 Ti, an i7-4749k, and 32 Gb of RAM, unless I lower a bunch of settings. This is simply unacceptable from an optimization standpoint.Also, a small PSA for you fellow Nvidia users: When Steam installs this game, there's a small chance that it decides to activate the 3D settings on your card. If you're suddenly getting your games in 3D, check your 3D settings in the Nvidia control panel to disable it.As it stands, I'd stay clear of this game until it gets patched.UPDATE: After spending 3 hours "in-game", I've managed to fix my game (don't ask me how though, I'm still not sure what fixed it...) I've put a little more than 2 hours into it now. So here are my thoughts on it so far:Performance: It's HORRIBLE! With the specs I have, there is no reason I should be getting ~35 fps in-game on High graphics. I'm sorry, but XCom 2 isn't THAT good looking! The performance cost isn't worth the visuals I'm getting at all, and the visuals really shouldn't be this taxing! I've ran Witcher 3 with everything cranked up to the max (including Nvidia's Gameworks settings), and my fps remained both stable and above 60. This game doesn't even come close to the Witcher 3 graphically, and I can't see why these settings result in such a bad framerate!Not only am I getting low fps, but I also occasionally get insane stutter when trying to move units. This has resulted in a few deaths due to missclicks that happened mid-stutter (which makes me glad I'm not playing on Ironman).Gameplay:The RNG can be very infuriating, especially when it doesn't make any sense. Point-blank range is something you'd think would be in th game. Sadly, it isn't the case. I've had a few moments where one of my soldiers is next to an advent, his gun is inches from his head, and he misses his shot! This is something many people have been asking for, yet it isn't in the game. Hopefully mods fix this.The game will have small pop-ups appear next to ennemies' health bar to show you when you can perform specific actions from the position you'r trying to move. Sadly, the game also has a very small "maximum zoom-out limit" which means you sometimes won't be able to see the enemies' health bars to begin with. Getting a bigger limit to our zoom-outs would be great.There are some bugs that can be very annoying. I've had 2 characters die while taking cover next to cars because they'd blow up without any indication that they were going to blow up (By this I mean that the car is in perfect condition and explodes the next turn without anyone attacking it). I've also had a Sectoid who couldn't die. His HP bar was at zero, but he was still attacking (that was fun...)Also, why is it that there's a turn timer on every mission? Why are they so low? Like, the second tutorial mission has this device that will explode, you have 8 amounts of turns to disable it. It's in the middle of 3 squads. Walking over there takes 3 turns in itself. See, I can understand timers for things like that bomb, or for rescuing VIPs, but turn timers in elimination missions are so weird! You have to eliminate these 12 enemies in under 6 turns. "What happens after the 6th turn? Like, what's the reason we have to retreat?" "No reason. We just felt like giving you an arbitrary limit, or else you wouldn't be challenged."Customization:Ok, I have to ask: Why do characters from the character pool get promoted to random classes instead of the ones they've been given in the pool? Is it for balance reasons? If so, that's pretty dumb. People like me, who want to create their own characters and get them into a squad end up having to re-customize them once they get promoted to a completely other class. Because we can change it it isn't really game-breaking, but stil, if they could get promoted to the class you've assigned them, it would be a nice quality of life change.Cutscenes:Honestly, my cutscenes have been less "rendered videos", and more "family slideshows". Seriously, I thought getting 20 fps while playing was bad, my cutscenes continuously drop to 5 frames and below!The audio and video syncronization is also constantly off. It gets really distracting when you hear an explosion and only see it 5 seconds later.Verdict:I can't understand how this game has been released in its current state! Its performance is horrible, and it has game-breaking bugs! Honestly, it feels like I'm playing a beta. I just can't wrap my mind around how someone could sit down, and say "Yeah, this is ready for the masses!"As of right now, there are no client updates, and I've yet to hear about plans for one (though I can't wait for one to come out). It does have potential, but I'd recommend you wait until it's on sale, or until they release a few patches before getting this.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												Read Full in depth review and my tips on DVS Gaming[dvsgaming.org] that includes a lot more details.Looking at the gameplay a lot of it will seem familiar to XCOM players, especially if you’ve played XCOM Enemy Within. The interface is nearly the same and so are the mission styles and there is so much new stuff added on top of the old. As always you have a squad of soldiers ranging from 4-6 people to clear every mission.Every soldier will have one of 4 classes that then goes into another 2 types of subclasses, so even though that sounds very limited compared to The Long War mod it still provides for a lot of unique and great combos.XCOM 2 brings a lot of uniqueness to the things it had already in the previous game and therefore keeps it fresh and new enough for it to be a sequel instead of a huge upgrade/expansion of Enemy Within.XCOM 2 picks up the story 20 years after the events in Enemy Within. The guys from the former game have been busy trying to rebuild the XCOM project and rebuilding the base. So here you are in the middle of a world where aliens are the masters and humans are the slaves marked as renegades, fighting in the shadows to save the world from the aliens’ newest project codenamed Avatar.You’ve recovered an alien ship that you are using as a mobile base of operations, unlike Enemy Within, and you are flying around the entire world map gathering supplies, building contacts, gathering intel and much more. As the game goes on you can expand the ship with more rooms in the same way you could in the old XCOM base from previous games. You can also build and discover unique things across the world map that can make fighting the aliens a lot easier.You will need to build contacts with the resistance in every country to expand your operational area and to receive more supplies to rebuild your army. This creates a great way of dealing with research, upgrades, buildings and much more in a great flow that can be boosted by completing unique missions and picking up loot drops on missions that can now FINALLY be performed by your soldiers without them having to spend a year researching it.To explain that statement a bit, when you kill an enemy you have a chance that they will drop a loot item that can be anything from a weapon upgrade to PSI implants that will be usable if you collect them during the mission and then complete the mission. Weapon and PSI implants aren’t the only upgrades to be found. There are also ammo upgrades, grenade upgrades, soldier upgrades, armor upgrades and more. The combination of the level of customization available for each character and the number of possible upgrades makes for a level of overall customizability that rivals that of the Sims Universe. (You can’t dress up as Batman yet though, but give it time. Somebody will make a mod for that.)Recruitment in XCOM 2 is different from Enemy Within. In Enemy Within you just recived a group of random recruits and and were cut loose. In XCOM 2 you can pick your own recruits to start with from a long roster and then when you’re unlocked a certain room (trying hard to avoid spoilers) you can train them into certain classes to avoid the dreaded rookie stage. While this is a relatively minor change, it really makes your recruits and soldiers feel very much like your own people.As if all this wasn’t enough, Firaxis has brought out some truly scary aliens to woop our asses this time around. Everything from small creepy things to insanely huge monstrosities that make you wanna run home and cry. You get a great feeling for the difference between every alien and you will be able to tell them apart easily to know which you can shoot at and which you should just blow up with the biggest weapon you have.All in all a great experience that will make you scream, cry and laugh as you slaughter your way through aliens to save the planet.

number of helpful: 172 of 291 people (59%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
 Summary: All in all, I'd love to have given the game a recommendation, but in it's current state, I'd rather recommend any reader to rather go play XCOM EW with long war mod or X-COM Apocalypse.Edit: It should be mentioned that XCOM 2 is far from a bad game. Also, some of the drawbacks of the game can be altered with mods like "Stop wasting my time", "True concealment" and "Shut up Bradford".  Review:  I've been looking forward to XCOM 2, while also dropping most of the PR about the game in it's developmentphase. The game adds an interesting continuation of the story from XCOM EU/EW and while the premises of the game is different from the endring of XCOM EU/EW, this is allowed for by events in the game. In XCOM 2, the aliens are in control and the remnants of the XCOM organization is in shambles and beeing hunted. Your task is to build up a strikeforce and connections around the world, work against the alien propaganda, discover what the aliens are up to and sabotage said plans.  Positives:  The premise of the game is positive. The aliens have conquered earth using overwhelming force, XCOM is shattered and the population is under strict control and anti-freedomfighter propaganda.Destructible terrain. I loved playing X-COM Apocalypse and beeing able to destroy pretty much anything, if needed or wanted. This is also the case in XCOM 2, where most terrain can be destroyed with either liberal use of ammunition or explosives.Use of explosives is slightly less punishing, as most enemies do not drop anything lootable. Research, base construction, gathering intel and research is quite intuitive with few quirks. It can be somewhat annoying having just starting checking out (scanning) a rumour, then having to fly to the other side of earth to do a mission, but that's part of the game.The game is mostly enjoyable and can become a decent addition to the XCOM / X-COM games, given proper mods or patches.   Negatives:  Insufficient quality assurance. a) Watching twitch streams and playing the final mission myself, the game may suddenly 'corrupt' in the last room, 		with visual artifacts and colors blooming and flickering. This bug makes it hard to concentrate on the (acid trip-looking) gameplay.b) The game may crash to desktop after killing the last required enemy on the final mission, in one instance causing a corrupt save.c) Overwatch shots may go through solid walls and hit.d) Melee attacks may occour through solid roofs or floors (vertical).e) Pull mechanics may go through multiple covers, visibly dragging the unfortunate soldier through.Constant nagging from Central, combined with loss of cameracontrol. This remains an issue even with the reduced v/o option.Constant delays after completing actions, e.g. heal a unit with a gremlin (drone) from far off, then watch as the gremlin slowly flies back to the operator. The loss of cameracontrol cannot be cancelled.Mods are great, but removing or adding mods can (or will) ruin your savegames. Considering mods can be withdrawn from the workshop, this can be an issue for ironman playthroughs.Accuracy. For some reason, standing in the tile next to a flanked muton gives less than a 100 % accuracy when using a shotgun.  In-betweens:  The player is limited to four classes, each consisting of skills divided into two subclasses. Stats like health, movement, aim, etc. are standardized and a soldier is simply given a class on promotion from rookie. Personalizing soldiers based on stats, e.g. making a high mobility assault/scout type soldier, is no longer an option. Personally, I found it giving to be able to select gear, classes and skills with stats and end results in the field in mind.The Psi-operative is nigh overpowered compared to the other classes.The concealment mechanic is interesting and allows for setting up ambushes or completing exfiltrationmissions almost without combat.Soldier panic can be chaotic. Soldiers can run to new cover and shoot or use items. This can lead to situations where the paniced soldier runs towards the main army of aliens and turns around and lobs a grenade toward an alien standing next to the rest of your soldiers. The result is no cover for your own guys, possible death and more panic, not to mention your paniced soldier possibly beeing exposed (thus dead). Drawing lines back to X-COM Apocalypse, simular actions could happen, as a paniced soldier would either freeze, start shooting at whatever was in front of him (including friendly fire) or run away from enemies. Personally, I find that a paniced soldier is too unpredictable in XCOM 2, as the friendly fire can be a bit over the top in a game where friendly fire is mainly a none-issue. It's a matter of taste.Turn limit. Most missions are limited by a max number of turns to complete the mission. This serves to give the player the feeling that the aliens at any minute may tumble down and create a full lockdown on the area, but in most cases, it makes little sense to activate the timer when the squad is concealed. For some reason, it's OK that it takes maybe 6 hours to fly to the mission, but somehow, you are limited by minutes from the minute your team hits the ground undetected.New mechanics have a tendensy to be stuffed down the player's gullet. Prime example is trying to kill a muton with a melee attack (specialty of the ranger), only to have said muton block and counterattack the ranger. I'm usually a fan of aliens beeing scary in itself, e.g. the popper, multiworm or brainsucker in Apocalypse, but I'm not a fan of counterattacks with no other possible counterplay than not ever using melee on said unit.Restart mission option if you fail the final mission, even with ironman activated. Why...?

number of helpful: 30 of 41 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19
												Dropping the tag of a covert ops group looking to defend Earth, XCOM 2 sees you reinvented as a Guerrilla fighter unit, battling an occupying force of Snake Men and robotic foes.Whereas before you had to enter the battlefield blind, XCOM 2 adds to the formula by providing you the chance of sneaking up on your enemy.Concealment acts as mode where you can avoid enemy fire and set up your own ambushes. It means you can take on a whole wave of foes and enjoy finishing them off in one foul swoop.The battle system remains the same, challenging players to move their fighters across blocks of movement spaces, finding cover to help them survive through the AI’s turn.From the start, it feels like you're against the clock, be it on the ground or in the air. The isometric battlefields throw-up procedurally generated maps and mission objectives, meaning the problem of constant grind has been dealt with quite effectively.XCOM 2 also does a good job of tying its story with real-world events, you must wreck Advent's plans at every turn to pushback the inevitable chaos that will consume humanity.Building the right rooms and facilities will mean reducing healing time, however that will also remove the chance of something else that could provide better weaponry. This gives rise to a multi-layered adventure that follows a different course each time you play. One thing you can never factor in, however, is luck.While the game does seem a little less random than Enemy Unknown, you are still faced with times of joy and frustration.Luckily, XCOM 2 single-player offers a great deal of content for its price tag and can make for quite a thrilling ride.THE GOOD- Great strategy and tactical layers- Command decisions makes each playthrough differentTHE BAD- Enemies sometimes ignore rules- Some performance issuesDISASTER | BAD | MEDIOCRE | OKAY | GOOD | GREAT | AMAZING | MASTERPIECE

												Quite simply the game is brilliant. The gameplay is super solid, it looks gorgeous, it plays very well, and it is one hell of a challenge. If you liked Firaxis's original XCOM, then you simply have to play this. They have improved practically on everything. This is just the best turn based game ever, and for me this is the best game of 2016! XCOM 2 is a worthy heir to the franchise and a refreshing script which makes us join the resistance against alien invaders. A very worthy investment indeed.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2016
												Going to be my first review on Steam, and sadly I can't make it a good one.I absolutely loved XCOM EU across PC and consoles and was really excited for this, but like other reviewers I encountered far too many bugs to fully enjoy the game.Specifically:- Terrible FPS no matter what settings- Game breaking glitches with objectives not allowing me to 'activate' them numerous times (this ruined an iron man run mid-game)- Animations not working (Seems to be triggered by soldiers falling through a ceiling after an explosion)- Important effects not appearing (AOE attacks from enemies especially had no area markers so I had no idea where was safe on my next turn)- Ocasionally had a totally unresponsive game (Not frozen, but not reacting to any commands)- Soldier perk bugs including the game becoming unresponsive when I used combinations of abilities, but was 'fixable' by skipping my turn in that case... I lost a lot of soldiers that way!- Broken/buggy action cam; The game would often zoom to a seemingly random part of the map while a soldier took an overwatch shot, for example- Moves taking up to & around 20 seconds to register as completeIt goes on and on. Definitely avoid this game for some time. I took a chance pre-ordering after promising myself that Arkham knight would be my last, because I loved the previous XCOM.To make matters worse I went away for a week just after the game came out, and was looking forward to a patch when I got back - I came home to a hotfix that made things noticably worse and at the time of writing there is still no patch three weeks after release.Another one for the VERY long list of broken/lazy releases over the last year :((Playing with an OC'd i74770K and a GeForce 980ti)EDIT: I've been playing the game more since the patch and am happy to say that it has resolved almost all of my issues - The game looks, plays and runs SO much better.I'm not going to change this to a positive review, since clearly the game was not ready for release and I'm pretty tired of these non-stop sloppy releases. But, I'd be happy to recommend this to XCOM fans now - minus a few questionable design choices it's a solid game at last!

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												I can't recommend this game.  It's no longer a strategy game, just a race against XCOM's legendary rage-inducing RNG.There's so much here to build on, and that's part of that makes this so disappointing.  There's a great stealth mechanic...that you can't use because of the turn timer, so you blow it on the opening group of enemies you see.  It's neat, fun to play with for a few (failed) missions, then you leave it alone because the turn timer invalidates a piece of great design.There's awesome classes with neat abilities...except sharpshooters are worthless since using them like the sniper they're supposed to be means that you lose them when the evac timer runs out.  Once again, the turn timer invalidates another piece of some really good class/game design.You could always counter the whims of the RNG in XCOM: EU/EW by playing safe with overwatch and setting up a good sniper position, and you can see the design intent to stop that with the turn timer.  But that turn timer coupled with the whimsical RNG turns the game from a "series of interesting decisions" into a series of bad ones and worse ones.It's really close to being the GOTY candidate so many reviewers are making it out to be.  But without a balance pass, it's just an overengineered race against a timer full of nigh-impossible missions.  Any strategy is invalidated by the timer, so you just roll your shots and hope they hit, because if they don't, you're dead.This is XCOM.  They don't hit often enough to stop you from dying.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
												This game alone is enough to make the year 2016 an awesome PC gaming year. What an amazing turn-based strategy game, with a staggering amount of nice character customization (especially with Steam Workshop mods). If you liked XCOM: Enemy Unknown, you will like this even more. If you never played the first one, you will still like this one. With a full mod support from the moment of release, and with the SDK now available, the game will have an extremely high replay value. We already have tons of great mod content, and its only getting better. Highly recommended to any and all friends of turn-based strategy games! If I believed in numeric ranking, this would be a solid 9/10.Why not 10/10? My personal complaints:- The game has some serious performance problems: with i7-3770k, 16GB RAM, GTX 970 and played from a 250GB Samsung EVO 850 SSD, @1440p or @1080p and medium/high settings (won't matter much), the game will average to about 35-50fps, will constantly drop below 25fps, sometimes even below 15fps(!). Lowering quality and/or resolution won't help much, so the problem is deep in the game. Holding steady 60fps is very rare.  This must be fixed ASAP! In its current condition, I'd say many gamers will lose their freakin' minds over this.- late game content seems a bit unstable. I had 3 crashes during the last 4-5 hours of the game.- EDIT: Stop Wasting My Time mod helps on this. "SHUT UP CENTRAL!" mod would be amazing! Im tired of that guy saying the same things over and over again, always cutting me off from my game. Why can't I just keep playing while that guy talks ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t? Stop cutting my game off!- timed missions are partly great, but they have not been well developed here. A single mod made all the difference: mission timer start only when your team is revealed from concealment. This way you can play much more strategically, and without rushing like an idiot on some missions.

Posted: June 9, 2016
												I just thought about writing an overall positive review on XCOM 2, but still mentioning all issues the game has, but I won't because I'm getting tired of constant crashes and so called "patches" since the game is still unstable and I have seen multiple crashes during the loading screen. The interesting part is that, the day before I wrote this review, this game worked fine without any major issues (not counting some FPS drops here and there and long loading times) and I have a lot of mods in this game. Say what ever you want, but this game has a weird way of working at sometimes and other times it doesn't for any particular reason. So, I decided to mention some of the most serious issues that are (including the DLC content) in this game to warn everyone what they are going to experience during the playthrough.*Long loading times*Random FPS drops*Multiple crashes during loading screens (I feel sorry for those who play with Ironman on)*Cutscenes with audio playing before the video itself (really??!!!, couldn't you just do a pre-rendered cutscene video and audio at the same file instead of this)*Occasional bulls**t logic in game like: -Enemies dodging fire when stunned or frozen -Time limits even though the enemy doesn't know you are there (can be fixed with mods, thank god....) -Alien ruler reactions; one action = ruler gets one action too (because soldiers can't run from the danger at the same time)*All these performance issues for a PC exclusive (and now they are going to release console versions, thx for the announcement Firaxis, we really appreciate it.....)*Situations where there is invisible cover or no cover at all in the most obvious places, so the game is buggy tooAnd even though some of the issues could be fixed by downloading unofficial patches from the Steam Workshop, it's still possible that some of them could make the game performance even worse and admittedly I'm not an expert on these things, but thats just what I think.(Also apologies if my review has any grammar mistakes)

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												First off the pros of the game.1. Very flush gameplay that looks great when playing on all 8 cylinders. 2. A truely different system that feels less punishing than EU's council did.3. Well people may or may not agree. The game is a hell of alot easier in the begining than EU.Now the Cons. 1.Poorly otomized. I partipated in the Devision Beta that game had cutting edge graphics that would put this game to shame yet this game lags regardless how much I lower the video settings. Cut scenes lag, game lags randomly, it will go choppy without warning ruining much of the game's fun.2. Narative is almost non existant. Forget being an unpopular narative to begin with. At no point is't the story really told of what excactly went wrong in the first game. You just have one cutscene with the chip being removed and the Archives have almost no information. Just fluff Inomation that I think was copy pasted from a fan site. To eleborate on this the characters all act like you already know what's going on. No "Okay this is what happened and how we got here." It's litterally "Welcome back. Let's get to work." 3. Even less customization than EU with soldiers. Yes you heard me correctly. Less. One thing I loved about EU was that the soldiers would speak in their national languages. Forget the fact Asian soldiers from Japan and China somehow speak English with an New York Accent. There's even less languages represented then before. And for some reason the toggle for the Soldiers to speak their own national languages doesn't work. You have to manually choose their language. 4. The procedurally generated maps.. Seems to be a lie. Do not chew me out for this one. But On my first play through I gotten the same excact map 5 times. Do not get me wrong but wasn't that the big deal with this game? It's one step forward then 20 steps backwards.5. Hostile social Justice Warrior Moderators on the discussions section for this game. Well not technically part of the game itself. The 2k moderators on the disscussions are the worst I have ever seen. Openly hostile and abusive of the rules in place. People are banned for critizing the game's premise. Which if you read number 2 turned out to still be a problem. They're banned for asking questions or just plain saying any part of the game is something they don't like. Some of the moderators even would start arguring with people just so they can ban them even if the person they started arguring with never actually responded to or acknowledge them. One of the moderators I want the personal adress for since what he did was technically criminal threatening. The people you leave in charge of your discussions boards for a game do infact represent your game studio, game and brand. How buggy is the game so far? Well as a person who plays Bethsoda games. I have to say atleast Bethosada games are playable at launch.Update: Just beat the game. I now seek a refund. And to retract earlier made statements.1. The game is less forgiving then prior. The Avatar Project system artifically jacks up the difficulty. The Majority of Missions are timed. There's is too kinds of difficult when it comes to a video game. Frustrating and challenging. Darksouls is a Challenging game. This game is Frustrating. Frustrating due game breaking bugs. Bugged Animations. Missing cutscenes all over the place. Get used to Blackscreens.2. Clear intention to make terror from the Deep style sequel.  Ending cutscene as well as others lack luster. To sum it up violence in the ending cutscene is censored. No satisfying seeing a mob of baseball bat armed civilians bashing an Advent Trooper's face in. Just cuts away with it implied. Seriously we can slash in the game shoot things in the fact Civilians included. But god forbid an angry mob be portrayed accurately at the victory screen. Also that annoying speaker guy there's a cut scene where the truth is displayed and a mob rushes in to beat the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of him. Again cuts out and you never see the satisfying boot to the face from an angry mob. 3. Balance is very poor. Some of the toughest enemies release early in the game while the easiest release towards the end. What do I mean? Sectopods realrease very very early into the game. Long before you see the Bioshook knock off guys. 4. Victory screen bugs. Just a box saying "Collecting server stats." Which will sit there until you hit cancel and contine. 5. The set up for this game forces you to rush everything removing much of the strategy element. Oh poorly equiped and niether anything better than a couple of squadies with one gun attachment no equipment upgrades? Well you better figure out how your gonna destroy those two facilities in under a turn or you auto lose the game.6. Can't pick starting location? That's something I liked about EU. You could pick your HQ location. Here.. Not at all. It's random. You just gotta start over and over and over and over until by the grace of the RNG Gods you get the location you want. By the way continet bonsues still a thing so it's not just a flavor thing.But the most annoying bug. It crashes on shut downs. Often! You'd think shutting down a game would be an easy feat anyone can master. Apparently not. If I'm done with the game half the time I have to edit game setting make it windowed so that if it crashes I don't have to manually restart my computer. I am unsatisfyed having beat the game. Hell the DLC never once makes an appearance if you paid for it. Other than the stupid Resistance style armor pack. Which does not cover anything past starting gear. I never gotten that veteran soldier. Even with the increased customization options.. Customization is far less than EU. I will now seek a Refund. Anyone else disappointed in this game I'd recomend do the same.

I look forward to this game when that happens. Until then, fix your product Firaxis, we'll be watching.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												As it often happens with games that go crazy on marketing, the core game is very frustrating.The computer "cheats", and all the bad from the first X-Com came back and enhanced.The good: -Some cool ideias with base design and facilities. -More lore about the auxiliary characters.-Very few bugs so far (wich means that the comp cheating is intended)The bad:-Free move. The computer always get a free move. No matter what. This removes any try of the game to be a turn based strategy, and become just a Human vs bad AI game with "challenge" added by cheats like free movements.-Time counters on every mission. If you hated the first game when you had X turns to do something, well, now you have this on EVERY mission. No strategy, no sense (cause most of time you take days to reach mission site but exaclty 10 turns befora a bomb explode... wow, super awesome for some 6 year old)- It took like 2 hours to get the first chance to edit a soldier or modify your base... 2 hours being told to click here and click there. Again, 6 year old tutorial that bore you after 10 minutes.- Huge loading screens.This game isnt a turn based strategy. Its more like a rogue-like rush game. You will die randomly. The comp cheats. The same rule that aply to your forces dont aply to the enemy, this kindo of thing that essentially destroy a turn based strategy game. Seems like the game was designed to make you go, rush around dying just to see the layout of the map and where the enemies are, then load the game from the start of  the map and go the perfect route to ambush the enemies with overwatch. If you try to ambush them by shooting, they get the free "nonsense bad design" move and go to cover before your second soldier can shoot. But if they get you in the open, they all shoot and kill before you can react, cheap cheating is cheap.The game isnt a complete fairule and i would wait a little for modders to make the game people really want to play, my only concern is the timers, since all missions are designed about this stupid "blitz mode, no thinking" timers, even if a mod remove them, many dialogues would make no sense. Everymission there is a bomb, a trap, or a incoming something, that you need the timer... awesome diversity i must say, by the third mission i was so dissapointed by the timer that i kept playing just to try to see where the stories go.If you like this kind of rush game, go ahead, if you like strategy, this game isnt for you.Edit after playing to the last mission:Added bad:- buggs everywhere, and sometime is even dificult do know if is a bug or intended. Bugged exactly on the LAST hit of the last mission after 3 hours playing the mission. 3 wasted our of my life.- Scum save game. This game is simpe: No strategy as posted aboved, complete save and load game. After scumsaving every mission, i ended each mission with about the hit rate i would have if the game engine of random numbers wasnt broken. I take most of my shots at 75% chance, without scumsaving, at the end of a mission i hit like 40% of the shots, after scumsaving i get around 70 to 80%! so i am not  even saving and loading to make everyshot hit, but you have to scumsave just to make the game behave as the aim % say it would behave!After all this time trashed on this game, i probably will play last mission again just to see the end, but the game is SO unfun to play that i am really have to make a effort to play again. Bore repetition with scumsaving around.Cant recommend  the game. Probably will be much better with 16 y.o. modders showing a professional company how to make a game. Wait for like 3 or 4 months and try again, thats my recomendation.I was really disappointed when they insisted on make a game disregarding all X-COM EU final, fanboys kept telling me to wait for the game... you have to be REALLY a fanboy to like the game in the current state.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												It is unacceptable to release a AAA game in such a buggy and unoptimized state. Is it playable? Sure. However, the constant slowdowns (even at reduced graphics settings), animation bugs, floating heads (armor doesnt load on background characters), and camera bugs definitly take away from the experience. It is very clear to me that the publisher said screw the polish, just release it. It's been several days now and still no patch to fix any of these issues. $60-$75 for what? A bunch of reused assets on a three year old engine? AND it doesnt run perfectly? Thats what really bothers me.Is XCOM2 better than the last one? Yeah, the game mechanics fit the setting a lot better. The world map is more interesting, even though it just feels like im playing a cheap board game. Is it worth the price they are asking? sadly, no. I should not have bought this, you'd be better served just waiting for the 'complete' version for 10 bucks. If you are lucky, by then it'll run properly.Update:Still no patch... finished the game regardless. Spoilers ahead, you've been warned: I have to say i'm all around a bit dissapointed with the story. It's so linear, nothing interesting happens, no betrayals even if the side commentary keeps hinting at certain characters not being trustworthy. No twists. The idea of the Avatar project feels ripped off from mass effect2. Then it all ends with an episode of dragon ball. I have to wonder, did they not hire any writers? Did they let the intern write the story? I'm thinkin so.Update2:So it's been about a month, and still no 'real' patch from the devs. Game is still a mess, and they've done a good job here making me regret supporting one of my favorite franchises. Pathetic.Update3:Finally a patch. While it does fix some issues and speed up the game play, it also lowers the gfx. Can't seem to re-enable them either, game is noticeably uglier. Pretty lazy, clearly they didn't want to spend time to optimize the game engine and just nerfed it instead. Still Pathetic.

												Preamble: A bad review is not "unhelpful" just because YOU like the game, Fanboi. ;) If you feel you could add something that helps other users to decide weather to buy or not, pls. use the comments. Edit: This hilarious video perfectly depicts the problem I have with the game. It's not too hard. It's too unpredictable. That's a huge difference for a tactical game.


Xcom in a Nutshell [SFM] 
A Video of XCOM 2
By: Admiral General Dictator

			My experience with Xcom to this day Music: Xcom 2 OST - Retaliation		


Now the original review:It's really hard to say "no" here, because I liked XCOM Enemy Unknown, but this one feels more like gambling. There are a lot of glitches that let you say "WTF" constantly.The Good:- it IS fun for a while- dense atmosphere- all good aspects of Enemy Unknown/Within still there- nice character classes, loadouts, customization- new aspects on strategic play on the world mapThe Bad:- the unpredictable hit probability now hurts with the more powerful enemies, example   * trying to hit a flanked sectoid from the very next square with a gatling, 63%   * aiming an enemy from behind cover = 62%, advancing to half distance, no cover, enemy in front = 70%. Yes, half distance and leaving cover brings a plus of 8% for an uncovered enemy.   * and so on and so on and so on- hit or miss, so missing an 98% enemy on the very next field with the gatling = zero damage instead of reduced damage (this was also an issue on the other XCOM games, but now this is reaaaally painful, because you must not miss!!)- often the pace is too high, both in tactical (often need to rush because of turn countdown) and strategic (several events a day, right from the start, you don't get into it)All that comes out to gambling. Even if you did everything right when it comes to tactics, you just need one single bad dice roll and you have a killed team mate or even a catastrophe. The game recommends "veteran" level (second level) for players with XCOM experience, but this only works with a lot of save and reload for me. Far away from Iron Man.So, if you like the gambling factor in a tactical game, this is for you.

number of helpful: 48 of 76 people (63%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
XCOM 2I was a newcomer to the XCOM series, picking up Enemy Within during the summer sale last year. I was quickly engrossed by the game's mechanics, and when I found out a sequel had been announced I knew I'd have to jump on it. With two DLC packs and a cosmetic add-on released now, as well as several patches, I believe it's just about time to take an in-depth look at the latest product of Firaxis Games.GraphicsThe most apparent improvement in XCOM 2 is the graphics. XCOM: Enemy Unknown had a distinct art style, but it didn't appeal much to me and the game itself also just didn't look that great because of its low level of detail. There are almost no such issues here. Your troops have realistic proportions, their weapons are properly sized, and the models and textures themselves have improved greatly. This extends to your opponents, as well; each of which receive a fantastic face-lift. The animations are relatively fluid, and XCOM 2 also offers a host of new customization options for making every XCOM trooper feel just a little more unique and personal. The environments are also much more detailed than they were before. Utopian cityscapes maintain an eerie sterility, which contrasts with the wilderness of the cold wastelands of Siberia and the unbearable heat of the Sahara. XCOM 2 definitely earns itself some praise here, and really raises the bar in its genre, even if it isn't groundbreaking.


XCOM 2 
A Screenshot of XCOM 2
By: Blaster🎃




AudioAnother big improvement in presentation over Enemy Unknown for XCOM 2, audio design has been greatly enhanced. Each environment features appropriate ambient sounds, adding to the suspense before you engage. Your enemies all have unique responses to whatever situation they're presented with, from the hiss of a Sectoid to the Earth-shattering stomp of a Sectopod. XCOM's own weapons all sound satisfying, and there are a variety of options for your troopers' voices. Voice acting is of similar quality to that found in Enemy Unknown; while I hoped for an improvement it is still perfectly acceptable. Perhaps one of my favorite parts of Enemy Unknown was the soundtrack, and I am once again greatly impressed by XCOM 2. Every track is splendid, from the suspenseful main menu score to the theatrical combat music. Timothy Wynn's work definitely doesn't disappoint, and XCOM 2's soundtrack stands up nicely alongside that of Enemy Unknown.PerformanceI'm afraid that this is going to have to be the low point of the review. XCOM 2 still doesn't perform well, even on a PC that exceeds the recommended requirements by a great deal. It's very unfortunate that this game suffers from such lackluster performance, as it drags down an otherwise well-rounded performance from Firaxis Games. The 30 frames per second I maintain is simply unacceptable given my hardware; there's no excuse for it, and there's even less of an excuse for the 10 frames per second I maintain on the Geoscape map. With that said, I haven't had many issues with crashing, but there are some bugs and glitches that have yet to be officially fixed. These aren't game-breaking in my experience, but they are very annoying. Fortunately, there are a variety of modifications on the Workshop which address almost all of these issues, but I would expect an official patch by now.GameplayXCOM 2 shares many gameplay elements with its predecessor, Enemy Unknown, as you might expect. It is a turn-based tactics game focusing on the control of multiple troopers, and each of them have their own unique equipment and abilities. The game uses a two-moves-per-turn system; every unit has two available actions, and moving any amount within a radial area consumes one movement point; typically, activating abilities consumes one or two movement points, and firing always ends that unit's turn. This comes together very well, and makes for a game that is in-depth enough to excite while not being overly complex. There is a line-of-sight system which is used to reveal enemies and parts of the map, and a variety of units to choose from. These include ordinary humans, cloned government troopers, XCOM's own version of the krogan, xenomorph-like arachnoids, and massive bipedal robots. With this variety, it will take some time before one becomes bored of the game's cast.


XCOM 2 
A Screenshot of XCOM 2
By: JIM RAYNOR




SingleplayerThe singleplayer campaign of XCOM 2 places you in the shoes of the illusive Commander, a faceless strategic genius in charge of the XCOM organization. This time around, you eschew the underground command center in favor of a massive VTOL supply spacecraft, the Avenger. This mobile base completely overhauls the strategic world map, known as the Geoscape, forcing you to manage your resources carefully since the nations of the world have capitulated to the alien menace, ADVENT. You'll face these human enemies more often than not, but after you escalate and take the fight to ADVENT's strongholds, you'll encounter aliens more and more. Missions are similar to those of Enemy Unknown, but some enforce a turn limit before the mission fails, which is both challenging and aggravating. There are more ways to customize troops than before, as the classes from Enemy Unknown are replaced by five new ones. New technology and stat-boosting items provide various bonuses to troopers, giving players the edge they need to destroy ADVENT and incite a worldwide uprising. The singleplayer keeps you on your toes and threatens you with destruction, from start to finish. Most players will spend most of their time here, as it is the focus of the game.MultiplayerXCOM 2 also features multiplayer, which allows for players to assemble a cadre of troops from both ADVENT, alien, and XCOM forces, with similar abilities to those of singleplayer units. There are a handful of map types to choose from, but the big issue with multiplayer is the lack of options. The adversarial gamemode quickly becomes uninteresting, and other ways to play would greatly improve the game. One idea is singleplayer gamemodes being introduced to multiplayer; one player must defend an objective, the other must destroy it; perhaps one player is attempting to defend a stronghold of civilian units against another. No matter how you look at it, more variety is needed for multiplayer, and as a result you probably won't spend a ton of time on it.Community ContentXCOM 2 earns fantastic praise here. A full suite of development tools, workshop integration, and bringing the Long War modding team in to work with Firaxis on XCOM 2 modding features shows how dedicated the developers were in their integration of community content support. Take one look at the workshop and you can already see a fantastic variety of modifications: New enemies to give you an even bigger challenge. A total overhaul to how the game is played, making it more like the previous XCOM games. A new weapon tier, or new weapon classes. And a host of new trooper voices and customization options, to scratch whatever science fiction itch you have. This plays a big part in my recommendation of the game.


XCOM 2 
A Screenshot of XCOM 2
By: imaginee




VerdictXCOM 2 is definitely a worthy sequel to the previous reboot, Enemy Unknown. While it takes a few steps back with features compared to the Enemy Within expansion, its community content support takes many more forward. It changes enough to justify its purchase without changing too much from the XCOM formula, and once again sets the gold standard for the turn-based tactics genre. Though they might be put off by the performance issues, fans of strategy and tactics, as well as those who enjoy Sid Meier's Civilization V, are sure to enjoy this title.I would recommend XCOM 2, but would suggest waiting for a sale.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2016
												Save your money. My experience with this game is rather like most people, even Gollop's: several weeks and haven't managed a win yet. Or rather, I've lost the game to a ******* timer. - Strategic tasks like resource gathering and contacting new zones take far too long and don't leave much time for actually combating the alien threat.- The only game I've ever played that punishes you for doing what it presents as something you should be doing. That is: researching or spending time and resources on anything that isn't related to main quest. No matter how many missions I succeed in, I am always behind the curve. If I'm investing resources in Soldier upgrades, new technologies, or black market purchases, I risk losing the game (months before I actually know for certain that I've lost).- Why is the monthly paycheck only in supplies? Does no one have intel to share? This would help alleviate the above. Also, the XCOM Spokesman rewards me with supplies, but I have to spend 3 days picking them up? That's 1/10th of my time every month.- We are overcharged for using Overwatch. Example: Soldier uses an action at T+0 to set Overwatch. Enemy movement occurs, and Soldier fires a shot. At T+1, this Soldier has _NO TURN_. Presumably, the Soldier spent the previous round's action point on Overwatch and they should have two actions the next round like anyone else. Right? Nope. Frozen, and probably in need of ammo.- AVATAR PROJECT. No. At least in the real XCOM games you could continue to struggle against the alien menace until they were mercilessly dismantling the XCOM Project, fighter craft and soldiers and base facilities all. You were given the opportunity to fight and a slim chance to win. XCOM2 gives you a set timeline, and some opportunities to push it back, but your loss is guaranteed unless you research what you're "supposed to" research, are fortunate with your zone expansion choices, and neglect to pursue what are presented as strategic/combat advantages. It's an I win button for the PC, and a very inelegant design "solution" for summarily ending a playthrough based not on the player's actual failures but rather on what the designer felt would create a sense of urgency.My interest in future products from this developer/director is nil.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												There are a lot of improvements on this game that could make it more enjoyable than XCOM enemy unknown. Character custimization, weapon mods, melee combat, stealth mode and a cool story line for example.  However, the addition of so many timed missions completely ruin the game for me.  I really enjoyed xcom enemy unkown's turn based tactical shooting style and expected the same from this game. Every move of every turn required planning, for both that character and the squad as a whole.  Having a strategy to tackle the mission was essential along with the ability to adapt to unkown enemies that you didn't see.   Instead, the timed missions of XCOM 2, which seem to make up the overwhelming majority of missions, force you to play a blitz style game.  Your only option is to make the shortest route possible to the mission objective in which you are forced to make long range movement, puting your characters into positions of disadvantage, and efffectively removing any type of tactical strategy from the game.  Let me be clear, my complaint isn't that the game is too hard, it's that the developer's have completely and utterly changed the game from a tactical shooter to a run and gun style game that i think they hope will compete with the more fast paced first person shooters. All in an effort to attract a new generation of 12 year olds who don't have the attention span to enjoy anything but a call of duty style game.  The rushed gameplay style ruins any other good aspect of this game.  I strongly reccomend you spend your money on somehting else, I wish i had.

number of helpful: 31 of 46 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17
												I have loved this series since the original, and I especially loved the previous XCOM installment for PC. It modernized the gameplay of the original and kept alive the feeling of saving the world with the power of good planning, management, strategy and combat tactics. You could choose your path, to an extent, and there wasn't always one clear "best" decision to make.  XCOM 2 removes all of that.There is always only one clear goal to accomplish, and only one way to get there. All of your choices are limited by this. For example...You have to raid the facility. To raid the facility, you first have to contact the region.To contact the region, you first have to contact the region in front of it.To contact that region, you have to build a comms facility.To build the comms facility, you have to clear out debris and collect resources.So all of the management decisions from XCOM are gone now; In XCOM 2 you're just checking off bullet points and jumping through hoops when they appear. Overall you'll generally feel like you're catching up and not in control.As for the combat, it is much less balanced. It is sometimes boringly easy and sometimes frustratingly unfair. For instance many of the enemies you encounter have mind control and/or instant knockout abilities that can take your team members out of the battle instantly and unexpectedly WAY too easily and way too early in the game. They don't even have to take advantage of your poor planning; Sectoids only need one turn of line of site to ruin your entire team. All it take is for them to successfully take control of a melee ranger or a grenadier and you're doomed.The challenge level and randomness of this game feel like they'd be more appropriately suited for your average indie roguelike. You're always one die roll away from a disaster that will make your progress essentially doomed. This feels out of place in such a large-scale AAA game and it really adds to the feeling of lack of control. It's all up to the dice and you'll find yourself quitting or save-scumming way too often. There's never a sense of balanced challenge to be found; just success or disaster with nothing in between.

												Xcom 2 was not a very fun game to play. The game starts out with a very "do the right thing" feeling behind it, but that just hides the fact that is a retexured mod with birthday candles on top. The new "stealth" aspect looks like it had no work really put into it. The missions where you start without stealth are the ones where you are stealthier. Guerrlla missions are like the Exalt missions from Enemy Within, the DLC to Xcom Enemy Unknown, except you get punished for making sure your guys dont get ambushed (e.g. Overwatching). At least 80%, not inflating that number, of the missions I ran were timed where you had to exfil (aka leave) the mission in 6-12 turns or congrats! You lost all your best guys, woo. Not spoiling anything, but even the campain is timed. Instead of Enemy Unknown there no "Saving who you want" and Helping to reduce panic. Nope the game just says straight up "You're Doomed" and hands you a peice of swiss cheese and says its a sail boat. But dont worry! I am not 100% negitive, there are  more customizations for your solders than there are colors of paint at a hardware store. That way when you loose each mission and squad after squad gets wiped, at least they looked FABULOUS!   The movement system is all kinds of wonky, but still the only improvment over Enimy Unknown,  The aiming got worse, somehow . The new Ranger class is an example, The 60% with a shotgun RIGHT next to an enemy will hit more often than the 91% with the sword. I'll be straight with ya now, honestly wait until it goes on sale, or a mod that fixes the "bugs" in the game.  Buyer Beware.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												Better than the previous 'new' XCOM but obviously there are plenty of issues in game mechanics. The enemies still know when you see them and the ridiculous reaction move is still in place. The cover system is pretty much as bad as it was in the previous game and even though many guns shoot bursts it can always count only as a single attack. Also you apparently can't hit wrong enemies by accident. Corpse reanimation via psi powers is an instant action and seemingly requires noi 'maintenance' by the the one doing the resurrection. Also all reinforcement actions are poorly 'translated' into turn based environments. At times when you look all the things that happen you can safely say your team is having a nap while the enemies do strange chains of actions.So in essence this game pretty much has all the flaws I expected it to have and for now I haven't seen that many improvements over the last version. There are some small tweaks in functionality but for now I have completed only a couple of missions so there are still plenty of things to discover.Is the game currently worth the full price? No, not really. I suppose some issues may get an official fix and mods will probably fix some others so this game has a fair potential. Even as it is the game seems to be reasonably enjoyable but the actual game mechanics seem to be on par with the most simple board games ever created.Edit: Started out with a recommendation but now that I have played more the game just feels so unbelievably scripted. Ammo clips also don't last very long as these 'soldiers' spray and pray all the time. There are no single shots for most weapons, meaning that even your more senior officers will act like total rookies to the end of time. Also movement rate for everything is far too great compared with the other things you can do. Also firing a weapon ends the turn for that soldier. You can run before moving if you like but you can't do it the other way around. This game getting over 90 points is just ridiculous and 80 would be a far more accurate.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												Coming from a guy who spent more than 200 hours on the game, a negative review is perhaps quite weird, but here's what I think as of now:+map generation, you will never play the same map twice, altought you will see some identical areas on different maps+mods, lots of mods available-Performance, the game just looks like the old enemy unknown with somewhat sharper textures, but whereas the old game ran silky smooth on my machine, this one has a bad framerate on anything but lowest settings-Bugs, in a game where iron man is pretty much is "the way it's meant to be played", there are way too many bugs. Enemy unknown did have some, but I never observed them in my 147 hours in that game. Various bugs in this one includes not being able to open a door, smoke grenades not working properly, an enemy visually appearing in the wrong location on the map compared to where he actually was, an enemy going under the map and making me unable to win the mission, an enemy attacking through a closed door, and two enemies who both "cloned" themselves upon death, so that they efffectively took no damage despite my soldiers hitting them and triggering a death animation on both-You cannot develop a particular type of ammo/grenade/heavy weapon/armor vest, if you try to develop ammo you just get one out of 5 possible types at random, if you try to develop a grenade you get one out of 3 possible types at random etc.-Concealment, where your soldiers start the map in a "stealth mode", it just makes the enemies extreme short-sighted, until you blow your cover and they magically gain long-sight. You can run almost right in front of them and they won't notice when you're in stealth mode.-Assault class in EU, who relied on it's shotgun, has been replaced with this ninja class who has a shotgun, but also relies heavily on a sword, and can act as a scout. The sword in my opinion doesn't fit in the game. Having a scout is very useful, but also a very boring way to play-Sniper class in EU has been replaced with a revolver cowboy class who also carries a sniper rifle. This class is designed to attack multiple enemies in the same turn, rather than focus on important enemies. Doesn't fit in the game.-Panic, is better than EU, but still not good enough. Your soldiers won't start killing their friends at random like in EU, but they will run randomly towards the enemy, into a position with inferior cover. Makes no sense whatsoever.-Psionic units are now a class of their own. You train them not by using them in combat, but by having them sit in a training room in your base. Boring.-The combination of turn timer, some really dangerous enemies, and some really strong soldier abilities, makes the tactic of "destroy the enemy pods on the same turn the engage you" the only viable tactic. If you can pull it off properly the enemies won't even have the chance to attack you, which isn't much fun. Colonel rank soldiers are too strong. Lancers and shield bearers are a big pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ Sectoids may sometimes be easy to deal with, but in early game you may have bad luck and lose a soldier to mind control. You are forced into carrying flashbangs to counter this, as it is the only reliable counter. Turn timers are the least problem as they can be fixed with mods.-Very armored enemies, like sectopods, force you to bring a heavy gunner on every mission, in order to deal with the armor, or alternatively equipping many soldiers with armor piercing rounds. Limits your options, not fun.-Poor enemy design. The sectoids in EU have become humans with weird jaws, the thin men have become snakes with boobs, the floaters have become some sort of statue with a built-in jetback. The avatars are just humans with glasses and funky hairstyle. The advent troops are humans who speak in a different language. Codex is a yellow human. The andromedon and the gatekeeper are good and alien-like, but they are the only ones.-The futuristic style of houses, vehicles, street lights, fences, etc, are uninspired, and doesn't give the game much of an atmosphere. It also lacks the mystery surrounding the aliens. Much unlike enemy unknown, that game had great atmosphere. Overall: xcom 2 fixed the issues with enemy unknown, in that you don't have to replay maps, and that you can add and change a lot with mods. But they messed up almost everything else.edit: actually I can think of another positive: the level destruction in the game is great. most objects, including floors/roofs, can be destroyed.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												What can I say, I love XCom.But I have to admit this one is just a bridge to short for me.  Wasn't a fan when they shrunk squad size in Xcom 1 (Reboot) but it was still a good game. This one is also not a "Bad" game, but I am coming to the conclusion it isn't my kind of game.While I love alot of the mechanical changes, concealment, new overwatch mechanics, assignable engineers and scientist, ect. ect. The thing that is killing me most is almost every god damn mission has a turn limit. You are almost always up against some kind of clock. And for me that just kills the tactical aspect of the game.Just turned off the game due to getting a guerilla mission that only gave me 8 turns to reach the objective. Took 3 of those turns just to reach sight of the objective and to get positioned before I broke concealment. But then as Soon as I broke concealment I ended up facing 9 enemies almost immediately. With only a 4 man squad I just can't bring enough firepower to bear without save scrumming. Even when I save scrummed hard enough and accepted losing a guy and taking wounds across the board on the rest to complete the mission with 2 turns to spare. As soon as the last guy went down the dropped reinforcments down right on top of me. And that was the final straw.Now I won't say I am a truly gifted player. Tried Ironman mode in Xcom 1 and will freely admit it was to much for me. But I am no slouch when it comes to strategy games. But it feels like they really went over the top on forcing you to constantly scramble in this version and it really detracts from what I see as the tactical puzzle solving aspect that I have come to love from the franchise.Maybe if the Long War team does a version for XCom 2 like they did for Xcom 1 I'll give it another go.  That mod team made Xcom 1 the game it really was meant to be.

number of helpful: 302 of 541 people (56%) found this review helpful61 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												This game once again vindicates my resolution to never buy a game at release. I made the mistake of not holding to that with XCOM 2 because I loved the predecessor so much and I promptly got punished for it.In short, XCOM  2 is a great game which improves on XCOM in multiple small ways so if you liked the first one, you will probably LOVE the second.BUT it has so many bugs and technical problems atm that imo it should not had been released when it did. None of the bugs I encountered was game breaking, but there are so many small annoyances mounting up that I almost put it away on multiple occasions out of sheer exasperation.The game is still great, don't you believe otherwise. But if you successfully avoided the preorder trap, wait a little longer until they have all (or at least most of) the bugs fixed. You'll get a much less tarnished experience and will enjoy the game a lot more without minutes long loading times, clipping errors, sound cutting out etc.I am sorry to say, I cannot reccommend buying this game at this point in time.Edit: Rejoice, for I have been shown the way. I has been made clear to me, that I wrote my review in blatant disregard of the intellectually challenged of our esteemed colleagues out there. But fear not! You just have the one braincell and nothing to rub it against to make it spark? I will take you through it step by step.Since you read this review, I am assuming that you have not yet bought the game. If you did, what are you doing here? Go play it, it is a good game!I spent a three digit number of hours in this game, yes. Did I enjoy that time? Yes.... mostly. But I spent almost double that amount on XCOM and far less moments where I wanted to punch through my screen and exactly zero minutes contemplating a critical review.So assuming you did NOT buy the game yet. From the top of my mind, there are two reasons I can think of why.A) You desperately want it, but are broke. And while scrounging the money together, you amuse yourself by reading about how good this game is, trampling its enemies into the dust, grinding their bones for your bread and♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥on their graves. Yay you! Good for you, everybody needs a hobby, I guess.B) You wanted to see if the game is worth your money and your time. For you, I wrote this review. Is the game worth it?That depends, do you want a really good game (yes it IS good as my hours can easily testify, even if you subtract the idling time) NOW? Or do you want a great game in about half a year (where realistically at least a few bugs will have been worked out and it will probably have already been on a first 10% sale)?Chocolate bar now or tub of ice cream later? What I am saying here is that in retrospect, I should have waited for the ice cream. But hey, it's your decision in the end.Still not getting my point? Go pester your mom, she (hopefully) can explain it to you.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												Summary: Rushed and shockingly bad sequel to the excellent xcom Pro: um, art design?Con: Randomness from the distance to your timed objective to the foes you face determines how well you doCon: Fake stealth that roadblocks you at the first mob you seeCon: ANNOYING run around and wait world mapCon: No real attempt at balance, I mean, shock trooper.Con: Short, limited more like a bad expansion packCon: No controller support like the previous title Con: Runs poorlyCon: Major bugs (faceless roof collapse double move bug)Con: Boring class choicesA game suffering with design issues. It's both too easy and yet too difficult due to cheap enemy abilites added late in development to artifically increase the challenge. With the addition of timers from the very onset of the mission (not when you break stealth), luck plays a very large roll in success or failure as you run and gun your way to the end. Just run and gun and hope for the best.The world view simply doesn't work, putting forth both pointless busywork and demanding you move from place to place to place as random things happen. The performance is horrid, lack of basic features from the first one like controller support offputting and overall a great disappointment.Still you will like it if you are looking for luck based puzzle like gameplay employing run and gun.  For a serious, difficult but fair tactical game try Long War.And just fully enable controller support already, sure enough steam controllers have been sold by now.

content:
Posted: January 16
												At it's core, I wanted to love this game. It has everything in an RPG turn based long term developmental strategy game that makes the experience fun.It's the tactical nonsense that makes this game so frustrating and difficult to actually enjoy.First and foremost, enemy units once alerted or brought onto the map are given both a free movement turn followed by a complete turn themelves. This may not sound like a big deal, but it essentially enables the enemy units to nearly completely outflank you or position themselves in such a way that you won't be able to complete your timed objectives with any surviving members.Next, the timed objectives are ridiculous. You're given such a short time span to actually complete the mission (for instance, access the network in under 8 turns) that you literally have to beeline it for the objective with no regard for your units' safety. This wouldn't be an issue if you weren't being surrounded AND having to deal with eventual incoming reinforcements. There's no path you can take that doesn't require a conflict...so the only thing you can do is set up for as favorable an ambush as possible and then hope RNG works in your favor. If you don't get most/all the enemy killed right off the bat, you're not going to make it.I'm all for difficult missions and challenges that require tactics, but once the enemy units get free moves, and constantly get missed on 80 and 90% hit chances while hitting your guys in full cover, and half your team panicks when a member falls unconcious from a single hit, yet is still nearly at full health....the game starts to get way more than frustrating.It's not fun....and simply not worth proceeding. As much fun as the game looks, I'm already done with it. Thanks, but no thanks.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
												Let me start off by saying that I loved XCOM: Enemy Unknown. So much that I played through the entire game twice. When XCOM 2 came out I was really excited about it. But after having played 8 hours of the game and have won maybe 3 out of 15 encounters I gotta say, I'm really disappointed. It's not that I don't mind a challenge, in fact I was hoping this game would be slightly MORE challenging than Enemy Unknown, but this game is more than just challenging. This game is, for lack of a better term, ridiculously cheap. You've got enemies that can run for what seems like half the map and one shot your soldiers. You've got insanely overpowered enemies that swarm you from all sides early on in the game, before you have any time to research new technologies and have half a chance at winning. You've got multiple enemy types that can incapacitate your soldiers for multiple turns/the rest of the match. So you basically go into every battle with 2 guys you're just sacrificing to the enemy no matter what, and then left with 2 other grunts to try and fight 8 overpowered, cheap, enemies. And, you have a lot of missions with turn limits, which ruins any chance you have to set up any ambushes, and ruins any chance of you having any sort or tactical advantage at all. This game should be called XCOM: Hurry Up and Die I'm going to try a new game on Rookie mode and if it's more fun that way I'll update my review but for now, I'm pretty♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥I spent 60 bucks on this.UPDATE: Started a new game on Rookie mode and couldn't beat the 2nd level. Completed one objective while remaining hidden, immediately got noticed by the enemy even though I was out of sight. Shortly after my opposition went from 2 easy alien soldiers, to 10 aliens. 4 of which were those one shot kill "stun" baton guys that can run way too far. My entire squad couldn't hit anything they shot at, even at close range with 70+% odds, and then eventually became dead or mind-controlled by a swarm of overpowered aliens. Rookie mode has actually turned out to be more difficult than whatever I was playing last night. I feel ripped off. This game is not fun.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
PROS+ Snazzy new graphics. Weapons and armour look amazing.+ Environments are varied and look a lot better than XCOM:EW. + Environmental destruction! Need a quick exit? A grenade on the far wall will do the trick nicely!+ Psionic soldiers and powers are a lot more fleshed out.+ Skills and abilities a lot more interesting.+ Customization options.+ Weapon upgrades.+ Ammunition mods.CONS- Everything needs to be scanned and everyone is always in a rush and demand your immediate attention. There's a lot of flying back and forth across the world map. "Commander, we have supplies waiting for pickup in Asia." You fly over there to pick them up and then immediately something else pops up and requires you to deal with it. Then another thing. And another thing. And so on... It's annoying.- Missions with timers are a Run-and-Gun gauntlet. This severely prohibits you from playing how you want and it detracts from the overall enjoyment of the game.- Psionics are overpowered. Field a squad of Psi-Ops and you'll rarely want to run any other soldiers.- Poorly optimized. Plenty of framedrops even with certain options turned down/off.- Suffers from typical Firaxis-sequelitis with a touch of Bethesda-modanium - okay that was bad, but still. The fans are expected to "fix" the issues in the game with mods because it was half-arsed during development.- Hacking and the weird randomness of it. Having a high hacking skill seems to do naff all. I've had a lot more success with non-specialist soldiers hacking things than with the class that is supposedly an expert on it.- Accuracy is incredibly wonky. Standing in front of an alien, in the tile right next to it, does not give you a 100% to-hit chance.- Pull mechanics from the Viper-alien is horribly broken. They can pull you straight through walls and obstacles.- Melee attacks are also broken. Attacks through walls and obstacles are commonplace. Cover does nothing. I've had instances where I was able to strike an alien standing on the floor above me.- Overwatch and shooting in general isn't making much sense, either. You can shoot through walls and hit the poor ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ standing on the other side of the map as long as someone has spotted the enemy.- The delays after every. single. action. Heal someone? Delay. Hack something? Delay. Shoot something? Delay.- Unskippable cutscenes and Central bugging you constantly.Final thoughts.XCOM2 isn't bad but it isn't good either. The lack of quality assurance is clear; everything from poor optimization and broken pull-mechanics to all the delays after every single action. It's not much but every little thing adds up. I've spent over 300 hours in XCOM:EW (and god knows how many more in the originals) and I've enjoyed every single one of them, from the missed high-percentage shots to the one-shotting of the Über-Ethereal in the final mission. I have 50 odd hours logged in XCOM2 and I think I'll log another 30-40 to get the last few notable achievements (not Multiplayer, not touching that in an XCOM game) and after that, I don't think I'll play more. Not unless a major optimization patch fixes things.What's the verdict?Good question. I honestly don't know. I don't dislike the game but I don't like it either. It's all very "meh". It has so much potential but it is held back by its own failings. Final verdict on XCOM2 is a 6/10. It is just... average. I only barely recommend this. It needs to be fixed before it can turn into a truly great game.

Posted: February 6, 2016
												There's a lot of good here that's let down by the short turn timers and buggy gameplay. Hustling into poorly set up engagements because preparing properly takes too long isn't particularly satisfying, and the solution - especially in Retaliation missions where you need to get to 6 civilians that are often rather far away from you before they're killed - is primarily to have enough firepower to not get bogged down in combat for too many turns. Actually outmaneuvering the aliens to success is largely too slow to consistently beat the timer. I preferred the risk/reward decision-making of collecting Meld in Enemy Within over this ham-fisted way to always force aggression.The deal breaker for me is however the bugs. Dealing with glitchy cutscenes, random black screens on enemy reveal, getting shot through solid floors, UI that completely locks up, and combat turns that just get stuck and never end was trying, but I've finally given up after the timers on the strategic map started counting past 0 into the negatives, preventing further progress.I want to love this game, but it doesn't seem to want to love me back.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												So you've probably heard people complaining about the round timers and rolled your eyes. "Xcom is supposed to be hard, and you're supposed to be fighting a guerrilla war."I thought the same thing, and dove right in without a second thought. Here's the problem: All levels are randomly generated and difficulty does not affect round timers. It is very possble to roll a level where you can play flawlessly, bulldoze your enemies, complete the objectives in record time, and not have a chance in hell of reaching the evac in the rounds alloted. And when that timer reaches zero, you don't get to pull a Payday and fight off another few waves before evac comes back, that squad is just lost.This, and the mountains of gamebreaking bugs leaves XCOM 2 with a lackluster presentation that rides on the coattails of a better game, and promptly falls on it's face once it's in your library.
