content:
Posted: September 1, 2016
												This is a hard game to review. There's some elements to it that I love, then there are some that I hate so passionately it beggars belief.If you liked the original (which I did) then initially you are in for a treat. The mechanics are the same albeit more streamlined and the graphical upgrade is very welcome. The stealth addition works suprisingly well and the change in storyline and subsequent game mechanics also feel fresh and well researched, although once again a little light on the details in comparison to the original XCOM. What I HATE though, is the lack of immersion and the funky 'logic' the game uses. If you can accept that this game is based on a framework of stats, numbers and percentages that will over rule the in game logic then you should be fine. I wasnt. When im standing 3 feet away from an alien with my assualt rifle up his jacksy, I dont expect to see %65 chance to hit.The game is designed to pummel you, you WILL lose people and there will be NOTHING you can do about it. I understand this is a design decision, but it ultimately ruined the game for me.In summary - this is a great game if you can deal with unfair spawning, nonsensical 'logic' and frustration.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												Long War Update: Long War adds SO much to the game, and it also makes everything in my original review worse. One would say that it accentuates the original experience, so, if you enjoyed XCOM 2, then you'll have a blast. For me it was a big let down. Not only performance drops to it lowest point ever, but the friggin timers are back.I assume LW doesn't play nice with the mods I had, so that's another problem I would have to deal with if I felt like playing this game in the future (which I won't).First Update: You can now remove explicit timers from the game via mods (doing so won't disable any achievements). Keep in mind, though, that the game was designed around that "mechanic", and there're still plenty of implicit timers around (civilians, objective defense, unlimited spawns, etc). In light of that, and the fact that modders are just kind strangers and not Firaxis, my review remains the same.Original review:Here's my -entirely subjective- view of this game as of now. For the record I'll say that I'm a big fan of the old XCOM as well as EU.**** CONS **** (i'll list them first since this is a negative review)- Plenty of timers. If you liked the council missions where you had to deactivate the bomb on a timer, then you'll be fine. However if you're like me and you like to approach things carefully, then those kinds of ops are going to get boring, fast. I get the whole "urgency" thing, but when 4 out of 5 ops end up being timed (either by a turn counter, or a civilian counter, or any other counter for that matter) it becomes somewhat frustrating. It may be ok on the easier dificulties, but the higher you go the more you'll hate them. And that's not even mentioning having to beat the Avatar Project.Man Firaxis sure love their timers.- Shorter soldier list, longer recovery time.Your guys are expendable, especially during your first hours with the game, but combine the fact that the aliens are now more dangerous and resourceful with the fact that soldiers may take several weeks to heal up after they're wounded (provided they don't die) and you'll end up recruiting A LOT of cannon fodder, spending precious resources that you won't be able to dump anywhere else.- Friendly Fire.It's always frustrating to see your soldiers shoot themselves when they panic, but now they not only do that, but also blow your entire squad up with their grenades. Combine with the previous points and you'll get how infuriating this can result.- Unlimited enemy spawns.During some ops the enemy will reinforce their numbers, as they did in the previous game. Only that now they'll continue to do so every few turns. What's that? You don't want to risk your guys? Tough luck, you'll do that or you'll be royally f***** whithin a couple turns. Combine with the previous points.- Bad optimization.The game ran poorly on my (high-end) system. It'll probably be fixed once the drivers get updated and all that jazz. Hope so anyway. This was the first time I had any kind of problem of this type with XCOM.- Losing stopped being fun.Because unlike EU or the older titles, this game does not punish your mistakes. It instead pushes you to make them, then punish you for it, which I found to be a little too much, and I was a regular Ironman Imposible player back in EU.If you're of those who consider timers realistic, think about this, everyone knows that you never EVER dash/move twice on Classic or Impossible, yet the turn limit forces you to do that. How bad is it? Well, aside from the fact that worrying about the timer takes away from enjoying the rest of the game, you'd think you can always dash safely while conclealed... Only to realize then that you triggered 2 unseen groups and a turret and now your Ironman campaign is going down the toilet, fast. Remember how good it felt to carefully coordinate your squad to wipe out that alien pack in a single turn coming out of concealment?Good, remember it well, because chances are you're not gonna get to that often.**** PROS ****- No thin men.JK, you'll face worse.- Meaningful choicesThe game is full of them, but the ones I liked the most are those related to soldier classes. A lot was done to improve the skills you get to choose when your guys level up, unlike EU where you picked more or less the same every time.- No satellites.Building satellites was a chore, but was almost mandatory in the previous game. That is, luckly, a thing of the past.- Soldier and weapon customization is over 9000.- Maps are more diverse and feature a lot more detail.- You get access to a lot of tech very early on (by XCOM standards), likely to balance the increased alien threat.- The story is a lot more fleshed out than in the previous game.I have a lot of positive things to say about XCOM 2 regardless of my negative review, and it's certainly worth the price, if you're the kind that enjoys the changes they made to gameplay. I'm not one of those people, and that's why I'm giving this one a thumbs down. Consider it carefully before buying though, or you could end up like me.*** Closing Statements *** (Spoilers) So I've finally -almost- finished the game. I've seen everything it has to offer and my feelings are of disappointment more than anything else. The equivalent of the base defense and -especially- the final stand are long ops that end up feeling like a chore. The final mission is pretty similar to the one on EU, perhaps a bit shorter, but pretty much the same. What's unforgivable, at least for me, is the fact that they spiked the difficulty at the end so hard it makes no damn sense.You can pretty much complete the op breaking face all the way to the last encounter, which throws A LOT of BS your way. So I basically shut down the game and fired up YouTube to see the ending cutscene, because I was not going to do that all over again (You can see how much I cared for the game at this point).Completing the campaign (or at least 99.9% of it) on Commander Ironman took me a sweet time and was fun at times, but there was a lot of stress and boredom involved as well. There were times when I just wanted to get it over with, and the final op was the last nail on XCOM's coffin for me, I didn't feel any reason to re do everything and try again afterwards, much less jumping on legend, though the game cheats a lot less than it did on Impossible back on EU.If you made it this far I thank you for your time :)Cheers.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
tl;dr XCOM2 isn't a bad game. However, in its current state(bugs, brutal difficulty, optimization issues) I am giving XCOM 2 a thumbs down.  Forward -- My Perspective I played the original XCOMs to completion along with the EU reboot.  I enjoyed these games.  I am a tough critic.  I expect a game to be fun and enjoyable from my first hour to my last hour.     PROS  (+)Great atmosphere(+)Competent tactical combat(+)Large variety of aliens, items, structures, and skills (+)Customization of troopersCONS  (-)Bugs.  One such bug is the game allowing troops to shoot through one or more solid walls/ceilings/floors.  If the cover system doesn't work in a cover based shooter, then the core functionality of the game is broken.  I don't understand the problem here because these mechanics worked fine in EU.(-) Poor optimization. (-)The first mission is a 100% on the rails "tutorial" followed by a far(far) more challenging real mission that is very unforgiving -- this is an "interesting" design decision.  (-)Time limits along with procedurally generated maps & random spawns = lol, you were punked situations on occassion. (-)Development traps, RNGesus, unforgiving gameplay, and uneven difficulty limit the way you can play the game.  Over reliance on grenades is almost a requirement in many places.(-)Save scumming is how many (if not most) people will deal with the above "challenges".  Designing a game to require save scumming from many players is a questionable decision (imo).   Review Counter Arguments  Why you are right and I am wrong.Get Gud/Learn2play noob"That's XCOM"Load some modsPlay on rookieYou dislike a game I like so  you are "Another cry baby"

content:
Posted: August 2, 2016
												This is a review of the base game, without mods, which I bought 6 months after game release.Summary:Playing this game was like drinking a nice soda and finding a hornet in the bottom of the glass!Pros:Good UIMinimal game-engine problemsGood to great graphicsInteresting soldier mechanics and play stylesExplosivesCons:The PlotPacing.  The Avatar timer mechanic in particularCharacters, or lack of them.  Shallow and relatively obvious tech treeUtter lack of surprise at anythingSave files that balloon in sizeThe cutscene before the final mission causing actual computer crash when equipping WAR suit.A game that feels way too short and unfinished without DLCI had a feeling Firaxis would make a mess of this game... and I was right.  I decided to play the vanilla game, mod-free, without any DLC.Getting to a good balance of difficulty was tough.  I eventually settled on veteran, then realized once you know how to play this game most of the mechanics are largely irrelevant.  There's a more or less simple solution to every problem.The missions are fairly repetitive.  Some require more stealth than others, and some require killing all enemies and other requires soldiers to evac out.  My basic playstyle of XCOM1 was totally fine: lots of heavies and snipers, with supports and assaults carrying rifles.  Explosives destroy cover and shred armor, everyone else gets shots at exposed targets.  Robotic enemies are nasty... until you realize that your supports are absolutely OP against them.  Again, kind of typical of the laziness on Firaxis' part - create an enemy with an insta-counter.  Heck the biggest risk is that you don't level up early supports because you think they're useless.The overall missions were fun, especially once I got 6 colonel ranked soldiers and started blowing everything up.  I didn't ever deploy a single psionic soldier, and it was no big deal at all.  Anyways, the cutscene before the final mission literally crashed my computer!  It resembled a power cycle (and this happened 3 times at exactly the same point in the cutscene)... people on the internet have also experienced it... mine was solved by removing the WAR suit from the soldier who had it in the loadout scream, which apparently caused a graphics glitch.  That is unacceptable, Firaxis!  A known, full-crash bug that still hasn't been addressed.In sum, I think the fun factor of this game is probably in the mods... however it speaks poorly to the creators that the best thing about their game is that other people can make it better.  I am not a modder, I believe games should be good as sold, and that they should not suck in general.6/10, regret buying

content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												XCOM 2, the sequel to XCOM Enemy Unknown, is without a doubt one of the best strategy games I've ever played. XCOM as a franchise has always been some of the best strategy games out there and I am pleased to say that this new entry more then lives up to the legacy of its predecessors.XCOM 2 assumes that you got your♥♥♥♥♥handed to you in Enemy Unknown(Enemy Within if you got the expansion, also reccomended), and turns the tables on you. You're now leading a resistance movement to overthrow the alien run ADVENT coalition, who are now operating a global government. 20 years have passed between this game and the last, and it shows. ADVENT is well entrenched, not only resource and infrastructure wise, but also in that they have the popular support of the people. Assuming you play the tutorial, the game begins from the perspective of Central Officer Bradford, as he leads an operation to rescue The Commander(Read: YOU) from an ADVENT facility. After the tutorial's crash course in some changes to the ground battles, such as concealment, you're taken to your new mobile headquarters.XCOM is now operating out of "The Avenger", a re-purposed alien cargo vessel, now serving as your mobile base of operations. Striking from the Avenger, you travel the globe, uniting resistance cells and striking at ADVENT facilities wherever you can. While the previous games had you countering alien abductions, and defending populations, the new version pits you in a guerilla warfare situation. Now your missions consist of hit and run strikes against research labs, local armories, and other facilities, to rescue VIPs, hack their network for intel, destroy data-relays, or protect your own network taps. Some missions even involve kidnapping or assasinating key officials in their organiszation. Dirty Collaborators.Maps are now procedurally generated, so that you never get the same one twice. The new maps are beautiful, and fully destructive. If you need a door somewhere, feel free to make one. Heck, you can even collapse the floor out from under an enemy's feet, or lure them into a building and with a few well placed explosives, drop the entire building on top of them.The change in pace is noticeable. Almost every mission has some sort of time limit, either due to ADVENT actively destorying whatever you need to protect, or an actual timer untill the mission ends. This adds a sense of urgency to missions and encourages more risky play. Gameplay feels more fast paced then in previous installments. This also adds dificulty, not only must you achieve a hard task, but you need to do it in the next few turns or you won't have enough time to make it back to the evac point.Speaking of Difficulty, XCOM 2 continues the franchise history of brutal and unforgiving gameplay. The easier difficulties are just that, easy. You can coast through them and learn the game in a more forgiving and casual environment if you want. Rookie to Veteran is a significant but manageable leap, however, the difficulty spikes hard changing from Veteran to Commander. The last of the training wheels come off at that point and it shows. The real test of your abilities comes from playing under the "Insanity" setting. The training wheels have been long forgotten, no more punches are going to be pulled. The game will officially break your nose and toss you overboard into shark infested waters to see if you can swim. That's not to say the game is unfair, because it is. You can beat insanity mode, but there is no longer any margin for error. To win the game, you'll need to unravel the alien's true agenda. The ADVENT coalition is up to something, in the form of the AVATAR Project. This is the alien's win condition, and puts a timer on the game as a whole. If the aliens can make enough progress on the project, game over. Thankfully, you're given ample oppertunity to sabotage facilites critical to this initiative, slowing and even reversing their progress. If you can discover the truth about their agenda, and put a stop to it before they complete this plan, you will reign victorious.A commander is nothing without his men, and to put an end to the AVATAR Project, you'll need the help of alot of them. Lucky for us, customising the soliders under your command has been greatly improved from the last game. New customisation options, incuding scars, tatoos, and individual armor pieces, can help vary the look of your troops. The Character Pool function allows you to save your favorites to share with your friends, and characters in the pool can appear at random points in your campaigns. New looks are accompanied by new skills. The Class based system is back, but has been changed dramatically. The Heavy, Support, Sniper and Assault classes of XCOM EW, have been replaced with the Grenadier, Specialist, Sharpshooter and Ranger, respectively. Each bring something new to the table, but hav roughly the same roles overall. A powerful 5th class exists now as well, if you're willing to spend the time to unlock it.One more noteworthy feature is the extensive mod support, the steam workshop has over 500 mods already published at the time of writing, and more are on the way as modders explore deeper into the game's code.Summary: XCOM 2 is a great game for the strategy junkies in all of us, offering compelling story, beautiful visuals, top notch gameplay, and brutal, but fair, difficulty. A solid 9.5/10, Must own for anyone interested in strategy games, or who enjoyed the previous installment in the franchise.TL;DR: Buy it, game is good.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												I love the entire XCOM and UFO franchise. I played all previous games, I preordered XCOM2, I was waiting like for the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ christmas. But no. I'm disappointed, I'm very disappointed.Because it's not strategy right now. It's "rush forward and wish for lucky shot or reload latest save if you miss".Timers, timers everywhere. Every mission crucial for the plot is on timer, main quest on strategic map is on timer, but that's not the problem. Problem is that these timers are set up so you have no tactical or strategical options other that mindlessly rushing forward. Only other choise is defeat from running out of time. You can't outflank enemies, you can't set up ambushes, you can't walk around them because CLOCK IS TICKING.Why? First XCOM didn't have those (yeah, terror misions, but they make sense. It's either aliens kill everyone around, or you manage to kill aliens faster, no issue here). Technically you could take all the time you wanted. But the aliens were also growing and advancing, they were attacking, they were getting new units and new toys. There was no clock but the pressure was there all the time. That's the difference between enjoying the challenge the games gives you and just being worried seeing diminishing turn counter. I want a game where I have to worry about long term decisions and about outsmarting enemies on tactical level, not go Call of Duty dakka-dakka style.Then there is performance issues. It's not even about FPS drops. New games always have issues like that, they will probably patch it soon. But visible animation issues? You can see where animation of soldier running ends and animation of sticking to cover begins. And after you complete some action the game just waits for several seconds like it is thinking what to do now. Or my soldiers lands a shot at the enemy even if he is looking in COMPLETELY different direction.THOSE WERE ALL PRESENT IN FIRST XCOM. HOW MANY YEARS YOU HAD TO CORRECT THOSE?And this feature of editing how your soldiers look and behave? You advertised this as best thing since sliced bread. It's just few options more than first XCOM. And what logic allows you to edit those only after soldier get higher ranks?If I had to rate the game.As a standalone game, not looking at the title - 6/10. Big game, lot of content, good graphics, complex, yet annoying mechanics. Still much better than most other on the market.As one of the XCOM series - 2/10. A disgrace to to the brand for reasons mentioned above.

Posted: May 12, 2016
												Solid improvement over XCOM EU/EW. I really enjoyed the change of pace and base management. A lot of the systems they changed felt like an improvement too. Offers a lot of replayability and character creation is a time sink as always.I do feel that in some ways they could really improve the character customisation (more voice, armour, camo patterns, helmets, hair colour, etc.), even by importing older assets from the previous games. They seem to have left it to the enormous modding scene (they offer tools for this), which is a bit of a shame. Of course, that's not to say that the mods are bad - quite the opposite.Yes performance is sluggish if you don't meet minimum requirements (and trust me, a GTX 560 is bare minimum at 1080p), but turning down the graphics settings will improve things (obviously).  Definitely use a 2GB graphics card which is faster than a GTX 560. Running full screen seems to improve CPU load balance, but then I already have a fast CPU (i5 4690K) so it doesn't make much difference to me.It's an unqualified recommendation if you meet the system requirements.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												If you liked the last xcom, you will enjoy this one.  I am finding it to be a bit more challenging, as a lot of the aliens have been rethought in order to spice up the strategy. It's got that classic xcom feeling still though, massive heart breaking losses of favorite characters, epic hail mary long shots.  Lots to research, and a constant feeling of progression of strength in the war.  The one thing I will say I wish xcom had is a bit more diversity to the types of missions.  The game would feel more immersive if certain things were not so heavily scripted. Do the aliens really need to retaliate every month end?  And can I get a nice easy mission every now and again to help train rookies on?  Once you see a new stronger alien type you are doomed to forever see them in every mission.  These are minor gripes though, and you should be killing aliens... like right now.

content:
Posted: March 26
												This is an *Excellent* game.  Well designed, a great challenge, and it's as much fun to watch as it is to play.When comparing to the first game (XCOM in 2012 with expansion in 2013), it's got a "spin" on the story that's nice.This game takes place twenty years after XCOM lost the first war.  Yup...you read that right...you lose the first game.There's debate among friends about whether you actually lost the battles you were fighting (there is a "bad" ending to the first game), or if you won the missions you were playing, but the aliens snuck in a sucker-punch after the game's official ending (which is my preferred theory), but regardless, you're now fighting as what's left over as the old-guard of XCOM.  Some characters return...so, not so much.The economy of the game is very different...you deal in both supplies, alien materials, and intel.  Intel is the tricky one until you get the hang of it, but without it, you can't expand the resistance.Initially, I didn't enjoy this as much as I did the first one, but as I got deeper into the game, I grew to appreciate even more the work that the developers did.  The story is engrossing, the voice acting is excellent (I wish they had gotten the original voice for Central, but this guy still did great), and the game balance is very challenging.It took a long time for me to "turn the corner" on this game.  Initially, I lost a LOT of soldiers (may their pixels rest in the electrons) either through my inexperience of the game or just a balance issue that I had trouble gettng in front of.Nice addtions / changes to the game mechanics:-weapon and armor improvements are now squad upgrades...you don't have to build five or six plasma weapons...when you unlock plasma weapons, all of them are automatically upgraded.  Pretty much the same with armor and explosives.-new alien classes that build on the story from the first game.  It's clear that someone had a general story arc planned out.-outstanding DLC.  "Shen's Last Gift" and "Alien Hunters" add some amazing content to the game.  The SPARC unit from "Shen's Last Gift" is a nice addition, -amazing tweak of Overwatch.  You no longer have to watch in dismay as all your characters on Overwatch (essentially guard duty for the unintiated) all shoot at the same alien, which is taken out by the first shot and all the other shots are wasted.  Now, Overwatch shots are taken in sequence, allowing your squad to react and cover ambushes better-reloading your primary weapon no longer ends your turn.  If you don't intend to move, you can reload and fire in the rame turn (yay!)Things that took getting used to:-very different economy.  You just have to learn this one as you go.-different globe interface.  This isn't bad, but it's a lot more interactive than the globe in the first game.-there's a lot of NPCs demanding attention and wanting things from XCOM.  It can get overwhelming at times (which is part of the fun challenge of the game)Overall, this game shows a polish that illustrates that the developers are fans of the franchise and it was, to some degree, a "labor of love".I highly recommend this game.  If you haven't played the first one, pick it up also, but I recommend you play them in order.  Once you play the second one, there's some things about the game mechanics that you'll find frustrating (the second game simply has some nice things added that you'll miss going back to the first one).Two thumbs up.-HitmanHart

content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
												I never preorder games, but I loved Firaxis' reboot of the XCOM series, I was excited by the concept of fighting a guerilla war against invaders who had already conquered the world, and I wanted to support good old PC gaming, so when it became available, I went ahead and preordered XCOM 2 with the Reinforcement pack. I regret that decision, I regret buying the game at all, and I will never again make the mistake of ordering a game before there are significant numbers of user reviews.The game does some things right; there are some changes from the last game that are genuine improvements, but the flaws in the game overshadow these and make playing the game a chore. For starters, there are the performance issues that still plague the game months after its release. The game has much more demanding hardware requirements than XCOM: EU, has trouble running on many systems that exceed its recommended specs, and yet, in the end, does not look significantly better than its predecessor. And what is the deal with the ridiculous load times before and after a mission? What exactly is being loaded? I could understand the load times before missions if they were being used to generate the mission map (though that's apparently not the case), but why on earth do I have to wait 5 minutes just to get back to base? I can play three or four games of XCOM:EU in the time it takes to play a single game of XCOM 2, not because the campaign is longer, but because of all the stupid load screens and unecessary delays in the gameplay.The worst flaw in the gameplay itself is the number of missions with a turn limit. The problem is not with the turn-limited missions themselves—it's not that they're too hard or unbalanced in any way—no, the problem is that there are just so many of them that they become dull. The bomb disposal missions in XCOM:EU were a welcome change of pace, and I found myself wishing there were more missions like that. In this game, however, I breathe a sigh of relief whenever i get to play a mission that doesn't have a turn limit.  The developers have stated that the turn limits were designed to speed up the pace of gameplay. In reality, they slow it down. Because each move is more important, you have to spend more REAL time scrolling around the map and carefully planning your moves and less REAL time shooting aliens and having fun.  Again, if it was only a quarter to a third of the missions that had these timers, I would love them, but when it's over 90% of missions, it just gets boring.I won't review the DLC here, but suffice it to say none of it was worth the cost.The biggest problem, though, is the constant bugs. They make it impossible to play ironman. Even with the latest patch, I've had soldiers who got stuck after opening a door, soldiers who were injured by elements they were supposed to be immune to, soldiers killed by explosions in squares they had already moved away from, mission objectives that suddenly went from full health to zero in a single turn with no one shooting at them, and many many others. Granted, not all the bugs have been in the aliens' favor: I did once have a soldier who was killed, but was still somehow able to shoot (though not move). The game has also been crashing on startup with increasing frequency. I can fix this by verifying the game cache and letting Steam download the files that fail to validate, but lately I've been having to do this every time I want to play the game. I'm writing this review now because I just unistalled the game fully intending to reinstall it and see if that fixed the problem, but now that I've removed it, I've realized that I don't really WANT to reinstall it.I preordered this game because I wanted to support PC gaming, but if this is the kind of crap we can expect from developers, maybe it would be kinder to let it die.

												A long time fan of strategy games of both real time and turn based, I found myself rather surprised that I did not enjoy Xcom 2, and in fact found myself rather hating it. Unlike it's most previous predecessor which I enjoyed throughly, the increased random get fukd elements of this game really put it off for me. People who enjoy less predictability in their strategy games might rather enjoy this, and from what I understand of previous Xcom titles this is more the norm, but for me this is not the case.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2016
												Gameplay core is mostly good, turn timers force players to think ahead but can sometimes be frustrating due to unforeseen twists. Campaign pacing leaves a lot to be desired, you spend a lot of time repeating the same types of missions and hunting avatar facilities. There is a great deal of potential missed in terms of delivering a compelling narrative and aesthetic. Art direction doesn't work with the revolutionary / seperatist theme, a weak and disorganized splinter cell of old XCOM somehow has the ability to produce factory fresh equipment just as good as the old. The music has the same heroic tone as it had in the previous game but it doesn't really work well outside of the idealistic context of a united global effort.From launch this game was a technical mess, now after several patches it still manages to run poorly on setups clearly meating recommended system specs.Mod support is very nice, many good mods are available, some that add basic features and tweaks that should've been in the game from release, as such while yes, the mods are good, the game itself should be judged without those taken into account since we pay the company, not the modders.Perhaps in a while after all DLC's have been released and some more tweaks have been applied this will be worth getting on sale, right now i'd recommend getting XCOM:EW instead.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												I have to give this game a negative review. Mainly because it's so much missed potential and some major design decisions that ruin the experience. Don't get me wrong, it's a decent game, but I feel it does not deserve all the credit it's getting from official reviewers, and frankly giving this game anything higher than 7/10 just proves that they have no real grasp of game design or game mechanics.At a first glance the game looks and plays very much like the previous game, I recon this is why it's getting good reviews from a lot of reviewers who haven't really spent that much time playing. I played this on iron-man, and veteran settings because that's how I believe X-Com should be played to offer an interesting challenge. If you play it on easy settings your soldiers will have some unfair bonuses to your aim and damage.The Good:- Upgraded graphics- More events, locations, enemies, gadgets and weapons- The random map generator. (Adds some degree of replayability to the regular missions)- The mod support- Addition of "stealth"The Bad:- Too much randomness, random events that screw up the most carefully planned mission. Events that you as a player could not have had any chance of predicting. It's just too much.- "Unfair" rules, say that you sneak past a group of enemies and think you were smart, think again. If you complete the main objective all enemies that have not been activated might be activated at once and rush you.- Timed missions, most missions have a timer attached forcing you to have to sprint forward in order to reach the objective in time, This in turn makes stealth tactics or any tactics for that matter pretty useless.- Enemy behaviours don't match their roles. As an example zombie aliens can move about as far as your soldiers per turn, even though they look and are animated like they should be far slower.- Lack of unique soldiers/recruits. They are so obviously randomly generated that they sort of lose their "personality". Lazily written descriptions where there could have been hundreds of stories for the soldiers making them seem more real.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2016
												XCOM 2 is the sequel to 2012's XCOM: Enemy Unknown, developed by Firaxis Games (Civilization) and published by 2K Games. The game is the latest in a long history of infamously unforgiving XCOM games, dating right back to 1994's cult classic, UFO: Enemy Unknown. The premise for the series is that a hyper-intelligent alliance of aliens invade earth, and the player, known in the modern games as "The Commander", must lead a group known as Extraterrestrial Combat (X-COM) to defend the Earth. The series was rebooted in 2012 with Enemy Unknown, bringing the dated series back into the public eye and gaining newfound popularity.XCOM 2 takes place 15 years after the events of Enemy Unknown, of which the canon ending was that the player failed to defend the Earth from the alien invaders. Firaxis have said that they decided that the canon ending is failure who have now taken root on Earth as a governing body known as ADVENT, parading as something akin to prophets of the benevolent Elders, providing cures to many diseases through gene therapy and bringing a newfound unity to the human race. A sinister new "Avatar Project" has been discovered by the XCOM Initiative, and it's up to you to investigate and combat the threat to humanity, and hopefully liberate Earth from the Elders.The gameplay of the game is threefold: first, you have the turn-based combat. This makes up the very core of the game, and the vast majority of your time will be spent blowing aliens sky-high. The combat system is deep, and easy to come to grips to, with 5 classes for your soldiers to experiment with (6 with the Shen's Last Gift DLC). Missions vary, but all take place on procedurally generated maps. The objectives differ as well, you control your squad of up to 6 to complete goals such as stealing sensitive data, protecting a resistance camp from an alien counter-attack or recovering a VIP to gain precious intel - an important currency in the game. In addition to the combat side of the gameplay, there is  a large element of base management whereupon you build facilities with different functions, research new tech, develop upgrades for your soldiers' arms and armor, as well as decide what areas of the "Geoscape" to scan. Your base is a flying ship, and the Geoscape presents you with different options to explore to recover currency, new troops or investigate new leads. The third facet of gameplay is managing your emotional wellbeing. I'm still not quite over losing my favorite sharpshooter, Captain Yoko Littner.XCOM 2 is perhaps one of the best examples in the video game industry of evaluating your risk vs your reward. As a tactical game notorious for its difficulty, literally every decision you make has an impact on the game. Across the roughly 20-hour campaign, decisions you made near the start can come back to haunt you. A misplaced power relay in the base or a poorly chosen skill selection on your soldier can have serious ramifications. Perhaps the best testament to the difficulty of the series is shown in the plot of the game: Enemy Unknown's canon ending is a failure because "everybody fails their first XCOM campaign".Normally in strategy games, you can afford to make a mistake or two, but XCOM 2 takes no prisoners. Leaving a soldier without adequate cover can have disastrous effects: not only may your soldier be killed, but its death may send the rest of your squad into a panic, causing them to fire off randomly (possibly at your own troops!) or unusable on the next turn. Similarly, if you hold off researching new armor for even a week too long eventually the aliens' tech will begin to vastly outclass the HP bar of your soldiers, and you will find yourself being steamrolled time and time again. The difficulty takes some getting used to, and can be infuriating on your first campaign after failing your sixth mission in a row, but once the learning curve has been surpassed and the various nuances of the games tactical turn-based combat have been mastered, the game becomes a lot fairer. If The Commander makes good choices, your greatest enemy will become luck.This, however, leads me onto one of my only criticisms of XCOM 2, and generally one of my only criticisms of the entire series. Luck can be your greatest friend in this game, but mostly you will find it to be your enemy. Chance-to-hit percentages feature prominently in the combat of XCOM 2, and there is nothing worse than your soldier missing a crucial 90% chance shot, or scoring the lowest possible damage and being killed by that same enemy with 1hp left. There is a lot of discussion as to whether players simply seem to notice their failures more than their victories, but while playing the game I couldn't seem to shake the feeling that a 90% chance to hit was something closer to 60%. Similarly, ordering your soldier around a corner and activating three separate groups of enemies at once because the game generated the "pods" unfairly close together is equally as rage-inducing.Outside of that gripe, however, the rest of the game is an absolute gem. Visually, the game is a huge step up from the previous game, with stunning landscapes and wonderful character design. The models for the aliens are brilliant, and the character creation is incredibly pleasing, and all of your changes are realised on the battlefield. That is, until the soldier you spent an hour customising panics and shoots the soldier you spent TWO hours customising in the back of the head. Wonderful stuff.Coupled with the gorgeous graphics the game comes with a stellar soundtrack (composed by Tim Wynn), which is well worth a listen to on its own. The atmospheric music sets the tension for the game, adding a wealth of depth to any skirmish. A personal favorite of mine is called "Lazarus", which plays while overlooking the world map on the Geoscape. The deep bass with anxiety-inducing strings complete the wonderful package that is XCOM 2, and bring it to an all-new level of awesome.XCOM 2 also features Steam workshop support, which adds a fantastic array of community-made mods to the game, with everything from complete gameplay overhauls (a favorite of mine is a wave-based Tower Defense take on XCOM), to cosmetic upgrades and even fan-made soldier classes. With mods, the replayability is endless.In short, XCOM 2 is a fantastic game, and more than lives up to its predecessor's legend. Simply a must-have for any sci-fi or strategy nut, and will surely give them something to enjoy. It improves upon the tried-and-tested XCOM formula in every way, and I can only wait with baited breath for what Firaxis has in store for us.  I just hope they don't decide that the canon ending is my poor squad dying a horrible death and failing to complete their mission.This review was written on behalf of TeamTom's Reviews. You can check out the steam group  here, or visit us on our  website[teamtomreviews.co.uk]

content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												XCOM 2 is definitely a game with a few issues, mainly in the performance department. That said Firaxis have been supporting the game and patching it to solve issues many have had. I can run the game fairly decently, and enjoy my time with it.It's also a turn based game, and while that's no excuse, a lower FPS than 60 is still playable here. The gameplay itself is a step up from it's predecessor, with you taking on the role of Guerillas rather than Soldiers. It's an interesting take on the franchise as you'll be the one making the decisions on when to attack and ambush rather than the other way around.In the first game you'd overwatch crawl your way to victory, trying to avoid activating pods in unfortunate scenarios. With Enemy Within, meld was an incentive to do more than just crawl across the map, and it worked fairly well. XCOM 2 expanded on that idea with a good chunk of missions having a timer where you'll fail the mission if you don't complete it in time. It's a bit contrived but gets the job done, however to make up for this you start most of these timed missions in concealment allowing you to pick when to engage and blow your cover.It's not a stealth game, I still have yet to complete a single mission without 'alerting' the aliens, however the stealth system does allow you to do something you had a harder time doing in the first game, ambush the enemy and pick when to engage. The gameplay itself has a lot of mods in the works, and is much easier to mod than the first game. Already there are plenty of mods that add new enemies, soldier customizations, voice lines, and map parcels (Maps in XCOM 2 are randomly generated so they get less static than the ones in the first game). There's nothing on the level of Long War for Xcom 1 yet, but the possibility is there and if the community makes the effort to create something like that, I'm sure it can be done.Is XCOM 2 a worthy successor to the first game? I'd say so. Is it a replacement for the first game? Well, the first game with no expansions I'd definitely say so. However is it a replacement for Enemy Within? No, I'd suggest anyone who's yet to try XCOM try out Enemy Within first, however I do think XCOM 2 is simply better than Enemy Within (Optimization aside). I'd put it like this, Long War for XCOM 1 has more depth than XCOM 2, however XCOM 2 is far superior to Enemy Within and Enemy Unknown. I'd also argue that XCOM 2 is an easier game on the harder difficulties, however mods already exist that can tweak the game to be harder or easier to whiatever suits you. Whether it's worth the price of admission is up to you, but with Steam refunds being a thing I'd certainly suggest trying it and giving it a shot, especially if you're a fan of the first game. If strategy games with a bit of chance are your thing, then XCOM 2 and it's tense engagements will certainly be for you.Edit: I've read a few negative reviews and most focus on the timed missions and Strategic side of the game. Here's the thing, the timers prevent you from simply crawling up the map without taking many calculated risks. If you dislike the timers you can edit them in LTX files or download mods from the workshop that elongate or remove them.As for the Strategy side, many were complaining that they didn't have enough time to do everything available there before getting into a mission. That's the point, with Advent controlling the world you'll have to make decisions about where you dedicate your resources. You'll usually be able to get one of the 'resource blips' before a mission, but not all of them. It's about choosing which one you think is more important to you, going for it, and then doing the mission. What's nice about XCOM 2 is that failing a mission or skipping a mission isn't a death sentence like it was in the first game. Yes on higher difficulties missing early missions can be terrible, however there are ways to get around this. Missions simply aren't as impactful, they're still important...But you have ways of getting around the cost of failure.You may have failed a mission and lost a Veteran soldier, but you now have ways of acquiring new soldiers for resources you have. Managing your resources is an important part of the strategic side as I mentioned, and they're much more important in XCOM 2 than the first game. Not only can you get new soldiers but you can get Scientists and Engineers as well, though it's important to remember you'd miss out on other things such as making new contacts, or getting some weapon upgrades. You can even spend resources to rush some research or building if that's what you'd like to try doing.The types of strategies you can emply thanks to these extra systems are just another bit of depth outside the Tactical game. So yes you won't be able to get everything available on the world map, you'll have to pick and choose. The thing is, you have much more to do resource wise, and many more decisions to make that add depth to the game. Also important not to forget, thanks to how easy it is to modify the game and how open the devs have been with this, you can change things such as timers or how long collecting resources takes yourself or by looking around on the workshop. Hope this helps clear a few things up and spread some light on a few issues I've seen people have.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												I loved the last XCOM game to bits and XCOM 2 was supposed to be an improvement in every aspect. Instead, it's the most frustrating game I've played in recent years. Unless you play games for a living, playing XCOM 2 for maybe an hour every day will lead to nothing but frustration and resentment. Why? Because even on normal difficulty the odds are stacked against you at all times, to the point where it becomes grueling. Once you're a couple of hours into the game you will have to scum save every move in order to make it through the mission by reloading it 15 times. There is not a single mission where the balance is not one step away from being completely out of whack. Move one tile too far and you will aggro another - previously invisible - enemy squad that can tear your group apart in a single turn.  With the over-abundance of escalating missions and the timing constraints added as a new ‘feature', strategic depth is simply AWOL in this game. Only rarely are you given the time to set up your units or prepare an ambush. If you don’t like trial & error games where missions randomly go south, you should avoid this game.On the plus side, the graphics are much better (albeit laggy most of the time) and the controls have been improved a lot.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2016
												First off I want to preface that my review is based on "what you pay for, and what you get in return." Secondly, I realize I'm going to get flak for this so if you are a die hard fan of Firaxis or the XCOM series you can stop reading now because I doubt this review is for you. This review is for people who want to know if the money they spend is going to be returned. That being said, I flat out cannot recommend XCOM2 right now. I know a lot of people have mentioned bugs and poor optimization. I personally run the game on ultra, haven't seen anything exceptionally bad except for frame rate issues when a mission is loading. So my gripe isn't because of it being poorly optimized. My problem with XCOM2 is game play, or lack there of. First, it is the real lack of character customization with the base game, sure you could pay $5 for the anarchy's children pack which adds a little more to the game but even then it's not really worth it. Secondly, where you do have some armor choices, the tactical advantage conferred by those armors is either overlapped by other armors in various ways or not something worth utilizing a lot of the time. Third, the missions very quickly begin to feel repetitious, the environments all feel the same, the goals very often are the same and the enemy variations and tactics don't really call for major squad changes for most missions. In fact my third gripe is the one that really killed the game for me because XCOM2 got so repetitious so quickly I very quickly lost interest after feeling I had seen all the game had to offer. Now it's not all negatives, between XCOM and XCOM2 the tactical turn based strategy hasn't changed all that much. There are a variety of powers and weapons you can bring onto the battlefield to help give you an advantage, along with class specification getting some nice new additions (like the gremlin which I really enjoyed). During XCOM2 there is this AVATAR project timer that is supposed to give added pressure and force you into making decisions at times rather than waiting for when your squad is optimally prepared for the mission. However, this isn't a problem,  and I find this change acceptable given the story.In conclusion, I really wanted to love XCOM2, I really enjoyed Enemy Unknown and was so hyped to see a sequel to a game I enjoyed so much. So in some ways this is my disappointment talking, XCOM2 feels very unimaginative and doesn't bring anything new and necessary to the series. So for this reason I suggest if you love the series either wait for a sale, or wait and see if there is a DLC release that really opens the game play up (not just a rehash of the previous game please).

number of helpful: 18 of 27 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												XCOM 2 is the sequel to XCOM: Enemy Unknown.  I played over 1000 hours of the first game, including on my Android device, and it was my favourite game of all time... until now.  If you're looking for negatives, scroll to the bottom.  Otherwise, I'm going to discuss all the things about this game that make it better than its predecessor.  (Other than the procedurally generated maps; the feature I was most excited about before the game launched.  The maps feel handcrafted and still provide near endless variation.)XCOM 2 is a genuine sequel, not a polished re-skin with a few new buttons.  This game is a sequel in terms of story, your opponents, and even the difficulty level.  For that reason, if you haven't played XCOM: EU, I recommend you begin there.  Despite my experience with the previous game, XCOM 2 destroyed me on my first attempt, at the difficulty level I played most on EU.  I'm thrilled about that because fans like myself can experience the challenge, the rush, the highs and lows of the war, and those moments when everything's so intense that your heart pounds but you keep on playing!The story and the characters in the campaign have been improved immensely.  The tutorial introduces you to them, and the setting, through a series of story missions that'll make you feel connected to them in a way you never did in XCOM: EU.  As the story goes on, the connection you feel to each character continues to develop, and the story might stay with you for a long time.  In addition, the ending is much more thrilling and rewarding than the end of XCOM: EU--however, this game makes that somewhat disappointing ending into a spectacular one, and then goes on to give you an even better ending in XCOM 2!The strategy layer of the game has been significantly enhanced in XCOM 2 as well.  In the past you could do research and construction however you wanted, but that isn't the case in XCOM 2.  No more watching the hologlobe spin while you pass time at the base either--now the Geoscape is like a board game.  Your decisions on the strategic layer have a major impact on the way the game plays out, and the aliens are also playing their own game against you.  You'll need to adjust your strategy on the fly to counter the aliens' projects and prevent their victory.Additionally, the tactical gameplay is better than ever--and that's where XCOM has always been strongest.  Many games try to copy the tactical combat of XCOM, and you might hear games described as "like XCOM."  I assure you that having two actions per soldier per turn, and a cover mechanic, DOES NOT qualify a game to be declared "like XCOM."  The number of enemies and their combat abilities, combined with psychological effects your soldiers can suffer, really sets this game apart from imitators.  In XCOM 2, you're fighting to liberate the world from an occupying collective of aliens that has superior technology, and many missions will feel impossible--even with fully trained troops, using the best gear.Last but not least, the audio in this game is phenomenal!  The cinematic scenes and sound effects are as good as a blockbuster action movie.  The voice acting is impressive, and the dialogue feels natural.  The music enhances every moment of the game; from ramping up the tension in the most threatening combat situations, to relaxing you after a hard-fought battle.Negatives:1.  XCOM 2 has some bugs and performance issues at launch, but keeping regular saves and back-up saves will prevent some frustrating issues.  I had one crash during my first 65 hours of play, and the save file got corrupted.  I do not recommend playing in Ironman mode until the game is patched.2.  Some people don't like the pressure of turn timers on some missions.  I love the timers because the tension is part of what makes XCOM 2 special, but not everyone wants to play a game that requires skill.  Don't worry, however, as there's already a mod to take away the timer if you just can't play the game as it was intended to be played.3.  It will probably be several years before XCOM 3 comes out.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2016
												A strong 2nd effort in reimagining the Xcom series.  They came up with new mechanics that added something to the decision making, specifically the replacement of the pointless interceptor piece w/ a campaign map you fight to recapture from the aliens.  Coupled with time pressure both on the campaign map and on missions (which love it or hate it does change the game dynamic) and you'e got a new take on a familiar turn based game that adds purpose and context to the missions by providing a larger picture objective.  I really liked taking back control of what I was doing at the strategic level, in the last one (which I still loved) firing up satellites was the entire extent of the strategy invovled in the campaign level.The one reservation I have is with the DLC which was uniformly underwhelming and not even close to the the DLC Enemy Within from the 1st one.  This time Firaxis phoned it in with cosmetics and DLC that only made the game harder not more interesting.Base game: big thumbs up, DLC thumbs down

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												I can't recommend it. All the right ingredients are there, and it should be the best XCOM game ever made according to the sum of its features.Yet the restrictive turn counters that appear in most missions utterly ruin the game, and indeed go against what has always been XCOMs central concept. No longer do you carefully plan your way to victory, but instead find yourself scrambling to rush to an objective completely arbitrarily. Apart from anything else, it simply restricts the way you can play a mission. In the past, if people wanted to rush an objective, that was one of many possible strategies. Now, in most missions, it is the only possible strategy.The problem is only exarcebated because most of the maps are randomised, meaning there is no guarantee an objective is even completeable in the time allowed. When your entire squad can be wiped out on failure of certain mission types, this becomes a simply inexcusable and frankly game ruining design feature.In all other aspects this is a truly fantastic game, and those 1 out of 10 missions where there are no timers can be incredibly gripping. But knowing that a potentially game ending mission (through no fault of my own) could be just around the corner makes it increasingly difficult for me to play this.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												A very shaky launch for this one.  Performance is pathetic.  In 2016 we have to talk about "optimization"?  This is why people play consoles.  Mission timers on every mission.  You'll have between 6-8 turns to get across the map and do something.  Squad wipes are very common as you rush forward into danger.  If you werent a save-scummer in the previous XCOM, you will be with this one.  If the timer runs out, you lose the mission and your squad.  So, the combination of poorly crafted code resulting in choppy performance on top-tier systems and the dubious design decision to make every mission on a timer is not worth full price right now.  Wait for a substantial sale or at least a patch from Firaxis.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												-Review may change-I can recommend this game if all the issues are fixed, BUT right now, AT THIS CURRENT TIME, if i were you, i would wait until the bugs, imbalances and core problems are fixed, because right now it makes the game barely functional. Take note that my review is from only having played the very old Xcom games, and not any of the recent titles. (im a bit of an oldie gamer). A lot of people are saying the same thing, the cons outweigh the pros.-=PROS:=-A) The Overwatch system is a great new addition to the game, the ability to setup an ambush from stealth is a great way to open a fight, however..it comes with its own problems (See Cons 'A')B) The graphics, music and voice acting are all amazing here apart from 'The Council's voice...never liked that movie-voice dude, its a bit too over-the-top > to > just plain annoying, TALK PROPERLY DAMMIT.C) I love how you can customize your characters and even import/export your friends characters to the game, making every soldier in this game someone you care about, and not just another worthless grunt. You CARE about your teammembers.D) I love how destructible the maps are.-=CONS:=-A) Unfair Enemy advantages, leading to poor balance where 'save-scumming' is the only way to win (repeatedly saving again and again until there is actually a possible way to win or proceed. See below:a1) Enemies have a free movement action DURING YOUR TURN when discovered rather than at the end of your turn, meaning your overwatch ambush from stealth, (which hasnt yet been finished being setup), isnt allowed to be finished during your turn because the free movement action allows your enemies to run away or take cover before you have applied Overwatch to your teammembers. This is highly unfair when NOT discovered. This almost removes the fact that it is a turn-based game, when your enemies are breaking the most basic rule of a turn-based game. If they can move during your turn, as they are now, it makes completing missions almost impossible in a high number of missions because YOU dont have the advantage of moving however the f### you please when its not your turn.a2) Enemies are given an unfair amount of action points which seems to change repeatedly. For example, (and you'll know what i mean if you have played) Players are limited to 2 action points, enemies however seem to breach this. I had a Viper who MOVED, TONGUE-PULLED, COILED, and ACID SPIT the rest of the team all in the same turn, turning my winning game, into a lost one, in a single turn that was not possible to defend against. Another example are Stun Baton soldiers, who are given 2 Running actions, and are still allowed to attack, which leads to another gamebreaking problem:a3) Most Enemies are all given very unfair 'INSTANT KILL' and 'INSTANT INCAPACITATE' abilities, which are able to be carried out from absurd distances. 1: Viper Tonguepull into coils from 8 spaces away, through 5 'Full Cover' walls (another bug/exploit). 2: Mindcontrol from 12 spaces away (meaning your team has to make a suicide run up to the controller to stop it, meaning, you're screwed 3: Stun Baton from over 10 spaces away -.-, the list of Instant-Kill abilities just goes on, which are super unfair considering my next point:a4) Your team size is limited to between 4-6, you can end up in fights against 20 aliens at the same time...meaning they get far more turns to kill you, and most aliens (see a3) can choose, whenever they feel like, to instantly kill your whole team in a way you cannot defend against, with no counter especially early-to-mid game, way before their turn is even over. Xcom original let you take way more soldiers and even tanks into the battlefield, why are we limited to such a small team size? And dont give me that 'Graphical limitation' bullcrap, Xcom ran tonnes of soldiers and aliens at the same time on the Commador Amiga, back in 1994.a5) Cover and Aim, is bugged and broken. Cover doesnt do anything right now, everyone just shoots you or instant-kills you THROUGH it. You can be in an aliens face with a shotgun, whilst flanking, from behind with a 95% chance to hit (why the hell isnt it 100%) and that 95% shot will ACTUALLY miss 50% of the time. Now i know Xcom is about RNG, im a very experience player of these types of game, but the Aim RNG is actually BROKEN. The % shown to you is not actually the correct %. Many many more players are confirming the same bug. You can actually shoot enemies, and they can shoot you, through Solid Rock, and multiple thick layers of alien metal and still hit you for full damage....wtf is going on here, FIX THIS FIRAXIS.a6) Some missions are so hard, that you can die on your very first turn, wth NO way to survive it, and given no control whatsoever to prevent it. I started a mission to protect a village from attack, (early game too) and had 2 heavy armor units, 3 special health-regen enemies, 2 mind control units, and 5 Advent soldiers who had all started, spawned right in front of my face at the beginning of the mission....they of course Instantly got a Free Movement Action during MY TURN DAMMIT, and then once i told them to take cover it didnt matter..the mission was impossible, and was Instant-death from the moment i came out of the Mission Start screen -.- this is BROKEN. Holy crap i think im done with point A.B) There's no time to do anything in the world. The moment you want to collect a resource, 10 major disasters will happen the moment you want to attempt to get some basic income going, even at the beginning of the game, collecting basic Starter resources gets you screwed over. These disasters and events seriously need reducing in frequency. If you dont do them, the penalties are so harshe theyre too easy to ruin the rest of your game right from the beginning! It's too much of a rush.C) When you do the final misison (no spoilers of course) the game is just OVER. No more freeroaming no more 'confront alien invaders' its just THE END. You cannot continue playing......WTF Firaxis. This needs to change, once the story mode is over, random alien attacks, missions and enemy ships should still be happening, like the good old days of Xcom where the game mode is Infinitely long and you can continue playing to your hearts content.D) No Skyranger VS UFO Ship  battles and downed-ship invasions to recover parts like the good days of Xcom (how Xcom was supposed to be played), if you run into a UFO, the game just goes "You have instantly lost, defend your ship" or in other words, GAME OVER, lets just drag out your slow death by rubbing it in your face for the next hour.E) The Avatar Project timer which limits everything you do to a GAME OVER timer, ruins the game for me, seriously just remove it entirely and go back to the classic Endless Mode of the 90's. I dont want the duration of my game to be limited and then END when its the end of the game...it makes all my efforts feel pointless, because The End means you cant play anymore.F) No friendly fire means you can shoot a minigun at an enemy who is engaged in melee with several other squadmates with no penalties or chance of them being hit. This is just WRONG and senseless when you watch a cutscene of 100 bullets go literally through your allies to hit an enemy, friendly fire needs to return.-and many many more issues.HOWEVER....all is not lost here. The game feels amazing to play, this review could easily change to RECOMMEND if Firaxis does the following:1) Fix the bugs, many of them are gamebreakers.2) Work HARD on balance, because you have a LOT OF WORK to do here.3) Allow greater squad sizes +Tank/Heavy Armor like the good days of Xcom. This game is a downgrade from the 1994 systems, and those fit onto a 2.4mb floppy disk -.-4) Bring back ENDLESS MODE, no Xcom veteren wants the fight againstthe alien to just 'end'. -.-5) Bring back SHIP - VS - SHIP battles

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Awesome addition to the XCOM games! Quick rundown:+ Graphics look good & unit customization is great+ Solder pool allows you to save favorite looking solders, or import other people's solders. One from the pool may show up in game as a solder, engineer that has to be rescused, or even an enemy informant you need to kidnap or kill!+ Maps look great, and are all of a good size, as well as variety+ Enemies are varied, with more types than before. Aliens are actually a threat!+ Tons of different items for solders to use (various granades, ammo types, gun mods)+ Turn based missions make overwatch turtling an impossible strategy, which was pretty much the I-Win-Button for XCOM EU/EW. Also adds a sense of urgency.+ Ranged heals+ New classes are well designed and have some neat perks- Some performance issues. Sometimes there's a 5 - 10 second pause at the start of the enemy turn. Sometimes on the enemy turn the screen will go black. Sometimes FPS tanks for no discernible reason.- Navigating multi-floored buildings just as much of a pain as XCOM:EU/EW- While I find the time limit missions (which seem to be about 50% of them) fine, I think extending the timer by two turns on a mission would help out the casual XCOM players.- Russian & Polish languages missing. These were added in Enemy Within (along with localization), and should have remained. Even if Firaxis didn't localise there for XCOM 2, I'm sure a copy/paste of sound files from EW would have pleased those overseas. Though I am of neither nationality, I did like my Russian & Polish solders speaking their language, and hope this is implemented in the future.

number of helpful: 85 of 153 people (56%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 23, 2016
												I am overall disappointed with the game, being an XCOM enthusiast. I've played XCOM1 for 255 hours, but I do not feel like giving XCOM2 more than the 55ish hours I gave it so farXCOM2 follows the same pattern the previous games did: start with rookies, study alien tech, build some armors and weapons, learn psionics, find a way to the aliens' base and destroy it, and have your base attacked at least once in the process. There's even pretty much the same tech development - assault rifles into magnetic guns (laser guns) and then plasma. Only 3 armor tech levels too. Sure, there are modifications and some fancy variations of weapons and armors, but that's still underwhelming. This is hardly an improvement on XCOM1:EW. I expected XCOM2 to be much more developed than EW, but it's merely on par. It's not even longer than XCOM1.The final mission is also an insult to the player. I don't want to spoil the surprise here, but it was not just difficult, the designers made it simply unfair. I was about to prevail against the odds, when the crucial enemy I needed to kill teleported away to the other end of the gigantic map leaving me sorrounded by a dozen enemies. The game is a bit glitchy and unstable - hopefully there will be patches in the future to fix that. Fortunately, not everything is gamebreaking, but I had to restart the game and steam several times in my playthrough. Frozen cutscenes, cutscenes displayed more than once, disappearing/stuttering/looped audio. Currently, it is not worth its full price - I recommend waiting for discounts. What is perhaps the most puzzling is the poor design of gameplay. Sometimes I would roar in frustration because I had to listen to the same dialogues over and over again after restarting a mission and there was no way to skip it - the apogeum of frustration are the terror missions. The game still hijacks the camera away from you (I think I know better what I want to look at, thanks). Also, does the cam really have to center on the soldier I switch to every time? Lots of your time will be wasted for no reason at all (I recommend getting some mods to fix that - they don't change any balance, such as Quiet Bradford) because apparently you need full 10-15 seconds to be told that there has been progress on the Avatar project. There are several improvements though: waypoint soldier movement, reloading does not end the turn anymore, more class balance, diversified enemies, diversified terrain, soldier customization, simplified base build-up, melee attacks (finally!!!). I might have forgotten some things, but they certainly do not change my opinion of the game.

number of helpful: 22 of 35 people (63%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												Jeez, I really like XCOM, however, at the moment it is difficult to recommend.In a lot of ways this sequel is a move in the right direction. The game makes you feel pressured and you often have to decide on the best of two bad options. The field game is a lot more in depth and plays a lot more like old school X-Com. that said there are a lot of problems. Some of this stuff can be fixed with patches, however, on some level the game is just fundamentally flawed.It's hard, and I'm fine with that, XCOM should be hard, though I feel a lot of the time it's hard in the wrong ways. The missions often have time limits, and that's okay in itself but combine that with the way aliens enter the fight (they become active in packs of 2-3 as soon as one of your soldiers spots one of the pack, at which point they get a free move to cover) means that it is never smart to push out more than a few spaces a turn. If you discover a pack with your penultimate or last move of a round, 2-3 strong aliens get a free move to cover (or, even worse flank you) and then have a whole round to take down a couple of guys.The game pushes you forward with time limits and then punishes you for moving forward at even a moderate rate.Also, a lot of people seem to feel melee is OP, I'm not sure I'd agree with that, but I don't think it feels very good. If you run up and take a sword swipe at something and miss, that soldier is probably dead.The geoscape gameplay is not very well explained either, I'd advise treating your first game as a throwaway until you get the hang of how that works.Lastly, this game is really badly optimised, lots and lots of slowdowns, the game hanging for 5-10 seconds. Lots of gaps in the action, you'll throw a grenade, and there is significant gaps between the grenade being thrown, exploding, damage being dealt and the next action taking place.This game does have a lot of potential, but I don't think they can change the gameplay enough with patches to really make the gameplay coherent, the mechanics complementary and the difficulty.tough but fair.

												This is a rantLong version: new vs old gameWith mods this game is pretty good considering only 1 of the DLC's (Shen's Gift) is any good. if only they would add secondwave options, and somehow get the enemy within stuff with a third faction and gene mods while increasing the turns allowed in turn attack missions. The soldiers and abilities in this game are not as strong as in the old game (dont listen to totalbiscut) while the enemies are much stronger. they have removed key things in this game, such as proper base building like in the first one, Rockets are gon unless you use a heavy or power weapon with the powered armor. snapshot for snipers is gone (but they do start off with squad sight(and mods bring back snapshot)) SHIV's are gone (though they really werent vital in anyway) they completely removed air combat and medals are gone too. you dont even need to get psi troops to finish the game. this game is more cinamatic then the old one, more story driven. bradford gets facial hair and is much more annoying in this game. Terror missions are harder because you must save atleast 6/14 people or fail. the maps are much more diverse. and the game is buggy (say if you want a soldier to move right there behind cover the game might make a snap second option to send them right into the middle of an enemy group out of spite, because you are doing well)short version: new game vs old oneweapons-weakerabilities-weaker or equal toenemies-strongergameplay options-way lessDLC-3 of 4 are badMods-INSANELY AWESOME THERE ARE SO MANY!!!!!!!(they make up for the lack luster dlc)how attached can you get to a soldier?-Very. you can write their own epitaphcustomization- A LOTvoices-missing a few different countries but mods can bring you voices like deadpool, Lara Croft, Lana Kane, Homer, or even Duke Nukem , Ripely, Freemans Mind and much more.bugs-commonsecondwave - Nomedals - Nonot considering mods XCOM EW has much much more then this game content and gamplaywise. But XCOM is a decent game so thumbs up for new things!

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												Fun, brutal, and oh so unforgiving. This is truly what a sequel should be, improving on the bad, making the good better, adding some new features, and taking away anything unecessary. This game feels exactly like the original (the one in 2011) and former Xcom players will have no problems jumping in. Likewise, newcomers will find this game to be a bit harsh at first if they don't know what they're doing or if they don't know what the best strategy is, though there are lots of guides to help with that. To me though, the hardest part definitely comes in management. The Avatar Project, or the main thing you're fighting, can only be slown down by certain operations, it's no longer the take your time that we're used to in EW, but it still can feel a lot like it the further in the game you go. On a similar note, combat has been revamped and with all the other people talking about concealment and timed missions, I won't go into it, though I will say I like both. Another good thing is the multitude of ways to finish missions. In EW it was straight up kill all enemies or rescue certain amount of civs then kill all enemies. Now, there are missions such as hostage rescue, comm defense, comm destruction, vip capturing, and even detonating bases. The way they all function is great as well, they have multiple ways of finishing them, you can either go in guns blazing with a full squad, or use a lone soldier to capture an objective and then high tale it out without killing anyone. In general, it's a fun game and a great way to feel mad after seeing your rookies constantly mess up. 9/10

Especially not when compared to XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Enemy Within which is one of my all time favorite games.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												I've been on the fence about whether I should review this or not for a while: I'm going to open with that slightly cheeky statement "I wish there were a neutral button."But, I really do. The reason I've gone with "Not Recommended" is because, frankly, for me it didn't do enough better than EU - and it actually makes several aspects of the gameplay worse. There's still a lot to like, though, and I think if you read all the Steam reviews and on balance think you wouldn't care about the negative aspects people have noted, then I would say it's worth a punt because a lot of people genuinely seem to love this game (especially professional game reviewers) ... which makes me wonder whether maybe I'm just bad at it. The game has clearly been lovingly made, as well - and for what it's worth I didn't experience many bugs at all really (GTX 970, Ivy Bridge i5 unlocked). If anything I had a less buggy run than I did with EU. There seem to be plenty of people on Steam listing the game's flaws (as I perceive them) in great detail and I don't think another such review is needed: in short, the various timers spoil things too much and the game is, frankly, just too difficult too much of the time. I saw a guy on here saying that he "plays games to relax" and complaining that "XCOM 2 was too stressful", and I kind of agree with that from my own personal perspective; but the real problem for me is the fact that the game doesn't actually really handle the stressful aspects very well... Constantly being badgered by Central on the map and basically everybody else makes much of the experience feel like busywork rather than a rewarding, fair, and appropriately challenging one. And on the battlefield, simple mistakes (honestly in my case sometimes because of the UI being so sensitive), resulted in devastating consequences for my outfit. This basically forced me to save scum even when I didn't want to, since it seemed like the game was trying so hard to stop me from doing that. Which, I guess you could say, is incongruous.  So, I reluctantly give this game a thumbs down. Rarely have I seen such a big dichotomy between "average player" reviews and "professional" reviews, which is quite interesting in itself and that's what led me to want to write this ... but I feel like maybe someone might read this review alongside the others and think twice about spending what might be quite hard-earned cash on this and get something else they've been looking forward to playing, instead. With refunds I guess that's less of an issue nowadays. Anyway, like I said, people obviously really cared making this game: it's just that I don't think the design choices the developers went with to try to make this a unique experience that stands out from its predecessor make all that much sense.

												I tried reallly hard to like this game. But I failed. Most of the gameplay is all about RNG, which is uttelry infuriating. Seeing how your Sniper Guy misses an easy shot with 90% hit chance, which causes a chain of events that kills half of your team is just.. not enjoyable.I also despise the fact, that those "rulers" can appear on ANY mission - even the ones which have a restricted amount of turns  AND are crucial to the outcome of the "Avatar" Project (practically a "you-lose-no-matter-what-event", that has a countdown over the whole game process (who thought this was a fun game design???)) until you automatically lose the battle. So either you can decide between sacrificing your soldiers and completing the mission, or play safe and maybe still lose some soldiers and also the mission. Even if you are a cheap cheat and use save files to reload your game, you still might not be able to win.. sooo.. yeah, that't that.The missions feel kind of repetitive after a while, except for the "ruler" events (they ♥♥♥♥ you up most likely and make you want to uninstall the game)
