content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												I just can't recommend this game. I'm a long term fan of the franchise with 100+ hours in EU. XCOM2 just fights me at every turn. It's more frustrating than fun. The difficulty seems moreso frontloaded than XCOM is known for, so I'm not entirely sure this game is for newcomers to the franchise either.I sat back and asked myself, was I having fun playing this game? Not much fun to be had in getting punished for playing honestly without reloading in the form of post-combat debuffs (gravely wounded for 5/7 hp? sure, thanks for that). XCOM2 feels like it just devolves into reloading the last save (which takes a bit) until you get the desired result.I usually enjoy difficulty and challenge (granted this example is cross-genre, but Bloodborne is one of my top 5 favorite titles of all time) but XCOM2 feels contrived and frustrating. I don't get any satisfaction after overcoming a level, instead I found myself breathing a sigh of relief that I was just done with the mission.I'm sure there's fun to be had here; it's just not for me.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												This is a poor excuse for a tactical game.  Strategic elements are entertaining and interesting.  I find it challenging that attempting to gather resources may cost you in the long run because it forces you to choose between gathering or accomplishing missions rather than being able to achieve both.  In terms of tactical combat, this is a terrible game.  The cover system is horribly flawed.  Elevation plays no impact in the game whatsoever.  Having a good angle on an opponent means nothing if their plane of cover is between you and your target.  Fog of war prevents you from being able to make rational ambushes more than once per mission.  It's as though the game is designed around quick saving because they can't come up with a more creative engine, just nerf certain aspects such as overwatch.  Honestly had way more fun with the Front Mission series.  It's not that I expected this game to be that series, it's that it doesn't offer anything more than it.  A good tactical game should allow you to recover from an initial mistake if you play your cards right, not heavily punish you for scouting fog of war.  If you're going to make it so enemies can instantly discover me behind cover, you may as well make them all aware of my presence after the first ambush.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												EDIT: Comments and further research have shown that whether or not the game runs fluently has less to do with the power of your PC but hardware lottery. Some people with terrible machines have it run just fine, while others with beastly monstrosities have experienced all sorts of issues. There seem to be a lot more people with problems than without, so you may not even be able to have this game run fluently if you do have a supercomputer.ATTENTION: If you work at NASA or have access to the computing power of IBM's WATSON, you will find this to be a fantastic game. Otherwise, you will have big problems with performance where there should be none, not to mention the fact that this game is buggier than a square kilometre of the Amazon rainforest.XCOM 2 is, gamewise, a worthy successor to XCOM. It may not feature the full range of contents yet, and the story is a♥♥♥♥♥♥poor as you'd expect, but if you bought this expecting something on par with Mass Effect, you should not have. XCOM is about shooting aliens, machines, and alien-human hybrids (seeing as the players cannot be expected to simply be fighting human soldiers who have threwn their lot in with the alien overlords), and if good turn-based tactics and moments of euphoria followed by indomitable rage are what you're into, this game is for you. Sadly, it seems Firaxis somehow managed to do many of the things it did right terribly wrong. Yes, there is full modding support (as in: the tools the devs had, we had available on day 1), but the documentation on it is spotty at best. The character pool was a great idea, but it turned out to be an unweildy and unecessarily complicated feature. Not saying you wont get the hang of it, but once the ranger guy you carefully worked out to be an insane brute becomes a specialist because the game refuses to use the class you specified you'll be quite mad, I assure you.This is also one of the better sides of the game: the mods. The community is already hard at work, and some fantastic groundwork has been laid out, so you can be sure great things will follow. Firaxis loves the modders already, and maybe that is because they hope they can figure out a way to improve the horrendous performance, but the encouragement people are getting can only be rivalled by Bethesda. And seeing as EVERYTHING is moddable, workarounds for everything you don't like about the game will be available soon enough.Still, I cannot recommend the game in its current state. Wait until they fixed the performance and the modding scene is a little bigger, and this will be well worth your money.

												Ok this is not gona be easy to say but some one must say it.The game is not finished. After installation i could play for 3 min before game froze and i was forced to restart my training mission. That is your first mission to do (That is also forced on you). So game out of box is not functional. But after deleting one file (Documents\My Games\XCOM2\XComGame\SaveData profile.bin). The game works fine. And i could go on and explore Xcom2.The game looks nice, and it feels nice in the eyes. With all the shadows and light laying down correctly on the characters and ships and consoles when you look around in your HQ that can fly !  And it have big potencial for mods with accessories and stuff. But what i feel the game lacks big time and is a game breaker is the % to hit stuff. I was playing the game and having a blast when i got the game to run. But i fast feelt that some thing was odd and strange about the game. It took for ever to do some thing in game. And when i have done some thing. I way often missed all the shoots my characters was taking. If i had like 50% or more to hit, i oftenly shoot around the enemy. But if i had under 50% to hit. I more oftenly did hit !. And it did not mater if the target had cover or was running or if it was a long distance. It hits !So i started to get iritated by it. And after lite more game time i was raging. I know and i do feel that Xcom is a game that should be hard and unforginving if you do a wrong move. But even tho i do it correctly as much that i could. But i keept on loosing and loosing and loosing. Even tho the mission it self says Easy. No way ! No way ever ! In my eyes the game is rigged and incorrectly built. And all i can say is that Xcom2 have allot of problems that Xcom:Enemy Unknown had. So in my eyes Dev's have not put in enugh effort to fix old problems to the new game that they know was there.I do not recomend this game in it current state (2016-02-14). I am gona shelf this game and hope for a big update to fix this un-balanced rolls and hit %. Before i even think of opening the game again. If you have purchased the game or if your thinking of buying the game. Refund your money if you can. And then wait for the game to be fixed before you support this game.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												First off I will point out that I am enjoying the game to an extent and I will put more hours into it, but I am giving it a thumbs down because of the aggressive mission timers.  They ruin the pace and strategy of the game for me and force you down one path - rushing the objective.  In a single player turn based strategy game I like to take my time and try different ways of achieving the objective.  One suggestion would be to make it so the timer doesn't even start ticking until you are out of stealth at the start of the mission, but overall I just don't like the timers.  I certainly don't think that they should be in 75% of the missions.  If timed missions came up around 10% of the time I would be OK with it, so maybe it is a question of not enough diversity in the mission types?Hopefully the modding community can sort this problem out.The other problem is the performance of the game, which I have found to be all over the place, and I have a pretty good PC (i7 4790k, GTX970, 16GB RAM, SSD).

												WAIT!!!!I love this game, i love it so much. I played this game right after playing xcom enemy within and nearly everything has improved. It chugs when loading the main menu and missions, it chugs when you throw a grenade, it chugs when something explodes, it chugs when the aliens take a turn or do literally everything. This game would be a glowing reccomendation from me , but until these nonsensical performance issues are fixed, dont buy it. Wait till a sale or for when the issues are patched

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												It has been stated before, but i just have to say it again.The game is basically a nice improvement over the first part, but two very annoying issues drive the fun out very quickly.The first one is the mission timers. Timed missions were the curse of the first part, because all the nice setups you can plan in this kind of game just need to be hurried and you cannot explore with a timer. This happens almost every single mission now. The entire laid-back feeling that made the XCOM series great for all that time is gone with this single change. It wouldnt be so bad if this happened to b the occasional odd-one-out timed mission. But it is almost every single one.The same principle applies to the whole campaign by the way. Your only have the illusion of choosing your goals in the campaign, because the very narrow time limit has you chasing after primary objectives and the means necessary to acces them (contacts/intel) all the time. This always hectic feeling really squelches the fun out of what could be a prime gaming experience.The second issue is the ridicoulous low performance and memory leaks.The in-combat performance is really low on default settings, but can actually be tweaked via lowering graphic options to manageable levels. The bigger problem here is a kind of stuttering that is introduced after you run the game for some time. Usually starts with slightly longer breaks between turns, missions or changing a screen on the campaign map. The longer you play, the longer the pauses, until you feel like the game freezes every couple of seconds.Now this feels like something that could be patched in time, so the question remains: why on gods green earth does every premium developer nowadays resort to releasing half baked products?

content:
Posted: August 14, 2016
												This will be my first review ever.This game is not remotely as much fun as the previous one. The game is totally different and feels unpolished. Enemies will shoot you through floors/roofs. When in overwatch, my players will fire at enemies through the roof/floor as well. It makes for difficult game play when the game gives you an x amount of moves to complete the stage. You can't play tactically, for its a rush from the begining just not to run out of turns. The turns system ruins it for me. I like exploring the stage and getting my snipers in good positions. You will get let say 12 turns to extract a scientist and then get to the extraction point. To move to the scientist will take about 3 - 4 turns without encountering any enemies. To then move to the extraction point will take atleat another 3 - 4 turns without any enemies. Throwing enemies into the mix makes that you have to blindly just move forward and hope you choose good positions for you don't know where the enemies are. When you get the scientist the AI will drop enemies straight in the path to the extraction so if your players miss shots that says 70% chance, and they hit you, you barely have time to heal them. When they are hit they will be unavailable for a few missions.I am not happy I purchased the game. I don't mind playing difficult games, but taking the part that I enjoyed out ruins it for me. Other players might enjoy it, I don't.

number of helpful: 84 of 153 people (55%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 13, 2016
XCOM 2 had the potential to be a bigger and more accessible game than its predecessor, but this sad fact only makes its resulting mediocrity all the more disappointing.XCOM 2 continues on from the events of XCOM: Enemy Unknown and things play out in much the same way as they did before. Players once gain assume the mantle of commander and must oversee an entire war against the alien menace, organising strike teams, and researching better weapons and upgrades that will (hopefully) result in victory.The aliens rule Earth now though and they've installed their own Orwellian world government that regulates every aspect of life on the planet. XCOM is no longer the sanctioned anti-alien outfit it used to be either; now it's a downtrodden rebel alliance intent on ousting the ADVENT council through covert tactics and guerilla warfare.It's a fresh setup that brings new pressures to the planning phase. Your role as commander is as all-encompassing as it was before and your duties have expanded to include some interesting new responsibilities. You'll need to make contact with rebel settlements across the globe and construct communication relays in order to improve your network of resources. The aliens are more proactive too so you'll need to work fast in order to counter their battle plans whilst reserving time to investigate the numerous points of interest that appear on the world map.This simulation side to XCOM 2's wider gameplay makes a good first impression and it provides some of the most thoughtful, if a little vague, decision-making moments that the game has to offer. The aliens' ominous Avatar Project acts as a game-ending timer for your actions at large. Answering distress calls and investigating supply sites costs valuable time and with each passing in-game month the project's completion bar ticks forward another space. Not wasting time is critical to your ongoing success and it means knowing when to make sacrifices in order to focus on the big picture.The turn-based battles themselves have undergone dramatic changes with all of the showy muzzle flashes and tactical manoeuvrings being right where Firaxis left them. And yet, combat is also the first noticeable area where XCOM 2 as an experience begins to completely break down.Nearly every mission in XCOM 2 is timed and success will often be measured by how quickly you can complete objectives before the timer expires. Whilst the objectives themselves are varied enough (kidnap a VIP, disarm an explosive etc.) the whole approach of limiting turns is completely at odds with the game's otherwise methodical turn-based gameplay. Carefully positioning your snipers and moving your forces between cover spaces is no longer a vital tactic as much as it is a luxury. Missions too often devolve into a mad dash towards another arbitrary point of interest and in a game that features character permadeath as a core gameplay mechanic, players will be re-loading their saves constantly.This change in direction also highlights the new concealment system which masks your squad's position until the first bullet is fired. As a pseudo form of stealth, concealment allows your soldiers to get close to an enemy's position without immediately prompting return fire. Once concealment is broken though, it's pretty much lost for the remainder of the battle and any new enemies that enter line-of-sight at this time will be immediately alerted to your presence. This is incredibly annoying when your squad has already exhausted their actions for that turn as it leaves them completely wide open to attack and with XCOM being XCOM, you can always bet on losing at least one soldier in the crossfire.Adding to this difficulty are several early game enemies that will happily wreak havoc upon your squad. The vcious snake people and Sectoid powerhouses have upwards of eight health points a piece and they have no qualms about binding, disorientating, or even mind-controlling your troops into submission. The ADVENT Stun Lancers are even more obnoxious in this regard as their huge movement pool allows them to cross the length of the battlefield (often ignoring retaliation fire) to strike your troops down, often in a single blow.Enemies of this ilk are indeed a fine challenge when you consider how blissfully overpowered humans can get after a few levels, but when you're meeting these game-changing foes as early as mission 2 - a point where your squad can barely muster together a basic medkit - then it makes for a very unpleasant difficulty curve. Hearing that this is a very hard game probably won't come as much surprise considering the series' reputation for brutal difficulty, but XCOM 2 always feels cheap before it does challenging.It's also worth mentioning that whilst the variety of enemies is strong (maybe even too strong), their anthropomorphised designs seem a tad stale. The new foot soldiers fit snugly into that 'dudes in armour' category, the existing Sectoid enemies have completely lost their quirkiness, and the snake warriors actually appear to have breasts for some reason. Similarly, the design of the infuriating new Codex enemy is so nonsensical in this regard that Firaxis Games should really be charged with first-degree Deviant Art baiting.The "scarier" alien designs in XCOM 2 are also indicative of how seriously everything is treated this time around. Your communications manager called Central is a walking microcosm of this shift; his newly grizzled face and loss of charisma gelling awkwardly with an inability to keep his mouth shut. Like the world's most annoying project coordinator, he is always on your case. Everything is "ASAP" with this guy and he rarely stops explaining to you how "time is running out", or how "civilians are dying", or how you're presently doing a cruddy job at spinning all of these plates he's put in front of you.Now in some ways XCOM 2 does improve on the formula established by its prequel. The base-building system is leaner for one, it's much easier to heal troops in the heat of battle, and the achievements are more interesting this time around. It's a visually impressive game too especially during those cutaways that show the soldiers (or aliens) gunning down their quarry in a blaze of plasma fire. And yet the game can be dreadfully slow when in motion. There's a noticeable delay upon issuing orders to your troops and transitioning between menus at XCOM HQ is tedious, especially when you consider how frequently the different departments request your attention.Amid the odd performance concern (I experienced a few stutters and one CTD) there are a few mechanics that just seem weird. Damage indicators sometimes fail to display, troops can't seem to climb into trucks that have had their housing destroyed, and I'm still not sure how how a Viper at street level is able to grapple a sniper crouching atop a three-storey building.The XCOM 2 Digital Deluxe Edition is a mixed bag too. Included in this version are several bonus DLC packs that add more missions to play and equipment to use. Extra weapons and costume parts are always welcome, but the idea of adding more missions is hilarious considering how much stuff you have to deal with already. Your attention is always being diverted by another alert from XCOM HQ or by another distress single or by another painfully slow update to the Avatar Project track.It feels as if Firaxis Games went too far in satisfying the upper 1% of their playerbase. This is an unforgiving game at the best of times and it relies far too heavily on its brutal difficulty to provide a wider sense of character and appeal.Read the full review at my blog »[www.celjaded.com]

Posted: August 15, 2016
												It's only worth it on sale, maybe not even that. Marred by issues, the pros don't outweigh the cons.PROS:* Gorgeous cutscenes, and the graphics are nice when they're not bogged down (which is unfortunately more often than not).* Very interesting narrative and story setup.* Highly customizable units.CONS:* Graphical stutters and lags unlike any game I've played on this machine. I'm sure tweaking the settings would bring it up to speed, but this is unacceptable, my rig should not have to turn down anything for this.* AI takes an obnoxious amount of time to respond sometimes. You could end up waiting up to, say, 15-20 seconds before that last alien makes its decision on what it's going to do. Maybe even longer. I've gone AFK sometimes. That's also unacceptable, and combined with the graphical stutters makes for quite the chore.* On the whole, it's too damn difficult. It feels like I'm fighting against the game makers and they're like "a-HA! gotcha AGAIN!" like they're torturing ants. Or more like, bullying children. Because "oh, it's too hard for you? You're weak, git gud! Hahaha! Have another Codex thrown at your squad!" It's just obnoxious.* On that note, the RNG is very much NOT reflective of itself. I don't know what smokescreen they're trying to pull, because "idk, it's random! you could just have bad luck!" but no. This ain't no bad luck. And early on, getting hit literally once could spell doom for the rest of the mission. Oh wait, that's later on too.* And of course, walls only sporadically work for line of sight. You *could* argue that they're shooting through walls if you've already given away your position--which is fair--but not fair when one squaddie gives away everyone else's position everywhere. And for the rest of the mission.* Stealth/ambush/whatever element makes no sense contrasted with the time limits and "rescue X amount of civilians" elements. I wanted to like this game. A LOT. But frankly it feels like a chore after a while--too much work for not enough pay, so to speak. I'm not about to throw myself at the same missions for hours just to end up being left with a (loaded) dice roll against me as usual and likely a dead squadmate or three if I *happen* to get any luck. I took similar issue with the previous title, but that was significantly more tolerable than this mess.See, these difficult RNG games *can* be fun, I'm all for them, but the problem here is that victory just isn't satisfying enough. You're quickly going to be thrust into a new mission again with a now-broken squad and very little, if anything, more to show for it. So what's the point? To just continue watching my squadmates die while I replenish them with recruits that just end up dying too? Oh, my reward for this mission is a scientist and a smattering of resources? Hardly makes up for the dead and injured.I might seem a little salty--and I am--but it's largely because I got this game on release, and now that I've waited months to try picking it back up again in hopes it's been tweaked to be more fun and technically sound, I'm instead greeted with some weak DLC. Difficulty and gameplay issues aside, it's the technical issues that really just kill it for me, that just adds insult to injury.Overall, while I love the game's presentation, I can't recommend it, but damn it I wish I could.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Years after finishing Enemy Unknown and loving it, I couldn't wait to get XCOM 2. However, after many dozens of failed missions and restarted campaigns later, I just can't recommend this game. It's too random, way too luck-based, more than before, to the point it becomes aggrevating. Countless of times I found myself yelling at the screen when my squad mate misses a target at point blank range with 90% hit chance, only to be gunned down with ease by another enemy 30 yards away. People say "that's XCOM", but I say it's just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. The beginning missions are ridiculously difficult, even at an easier difficulty, your squad mates die constantly, so you have no promoted soldiers and therefore no edge against the enemies. When you complete an objective with barely your squad intact, more reinforcements show up to kill you. I had a scenario where 1 enemy with a stun sword killed my entire team. It's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. It's even worse when you have to complete an objective in X amound of turns, forcing you to hurry and dropping your guard, so you have absolutely no way to plan a careful approach, which is what XCOM is supposed to be all about. Instead, you have some annoying ♥♥♥♥ back at the HQ barking orders at you while he's eating a donut, telling that the Alien relay is closing down, as if you didn't know why you're there in the first place.XCOM 2 is like playing Mount & Blade and selecting "Auto-fight" before every encounter and getting your♥♥♥♥♥kicked by the computer. You can maneuver, yes, but ultimately it all comes down to a dice roll and you will die in situations that would never happen in real life, like missing a shot, when the gun barrel is literally at the enemy's stupid face.There's just so much frustration in this game. Creating a squad of friends and seeing them all die during the first mission is beyond infuriating. To me there's nothing more annoying than an unfair challenge and that's what this game boils down to. Some people get easier missions and scenarios early on so they can build their team, but if you're like me, you just get humiliated again, again, again and again. You start feeling like an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, because you paid full price for a game that makes fun of you at every turn, and forces you to turn down the difficulty, because you're too much of a ♥♥♥♥♥ to play on Ironman like you did in the previous game.It was also plagued with weird gamebreaking bugs, like a zombie ragdoll glitching through the floor and flying around the map, preventing the game from progressing. I have never seen a game, where a round continuing is dependent on whether a random ragdoll is stationary or not. Astounding.Overall, I felt like I was going insane while playing this game, I almost broke my mouse and my keyboard. If you buy this game, you might have an easier time, but I'd rather shove a pineapple up my♥♥♥♥♥than play it again.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												XCOM 2 is a turn-based strategy developed by Firaxis and published by 2K Games. It is a direct sequel to the previous XCOM: Enemy Unknown and the expansion XCOM: Enemy Within.In XCOM 2, follows the story where the XCOM lose the war to the alien. The aliens rule Earth, building shining cities that promise a brilliant future for humanity on the surface, while concealing a sinister agenda and eliminating all who dissent from their new order. So they said it, we are now on the offensive on XCOM 2. With only limited resources, XCOM must retake back Earth from the ADVENT.XCOM 2 gameplay are quite similiar with XCOM: Enemy Unknown, but plays differently. In fact, you feel like you already knew how it plays out until you see the timer. Yes, each mission has a time limit to reach certain objectives. But most people describe it wrong as a turn timer or whatever it is they said. The truth is, it's a turn limit to reach certain objectives such as hacking a device, rescuing VIP or destroying key objectives. Most of them if completed, then the timer is gone and you can have all the time you want to kill the enemy. NOT all missions has this turn limit objectives however. Overwatch in XCOM 2 is even more powerful I think, even if some people didn't like the turn limit, overwatch now doesn't trigger all at once, they trigger one by one that you can be sure every overwatch is count. Base building retains the same element but building adjacent bonuses are gone, instead you get to upgrades with resources. The global map have been changed too. Since you have a mobile headquarters, in the global map, you need to move from place to place to scan for resources, intel or even contacting resistance on other location.There is this thing called Avatar Project or simply AP by the community, I think, it renders your campaign has time limit which you have to act fast to delay or setback the project progress. You can do this by assaulting alien bases or hacking then kill the alien codex. There's also Dark Event, which some kind of random even that if left unchecked will, I say again WILL give you disadvantage and give the alien an advantage. Like XCOM: Enemy Unknown abduction mission, not all Dark Event mission can't be completed, you have to choose which you think is the best... or the worse. All of this makes your campaign has faster pace then the previous.Tactical combat also has become more difficult, at least for me. I can see more challenge here. Remember Sectoid? They're not what you remember now, they posses more power and can mess you up if you don't kill them real quick. What about Thin Man? Now you will see the true form of the alien infiltration unit. Soldiers now also has even more useful abilities, some are in fact powerful if you know how to use them. Soldiers can even be upgraded further to gain more advantage, whether it's a weapon or the soldier themselves. Turn limit may be frustrating, but in my opinion they're not as frustrating as some people said.Customization in XCOM 2 are great, I will say huge if they actually add more content or option into it, nevertheless we have modding support. There is a dedicated place where you can create you characters before you even play the campaign. Characters you created can be set to appear as XCOM soldiers, or VIP which is scientist or engineer, or even Dark VIP which will appear on some mission and you must capture them. With mods, customization will be unlimited.Firaxis did improve the graphics and effects on XCOM 2. They look prettier than XCOM: Enemy Unknown. The downside XCOM 2 has is the performance. It is unoptimized that I can barely have FPS above 35. Most of the time I get stutters and lags. Mission loading time is quite long. They need to fix this.Overall, XCOM 2 is a great sequel. Some people don't like the turn limit, but for me, knowing that we are on the offensive with guerilla style warfare, that's just about fair and challenging. With mods support is even better. If only the performance were better on release, I would give XCOM 2 way better score. I recommend XCOM 2.Rating 7/10

content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												XCOM 2 is largely a refinement of and an advancement on XCOM: Enemy Unknown. It honestly doesn't feel like a full sequel. Feels like XCOM: Enemy Unknown 1.5. But that's not really a bad thing. As mentioned, many things have been refined and streamlined, and there have been a host of new additions that do mix things up to a certain degree. Though yes, at the same time, I must say I am a tad disappointed that things aren't more different. So, long story short, if you like XCOM: EU you will most probably like XCOM 2 as well. The campaign length for a first run is around 40-50 hours. Now, the game has some glaring issues. One is optimization. I honestly do not find the graphics to be anything stellar (they don't seem that different from in XCOM EU), but even on the lowest settings I am getting absolutely terrible performance. Another is from time to time, the game can bug out. I hacked a Sectapod successfully, yet somehow it remains out of my control and kills my troops on the next turn. Then there was once a muton who was actually on the roof, but the graphics made it look like it was at the bottom of the roof. And once my scanning went to -3 days (it just bugged out). Gameplay wise, too many enemies are just bullet sponges in the mid-to-late game. Now that I am right at the end of the final mission, I can say that this game suffers the same two issues from XCOM EU. 1) The mid-to-late game is relatively much, much easier than the fiendishly difficult early game. 2) There is no "middle ground" difficulty setting between Veteran (a tad too easy) and Commander (a tad too difficult)This game is a net recommendation actually but I leave a thumbs down until Firaxis can fix the optimization issues at least.

												One for the sales probably. If you can grab it on the cheap a few months down the line when the mods have fixed it this would be a really good purchase. As it is, it's a bit meh.Has a few really big flaws:1. Oversimplified strategic layer means every game pans out pretty much the same way.2. There are too many 'get out of jail free' abilities either on high level characters or in the form of grenades or psionic powers.3. Really short. You can spin the campaign out a bit if you want to but there's very little there.4. It's way too easy once you get the hang of it and what's more it's front-weighted the challenge again. In other words it starts really hard, then gets easy and stays that way, especially if you start again.Other than that s'okay I guess.Edited to add, almost a year later, and so I don't look like one of those nutters who've got hundreds and hundreds of hours in a game they don't recommend, mods do fix this game. The Long War mod specifically fixes it very much into what I want it to be. Takes a lot of time and tinkering but if you're willing to put that into it then it can be great.

												Disabling v-sync and framerate smoothing, while lowering anti aliasing from msaa 8x to fxaa will pretty much fix any stuttering issues people are experiencing. There are already two mods, one extending timers and one disabling timers on the workshop. So that fixes that complaint.With those two issues out of the way, the game looks good (the people that claim it looks like xcom 1 or looks worse are full of it)  the concept is great. The customization options are crazy, and will only expand as more mods are made. Can't wait until there's a long war equivalent mod. Playing on a i-7 4770, gtx 970 and 16 gigs of ram, aside from the cutscene stuttering that was fixed with the above options, the game runs smooth for me. Haven't run into any bugs yet, I'm sure I will though. Some advice, don't grow attached to your squad members.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												If you buy this game, immediately look into mods. Without them, it's just not worth the purchase.  Previous iterations of the XCOM franchise prided themselves on torturous levels of difficulty and tragedy.  It was balanced by a keen sense of style and humor, rooted in 50's/60's-era alien invasion paranoia. With XCOM2, the developers seem to have bought into their own "difficulty" mystique and made a game that borders on being more frustrating than fun. To do this, they added gameplay elements (e.g. timers, terrain-ignorant fields of vision, and plot-wedging "Advent Project") to ensure the game is challenging for experienced players, but often defy logic. On paper, some of the new elements sounded great; previous iterations frustratingly relied too heavily on RNG to increase difficulty. The result, however, puts XCOM2 "on rails", meaning that despite the awesome amount of thought they put into class customization, maps and new "concealment" element (which tantalizes an option for stealth gameplay), missions can only really be accomplished one way. Players are forced to brute-force their way through most (if not all) objectives, which quickly becomes rote and frustrating, given the difficulty level. In other words, missions can't be accomplished with much creativity on the player's part. This vastly diminishes the reward for employing strategy - and this is a strategy game after all.  Thankfully, there's a community of modders who felt the same way.  I recommend saving yourself from feeling like you wasted money by looking into the highest rated gameplay mods on Steam and download (i.e. "subscribe" to) them before even starting your first campaign. Sadly, XCOM2 has lost much of the whimsical approach to alien invasion, in favor of scarier, or more intimidating aliens (unsuccessfully, IMO).  There are story, voice, and character design mods to be explored too but dive in at your own risk.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
												I will be brutally honest about my review here: I am not being objective. This is pure oppinion and if you enjoy the game it is completely and utterly up to you.So, did I like it?No, I hated it fully and completely. The game has very clear goals and none of them are admirable or interesting. While XCom: Enemy Unknown had issues, two things that I loved about it were the scope and the story. It felt like the desperate attempt of an unsuspecting planet to fight against a highly superior invader. That feeling is gone. The game tries to go for a "fight the POWA!" feel, but it utterly fails on a mechanical level. Missions are always about attacking and routing or anihilating the enemy. Enemies (like before) only activate once spoted, so you never feel like a covert ops team. In fact, your soldiers become so strong during the game, I hardly ever had one seriously hurt. By adding more content, the developers overlooked the dreadded powercreep. Now for the second titanic issue: The story*Spoilers*While XCom: Enemy Unknown went with a very event and action driven narrative that was mostly told through the memos and Ufopedia entries, it allowed the player a very good feel of what the enemy was up to and made it clear that XCom, while necessary was a very shady organization. You got black money from a shady council, constantly lauched military actions in neutral airspace and basically confiscated alien technology right from the soil of sovereign nations. Your actions were not black and white.XCom 2 forgoes these ideas and makes it obvious: Aliens EVUL, rebels GOOD, you HERO!The narrative is mostly character driven, following 4 people who handle everything (scientists and engineers only support, you never get the feeling that there is a whole legion of workers behind any breakthrough). Sadly, the characters are neither very deep nor very interesting. Due to the fact that rebels need constant rescue from you (the new terror missions are attacks on rebel bases), they come off as completely ineffectual and kinda sad. Your fellow freedom fighters have the same AI as civilians in the first installment and never take a shot or fight back. Finally, there are the aliens... The strange, unsettling enemy of mankind that has unified dozen of species and attacked you without provocation for no reason have basically become Dr. Robotnik from Sonic. Their motives are outright stated at the halfway point and their evilness is underlined with Auschwitz-imagery and their personal Steven Jobs - like spokesman. At some point they "want to harvest the entire genetic material of the world" by putting people into meat grinding factories. The final cutscene features the Commander himself in Psy-battle with the alien leaders. Yes, it has become that simple and dumb. It ends with a hint at what I assume will be the next installment. Anyways, I really didn't enjoy this game. Sorry, hope you do

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												I just want to start off by saying that at its core, this game is phenominal. Enemy variety is plentiful and is for the most part really well balanced. The game is a decent looking game too. Sadly, the enemy variety sort of goes out the window late game and the longer you play, the worse performance gets due to a nasty memory leak. The Avenger base isn't anything special. It's just slightly better than it was in EU and not really worth mentioning. Oh, and the sound design, both with the in game voices and sound effects to the phenominal score is nothing short of amazing. I absolutely LOVE this game. XCOM has always been a series that I've LOVED since I was a child. And because of the love that I have for the series, I HATE writing a negative review on this game. You see, aside from the core aspect being amazing, that's really the only positive thing I can say about this game. It's quite clear that this game seriously lacks polish. There's even evidence that the developers actually panic patched the game at the last minute to make it harder. And there lies the problem with XCOM 2. The XCOM games have never been hard, challenging yes, but never hard. This game however is hard for all the wrong reasons. From spawning 2 Archons and 2 Advent elite troopers at the LZ of a timed mission (and then landing another 3 troopers ON the LZ making it 7 foes to face) to having your troopers caught during the "concealment" phase without so much as a warning to let the players know that said troopers can actually see behind the 2 buildings you're at. The game honestly feels completely botched. I NEVER felt screwed over when I played the older XCOM games or Enemy Unknown/ WIthin. I've always played on the harder difficulties to make it more challenging. The AI has ALWAYS cheated in the older games (it's a fact), but NEVER as blatantly as they do in this game. This game has absolutely no sense of balance nor fairness. And the game completely contradicts itself too. It wants you to sneak around and set up well planned out ambushes. Well, that takes a lot of time to pull off and 90% of the time you're expected to use these ambush tactics, there's a timer where you have 8 turns to hack into an item across the map or you lose meaning that instead of doing what the game was designed to do (at least in the early stages of the level), you have to dash towards the objective. It makes no logical sense. Not to mention that flanking offers the player no reward aside from higher chances to land a critical hit on an enemy and the high grounds offer no real advantages either (though you still do get a bonus for being up above). A lot of the times the player is actually punished for making tactically sound maneuvers. The aim penalties in this game are beyond insane too! It's tooth shatteringly logic defying when a giant metal floating ball is floating 1 square away and I have a plasma rifle aimed at it with only 50% chance to hit on my colonel ranked support character. I understand that since it's floating, it gets a "flying buff", but when it's no less than ONE SQUARE AWAY, should't I be at 100% to land a hit since it would literally be impossible to miss that shot? I have MUCH more to say about this game, but I fear that, that would require me to write at least 4 pages worth of complaints. And that's not even me talking about the TERRIBLE optimization and performance issues (I have a 980, i5 4670k OC'd, and 16gb of RAM) that this game has nor the countless bugs. Fun fact, the reason that I ran into a terrible (even game breaking) bug that wouldn't allow me to make any actions, but if by God's good grace I managed to pull off an action, the game would just freeze up. And no, not crash, the game would literally just halt at the zoomed in character that is about to make a shot. Background noise and music still playing and soldiers and aliens still doing their idle animations. It was nearly impossible for me to finish the mission I was currently on. I did fix it though. It really saddens me that a PC only release is plagued with such mediocre and amateur mistakes. Especially from a dev team like Firaxis. As the game stands now, I cannot see how ANYONE could give this game 9's and 10's across the board. This game is a 6/10. It's such a shame, because I want to love this game (more than I already do). It sucks to say and even think this, but I can't wait for the patches and modders to fix this game. Once it's fixed, I know that this game could easily be a 9 or a 10.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												In regards of this review: I will only review the un-modded "vanilla" version of this game.The game is quite badly optimized. To give you an idea of my specs:Gtx 980Intel i7 3.5016 GB ram--------So, the game makes my pc STRUGGLE at max graphics, a pc that handles witcher 3 on max with no issues whatsoever. However, it only struggles when i maximize the settings. If i set them to medium, there will be some framerate stutters here and there. I do not know if this optimization issue is only relevant to the GTX 980, or if it is worse on other cards out there on the market.The gameplay is the same as the first one, with some annoying things (that can be solved with mods, true- but we're reviewing the game itself here.) The gameplay has to be described as "annoying" because that's exactly what it is.  If all of your squadmates are on the same extraction platform, why do you have to extract each and every one of them individually, why not add an exctract all button? (There is a mod that solves this, however.)The game continiously annoys the living crap out of you with dialogue, dialogue hindering you from doing anything on your turn. "We've just recieved a transmission due to X". Or, one of your officers pop up in the right side window, mentioning you do not have many turns left. Why am I not allowed to do anything while he's talking? And this goes on and on and on in the game! I couldn't bring myself to play it any more. (However, there is a mod that fixes this.)The worst experience so far- for me, Is the world map. I had one day left on my research, and I started it. One day usually takes 1.5 seconds to pass. This took me three minutes, due to dialogue popping up, that was unskippable, mentionings of the avatar project growing further. The camera pans to where the avatar project is on the map, but does not pan back to where you were before on the map. HALTING your production as well. So, I start it again and another dialogue pops up. It's atrociously annoying!If you did dislike timed missions in the last XCOM game, then this game just isn't for you. 80% of all missions are "8 turns left to finish before X explodes" or something else. While, it encourages the player to use tactics, it is just too much of it. Almost every god damn mission! (there is a mod that fixes this.)The loading times are bad, just dreadful.The game saves itself ONLY because of mods. Mods made by players to fix this boring & annoying game.I would not recommend you buy this game. But if you do, I would recommend checking out the mods in the workshop section fixing this game!

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												Harsh design, poor optimisation and a baffling lack of truly random outcomes spoils an otherwise interesting sequel.  The strategy layer is much improved, the concealment mechanic interesting (if not actually all that useful) and the new aliens and soldier abilities expand into new territory.  It's such a shame therefore that it seems hellbent on preventing players having any fun at all.  Tweaks can be applied by mods to smooth out some of the worst, but presently there is no way to ensure the game properly delivers random outcomes to possible actions, meaning all the decision making by the player is ultimately irrelevant.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2016
												Xcom 2 isn't a bad game, the problem is that it's not that good either. Xcom Enemy Unknown (and later enemy within) kept me coming back over and over again. While there was a host of problems with the first one, it still had that feeling, you never know what you're up against, and you never know if a mission is gonna end well or not. In XCOM 2 you know what you're up against, because you only ever fight the same 3 types of enemies with very rare exceptions. Half the classes are really broken when it comes to balance, which ruins the experience if you go for a higher difficulty run. Risk/reward analysis forces you to play in an incredibly boring manner, which makes the whole point of high difficulty gone. In the first game, I would sometimes have to go for a hail-mary, and risk everything to keep my men alive. This never happens in XCOM 2, as there are no classes that can do anything close to a hail mary move. My advice, get XCOM enemy within, and when you've gotten good enough, download "Long war", it's way way better.Oh, and also, it's completely impossible to play Ironman mode in it because it bugs out and messes up everything regularily

												Look this game has a 91 average from the kind of people who tend to get mocked for liking their games on easy mode only. If they can adapt and like XCOM 2's general stratagem change of "no you can't overwatch turtle anymore", so can you.(And if you love overwatch turtling that much, there's already mods that cater towards your casualness.)More seriously this game does have some major optimization issues that'll make you wonder what kind of rigs they have at Firaxis Games, but nothing at the severity that will make the game truly unplayable for you in my experience. If you like Enemy Unknown and are willing to adapt (or download a tiny mod that'll change the game for you), XCOM 2's right up your alley. It has the ability to save customized soldiers you love so you can see them live, die, and live again, its got a much more improved Geoscape side of the game (even if I'm still uncomfortable with ex-drunkard Bradford being the pilot of the Avenger), its got fully destructible terrain, and it has a SDK with an absurd amount of stuff you can do with it if you're the sort that likes tinkering with the games they own. At the very least, pick it up next steam sale if you're a fan of this kind of genre.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												It really breaks my heart having to write this review to not recommend this game with flying colors. I am a big fan of the franchise and a big fan of the previous game, enemy unknown/within. XCOM 2 was probably the one game that I looked foward to playing in 2016. I was more excited about this game than any other AAA games or indie games that are coming out this year. It is sad to say that the game did not live up to my expecation at launch. I say this because the core premise of the gameplay is good, but the technical aspect of the game is horrible. The peformance and bugs that came with release of this game can rival that of Batman Arkham Knight and Assassin Creed Unity at launch. What really gets to me is that this is a PC exlusive game, so it should have beeen the game that comes out the most polished on the PC platform in this current generation and the graphics in this game are good but not mindblowing to a point where gtx 970 should not be getting 20fps in sideview of your avenger base. It is hard to defend this game base on optimization and bugs because the game have been delayed so the developers have ample amount of time to fix the performance and bugs reported from the review copies of the game. Aside from the technical problems, I really enjoy playing this game because it is XCOM at heart. If you are new to the franchise I recommend waiting until hotfix or performance patch have been rolled out. I would glady change my review when technical problems have been solve by patches but I feel like performance wise this is the best we are going to get. I am not hoping to see major performance upgrade from patches because the peformance problem may tied in to their heavy tinkering with the Unreal Engine 3. I hope they prove me wrong.

number of helpful: 19 of 31 people (61%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												I'm disappointed in Firaxis. I'm disappointed in the development team. I can't imagine that there isn't at least a few of the developers, whether writers artists or programmers who didn't think "Man, there's going to be a lot of really angry players."This game is a reskin. That's it. That's the entire review. Everything else is just exposition and nuance. Satellites are now Listening Posts. The Council timer is now the ADVENT timer. You excavate a starship like you excavate a bunker (amazingly straight down only. No, you can't excavate starting from the bottom or sides ignore the areas of the ship around this smaller-base-than-XCOM-1 you must excavate down). The Terror Missions are now named Retaliation Missions. The Classes are still split into Heavy, Sniper, Support and Assault but there's been some rebalancing to remove certain abilities players were abusing and name-changes to protect the innocent. Combat is the same. The AI is different, but also in a strange way, the same. Did you play Long War? Did you listen to Long War talk about what was wrong with XCOM1? Congratulations. You've already played XCOM2's combat. It looks the same, it plays the same beyond minor tweaks (if the enemy getting free moves bothered you then you'll be happy to note: its now an essential gameplay mechanic). This is the same engine. Same content. Same everything. Its ctrl+c; ctrl+v. Its lazy... and amazingly it doesn't have things that we find in the first XCOM like Second Wave mechanics. The cynic in me says that Second Wave will be released under a new name as DLC. Again. It feels like an expansion pack. No, it doesn't. Scratch that. It feels like the Blue Shift or Opposing Force campaigns. Allow me explanation on that one in case you're not familiar with the examples. In Half-Life1 you had some alternate campaigns that were released as expansions. Same game, same engine, obvious recycles the whole nine yards. You just played the same story from a different perspective. The same happened in a lot of older video games. You got two campaigns. Usually an Allieds and Axis, or Rebellion and Empire. That sorta thing. This feels like a Blue Shift campaign being marketed as a sequel in hopes that the playerbase is too stupid to notice. That's what you get here. Not a game in its own right, because you've already played it and this game is so identical that you could probably mod in XCOM2 back into XCOM1 without a whole lot of work. And you know what pisses me off? What really angers me the most about this? This isn't like the trailer. This game doesn't even reflect the main menu (for those of you who haven't seen it, its one of your soldiers in the suburbs about to ambush alien police officers). You don't build up multiple fronts of cells. You don't fight and take cities. There's no thought or complexity in this beyond "hack the thing and shoot everything in the face". There's no campaign beyond flimsy goalposts of "research this" or "stun a Sectoid Commander for interrogation" (in XCOM2 its stabbing ADVENT Commanders in the face with a probe to interrogate their faces directly) but that's one of the requirements.Obviously there's a lot of money in the XCOM franchise. XCOM1 sold well. The DLC sold well. The Enemy Within expansion sold well. There's a lot of people like myself who bought the second game with little more than a trailer and some hope. The press releases for XCOM2 were... quiet, but what was released promised something more than just a reskin and taking notes out of a modding community's playbook.If I had to sum it up: XCOM2 was a♥♥♥♥♥♥move, Firaxis. You should be ashamed.

number of helpful: 39 of 69 people (57%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 5, 2016
												Let me start by saying as I played through the game, I started out loving it and enjoyed it less and less every passing moment. Also, I am a diehard XCOM fan and have played every game from the original through the expansions, Xenonauts, XCOM:EU and EW, The Bureau, and now XCOM 2. I also believe Ironman is the only way to go, otherwaise you can just negate every bad thing that happens. Now to the review:The start of the game is fantastic, and Firaxis has made some awesome refinements to the combat systems from XCOM:EU/EW. The textures, animations, and overall polish are crisp. The game started out hard, as an XCOM game should, but not unfair. I then found myself constantly interrupted by ceaseless side missions and events that interrupted the flow of the game back at base, while I was able to quickly field a force that was unstoppable and never lost a soldier after upgrading to Mag weapons. By the time I got plasma's, it was no contest. The game quickly turned into a tedious affair, but I had high hopes for the final mission. The second to last mission, which I won't ruin was phenomenal and I found myself re-invigorated and ready to finish the game on a high note and write a stunning review. The last mission was going awesome until the final battle. I suffered innumerable bugs, the worst of which was that when I moved my soldiers across a certain point ont he bridge, which if you've played you know what I'm talking about, a cutscene triggers. This cutscene locked the camera on the final position the camera was in when the cutscene ended, and I could not issue any commands to my troops. I had to save and exit then reload for every single soldier, which took about 30 minutes to just get through that position. Then the final battle occured. For the first time in any XCOM game or XCOM spinoff, I felt cheated. It was not just difficult, it was blatently unfair. There seems to have been no creative process behind this battle and in order to make an epic final challenge, the developers decided to throw endless waves of troops at the player, while supporting that with several of the most powerful alien forces in the game. This might seem like a a fun challenge, but an ability with a four turn cooldown, meaning there is only ever a one turn break between attacks, takes off half a soldiers health and is AOE that spand half the room. You have a similar attack, but it also forces a position change, which there is almost only half cover throughout the room, which is equivalent to no cover. I felt cheated. I was destroyed on my Normal/Ironman game with no hope of winning whatsoever. I could have employed some cheap tactics, like hiding out back on the bridge and mowing the enemy down one by one until I fulfilled the objective, but that would be an exploit of the AI system and would not have felt fair.TL;DR First XCOM game to botch the insanely difficult but always fair feeling of the game. Cheap tricks employed by the developers at the expense of a clever but difficult final challenge result in frustration. Bugs abound, even after multiple patches that break gameplay and ruin the core experience during the most critical levels and dramatic moments. Save yourself the headache, get XCOM:EU/EW and Xenonauts unless you feel that exploiting AI systems instead of tactically challenging gameplay is fun.

number of helpful: 30 of 52 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												Truly a great successor to the first XCOM: Enemy Unknown and Enemy Within.XCOM 2 has a story that is a lot more engaging compared to the first XCOM, and I managed to finish the entire campaign on Ubuntu within 51 hours on Veteran. That's a drastic improvement in content over the first XCOM, which could be completed in 20 hours on one playthrough.Gameplay mechanics have been improved quite drastically to keep things fresh each time you play a mission, and difficulty rises as you progress but does not feel insurmountable once you know what you are doing.Customizations for your soldiers really let's you get attached to your soldiers, and I even found myself scolding my ranger often for failing his Bladestorm attacks but never wanting him to be in harms way.The Linux port is very well made, with one caveat. Performance is not as good as I would have hoped, but I do trust that performance improvements will come in the near future. It is playable, but not as enjoyable in that aspect as it could be on a GTX680 at 1080p.The only last real caveat I feel the game suffers from is timer-based missions (gameplay mechanic). Some of them force you to abandon tactics, and sacrifice soldier's lives for the sake of completing the mission in-time. This is a turn-based game, but it feels like I'm being forced to play it like an RTS which is off-putting for those missions. Thankfully most main missions don't have these turn timers or have well-balanced timers.Overall, a worthy successor to XCOM EU & EW. Highly recommended for those that love strategy games, but even more so for those who do not define their libraries by genre but rather by engaging and well-made games!

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												This game feels like visiting one of your best friends from high school, but everyone told him he was awesome, so he's decided to change. He's the same physical person, but he likes different things, has a different sense of humor, and he is a sore loser at games and often cheats. That's how XCOM 2 feels compared to XCOM. It's not more of the same, but instead it throws out the well balanced strategy layer I and others found fun, and it replaces it with a chaotic mess with a timer that can randomly tick up faster certain months. The resource restrictions feel more annoying than enjoyable, and much of the game feels scripted, the opposite of what any XCOM game should feel like.In all honesty, I take this personally. I love XCOM and have bought it on PC for myself and others, on XBox, and even on iPhone. This was a day one purchase, but I've put off playing it because it feels like the game is upset with me playing it. The game is no longer well balanced for Iron Man mode and seems to encourage save scumming instead.To be honest, because I want to beat it and see the ending, I've been playing on Beginner difficulty (with Iron Man selected because I enjoy the perma death aspect still). I've almost beaten it in my sixth game. I've lost five games on normal difficulty and had to resort to beginner just to have a chance, and it's still hard.XCOM 2 feels like playing a game with a child who cheats and changes the rules. What hurts my feelings is that my favorite game is XCOM, so this feels like an old friend who has changed who he is for no reason and has become a sore loser to boot.

number of helpful: 11 of 16 people (69%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 14, 2016
												I would recommend this game, and for people who truly enjoy strategy games, science fiction, strategy, and cheesy storylines, I would still recommend it - but for numerous reasons, to the general rpg and strategy player, I simply can't provide my recommendation of XCOM2. Here's why.First of all, the game is incredibly demanding on PC resources - so much so that even with a near top-of-the-line air-cooled rig, I run it on low settings. It is buggy and crashes occasionally. There are frame drops and hiccups. I had issues with the cinematics when it was first installed - sound would play out of sync, and sometimes the cinematics wouldn't show at all.Secondly, it is overpriced for what you get. The DLCs add very little to the game, and the rewards from completing them are quite hefty from a resource-cost standpoint. Even if you forego all of the DLC, on Commander+ difficulties you will find yourself grinding missions simply to get more resources before the final assault. Throw in the DLC rewards, and you will very quickly realize just how much of a grind XCOM2 can be.Third, there are no *real* choices in XCOM2. When you have access to three guerrilla operations, you are merely choosing between the best reward in most cases (which is typically fairly obvious.) Outside of that, your only choices will be whether or not to spend intel to buy a weapon upgrade on the black market, or spend resources on your ranger shotguns instead of sharpshooter sniper rifles. Missions are completely linear, and some missions are literally impossible to complete thanks to cheating AI and random spawn locations. (One time I spawned on a map with four alien groups that triggered simultaneously the following turn, even if I didn't move.)There are no alternate endings besides success and failure. Missions do not change much even on new playthroughs - you will meet new aliens at approximately the same times and in the same order. There are only three or four game-progress missions that *require* completion. The rest are time wasters and provide a slow trickle of resources...which are the only real impediment to your progress. Player skill and good decision making will not impact your completion speed much - only the random rolls for whether or not you get downed UFO missions will influence that.It becomes painfully obvious eventually - 95% of the missions are simply obstacles to your progress within the game, and barely feel like they *are* the game. They're more like a house fly that won't stop landing on your arm. Your actual success or failure depends not on completing these missions, but rather on whether or not you have the resources to obtain region contacts to reach the missions you *need* to progress. This lack of importance makes 95% of the game - the mass of meaningless missions - feel like the filler on a one-hit-wonder music album.If I were to rate XCOM2, I'd give it a 6/10. It's not a terrible game by any means, and I know a lot of work went into it, but it seems like they never finished it. Maybe they expected the mod community to do the work for them...maybe they figured they'd make their money back and some more, and that'd be enough. But the lack of RPG-type customizeability on soldiers, the apparent meaninglessness of most missions, and the on-rails story really ruins what would otherwise be a solid turn-based strategy game.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2016
												This game probably has a lot of potential, but it's too broken to know for sure.  Many times I would have a soldier aim at one enemy, but then shoot at another one that I didn't intend because of some glitch.  The camera has an odd tendency to slowly drift on its own when you're planning a movement or aiming a grenade which results in leaving your soldier in the open or missing a toss.  Whenever an NCP in the game talks to you on the radio, you're not able to take any action, and there is ALOT of radio chatter, which is usually reminding you of mission objectives that you already know or telling you about the mission timer of which you're already well aware.  There is an option that makes it seem like you can reduce this needless dialogue, but it has no noticeable effect, making missions last much longer than they need to and adding frustration to the already broken system.  It's disappointing to have the experience ruined by game glitches, bugs, and wasted time, and until they fix these problems, I cannot recommend playing this game.  Was very excited for XCOM 2, but ultimately very disappointed and frustrated.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												This brief review comes from an old time veteran of UFO games going all the way back to the 90s. Being a great fan of the relaunched Xcom the second installment was an autobuy. And I am very confident they will eventually patch it to where it should be, but...Even on easiest setting some of the missions are extremely hard - mainly due to the RNG gameplay mechanics built into the core mechanics: I've had to reload for literally 2 evenings to finish one of the missions because of flaws in my team that I simply could not have prevented as a player. And that comes from a ironman player of Xcom 1. I have no qualms with being punished for stupid gameplay - in Xcom2 I am constantly reloading simply because stuff happens that I have absolutely no control over.The alien opponents seemingly use their maximum movement range and still melee attack - or they have insane range. And why Aliens get an out of turn movement phase when they are surprised by my team beats me. Result as so often is that they can essentially flank the hell out of me without my team even being able to reposition. The timers are extremely tight and often enough I had to restart missions all the way from the beginning simply because I had that one turn missing to finish the extraction. I even had to leave folks behind due to the constantly reapearing aliens - without my guys having a fair chance to fight their way out. No one left behind? Not in Xcom2. And don't get me even started on the hit/cover percentages... Let's say it this way: they really need some love.Story and core combat of the game are great and absolutely addicting. It's just not really polished for the player yet. But I am sure it will happen over time and then my hesitant "NO" will become an overwhelming "YES"... until then: you either have to be a lucky star OR masochistic. Or both...

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												While I'm still playing through the campaign, I can say that XCOM 2 is overall a well-made game, but there are some downsides with it. For me, mainly two: the game isn't as optimised as it should be, I'm running a 650 Ti 2GB currently but I feel like it should be able to run the game at higher frames (although the game has never outright crashed). I also feel like the difficulty of the game needs some tweaking - I've been playing on the second difficulty and it feels too punishing in certain areas. If you make one mistake in your research, mission choices or facility choices, you can find yourself in completely frustrating situations, like not having enough squad member slots, or wasting all your money on new soldiers because you didn't buy the facility needed to use the speed boost that heals your current soldiers faster and in time for the next mission. Once you realise your weaknesses and start trying to correct them down the road, the Avatar counter will keep ticking up as expected, not giving you enough time unless you want the red bar almost completely filled by the time you're prepared for the mission.Making these types of oversights can make the game extremely tedious unless you constantly revert saves, which isn't how you want to play it. You can find yourself saving after every mission so you can revert to any point of the game and change your choices so that you can avoid the problem that made you revert in the first place.Overall, good game for strategy players and one that improves on Enemy Unknown. Don't buy if your graphics card is old or if you don't want to constantly revert saves or constantly lose all time and effort you invested into your playthrough.(Yes, I understand XCOM is meant to punish bad decisions, but personally I feel it went too far in that direction and could have been more forgiving at least a few times, especially on the first two difficulties).P.S. I wrote this review for the Pillar of Community badge.

number of helpful: 23 of 39 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												XCOM: Enemy Unknown - the complete version is one of my most favorite games of the recent past. I played it on my PS3, PC/MAC, and my iPad. Hell, I still play it on my iPad. I then got into the Long War mod, and I couldn't play the base game anymore (except my iPad). XCOM 2 had some large shoes to fill. Did it?I think it did. Let me first put a disclaimer up. I didn't experience any crashes or game ending bugs. I somehow missed all of those. Sure, I had some slowdowns and long loads, but no crashes. Very few bugs at all. I don't even have that great of a system, but that's besides the point.I love XCOM 2. It took me a while to accept the timers, but when I did, I got over one of the few qualms I had with the game.I love the new story. We lost to the Aliens. How refreshing. We are having to fight back and try to re-conquer our world. AWESOME. We have new mission types, and we use the hellicarrier from the Aveng....  er... floating alien transport ship instead. We are a guerilla force out to exact revenge as we uncover the plot of the story. The unit rebalance and customization is great. The new gameplay is great. The timers... um, not so much. But then we have mods.Oh the mods, the glorious mods. After downloading a dozen, I can't play the base game anymore. The modders are making this game even better. How would I score this game? Hmm, I would certainly recommend it, but players need to accept that the RNG is brutal. Really brutal, and the game is harder than XCOM:EU was. Is it as hard as the LW mod? No, but it can be on the highest difficulty.I have many more thoughts about it and if you are interested in reading them, here's a link: http://explorminate.net/2016/03/04/friday-excursion-xcom-2/Have fun commander, and if you want to know what mods are a must, just comment here and I will let you know what I use.

number of helpful: 135 of 253 people (53%) found this review helpful11 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
												It's like they attempted to throw every idea they had into a melting pot, but implemented every single idea in such a way as to specifically annoy the player.-Turn timers that are barely long enough to complete the mission, or sometimes are so long you can ignore them, and you have no idea which is which.-A spawning system that places groups of enemies in the exact worst places, resulting in critical mission failure because you trigger three groups at the same time for reasons you couldn't possibly see coming.-Soldier levelling options that force you to make Hobson's choices between useful abilities and not-useful ones, screwing you over if you accidentally pick the one that isn't useful.-Soldier levelling options that deprive you of useful abilities on a specific soldier, resulting in needing to bring two specialists along because you can't both hack robotic units and be able to revive and heal your teammates.-A stealth system that is hilariously useless. Bypassing enemies will just result in you being pincered every time, when it's even possible in the first place. The aliens will actually pause their patrol path while you're close to them, and then resume it as soon as you move forward, resulting in them walking right up and seeing you - even if you waited 15 turns with them just standing there, the instant you move, they move too!-Grenades have to be engineered one at a time. Soldier armors and weapons do not. What?-Overworld pacing is horrible. Nothing can wait. If you try to finish up a task you have an hour remaining on, the game will immediately say "No, you have to do this now!" Ignore that and you inexplicably lose an entire region. I guess extracting that VIP was critical to the resistance's very survival or something, and it couldn't wait an hour, even though it takes you six hours to fly there.-They tried to make the game much harder, and make you have to deal with soldier losses instead of just reloading every time. Unfortunately, with the value of skilled soldiers, you're screwed if your A Team dies, so...-General performance issues. Long loading times.-Every time anything happens, the game locks your input and zooms over to it. This includes things like a soldier returning to cover, a soldier changing weapons, a soldier saying something after killing something (in which case the game waits 2-3 seconds!), a new enemy being spotted (sometimes multiple times in the same turn), a civilian dying, anything. While the total time is neglegible, it's just long enough to become annoying. It's astounding how they seem to figure out a way to get the game to wait exactly long enough for you to be annoyed.By far my biggest complaint, though, is the difficulty. No, the game is not too hard. No, the game's not too easy. It's both. Yes, both. This game does not have a difficulty curve. I'd be tempted to say it has a difficulty sine wave, but that's not true either. A sine wave is predictable. This game has a difficulty scribble. Certain missions are ungodly hard for no reason I can adequately determine - I've had to reload and restart some missions eight times while playing on normal - and other missions are laughably easy. The easiest mission I've had so far is a BASE DEFENSE. How screwed up is that? There are almost no missions I can remember that had a difficulty that was just right. Everything is either too hard or too easy. The things that make this game difficult aren't facing tough, smart enemies who will move to flank you - it's when the game decides to throw you a mission with three groups of enemies all clustered in the same place right around the VIP you have three turns to extract.I'm having some fun with it, but this game isn't worth the price being asked. It needs serious balancing and many patches, perhaps a complete difficulty and mechanic overhaul, before it would be worth anything like the asking price.It's astounding to me that they screwed up this badly. I had the utmost confidence in them. XCOM 1 had issues, but it was a fun game. It wasn't annoying. This game is annoying. And that's horrible - it's one thing for a game to be bad, but annoying? I'm so disappointed. :/

												I wanted to love this game. I was excited for the hype. I made my name doing Let's Play videos of XCOM:LW. Someone donated to me the $80 pre-order edition. I hyped it up for a year before it was released. I made over 150 customized soldiers before even starting the campaign. It had so much potential.I'm going to try and keep this brief, so that I don't lose too many people.- If you loved XCOM:EU/EW/LW: All strategies you learned in that game you will be punished for in this one.- I got this game to fight aliens, not timers. The timers are overwhelming and ruin the game.- The storyline is the least important part of the game. The strategy even less important.- The stealth mechanic they hyped up forever? Completely useless in every way in every encounter except for the very first attack. After that it might as well not exist.- Everything I love is dead.EDIT: So I went back to it, through huge recommendations from my stream. I played all the way until the last mission on Ironman Legendary. My opinions of it haven't changed. The game is programmed to cheat if you're doing too well. Firaxis had no interest in balance or fun. The community is so masochistic as to be toxic if you're not enjoying the game punishing you for trying to HAVE fun. 100% artificial difficulty instead of any actual strategy involved, and a community that is so used to being told, "If you're losing you're just not good enough" that they can't see bad design when they're being beaten with it.Firaxis: You did so well on XCOM:EU and EW. What the hell went wrong?
