number of helpful: 16 of 26 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												In Xcom 2 Firaxis have done what many thought impossible and improved on almost every aspect of Xcom EU. And if you are a fan of turn based stratagy games then this is a must-have purchase. That being said however, It does have it's drawbacks.Pros:1. Far, far deeper customisation for your soldiers, now being able to choose things such as face paint, camouflage and individual options for the torso, legs and arms of their armour.2. Randomly generated levels meaning that you won't play the exact same level multiple times like in EU.3. Consealment. Now when you start most missions you are in consealment meaning the enemies don't know that you're there, Allowing you to move without being attacked and set up abushes.4. Strong class system requireing you to think tactically about who you bring on each mission and what equptment to give them.5. Much improved Visuals.6. Mod support.7. More varied enemys with unique abilities to each other.8. More methods of going about the task than just shooting. You can now use a specialist to hack robotic units, or use a ranger to deal massive amount of damage with their sword.9. More mission types. The missions are no longer just kill everything or escort someone across a map. There are new objectives such as destorying a communications relay. Breaking VIPs out of prison or having to carry an unconcious VIP across the map to the extraction zone.10. Almost fully destructable environments. Is there an enemy flanking one of your soldiers while on a rooftop, and there is no way that you can shoot it to death in that turn? Get a grenade and blow up the floor beneith it! making it take the grenade damage, fall damage, and if you're lucky, fire damage from the building begining to burn down.Cons:1. Clipping issues. Soldiers will often fire through solid walls, break windows that have already been broken, or standing on absolutly nothing in order to shoot an enemy while positioned on a ledge.2. Performance issues. For some unexplained reason this game is far more demanding than it deserves to be, or that the reccommended settings say it is. Unless you turn off MSAA then it WILL lag. Even without MSAA it will still lag, jusst not as much.3. long load times. Even on an SSD, expect load times to be 30 seconds+. While it is understandable on the way to the missions due to generating teh map, on the way back the load times are even longer. An issue that can inexplicably be fixed by pressing the 'Caps Lock' button which makes it load almost instantly.4. Mod support. While I said that it is a good thing that it has it, it has been implimented in a way that means that any mod you turn on creates a dependancy for that mod in that save. This means if you install a mod, play a mission with it an descover you don't like it then you either need to keep playing with it, revert back to a save before you had it, or with Ironman player, restart the game.5. Steep dificulty curve. While in Xcom EU the first 3 missions would be fighting sectiods, then they intoduce thin men who can spit poison, on Xcom 2 the first 2 missions are fighting nice, weak enemies, then suddenly the introduce sectiods in the 3rd which can panic and mind control your soldiers. In the 5th mission the introduce vipers that can grab your soldiers from 7 tiles away and pull them out of cover. The game gets very hard, very quickly.6. Mission timers. Most missions now have a timer for you to finish them in before you fail and are either force evacuated or captured by the aliens. The problem is that they give you usually less than 10 turns to kill about 12 aliens, finish the objective then get to a set evac zone on the other side of the map. Another problem is that most of the reasons for the counters are 'drop ships are coming to attack you' or 'the aliens have rigged this thing to explode' but when you enter the missions you're consealed so there is no reason for the countdown timer to start in that case.Although I listed almost as many cons as pros, the good things that the pros bring by far outweigh the badness of the cons, and none of the cons are things that can't be fixed in updates or by mods. And yes, this is a difficult game and I have rage quit it many times, but i'm not going to be pathetic and post a negative review, just because I wasn't thinking tactially enough to get myself out of those situations.

												FIrstly, I need to start by saying that I love the XCOM series and have played each and every one of them for endless hours over the years. However, XCOM2, despite having fantastic new game mechanics, is rendered virtually unplayable due to ridiculous framerate issues and mission load times. The recent patch did not improve the situation whatsoever. Simple gameplay is made frustrating and this ongoing issue has totally taken the joy out of the game. Even throwing a generade is hazardous due to the lagging interface, and so ironman styled games are almost out of the question. Simple navigation around the avenger is frustrating also. Mission load times are more often than not, extremely long. I can go make a cup of coffee whilst waiting for missions to load from the skyranger, reminding me of the days I would load my hotmail inbox using a 56k modem. I love this game, and I want to sink endless hours into it. However, whilst these performance issues persist, I cannot recommend you buy this game. You will be paying full price for a half finished product. Go play some Enemy Within whilst the devs sort this out.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2016
												XCOM 2 PC review: Well I tried for 13 hours and it’s not very often I quit a game especially a game like this where I loved UFO Defense, Terror from the Deep, EU and EW but I can’t take it anymore. This game has WAY too many time constraints and timed ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that all it does is ruin the gameplay. Here is a quick list of all the timed ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t I came across: loot, crates, consoles, missions timers, vip timers, avatar project timer and hostages (doesn’t really count because it’s in every game but it’s one more timer on your shoulder). There are some people who like this style so more power to you but this is just not fun to me what so ever. There were some cool new elements in the game that I liked but it was just completely overshadowed by all the other ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. I hope the next game does not follow this same time limit garbage because that is an absolute game killer for me. ♥♥♥♥ this world and ♥♥♥♥ this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												First of all, as many have begun with: I really loved XCOM EU. I was hooked, no question about it; I set myself offline on Steam and Skype just to keep playing, and didn't regret not seeing the light of day. And even, to top it off, the only surviving soldier from the very beginning became my first Psi soldier, and she ended up triggering the final cutscene - MVP? Definitely. I was fully invested in the most understated sense possible. However, this game, whilst it's definitely not a bad game, doesn't have the same level of connection to me. Whilst I get that the beginning levels of a game shouldn't be unfailable, nor should they feel like the halfway point of the previous title in the franchise. I get the whole "You've lost the war, you're on the backfoot; survive." sort of thing, and I like it in concept, but in action it just feels poorly done. I neither feel like I'm the underdog - since I'm getting to every conflict on my side of the globe with six soldiers, a flying boat, and a ♥♥♥♥-ton of grenades - nor am I the remnants of a super-efficient private war unit - since I've got a scientist, a girl who makes her colleagues do everything, and a commander who won the award for "Most cliche, expressionless soldier" at the army's summer ball. It just doesn't feel like XCOM. The aliens have really ramped up their abilities too; of course this makes sense, but towards the end of XCOM EU this felt like a tactical issue rather than a resigned "Yup". My skirmishes go somewhat like this: "Alright, okay, everyone in position. Twelve turns to move this MVP and the squad up to the evac point (which could have literally been on top of us, but okay). Put these guys into position over there annndd ♥♥♥♥. ♥♥♥♥. Okay, we'll flank h- ♥♥♥♥. You're mind controlled are you? Okay, right, he's floating in the air." and so on. That floating in the air bit actually happened at a point where two of my soldier were side-by-side on a church rooftop, which got blown out from underneath them. One fell to their death, the other just calmy stood up there, not being able to move off of the nothing that he was now perched on.In summary: it's frustrating, it's slow, and it's definitely not the sequel to XCOM EU.But since I'm not one for spoiling things, I'll let you find out about the performance issues yourself.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
XCOM 2 is the second BIG triple A title to come out this year and so far the year looks good for PC gamersXCOM 2 is a TBS (turn-based strategy) game and the improved sequel to 2012's reboot of the series, XCOM: Enemy Unknown.The story picks up 20 years after the events of the previous game. Aliens have taken over the Earth and it is your duty to reclaim our planet.All your favourate character classes are back: Snipers, Assault, Heavies and support.Heavie is now called the Grenadier and, as the name suggests, now carries a powerful and upgradable grenade launcher as well as the good 'ol minigun you already know from the previous game.Snipers now have a powerful pistol they can use as well as their usual long range sniper rifle.Support is now known as the Specialist and they have a military drone that can hack into the enemy's network, heal teammates or electrocute enemies.Assault is now called Ranger and they wield swords. You read that right. Swords, baby, swords! Hack 'n' slash through the alien ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who shot down your ride!You can now customise all of your soldiers tho. You can change their sex, name, nationality, voice, hairstyle and colour, armor style, colour, camo and same for weapons. You can even download mods from the Steam Workshop to take customisation to the next level.I had a tough military looking guy in my squad. His name was Arny "GetToDaChoppa" Commando and he used the Arnold Schwarzenegger Voice Pack. Amazing!R.I.P Arny Commando. You'll be missed.Your base is now an alien spaceship. You can fly it around the Earth to collect supplies, build resistance radio towers, contact and join your forces with the resistance in different countries, visit the Black Market and go on missions.Where we’re going, we don't need roads.Remember collecting resources with the Normandy in Mass Effect 2? That's basically how the "Earth map" plays out in XCOM2. It may sound like there's much to do on that map but there really isn't. Fortunatelly you don't spend too much time there. It's a cool addition but near the end i realised how repetitive and boring it really was and it just turned into a chore after a while. It's still a cool addition tho. I just wish there was a bit more to do on that map and that they wouldn't spam counsel missions that much.What more can i say? The graphics are improved. The gameplay is exactly the same as in the previous title which is good. There were couple of graphical glitches and i experienced 2 crashes in my 38 hours of gameplay but overall i'd say  that XCOM 2 had a pretty good launch (which seems to be rare in this day and age) and is an absolute joy to play. Definitely a must buy for all strategy fans.Buy it now and start savescumming!

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												Xcom 2 retains most of the same formula as its previous game except this time they added more, The enemies are stronger, tougher, and smarter and made missions much more faster paced. Humanityhas new ways to fight from new technology to even strategy on the field. Xcom is even more bad♥♥♥♥♥than before and adds so much more. It starts off a bit hard, gets harder and then pisses you off if you've made the wrong choices or just bad but still a good game. Video Review 


YouTube™ Video: Xcom 2 PC Review 

			Views: 2,826		

			Loving the sequel to this right now, It's the same formula but moar! more tech more weapons, more strategy, more aliens and more miss on 80% faceshots!		

Graphics The graphics is improved in this version of the game while still using the same engine and a beefier pc is needed to run it although it isn't drop dead gorgeous it still looks very good. At the same time there are some performance issues for the game even for me running a Titan and higher end processor but it is minuscule and the situation seems like it can be fixed via patches.The environment is more detailed and come in many different varieties all over the world towns, cities, snow, rain, sand etc. Sounds and music New alien sounds and voice acting in the game along with some returning familiar voices. The guns sounds great and new alien devices just blows your eardrums with its creative sci fi fx along with thier speeches. Accompanying this are also some great voice acting which goes does a really great job for the story. The music pieces for this game is phenomenal and gets your adrenaline going. StorylineThe story is much more action packed this time around and explosive along with time sensative missions. Most of the game is accompanied by cut-scenes but there are also in game chatter between characters to let players understand the lore and situation of what has has been happening to the world in the past years. There are also archives and logs players can go throughto discover and read to obtain more insights. The aliens are up to something but what exactly play it and fondle thier plans.GameplayThe game pretty much follows the same formula from the previous Xcom game except the r.n.g the game (Random number generator) during shots seems alot more improved (Sorta LOL)_. You can still of course miss shots at 40% or even 50% but it doesn't happen ALL THE DAMN TIME! Although 80% chance to shoot in the face can still miss lol.Along with the returning gameplay there is more strategy and the action is faster paced since there are many missions which are turn sensative (many of them). The new concealment system helps player plan ambushes on the battlefield and also strategize ambush attackson the aliens before they can react along with new devices to scout, technology to upgrade, guns, armors and even environment hacking  to buff your units or debuff enemies  for a better chance to fight back. There are also plenty of new class promotions, skills and load out for characters. The enemies this time are tougher, harder and even more annoying. They will bind you, poison you, shoot lasers at you, mind control you,teleport around you, aoe you, blow you up and kick your teeth in, thankfully you can retaliate.Everything is randomized as usual even your start location so you don't really know whats going to happen as you play the game because your planning on resources will have to be appropriate for the counter. Sometimes it can start out smooth or harsh but it all depends on what you invest in and your choice. Pros + Graphics looks much better maxed out on the pc.+ Much of the same formula and gameplay, improved rng+ environmental destruction improvement adds so much to the strategy including grounds building floors blowing up which can create win conditions.+ New Concealment system, More weapons, technology and loadout and class trees with stats to help in the battle against the aliens.+ Emphasis on the base building of choices you can invest in to get stronger. The choice is yours but the wrong investment can spell your downfall. Go for Supplies? More scientists? Engineers? or keep attacking?+ Your base is now a badass mothership, and even called avengers at times I thought it was the avenger ship+ Randomized missions and more side missions, the aliens COUNTER ATTACKS this time too.+ Many new types of alien enemies and they look damn good. They'll knock you around like pebbles.+ Multiplayer with ranks, quickmatches and custom games.+ Mods support+ Close your windows, shut your doors, hundreds of hours galore Cons - Some performance issue in certain areas and a bit of stutter/fps drops (miniscule such as loadout and lifting off) - hopefully they patch this up!- Some graphic clippings, enemy clipping walls, you making wierd shots, invisible guns but miniscule things due to engine.- even though the rng is better a bit with the new buff skills, you can still miss an enemy while standing in thier face with 80% chance of shot lol.- Most missions have move times, its super rough if you aren't fast. This can♥♥♥♥♥♥off some slow people who can't react to the pace that wants to take thier time. Recommended for you is easy so don't play veteran- Camera during the attacks can be a bit wonky aims at wierd places which can throw view off a bit.- The chatting between characters can cut off quick if you press a button on the menu too soon on the ships before you can listen in on them or sometimes it overlaps other voices.- Can't think of anything else- Oh god they're taking over my mind- I can't move- must.... call... for... help... xcom.... mayday

												I really want to like this game. I'm not going to ♥♥♥♥♥ about the difficulty which is really inconsistent in my opinion, but I will comment on it.I don't play a game like this with the idea of winning through failure. I like reloading and trying new strategies out. Sometimes reloading resets the RNG, sometimes it stays exactly the way it is whether your moves are the same or not. This gets frustrating in some situations like: moving your troops to better hit the enemy, moving your troops to avoid being hit, or running to try to complete the mission.So basically I find 95% of the time no matter what my moves are, if I miss 4 times in a row the first time I try, it will happen no matter my % of hitting or where my troops are. That doesn't feel good: I've reloaded a single spot 25+ times and every option comes with 2-4 misses and minimal damage, while every retaliation 1-shots one of my units. Besides personally irritating, it seems completely scripted to me.Otherwise the building transparancy gets frustrating a lot. I don't think it "ghosts" through buildings half the time I need it to, only to not figure out how to get it to work. Overall the game has a great concept but the overall player experience is sooooooo irritating my desire to play wears thinner every time I play it.

												XCOM: Enemy Unknown successfully revived an old, mishandled series by taking the core of what made the classics so great and boiling it down into a much more accessible formula. This reboot did a good job of gently introducing its ideas and mechanics while retaining the challenge that is part of the series’ identity. If XCOM: Enemy Unknown and its expansion were a well-oiled but slightly drab machine, XCOM 2 is a relative fire-spewing monster truck that could do with a good deal of repairs. Tons of changes that seem relatively small by themselves add up to make XCOM 2 a significantly different and more daunting game, and while many of these changes hit their mark, others go a bit wide, and the entire experience is hampered by persistent technical issues.Continue Reading[www.newgamenetwork.com]

content:
Posted: May 12, 2016
												Finally fully finished a run of this game so I am now able to give a complete rundown of the game.This game takes the normal formula of an XCOM game and twists it to fit the guerilla warfare style of the story. While this is refreshing and forces to player to play far more offensively and aggressively there are some issues in doing so that I feel were not ironed out before launch as was left up to the modding community to fix.Story:The story opens with the Commander being rescued by his old advisor and reveals that Enemy Unknown/Within never happened at all and that it was a series of simulations done by the aliens immediately following the instant surrender of Earth after they captured the Commander. The story continues to unfold with the game and the decisions of the player but every so often key parts of the story open up and show that the aliens are actually doing bad things to humanity rather than actually helping them and culminates on a final assualt. A lot of people had a problem with how the first game was relegated to simulations but I find that outcome not only logical but hilarious considering that only 10% of people even beat Enemy Unknown at all with how easy that game is. My problem is that the stance of the aliens is barely explored at all throughout the game and only does get explored on the final mission.Gameplay:The gameplay is still the same at its core as it was in Enemy Unknown but with added features and elements. The main feature added is the Concealment mode. This allows your team to move around without enemies heatseeking them until you open fire or enter their field of view, which in turn allows you to set up an ambush.Along with concealment, some new features were added along with some new goodies, too. A lot of classes have been reworked from EU and gun attachments that augment how a specific soldier operates and new explosives and armor have been added as well. The main problem with the gameplay is how Concealment works logically with some of the timer missions. Why would they rig their own supplies to explode when they don't even know that XCOM is in the area?Graphics and Performance:This is where the game really falls apart. While the game as a whole looks pretty good, it performs like absolute♥♥♥♥♥♥ With a 970 memecard, I was getting huge frame issues on max settings even after the patch. Turning off ambient occlusion and reducing AA to FXAA helped a lot but there were still issues that caused it to dip into the 40s after turning off some partical effects as well.Audio and Music:The music is still roughly the same as it was in EU but sounds a lot more triumphant upon a victory than before, mainly due to being a tiny rebel force fighting a huge alien force that has the planet in its grasp. The audio is about as standard as it gets but voiceovers can NOT be skipped and during retaliation missions, Bradford never shuts up and continues to repeat the same unskippable dialogue over and over each turn.Other:There isn't much else to talk about aside from the modding community. While Firaxis left a lot of issues in the vanilla game, they made modding tools very open and acceisble to the community and they have done wonders for this game. From adding small aesthetic mods to full blown mods changing how Concealment and timers work, the modders have done good work and have effectively fixed all the issues of the game. This does not excuse Firaxis for releasing the game in the state it was, but it allows players to easily change the game to either their liking or just enough to fix some issues they have with some game mechanics. Keep it up, mod community. You guys do good work.Epilogue/tl;dr:Even with all the graphical and gameplay issues, the game is still solid and adds a great deal more content to play with and against and any issue a player might have with the game can be fixed with the click of a button in the workshop.WARNING: Adding a mod to a campaign and then removing it and attempting to continue playing will result in an error and bypassing that error may result the campaign corrupting or becoming unplayable.I give this game a solid 8/10 and recommend it to anyone who is a fan of XCOM, new or old, or strategy games in the vein of XCOM in general and would recommend those that aren't to at least give it a good shot.

												Good tactical game..is not a strategy game.At that it is more of a luck based game than a tactical one.It is a good sequel and has the xcom tactical spirit.  Frustrating things:- Enemies shooting through walls- vipers tongue grabbing or poison spitting through walls/ceilings- timed missions where the only win solution is to run and sacrafice soldiers..if you stop to engage enemies you will time out-Success is more luck than tacticsHere is the short story...it is a good game but luck is way more important than skill.  You will be punished even when you use good tactics.  The first few times it happens it is annoying, the 50th time a Viper tongue grabs your soldier from inside a train or a house..not only from all the way across the screen but though a wall, it gets..well...not fun.  Might not sound like a big deal but very often a singular event like that will result in the whole squad dying...which is great if you screwed up tactically.  It sucks when it is crappy game mechanics.I've given it a good go.  Not sure I can play to much more as is.  I like being rewarded when i play smart and getting smacked down when i screw up..too many times it works the opposite.

												First: Love the game, Love the gameplay and Xcom series is my favorite series of all time, by a very large margin.Having said that: This game is unplayable.  I'm playing with a Nvidia 4gig 460 GTX, and a 4.7ghz 8 core AMD cpu which should run this at a reasable rate.  Min settings: caps at 27 FPS.  Max settings (excep AA is turned way down) 25 FPS.  Something is just wrong there.  This, I could actually tolerate.However: The crashes are so prolific it's unplayable.  It crashed 3 times at different points in the tutorial, two of them during cutscenes.  Disabled tutorial, and I get 20-30 crashes per mission.  I can usually get 1-4 turns off before it hardlocks my PC.  I've went through about 40 hours of troubleshooting, and without a doubt it is the the game software.  It's not my hardware, it's not over heating, it's not drivers, it's not corrupted software.  The software itself repeatedly crashes on a significant number of people.Judging by the overwhelming number of compliants of poor performance and random crashes, it's clear they did not beta test this properly.

												This game runs very poorly on recommended/above recommended hardware, that alone leads me to in turn, not be able to recommend this title. (this will likely be fixed soon)Also the turn timer is limiting, and gets very tiresome after about the third mission. It's not fun when the game forces you to make decisions which are sub optimal. Especially when those decisions lead you to get burned from placing your hope in one diceroll, which was a perfect example of a misplay in EU/EW. The thing is I loved XCOM Enemy Unknown, I got enough enjoyment out of it to play for 200 hours. I don't consider myself very good at it, but I still tried and failed a few times until I became experienced enough with the game to complete Classic/Ironman. Obviously something kept me going to try again when I failed and I still had a good time even when I was playing poorly. This is not the case here.Between the performance issues and the game telling me I can't have any enjoyment on a level for more than 8-12 turns, this game is more of an exercise in frustration than it is fun. This game tells you exactly how it wants you to play it, and that can't deviated from whatsoever. Why not just put me in a level with minimal restrictions and let me discover for myself what works and what doesn't?If I could get a refund for this, I would. I can't recommend a title which is so tedious and frustrating to play as this happens to be.Honestly, it's a shame.

number of helpful: 32 of 57 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												So, Xcom 2 is here and people are asking "How is it?"Overall it is a great game and a really nice improvement over the last Xcom game, but it is not perfect. Let's start off with the Negatives shall we? The game is not optimized very well and has some bugs, this seems to vary from person to person but there is no denying Firaxis needs to get to work on some performance fixes. I also had a few graphics bugs when my character goes to pick up his teammates when they are down and a few times the game has gone below 50 fps. No gamebreaking bugs and the performance issues have not been disasterous but they are there and should def be mentioned.With all that said, shall we get to the positives now? There is alot of them so let's get started. First off there are some wonderful additions that really add to the gameplay and overall enjoyment of the game. The animations and graphics are also better, not drastically huge improvement but without a doubt things are smoother and tighter as far as how the game looks. There is a bunch of other new features that add to the game and make it feel like a well thought out sequel instead of just more of pretty much exactly the same as before ala AC or FC series. Voice acting is good and the game also controls very well. I can see myself playing this game for many, many hours. Alot of hours have gone into the old Xcom games and Enemy Unknown for me and this one will be no different, it is very addicting.Overall the good far outweigh the bad for me personally (and by a good amount) but some might want to hold off until a patch or two come out for the performance issues and small bugs. These are my thoughts after 16 hours on the game so far (I will post more after 50 hours, this right now is just a first impressions), if you love Xcom as a series this is a no brainer, I liked the last Xcom but it wasn't as good as the older xcom games, this game here though takes that the last game did well and adds a bunch of great features and improvements, while unfortunately suffering from the odd nagging issue. Xcom is back and it is back in a big way, once the kinks get ironed out this will be even better. Already a game of very high quality but at the same time one that can improve and get better in a few aspects. There are so many aspects to games, from graphics, to ai, writing, voice work, to gameplay,  performance, controls and much more. This game nails 90% of these things with near perfection, but struggles with that one issue, optimization.So many mods for this game! Played a ton of hours on it now and I am blown away by how many cool mods there is already. New Classes, New Voice packs, new helmets/hats/tattoos,etc.. for customization your troops. Yes the game has bugs and performance issues, but that is really the only problem, everything else rules and is a nice improvement over the last game. Did I mention all the mods being awesome yet? LOVING THEM! Especially for my second go at it!

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												If I could refund this game I would. Unfortunately I fell for the hype and preordered this half baked turd. Wait until people have modded the hell out of this to make it actually good.Class trees have been dumbed down to either pick every ability on the left, or every ability on the right. No more mixing and matching to create different synergies. Missions have been dumbed down with their stupid timers forcing one type of playstyle and removing any option to use tactics other than run and gun. The new mechanics of this game should encourage us to explore various ways to overcome and solve them and allows us to develop multiple playstyles. Instead we are railroaded into only one aggressive playstyle which means we have to rely on RNG to go our way too often. A huge step down compared to Enemy Within. The devs should be ashamed of themselves for releasing this garbage.

												Inexcusable performance issues with this game. Very low fps/stuttering performance (I can max Witcher 3 @60fps but not this?), graphical glitches, loads of sporadic bugs in-game, and let's not forget the mini hangs/pauses. Probably the least fluid gaming experience I've ever had, it's like I'm in kindergarten playing Red Light Green Light again.This is a PC exclusive, there really is no excuse Firaxis. The reviewers weren't wrong (unless you hate timers), the gameplay is rock solid. The modding support is excellent. On most fronts its XCOM:EW 2.0. But I'm starting to think the only reason it is a PC exclusive is because the amateurs can't get the game to run on anything else.I tremendously hope they patch this so I can change my review to positive, but Firaxis isn't exactly known for fixes outside of expansions. I'm not holding my breath.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2016
												Even being an experienced X-COM series player, I simply can't stop feeling angry by losing without doing anything wrong at all! No matter what you do or how expert is your strategy, you'll be right in the edge of loss without explanation. Not even the probability of hitting a shot seems to be fair.. I mean, you'll never miss so many 70%+ shots again. It's not "cool, it's challenging. I'm excited how to defeat this level" at all. It's just "forget it, it's not funny lose without guilty". I mean, X-COM has always been known by being a very hard game.. but you could definitely win if you didn't nothing wrong..The new "Concealment" stuff is pretty cool but to be honest it doesn't give any advantage at all, as there are almost always a "time-limit" or "turns-limit", so you'll not be able to use it in your favor the way you wanted. There are simply too many missions being poped-up that you can't even enjoy "building" your ship/researchs/weapons.And, as people mentioned, there are several performance's issues.This game isn't even close from the first X-COM award-winning. I'm deeply regretful for buying this game. Please, stick with the first one.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												While the Game itself is everything I'd want in a sucessor to the xcom enemy unknown 1 (which I played on console). it's an ubalanced fleshheap of a game that is riddled with frustrations rather than anything one could amount to "If I had posistioned better I would've been able to have gotten out of that gah I'll improve next time!" its a more, "Oh those aliens who somehow conquered the earth have no idea of self preservation and will bull rush you regardless of where you're standing they also do more have more health and take less damage than I do" it's the same fault I find in the game dark soulsThe difficulty is all artificial and isn't something that could be considered a strategy to overcome gameYou have enemies that can teleport behind you across an entire map instantly flanking you and then they still get a shot seeing as the spell "teleport" is actually used as their move. they will never NOT flank you instantly and neither will the soldiers. the aliens in xcom enemy unknown were at least cautious in how they made their plays but these ones will even walk out of cover into one where they're flanked just to get a closer and higher percentage shot so you can't be cautious at all you just have to attack the hardest and by then all your units should be injured and sitting out for half a monthThe patrol paths are not set and they are not patrolling. They walk towards you constantly unless you're moving towards them. I tried a sneaky approach on one of the missions where instead of a frontal assault on a base I tried to flank around the rear closer to my objective and sneak in with a quick recall out. instead when I reached where I was at I realized that all the gaurds that I had passed were actually just walking at their "patrol" pace towards me on the map. who cares if I had waited turns for them to reverse their directions so I could sneak past? it was a forced combat situation in which 14 units (8 of which who were snakes that all instantly bound every soldier I had) were dumped into my lap completely unfairlyThe rate at which missions happen and the end game timer runs up are way too simultaneous and uncontrollable. instead of you running any form of what could be considered game it's more of a see how fast your rat army can scramble as you constantly get kicked in the ribs and bombarded. the timers in missions go incredibly fast and seeing how you'll always be facing around 6 units at a time unless you make incredibly risky situations you will just BARELY ever be succeeding in them more often than not you'll have to save scum your entires missions or risk losing the game because your units have paper mache' for flesh and glass for bones (which is suprising seeing as they'll jump down two story drops of their own will rather than use the nearby ladders)In the end this game is just you getting kicked in the teeth for however long it takes you to finish it. 3/5 could be way better if there was a lot more balances to it

number of helpful: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
												Let me be honest: I love this game.LOVE. Not "oh, this game is fun and I spent a lot of time on it, so I must really enjoy it."I love it. Solid gameplay. Great story that carries on in the tradition of the ones before it. Wonderful details in characters and environments. Amazing sound quality. Deep customisation options. Ramped-up sense of danger and difficulty. I could sing the praises of this game for years, for all that it has done right. I love this game and have missed family events to play with it. I have left friends waiting in the rain to finish missions because they were so intense and nerve-wracking. Amazing on so many levels. Ask me, and I'll gush!Which is why it pains me to say that I wouldn't recommend this game to a friend.March 17th Update: I told you folks I'd update you when I have a better idea of what's gone/going wrong. To all the "toaster" comments" and the people talking about attitude, I have to say only that you need to examine the whole of the situation. People are having problems. Nobody knows why."Hardware roulette" is a thing with this game. Somewhere along the way, script got broken or a setting got changed without direct input, preventing some mods from updating. I forcibly removed everything (everything, people) that the game placed on my machine and reinstalled. I then had to validate files almost instantly because things weren't woring properly. Whether this is Steam or XCOM 2 is unknown, but the problems are now fixed after reinstalling the game a few times and making sure the files are validated.There is, undeniably, something amiss. Firaxis has admitted as much, and are working hard alongside the customers and mod developers and magic code sprites to brings things up to speed and deliver the game that was promised. Kudos to all involved.However, it's still kind of lame (and quite infuriating) to have the ability to run at mid-to-high settings and be stuck at low-to-unplayable. This is sadly common and I cannot recommend a game that was so obviously pushed out before it was fully-prepared for launch. "Big AAA" means nothing if the delivery system or the product itself is flawed.It's like buying a used lamp from eBay and it arrives broken at your doorstep. Who is at fault for the condition, and how do you fix the situation easily? No simple answers, but it will take time.In its current state, I don't know that I can recommend in good conscience. Given some TLC, it can be THE game of the year. My review will stand as-is, since I will likely be back to playing it indefinitely without coming up for air. I hope I can tear it down and post an "ALL FIXED" update with a rave review, but the many problems my friends and myself (with many others) are encountering for no reason other than a rushed product (and it doesn't feel that way until you examine it, believe me; it's the most well-polished 95% of a game ever!) keep me from given this game the Thumbs-Up it desperately deserves. Maybe in a week or two.TL;DR: I love the game, but there are a few game-breaking issues, mod support is amazing but buggy at times, seems over-polished without being fully-realized. Worth buying, for hardcore fans and gamers, but may give some troubles.I don't mind "negative" comments, but let's at least keep them relevent instead of bashing preferences or systems. Hardware and OS aren't the issue, in my case, just a sloppy bit of coding that created conflicts. Anyone wanting more information about specific issues will be answered to the best of my abilities.

												Looks like I did not win the hardware lottery requirements for XCOM 2 with an SLI 680.  Have read other people's experience regarding the poor performance and bugs and the like and finally tried to give this game a go - pre-purchased after all. Experience so far - decent intro sequence to introduce the player to the world. Then:Going through tutorial, and the triggers for the next action seem to take 2-3 minutes. E.g. game tells me to click at a certain spot, I do so, then wait 2-3 minutes before I can interact with the game again. Impressions - although they have improved the graphics, it just feels like too much information, messy if you compare it to XCOM Enemy Unknown. Probably just need to get used to it;  I suppose I will try and get this to work by tweaking settings etc, however this kinda sours the experience of enjoying a game if you have to do this. Definitely unrefined compared to the previous instalment.Update: Tutorial still buggy. Went straight into campaign: Dislike- layout of maps messy- jerkiness of movement of soliders, it appears that they are programmed to move square by square especially when turning corners, instead of just a smooth run from one point to another. Example - move one square, stop, move a bit more, then run to selected location.- one of my soliders used a movement point, completed turn the turn moving left, and some how ended up 2 movement points away to the right.Like- I do like how it clearly shows damage/miss- Action cam and slow motionUpdate:Again, issues with triggers - place the X4 mine, and then can't do anything for 1-2 minutes after which the map finishes.Update: For the issue with triggers, seems that all that was required was the good old reinstall.

number of helpful: 47 of 86 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												I am so pleased to give them thumbs up to this game. I was so stoked to get my hands on this new reiteration of the XCOM franchise, and after finishing the campaign, I am very happy to repport that 2K & Firaxis took it to a whole new level. They improved almost every aspect of the game, cutting off the unnecessary ones and gave us even more control over everything. That is how a sequel should be done! I remember my initial dissatisfaction at the delay in the launch date, but my, now I am so happy that they did, cause all the extra game polish worked wonders!XCOM2 is all about survival of the human race. The canon story behind XCOM Enemy Unknown/Within is that we lost horribly and the aliens decided to take the role of "benevolent" rulers who are constantly improving and "helping" humanity. Pockets of resistance across the world still remain and one of them is led by none other than "Central" - our trusty right hand, office Bradford from XCOM1. He goes on a hunt to discover YOU - yes, you, Commander are in the game! And so it begins...In true fashion for my reviews, I will take a look at the good and the bad.The Good:1. Extremely immersive gameplay. To me, this point outweighs every single other. You will get immersed in the story, you will care heaps about the world you are living in, you will care about your soldiers as if they are your children, you will feel happy when all of them make it back and sad if someone gets injured or doesn't live through a mission. You will remember and tell their stories, and I can assure you, there will be tons of stories to tell.2. Amazing story, with great buildup, that only gets better till the final showdown. You will have full CLOSURE in XCOM2, and you will have a lot of fun finding out what happens to you, Bradford, the Council Leader, the old team, new team, everyone! Hell they even tell you why a Sectopod is called like that!!!3. A soundtrack elevated to the next level. Every single song will get you very pumped up and ready to go kick some alien♥♥♥♥♥♥ Turn up the volume, cause you are in for a treat!4. Customization brought to a whole new level - every single thing is customizable now. You can totally expect to spend an inordinate amount of time just making soldier(s) look the way you want. You can fully customize: 4.1. Your soldiers - name, sex, race, nationality, voice, posture, armor types, accessories, colors, etc. You can literally do everything.4.2. Their weapons - as in XCOM1, you have 3 tiers of shotguns, heavy guns, sniper rifles, pistols, and assault rifles that can be named, colored, improved with loot you find on the field, which leads to a ton of new combinations that fit your taste or vision of how the soldier should play out.4.3. Their armor - once again, you have 3 tiers of armor, which is extremely slick and aesthetically pleasing. In XCOM2 you get to kick♥♥♥♥♥♥and look good doing it. What's more to ask? To make things even better, armor types of the same tier don't get obsolete - and you can even make experimental armors to boot!5. The new Avenger, the better take on the world map, and the improved research and engineering – you are no longer forced into using the same best strategy over and over again. The Avenger is your base, and even though it is very much like the old one with levels and stuff to clear before building, it is mobile, which lets you get creative. The world map is your playground where you and the aliens both have your goals – they must complete the avatar project, you must prevent them from doing so by making contacts with other resistance cells, hitting them where it hurts, choosing in what way to hinder them, and so on. The research and engineering have seen marked improvement, and you are even allowed to do meta projects that are not mandatory, but can give you better gear, ammunition, powerful psi abilities, bestow skills from other classes to a certain soldier, and so on and so forth. This gives you a plethora of ways to approach the game!6. The graphics – XCOM2 is undoubtedly gorgeous. Streets, signs, the skyline, everything looks amazing.7. The Combat – the combat remains very much the same as it was in XCOM1, but there have been a lot of small tweaks to make it more fluid. A lot of actions that used to end your soldier’s turn in XCOM1 are now just half the cost – most notably the reload, which now means you can reload and then shoot! Add to that the whole new concealment mechanic where it is actually YOU stalking the aliens! 8. The enemy variety – there are even more enemies in the game, ready to surprise you and make your life a living hell. Every enemy in this game comes with own set of skills and own danger level, and you will have a lot of “fun” discovering who can do what. And when you think you know everything, the enemy will suddenly use some secondary skill you never know he had… like that time a Muton charged my soldier and melee attacked her. And I was expecting shots or grenades…9. The soldier class variations – you may be disappointed to learn that you only have 4 main soldier classes (plus a secret one that I am not going to spoil for you), unlike the crazy amount that the Long War mod introduced, but don’t hate on the game just yet. Each class can be customized with skills (some that even belong to other classes!), psi abilities, weapons and weapon mods to such extent, that you can barely recognize your starting guy.10. The mission timers – so many people hate them, and it is understandable, but as an XCOM veteran, I welcome them. They give a sense of urgency and prevent cheap half move/overwatch tactics. And if you still think this is a bad thing, read No. 11!11. Modding – as Jake Solomon himself said, once you buy the game, it is yours to do whatever you please with it. Less than a week after release, there are already a good number of mods for you to choose whether to use or not, including ones that extend or flat out remove the mission timers people hate so much.12. The line of sight indicator – now you always know whether you are going to be able to shoot an enemy if you move to a certain position. While the camera could be a bit finicky to position in order to see whether the cross appears or not, whaddya know – there is a camera mod that helps with this!The Bad:1. Bugs, bugs, bugs – XCOM1 was no stranger to bugs on release as well, but so far I haven’t had gamebreaking ones, and 95% of them can be solved with a simple save and reload. Unless you are playing Ironman, you have at least 3 mission autosave points to return to.2. Only 3 tiers of weapons and armor – while I don’t terribly mind, the Long War team was employed to help 2K/Firaxis, and they did create number of additional weapon and armor tiers for XCOM Long War… I guess it just wasn’t a priority here. I am quite sure there will be mods to remedy this, though.3. The learning curve – XCOM2 is a whole new XCOM, with many new things for you to discover and learn. It can be quite daunting of a task for a new player and even for veterans with hundreds of hours of XCOM1 under their belts. The game will also force you to break a good number of old habits, which can be quite disconcerting for some.4. Framerate is all over the place – many other people have found this to be an inconvenience and it is fair to point it out.5. Hefty hardware requirements – for a turn based strategy game, the recommended specs for the game are actually quite hefty.Conclusion: XCOM2 is a marked improvement over XCOM1 in every feasible aspect. They learned from XCOM1, cut all the fat and put even more meat where it was sorely needed. 2K & Firaxis took a game that is already awesome and brought it to a new level of brilliance. This game is worth every cent of its purchase price, and then some. Once all the bugs and oversights are dealt with, you will be in for the best combination of turn-based/management/tactical experience to date.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												I have just finished playing XCOM 2 and here are my thoughts about the entire experience.XCOM2 did some great things but executed the overall game poorly.TLDR: Until FRAXIS can deliver a polished product onto the market, they will not deserve money or respect.Good things about XCOM2- Music was great and I enjoyed the atmosphere it created- Graphics were pretty good even though I had to run the game with minimum options for the sake of performance- Great enemy diversity compared to XCOM EU/EW, each had their own unique look and actions- Hacking mechanic did not seem like a gimmick but a solid tactic- New classes are fun to play with, Psi ops are particularly awesome- Diverse grenade/ammo types in the research tree- Lack of overall polish for the following reasons- HUD is pretty much the same in EU/EW- HUD mods vastly improves gameplay- Navigating through the Avenger unmodded is unnecessarily slow with the graphics- Constantly bombarded by annoying NPC chatter- Game does not run optimally, even after lastest patch in March- Bugs that I came across at least once during my playthrough: game crashed after trying to use waypoints for the first time camera shaking after a kill that is not resolved unless the game is reloaded Advent MEC immune to grenades Death Audio looping even after Advent unit is dead Dead Advent troops flooding Advent troops becoming poisoned without being fired upon Dead archon flying/floating underneath final room in the final mission


Archon Flying Underneath Final Room 
A Screenshot of XCOM 2
By: Reversal




 Graphical glitches during final mission at the end- Final mission AI was bad when it had Advent clustered themselves around one platform ready for death


SMRT AI is SMRT 
A Screenshot of XCOM 2
By: Reversal




With all of this said, Firaxis should have done a better job in delivering a quality product. This is not a terrible game by design but an unfinished product rushed for an easy crash grab.

number of helpful: 11 of 17 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10, 2016
												EDIT: as 2017 commences, I thought I'd make a swift dash through this game again, as many mods have seen much work since I had enough, and some new may have come on the stage. ANYWAY; the game is now unplayable, not only for me, but for a growing number of ppl, due to CTD either in main menu, upon trying to launch combat missions, or in a specific scene of a mission. "pure virtual function called (GlsRunning = = 1)" RE-EDIT: February 2017 and XCOM 2 inexplicably works again. Strange.First off, if you enjoyed XCOM1, you will enjoy XCOM2. But wait, performance fixes are needed, and modders are doing a good job patching up what Firaxis has delivered, it is becoming a game. When it came out, it was mostly a storyline, non-canonical at that. Again.What do I like? The battles work much better, now you can actually sneak about - set up ambushes, and spy on patrols and try to predict where is the best angle of attack. Mostly the same game as XCOM1, but with has an abundance of cutscenes and animations, which is a bit of a problem for some in regards to performance. I manage. Snake people are back, instead of the thin man concept, they are actually snake people.Science is still stupid. Always was. If the soldiers given an alien a nickname in the field, that's basically the name that sticks, and you get the animation with the analysis when you initiate the research, not when its done. Well you get it then too - more text, no new content. Lots of loading, nada content. But it was always like that, now its just - IN YOUR FACE. Engineering works much better. There are no MEC's this time around, though. Instead they have more armor, and a hectic game pace. This game is actually a bit of a challenge. BUT: There are no factions, like in XCOM1, you just have money handed over to you from more or less irrellevant sponsors. Why of why have Firaxis abandoned the concept of factions - which were brilliant in Apocalypse, when you could pillage, raid and wage war as much against human organizations, as against aliens, and they would gravitate towards XCOM or the alien "masters" (otherwise that game was extremely silly with teddy-bear graphics...)This game, with its terrorist angle would not be any less of an enjoyment if you could try to make alliances with other resistance groups, could try to convince corporations to lend you aid covertly, or attack these treasonous groups outright for supplies and corvè labour. It is a blunder and missed opportunity that tells me that Firaxis is more interested in mass production than quality.Then we have damage. You can actually kill everything here. You kan kill every civillian and level all buildings without any consequences whatsoever. Of course there is 1 type of mission where you HAVE TO RESCUE 6 people. Because they are yours. But even here you can safely blow up the rest. This is stupid. In the "olden days" collateral damage, even damage to infrastructure would harm your budget and support. Now maybe, as a terrorist, bombing buildings would not have a totally negative consequence but playing ISIS is completely possible here, and doesnt affect the game at all. And is stupid.Now, I have to mention that physics is back where it used to be before Firaxis took up the thread. Now objects will not be hanging in empty space if the supporting structure is removed. Killing aliens by blowing up walls and floors, making them fall many stories, or having the roof cave in on them is actually a workable strategy, and this is a huge and welcome improvement. I could not believe why this was not the case in XCOM1.Now I must also mention the stupid mistakes they have made upon launch. Like smoke grenades actually not providing any game effects at all. Oh you might think you got some defense bonus, but that's just a puff of color you have there. Fortunately, the modders have fixed it, but you HAVE TO get one of those two mods. Like the sound options; you can tone everything down, but there are some ambient and triggered sounds that DONT RESPOND to your commands in the options. Like the intro music that will still blast you upon launch until the menu appears, like the sound that comes when aliens are revealed, this will always be loud, radios and other sources in game will jabber on. So if you play on a headseat, or late at night trying not to wake others from sleep, be aware of this so you dont go deaf or something.Also, still there are no bases to be built. Now you fly around in a captured (?) UFO, which is fine for a resistance I guess, but it must get cramped and you loose any possibility of specializing your capacities. So there OUGHT TO be a feature where you build small bases, which would act as your recruitment/training facilities, the listening posts, R&D stations, etc. But there are No such Things. You fly around the world and set up radio towers. Like the analogous radio network would be beyond the capacity of aliens to infiltrate. There are no base attacks either, so this time around Firaxis saved themselves ALOT of work. There are no alien landscapes at all in this game. Very few aliens as well in fact (they are all projections or genetic reworkings, the aliens are gone).The storyline hints at a dynamic approach with the option to turn against the resistance. This is only in words, there are no such options in the game. It is a uniliear storyline, with very little strategy, and these make up my primary problems; No strategy, no factions nor economics without any diplomacy and very little responsibility.Tactics work fine, great and much better than last time.If I can manage to learn, I will make the factions and the ways to deal with them myself. Cause of course without modbuddy this game would be DOA.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												XCOM is a tough kind of game to sell, because when it's good it's bad and when it's bad it's bad. The best time you can have in XCOM is when you're scraping on the skin of your teeth with one soldier dead and another one bleeding out and a sectoid waving his finger ominously in the distance, and so it's hard to sell to someone who just wants an easy time. Thankfully this is the sequel, so presumably everyone here is a masochist who enjoys feeling like they've lost even when they've won. The first thing that surprised me in XCOM 2 is how much they've expanded the unit customization. Unlike in the previous game, which was somewhat dull in soldier clothes and left me just giving everyone the classic Guile hair, 2 features a pretty wide variety of glasses, hats, hair, beards, and other ways to form a personal relationship with your soldiers before they're eviscerated before your eyes because of your own orders, blood which will never wash from your hands. You can even choose from different arms, legs, and torsos for each type of armor, though the later armors usually have less variety than the early one. The game also has a stronger emphasis on story, with more cutscenes and development to the characters. I thought it was a welcome addition, though it does leave things slightly less resolved at the end than I would've liked. Most of the enemies are reworked versions of the old ones, but there are a few new ones here and there, and they all perform a bit differently enough to give veterans a surprise every now and then. There are still the usual customization options for your soldiers' abilities, but the more interesting ones from Enemy Within like genetic modification and augmentation are missing, leaving the game feeling like there's something more interesting hiding in that expansion pass. Other things like UFO landings also return, but they don't seem to have any real significance like they did in EU aside from just being minor resource grabs. My only actual problem with the gameplay is that in some ways it feels like more of the same in a bad way - they introduce a Concealment feature where your soldiers start some missions hidden and can ambush the enemies, reversing the typical xcom formula where you're the one being ambushed and fitting in with the game's guerilla warfare theme, but after you break concealment the first time it's gone for good except for special skill-based circumstances, and after that the game just starts with the same traditional gameplay. I'm not wanting to change the game into Invisible Inc. or anything, but I think it would be interesting for some of the more low-key missions like hacking a relay to be able to done with a small squad in stealth (or maybe it can - in my game whenever I tried there would be humans blocking the doors to every building, but maybe I just had bad luck). Another thing in this vein that bothered me is that almost every mission in the game requires you to kill all the aliens, rather than just do your work and get out. This is something that made sense in the old games, since you were defending earth from invaders, but in XCOM 2 they've already taken over, and killing this tiny group of aliens is completely inconsequential to their overall effort.But while I overall enjoyed the game outside of those minor flaws, the big problem with this game is the actual build quality. On my GTX 970 and overclocked i5, I managed about 15 fps on the main menu scene, with maybe 20 to 30 in-game. This isn't necessarily a problem since it's a turn-based strategy game, but the problems got worse as the game went on. Reaction shots would sometimes cause the game to hang in front of the character shooting for several moments, enemies would stand still for upwards of 30 seconds before moving, just flying to the single-screen or loading a small map with one building might take 30 seconds or more on an SSD, etc - and that's not even going into all the times characters would go flying around the map or robots would get stuck in trees. During the final fight my game crashed 5 times, and on 2 of those crashes it corrupted my autosaves and made me start back 10 minutes or so. It even caused my computer to bluescreen at one point. The build quality is so terrible that it makes me think that the only reason the game is PC-exclusive is because they couldn't get it to even boot up on a console without it immediately melting.Overall, XCOM 2 is a game that's still good enough for me to recommend, but just know that you're going to have to take some bad in order to get the good. Maybe in the future Firaxis will patch the game, but in the mean time you might want to double-check your specs before jumping on.

Posted: February 11, 2016
												Xcom2 is a difficult and challenging game. If anyone new is thinking about getting it I suggest lots of research and learning on how to apply the game's available mechanics successfully. My perspective is purely from some one who's new to the series and haven't played much turn based strategy in the past.Much of your success will be based on probability rolls. What this means is, even if your shot has an 85% chance of success, you could still very well fail. It can be infuriating, but careful planning and smart use of the tools available can very much help mitigate some of that frustration.


YouTube™ Video: XCOM 2: Initial Impressions (Turn based strategy, Gameplay, and Review) 

			Views: 288		

			XCOM 2: Initial Impressions (Turn based strategy, Gameplay, and Review) Relevant information on American Truck Simulator and links below ► XCOM 2 hours played: 11 ► Completion Status on American...		

I've mentioned that this is a difficult game, and indeed the learning curve is very high but strangely enough, understanding the core mechanics was easy and well paced. Learning how to apply them is the challenging part.Overally XCOM2 is a very satisfying game when things go according to plan, but can be infuriating when it doesn't. I like it!

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												If we purely look at the content, the game is absolutely great. Possibly the best thing that developers have introduced are procedurally generated maps. Maps are not random, instead they are a combination of huge number of ‘modules’ (sets of these modules are exclusive to locations) that are picked and shuffled in a new way every time you start a game. If that was not enough, there is a number of weather conditions that take place – rain, night, flying burning ashes, etc.Classes have been revised, now you have five of them (sword person; hacker; sniper; heavy; and psi-soldier) and sixth will be added as part of the pre-purchase DLCs later this year. I really like the new psi mechanic, you now train your psi soldiers within the base, but you can take them to mission when needed and they will jump in back to complete their current education upon return to the base. If you train the psi-soldier long enough, they become a bit too powerful.Gameplay wise, the game is slightly tougher than ‘XCOM: Enemy Unknown’ and at the same time, I found it mostly more enjoyable to play.Downsides? Visual glitches and a few bugs here and there. Until they are fixed, there is no point to even try completing the game on Iron Man difficulty. Quality Assurance is not exactly the strong part of Feraxis. I hope that they will fix them soon, as they did with the first XCOM and Civ 5.

content:
Posted: January 7
												I dont usually write reviews this early into a game, but I really like this one. Love the customization, that most of the missions you do have some sort of impact on the future, good or bad, and that everything can go so wrong or so right after just one turn. I dont even like turn-based strategys, but this one sucked me in.There are some bad things about this one though, such as that while the customization is pretty good, you HAVE to level up a troop a bit before you can get into the real good stuff, which I dont really get since customization is purely cosmetics to a degree (not counting weapon customization, which isn't all that great).The game also is a bit to punishing for newer players such as me on difficulties higher then easy, absolutly demolishing me on anything higher then easy. Easy is also a bit to forgiving, dumbing down the AI to levels where a 10-year-old could beat the game in no-time with a bit of savescumming.Overall, I'd give it 7/10, since it is a pretty fun game regardless of if you thing it's easy or not.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
6/10XCOM 2 reminds me why I didn't quite like XCOM EU when I played it on console.If you've read around at all, the usual suspects criticizing this game aren't exactly wrong in their gripes about XCOM's core gameplay mechanics:This Game Is a Roulette TableNo pun intended on this game's apparent seeded RNG mechanic (That's a Random Number Generator for you non-nerds). Seeded RNG would be more like a loaded digital slot machine, which is exaclty how is games core mechanics funtion, but anyways...I love strategy games, so I know quite a bit about the niche, from classic cardboard table tops like Chess, Risk, Catan to old school computer titles like Starcraft, Warfrcat, Z etc. to modern day games like Front Mission, Homeworld, and so forth. But, XCOM feels more like being in a sketchy casino rather than a strategy game; It's like betting a big stack of money on an post-apocalyptic alien invasion coin flip.The never ending dice rolls is what takes so much away from this game. No matter what amount of skill a player has in this game, randomness is what sends you spinning out of control, epecially in missions on the harder difficulties.There is so much work lost through random-chance character deaths and mission losses, that any enjoyment and reward are overshadowed from the amount of frustration and hours of grinding and reattemps.And I can attest. I completed the last game on its hardest difficulty and played this one on its "Legendary Ironman" mode just to say that I did. So, I can honestly say I gave this game a complete and comprehensive playthrough before criticizing it.If you've read anything about this game, you'll have picked up on the flame wars in several threads between the highbrow critics and fankids. I suppose I am the former, but the issue is apparent.However, I am a patient completionist. As I said, I played the previous XCOM and beat it (Reluctantly, after several attempts) on its hardest difficulty. It wasn't fun. I did it simply to say I did it.And now I am playing this one on its "Legendary Ironman" and will beat it (Eventually, after several begrudged attempts). But, I gotta say it's really not fun. Needless to say, its really hard. But, it's so hard that it's not fun.I'm just going through the motions for some achievements.Playing it on its hardest modes only bring out the reasons why its reliance on its All-or-Nothing RNG gameplay is just not fun.I suppose this is what the game was intended to be like. That's just XCOM, as they say right? You could play it on easy mode, but why buy a new game at 60 bucks just to play it on easy mode a couple of times? Is that worth it?The gameplay mechanics not only make the game unenjoyable and frustrating, but seems to make alot of things unbalanced as well.I purchased this game with it's AAA price tag in hopeful expectation that I'd see some refreshing new core gameplay and a better level of enjoyment, but I rolled the 2K's RNG dice and it let me down once again as it has so many times before. SighMaybe I am the demographic that XCOM is targeting, along with the other gambling addicts and "masochists"?I cannot recomend this game with it's current $59.99 price tag and have usually told my friends who are strategy buffs to avoid it, as most wouldn't enjoy it. The majority of whom I know that have tried this or the last XCOM game have been disappointed, unfortunately.If you really want to try this game I'd say wait for a price drop or give an older XCOM game a go. Preferably try a free demo. Like I said, you might not enjoy this game because of it's core mechanics. It tends to put off many players.In the meantime, I hope that 2K takes heed from other turn-based tactical games like Square Enix's Front Mission series and reward skill, not gambles.

												As someone who very much enjoyed the first XCom, despite all its flaws, I was really looking forward to playing this.Unfortunately I can't say I'm enjoyig it.I was able to forgive the flaws of the first because it was a new, enjoyable experience.  The 2nd installed comes with all the same problems.  They haven't really tried to rectify any of them, plus it brings some more of its own.Problems such as*LOS issues*Tight Turn Limitations (new)*Free enemy movement on reveal*Inconsistent difficultly curve (a round is either really easy or almost impossible)*One turn wipeouts.  With very little warning you can be doing fine one turn and then the next turn have half your squad dead or out of action, making the mission a guaranteed failure.*Missing when standing next to enemies*Badly implemented "stealth" turnOverall the game just isn't fun. And that's the main problem.  The introduction of the turn timers in particular.  I just don't find myself enjoying them game.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												I am giving a "Not recommended" for the release version. Wait for a couple of patches is my recommendationRasons:- Really bad performance, even on top end systems, like mine. The game recommends me to use highest settings with my system but I actually have to run in medium settings as not to get stuttering or massive frame rate drops. It is a shame considering how good the game looks in max settings :( - Turns are stalling in between player/alien turn switches. - This is a big negative one one for me: Timed missions are poorly implemented. The timers are way too short.  Missions often end after just 8 turns. It is just enough time to force you to rush to a mission end but you can't enjoy the map or possible side actions.  On top of that those timed missions are way too numerous. It makes it impossible to enjoy a stretched out tactical game for those players who like it slower paced and are not overly aggresive.- Melee is far too overpowered. All you need is a squad of sword swinging maniacs and you cut through the aliens like butter. No more tactical weapon usage required.  - Camera angles are awkward at times- Grenades are bugged in some instances when you explode walls- character stances are bugged in somes instances and facing the wrong way while shooting Plus a dozen other smaller bugs that by themself can be overlooked but with those piling up fast are starting to annoy a lot.It very much looks like this game did not get a proper quality control testing before release. *sigh*

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Bug ridden, even after 9 months of release (no mods installed). Just a list of potential issues, including a gamebreaking one:- sound is lagging- game runs smooth, then time to time lags as hell- the longer you play, the more the FPS drops- after missions the camera is stuck, no chance to progress in the game; gamebreaking bug, solution is to validate the game files, then it will redownload one file. Then you are allowed to replay the last turn of the mission and game progresses. Every ♥♥♥♥ing time!That was the last time when I bought a Firaxis game.EDIT: So, the third game verification fixed the game for me to an extent that I can play 2-3 missions without the need for reverification. It's a pity I didn't buy it on Steam and cannot get a refund.Also discovered other bugs (like a certain sound effect stucks, if it should cease in a way devs didn't think it will; like supressing an enemy, then killing that enemy in melee), none of them game breaking, but pretty much discouraging that 9 months after release the game is still plagued with such issues and random freezes.By the way dear 2k, if I refuse to accept your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t online service terms, then PLEASE STOP NAGGING ME, BECAUSE I REFUSED IT FOR A REASON.It's a shame that games industry reached such a stage. Until people stop purchasing tinkered and poorly supported games, nothing will change.FINAL EDIT: Ok, I played this game for a while now, so I can give a final word on it. The game is definitely fun when bugs are absent. It has the typical Firaxis "just one more turn" charm, although it's not flawless. Instead of the ♥♥♥♥ed up satellite-fest of XCom, now you have timer-fest. Really, you are running against timers all the time, on the main map, during missions, almost everywhere. Guess the game designers were lazy, it was easier to overuse this element. For the first few missions, it adds excitement, then it just becomes "meh".Some other bugs I discovered, so you know what to expect:1.) after loading a game (during mission), hotkeys don't work, can't order troops to move, have to reload a campaign map save game (you already had progress in the mission? Firaxis says ♥♥♥♥ you and deal with it)2.) NPC message overlays stuck on the screen without any text3.) music just stops, plain and simple, game restart fixes the problem4.) loading a game makes you stuck on the loading screen, reboot fixes partially, since chances are that you will fall back to bug "1"5.) random gen seems to be iffy as well, like missing a 98% shot, then missing a 96% shot, then missing a 9x% shot, in this order (I start playing lottery now)6.) grenades work strange time to time, enemy units are in the area of effect, it blows up everything around the enemy units, but fail to damage them, reloading save game fixes the problem7.) make armor / items available button either puts you back to the campaign map or plainly makes the game to freezeSo yeah, don't buy it, unless you are happy with paying for a bugfest.
