content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												I loved the game from the start. Even though in any graphical configuration but for minimal the game was full of lag - a problem I hadn´t have with any game in my current pc before, I didn´t mind as the gameplay was fantastic. The innovations and changes refreshed the serie and everything feels different from the previous XCOM even though a lot of concepts are unchanged. In some reviews people complained about the turns limits, but in all the missions that I played that had those, I didn´t need to rush too much and managed to complete the objectives just in time with few turns remaining in a way that it seemed that the number of turns was well balanced - neither making the mission too rushed nor letting you move slowly abusing overwatchs. However, soon the crashes started. Firstly, I tried hard to make excuses such as that the problem was with my computer or that it was just something occasional so I could just let it pass and keep playing. But they persisted and striked everywhere: in the middle of a mission, in a loading screen, in the geoscape, etc. And they have the peculiarity of even if I reloaded a save happening again if I tried to do the same thing that resulted in the first crash, which worsened substantially the problem. In the end I couldn´t evade from the obvious and unfortunate conclusion that the game was UNPLAYABLE - at least in my PC, but I didn´t have such problems with any other game before. Certainly this will be fixed in the first patches for the game but it is rather frustrating to have bought this game in presale and to have waited so anxiously for its launch to receive a product unplayable and to have to wait more for the patches to be able to properly play it. Anyway, it may be that the problems I am having do not extend to all players, but if you are thinking on buying XCOM 2, the safest route would be to wait for the game to be fixed. A part from those problems, the game is great and I will totally recommend it once it hopefully becomes completelly functional and playable.

number of helpful: 32 of 58 people (55%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												Xcom EU/EW is easily one of my favorite games of all time.  If you don't have that one, skip this and get that.  If you do, keep reading.Summary:As a lot of people here have said, this is one of those games that I really wish I could give a middle recommendation for.  The underlying mechanics are mostly solid, but as people have said, the graphic problems are surprisingly bad.Specific Areas:Performance: Dominions 3 is one of my favorite games...I do not generally care about graphics.  But if I could go back in time and not buy this game, I would because of how bad the graphics issues are.  I don't care enough to type up a bunch of specs, suffice to say that xcom runs worse that possibly any other game I own.  Frankly I wish they had just left them alone, because EU/EW ran at least.  While the game technically runs on the max settings, I can't see anything that is happening.  Even on the lowests settings, I'm probably getting about 20 fps and the game is extremely jumpy.  Its distracting to the point of being stressful.  The cutscenes are great, and I would be happy if the rest of the game looked half as good.  Be prepared to be constantly taken out of the moment.Difficulty:  I don't mind the timed missions, though they can be "unfairly difficult".  But xcom has always been this way. War is not fair, and xcom has never been a game of chess.  It is more about recovering from impossible situations...or even just failing spectacularly.  Xcom 2 just ebraced the dark side.That said, this creates a new issue that EU/EW didn't have.  Xcom2 isn't more unforgiving, because that implies that if you didn't make any mistakes you would be okay.  While I appreciate impossible situations...here they feel a little arbitrary.  This might be an odd comparison, but Dragon's Dogma handled this extremely well.  From the beginning, you could run into dragons that you had no chance of beating, but you could also just look at them and being like "yeah no way is that happening".  In xcom, there is giant pressure to do a million things at once, and any one of them may be just completely impossible given your tech level, current team, etc. You have very little insight into what you will run up against, which given how much "recon" is talked about, seems like a missed opportunity.  From what I have played so far, half the time I am collecting or securing some kind of recon, but at most it is always "hey there is a mission here".  Why isn't it ever actual recon, such as "there are 3-8 vipers in the area".  Instead I go on what seems like a story mission, and hey its a Viper King and he kills my entire team in two turns because he follows different rules than anything else and has a billion health.  Which would even be kind of okay because then the game is about how do I recover from losing an entire team, BUT NO hey one of those guys was critical to the story so I lose.  If you want to reload saves a lot that's fine I guess, but I'm only really interested in Ironman.Long story short, Xcom2 is often not great at giving you leeway to think on your toes.Everything else:Its xcom, there is just more and its different.  If you can get past the stuff above, you'll like it.  I'll probably try to finish it.  Someday.  But the performance sucks enough that I might wait til I have a better computer. 5 years from now.  Maybe they'll fix it somehow and I'll change the review and get to enjoy the game.

												The game itself is quite solid and enjoyable, but in its release state, it is desperately in need of work to address issues of balance, functionality, and stability. This is currently an unmarked beta, and it's absolutely not worth the AAA pricetag it's demanding.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												This game isn't XCOM at all, it's more like a strategy game race to get from Point A to Point B, I get there may be some missions were a timer is needed, but it is forced in nearly every single mission. If I have an ambush opportunity, I have time to fly across the United States to get there, why do I find I have 8 turns to complete the mission and extract my soldiers? 0 Point in Snipers at all, I lost mine as I could exctract them in time. I wouldn't recommend at all, until at least some kind of Long War mod comes out, I'm a few hours in and already it feels like the game is forcing me to do this and that as quickly as possible, the campaign has a timer, so you can't even really spend time doing the missions that pop up, you have to throw yourself at every opportunity (even with full Rookie squads, as things like Codexes appear, and you are fighting two boss enemies, after clearing the map, with a basically dead team, wiping them out).Furthermore, Overwatch in Concealment Sucks and is broken. I had a stun trooper, walk in range of all four squad members, all four in overwatch, hit my medic in the face, and then it was my turn? Not a single shot fired by the overwatch guys?!It's a good game mechanically, but the forced nature of the story and every single mission makes me wish I had not of purchased it and waited to see if the modders can fix it.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Previous review was about the spike in difficulty (enemies gets a free move on you, they have OP abilities from start, there are timers for every thing, and so on) but those are not really problems any more with all the mods that came out in the weeks after this games release.What is still in the game thou, and something that maybe will never get fixed is the sheer stupidity in the combat system. I'm not far in to the game (as I waited for mods to even be able to play it) and the amount of bullcrap this game has done is staggering.Enemies will see your sneaking, fully in cover soldiers when they are sneaking on top of a roof two floors up. They have some sixth sense (or wallhacks) and will spot you (and shoot you) from positions that defy all logic or fairness. The game will give you some really neat action shots of your guy shooting an enemy thru a floor, a wall and a busstop. Boy, those are some strong bullets you have in your rifle there soldier!and as every one knows by now, the game runs like crap. It will make your video card work a staggering 116% (as reported by MSI afterburner, GPU meter and HWmonitor) so you better have it water cooled!TL;DR unplayable in it's vanilla state for everyone but the already initiated, the game will constantly "cheat" and it will take your system to the breaking point no matter the hardware.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
												Multiple \"performance\" issues make this game fairly unplayable. And yet I still play it. At it\'s core, it\'s XCOM, and that\'s great. But there are unresolvable issues related to interface lag. I put performance in quotes becaues the game is still rendering, camera can pan, etc, but there are often 5-10 second delays all over the place. Incoming radio transmission? The UI will be unresponsive for 10 seconds. Kill all the enemies and win the mission? Wait 10 seconds. Working in the base and telling Shen to do something? Wait 10 seconds for an \"aye aye commander.\"I recommend waiting until these issues are resolved. Read more about it around the web, for example here: https://www.reddit.com/r/Xcom/comments/446ym8/speeding_up_animations_and_gameplay/

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6
												If you like TBS games in general and you liked XCOM: Enemy Unknown - you will love this game too.Just like with XCOM:EU - you will get sucked in from the very first minute. Holy sh|t it's so fun early on. It gets really hard to turn off this game once you start it. There are lots of things to do and to learn. XCOM 2 changed quite a bit from XCOM:EUCharacter customization is pretty huge! There are many new items, skills, abilities and enemies. The whole gameplay feels really solid and without any hiccups. RNGesus is still bread-and-butter of this game and I think that's the main reason why it's so fun to play XCOM games overall.First 1/3 of the campaign is just awesome. You have so many things to work on, but eventually you will get to a point where everything becomes quite a bit stagnant. It was the same with the previous games too. When you reach the middle-late game - it starts to feel a little bit repetitive. I would have liked to have a bigger variety of things to do on the World map. I think it was a wasted opportunity to make this game more in-depth in that category. But hey, you can't have all the things in this world.Apart from the strange approach to implement RNG into Proving Grounds (a facility where you can research new items and overall upgrades to your squad) item projects. If you are not lucky - you may not even get the items you want in a single playthrough. For example - I wanted to get an Acid Bomb from Experimental Grenade project. I did more than 5 and I still didn't get it. I ended up with several Incendiary and Gas Bombs. Oh well. This game delivers a fun, challenging and highly replayable gaming experience.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												Xcom 2 was an impresive sequal to enemy unknown. with over 250 hours on enemy unknown, i was Antisipating this game to come out. Since it was released I have restarted the game 48 times the vanilla game is a complete pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ but you feel a sense of achievment once you beat it. But not only that , the game is easly modable so you can easly rebalance anything in the game to your liking, and achievments stay active. The Mod community for xcom 2 is amazing, i love the soilder detail and the custom voicepacks mod. As well as some of the beta gameplay mods comming out. There are a few mods that are in progress of being made and im excited for, one of which is the Longwar mod for xcom 2. The game itself has lots of replay , but mods make it forsure that your game will never be the same.                                                                          PROS        : Graphics are smooth and extreamly high quality( most of the time details later)         : Good balance between all dificulty's, the Difficultys do what they say.        : Rng is high which means you will be investing into a new computer because of salt.         : Ironman mode #master race, Those who want to play casual can disable it tho :P (scrubs)        : Lots of classes and well thought out abilities. Between mods adding custom classes and the base classes the game is diverse. Both sides of each tree have completly different play styles which means you can fantasy your dream team to follow your playstyle. (personaly i go with 1 psi 1 ranger 1 granadier 2 spec and 1 sharpshooter)         : Combat does feel much smoother compared to xcom 1, When your soilders miss they dont miss by a football field, all xcom vets remember those moments, 98 % chance to hit, pointblank range , Somehow fires just straight up.                                                                               CONS * Biggest annoyance but adds to the difficulty are the timers in xcom 2 , Now i do reccemend you try beating the game first. but I used a mod which increases most timers by about 2-3 turns. This is not really  a con , Vanilla xcom 2 is a very fast strategy game.*Even though the game is smooth, it has a metric♥♥♥♥♥ton of bugs , like today, i found out if you haywire a mech and hack it. If you put it in overwatch, and it go's back to the aliens team with the overwatch, It can move and stay in overwatch permanantly, Essentialy until you kill it every time you move your unit it gets a shot at them. (until it needs to reload.) *Another bug which is more halorous then anything, Is sometimes how the bullet enviro damage works. When your sniper is on the middle of a roof and he fires at an advent trooper on the ground, the bullet hits him, but takes out one side of the building hes standing on, Which happens to have my ranger sitting on the side in half cover, And my ranger falls to his death because High velocity tank shells are used in sniper rifles. *Explosives OP *theres a mod to fix this, But just how generaly stupid sectoids are. I have a mod which makes them Satans minions. But in vanilla they are some of the most ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ mobs. *  another mod to fix this, But how random the injury timers are. Even if you have a soilder on (impossible difficulty) 5 health and he takes one damage, He can be sent to the med bay for 34 days gravely wounded. And somehow someone who was bleeding out get revived and is sent to the med bay gravely wounded for 14 days. Thats really all i can say bad about xcom 2. I highly rate this game. It is a worthy predissesor to Xcom Enemy unknown.BTW MUSIC IS ♥♥♥♥ING AWSOME :D

content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												Damnit Firaxis! Why did you release this game in such a buggy state?Short version: The game is actually OK, but you risk running into gamebreaking bugs along the way. Without the bugs, the game would be about as good as the XCOM reboot (The prequel to this) with the bugs, you risk major frustrations.Buy the game if you want more of the same, and don't mind restarting your progress.In fairness,  I must have hit about every bug in the game. My first encounter was the second mission, that would not complete. Then around the middle, the game crashed when i tried to research Mag-Weapons. I reloaded several missions worth of saves back in time, but to no avail. That is when i restarted the game. Then, for the last mission, my game just hang on the crew selection screen after the cutscene for the mission played. I only got past that on the last update, and i started playing when the game came out.Mix into that annoying crashes, that resulted in in-game cutscenes being replayed again and again when i loaded the game back up, and you have yourself a full frustration-sandwich.I have lost a few lumps of hair to this game, which is actually a good game, but stupidly buggy.I would not buy it again if i had the choice.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
												It keeps the same frustrations from XCom and adds to them. Unfortunately, everything comes down to a dice roll, which is not good for a strategy game. The player makes a strategy but can't rely on 70% chance to hit, can't move foward to surround the enemy without risking unveiling another group of enemies hidden in the shroud who were just sat there, who will then have flanking shots into that soldier you just moved and you can't do anything about it.The randomly generated maps means you often end up with a map which makes the objective nearly impossible unless you bee-line to it and pop every pod of enemies on the way. Not to mention you sometimes simply don't have any cover when the enemies have plenty of full cover - then again you can't rush to it without risking popping another pod. This wouldn't be a negative if it was intentional map design, but its not, its randomness which screws the player.There's a lot of positives, the new classes are pretty good and fit the Guerilla style very well but the game has fatal flaws at its core which feel like a much bigger drag on enjoyment than with Xcom EU/EW. I've put hours in, finished it on veteran/ironman and tried a second playthrough but it's hard to try and enjoy honestly.Not to mention the DLC so far has been atrocious.The mod community is pretty good though.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												A worthy successor to the XCOM franchise, featuring your usual incompetent rookies with crappy off-the-shelf gear, RNG that'll make you wish you weren't playing on Ironman mode, and a wide variety of aliens ready to perpetrate all of the usual♥♥♥♥♥♥moves upon your soldiers. Like its predecessors, this game is NOT a power fantasy and will constantly remind you of that.If you're looking for a challenging turn-based strategy game with a campaign polished to perfection and a plethora of replayability as you work your way up the difficulties (and take off the training wheels by turning on Ironman mode), look no further. Just the base game was worth every penny, though I can't speak for the DLC or mods.But before you buy, some cons worth noting: this game has a few performance issues and bugs, though most of them have been patched out over time. If you don't want to play with "potato" graphics, you'll need a good-quality computer. Also, there is a multiplayer, but it's very barebones with a ranked leaderboard and not much else, though there are still people playing and the netcode/balance is adequate.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												Still the same card-game mechanics, except this time the game itself isn't even sure if it wants to be Mass Effect 2-like, C&C4-like, XCOM-like or something else-like. More timers, more pressure that isn't quite justified, less balance, most things that were bad about XCOM are still unchanged. The one thing that was fixed was how overwatch targets are handled - units do not waste their overwatch shots on downed enemies anymore if they have a different target on that same turn.Of course, wierd pauses pretty much everywhere are still here; poor intel (actually, criminally poor intel, lore-wise) is still here; atmospheric immersion is worse, ironically because there is more of it - more points of failure have emerged.XCOM you could play while drinking a beer and watching what was on your screen like a nineties action flick - brave americans kicked some alien♥♥♥♥♥and looked cool doing it. This game doesn't play like this. It doesn't even play like a 'rebel tactics'. So all in all, while being graphically an upgrade over XCOM, logically and atmospherically it may well be quite the opposite.Disappointment reigns.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2016
												Although it sucked away 33h of my life, I can't really recommend this game if you want a good XCom game.Cons:-If you have a 60% chance to hit the shot you're going to miss it 100% of the time. Same with hacking and melee when you have 90% chance to succeed, you're probably going to fail 50% of the times.-Doesn't matter if you're in full cover or half cover, the enemies are still going to hit stupid shots on you from far away with their rifles. They also shoot you trough a wall and you can melee attack them through a wall as well.-Abysmal fps. During the opening sequence to a mission, you'll go down to 2fps even on a good computer. Cinematics are 30fps at best and gameplay is 60fps when it's feeling generous but 30fps most of the times.-Stupidly contrived story mode. It doesn't take skill or good tactis to advance the storyline. You just have to wait around until the build, research or excavation timers run out so you can do something until you have to wait again and then constantly be interrupted by stupid alerts and investigations. Allah forbid if you try to research or build something the storyline doesn't tell you to, then you're left sitting there with your♥♥♥♥♥♥in your hand while the avatar project advances more and more and you're flying around trying to collect supplies only to be stopped by a mission to go rescue John Mc♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ from alien captivity. Speaking of missions, the mission timers are ridiculously short. It pretty much expects you to run straight ot the objective and then to the rescue zone but it forgets that you have to fight several enemies on the way who have a 80% chance to hit you from whenever and you only have about 30% chance to hit them even if they stand right in front of you.-Soldiers stay wounded for stupid amounts of time. If your best soldier falls and scrapes his knee, good luck seeing him in any of your next 5 missions. Not only do they stay out for a long time, they also lose will if they get injured too much and then they'll panic even if their teammates ♥♥♥♥ing sneeze next to them and then they run out of cover and get themselves killed.-Sectoids are stupid. They have way too much health and they can just mind control you from really far or just make you panic or confused. Mindshield protects from that but why would you waste supplies on that when you can only buy one thing  before going broke. And grenades are more useful anyway since you can't rely on your weapon's accuracy.Vipers are pretty dumb too since they can try to bind you and if they fail they just take another action and poison or just straight out shoot you but at least they have less health and are easier to killPros:-Good customization options. You can give your characters a lot of different armour and headgear and you can choose from a lot of different colours. Gives your squad a lot more personality and variety-Workshop support. The mods make the game a lot more enjoyable. Too bad if you install too many the already♥♥♥♥♥♥♥FPS goes even lower and it basically becomes unplayable.-Enemy variety. Lots of different, good looking and visually well designed enemies.-Good class system. Although not perfect, at least they added new stuff and the mods make the classes even better.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												Full of bad implementations, lack of polishing and optimzations, while it is expected that most of the bugs/freezing and simply not launching issues are going to be adressed soon, this game had plenty of testing time to actually completely avoid those, not to mention that since is a sequel, experience shouldn't be lacking, yet it does. How do every animation looks worse now? wont they ever learn? just pay attention to EVERY SINGLE dying enemy, the ragdolls are ridiculous. Lacks proper closure, explanations and is excessivelly supernatural even for an 'alien' game. Late game, you may ask yourself why you even need a gun when there's X Y Z factors present (i'll not spoil)However that is not the worst, X-COM is known for it's difficulty, and this one derailed badly on this behalf. Best case scenario, forced a challenging concept that should have been left in the 90's. Time or turn limit, whatever people want to call it, is the plague that affected this game even in before release, that wich is clearly a disgusting attempt to compensate for the terrible (brute force oriented) A.I. Pretty much the same as it's predecesor XCOM:EUBad review? so what else is wrong with it?-The game may simply not launch, forcing a validation check, that may or may not work-Bad support-Glitches, promotions sometimes simply do no work until going through the next mission (one last rookie ride maybe?)-Even on high end machines it stutters horribly-Every action has a 1-2 seconds delay, afterwards it may freeze for 3-5 second by the end of the action-Every cinematic has a "hiccup" or small freeze-Lip-synch is laughable-Animations are clumsy and not fluid, not to say that they actually defy the laws of physics-Shooting through walls/doors/windows and corners! never stay on a corner because it doesnt not block the line of sight as it should!-Melee attacks over walls/doors and windows as well...-The plot is weak, too many questions, not enough answers-Over supernatural even for alien stuff with kame-hame-ha shows going up and down.-Over novelized, terrible closure-End game armors/weapons are extremely generic-MASS EFFECT COMPLEX (this one assures a bad review by its own)Now so I'm not being biased or simply unfair, there are the pros. It's a newer game after all, the graphic is overall better but at some heavy hardware cost, the maps are beautifuly crafted, cannot lie about that, and the customizations is awesome as well, you could spend hours just customizing your squad with very unique appearances.TL;DR on top of the foul turn limit system, its plagued by technical issues and lacks the "smooth and polished" feel for such a title. Wait for patches and fixes, you won't be missing anything, and will save yourself some few gray hairs.

Overall too much Xcom not enough tacticsfirst missionhttp://images.akamai.steamusercontent.com/ugc/321248520393811520/4284E5F44E5B91E2B07288FEFB93EDE26D1E2FF4/I rest my case.Round 2 review: After much "scorched earth playing" with 2 to 3 grenadiers, 1 baller♥♥♥♥♥sniper (Ping MA! CHINA MAN FROM THE KUNG FU LAND) 1 ranger or specialist (depending on the mission) and just blowing the ♥♥♥♥ out of the map. I've found more fun little mechanics the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ AI likes to slither around with. Welcome to search and destory! oh you dont like that? ♥♥♥♥ you. Oh the AI has to kill an uplink for the mission? LOL nope. Keep assaulting the enemies positions because thats the only way to make the game difficult once your main ♥♥♥♥♥ gets the plasma lance and kill zone. If it was a joke it wouldn't be funny. Don't buy this game at 60$ its practically an expansion pack. The grenade mechanics are still a bit wonky too.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												This game is why Fireaxis needs to start implementing emplyee drug testing.  It isn't just broken, it's bad.It's not the difficulty, it's not the graphics, it's not the lag: It's the horrible, poorly thought out game mechanics that traded in working, balanced gameplay in favor of cheap gimmicks yanked from tacky Korean MMOs (read: lottery loot) and a total clusterfark of a strategic map. And the entire plot was unabashedly ripped striaght from Sorcerer King.The Doom Clock is nothing more than an arbitrary time limit that does nothing more than artificially force you down a certain research path & gameplay style under the threat of losing if you deviate from it in any way. The fanbois says this game is proactive instead of reactive - that's complete horsepucky.  This series has never been more on rails than in this iteration.All of the Second Wave options you knew & loved are gone. Random stat bonus on level up? Gone. Random rookie stats? Gone. Flanking aim bonuses have been reduced to a flat rate that doesn't involve any real math. Ditto for criticals. The experience points system have been traded in for raw kill totals.  Comparing the tactical game mechanics of XCOM1 to XCOM2 is like comparing chess to checkers.Your base experience, likewise, has also been dumbed down. Alien containment? Gone. Interrogations? Gone. Interceptors? Gone.  The once mighty research tree has been trimmed down to a pathetic shrub, mostly so that they could implement their latest gameplay gimmicks over in engineering.The engineering room is the epitome of XCOM2's failures. Shen tells me that she's got the technology to make a powered armor exoskeleton combat suit with flame throwers in the arms that can phase through reality and walk through walls like a ghost... but then tells me that the only way we can put a scope on rifle is to loot one off a dead enemy, because manufacturing such an advanced piece of obviously alien technology is clearly beyond her capabilities.  And it gets worse. If you want to make a +1 hitpoint vest then you go to engineering, spend the materials, and produce one vest that can be equipped by one soldier. But when you make a single +4 hitpoint armor suit literally all your soldiers can now wear it all at once. But if you want to make a powersuit then you have to manufacture each one by hand, one by one. But if you want to make plasma rifles you can build one and now literally everyone has them. But if you want to make a fancy hand grenade you have to make them one at a time and, oh yeah, they're completely random even if you've already made one exactly like it before. But that one hand grenade can be used an infinite number times. But only by one soldier at a time.  Shen, your drug test came back and it says you're a carrot.Mind you, these are all the game mechanics that are actually working as intended. I haven't even mentioned the bugs and I'm not going to, because that would take another six pages. Sufficie it to say, the graphics aren't the only place where Firaxis slept through their workday.Yet now I must get to my conclusion and the core of my complaint about XCOM2, and it is thus:FIRAXIS HAS CLEARLY PULLED A BETHESDA ON US.They looked at XCOM1 and how popular LongWar was, and they realized that, oh yeah, they didn't actually have to do any of the work that went into LongWar. The modding community did (specifically, one small and amazingly talented group of modders). They took an already good game and made it great. Firaxis took that lesson and ran with it... and ran with it... past the touchdown line, into the parking lot, and into the next state over.They released two things at the exact same time: A buggy, barely finished game that featured only a minimal amount of core material... and a modding kit. Golly, I wonder what they expected to happen next? It's rather obvious - they, like Bethesada, are 100% counting on a bunch of talented people from the modding communities to figure out how to use their SDK and finish making their game for them.Only 4 classes? Eh, let the modders fix it. Only 3 weapon tiers? Eh, let the modders fix it. Poor interface choices? Eh, let the modders fix it. Limited enemy variety? Eh, let the modders fix it. Weak core, lack of variety, poor optimization, bugs and generally bad design decisions all around? Eh, let the modders fix it. It works for Bethesda, right? Why pay our own people to this game's cornucopia of problems when you can make the customers do it for free?I can sum up all but one of the DLC in two words: "Horse Armor."In summary, Firaxis has given us lazy, poorly thought out game design that focuses on gimmicks rather than real upgrades & deeper content. The gimmicks are trying to prop up gameplay mechanics that were either devolved or removed outright and they just aren't up to the task. XCOM2 did succeed in bringing us a different game experience than XCOM1 did, but it failed at bringing us a better one - or even a comparable one.  This is isn't the brutal blend of strategy & tactics that we've come to love.  This is 2/3rds "Barbie's Army Dress-up Playset" and 1/3rd of blatant "V - The Visitors[en.wikipedia.org]" rip-off.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												No, i would not recommend this game until bugs are fixed! The most annoying for me are "vison" problems - enemies can see and attack you through the roofs\walls sometimes and your squad members can do the same so you can just activate multiple enemy pods because of this. Last mission was crazy! I was unable to aim grenades properly like there was a wall in front of my grenadiers, got visual artifacts and huge fps drops at the last battle. With the lastest hotfix (18 February 2016) and ini-file tweaks from here http://steamcommunity.com/app/200510/discussions/0/846960628563773260/ fps is... fine. Not the perfect but fine. (I have: Geforce 780 GTX, i7 2700K@4300, 16GB RAM, SSD). Visually game looks really nice.Game play is fun actually! Much more interesting than XCOM: EU/EW for me. I was mad multiple times at the beginning (Legendary difficulty), but after i learned enemy abilities and AI i'm ok with the difficulty. There is some BS ofc but it's xcom so nothing new here. Maps (randomly generated) are interesting. No scripted missions! Aliens have lot's of abilities so battles are interesting and intense.Overall there is huge potential in this game but in its current state its just unfinished product. I really hope for the future pathes.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												You can make a mistake once, and this game repeats TWO of the previous games mistakes. First: when aliens see your troops they do that stupid "war cry" and hide free movement. So you cannot plan and execute good ambushes, not even with this concealment system. Second is that hit percentages don't have ANYTHING to do with the weapons range, accuracy, range to target, possible obstacles between you and the target... In both games my SNIPERS, who should hit the target, regularly miss with 90% hit chances. AND I AM WELL AWARE OF RNG SEED MECHANIC that prevents save scumming. Even with 100% chance to hit, my guys miss the shots. Flanking the aliens does not seem to improve hitting them, even when i'm standing next to a huge sectopod, gun barrel touches that robots leg, quess what happens, missed shot, with 95% chance, several times and no save scumming. It is quite hard when 5 out of 6 soldiers miss the shot in same round.When your tactical decisions don't mean anything it is really frustrating to play the game. I hope second games incresed modding helps with this.In the next game, would it be possible to fix the percentage to calculate at least the range to your target having some effect to the hit chance?Second thing, like the original 1994 xcom game, this one and the next should calculate actual bullets firing from the gun. Now the game engine just shows the percentage to miss and nothing else. Back in 1994 is the original XCOM, you had to be wary of chokepoints, shooting when you are behind your own soldier, where the stray bullet might hit, etc... I still remember when using autocannon my soldier missed intended target, but the bullet travelled on and hit some hidden alien on the other end of the map. Or in the UFO: extraterrestrials stray shot went on and caused explosion that killed two of my team.It's hilarious when my grenadier misses big Andromedon with minigun and then hits the wall behind him. Learn from your mistakes Firaxis.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												Would not recommend the Mac version at this time. Performance issues seem as bad or worse than those being reported by PC users. I'll wait a few days to see if a patch fixes things, but expect I'll have to request a refund. I was very much looking forward to XCOM 2, so hopefully the game will be worth a second look once they optimize it and resolve the performance issues.Here are the main issues I noticed playing the tutorial and initial section on the strategic layer:1. The game fails to launch more often than not after hitting "Play" in the initial Mac options window. I only managed to get the game to launch twice out of 8 or 9 attempts. When the game fails to launch, the XCOM 2 app is unresponsive and requires a force quit to close.2. Very poor framerate as reported by PC users, especially during the pre-mission Skyranger sections. I was aware of the reports of poor performance and turned off anti-aliasing, ambient occlusion, and VSync before my tutorial run. Other settings were at "high" except for max texture quality, resolution at 2560x1440. Game was very laggy outside of cutscenes. Exited the game to turn on the Steam FPS counter so I could do some more fiddling with the graphics settings to try to increase the FPS, but couldn't relaunch the game.3. The main menu screen is quite noticeably bleeding through the background at times in both missions and the strategic layer. Distracting to have a ghostly portion of a desert scene suddenly pop into view when you're assaulting an urban Advent facility.System specs:iMac (27-inch, Late 2013)3.4 GHz Intel Core i58 GB 1600 MHz DDR3NVIDIA GeForce GTX 775M 2048 MBOS X Version 10.11.2

content:
Posted: May 9, 2016
												I love the X-Com series, loved the original title back in 1994 and love it's sequel. I even have a fondness for the reboot of the series, of which, to some extent...I would recommend. This title however, though it has some great mechanics in place and could be quite enjoyable, has you suffering through so many peformance issues that you really have to wonder what the hell they were playing this game on while in development. They MUST have seen these issues that literally every one of their customers has witnessed, yet they just didn't bother to fix them.More often than not I sit around 50fps, then at times I will drop down to 40fps in retaliation sites. On an i7, 16GB RAM and a GTX970...that is far from acceptable for this type of game. Character customisation is great, you can set up some great plays and feel like you are being quite sneaky. In the end though, performance becomes your biggest enemy and the RNG regarding your soldiers shots cuts down any tactics you had in place. I want to play it, and I want to enjoy it...but they messed up so damn hard. Sorry, Firaxis, fix it before releasing any more DLC and we might see a change.

content:
Posted: March 23
												The game features some nice updates since the first part: hacking, soldier customization, even the increase in difficulty and the change in settings where you are always being pursued by the aliens (which I personally do not like, but am willing to accept). Visuals look great too. If I were to base my review just on gameplay, the review would be positive.However, the game is still very buggy, even though it's been a long time since the original release. This is the reason why my review is going ot be negative. It has problems setting resolution (requiring me to reset the game resolution every time I launch it), the support for gamepads is buggy (I don't use a gamepad, but I have a few joysticks connected and the game assumes I'm using them, even though I have Mouse as the control scheme - the buggy controller support results in inability to name saves, because edit boxes behave as if the left arrow were pressed all the time), the game crashes once in a while - and those are just the biggest problems. These problems seem to have been known for a long time, so it doesn't look like they are going to be fixed ever.Then there are a few intentional interface design decisions that make things difficult. Texts are rendered on floating screens with a pulsating random effects - making it painful (literally) for someone like me, whose eyes are not perfect. Fortunately, this can be turned off by directly editing the config files. The transitions between different parts of the ship interface may look great, but seeing the same transitional 5-second animation for the 50th time during an evening isn't fun. And again, there's more.So overall, the gameplay is great, but the technical problems make the game so much worse than it could be. Thumb up for just the game contents, but thumbs down for the technical problems, resulting in an overall thumbs down.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												XCOM is back and aside from a few annoying details, it's better than ever.Virtually every area of the game has seen an improvement in some way. The strategic layer, combat, classes, soldier customization, enemy AI, enemy variety, mission variety, maps, resource management, all improved. But optimization and overall polish has definitely taken a hit, and there are a few questionable decisions that hold it back from being perfect.On the strategic layer back at the Avenger, managing your base's allocated space has seen a pretty drastic overhaul, and the new contact system replaces the satellites of previous games. In general, you have a lot more control over what missions you take and what you spend your time doing, instead of always passing the time by scanning for activity like in Enemy Unknown. Now as different scanning opportunities pop up with all different kinds of rewards, you can proioritize which place you'd like to take the Avenger to scan based on the rewards that each location gives out.As far as managing your space goes, the new upgrade system is a welcome improvement over EU. Now you don't need to wait until late-game to get the most out of building generators, for instance. When you unlock the next level generator that increases output, you can just upgrade the generators you have. It's a system that punishes you for early building considerably less than EU did. In addition, each facility can now be staffed with engineers, which are a resource that you'll gather over the course of the game. Staffing facilities gives different bonuses depending on each facility, and you can switch up which facilities are staffed on the fly to focus on what you need at any given time. Combat is much the same as EU and EW, with some subtle refinements and UI improvements here and there. Grenades and explosives are more powerful and more important now, as you'll often fight armored enemies who need to have that armor shredded by explosives before they become vulnerable. Verticality plays a larger role now as the new maps are built more with setting up for height advantages in mind. The procedural map system works brilliantly and honestly feels like these maps were handcrafted. Each of the replacement classes for the classes from EU is a step up from the last game, and each one has two distinct paths of skills that almost make each side feel like their own class. The Ranger replaces EU's Assault class, and can be specced for stealth melee or a shotgun vanguard. Sharpshooter replaces the Sniper and be specced for pure sniper or as a gunslinger (a pistoleer that actually has distinct advantages over a sniper -- I once took shots at 8 aliens in one turn using the Faceoff skill that lets you take a free shot at every enemy in range). The Specialist replaces the Support and can be set up as either a field medic or a hacker, and comes with a drone that allows him to heal or hack remotely. The Grenadier replaces the Heavy and can be either a demolitionist focused on explosions or a heavy machine gunner that focuses on the usage of miniguns. And there's a fifth class this time around, the Psi Operative can be acquired earlier in the game than Psi troopers of EU, and is its own distinct class with tons of great abilities. My favorite is being able to permanently mind control one enemy per mission. And the best part of all of these classes is that you can mix and match skills from both sides of each class, so you have a lot of freedom in builds.Soldier customization is great. You have a lot more control over how your soldiers looks, with customizable faces, names, nationalities, bios, props like shades, headbands, bandannas, headgear like hoods and helmets, full control over weapon and armor color, you can add patterns to weapon and armor (and might I add, weapons and armor can be customized separately), you can pick variants armor torsos, arms, and legs (except for the  middle tier of armor -- you can't change the torso there for some reason) and can even upload your characters to a global character pool so the people you've created will appear in future playthroughs. One big missing feature: If you save a character, you can't load that appearance/description onto a rookie, you just have to hope you bump into that soldier again randomly if you want to use him. To that end, I refrained from using the character pool and will just manually recreate my soldiers next time if I want to re-use those characters. But you can also create characters to be engineers, doctors, or bad guys if that's more up your alley. And finally this one is to Firaxis (thanks for reading, Jake): Give us some more helmets, please. Such a great selection in EU and EW and yet there's only a handful in XCOM 2, and they don't look so good.Now for some negatives: The game is not optimized well. At all. Back at the Avenger it's  not uncommon for dips down to 10-20FPS, and I have a capable rig playing on reasonable settings. I had better performance on missions after the initial ten-second stuttering as the map first loads, but many people have terrible performance all around. Here's hoping Firaxis addresses this in a future patch and manages to make this game more playable for more folks. It's unacceptable that a game in 2016 that was delayed and made exclusive for the PC runs this poorly, especially when the visuals, while ultimately good, are nothing crazy. There are also frequent hitches like the game hanging in between turns, actions taking longer than they should to start/stop playing, UI and sound bugging out. It's hard to understand why the game shipped like this when Firaxis generally knocks optimization and overall polish out of the park.Mission timers. Oh boy. Mission timers are a divisive topic within the community. Some people love them, some people say they ruin the game, some people don't care much either way. I played on normal ("veteran", as it's known in-game) and won my first campaign, and on normal the mission timers are very tolerable. On higher difficulties however, the general consensus seems to be that they're only there to force you to rush and make mistakes. I definitely agree that they're artificial difficulty at best and while they didn't bother me so much at my difficulty level, if I had the choice, I probably would have disabled them. They didn't detract much from the game, but at the end of the day they didn't really add anything.Wounds. My biggest gripe with the game. Injuries for your soldiers are much, much more prevalent this time around than they were in EU. If a soldier takes any hit, no matter how strong their armor is, and no matter if they get healed with a medkit, they're wounded. Wounds come in three flavors, lightly wounded, wounded, and gravely wounded. Grave wounds last up to an in-game month, and while this isn't so bad in the early game, by late-game you're going to be on missions where high-ranking soldiers feel almost mandatory to counter what you're up against. There's a facility where you can staff an engineer to cut recovery times in half, and even then the amount of time your soldiers spend wounded is obscene. The EU system of soldiers only being wounded when they take more damage than their armor adds to their health was much, much better, and I hope this new system is addressed in a patch.Negatives aside, the game that we got is pretty much just EU but bigger and better in every way. It's not perfect, but what is? It's got some problems, but what doesn't? I would still wholeheartedly recommend this game to anybody, especially people who liked Enemy Unknown.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												What a let down.   Game is only a short 20-30 hours tops.   Very linear, extra simplified over the other Xcom remake, has some annoying game save corruption and other odd perf bugs.   The game has really strayed far from what X-com is about.  Hopefully someone will mod in a real xcom game here.Instead of tactical game play, there are tons of missions where you have to do something in a small fixed number of turns (ie, defend/destory X object in 6 turns.)  this means you just have to rush to the objective and end up losing tons of units less you save scum or don't care and just go and lose the mission. Instead of a really good AI, they got lazy and just added in teleporting monsters (teleport next to your guy, free shot, rinse repeat),  ones that have very high move rates so they can close in on you in one turn even if you setup a shop tacticaly a few screens away.Due to the forced events that control game time, the game has limited replayability (compared to say X-Com:UD or X-com:TFTD.)  Save your money, buy it for a one time $5-10 expiernce when it goes on sale.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												I like the game because I love xcom, but I can't recommend it. There are performance issues, bugs and just unexpected lazy efforts in some areas by the devs. My computer is high end, I get mega load times and huge lag spikes some graphical errors here and there with animations. They say it's not universal and they are aware that some high end systems have issues. That's basic laziness because things like that would easily be found out with any, ANY competant testing. Who did the math calculations? They should be fired and never allowed to work anywhere near a computer or anything electronic again. Oh you can miss 98% shots 10+ times on a playthrough but good luck ever making a 30% hack. 30% = 3 out of 10 in most parts of the world if not all. Try a 30% hack 500 times and let me know if you ever succeed. These aren't game breaking but seriously annoying. Gee let me try that 50% hack, nope denied, everyone is discovered, enjoy, be sure to try next time. Seriously? There is very little strategy in this one too, kill, kill, kill, kill. What you build and in what order matters very little in this one, just do every missions, destroy the avatar buildings as fast as possible, unless you like reloading saves never try to hack anything and never bet your mission on a single shot unless it's 100%. It feels more like a step back from the Xcom Enemy Unknown not an improvement. This one EVERY rookie can be a psi operative lol, and no jets vs. saucers, if I didn't know better I'd think this game came first and Enemy Unknown was the more advanced newer game. Just my opinions, play it and judge for yourself. If you never played the earlier versions you'll probably love it, if it runs well on your computer.

												I don't normally downvote games when I have so little playtime, but here, I feel it's justified. That playtime you see - about 15 minutes of it is actually game time. The rest is being stuck on a black screen right after the 2k logo etc., I have tried nearly every fix there is, and that I could find, to no avail.If I pay $60 for something, I expect it to at the very least be functional on the most basic of levels the day it releases. Yes, it functions for some users, but many have various performance issues - mine being one of the worst out there. So, I am posting this review of the game to clue prospective buyers in - it may be hit or miss with your performance, and it may not even run if you're really unlucky. For those curious, I am running Win7 64-bit, gtx980ti 6gb, 32gb of ram, and an intel6700k 4ghz. Maybe this information will help you in deciding whether you want to buy the game or not.Perhaps if they fix it in the future, and I decide to buy the game again, I will change/delete this review.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												AFter playing XCOM: enemy unknown I was interested in the XCOM series, but I wasn't too keen on getting XCOM 2 because I found enemy unknown to be lacking and at some points rather dull. But for the autumn sale I got deluxe edition. And I can say this, I love this version of the game! It has more refined graphics and the characters movements look more natral whether its a cutscene or actual in game movement, theres a wider veriety of enemies to fight and the story is very interesting and with the DLC's you get more weapons, items and even some unique units to put into your squad (which I won't spoil). I love the depth of character customization and equipment modifying that helps me make my best squad.Along with this the game has new types of missions and mechanics. such as if one of your characters is unconcious and the mission requires you to go to an evac point, you have to carry that character with one of your other squad mates, otherwise they become MIA. But if a member goes MIA that isn't the end of them, it is possible for you to recover them if you get a VIP rescue mission because they can sometimes be the VIP you have to rescue.Theres so many things to talk about in this game, but one thing I'll say is this. This game far outdoes the previous game and is well worth getting.

content:
Posted: February 3
												Around a year ago I was in two minds when it came to recommending XCOM 2 or not. I enjoyed my first playthrough, but there was something I could not put my finger on that, unlike XCOM:EW, deterred me from repeat playthroughs. That has certainly changed with the introduction of the Long War 2 mod. It turns a solid but somewhat unoriginal sequel into something that I'm enthused by all over again. It makes the game different enough from the preceding game in ways I care about.Without mods, XCOM 2 felt like a solid refinement, but not enough to sustain the time investment that multiple playthroughs would require. And without multiple playthroughs, it's hard to get a solid feel for how the hidden numbers behind the strategic layer play out. And without a firm understanding of that, it simply becomes a long string of loosely connected tactical missions.I'd still recommend XCOM: Enemy Within before this. If only because that's bound to be cheaper, and is still an excellent game. After finishing that though, I do feel that the current state of XCOM 2 with the mods that are available makes it worth moving on to once you are done with EW.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												(05/02/2016)I dunno, feeling bit iffy.97% flanking shots missingevery mission is a race against time.I dunnoPlayed x-com 1 on impossible, and it's got less bu****it shots than this one does on 'classic'Left me with a strange feeling.Doesn't feel like x-com in any way.Gonna give it some more time.But it's allready drained all my energy today.Left with a sort of sad, empty feeling.My expectations where too high I guessEdit: (06/02/2016)Not only that, but it is very clear the game got rushed.Too many bugs ruin the entire experience.One time you can't see what you're hacking, as the camera thinks holding a wall in front of your screen is more interesting. Another time, you see an enemy soldier slow-walking out of his position, rubberband back to where he was. Then he performs the same move, and suddenly one of your own soldiers drops dead without anything attacking him.When trying to move your squad somewhere in cover, checking out good locations, the camera also loves to jerk back to the character every 2 seconds.Picking a good spot can thus result in the wrong tile being targetted instead, ruining everything.On other times, targetting the correct spot refuses to respond to the move command untill you wiggle the mouse around a bit.Too much 'lagging' and extremely long loading screens ruin the experience even more.A high-end computer turns into a vacuum cleaner and has trouble switching smoothly from one screen to another.This is especially the case in between missions.Even returning back to base gives you enough time to do some groceries.By the time you get back, it may have finally loaded.There's also too much aggravation during missions.A 99% hit shot at point blank range against a berserker decides to result in a miss.And more too often, do enemies with 20% chance to hit your people, get a perfect shot at them.Launching/throwing grenades now 'locks' to a tile.No more free-aiming, when you know you could hit 3 targets if it didn't force you in this position.Resulting in more too often, having to choose between hitting 1 big enemy, or 2 smaller ones.While free-aiming could perfectly get all of them.X-COM 1 had me hooked from day 1, and still makes me play it with a lot of pleasure on impossible difficulty.X-COM 2 is depressing me to a point, where my energy is drained. And I must even push myself to turn the game on.It definately needs a decent fix at the point of this writing.Looked forward to this one so hard.Never have I been disappointed so horrendously before.Guess I expected too much.Edit: (07/02/2016)Now even more bugs pop up, as 2 mutons and a berserker show up.Having hit a regular muton with fire ammo, he is going to burn to death on his next turn.So the heavy can focus on the berserker.No matter how many times I reload this particular save, the heavy keeps firing at the near-death muton, no matter how many times I try to force him to shoot the berserker.There is even the third one in his sight, and that one isn't even an option when klicking it's icon.The grenadier guy wants to finish off the dead muton, no matter what.(spoiler): If even troops start taking random orders (not even disoriented or anything), then central could have saved the trouble of freeing the commander. Since these freedom fighters take orders of their own anyway.Watch the bug here:


YouTube™ Video: X-Com 2 infant problems: Bugged to the core 

			Views: 42		

			2 days of suffering since it's release, is what X-COM 2 has been. This is only one of the many issues the game suffers from.		

And after trying to move a ranger in close from a different angle (since the suggested path makes him open), the game suffers a critical crash.The game definately needs a stabilize protocol at it's current state.Edit: (08/02/2016)Bugs keep popping up left and right.Game crashes, wrong actions being taken, etc...Launch grenade! ..... evac point gets marked instead... -.-Wait... wut?For 3 days, I've been sighing and staring depressed at the screen how one horrid bug after another unfolds.When you're reloading the same file 10 times in a row, hoping the bug will not trigger this time, you know you got some real quality on your hands.Also, why do extract data missions require you to kill all aliens as well?Package is secured, there's 135464645 billion more aliens around on the entire planet.But killing 3 more is a must to have the objective completed (or it's marked as failed).Sir, we got the data allready? -.-Just sitting, feeling your life drain away from all the stupidity that occurs, and sighing the day away.I thought games where meant to be interesting and entertaining?Even the people living with me are affected by the way this just brings me into a dark depression.I understand there some masochists out there, who love seeing their entire squad get bludgeoned.I just want to see my people make it through the day and actually advance (without stumbling into another 50 bugs).Left with an empty feeling.Forcefully pushing myself to advance.Why am I not playing boshy or another anger-inducing game then?Because X-COM did things right.Yes... did.This one... it's something... but it's not X-COM...Final report (10/02/2016):After 5 days, beating the game on commander (classic) difficulty, I can finally make my final report.And sadly enough, it still remains a non-recommended from my point of view.Replayability is extremely low compared to it's predecessor.The Avatar project counter ensures that you have to, sooner or later, make a move towards the end objective.This excludes having time enough to explore more, train more troops, and all around have a lengthy ammount of good fun.The player is constantly being rushed and pushed. The game tells you how much time you have, untill you're forced to end it, taking away the player's freedom entirely.Thankfully, the modding community is very active. Most likely, there'll be a mod where this avatar project no longer limits your play time.I loved spending hours in X-COM 1, finding new recruits and exploring their potential. Literally playing for months on one playthrough, in search of assembling those particularly unique good people.Which also brings me to another minus point: There is no second wave option, once you beat the game.'None are equal' and 'hidden potential' are nonexistant, 2 of the options which where my favourites.Once you beat the game, you get the choice to make another playthrough, and that's it.Only ironman remains, but what's the fun if you can't add in random generators of your choice?Again, it'll be completely up to the fanbase to make mods for these.There was also a dissappointing lack of customization options in terms of character creation.What was promised as an endless ammount of possibilities, ended up in only 6 faces to pick from.Also props and such, fall pretty short if you look at them.There's too much 'cheating' going on in the game as well.Have a patrol passing by, and waiting for them to leave to sneak past?The moment you do so, the computer decides to send this patrol right to your hiding spot, instead of completing it's patrol route.Dumbass enemies like the sectopod, andromedon and gatekeeper, destroy their own facilities with their patrols. Showing little to no care given to the facilities in which their own avatar project is being processed. Some patrols even refuse to move, when your team is hidden away, waiting for them to pass. Resulting in an endless loop of ending your turn, waiting for these stubborn guys to move on.This ruins the stealth aspect of geurilla attacks, negating them pretty much entirely.Operating in shadows is only good for getting that first scout off. It pretty much ends in guns ablazing. An attempt at being groundbreaking, but failing to do it's part.If you plan to play the game vanilla only;Wait untill it's on sale.With the game now completed, it fails to keep me in a grip like X-COM 1 did.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												Firaxis is kinda infamous for buggy releases but this time prelease reviews were claiming it's relatively free of game-stopping bugs, only chock-full of visual animation/camera bugs. While it seems like there aren't a ton of of game-stopping bugs there's still one pretty major one: During any mission the game can crash and corrupt every single save made during the mission, including autosaves. On ironman this means game-over - you have no chance of salvaging the run. Without ironman you can go back to the latest save made on the world map - though considering that the intended/prefered way to play xcom as stated by the devs is ironman a bug like this is unacceptable. Personally I ran into this bug around 3 times even before the final mission but what takes the cake is that this bug seems to be most common during the final mission - several prominent streamers had their ironman-run killed right during the final mission due to this bug and one streamer I occasionally watch is now waiting until there are any fixes for this bug before attempting the final mission.Other noteworthy bugs include the enemy AI completely borking out which in turn has the effect that the AI's turn takes an abnormal and aggravatingly long time while actually remaining completely stationary and inactive.Another common bug is the alien viper enemy being able to use their tongue-pull to pull your soldiers without any line of sight and through entire buildings.Combine these technical issues and game-stopping bugs and the extremely poor optimization that a lof of people already have drawn attention to and I don't see how Xcom 2 deserves to be supported/bought at full prize in its current state. If you put aside the technical issues Xcom 2 is a fairly fun and decent squad-based TBS/RNG-BS game and would be worth the full prize for fans of the genre like myself - in its current state it's a lot less clear cut. My advice would be to hold off and wait until patches are out and while you're at you might just as well wait for a sale. Personally I won't buy any Firaxis game at launch anymore and instead hold out for patches and sales. At this point I just don't trust Firaxis to not release a game with game-stopping bugs and I don't think they should be rewarded with full-prize sales for a MO like that.edit: i feel like a lot of reviewes kind of glossed over the more major bugs, this one does a good job at addressing the issue imo: http://www.giantbomb.com/reviews/xcom-2-review/1900-733/

content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												For someone, who don't want to read this all:Positives:+ improved game mechanics+ "new" classes of units (Grenadier, Ranger, Specialist, Sharpshooter, Psi Operative, SPARK - in DLC Shen's Last Gift))+ many kinds of enemy units+ more tactic possibilities than XCOM: EU or EW+ great graphics+ nice soundtrack+ thrilling storyNegatives:- unlike old x-com series you don't have to take care of many things (game is easier in some ways)Ok, where to start. After XCOM reboot, most players were expecting, that this XCOM will be underwater. Luckily it's not like that. I mean, I like Terror from the deep, but it didn't bring anything new (but this game has a little legacy of Terror from the deep - magnetic weapons). This XCOM is really big surprise to me. It keeps game mechanics of XCOM, but it has many improvements. You are on the opposite side in this game, prepare to be an intruder. Now it's not the time to defend the Earth, but conquer it back! Your forces are hiding in flying base and it's your responsibility to make right choices. I'm disappointed with one thing. Games in this age are getting really easier. I don't mean, when you switch difficulties (you can make every game really challenging), I mean, do you remember old x-com series? There were many things that you have to take care of (richer micromanagement). In this game are only several things. However, it won't stop me to really enjoy it. I recomend this game for fans of the old series and for players of new XCOM.Guys, just enjoy it!P.S.: I consider XCOM 2 better than XCOM: EU or EW.(Edited and updated 01.10.2016, 23:20)

content:
Posted: February 26, 2016
												TL;DR? = Unenjoyable, Every mission felt like a chore, stupidly flawed probability system, missions gradually become impossible to complete, game forces you to play how it wants you to play, timer to beat the game makes it virtually stressful and unrelaxing. I personally enjoy turn based games with a strategic and tactical element implemented to make you feel like a commander of a fireteam. This game fits right in there but with major disappointing twists that have rendered it unejoyable and everything about it is forced onto you. In addition, one thing I HATE the most about this game is the element of probability, and not just that but the probabilities you get in terms of a successful hit are very unrealistic and just straight out annoying.In the beginning of the main campaign, I was having fun. Missions were playable, but only easy if you knew how to position your fireteam and target the most lethal and threatening enemies first while taking care of your own team in order to suffer little to no losses or damages. I was mastering that pretty well. The enemies I faced were a suitable match to the soldiers and lack of equipment I had to begin with which was fair enough. Then came this AVATAR project. Now I understand Firaxis wanted something unique, but to implement some sort of timer required in order to beat the game well thats just thrown any form of relaxation and joy of the game straight out the window. Then enemies staretd to become harder, and I couldnt keep up with improving my team and equipment. The game forces you to use your veteran teams more often due to the sudden rise of difficulty. Leaving you with no chance of using any additional rookies to promote them and give them access to better equipment. The further into the game I got, the more stressful it became when you lost even one soldier (who was either a squaddie or Cpl) because that meant you needed to replace him/her, but that was vitually impossible because I have now reached to that part of the game where every mission I play now is extremely difficult for rookies. I then eneded up having to restart because I kept losing soldiers bit by bit after every mission. How I was losing them I will explain later.Now the missions themselves I believed were forced onto the player. You're given a mission to do in which although you have an option to skip it, you will suffer a serious penalty if you do. Now you're probably asking, why would you want to skip it anyway? Well maybe because I was in the middle of picking up a supply drop and researching equipment to further improve my fireteam, and I know that if I don't finish those researches then I won't stand a chance in hell in doing any further missions. I understand that sacrifices have to be made sometimes in order to complete a mission, but sacrificing after every mission makes any future missions impossible to complete. It's stressful enough that you need to spend time in collecting supply and researching equipment in order to keep up with the mission difficulty, but then to stop me mid way and literally URGE me to do this mission or I suffer a penalty, its just silly. I also understand that they make us do these missions so that we dont go ahead of the difficulty and enter a mission with a fully kitted out fireteam making the mission a walk in the park, but the difficulty is already way ahead, after the fact that I lost two soldiers from the previous mission, and I had to waste supply recruiting more which will be useless because they dont have the equipment to even survive for two turns in the next upcoming missions (sorry for abusing the word "missions").Now onto the stupidly flawed probability system. 6 out of 10 ten times I was given a probability of a 70%+ chance of hitting the enemy and I end up missing. 2 of those 6 misses my soldier was in point blanc range of the enemy. Not only that but on several occasions my soldiers were behind full cover and end up getting critically hit back to the stone age as if they were sitting ducks out in the open (and no they weren't being flanked because the sheild symbol was still blue and not yellow). You were doing a good job killing off the enemy fire team with no wounded soldiers because you mastered the arts of flanking and cover just to have one alien, suddenly blessed by the vision of god and snipe one of your guys who was behind a brick wall. I stopped beliving it was due to unluckiness and started thinking that it was just plain bull, since it happened consistently. Overall, the game became less enjoyable after every mission. The missions started to feel like a chore instead of actually being hyped to do them. The probability system works against you and in the favour of the AI, despite following every rule in the book when it comes to a turn based, stay-in-cover-and-flank game. The game makes you play how it wants you to play, and any diversion from the "script", and you get severly punished. 2/10 would not get critically sniped behind full metal cover again.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												Full of bugs. - On some tiles despite the fact that the interface shows you can go there you cannot, this even if you change views. This totaly ruins the already limited tactics you can apply. - The game freazes in cutscenes (e.g when the Advent reinforcements arrive, when you discover enemies etc.) and also randobly after totaly random turns. You have to wait minutes until the game gives you back control of your units. - The game crashes in cutscenes (e.g. when you destroy a Avatar base and  it explodes at the end of the mission) - Idiotic tutorial, it forces you to move in particular places on the map, forces you to make bad decisions and you loose soldiers. This not mentioning the fact that it does not explain anything useful. I played most of the XCOM series and it confused even me. - The aliens are overpowered even in the second level dificulty (Veteran), they hit you 90% of the time from insane distance, most of the time with critical (even if your troops are under full cover) and 80% of the time your troops panic.  - Your troops suck, the sniper misses shots with 90% chance to hit 2 times in a row, the heavy never hits anything, so on so forth. The only good soldier is the ranger.  - Another huge inconsistency that prooves the AI advantage over the player: Turrets. A hacked turret never hits anything even from almost melee range while a turret in AI control will hit you half way across the map evey time. I will stop with the examples here im sure there where other players mentioning these things in other posts. My conclusion: - this game is not fulfilling his role as a recreation, is not fun, gives you no satisfaction, after playing and while playing it leaves you frustrated and with a very bad impresion. I know the difference between a complicated hardcore game and a really bad implemented one, this is the latter. Unless they fix it don't waste your money and time on it like I did.

												I'm gonna try and keep it short. I was a huge fan of Xcom Eu, and like many, was eagerly awaiting the arrival of Xcom 2. I preordered the game and found very quickly that i should have waited until it went on sale. The modding community is the only thing that made this game bearable for me. Why wouldnt i recommend this game? It's tedious and exhausting in comparison to its predicessor. The game constantly makes you feel rushed and forces you into sloppy compromises during game play, such as putting a 5 round timer on missions. Honestly, if it werent for the modding community, this game would be a wash. theres literally no compelling story line and the characters are easily forgettable. Read some of the more extensive reviews before buying this game, they do a much better job of explaining it than i, and please, if you feel the need to buy, at least wait until it is on sale.

number of helpful: 10 of 16 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												It's XCOM baby!Going into this I was expecting basically an up-scaled EU/EW with a tweaked storyline.  While it looks similar, the feel and gameplay vary greatly from the first game.  I just finished my first run through and I enjoyed every second of it.This isn't the old school "overwatch till death" game we're used to, You actually gotta take risks and think tactically to get anything done in XCOM 2.  Not only are you weaker than in the first game, the enemy is way way stronger, and you'll be punished badly if you make a mistake.  I accidentally moved one of my soldiers 2 tiles too far and lost 3 of them in the aliens' turn.If you enjoy getting the most out of meagre resources while fighting endless enemies with a few good, though fragile, men( or women), This game doesn't dissapoint.  The only criticism I have is the graphics glitches that sometimes occur, like a movie not loading, or the screen freezing for a while, but I put that down to growing pains, and the development team already said that they were working on those.

content:

												I loved XCom, and beat it on Normal Ironman [1] twice. But after eight hours XCom 2 (Veteran dropping to Rookie after a while, Ironman again) seems hopelessly, needlessly hard.May have another go on Rookie from the start, but right now am not inclined to.If you don't play Ironman, you may of course find it easier. Much of the hardness takes the form of viciously punishing small mistakes - being able to restart the mission would help a lot there.(I have no-interest in non-Ironman play - it just doesn't have the same rewards)[1] Self-imposed, since the single save isn't reliable against software faults.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2016
												The developers of XCOM 2 were upset that early beta testers of their game found it to be too easy.  They responded to this problem by adding difficulty, not by restricting the number of turns available to finish a mission or by making the enemy AI better, but by upping the enemy HP and throwing more of them at you than is reasonable.I'm on the first terrorizing mission of the game.  My squad size is four.  It's impossible at this point to have increased it to five because there haven't been enough missions to get someone to sargeant rank.  When I move forward for the first time on the map I uncover five enemies.  They each take a volley from my entire squad to take down.  The five enemies are: a sectoid, two commanders, and two stun lancers.  One of the civillians next to me is actually a shape shifter.  If I kill anyone other than the sectoid in the first round, it's immediately resurrected as a zombie.  The shape shifter gets to reveal itself and attack in the same turn regardless of whether or not I get close enough to it to make it transform.  There is literally no way for me to avoid having at least one stun lancer running through my party knocking people unconscious after the second round.XCOM - you didn't make this game more challening by making it more unfair.  You made it infuriating to play by obviously overstacking the deck against me.  This♥♥♥♥♥♥isn't fun.
