content:
Posted: September 24, 2016
												Well, after i have played over 200 hours, i think it is time for my own little review.I have played XCOM2 since release and it gave me very mixed feelings from start on.Is it a bad game? No, of course not. It really is a good game.I really do recommend buying it! (the base game, not the DLCs)Install all the cool mods that are out there and enjoy the game!But if it is a good game, why do i give it a thumbs down?I play XCOM since day one. UFO, TFTD, etc... I have played them all.I do not consider myself a pro gamer but i have played them all.And i really really loved the new XCOM EU/EW.But XCOM2 just makes me sad, mad and angry! It is so disappointing!On release the performance was just crappy and there were so many technical issues.Then there are bugs everywhere. Even today.This line of sight issue is just a no go for a game like this!Timers? I hate them!The user interface is just bad. This game is about numbers and gives you no inforamtion.It lacks any comfort-features and you need lots of mods to make it enjoyable.The game offers 21:9 support but no one adjustet the interface. Why do i need a mod for this?The global strategy gameplay is also designed very badly.Running an underground organisation and using guerilla tactics offers so much possibilities.All you get are the same 3 scripted missions that pop up every month at the same time and have the same goal.Why do i have to choose between 3 very hard missions when all my soldiers are wounded?Why can´t i just do an easy mission with some rookies an raid some kind of warehaus to get supplies and XP?I run a secret organisation. I am supposed to do whatever i want to do, whenever i want to do it!20 years ago, good old UFO gave you total freedom in your gameplay! There was no big story but it worked!The soldier classes are not designed and balanced very well.The DLCs are just bad. The enemies are not balanced and do not fit into the gameplay.Why does someone put in a giant sectopod when the graphic engine can´t deal with it?The rulers are a good idea but badly implemented.And so on...This game had the potential to become the ultimate Xcom but at some point in developementeverything went totally wrong. The graphics designers did such a good job butthe game designers totally went in the wrong direction. They failed miserably!But as i said, it still is a good game and i recommend buying and playing it.But for me, this is so disappointing. It just makes me sad! So sad...I really do hope for a big expansion that fixes some of this problems.

number of helpful: 26 of 47 people (55%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												9.5/10I've just completed the game on Commander difficulty and immediately decided to do it again but on Ironman as I did do a little bit of save dancing in the most intense parts of the game and want to remove the temptation next time.For anyone that loves a multi-faceted strategy game that delivers tough decisions at every layer then this game is for you.Pros:+Aliens are much more varied than before requiring new tactics, tough decisions and intense fights.+Your non-standard gear is random. I only unlocked a few grenades and some vests on my first playthrough and they went on every mission. Can't wait to unlock new interesting items.+You can play your own way. I finished the game without recruiting a single Psi Operative.+Every non-story map is procedurally generated, I have yet to see any serious repetition as I start my 2nd playthrough.+The new perk trees are interesting and fairly balanced, I did not at any point think I wanted to bring ALL of one class on a mission. Though I did exempt Psi-Ops just because I did not have time to build extraneous facilities.+The strategy layer is much more complex than the original and the addition of strategy missions for gaining resources along with the task of building a resistance network, recruiting and assigning Engineers to Excavation, Construction or Maintenance, researching specific technologies and dealing with the Black Market makes it an entirely seperate and sophisticated game within a game.+Character customization is now an incredibly powerful tool that will allow you to create many varied characters and through the game give some extra badass-ness to your best performing soldiers.+The character pool system allows you to add your family and friends into the game, but still nestled inside the random generation of the game. I recently had one of my friends mind-controlled and shot another friend in the face whilst attempting to escort a 3rd friend to safety as a VIP. This also works with getting attached to a character in a previous game and saving them to the pool for later games as this super badass.Cons:- The game bugs out occasionally with the screen being blank or units dancing around the screen, once my screen was blocked by scenery whilst attempting to hack and couldn't see the UI.- Nothing throughout the entire game prepares you for what you will face in the final missions, it was disconcerting when I first attempted them.- The main story is a bit weak but the game never focuses on it for long.

number of helpful: 26 of 47 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												XCOM 2 is to XCOM what Beyond Earth is to Civ V. The same game, made slightly different and released with a lot less features than you might come to expect after playing the previous game. If you're unfamiliar, Firaxis seems to be making a habit of releasing the bare minimum required to catch people's interest and to then release $50 expansions that slowly bring the game in line with what you were actually expecting.The game plays out much the same way, including all the graphical bugs we know and love from the previous game. There's no real graphical change, just a slight alteration in overall aesthetic. The Avenger is a simplified xcom base with an ideal layout that is obvious once you work out just what things do. Put the power on the big power things, put the workshop in the middle and then build everything. The interface is completely unchanged feeling exceptionally clunky with mouse and keyboard, especially when trying to use area of effect abilities such as grenades. You don't have any mechs of any sort this time, just soldiers which are divided in to five classes now, mostly the same as the previous game just psionic is now its own class that is easier to secure a soldier for and brings back memories of an avenger full of Psi Amps considering how strong it is.There's a lot more I could say about this game. It's not a bad game, don't get me wrong... but there's no way I could recommend it to anybody. This has sealed the deal for me on this developer. Wait until they're making xcom 3 and then buy a bundle with the full game when it's on special. Spend the $90 you'll end up saving somewhere else, perhaps on a developer who's willing to give you your money's worth on release.

number of helpful: 26 of 47 people (55%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												I don't want to write a giant wall of text, so i will keep it short (or atleast try to) and summarize the pros and cons of this game. Please keep in mind that these are based on my own experience with this game. Some people have little to no issues with this game. That is why the reviews are not all negative nor are they all positive. Anyhow, back to the pros and cons:Pros:- it has the potential to be a great game, if playable (some recurring new mechanics that i did enjoy: timed missions,    blacksites and class mechanics (all classes are good and none of the builds are inherently weaker than the other builds.    It really depends on the mission, to determine which build is more efficient. Also, don't be afraid to experiment with     your builds. You have the option to retrain your soldiers at some point in the game.) - most issues people have with this game are fixable- a great and friendly community (a lot of people, who have small performance issues, can find help in the steamforums    of XCom 2)Cons:- crashes and freezes that leads to crashes (black, grey, red, blue screens, i have experienced them all atleast once in the    last 4 days) - poor optimization (low to mediocre fps even on high end rigs)- a lot of bugs and/or glitches ranging from aliens detecting/shooting you through walls to allies sinking in the floor- poor technical support on the side of the developers (a friend of mine was advised to use the same strategy as with     XCom EU/EW. That is to play untill you crash/freeze with XCom EU/EW, then start up XCom 2 and play untill you reset    your pc. Repeat this process, if you want to play XCom 2 without black screen (or whatever colour you're    experiencing))- no patch announcements, so you can forget about short term improvements and/or resolutions.Conclusion (Well, i did promise to keep it short, so here are my final thoughts regarding XCom 2):I loved XCom EU/EW and XCom LW, but sadly i am unable to enjoy and play XCom 2 due to technical difficulties. So even if i wanted to, i just can't recommend this game to anyone, untill the game is properly patched. Which is a shame, because the game has a lot of potential. I just have to wait a few weeks (or more likely months) for the game to be patched, so i can enjoy the game thoroughly and on my own terms, instead of making compromises due to poor optimization and or technical issues. I sincerely hope, that i have dissuaded atleast some of you from buying this game in its current state, because i really want you gents and/or ladies out there, to have a great and memorable (first) experience with this fantastic franchise.Cheers!SnuPi

content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
												TL,DR Version: If you are looking for a challenge and got the system to run it, this game is for you.Long Version:Good game overall, suffers from some technical issues here and there. Seems to be fixed as of now.However it is HUGE in terms of datavolume (~25GB) so you better plan some extra time for the download.The graphics are fancy yet require quite the system to run with decent fps-rates. The storyline is interesting aswell as the tides have turned and you are kind of in the role the Aliens had before. The new classes are interesting too but sadly the melee aspect which firaxis tried to implement seems kind of weak and therefore (in most but not all cases) useless. A lot of missions have a time restraint early (I got the feeling this changed later on) and so does the genereal mission. So this is unlike XCOM: Enemy Unknown. I know a lot of people bragged about that, but I don't think it's that big of an issue. The limits in missions can hurt but also force you to take smarter and more effective decisions. While challenging, I think this would have worked better as a feature for the IronManmode. The general limit makes you feel an urge to go on and maybe also a bit of unrest or even panic which I like a lot. On the other hand this limit can be kept in check by regulary doing special missions which wasn't so hard in the end. It also feels like the difficulty went up a notch which is not a bad thing. I enjoyed it a lot but somehow liked Enemy Unknown/Within a little bit better.

												Awesome sequel to XCOM:EU/EW. You are now on the losing end of the stick and need to fight your way back to winning the earth back.New aliens, new fighting force (Advent) and lots, lots and lots of customization options.The modding is an awesome new thing too. 												If you were able to run XCOM with no problems on your desktop or laptop don't think for a second you can run XCOM 2 at the same capacity. I'm not sure why it's standard practice in "next-gen" games for every leaf on every tree be given is own physics engine to sway with absolute percision in the gentle breeze. And no, there's no turning that effect off. Where in previous games dumbing down the graphics settings makes it playable XCOM 2 might as well have two options: "You can't run it" and "You definitly can't run it." I love XCOM and the gameplay of XCOM 2 is solid. I just wish gaming companies would quite trying to shake the gold coins out of my pockets by demanding I buy a new desktop setup every year to look at their "next-gen" graphics. Great game, hindered by the alleged demand for 1080p turn based strategy games. Once a mod comes out that eliminates the RAM devouring effects of gentle wind and weather I'd be happy to revise this opinion.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												XCOM 2 is a game that tries too hard to be XCOM: Enemy unknown, by slightly changing the names of the classes and by introducing a timer and new aliens.XCOM2 Hasn’t learned the difference between “hard” and “punishing”. In XCOM: Enemy unknown both sides try to get the upper hand, the aliens through number and brute strength while the player can achieve the goals through destruction of terrain and positioning to flank, while in XCOM 2 if you don’t kill everything that you see in the turn that your unfortunate eyes sees them, which you won’t with the few hundred of them, which is understandable with the story, but with massive amount of health and damage that your B-B guns will merely tickle the Muton that will evaporate on your cavalry impersonator by looking at it funny. In addition, even XCOM: UFO defence which is known for being difficult is just difficult, not punishing. The aliens have a larger range and are usually hidden, so you have to be careful as you move, unlike in XCOM 2 where the Cortex will disable all of your weapons, teleport behind you and kill the only useful team member you have all in the same turn which will cause the animalistic “super soldiers” to go into a panic, run out of cover and then get immediately shot by whatever waits for them.XCOM: Enemy Unknown glitches are fun. You grapple onto a ledge and you get teleported under where you started, or by doing a Chryssalid dance with the dumb AI, while in XCOM 2: If you log out of the game while something is building, which you probably will as doing more than one mission at a time is about as desirable as grinding teeth against a cats ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, the building suddenly doesn’t exist, all the days that you waited for it have gone to waste, and the materials you invested into it are now gone. I mean, it’s not like you really need those Psi operatives to make the game playable.We’ve come this far without talking about the timer. XCOM 2 has introduced a timer for practically every mission, which isn’t fun, it’s just artificial difficulty that will make you panic. If you don’t do the mission in the time limit, the world becomes that much worse, everyone blames you while you were standing on a roof trying to not get absolutely everyone killed with the mass amount of aliens the game throws at you. Take Jet Set Radio into account: Would be an amazing game but gave everything a time limit, but there it made sense as it’s supposed to be a fast paced hip hop game.If you wanted to buy XCOM 2, my advice is: Don’t. I’m going to play some more XCOM: Enemy unknown.

content:
Posted: April 16
												I don't play many games through to the end these days. Time is short with a little kid running around. So it says a lot when I played X-Com 2 all the way through the final mission. What a fun game. I played the original X-Com as well as the first sequel a few years ago. This game captures the spirit of those, while adding some new twists and turns for seasoned fans. The story is engaging, and the sense of impending doom is there. Not a single game crash, or major bug experienced.You see, the game will end one way or another if you play it long enough. Either you take out the aliens and win, or they complete their world project and you lose. I played it on an easier difficulty level, and the game still managed to send plenty of my soldiers to the hospital bed for recovery. The final mission was nearly overwhelming. Everything in between had moments of challenge without getting stale. I'm contemplating playing through again on a harder difficulty level, because I didn't get a chance to really dive into psionics.My one complaint is that the game doesn't allow you to save, then load to get a different outcome (at least, not without going through some annoying hoops). I'm not sure why developers try and prevent players from doing this. If you are the type who doesn't want to go through those hoops, I suggest downloading the "Save Scum Roller" add-on. TacticalUI Counter is another good add-on, and the "Long War Perk Pack" is nice for some rebalancing. If you want an even easier play through, try out the "Flawless" add-on which rewards you for a flawless victory (still not easy to accomplish, but when you do, it gives you extra resources as a bonus).

												Only Reason I'm putting a negative is because I get tired of the snakes grabbing me THROUGH ♥♥♥♥ING WALLS... I know that's one hell of a tongue (impressive actually, it could have OTHER uses too :wink wink: ) but come on, going through walls? it gets annoying really fast, I mean the first 5 or 6 times all's well that ends well... but for the love of the holy avatar, it is ****** annoying and one hell of a bug. Aside from that there's some "lag" I'd say, sometimes windows break  even before a soldier charges in, or the snakes damage appears even before they grab and bound my soldier but that's fine I guess, maybe other ppl go through the same?Other than that, this game is amazing, love the mechanics (except the tongue thingie from before), enemies are great and tactics are well, actually that word, tactics, just like in the previous release you can't just go charging in guns blazing (or you could... heh that'd be fun I guess), you have a really nice variety of soldier classes and their skills are well thought, the system in which if they suffer an injury they can remain shocked is good, the cover system oh god that's amazing, love how everything goes from being the best cover to literally nothing, ashes.Story so far with the few hours I've put in is a blast, characters are even better than in 1 (except for shen, shen father was better than lily) and I'm expecting even more surprises.All in all I do recommend this game but that ONE BUG with the snakes is a negative, really negative point for me ruining completely some tactics on important points of the game.* Update after last patch *So I've been playing it a bit more, MODS are saving this game, they´re really, REALLY saving it, new katanas, new weapons, new enemies, new maps, buuuuut, the game retains its usual mechanics and that's a win.Although since I'm still facing same issues from before, I won't change my recommendation on this game, you need to polish the game (bad optimization maybe?) and the bugs a bit more Firaxis, you made such a great game and one of the best things it has is that even though it's a rush simulator it's fun, enjoyable and really well thought to let such bugs (and their workarounds - yes I'm looking at you cap rushing the return to the avenger without knowing that it can crash your game-) ruin it.* Update*Can't play this with mods and have to constantly verify cache? Way to go, I've over 30 mods at least in FO4 with no issues and you're telling me I can't have even 10 here? This game went from a not recommended to pure ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, if you're reading this you're better off getting this game from a torrent (yes, I'm saying to pirate this game to hell) ever since launch it had issues, it continues to have, it's not properly optimized and firaxis gives little to no attention to the game. In all fairness I've tried a couple of fixes... and got the debug screen in which I was able to select what I wanted to do or even if I wanted to go to the final product screen, come on people, that's utter crap, uninstalling because it's too late to get a refund.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												Its times like these that I wish Steam had a sideways thumb as this is not a bad game by any means, however it does suffer with a couple of issues.Let me start by saying that I believe Xcom 2 has the potential to be a great game, it has all that I would like in a Turn Based RPG and I’ve only just scratched the surface, however there are a few balance issues that need to be remedied that make certain things in the game impossible.I have played just under 10 hours on veteran mode on the opening weekend, and have had some really good moments, however there are certain issues which I know will eventually nullify my enthusiasm.1) CoverCover seems to be a bit pointless. More often than not I lose full health squad members who are either in full cover or in half cover (I understand half cover isn’t always guaranteed). On one occasion I was flanking around the side of a garage with two troops at full health. Soldier 1 was behind a road block and soldier 2 behind the garage wall, this gave me both Half-Cover and Full cover respectively. However this didn’t seem to matter because soldier 1 was hit at distance and died instantly loosing 5 health. Soldier 2 was shot through 2 solid non damaged walls and again was killed (How the enemy would have seen her I don’t know). That doesn’t leave a lot of room for setting up your team and formulating a tactical plan if the enemy can just shoot through cover as if it wasn’t there, this for me is a major issue. I feel that either the enemies are too overpowered or the cover isn’t working as it should do. Surely a concrete roadblock would assure a smidgen of protection.In another instance, I had a full health rookie behind a barrier; the enemy melee unit ran all the way up so he was positioned on the other side of the barrier (half-cover) and killed me with one thwack to the head.2) Timed GoalsI have no problem with the idea of a timed goal; however there are 2 issues I feel need to be addressed:a) Harsh countdown times - The timed goals given are on the whole too short, running and gunning doesn’t work as combined with the above issue of cover being like jelly, it makes getting to the goal impossible and in most cases I lose the majority of my team getting there, just to have to spend all of my supplies on new recruits and thus getting stuck in a vicious cycle. (and this was in the Early game).b) Random reinforcements are too penalising, as you just have barely enough time to get to the goal. But add in the fact that 75% of the time, reinforcements form behind your team, and just mop up with 1 shot kills.From what I’ve played of the game, there’s a lot that I’ve enjoyed, there's a lot of potential and I’m genuinely excited about it, but I personally feel there needs to be a re-think when it comes to the cover situation and the harsh countdown timers.There are also a few performance issues that I believe are being looked into, however, I’m not as badly affected as some.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
May contain minor SpoilersTL;DR: Not as good as expected. Maybe an Addon will bring more fresh wind but the Story is very thin and Missions get dull really fast. Would give 5/10 with Sideway-Thumb.The improvements over the first part are good:- Classes fit their role perfectly and different styles are encouraged (from very mobile agressive to very static lurking). Also the new character customization options are great. However there are some minor balancing problems (Melee of Ranger too weak for the amount of risk, most of the time you can just Run'n'Gun with Shotgun for more damage)- The rework of the worldmap need you to be more active and gives you the feeling of having more control over the given situation: You can decide to a certain factor, what you're doing and how you're doing it. (more about that later). Also different kinds of Ressources (Info, Ressource, Scientist and Ingenieurs) leave room for your approach to save the world.- New mechanics like Armor,Melee and weapon upgrades bring some fresh air to the battlefield. Especially armored opponents require more tactical work in fights and changes your Setup and Loadout a lot. - The new Enemies are fun to play against. Especially the Snake and ADVENT Melee need you to adapt to the situation fast- Starting in Concealment is an interesting way to let the players feel like hidden agressors and allows for better preparation of the whole sector. Works great! - The Basemanagment seems very well thought through. There's new buildings which fit perfectly to the game and the old buildings got a great rework. The building part feels less grindy and more impactful on your gameplan.What didn't went as good as expected for me:- The Story is dull. A modern version of "Nazi-Germany suppressing the population and experimenting with certain civilians." Haven't seen that in a while! After 2/3 of it I already had the urge to stop playing. Currently I'm in the middle of a Legendary Ironman run (Tier 2 weaponry and armor) and am not motivated anymore.- The freedom of the decisionmaking on the worldmap is mostly illusional. It's mostly contacting the sectors to the next ADVENT Base, clear Base, repeat. That's mostly it. Also you get interrupted by Advent a lot which gets annoying really fast. After the 4th or 5th time you sit there rolling your eyes and ask yourself "what's it this time?"- Repetitive missions already during the first playthrough. There's basically two types of Missions: First one is "Get to Point A (Hostage, Hack Terminal, Collect Information), then go to Point B (Extraction)". Even the special missions where you locate and collect storyobjects work that way. The second type are the missions known from XCOM 1: Rescue Civilians. Just more difficult since the aliens prioritize them more and there are less. Didn't find them interesting in the first part, here aswell. Also hidden enemies in those missions. Why?The last point is the dealbreaker for me. Even when every other part of the game got really really well refined, the lack of different missions in XCOM2 made it boring very fast for me.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 20, 2016
												This game plays like a bad joke, literally. You will have the feeling that somebody is telling you a bad joke or that you suddenly became part of a trashy movie. XCOM EU/EW were pretty cartoonish to some extend, but this game feels like it is the Goat Simulator of the XCOM series. And on top of that, all the hefty bugs make it even worse.It all begins in the tutorial that does not seem to end at any point of the game. You will be FORCED to make dumb moves and you will be forced to let two people die in order to learn how the game works. That is the first "haha" in your face and the prelude of the horrible joke that this game actually is. The second thing you will notice is that you will be told that you are "concealed" which will grant you a huge bonus: The element of surprise. That is not only a lie, it is a joke in itself. Because the next thing you will do is, you will plan out your ambush. Only to understand that when you fired the first bullet, all the enemies grant one free turn, again. The worst things of XCOM EU/EW have been made even worse. There is no element of surprise. Once one of your guys fires/is spotted/jumps through a window, all of your units are unconcealed. There is no combined ambush, no group surprise attack.Than you will learn the next important thing: Hit chances are also a joke. A parody. Lines of sights are completely broken, the cover system has no purpose and the hit chances should just be ignored. This is the only tactical game I know that punishes the player for smart actions and motivates him to just randomly ♥♥♥♥ around. Really, once you stopped caring for the hit chances, your hits will skyrocket. Ever since I just took every 41% hit chance, my overall hits went up to 75%. Flanking is broken aswell. There is one effective way to flank the enemy: Put a soldier right next to him. The rest is highly ineffective or sometimes does not work at all. There can be a clear line of sight from 2 metres away with no cover in your soldiers direction and the hit chance is 35% without any flanking bonus. Oh, that is another joke: Ignore the lines of sight. Yeah, your sniper cannot actually see the enemy, but squuuuadsight. Just take the shot and watch your sniper aim at the air, firing through 2 walls and blast this stupid enemy away. It is a joke. A parody  afterall. So just do random stuff.The maps are small. In EU/EW the maps were small, but you had time. In this game, you have timers all over the place. Active timers, passive timers, non-sensical timers. If you don't have a clear 8 turns timer, you will face a situation where the enemies are already killing civillians/shooting at some sort of goodie and so on. That is a timer as well. Even the loot items have timers. "It seems the aliens have programed their equipment to self-destruct". This, ... this is one of those lines that actually made my laugh. This is the moment you know, you are watching a crappy movie written by untalented, lazy writers. "How do we add more timers?" - "I dunno, man. Wait, how about we make the equipment go boom in 3 turns?" - "Awesome!". This is so cheap, it is hard to talk about it without making this game look like a total piece of crap. And the game is littered with stuff like that. The soldier that does not hit from 2 metres away will comment his failure with "Adjusting aim". Yeah. You just can't hit♥♥♥♥♥♥ Don't blame the gear. Your entire crew, whether it be the scientist, the tinker or the creepy guy that loves to call you "commander", will all lament on how you do not have time and you gotta rush, while you cannot do anything except listen to them, telling you in eeeendless paragraphs, that you don't have time. These contradictions make the game funny in a total unfunny way. You will be called "commander" all the time, but everybody will tell you what to do and the game will take away your control whenever it can. Sorry, I was talking about the small maps. Every map is a small rectangle. If you start in the lower right, there will be a troop of enemies in the lower left, the upper left and the upper right. That is it. End of transmission. To not trigger them all at once, so that 12 enemies get one free turn to get in perfect cover, you will always attack one troop full frontal. You have to. Time is running out and bla, bla. So, there is not much tactic in the game. You do what takes the enemy out of the game as quickly as possible.  So every map will be the same.Thin men suddenly became reptile aliens. I mean, just ... is it ... I cannot. That is dumb beyond any reason. The weakish thin men used their form to infiltrate humanity. In one of the cutscenes you see a thin man shaking hands with some sort of politician. A 3 metres high guy, looking like a giant. How can those people infiltrate humanity? And if they are viper things in reality, why did we not see any viper before? They are so awesome, they will pull your soldiers from behind full cover, through a wall and 2 cars across half of the map right into the enemy line. And than, you have another timer. The enemy AI is dumb as can be. It is not difficult to battle them mentally. It is difficult to mentally endure the artificial way this game was made difficult. If you fight a tank with a pea shooter, yeah, that will be hard. Impossible even. The XCOM AI is not smart, it will always take the same actions it did before. But is has better gear, does not care for your cover, has uber awesome skills, can take turns during your turns and when the glitches and bugs set it, they can even fly and melee attack your soldiers through walls and stuff. There are some enemies, that will have a turn every time you do anything. Literally anything. Or, when your soldier fails to hack the red light towers, the enemy does get insta-reinforcements. Right in the middle of your turn a spaceship will land and boom, here they are. All these facts combined turn the game into a huge, goofy parody of EU/EW. It will ask you to just rush and take dumb movements. Whenever you try to play smart, it will hit you in the face and go all "haha" on you. It will take away your control every ♥♥♥♥♥ing time it can. You will constantly switch between menues, because your scanning for this or that gets interrupted by "hey look at me".There is only one thing, this game is good for: If you like to create purple and pink pimps and strippers in pink fedoras with pink weapons, this is your game. Literally, that is the main strength of the game: The customization. It encourages you to go all joker on this game. And than you laugh yourself into stupidity while watching your pink grenadiers with sunglasses whip the enemy. Sadly, this is all there is. A big, fat, sad joke. A bad movie that plays a heroic soundtrack. A huge contradiction and sadly, if this has become XCOM now, I'd rather not see a third part of this series. I feel ashamed and insulted when I play this game. And that is why I could not force myself to finish it. I tried two times, I just can't endure all the crazy stuff I paid 50 bucks for. I would not recommend this game to anyone, at any time for any reason and price. A product, so flawed should be shunned.

												Short: In comparison worse than the first remake. Buggy, less fun due to strange physics and unnerving enemies.Long: Concerning Software, I really dislike that the mouseclicks tend to glitch a bit and my chars run to a different square. Meh. Worse is, I've had several times that the enemy's actionphase just.....pauses. It doesn't crash, it just hangs. So I had to reload the mission (not the savepoint, because it just repeats the prob at the exact same point).Smaller glitches like disappearing objects or wrong actionpoint are acceptible.Concerning content, (of course it's my taste) I really hate the 90% timebased missions (gaming-no gos: Pay to win, Waterlevels, Icelevels, Protectmissions, Timelimits!) as many others do. That there are unlogical lines of sight (my char can't shoot an enemy because there was a 1ft rest of a lantern pole) seems to be a USP of 3D Xcom   :PBut worst for me, and destroying my fun and the flow of the game, are the Special "Alien Hunter"-Lords. They can react every time I do anything?????? ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Maybe my fault for buying the DLC, but it made me stop playing the game a lot of times. Not comparable to Dark Souls Ragequits.Only the worldmap-stuff is more fun than in Enemy Within. Which is more likely to be replayed for me.

Posted: February 21, 2016
												I really love this game. It is well designed, beautiful, atmospheric, and did everything better than its predecesors.However, I simply cannot recommend XCom 2 at its current state. It is simply too buggy.The bugs ranges from minor issues like graphical glitches, performance drops, animation not properly displayed, to unfortunatly what I would call game breaking:I play on Ironman mode and I have lost two of my best soldiers to bugs. One of them got stuck to a wall and I cannot evac her at the end of the mission. Another was bleeding out but somehow I couldn't pick him up even the evac zone is one move away...[spoiler free, don't worry]Now the worst is the final mission...  there is a known bug that makes me afraid to even attempt it. As the game is designed you are allowed to restart the final mission should you fail, even in Ironman mode. However, people who restart their mission reported that all their passive abilities, ammo, and armor are gone. Given the difficulty spike of the final mission I don't even want to try it before they get this bug fixed.I'll update the review when Firaxis get the game fixed properly and it would be an amazing game. Until then, I don't recommend it.

												Let me cut right to the chase. XCom 2 is a great sequel and I would definitely recommend it to anyone who likes the prequels or turn based games. I actually don't want to get into detail about the gameplay but rather the things that need to be fixed as fast as possible.This game really fixes some of the issues with the prequel and reinforce the strong points that made it so great. Thus far I enjoyed the game exceptthe horrible technical problems, bugs and countless issues that really destroy the enjoyability of this game. This game has so many performance issues and the framerate is all over place even with a powerful rig. It's absolutely random and really decimating the enjoyment. Furthermore there are bugs, clipping errors and absolutely broken things. It also could add some more balancing here and there. Gameplaywise I would appreciate the timed missions to be more lax in order to give the player some freedom instead of the constant rushing.I see a great game that needs some serious patching before really being enjoyed. I hope they Firaxis will deliver so that I can turn this review into a positive one.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												WELCOME BACK COMMANDER !When the game manages to get on your nerves with its difficulty, but you still come back to it and spend every minute of your time thinking about how to improve your strategies, that's when you know it is a real gem and you are hooked up. And that is, exactly, the case with XCOM 2.This is one of my most favorites games. It is a tactical turn based strategy game. The critics are right: it can be unforging of mistakes. It is difficult. It takes a lot of patience. But if you spend time with the game it is absolutely addicting. You are always at a disadvantage. You are always juggling priorities. You are always worried to advance too fast or advance too slow. But that what makes the game so fun. This is not a game that requires any dexterity. It is a game that requires a lot of thinking and creativity. Not everyone's cup of tea but it is certainly mine.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
 There's a lot wrong with this game; to much to make it a valid 60 dollar purhase at this point. 	  Gameplay  The Random Number Generating system (RNG) is absolutely broken and completely rediculous. From what i understand, the RNG is a single element that applies to all XCOM units and ADVANT forces regardless of the circumstances.    For example: lets say you have a Ranger unit within 3 spaces of a target thats out of cover, and you have a 95% chance to hit; this Ranger then misses for some stupid reason. you can load from the auto save and try again, but now anyone is garanteed to miss the first exchange regardless of who attacks first and regardless of "hit percentages".  This type of situation can result in some pretty ridiculous kills. My best kill was a critical hit with a shotgun at it's maximum hitting distance, through a full cover wall; and that was an 11% chance to hit and 2% to critical it (AND THAT WAS REPEATABLE FROM THE AUTO SAVE!). Seriously, if that doesn't show how bad the RNG is in this game, I don't know what will.  Every XCOM class is unbalanced, overpowered, or completely useless. The XCOM classes have a handful of useful classes: snipers, medics, demolition, heavy gunner, and psi op; every other class is completely worthless unblended (putting all your class points in one skill tree) and will get your team killed.       The Combat Technician (combat hacker) gets the ability to hack mech units, shock enemies with a drone (minimal damage at best) and do local scans to find enemies within proximity of the user; Medics can heal, revive, and resurrect from a distance (that in itself is extremely overpowered, no need to keep the medic close by), and can get the ability to do all that to everyone on your team, all at one time, once per mission.      The Gunslinger (Pistol Popper) can use their pistol (not main weapon) to shoot multiple enemies, shoot multiple shoot at one target, and take a pistol shot before using their main weapon (really the only good ability they have). Snipers can shoot at multiple enemies with a more powerful weapon, set up killzones (overwatch on crack), obliterate armor or near instakill (deadeye), and shoot from anywhere as long as someone has eyes on the target.     The Blademasters and phantom skills need to be blended in order for rangers to be any good (if you didn't do this, good luck).  Alien units are Unbalanced and OP. There are a lot of Aliens you will hate to fight in XCOM 2; mainly: Sectoids, Gatekeepers, Shieldbearers, Vipers, and Codex.       Sectoids have a huge variety of psi abilities and sometimes use more than one in a turn.     Gatekeepers are tank-like psi enemies with huge AoE attacks and laser eyes.     Shieldbearers can turn any aliens around them into tanks or better tanks.     Vipers can spit venom like thinmen, and grab units with a long tongue like Smokers from L4D (btw, their snakes, not frogs, wtf, they shouldn't have a tongue ability).     codex can copy themselves, teleport, and AoE disarm units. The timers are stupid and make no sense in certain missions. Why do I have a timer for a rescue mission or an assassination mission? Why is there a timer for stealing enemy intel from a box or computer?   Release Quality   The game was released in an unoptimized state. It's glitchy, slow, and can crash pretty hard from time to time. I had to start three missions over because my autosaves were corrupted, and restart the game at the final mission to fix some texture issues.   Conclusion This game needs some serious overhauls and patches; the game is down right frustrating with the current RNG and game mechanics, and is a chore to get though. Wait till this game gets an update, patches, overhaul mods / DLC, and a drop in price to no more than $30.It's not a bad game, it's an ungraceful game that needs some serious reworking.

number of helpful: 41 of 77 people (53%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												All in all, a fun continuation of the Xcom series. If you enjoyed the first game, you will probably enjoy this. That said, if you are looking for big improvements on the first game, you may be disapointed. Much of the variety from the original (including the expansion) is not in the game. There is a really streamlined version of troop enhancements and MEC style troops, but it is not near as diverse or satisfying as the previous expansion allowed. Everything else is repeated pretty much right from the base game in a lot of ways except ship combat was completely removed. Considering that, it is disapointing Xcom 2 didn't do a bit more, but Firaxis as a developer is pretty well known for phoning in sequels these days. I don't mind that they didn't even attempt to improve on the interceptor game, but if it is going to be removed, players should see new content added. One could argue that the mobile base is that new content, but really it is the exact same base design mechanic as before with a different UI for interacting with the global map. That is about all it does.Also, the economy is actually pretty bad. Everything special in the game costs elerium cores, which is random drop only from enemies. In effect, you end up with tons of alloy and elerium, but nothing to do with it if you didn't save those elerium cores. It is nice that core upgrades, like switching to laser weapons (well, I think its called magnetic, but whatever) just upgrades all your guns and don't require individual construction.Difficulty wise, at least on normal/veteran, it felt a bit easier due to increased access to AoE, high damage ordinance. It really isn't that hard to get everyone sporting a rocket launcher in a reasonable amount of time and that is one of the weakest options available. A few other balance bits felt off as well, though the special weapons are satisfying to use.It could have been more, but it is what it is. If you want a fresh Xcom fix, go for it. If you can wait, then I would highly recommend waiting for a sale. As it stands, it is hard to justify this game as being worth full price.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
												I'll happily change to an affirmative recommendation, just as soon as the devs finish their work and fix the game so it works properly.  My system meets the minimum requirements, and yet whenever I play the tutorial mission (in order to start the game with Jane Kelly and a fully customized squad) it crashes during the Avenger arrival cinematic.  Every time.  If a person who wants to play the tutorial can't get past it into the game-proper, then your game isn't working.  Then there was the fact that smoke grenades didn't do anything, until a modder finished the devs' job.  Or how the "permanent control of turrets" described in the haywire protocol ability had to be corrected by a modder.  Or how your soldiers don't always fire on the correct enemy unit that you very specifically selected.  Or any of the multitude of other flaws reported by others.When the game works, I enjoy it, I'll grant that.  Well, except for the perception that the RNG *massively cheats* in the aliens' favour.  But the problem is, the game DOES NOT consistently work, and in some ways, consistently doesn't work.  And that experience isn't what I paid for when I bought this.Oh, and post-patch, the game crashes every time I try to load my save game.  Or start a new game.  So, basically my game is ****ing crippled by the "fix" for all the bugginess.  GOOD ****IN' WORK, guys!

content:

												Don't get the review wrong. The game is not bad actually. From the visual, stability and game design point of view overall it deserves the name XCom. It's in a decent stable state already at release day, which one can't say from the majority of games. Yes, it has crashes, yes there are bugs, but it's certainly playable (and thanks to auto saves, even if it crashes you just restart the game and continue from where it crashed).Still, I have to rate the game with not recommended.... And all of that due to two of the major game design decisions which for me personally don't make this a recommended XCom game:1. round limits in the majority of the missions2. the overall time pressure of completing the whole gameI always liked the game design of the old XCom games as well as the different forks which evolved over the time for allowing me to play in the speed and manner I want to (be it rushing through missions or just being quite sneaky and careful). Unfortunately at its current state, XCOM 2 does not allow that.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												If I'm expected to produce 100% of the money for a game on the spot, with no negotiation, wiggling, haggling, or reduction under any circumstances whatsoever, than you, game company, are expected to give me 100% of the dang game. Now.Well, not necessarily 100. No launch will be totally perfect. But I definitely wish I'd heard about the absurd performance issues from, you know. Games media, reviews, people with pre-release copies. Unlike with other games, I figured a pre-order was a safe bet here, having watched like half a day of Beaglerush streaming it and thus knowing the gameplay will be awesome. But uh, performance.Every review, negative and positive, on the entire store-front mentions this issue. And since the game was pre-ordered, I'm pretty sure the refund window for people bitten on this has already expired. Funny how that works, huh? Honestly, I'm just a tiny bit relieved it really is a global issue with everyone on every platform, and not just my computer being too far behind the times yet.This review isn't about whether I love the new XCOM under Firaxis, because I do. This is 'should you buy this'. And if you weren't already big enough into it to put down the cash, then please don't buy this yet. Wait for them to fix it, if they decide to.EDIT: I actually waited until the morning after going to sleep post-launch to make this review, just in case there was some emergency uber-patch. As, uh, far as I can tell, nnnope.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												TL;DR: Good, but buggy, not recommended for now - as good as the core game is, the bugs make it too frustratingMechanically, the game is fine - plays like the first one for the most part, with a few changes I would consider improvements, such as the "Concealment" system which - at least to some extent - makes overwatch crawling unnecesary for the first part of most missions. I, for one, like the "dumbed down" base building, seeing as in the first one, it didn't feel deep, it just felt needlessly complicated, but of course that's a matter of opinion.However, I've run into a lot of really annoying problems, mostly with the UI - not only does it seem poorly designed in a lot of cases, it also flat out breaks a lot. This includes stuff like not being able to click on buttons or icons for skills and mismatched tooltips.But I could deal with that stuff - it's just annoying, not really game ending.I will not recommend though, not until the number of bugs I (and apparently quite a few others) have run into. In my last session, all of a sudden, research and buildings stopped popping up when done. I didn't think much of it - the UI does a terrible job of conveying information at other times, so I figured I'd just misunderstood, and they simply weren't complete after all. But then I went to look, and construction timers and wound timers had gone into negative values - I had a facilty with a due time of "-195 hours", and soldiers with "-4 days" recovery, and I couldn't do anything with it, until all of a sudden I got spammed with alerts of completed stuff all over the place.In a game with fairly strict time and resource management, that's just not okay.Other than that, I frequently get "blackouts" during missions, where the screen turns grey with a red outline and only the HUD visible. The game still runs, and it will recover after a short while, but I just can't see what the enemy is doing, even though they're in my vision range.Then there's the framerate tanking, which I've seen quite a few people report here and there - it's simply atrocious. I'm running on a high end rig, I should not be seeing 15-20 frames.And whose brilliant idea was it to keep excessive screen shake in the game. One mission had a very strong shake throughout several of my turns. I kept my cursor completely still, but the shake of the screen meant that I was switching between 4 seperate tiles at random, making it really difficult to throw a grenade properly to hit 3 enemies.A lot of people are reporting crashes and shader errors, and the inability to quit the game without it crashing and mocking about - I get around this issue through the magic of Alt + F4.I want to keep playing, because the game is good. But the bugs are making it really annoying, and I will therefore in stead recommend picking it up at a later date.Edit: As a lot of people have pointed out, the game involves a lot of "timed" missions - many more than the first one. I'd be okay with that, if it didn't feel like there were just slightly too few turns to do stuff - if you step out in the wrong direction, you'll likely simply not have enough turns to get to the objective.I've rushed through missions, putting my soldiers in really dangerous positions and taking out targets as quickly as I could, but a lot of the time, they get reinforcements at the last second. So even when I rush, I usually get to the objective with 1 or 2 turns left, which is just barely enough for me to also "activate" the objective.The very highest I've had left (and I save-scummed on that one) was 4. The margin for error relative to the price of failure just seems off on many of the timed missions. But hey, maybe you're into that, in which case: Go nuts, you'll love it.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												It is mindboggling to me that I can run Witcher 3 on med-high settings on my 2-year old laptop but XCOM 2 crashes on a coinflip doing physics calculations when I blaster bomb a building apart. I love this game wholeheartedly and I want to play all day but the random crashing just became too much to handle. Please note I am not holding up Witcher 3 as a paragon of stability, just a very good looking cpu intensive game.This is a heartfelt and emotional plea to all game devs about QA testing: If you're not making Crysis and very upfront about making Crysis, please QA test outside of the sterile office environment. Go on a 8mb wireless DSL connection with a bunch of mid-end computers using different chipset manufacturers. There's not a lot of point to testing stability in the office on a $2,000 machine using fiberoptic internet. I just want XCOM 2 in my life but I can't in good conscience recommend XCOM 2. Thumbs down for me.for the tl;dr crowd, FIX YOUR GAME, JAKE!Edit: I left my laptop on idle for quite some time during campaigns. I've played about 30-35 hrs of XCOM 2

content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
												I am currently subscribed to 94 modsthink about that94 mods to make a game that should be good on release be fun to play, and even then, I have only managed to finish two campaignswhich is weird because this game is all about rushing short campaigns, it's all about time and turn limits on everything, but doing the same thing every time, with the same squad (thanks to the character pool) in the same 3 types of areas kinda gets old after a whileit takes mods to add diversity, which is the main thing I want in gamesyou know, when they release a sequel to a game, you expect it to have more, better content, right? this game should be Long War 2.0, instead it's Enemy Unknown 0.9and even so, probably due to the 94 mods, the game runs really bad and choppy, and I just bought a freaking 1080, dudethey released mod tools on release day, they expected people to make their okay-ish game good, and that's just bad and lazy company tactics dudethen there's the fact that XCOM 2 isn't about tactics, it's about luck, it's about setting up a play, and setting up a back-up in case that play failsremember the good old games like Silent Storm where everything was destructable in a good way, and every bullet, movement cost it's own AP out of 100-150 ish AP as your characters level up? when you had to use AP to go into your inventory and put an item in the usable slots? remember when there were more than 6 levels + a useless rookie level? when you got a whole skill tree to pick from, or stats to upgrade instead of just picked the good skill (if there is one) instead of the bad skill?well this thing throws all the stuff I love about tactics games out of the window, and simplifies everything... this is not a  real tactics gameso yeah, buy it on sale, get the top subscribed mods from the workshop, enjoy for a playthrough, a few months break, another playthrough, a few months break, half a playthrough, etc...the worst thing being unable to skip all the story scenes and dialogue, I don't care about seeing a scenic shot of the alien facility for the 15th time, just let me kill stuff alreadyon the plus side, snipers are no longer OP, they are fairly useless now, so it's nice not being able to just steamroll everything once you get squadsight

												Whilst the core game is extremely good, I'm not a massive fan of the direction they've taken the game in. Perhaps an unpopular opinion as clearly there is a huge segment of the player base who love the "Long War" mod and studio, I personally do not. Go on a 8mb wireless DSL connection with a bunch of mid-end computers using different chipset manufacturers. There's not a lot of point to testing stability in the office on a $2,000 machine using fiberoptic internet. I just want XCOM 2 in my life but I can't in good conscience recommend XCOM 2. Thumbs down for me.for the tl;dr crowd, FIX YOUR GAME, JAKE!Edit: I left my laptop on idle for quite some time during campaigns. I've played about 30-35 hrs of XCOM 2

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												I'm not going to get into details about the pros and cons, as other reviews have already done that to death. Instead I'll just throw in some "buyer beware" points if you're considering buying XCOM 2.So, it's definitely a lot better than the original, it has fixed a lot of the issues I had with Enemy Unknown. Things like the BS "choose one out of three possible areas to defend, and the other two will get a Panic Penalty and there's nothing you can do about it because reasons". But, it still has a lot of the same really frustrating issues. Things like the difficulty setting not really making enemies smarter or more numerous, but instead just tweaks the likelihood of you hitting enemies (down to ridiculously low chances) and the likelihood of your troopers getting hit (up to astronomically unfair chances). Enemies can still see and shoot through multiple walls to get ridiculous hits on you where they should not, and there are also a ton of other bugs and frustrating elements.There's also the newly added frustrating feature of countdowns in almost every mission. You need to get to point X before some random timer ticks down, or else you fail for no apparent reason at all. And the amount of turns you have to get to that point is often so low, that you're forced to throw any tactical thinking out the window, and just run for the objective before the time runs out - and hope to anything holy that you hit on every shot and the enemy suddenly somehow fall into a streak of bad luck.The game is also rather poorly optimized at the time of this writing. It runs fine if you turn off Anti-Aliasing, but once you try to tweak that up even a little (f@$k jaggies), then your framerate will tank even when you're just browsing your home base. A patch will hopefully fix this in time, but it is worth noting now. If you're allergic to aliasing/jaggies, then you'll get cancer from this game in its current stateUltimately, the game is enjoyable if you intend to play it on low difficulty just for the sake of the story and the progression of your troops (and the new character customization system is pretty robust if you look away from facial customization). If you liked the original and were completely blind (or for whatever reason chose to forgive) the glaring issues it had, you'll find a lot to love here. If you want tactical freedom in a supposedly "tactical" game, or if you absolutely hated XCOM: EU, then this will not be your cup of tea.So do I recommend it? I personally liked it just enough for it to barely tip over to a Thumbs Up rating. It's dumb fun, and with the already implemented mod support through Steam Workshop, modders can do a lot of the job that Firaxis were too lazy to do anything about (like the stupid camera rotation - come on, Firaxis). Just don't expect it to be a tactical masterpiece or a worthy successor to the old X-Com from '94. If a modern X-Com: UFO Defense is what you're looking for, I recommend looking at Xenonauts instead. Though don't expect smooth animations or amazing graphics.

												This was... disappointing.Whomever decided this was the way to go has (obiviously) never studied asymmetrical warfare.<rant>In AW you pick targets carefully, and let them go if they get away.  The timers are, in a majority of cases, stupid.These are guerrila resistance fighters: mobility and lack of a foot print are key points to their survival.  You don't have homebases on the surface.  You don't have established colonies.  You're nomadic.  Anything stationary is trapped to offset the cost of discovery with enemy casualties.  Just damn Firaxis, get it right, you're supposed to.</rant>On the more specific end of the spectrum, the arbitrary timelimit is stupid.  X-COM is a AW IP, where planning and limited gambling make sweet victory babies.  As it stands now, it's garbage.New map is cool, even if I don't know what half of it means/does.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												To be honest, it's not a bad game.  It's just not worth $60 and has issues that pervade the entire experience.-Feels rushed.  Still has the same issues as the previous incarnation and has balance and technical issues (slow downs).-Has moved further away from X-COM and more into the XCOM rendition.  It seems to have forgotten what made the old games great and is more of a linear story than the simulation that they used to be.-Everything feels "gamey" and artificial.  Over-simplified mechanics and lack of depth might work for a boardgame, but the PC should be a platform for greater complexity.  As it is, it is a pathetic shadow of games that came out over 20 years ago.-Lacks variety.  Tactics devolve into a set of stock manuevers that you will use ad-nauseum with little need to change.-The Geoscape is more reactive than proactive and you still have the "you can only choose ONE mission and have to fail the others" bullcrap.  Again, it feels arbitrary and dumb.  Why can't I have 2 skyrangers?  Why can't I have multiple squads en-route?-They've also removed interception as a mechanic, opting to have a mobile base.  Base building has also become more stream-lined, with no real choices for the player to make.  You NEED too many facilities and you're stuck in another "satellite" buying scenario in which you're wasting time, money, and space to build the pay-wall style crap so you can move on.I could go on, but the bottom line is:  buy Xenonauts, X-Com: Ufo Defense/Terror From the Deep, or even UFO: Aftershock if you're looking for a GOOD alien killing sim.  This is the dumbed-down beer and pretzels crap that they shovel out these days.

number of helpful: 25 of 46 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16
												After being a fan of the original trilogy, let me rephrase that as a huge fan of the originals - the reboots have angered me greatly as they have not done any justice in my personal opinion, if anything - have been a travesty to the Xcom franchise and Xcom 2 is arguably the worst because not only do you have the same cheating AI with miraculous almost impossible shots to spawning extra alien squads at the worst possible times making some missions all but impossible...and then, to add further insult...A large chunk of missions are timed with very tight limits making a front frontal assault the only viable option to meet the limit and that method almost always puts your prized troops at risk.    One of the main things what made the originals great was the fact that each mission the aliens was placed in random positions, and none of it was carefully scripted like the reboots - those scripts are one of the problems because first time around, you're going to fail and lose...multiple times doing it you've figured it out and even the harder difficulty settings are not that hard.Right from the start, you're against nearly impossible odds-   Even sectoids have been given massive psionic buffs and can mindcontrol your troops fairly easily right from the very first missions making mindshields all but a nessessity and this trend continues,  each fight you're spending more resources than your making back so its a constant struggle and after a while it starts to get frustrating. I try hard to like the reboots, but at the moment - they are lacking something that made the originals great.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2016
												So I've waited for the DLC to come out to see if Firaxis would release an update to fix this game. After realizing that almost nothing is fixed, I've just about had it with waiting for this game to be good. Instead of having a list of every single problem with the game, (for example, how health is displayed, the imbalanced difficulty, how detection tiles are incosistant, enemies are just given buffs later in the game instead of new enemies being designed, etc.)  I'll just list and explain the 4 fatal flaws with this game:1. PERFORMANCE: If you look at other revieews, other people are having a hard time getting this game to run well. For me its not too bad now, as I noticed that general stability is improved to a good range of 20-40 frames. But that's far from optimal. It's also far from the only thing wrong with the game.2. CHEATING AI/BAD AI: You can test this out on the first mission with the statue if there is one enemy left and you have a soldier (with no other soldiers nearby to possibly flank the enemy) near a statue. If both of you are in the high cover of the statue, and you move out of sight into the low cover base of the statue, the ai will abandon high cover and go into the low cover base to flank you, even though he couldn't see where you moved before. This makes fighting the AI holy unsatisfying. In addition, the AI in general is easy to predict (when it's not glitching out). Psionic enemies in particular always use their special abilties first before shooting, even if they go out of their way to flank you. Enemy soldiers have no sense of preservation, so overwatching in front of them will never keep them in place.3. BAD PACING: The biggest problem to the actual gameplay (in both combat and base management) is that the game always forces you in a rush. Got to capture a VIP? Hurry up and get him in 12 turns even though the enemy doesn't even know that you're there yet. Capture this cargo in 8 turns otherwise it blows up for no reason. Did you actually win a combat mission? Tough♥♥♥♥♥♥ the doomtracker's clicking down. It's always rush, rush, rush. There's never a time that the game (and by extension the player) can have a breather to calm down and get his bearings. In the prior game, base management was the way the game calmed down. You didn't have to worry about moving your base constantly that takes 4+ hours to land and take off in each area.4. LINE OF SIGHT BUGS: The thing that kills this game is the constant line of sight bugs. Literally anytime urban warfare is involved, you can expect to have shootouts through solid walls and ceilings with no visibility. Sometimes cover just doesn't work and you'll get flanked by an enemy who is clearly right infront of your cover. You might move a soldier behind a wall so an enemy won't have a shot on him, only to realize that the enemy can still see him and he will get shot like he wasn't in cover at all. The worst that has happened to me is when I was rescuing a VIP from a truck, and when I came into visual range, the walls of the truck didn't work so I saw the VIP. When the VIP was revealed, the enemies saw the VIP, and since the VIP isn't in concealment, then everyone of my soldiers lost concealment, no less after i made all of my moves. The game is frustratingly unfinished.There are positive additions to the game, which is what kept me for playing this long. But the more I played it in general, the more I was frustrated at its bad design and terrible stability. This game is unsalvageable.

Very little character customization and very little difference from the previous xcom, which I would rate as far superior in feel and performance to this game (even though I can only base my experience on a couple of missions and a modded version that skips the game breaking tutorial crash bug).  I'd wait a good long time to buy this and keep an eye on the discussion boards for if/when firaxis patches this game and makes it playable.  Modders may be able to fix this down the road as well but it is not worth the money right now.

												In its current state the game is unplayable for me. Yes yes, I KNOW there are 'fixes' for it. Trust me when I say that I have tried them all. Nothing works. Although I do get a FPS booast from some of the tweeks, but that's just turning off most of the graphical effects. Currently, the game locks up when a mission loads. That moment when your team is about to jump out of the ship onto the ground. Just locks up. The back ground music plays but nothing happens. Tried everything. I am sure that they will fix it at some point, but I've given up. It's been a full month since the game released.It's not like I am playing it on a potato. I have a AMD 9590, 16GB of DDR3, 290x, and running off a SSD. Sure it could be better, but it's hardly anything to scoff at. My point is, the game should not have been released like this. 												Honestly, this is the first Xcom game I've ever played and I must say im dissapointed. First of all, the bs %TO HIT system is dumb. Because in real life or just a normal shooter, there is alot more factors involved other than a random item you found on the ground's bonus stats which can be attached. Your character can literally miss a guy standing RIGHT IN FRONT OF HIM SOMEHOW. Theres also ALOT of waiting in this game. For some reason, the develepors of the game decided that you have to watch as they walk into their death duo to dumb % hit system. The camera's locked on the character that you told to move ALL the way, and they are slow as hell. Honestly, if I did not have to watch ALL my characters move to position SEPERATLY I would not have 11 hours on this game, it feels like you're spending hours on watching them move. DO NOT buy this game or anything like it. Hell it was just scratching the surface of fun starting my first campaign, but this game got boring so fast for me.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												Well..... I'm just not even sure what to say.  I loved XCOM Enemy Unknow, but this is rediculous.An enemy in the open and flanked with a 90% chance to hit? MISS!My squad in cover being fired at from across the map? CRITICAL HIT!It got to the point where it was laugh out loud aweful. I should have waited for it to go on sale, but I was so excited to play it that I just went ahead and bought it. Horrible decision.Graphics: not really better.  To me they feel like something I would expect in an indy game. Glitchy and it didn't look, to me, like an improvement on EU.Game Play: Not bad. The move counter gets annoying when you have to rush across the map to do something, but it wasn't so bad that I disliked it. It's turn based squad combat and I like that. I did like the new stealth aspect, but it kind of seems useless when the enemy gets to make a bunch of additional moves(see below).AI: I really feel like the Advent soldier's either had an unfare advantage, or my squad was just the unlukiest group of soldiers ever.  First off, when you trigger the enemie's awareness of you, they get a free move for some reason.  So the ambush you spent many turns setting up gets ruined. Second, their aim is impeccable from any position. And finally, they come at you in such large groups, even in the beginning of the game, that the fact that it takes 4-5 of your squads shooting at 1 enemy to kill them makes it infuriating.I think I'm done with the game for now.  I will take a look at it in a month or 2 after some updates have come out to see if it has gotten better.  3/10 would definitely not pay $60 for it again.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2016
												See I had high hopes for XCOM2. The first game of this re-imagining was fun, hard but challenging. Managing weapons, fighting aliens, hard bosses but plenty of ways to get around all the challenges. XCOM2 though...well were to start. No difficulty curve. It starts hard and does not ease you in. Hell the tutorial completely cripples you if you try to play the game with it. Now I know what you're saying. "Oh but this is xcom toughen up." NO ♥♥♥♥ you. Orginal excom hard was managing money and council nervousness and soldier skills not, throw what used to be an end boss mechanic in your second level. The lead dev even addmitted this. They made it harder at basically the last week before launch. (Because as we all know nothing says a well thought out game then a lass minute decision that completely underminds the entire programming of it.)Another thing their head developer admitted was that all of their testers hated the timer mechanic. Remeber in this imagining of it? That rare timed mission? Thats now 50% of your missions. Oh each tester said. "Stealth to timing mechanic (which mind you makes sense) was not fun. So what did they do? Got rid of the point of stealth and just started the timer quicker for each mission! Bravo dev team for NOT GETTING the point. Head dev's responce was literally. "Well I don't want to say, thats what the modding community is for, but that can be used to change your game." Because if you ship a broken game, its best to let your fans fix it. Good plan. A round of applause. Now about that no difficulty arc. Balls out hard can be fun. Oh I love a challenging game but this is just hard to be hard. Dont belive me? Remeber how in the first XCOM game there were two units that could scurry all over the map and pretty much instant kill you? Thats now most of the units. Psi powered badguys that can mind controll you? Available second level. Snake men that miss tonging you close from half a map away and then still be able to shoot poision at you? Check. Mind you this was on normal mode. Not the highest difficulty.Worse there is more stripping down of base mechanics. ow instead of an armory where you need to have more than one weapon or armor, you just research it once and BOOM suddenly everyone has it. As a rare plus, you can now place mechanics about to speed up projects and construction. There is no council to appease, so your mission decisions barely affect you. No worries about losing support now you stop "bad events" which really do not hinder you. If they do? I have not noticed. Blah blah blah. I know too many words. Here it is in short. Don't buy till on sale if you really want it. Ive had to break my save scrub code on this game and that pisses me off with all the promise it had. I see little replayablity and Ive honestly put it down and walked away from it for long periods of time twice now something a new game should never do.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2016
												Now that the patches are out this game became a lot better. The infamous stuttering of the loading videos and the Avenger management screen has not plagued my machine that much, but it was looking a tad ridiculous. (I repeat, it appears to be fixed.)Disclaimer: I am a savescummer. There is no way in this Universe that I will ever try it on Ironman.XCOM, our beloved super secret organisation is back with a vengeance, this time as a terro... a resistance movement who engage in kidnapping, property damage (extensively so), murder, mayhem, research and development. It's faithful to the classic three-layer design (global strategy and expansion; base management, R&D, recruitment and training; actually shooting aliens in the face on a turn based tactical screen (where face is applicable)). It continues what XCOM:Enemy Unknown started and improved it.The good: - it's everything I love about XCOM- a lot more diverse set of terrains in the tactical layer- creatively redesigned classes (they are still good but different enough to think a bit- cool new weapons- finally you do not have to take the damn things alive- finally, faces- soldier customisation options through the roof- loot system- time limits that add a sense of urgency to the gameplay- concealment for all your ambushing needsThe mediocre:- acceptable storyline that somehow manages to wriggle out of the confines of XCOM:EU's ending- solid characters- decent ending- some soldier development options were useless for me (think twice before choosing extra armor for the Grenadier instead of armour shredding capability)- plenty of bottlenecks in the game, got to think three steps ahead (I like it but it can be frustrating at first)The bad:- ridiculous misses in the tactical gameplay (five missed shots in Overwatch, hell yeah!)- line and splash effect placements are wonky (double-check the affected area before launching a grenade)- the Hellish Stutter may still be present on some rigs, I dunno- solid surfaces can be seen through at times, ending in megatriggers (you will see what I mean).

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												Overall, I love this game. I like that the mechanics didn't change much from the last one (it wasn't broke, they didn't try to fix it). I like the concept of us eing guerilla fighters with less resources. I like that they dropped the pretense of the crappy fighter minigame. I like the new aliens. I like the mission types, the maps, the character generation... so much of this game is right. But I would NOT be giving this game a perfect grade.First, lets talk bugs. Firaxis, I love you guys, but STOP releasing your games in buggy messes like this. My first playthrough failed because scanning for resources froze on two days left, while the Avatar Project kept ticking. My soldiers STILL get killed by aliens that shouldn't have line of sight. The Viper's constrict animation makes my soldiers and the Viper appear at random locations on the map (even though I can still shoot the Viper normally). Stahp eeet!Next, my biggest problem: Pacing. It's FAR too hectic. I'm certain some of the problems I'm having with being overwhelmed has to do with my unfamiliarity (shut up I make my own words) with the tactics of the new overmap; but I know that's not all. There's not enough supplies to keep upgrading, getting new troops (when you can't find them, which happens a lot), and building add-ons to the base. This makes me leap at every supply event I see, except I get interrupted several times during those scans by missions I really can't ignore. Not to mention the Avatar Project, which lights a huge fire under your♥♥♥♥♥ I would like that aspect, but on top of all the other craziness just makes gameplay on the overmap stressful. I don't want to feel stressed out by the game I'm playing, it sours almost everything else.I'm sure there's more I haven't found yet, but those two aspects of the current game need to be addressed I feel, and not with mods! Mods are great, but they shouldn't be used to cover up bugs or basic pacing problems in a game. It's still early yet, Firaxis, you have time to fix this.
