content:
Posted: April 4
												I was pretty exctied about this game and finally wanted to give it a go.   Unfortunately I couldn't tolerate the long, long, long, loooooong pauses between character actions and the painful process of waiting for your team's turn.  It took me 3 hours to progress through and beat the second mission.   Most of this time was the camera watching random alien soldier #64 run, jump over a low wall, and stand in place with a pause before watching random alien soldier #65 do the same thing.   Once you watch this 16 times per turn (2nd mission has you go against around 16 enemies at once)  you look down at your watch and realize that your life is ticking away as you are forced to wait 3-4 minutes between each of your turns.    Maybe you had to get this one at launch to really enjoy it?  I need a bigger return on my "fun" investment for my games these days.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												Xcom 2 is an incredibly addicting game and I've had just as much fun with it like I did with Unknown. That being said, two grips I have with it are some performance issues and the idea that not everyone will like the fact that the game is a little bit more streamlined. The game suffers from frame drops but an easy fix for this was to switch from MSAA to FXAA. Since then, I've had little to no issues. As for the streamlining, it's not so much of a problem with me persay but I know that series vets will have a bigger issue as base management is not nearly as big as it was with Enemy Unknown. Also, if you have played Unknown or Within, make sure to switch the difficulty to at least veteran (at times, if this mode felt a bit easy). Don't get me wrong, the game is still dificult but the first two difficulty options can at times make the game feel like a cake walk.With that said, I think this is one of the best ways to open the new year with because their are so many aspects I enjoy about Xcom 2. The direction of it's story, little changes with the classes, the unique enemy types, bigger focus on surprising foes through ambushes and so on. It's the reason why I keep coming back to it and it's already proving to be one of my favorite games this year.

number of helpful: 46 of 87 people (53%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												I like this game, believe me. But in the current state the game is in, i dont think its worth buying.Pros1. Incredibly challenging, as the game forces you to make decisions you may or may not like, which gives you a feeling that i cant describe to you2. Gameplay is solid, using turn based strategy and combat.3. Unique enemies to fight again, no longer copy and paste swarms of zerg, or crafty eldar4. An immersive story, which makes you feel like your actually playing and fighting for a cause5. Tons of customization options, make your soldiers look like friends and family6. The game is very moddable, and still lets you get achievements with modsCons1. The game runs like crap, even with people who have monsters of a computer. The game is very poorly optimized. Live through minimal graphics with twenty to thirty FPS to single frames per second with high graphic options2. The AI can sometimes be really unfair, or at other times a complete idiot, walking right into your overwatches3. The game has too much RNG, watch as a single ADVENT runt dodges almost every shot, and crits your soldier, gravely wounding them4. The game will sometimes stop after encountering a certain thing, and after a short pause it will tell you something you will mostly ignore5. Bugs and glitches galore6. It would be nice to have a 'Versus Mode' where one person plays as the ADVENT Coalation, and one as XCOM. XCOM would research new technologies, while ADVENT would be able to have aliens in their strike force.In Conclusion, i like the game, but i strongly suggest that you buy the game later in the year, when it will be more optimized, the bugs ironed out, and possibly rebalances in multiplayer.

content:
Posted: March 2
												Bug-riddled♥♥♥♥♥♥♥with no coherent design vision. Long War 2 improves it, but you can't build anything truly great on a rotten foundation. All DLC packs except for Shen's Last Gift are a joke, filled either with gimmicky customizations that are visually ridiculous enough to feel out of place in a Mel Brooks movie, or crucial features or items that should have been included in the base game (icarus armor - this was in the original XCOM, but here you are extortioned into buying the total sociopathically xenophobic piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥Alien Hunters DLC for it).And Pure Virtual Function crashes. Incessantly. Once you have installed a number of mods for this "mod friendly" game you will start to get CTDs so often that the game eventually becomes completely unplayable. Firaxis have had a year to track down and fix this, but instead they blame it on modders. As if any game of acceptable quality would allow mods to break it hard enouch to cause CTDs.If you're an X-Com fan and haven't played this yet, you are better off skipping it and looking elsewhere for you UFO Defense fix. Xenonauts 2 and Phoenix Point are both promising candidates on the horizon.

number of helpful: 8 of 13 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												Truly an amazing sequel for a brilliant reboot of XCOM. The gameplay is about what you'd expect from a turn-based game but of course with significant additions compared to Enemy Unknown and Enemy Within. Although I do miss my squad of superhumans and MECs, the new revamped classes are worthy replacements. The combination of rangers, specialists, grenadiers, sharpshooters and Psi operatives make one hell of a squad. Guerrilla Ops is a nice change of pace in which you enter a mission concealed thus allowing you to set up an Overwatch ambush. Fantastic addition to say the least. Gone are the days in which you can send out your Firestorms to shoot at alien crafts, and that is something I do miss at times. I won't spoil anything about the story here, but one thing I can say is that it gave me chills from start to finish and all of it in a good way. After such a long wait, it is good to be back as the Commander.ps. Optimisation issues are still troublesome as the framerate dips almost constantly from time-to-time, not to mention the loading times can take a considerable amount of time. It can be painful to watch the cutscenes stutter at times but Firaxis is working on it from what I heard. Hopefully they release a patch real soon. Didn't stop me from completing it though.

Clearly none of the developers actually tried to play it.I am done buying AAA games. Any remaining faith in the game industry is lost. I hope the industry burns to the ground and something worth my time and money grows out of the ashes.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												I am giving this game a no, though it has huge potential it has been horrible squandered. It might be salvagable with heavy modding or masive alterations. i would have prefered to give it a average revew but that is not possible hereTHE BAD1.the only improvement they have made to the tactics is the timer (on arround 80% of the missions) that forces you to throw away tactics and simply run full pelt toowards the objective most of the time.2. enemys can shoot you and often do through solid walls and can see you no matter what the lines of sight are.3. Apart from the odd ocation the enemy runs away they are all predictably dumb following the same procedures no matter what the situation (most often heading to cover and shooting even if falling back would be better)4. The only time you can get a suprise round is at the beginning, and once that is done with as soon as you see an enemy they see you regardless of distance or positioning.5. These points mean that the combat is simply a re hash of x-com enemy unknown, with new units and equipment, and if you do not get the right resources on the world map you are totaly ruined. (no enginers when you need them ever)6. The huge amount of glitches, press the overwhatch button and fire at the enemy, press fire and reload. thankfully these dont happen that often. but the frame rate drops are horrible as well as the eternaly long load screens (The huge amount of time you spend watching your squad in the transport waiting to deploy is rediculous).7. Poor late game Story, The early story is good and brings you into the game well (play the tutorial mission) but the end game story tells you nothing, and explains even less. It is a blatent set up for anouther game or an expantion and ruins what little stroy there is.THE GOOD1. Widely customisable characters with changable languages voices and aperance as well as attitude means you care if they die (sometimes)2. When they are running well good graphics and battlefield sound (listening to wanted posters and good ambient aperance of missions)3. Potential masive potentioal, with steam workshop support from the off there is potential for the  combat issues t be fixed by comunity mods, and maybe if there is enough work make this the A Star game it could have been but only with a lot of wotk.In conclution, this game is alright not worth the full asking price by a long shot, and not as fun as X-com enemy within/unknown, or as tactical as the long war mod for said game. the only redeaming feature is that it could be made into a good game but that is really it.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
												XCOM2 is a solid turn-based strategy game, and I really wish I could give it a full recommendation. However, as it currently stands there are a number of glaring issues with the game that need to be addressed before I can do so.1.) The game is a poorly optimized buggy mess. Frame rates are wildly inconsistent, and character animations are hilariously buggy (falling through the ground, breaking already-shattered windows, guns firing while on the back of the soldier, teleporting to another part of the map while being strangled by a viper ect...). The kill-cam is arguably even more buggy now than in XCOM: Enemy Unknown, especially when using abilities that initiate multiple attacks at once.2.) The UI is genuinely awful. Fraxis chose a concise and "stylish" look for all the important information in the game at the cost of the players. Damage estimates always show the highest possible outcome causing players to make poor attacks, what constitutes as flanking is completely unclear and not apparent before making a move, soldier skills are not viewable in the deployment menu,  the difference between "one-time" projects and "for all soldiers forever" projects in the workshop are not made clear, and information regarding the aliens outside of their health on the battlefield is never viewable by the player (what does "battle frenzy" even do?). No wonder many of the most popular mods are simply UI fixes.3.) Gameplay is enjoyable, but suffers from some minor issues.For the most part, the gameplay is enjoyable. If you liked the previous XCOM's gameplay, you will like XCOM2's gameplay. However, it carries with it the same problems of its predecessor. Firing angles are still bizarre and unclear; sometimes you can shoot through walls, other times your soldier cannot fire at an enemy clearly within range/view. Difficulty remains wildly inconsistent, with the early game being challenging, the mid-game unbearablely hard, and the end game being a bit too easy.The most controversial new gameplay decision is the addition of various turn timers to most of the missions. Whether you would like this or not really depends on how you play the game. If you like slow and methodical gameplay, you will probably hate it. Thankfully, not all missions are timed, so you still have some diversity in playstyle.In conclusion: unless you are a huge XCOM: Enemy Unknown fan, wait for a sale before buying this game. Right now it is an unpolished product that needs a lot of time and work before being worth full price.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												These were the longest, most intense 68h I've had. Starting on the day the game became available, I fought frustration, fear, anger and fatigue as my scientists studied new alien technology and deciphered important intel; my engineers built facilities to support the war effort; my contacts dabbled with the black market in a desperate search for needed supplies; and my soldiers fell on the battlefield, not knowing if their sacrifice would make a difference in this struggle, but certain no life under shackles was worth living.Yes, after that insane game marathon I have finally beaten the game. A moment of rejoice as my 4-day Carnaval break is endind and I have to go to work 4h from now. But I couldn't stop before it was all over. It is time to savour my well-deserved glory with my wife and the real world. That is, until the next campaign starts and I pause life for another 68h or so.10/10.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												This game is freaking terrible!  If you were a fan of the last reboot, and are wondering about whether or not to get this game, read this review!You start most missions in concealed mode, which allows you to creep around the maps and set up an ambush. In this mode, Overwatch no longer has an aim penalty, so you could set all of your soldiers but one on Overwatch, and have the last one attack, or run out in the open to trigger a 'pod'. (Group of enemies that are just stood there) Once triggered, they will most likely run for cover, and your soldiers will shoot them.  Concealed mode is an interesting addition, but during the timed missions, where you are given 8 turns to complete the objective, or you fail the mission, you cant really be messing around slowly setting up an ambush to deal with the enemies. In this way, the game comes accross as having multiple personality disorder. Because of the new abilities the aliens have, you have to be very careful, running away and looking for cover. But because of the round timers that the developers have, you have to be very fast, making sure to get there on time. The developers also saw fit to remove the ability to 'dash' to a door or objective and activate it in the same turn. That means that you have to move there, and use your second action point to activate the objective, or dash there, and activate it on the next turn. Nearly all of the 8 turn missions I have attempted have been failed with one soldier standing right next to them, ready to activate it! FOR GOODNESS SAKES! I failed 8 missions in the campain, and completed 4, (some of them tutorial missions) on the easy difficulty, even though I have played the other game on impossible.The aliens themselves have also been given much more power. Sectoids can now mind control, and appear just as early in the game as the last one. In the last game, only Sectoid Commanders could mind control, and you didn't encounter them until much later, when the research your scientists had done allowed you to manufacture advanced armours and weapons that leveled the playing field. Not only that, but Sectoids can also now raise the dead. So if one of your soldiers is unlucky (Literally, since the game is based around pseudo-random hit chances more than ever before...) not only does it hurt because you can attack the enemy once less per turn, but also it hurts because they can attack you once more per turn!  Killing the offending Sectoid will kill all the zombies as well though, but unfortunatly, it is rare that you encounter a Sectoid all on it's own. It is often accompanied by a pair of 'stun' troopers. These aliens are also encountered early in the game, and can dash AND melee attack your troops in the same move! Not only that, but they have a high chance to stun your troops, robbing them of their next move. It is hard to run away from these troops AND reach the objectives in time. Not only that, but while you run away for more cover, which is the only strategy in these Xcom reboots (everything else is random, positioning is the only certainty (and suppresion /explosives )...) you will invariably trigger another pod of deadly aliens, which will surely slaughter your entire team in the next go. What is also poorly explained, and completely ruined, is the geoscape. In the last game, you were given clear goals of what to do next, or what decisions you could afford to make. In this game, Everything is random. There are 11 continental perks, but there are only 6 continents. The game randomly picks your starting position, randomly picks 6 perks out of the 11 in the game, and randomly gives each continent one of those perks. I started in New India, in Asia.In the last game, you had a scan button, which would advance time. In this game, there are Scan buttons located all over the map. These buttons are essentially like bars, that get filled up as you choose to scan at that location, instead of another. once you have scanned it empty, you get the reward from it, what ever that was. Now, instead of monthly funding, every month, the funds you would have got are put down on the map somewhere, and need to be scanned for three days. You also need to build communications centers in your base to be able to contact more regions, and the regions are contacted in linear order.Research and base management works the same, with a list of upcomming events that get completed as you scan in the map. Manufacturing works similarly, but now once you have manufactured certain items (Like armour or weapons) You only need to manufacture one, and every troop can have one.There are certain missions in the game which advance the 'Advent' bar until completed, which when full, ends the game.  These missions don't disapear after a day like the others, and can be attacked at anytime. But only if you have contact with the continent that it is located in. So if you dont have access to that mission, you will have to build a communications center. But if you don't have enough power, you will need to build a power plant. But if you don't have enough money to do that, you will need to scan around to get some. While scanning, there is a risk a pick two, or pick three mission will pop up. You can choose to ignore it if you want, but there are 2 or 3 negatives associated with each of those missions, such as all enemies will have armour for the next month, or your funding will be cut in half next month. You can only pick one of those missions, and the other two negatives will happen anyway. But it will be difficult to beat those missions, with the new timer mechanics, and unfair enemy powers. If you dont have enough time to wait for all the building either way, then you will lose the game.There is no way to play the game like the last one in my opinion. Now, instead of being able to start a new playthrough and put on Ironman/Impossible, and follow through with a certain strategy you have been working on, the game does everythingrandomly, making it so you go in blind everytime. The old rules still apply to a deggree, elevation is good, blow up their cover, run away if you can to a more secure location, focus fire etc etc.But all of those rules go out of the window randomly. You rely on cover? Well what about if one of the humans running around on the map randomly turns into a giant monster, that can walk up to your soldier on a balcony, and swipe it's claws, and completely destroy the building your team is stood on, in one move? You always know you can run away from the aliens to secure a much better environmental advantage, like higher cover or a vantage point? Aww, well, too bad, you got a mission that expects you to kill 10 aliens and hack the box in 8 turns, with four rookies, and devastating consequences for failure. There are some positives though:They fixed the mouse lag, making for a much more enjoyable user experience. The game also runs well for me on my old rig, so I don't know why some users are reporting performance issues, but it may be a driver issue or something. The game looks pretty good as well. The game features well done randomly generated maps. The designs, the music, the sound are all great! One great moment I recall was a grenade knocking a soldier into a train, only to have a 'BANG' play, as his body hit the metal train! xD The game is also much more snappier than before, it's very responsive and less time-wastie to give orders and pan the camera. The game world and designs ooze atmosphere also. The tactical randomness lets the game down imo. You shouldn't have to mod the game to give you one or two more turns, that's something the developers should have anticipated.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2016
												I REALLY tried to like this game.  I'd heard so many good things and I was anxious to play it.  BUT IT JUST WASN'T ANY FUN!The story line kept forcing me into missions I knew I wasn't ready for.  I was constantly running out of power, running out of COMs, running out of supplies, running out of scientists, running out of enginners.  Everytime I attempted to address these things, I was forced into another Top Priority mission, and I would get even further behind. Which brings me to the combat.  Losses and wounding are part of the game ... I get that.  But the same problem with physical supplies ... it would take DAYS for a soldier to recover, and everytime I tried to accelerate it I was forced into yet another mission.   On the High Priority Advent missions, there were waves and waves of enemy reinforcements and my fixed number of soldiers would just get shredded.  Fighting with inexperienced rookies was a nighmare, as they would routinely go into a panic and run away screaming, leaving you a man down.It was an endless circle ... can't train soldiers without Training Facilities, which you can't build without engineers, which you can't recruit without supplies, which you can't accumulate because you keep getting forced into missions.I read up on different tactics and approaches and I even tried starting the game over a couple of times.  The game was a big disappointment ... I like to play games for fun, not punishment.

number of helpful: 11 of 19 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												The game initially showed promise, but I quickly came to realise that it's so tied up in the designers' decisions for showboating and 'what-would-be-awesomes' that it isn't actually any fun to play.The core of the original XCOM game is there and they've added some really solid new features to it, such as the armour system and melee combat, but the bad decisions significantly outweigh the good. The amount of RNG (which on it's own is fine), combined with new status effects that essentially render your soldiers completely ineffective for a turn (and the sheer number the enemy can deploy them on you) can quickly render entire missions impossible to complete within the first turn of combat, potentially forcing you to reload the same mission over and over. Animations in combat take forever and sometimes pause for a second or two afterwards for no clear reason, completely removing the sharp and snappy combat aesthetic they were aiming for and making battles take forever. The camera seems to snap all over the place for no good reason, even occassionally missing important enemy moves, and if I have to see that pointing animation one more time I don't know what I'll do.The stealth system, while a nice addition, seems a bit ad-hoc and doesn't seem to explore its own potential fully. I'm not sure how I'd change it up but currently it just feels lacking.The additions to the overworld gameplay are really fun and add a lot to the game, the more guerilla style warfare gives XCOM 2 a suitably refreshing style change from 1 and I think it's the overworld that's the strongest part of the game. However, that doesn't really translate to the battle gameplay.Additionally, I'll be the first to admit my machine isn't top of the line (or even all that good anymore) but the amount of variation in the framerate, even with graphics settings dialled down from recommended only increase the frustration of trying to play this further.In conclusion, a promising game sorely let down by some terrible design decisions for the battle system that would turn an otherwise fun game into a mess of frustration and disappointment. A real shame, as XCOM 1 is among my higher rated games.

												played for 12 hours. tried and failed to get into it. as a fan of the original i hate the fact enemies move on your turn, often flanking you near the end of your turn which seems incredibly unfair. the same old gameplay is incentivized (you don't want to 'trigger' a new squad of enemies on the end of your turn)there's also a great deal of bugs, shooting and melee attacks through walls; i once had a dead enemy perform a reaction shot on me. this game chugs with the framerates when it has no right to, considering that the graphics are nothing spectacular.i was playing on commander difficulty and i found it very hard in a frustratingly random kind of way. i restarted about 5 times a few hours in trying to keep my soldiers alive long enough to get some extra health so they aren't dying in one hit. this in itself is not a complaint - xcom is that kind of game. however a lot of the random elements are completely nonsensical and unintuitive. combined with the timed missions you can find yourself in a corner very quickly if you lose one guy on a mission. i can't imagine being able to continue after losing an entire squad and the mission.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												     This game is what small team strategy is all about. Your squad being constantly under preasure and outgunned, Xcom 2 captures the Chaos of war as you must adapt and overcome a dynamic battlefield. Do not expect to bring everyone back home, Xcom 2 will punish you and test your limits with the loss of your highly custimizable (and  often named) characters.  Despite the frustration of loss, youll take your beating and keep coming back for more.     Multiplayer needs work, the servers are shoddy at best and there is no punishment for someone who just drops out mid match due to rage. Also blade master rangers in multiplayer are a little broken as they will quickly take advantage of untouchable after easily closing distance and slaying oponents troops.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
												XCOM Is probably the most engaging game I've played in recent years, and XCOM 2 does great justice to the franchise. Let me break it down to pretty bullet points for you, in case you need help deciding whether to purchase this.PROS:- Strong theme and backstory, quite a mysterious plot.- Looks awesome, art direction is exquisite.- Tense! Some battles can really get your heart pumping.- Interesting mechanic for the strategy map.- Deep and fun soldier customization.- Diverse enemies and mission objectives add variety.- Long campaign!CONS:- Bad dice rolls can be cruelly unfair. Part of the game, tho! It's XCOM!- The first run (with the tutorial ON, that is) is too frantic for my taste. I like to be left alone.- Has some performance issues. Firaxis appears to be working hard on fixing them.- I've seen a few glitches and quirks. Bugs, that is.- Rather pricey, considering the above.CONCLUSION: 9/10, would name my gunner "Silvester Stallone" again.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												This is the best game I've played in a long time--it truly sratches the itch. There's always some great new, game-changing upgrade just a turn or two away; maddeningly challenging (but not unfair) battles, personality, and a scenario that you can really get into (alien occupation and human resistance).I really liked the previous XCom as well as the classic Xcom. If you enjoyed those games, I don't see why you wouldn't like this one. If you're not familiar with the franchise, imagine a turn-based strategy version of something like Deus Ex. Don't be put off by "turn-based." This game isn't boring at all, and you will APPRECIATE the time it gives you to plan each move, because each move counts. This game isn't about actions per second; it's about contemplating every possible move and choosing the most viable option. One last thing--most games, even ones I enjoy, I look forward to ending them and moving on to the next great game. With Xcom 2, though, I put off the story missions and tried to stretch it out as long as I could. I would've put quite happy to play for another 20-30 hours, and am already looking forward to whatever DLC is planned for it. In short: Great buy, even at full price. Money well spent!

content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												The animations gel well with the tactics. Positioning and well timed Overwatch moves are the keys to victory in this game. However, if one wishes a flawless victory every time, thsi game is not for that person. Also, be prepared to save after every move, because it could lead to a potentially bad situation that either kills off or cripples your choice soldiers. There are crash issues with animations freezing the game at times, and the framerate is choppy, but despite that, there is a mod for almost everything in this game, which makes the replayability go up by a factor of 10. Also, if one is not careful, he can get destroyed even in easy mode, something that sold the game to me, just like Divinity OS.If you have hours to spare, like customization and management, and are a fan of turn based combat, this is a must buy.Aku - Roku - Zan

												TL;DR: Way to buggy/glitchy to be worth. April 2nd, 2016, don't buy the game yet. Ever since the first patch my game has crashed multiple times on the same mission.The main flaw in the game right now is how buggy this thing is. For a game that was priced at $60 ( $80 for dlc), the amount of bugs is not worth it. Thank god for all the sales that are going on at this time, but even then I would say it is not worth it for how unpolished this is. After it is all fixed though I can definitely say this game is worth it. I loved X-com the first game. The gameplay in this one is even better with some annoying things gone such as the having to upgrade your own airships to takedown enemy cruisers, the new aliens are an interesting change. I wish they included more avatars for the later missions though rather than having only 4 in the entire game. The beginning is definitely challenging because you're limited on men and the aliens are so brutal, the mid game is kinda meh, and then the late game is a joke because if you research right and manage can manage your positioning you could take out hoards of aliens with ease especially when you get the soldiers with the right abilities. Hope someone does a long war mod of the game.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												So after several hours of gameplay, I can honestly say I recommend this game and love the new changes.  I played XCOM: Enemy Unknown and Enemy Within as well so I will give an honest review of the game. Quick Overview of Pros and Cons:Pros:* Really really fun - Matters because reason we buy and play* Good solid graphics* Great strategic play - Well thought out - Better than XCOM: EU/EW* Lots of options makes for very diverse play* Lots of maps - Really good maps/variety* Extremely immersive gameplay - You feel like you are trying to save the human race/world* Surprises, twists, and mystery - Great story telling so far* A large range of different enemies to fight* Mobile base and travel is well done and you have to make hard decisionsCons:* Could take some learning for new players - you might die :)* I did find one bug in the game during play so far - It was while in base, under the armory tab, and happened during customizing my units.  When I clicked on the "menu back" button it would not back out of the menu.  I did eventually get back out by switching to customizing another player and was then able to use the menu back.  Have not been able to duplicate this bug, only happened once.I know some do not like the "time limit" or number of turns you have, but I really thought it added to the game and made it a lot of fun so far.  It is an immersive element, you need to accomplish some parts of some missions fast and I liked it.  It gives some depth and weight to your choices on the battlefield and it makes sense from a story telling perspective as well.  It is well done, should try it before you mod it out imo.I know some have experienced some performance issues, I have not.  My system is good, but not top of the line.  If you have a below average system you will need to upgrade to play this game.My system:* i7 4790k* 8GB Ram* 120 SSD (game not on SSD)* 1TB HD* AMD 280 with 3GB video memPerhaps the current AMD video card drivers are better for this game than the current Nvidia drivers - I don't know that, but perhaps that is why some are experiencing some lag/stutter issues.*I have not had a single crash or freeze with this game.Overall this is a great game and extremely fun to play!  Lots of ways to customize and it's just a blast to play.  I think it is well done.  There are some out there that say it is poorly optimized, however most are probably not programers or developers.  I have electrical engineering and computer science experience and it seems fine to me.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
												In short this game is more or less XCOM 1.5. Though that is not necessarily a bad thing as the great gameplay from the previous one is still in there, the bad thing is that it feels as if many of the assets such as animations have been re-used from the previous game so it does not feel entirely fresh. And the graphics look sleek without being too good.Many of the new additions are great and since you are now on the offensive most of the time it means that many missions have timers, so you have to get your objectives done and then get out as soon as possible which creates tension and forces you to adopt new tactics compared to what you were used to previously. Though some of the missions have timers that either are too short or does not make much sense in relation to the objective. Such as the missions where you have to secure a supply stash, and even though you start the mission in stealth the enemy will still destroy the supplies if you take too long even if you were never detected.The endgame also feel a bit too easy, as there are no elite versions of many of the enemies, ADVENT soldiers of all kinds seem to level up and develop as time goes on, but many of the units such as the Vipers don't. Meaning that a once feared enemy no longer is a threat at all. So the pacing feels a bit off later on.Customization is really great, with many new ways to customize your soldiers, from a wide selection of hats and armours, even weapons and character personality animations can be changed to make your own squad more unique. Many of the classes also have been a bit more streamlined as well, and many skills feel a bit more useful and distinct. The specialist for example can now go down the skill path to become a medic or combat hacker. Both are useful so it is up to you how you mix and match character skills and builds.All in all I enjoyed XCOM 2, but I feel that they could have done more, it feels like a large expansion rather than a full new game. But if you liked XCOM: Enemy unknown, then you will probably enjoy this one, just be prepared that they are fairly similar while at the same time have enough differences. If nothing else there is always a steam sale later on. One thing is the same still though, RNG is still a ♥♥♥♥♥.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												I just want to make a short list of good and bad things in XCOM 2. So here it is:GOOD* There's always something to do, whether it's an operation or simple supplies gathering. No more boring weeks with nothing on the hologlobe* Nice visuals and cut-scenes. It was a strong point of Enemy Unknown/Within and they don't disappoint in this area. * Variety of mission types. No more "kill all the enemies to complete objective". Now you have to do something more than that * Character pool and customizations. It was always about soldiers and I'm glad they improved those options.* Weapon mods* Interesting and good-looking enemies* More random maps with some interactive features (aiming at explosive things, soldiers appearing as WANTED on holo-ads) * Badass Bradford* More 'progression' objectives* Very nice soundtrackBAD* Poor optimization, graphic glitches, freezes, long loading screens etc.* Avatar progresses too fast, without good planning you'll end up lagging behind* Too big reliance on explosives. You'll end up grabbing more Frag Grenades than any other items, despite wide selection of them* Poor chemistry between Tygan & Shen. Remember Vahlen and Shen senior? It's not even close to those funny taunts and conversations.* No more individual weapon creation. Now you grab one and it's available for all your soldiers.* Still 3 tiers of weaponry/armours. It may appeal to vanilla XCOM players but after Long War, it's a downgrade.* Concealment mechanics could be improved (e.g. you re-enter the concealment after few turns without enemy in range)* Timed missions force you to go straight to the point, with enemies always on your path. You lose the advantage of the map design, since you can't wander around.OVERALL:Strongly recommended despite minor flaws. Some future patches will probably fix most issues, and mods will improve the gameplay even further.

												My first review on Steam and sadly a negative one.I bought XCOM 2 full of hopes, having read almost only positive reviews on Steam (I just noted that this has changed heavily in the last days, (lesson learned....) and with great expectancies for the Definitive XCOM Game.All vanished after just a few hours of playing:The MISSIONS are based almost purely on luck. Particularly in the case of missions with a limited number of turns, there is no tactics involved, only rushing and hoping not to stumble in the wrong place at the wrong time. Often the missions end up being a Die-ReloadLastTurn-Die-ReloadLastTurn-Die feast, which I hate and is a horrible way to play this kind of games (but the only effective way). I never did this in any other previous chapter of XCOM or UFO.But what I hated the most, was the complete lack of freedom of the original UFO series which is definitely lost: you have to follow the plot that the devs have planned for you, no matter what.This used to be a great game about tactics, resource managing and freedom of choice.All of this is dead now, what is left is a very standard mainstream game, with good techical programming and very poor gameplay.I am SO disappointed.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												Contrary to other gamers I did not experience crashes and severe FPS drops but I can hear my computer on a heavy workload as if it were some high-end FPS game. Seriously, this game desperately needs some optimisation.And I get it: As a resistance you have to operate on a time limit but the constant turn timers force you into a certain play style. Gone are the days when you could position your soldiers for maximum effect. Snipers almost are a redundant class. Streamlining is one thing in a game. It is another matter entirely to artificially inject a sense of urgency with game play mechanics limiting your range of tactical choices. Thanks to some quick modders you can now set up longer timers or remove them entirely from the game which basically is a bloody cop out. The devs simply included too many of those timer missions early in the game which is rather unfortunate because that's when your squads are at their weakest compared to the alien opposition. Any mistake in keeping up concealment is punished mercilessly by this game. So you find yourself inching forward with the waypoint movement system. Even worse, this whole system of forcing you into quick movement tactics is counterproductive when you reach later stages of the game. The key story missions don't have timers and you'd be well advised to dust of your old EU skills of slowly advancing your front line.So what's the bottom line? Well, XCom 2 is a good game at least in theory. The enemies are varied and each species presents their own specific challenge. The timers are bloody annoying but you can get used to them. The real problems come from the bugs in this game. When you see your squad go to hell in an ironman game because one of those snake creatures can pull your soldier through a door and two floors, then you feel your frustration level rising because you were not defeated by a bad move but by a bad game engine. Sure, with some experience you learn to expect certain bugs and work around them but a truely excellent game would not force me to reserve some head space in order to avoid problems which shouldn't be in the game to begin with.pros:- interesting and varied enemies- a real tactical challenge- a good UI- a competent AI- tons of customization options- compared to XCom 1 a greater choice in missions- steep learning curve as the game is brutally unforgiving (if you want a challenge)cons:- still some performance issues- still some glitches especially with the detection and line-of-sight system- the game forces you to adopt a certain playstyle in order to succeed (at least early in the game)- melee enemies have unbelievable range- steep learning curve as the game is brutally unforgiving (if you are new to the game)

number of helpful: 16 of 29 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												After playing this game for 40 hours I figured i'd share my thoughts on it with you.Seing as it's been out a few days now, i figure most of you know the general story of this game, but just in case here is a short synopsis: It's 20 years after the events of XCOM. during that time, the aliens overthrew the human governments and founded their own. They are currently in control of everything. XCOM is njow little more than a  small group of freedomfighters, with very little to their name. The goal is to stop abductions, overthrow the aliens, and get the cake. Although not a very innovative story, it is certainly interesting enough to keep you hooked. Firaxis have let the story show through in some of its game mechanics-in both good and bad ways.  You are constantly on a timer, meaning you have to prioritize production of gear, research and facilities well. You may alos find yourself abandoning areas of the world to help out another. Every choice feels important, and this really helps carry the story forward.On the flipside of the coin however we have the idea of timed missions. In XCOM I enjoyed them as a nice little break from the normally slow phasing, But in this game they have taken it to the extreme. Practically every mission have some sort of mission timer, usually 8 or 12 rounds, but sometimes also 6, or via the use of a "dont let the aliens blow up the computer" mechanic. These timers are extremelly short for what you need to do, and you often find yourself forced to double move into unknown territories, just to keep up with the timer. This means you cant really react to what you find, and there's a big chance you put yourself in a flank. This mechanic would've been fine if Firaxis added a few turns  on each mission, but as it stand it is just infuriating.The game is also extremelly buggy. there are countless amounts of visual glitches, such as bladestorming a Viper as he is entangling you causing you to be stuck in the entangled animation for the rest of the mission, or falling through a recently blown up floor causing you to lose all your animations every once in a while. The list of minor bugs can go on practically forever. This however was probably anticipated as we saw similar issues with the release of XCOM.  There are however several game breaking bugs, such as falling through roofs and getting stuck in an enviromental piece, doors on the final mission not opening, or certain enemies on the final mission warping off the map. Enemy design is overall great. All enemies have a counterplay (although cryssalids are extremelly infuriating and not enjoyable in any way), and they all look great. They have all evolved in some way since XCOM, and it's always enjoyable to see Firaxis keeping their story at heart. The gameplay itself is just what you'd expect from XCOM, and with the exception of the timer, and classes being reworked it is near identical. The missions have different goals, and the game focuses more on destruction of cover.In short: The game is enjoyable, it plays mostly like XCOM EU/EW. It does have a glaring issue in the form of the mission timer, and it is absolutelly littered with bugs.  If you can overlook these two issues you will have a blast.

number of helpful: 15 of 27 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												Gameplay wise, XCOM 2 is a definite improvement over it's predecessor. A lot of the problems i had with XCOM:EU and EW are fixed here. The streamlined base building mechanics are also welcome over the confusing layouts in Enemy Unknown. The character customization is also very detailed, allowing you to create lookalikes of your friends as well as yourself. The story is genuinely interesting too, with the concept of Aliens runnning an oppressive government executed quite well, with high-quality cinematics too.However, the technical problems are very much present. Various animation glitches, crashes, terrain disappearing, aliens taking too long to respond in a turn, framerate drops etc. If this wasn't a turn-based game, i would have stopped playing a long time ago. i ran this game on an Intel 3970x @ 3.9 Ghz, 2x GTX 970s, 16gigs of RAM and the game running off a high-speed SSD, and the performance was pretty much the same, irrespective of whether SLI was on or off. And by that i mean the game runs poorly regardless of whether sli is on/off. In it's current state, i cannot recommend this game. My advice for a potential customer would be to wait until the problems have been ironed out before picking this up. Or maybe wait for a sale.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2016
												In XCOM 2 Earth forces have failed to stop the alien invasion of the first game and entered a pact with the invaders: most people now believe the aliens to have peaceful intentions and are happy to let them control most of their life. The XCOM project is still alive though and is trying to mount a resistance movement to find out the aliens' true agenda before overthrowing their government.The game is both an overhaul and a refinement of its predecessor and stands out as the finest XCOM game in recent times despite a shaky release.PROS:-the overall graphics are pretty good with nice effects and animations-good soundtrack-while pretty cliched the plot flows well and there'd a decent amount of mistery behind the aliens' plans-the new resistance-styled XCOM really has alot of character and charm-still sports some top notch turn-based tactical combat made even better by added mission types and better level randomization-the concealment mechanics are truly superb and provide good tactical depth-new soldier classes are excellent and great to use: said soldiers are also fully customizable in their looks, voice, stance etc-moddable weapons are fun-new alien types are quite interesting and can surprise you with some new abilities, their design and animations are also great-good length, each campaign'd last you at least 20/30 hoursNEUTRAL:-timed missions can be challenging or annoying, also depending on personal taste: still there's mods to make timers longer or remove them altogether-some missions can feel a bit unfair in regards to the amount of enemies thrown at youCONS:-uneven performance-long loading times-some line of sight bugs (like through closed steel doors) can be annoying and ruin your tactics-camera can be problematic at times-still has several bugs (a few crashes, audio desync in cutscenes, envirnment destroying itself for no reason etc...)

A Screenshot of XCOM 2
By: stranger1982




Going from a worldwide funded organization to a small resistance movement is quite a change and while I wasn't fully convinced at first I must say it works perfectly: you'll feel like a guerrilla squad operating behind enemy lines, facing overwhelming odds and slowly turning into a truly badass spec ops squad as time goes by and promotions mount up.The new mechanics Firaxis introduced provide an overall better game experience both in the field- with concealment letting you decide when and how to start going guns blazing, soldier skills providing many ways to get the upper hand over the aliens and synergizing well with each other, etc- and in the geoscape view- with mutually excluding missions prodiving different bonuses and drawbacks, POIs to explore, the Avenger to rebuild and so on. There's just so much to do, most of it is fun and well-designed and the game's brand of challenging, deep combat is simply as outstanding as it is engaging.There's a few dents into this great game sadly and most of them are due to a shaky release. There's some line of sight bugs where you can be discovered through solid walls and closed doors,a few AI hitches, shaky framerate, some jarring problems with audio in cutscenes getting messed up and the game can sometimes simply crash to desktop. Even after a patch things havn't improved too much so here's hoping Firaxis gets their act together and finally polish everything up.Even with all its blemishes XCOM 2 is simply an impressive entry in the franchise and a must buy for both long-time fans and newcomers: it's that good and it's only going to get better through patches, mods and DLCs.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
												There's a difference between challenging and frustrating. XCOM 2 simply isn't fun to play anymore at the later stage of the game. The game is very unforgiving, and brutal which is fine. However, it also doesn't balance the risk/reward of the game well. Often we are forced to risk the lives of our soldiers for minimal gain, and if we fail, we lose much more than we can recover. This makes the game into a long and hard grind, and more often then not after a few hours of playing I stop because the game just makes me tired and frustrated at it.Frustating Issues:Constant Interuptions - The game makes us scan every thing for days to get anything done, and yet it constantly throws interuptions and urgent missions and all sorts of stuff at you whenever you try to get anything done. It forces the player's progress to slow to a crawl.Always Outnumbered, Always Outgunned - The difficulty curve spikes insanely quickly after the first few missions, forcing us to always have to field high ranking soldiers if we want to have a chance at succeeding. Yet it makes it difficult to train Rookies, which in turn leaves us without a capable fighting force if we happen to lose our higher ranking troops. And we WILL lose them eventually.Timers - The game has too many missions with timers on them to play without the Disable Timers mod. Timers forces us to be reckless if we do not want to fail the mission, which in turn causes us to lose soldiers, which are expensive to replace.Overpowered Enemies Are Too Common - It's completely fine to have strong boss enemies. They make the gameplay fun and makes you feel rewarding when you manage to score a kill on them. One good example would be the first encouter with the Avatar. If done right, you could have your whole team fight the Avatar alone, and it made for some interesting and intense gameplay. However, one bad example would be the Sectopod. The first time meeting it was cool, but later on, the game simply spams the Sectopods and force you to fight one in almost every single mission, and they are often backed up by other units. By having these things be so common, it no longer a novelty to fight them. Instead it becomes a huge annoyance. Furthermore, some enemies are completely overpowered. Not only does the Sectopod have a insane amount of health, it gets to attack twice per turn AND overwatch after that. That is simply not fun. That's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.Sure, this game might appeal to the veteran hardcore XCOM fans out there, but as someone who just wants to enjoy the game, perhaps it'd be better if they left some of those things for the higher difficulties and made the lower difficulties easier. For now, it feels like the developers did not put any effort into balancing the game, and instead thought "How much can we frustrate and♥♥♥♥♥♥off our players so that they hate the game from now on?" and designed the game based on that.

content:
Posted: April 4
												As a veteran of previous XCOM titles, including XCOM, Terror from the deep, Enemy Unknown, and Enemy Within, I thought I'd love this game.  While it's not so hard it's unplayable, it is so hard its a chore, rather than fun.  The game maker's fetish with time limits makes the game much less enjoyable. 90% of missions have a time limit (and not a big one) and the entire game has a limited number of days until game over.Gabriel Garcia said it perfectly; That avatar project clock is a ♥♥♥♥ing pain.. i wanna upgrade my soilders and have better equipment before going into the harder story missions.. but what i fail to realize is that i dont have time to upgrade my soilders and build my base all nice and neatly.. i have to jump right into those missions as much as i can as fast as i can.. also i dont have enough radio transmitters in order to unlock more locations on the map so i can access the avatar project facility missions.. which means i have to build more.. which means i  have to clear debris.. by the time i finally build the radio transmitter beacon thingy.. two more advent facility buildings missions show up.. in even harder to reach places.. meanwhile im trying to keep up with "whats my scanning priority right now", and all the ♥♥♥♥ing dark emergency "go ♥♥♥♥ yourself" missions that appear every 4-8 days.. sigh.. what i do like is that it accurately shows whats its like to fight a losing battle against aliens that control the planet..﻿Also the "Avenger Bug" ruined my first and second playthroughs, so skip the tutorial.  And the game likes to crash once every mission or two, so save often.  A sad step backwards from the glorious XCOM Enemy Unknown.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												Pros-60 Hour Campaign-Many more alien types, creating more dynamic encounters.-UI Cleaned up from Enemy Unknown, quality of life improvements (reload only costing one action now, etc).-Far more soldier customization options, including weapon customization.-Game mechanics fit the Guerrilla warfare theme, having to contact cells, stay on the move, tactical insertions.-Improved story telling and cutscenes.-Ironman mode returns (requires tutorial to be disabled).-Graphically gorgeous settings and improved terrain.-Game now notifies you if you are flanking or being flanked by an enemy.-Smarter, more aggressive AI. They use their best abilities off cool down and flank hard and often.-Multiplayer is back and cleaned up/improved.-Sharing custom characters (can appear randomly through your play through, even as VIPs).-Weapon customization allows some counters, such as free reloads, increased crit or aim chance, and chance to kill outright.-Experimental weapon research allowing for random weapon unlocks, including flamethrowers.-More armor types.-Armor is now indicated in-game and indicates it's damage reduction, or if it gets shredded.-Classes redesigned but incredibly balanced with their talent choices, both trees are viable playstyles for all.-Permadeath-New event: Base defense, giving you access to ALL your soldiers over time while you defend the Avenger.-Can EVAC from any mission at anytime, but must deploy and reach your EVAC zone with each soldier.-Injured soldiers can be EVAC'd if you can't stablize them.-Line of Sight Indicator now helps tell you in advance if a move gives your soldier line of sight on what targets.-Concealment and Ambushes, incredibly powerful starts.-Potentional for PURE stealth missions (incredibly fun).-Buying Armor or new Weapons no longer require multiple purchases and are instead turned into default equipment.-High replayability.-Vast Modding scene.-Vipers <3Neutral-Can lose your 60 hour campaign at anytime (as in the Aliens can win).-Aliens don't wait around for you to tech up, deploying new aliens very often.-5x more missions than Enemy Unknown, you will get a ton of random side missions, only a few you can ignore.-Old mission types are back; UFO Landing Sites, Terror Missions, VIP missions, etc.-Terror Missions now require that you to save a minimum of 6 civilians out of 13-14, fixing the previous version's mistake.-Many missions now have turn limits (for objectives), forcing more aggressive play and less Overwatch spam.-Avatar Project: The Aliens final goal that can make progress incredibly fast if you wait around too long.-Injured or dead soldiers can be carried to an EVAC zone to return their equipment/weapons.-Weapon and equipment can be lost if the soldier carrying them dies and is not recovered.-Can slaughter civilians outside of terror missions with no reprecusions.-New Geoscape map takes a while to learn but is more streamlined.-Avenger base building is more streamlined, no adjacant bonuses (just need 1 of everything).-Can build PSI Operators much more early or rush for unlocking them.-Many aliens are mini-bosses (Sectoids, Archons, etc) more dangerous mechanics (Mind Control by mission 1).-Research for Science and Tech upgrades remains the same.-Only 3 Weapon Types; Standard, Magnetic, Plasma.-Soldiers can be lightly wounded, wounded, or gravely wounded, putting them out from 3-18 days or more (always occurs if any damage is taken, changed from Enemy Unknown).-Soldiers can become Shaken (Will reduced to 0), requiring kills or safe missions completion to remove.-Dark Events: A difficulty modifier where you chose 2 of the 3 debuffs that you want against you.Cons-Game difficulty can be overwhelming for new players, even on Rookie (the lowest).-Central nags at you very often on what needs to be done, even with Beginner VO turned off.-Missions occur very often, sometimes forcing you to stop scanning to finish something to go do them.-Avatar Progress can sometimes bump up drastically at random, even after destroying a Black Site.-Aim chances are lower all around and require heavy use of flanking to increase.-Hitting or Missing is now PREDETERMINED before you take the shot, and only rerolls when you move (crit not affected).-Early UFO missions are very overwhelming without more soldiers or equipment.-Some Launch day performance issues, v-sync, AA, and AO need to be disabled entirely to get or maintain over 60 FPS.Final Thoughts-Game is stellar and totally worth the purchase, but might be even more valuable on sale with the small season pass (which adds more customization, more weapons and armor, a new class type, and more story missions). Launch day issues have been very minor at best, my frame rate only seemed to drop during loading screens until the mission was loaded then returned to normal 60+. The customizations, difficulty, alien types all add to the vast replayability to the game and there are different paths you can take early on to determine how you want to play, instead of building satelites. Modding adds even far more to the game, and devs have given the tools they used to make the game to modders to expand upon that (name a dev that does that).

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												Great game with many improvements over the previous XCOM: Enemy Unknown.I'll start by saying I did not experience any of the bugs or performance issues experienced by other players. I purchased on launch and my experience has been very smooth. I have a mid to high-end computer and the game runs flawlessly. I did experience some crashing but it happens infrequently. Users with low-end PCs may have issues until the game is better optimized. The biggest change that players seem to be complaining about is the timer. The whole campaign is basically on a timer and you have limited time to research, make contacts and hunt down supplies as there are constant alien interruptions. You would think the aliens would have the courtesy to leave me alone for 11 days while I research the plasma rifle that is going to triple their losses in battle. How dare they try to prevent me from destroying their race. All kidding aside, I enjoyed this mechanic as it forces you to make the most of the time you have available and doesn't allow you to rush through the research and create early super soldiers. There are many ways offered to halt and reverse the progress the aliens make essentially giving you more time for your own activities. The only real flaw (and it is a major one, in my opinion) of the game is the RNG, or more specifically the in-game indicators of RNG are completely inaccurate and frankly, make no sense. I seem to hit more often with 43% chance than I do with 91% chance. The terrain also effects hit chance in a really weird way and the whole cover system seems to be broken. Overall I'm 18 hours in and having a blast. I'll freely admit I've re-run some missions that have gone poorly for me in order to minimize the loss of a favored soldier, but half the fun in my opinion is seeing what happens differently during a mission by taking various actions.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												XCOM 2 is a straight sequel to the 2012 remake XCOM: Enemy Unknown.In his infinite wisdom, Jake "Sid Meier is the dad I never had" Solomon threw out the expected Terror From The Deep follow-up from the meeting board and offers us instead a "what if ?" scenario where the aliens won and left XCOM in shambles.Also you get snake girls with♥♥♥♥♥♥cause he swore to never put snakemen in the game. Meta as ♥♥♥♥ !The game is pretty much a refined version of the first one. If you only swear by the original trilogy and Xenonauts, you might be dissapointed. Still, there are some new nice features.With no United Nations to back you up and Alien backed EXALT forces trying to hunt you down, the game flow is a little confusing at first. With your mobile base, you need to scan Earth's various regions to find supplies, troops and more importantly make contact with local resistance cells. This new version of the satelite coverage will become crucial as you try to thwart ADVENTs plans. Indeed, the aliens have an endgame, a doomsday counter called "The Avatar Project", which can't be stopped. It's scarier than it looks as completing story objectives and blowing up facilities will slow its progress drastically.Apart from the cosmetic lifting and the guerilla vibe, two features I really loved are the global revamp of the soldier classes and the concealment system. Every class is back but with a new edge, assaults get a melee machete, supports a cool robot, snipers become gunslingers, etc. It's such a great way to spice up the existing classes and make them much more polyvalent. Since XCOM is now a guerilla warfare operation, every mission makes you start hidden. It's up to you to spot enemies and ambush them WHEN you want it. It's a great way to set up a mission, especially since most of them are now timer-based.I don't have many problems with the game. The sad motto "Don't spot enemies on your last turn movement is still up or you are ♥♥♥♥ed" is still true and some enemies are pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t (like the lancers). But most of these complains will probably be answered by a "git gud, f4gg4t".The unsung hero of the game is probably Tim Wynn, the new composer. I was♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥at first that McCann didn't make the new score but now I realize it's for the best. XCOM was about mystery and unseen threats which matched the music perfectly. XCOM 2 is all about solemnity and the unshattered pugnacity of humanity. Music is so good it made me swallow a thesaurus.tl, dr: It's a new version of XCOM 2k12 with cool enemies, tons of customization and MOD supports.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
Home Sweet HomeGiven the alternatives, Earth is a pretty cool place to live. (although with pollution and global warming it sometimes seems we're doing our best to change that).It's just as well Earth meets our needs so perfectly because we don't have the ability to travel anywhere else to set up camp anyway... at least not yet (unless you count the moon, but we haven't been back there in nearly 50 years, governments would rather spend their money sending planes to drop bombs on deserts than sending rockets into space to benefit all mankind.)Real-EstateOne day, we will have the technological capability to travel to the stars, which will come in handy when the Earth becomes a less hospitable place to live.It's inevitable, whether it's climate change, lack of resources or the death throes of the Sun itself, eventually, if we want to survive as a species, we're going to need  to get off this rock and find a new one.The problem is, even if everything works out for us, if we survive long enough and develop the technology to travel on mass to the stars, we're still going to need to find another Earth-like planet with all the amenities (running water, central heating, oxygen, etc.) that we're accustomed to.Whatever happens, however we ruin our planet, for the moment, we're all stuck here so we have to make the most of it..Squatters RightsDo you know why life evolved on earth?It was because we have all of those lovely luxuries here already.There's a chance that if we did manage to find another planet that can sustain oxygen sucking life like ourselves, that it is already doing just that, sustaining some alien oxygen suckers that are perfectly happy where they are and have no interest in moving out and letting us move in.Aggressive NegotiationsSure, we could ask nicely, but if they didn't want to share there's always another option.We've been turning sandy deserts into glassy craters on Earth for a while now, why not just use our military might to clear a path for our forlorn colonists? Desperate times call for desperate measures. We can justify anything if we need it badly enough.If the native nuisance is still trapped on their own evolutionary cradle and we have the capability to get there, we're probably going to be more technologically advanced than they are (we'll have bigger bombs) so it shouldn't be too much of a problem.Envious EyesBut what if the tables were turned?We're still happy here on Earth, things are ticking over nicely, we've still got petrol for our cars, food for our bellies and oxygen for our lungs, then some alien eyes start to peer greedily at our planet.We'd be unlikely to roll over and give it to them, no matter how big their bombs are.It'd be a fight we'd likely lose (unless Jeff Goldblum and his trusty laptop are around to save us with a timely upload of a computer virus).But assuming this technological war or the worlds fluke doesn't come to pass, we'd be screwed.It'd take a long time to eradicate all of us though and a submissive populace might fit better with the aliens plans, besides, why make war when propaganda can enslave a people just as easily.A New HopeThat's where XCOM 2 comes in.It's been 20 years since the brief "war" against the invaders was lost, their propaganda machine has been in full swing for decades brainwashing the masses. The aliens are entrenched and the people cowed.But there is still hope. Pockets of resistance strike against our alien masters, there are remnants from the war, from the group that was meant to defend us from this alien menace.The survivors of the original XCOM project haven't forgotten the world before the overlords arrival and they want it back.Viva La ResistancePicking up the pieces of the devastated XCOM initiative, you are tasked with the job of unifying a global resistance against the insidious interlopers.If you've played any of the other XCOM games, especially the excellent 2012 title "XCOM: Enemy Unknown" then you're going to be on familiar, if somewhat prettier, ground.Starting with a small band of rookie recruits and a bare bones facility which serves as your headquarters (It's mobile this time around too!) you'll need to send out your team to engage in various hit and run missions against the aliens.In Enemy Unknown you were defending Earth against the alien incursions, the tables are turned this time as you strike out against the entrenched invaders, attacking them where and when you think it'll hurt them the most.Humble BeginningsBefore each strike against the enemy you'll need to select your squad from the pool of able bodied recruits you have available.They're all pretty green when you first start out, but the ones that you manage to keep alive will learn new skills and become adept at using different weapon types.You'll end up with heavy ordinance specialists, medics, snipers, etc. all of which will play a vital role in the often punishing tactical battles that you're going to find yourself engaged in.Again, just as with "Enemy Unknown" there's a promotion system to reward your best performing operatives, they'll even earn nicknames (which you can edit to suit your tastes if you're the sort that likes to tinker with these things).Man MakingTalking of tinkering, the level of customisation and attention to detail with regards to editing your team is exceptional.You can edit their names and nicknames to make them more memorable (Duncan 'McBig' Donald for instance) , engage in a little plastic surgery to make them look how you want, customise the colours of each individuals armour (I like to use different colours to represent different skill sets, heavy weapons guys in yellow, snipers in black, that sort of thing.)You can even select their nationalities (Their nations flag is displayed on their armour) and the language they speak, which you'll get to hear whilst they're chattering (or screaming) out in the field.It's not limited to languages  (English, German, Spanish, etc.) either, there are also accents to choose from.Under the British voices for example, you'll find Scottish and Irish accents available to really personalise your resistance fighters.The First Cut is the DeepestOf course, this customisation serves to increase your attachment to the little guys, which makes it all the more painful when you inevitably lose one of them in battle, especially if it's someone you've come to rely on, some you've been watching climb the ranks for a while, someone like my first major loss in the game... (You're sacrifice will not be forgotten Sergeant 'McBig').As well as the emotional loss of losing 'McBig' to hostile fire,  (I'll make the alien ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s pay for that!) there's also the strategic loss of losing a seasoned vet and likely having to replace him with a wide eyed rookie who will take several missions to become useful or more likely, wet his pants and get shot the first time he sees an alien.Engineering Greatness The aliens have been busy in the twenty years following "Enemy Unknown" too, their genetic tinkering has continued so you're going to find new and improved alien types terrorising the down trodden humans, which means new specimens to capture and fresh autopsies to perform.Researching alien tech (and biology) found in the field is vital, you're... [snip]For the full review (and others) please take the time to visit OUR SITE[www.review-well.com].

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												i was really looking forward to the xcom sequel.  i even pre-ordered which i quit doing long ago; now i remember why.  the gaming press is in the bag for the game companies.  I looked through multiple pre-release reviews and there was basically no mention of bugs or what is at times, completly illogical enemy behavior.  for example the game interface works fine on my laptop, right untill i dock it and use my mouse.  now when i mouse over a button it dissapears before i can select it. that's annoying but i can work around it until the hot fix but what i can't get past is the often completly moronic responses of the advent troopers.more than once they've advanced on my position to get a nominally better shot on one of my squad but expose themselves to another squadie.  several times i've had an advent trooper move from a firing position to a burning vechile, ensureing they die after taking thier shot from the explosion.  because they move with no hint of self preservation it's like you are fighting an OP zergling rush. Even that wouldn't be so bad but your squaddies fail about 80% of thier will checks, often creating a cascade failure that is irrecoverable because you're (seemingly) always fighting against a timer.I could probably even work past all of this but i get the stong feeling that failing at any one mission will start a larger failure cascade in the larger game and i don't think there is much of chance to recover once your (nominal) grip on the situation starts to slip.I understand this is supposed to be harder experience and i even embrace the idea but if failure is such a constant  the game becomes a chore.  I've got 6 hours into the game, and i've yet to see the fouth promotion skill for any class because none of the squaddies stay alive long enough.   There is no point in spending time customizing a squaddie if they are going to die in the next mission or two.  the only reward for good tatics in this game is that you might not get completly boned by the crazy enemy behavior, but i wouldn't count on it.The base control suffers from constanly haveing to stop one thing to go to another section to start a new research project, restart a scan that got stopped for the 3rd time, re-assign an egineer, move your ship, deal with a concil alert, and on and on and on.I'm going to table the game until the patch comes out, hopefully fixing the interface and nerfing the will checks a bit.  If it becomes fun i'll write a new review but right now it's just a gigantic dissapointment.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												tl;dr scores and tips at the bottom of the review.Xcom 2 is not for everyone, but if you enjoy learning through failure similar to that of a rougelike, this game is more than likely your kind of game. Xcom 2 is a turn based strategy game with some mild rpg elements (earning promotions that increase stats such as "aim" "move" "hp" and gives you two perk options per level.) Xcom 2 requires good tactical knowledge oa how to use and how to use your options. The appeal to the game itself is the amount of viable items, class builds, and even build orders there are to the game to form your coherent strategy. (This is enhanced tenfold with the mod support and the Long War 2 mod.)Xcom 2 is not a kind game, having perma death similar to games like Fire Emblem. You can not only expect to lose soldiers, and even the occasional mission, but sometimes even have to sacrifice a soldier to complete an objective on time or draw fire from a vip. This is ok in a game like Xcom, as opposed to Fire Emblem, because you do not have set characters, and can instead get more and more soldiers to replace your losses, instead only losing the expirence and any items the person was holding. Although smart use of tactics, abilities, and items can minimize these risks (such as using a flashbang to "silence" an enemy from using their psychic or physical abilities.) There are many different types of consumables, ammo types, armors, status effects, skills, psionics and classes to minimize the risk of death or to turn a death into an injury, making for a very intense game. In the end though, death will always happen, and is not always preventable. (As of right now I would always recommend an item called Mimic Beacon, as this item when used correctly can act as a get out of jail free card for the whole combat turn.)The expansion to the original 2012 Xcom, Enemy Within, added an incentive to speed along missions and stop the prevelant and honestly overpowered strategy of constant "Overwatch Trapping" which is when you would alert an alien on their turn and finish them off with overwatches during their scatter. In this game they remove the incentive instead replacing it with a requirement to move faster. Not all missions are about killing all the aliens, instead having to do an objective in so many turns and then get out. The turn limit, while being criticized by some, pushes against this strategy and calls for more risks to be taken ("Do I alert another squad of aliens and ADVENT to my position so that I can for sure complete the objective on time? Or do I risk not being able to do the objective and reduce the amount of foes I have to deal with this turn?")The game, despite it's optimization issues, is wonderful, for even reasons I haven't mentioned such as steam workshop mod support. Overall here are my scores for the game:Music: 8/10 (Will fit the mood in game but outside of the game just listening to the soundtrack is lackluster in some songs)Story: 6.8/10 (The game has some interesting twists and has some weird honestly anime style cliches in it, but don't let the story dissuade you from the game as it's not the main focus, and for what it is it serves its purpose.)Gameplay: 9.7/10 (There are a few things that need to be addressed like melee falling off in usefulness after final tier of weaponry and the way hp values are shown, although these are already fixed in some mods. Don't worry, you can still easily miss a 97% shot.)Graphics: 8/10 (If the game runs smoothly it looks beautiful.)Severity of bugs: mainly visual (like breaking a window that has been broken already) and framerate.Overall: 9.3/10TIPS FOR NEWCOMERS TO THE SERIES:- Don't be surprised if you lose.- Have backup plans, a 97% shots can miss, and yes it is statistically possible to miss four 86% shots in a row.- Flashbangs silence enemies and reduce their aim.- Acid grenades are the best in the game at shredding armor.- You have to make choices and sacrifices in your build orders, such as rushing towards psionics and making connections in the resistance the cost of utility items and updating your armory.- Just because you have concealment doesn't mean you play the game like a stealth game, instead use it to wipe out the first squad you see. If you try to play it like a normal stealth game you will get surronded when you get detected.- You can set waypoints using CTRL+Right Click.- Disorient and Fire silence, Disorient and Poison reduce aim (20 percent and 35 percent respectivly.)- There are a couple of deceptively useful skills such as Blademaster and Volitile Mix (DoT from grenades also get the damage bonus.)- Don't get disheartened if you lose a soldier or the game. The game is balanced around casualties.
