content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												Awesome game. An improvement I didn't think was possible from Enemy Unknown.The story is deep and the missions are ruthless.There clearly are some people whom are having trouble adjusting their play to the new timed scenarios but I'd say that they are without a doubt the best thing to happen to UFO/XCOM in a long time, especially so if you like playing on Iron Man. The reason is that they force your hand to action. You are no longer able to play ridiculously defensively going inch by inch through the level with all your guys always on overwatch but are going to have to make some really tough calls.Sometimes you'll make the wrong call, people will die, sometimes you'll make the right call and people will die anyway. Sometime leaving your guys to die is  the right call in the longer campaign. Previously Iron Man was simply an excercise in patience, since there were heavy consequences to having your guys shot at, the valid strategy was the one spent hammering overwatch and end turn never putting any of your guys at risk. If you never put anybody at risk, you don't need to load save games.In XCOM2, this is a luxury you seldom have. Usually there is something pressing you on, be it a beacon calling in enemy reinforcement, civilians getting eaten by aliens, a bomb timer ticking or just hordes and hordes of enemy reinforcements whittling you down. This calls for action and decisiveness, but if you over-extend and act too hastily, the game will still be there to punish your overconfidence.There are some missions where there is no timer or the timer will start very late in the mission or the timer might not start until you leave concealment (more about this later). These are usually the missions with the stiffest resistance as well. It allows you to revel in these occasions to really cheese the aliens as much as you can, pay them back for past transgressions, savor the ambush. (Un)fortunately these are also the missions where the aliens are the most well equipped to raise you on your cheese and give you a run for your money. The first such mission I ran into the only survivor was a sole rookie, objective in hand, runnning for her life from hordes of alien reinforcements. The mission was a success albeit a pyrrhic one as my best sniper, my best ranger and my last grenadier were left dead on the battlefield.Other pros:- The whole setting being insurgents against a state of dystopian alien opressors is awesome and surprisingly(!) fits the gameplay much better than the original secret government agency schtick that most other x-com games have had.- The new concealment system allows for some glorious ambushes though it doesn't hand it to you on a silver platter, you really have to be clever about it utilise it to it's full.- The game seems a lot longer and more content rich than previous Firaxis x-com games, that being said there is some heavy borrowing here and there especially on the gear side, but all in all more is more and there are few things without some new refinement.- The base building and management of the avenger (flying around doing missions on the map) feels a lot more refined and is more fun than in previous games. Also, it's no longer just about MOAR LABS, MOAR SCIENTISTS! Engineers are really nice and have a lot of versatility and tasks to balance.- There is a lot more verticality in the missions, allowing better and more varied level design.- Voice acting is good and the characters in your base have a lot of non-critical monologue/reflectections that are fun to listen to but easy to skip.- All aliens are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥sCons:- All aliens are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s- The user interface feels very laggy at times, especially during combat.- The framerate will suffer at times, more so than you'd expect from a turn based game. With that being said though, since it's a turn based game it's not a game breaker, but somewhat of an annoyance.- The game has a significant amount of minor bugs, nothing game breaking or super annoying though- The line of sight system is supposed to be super simple, but it turns out instead to be very unpredictable at times as it sometimes allows enemies and players to shoot through walls (it at least makes holes in the wall when they do). Also, what counts as cover from what angles is kinda gamey and you can have situations where it looks like you can clearly see an enemy but it turns out he's in heavy cover. The rules for when they are or are not are rather simple, so you can learn them but it does take you out of the moment sometimes.- You can only rotate the camera in 90 degree increments and have very low zoom in/out capabilities. I suspect this is due to the line of sight thing, since trying to look down from where your character is looking won't actually help you tell if there'll be line of sight or not.- Sometimes, especially when fighting in enclosed spaces, the wall transparence effect that's supposed to allow you to see what you're doing even if there's a wall between you and your character will also make the wall behind your character transparent making it very hard to see what's where and where there are walls and where there aren't.Overall, great game. I was pleasantly surprised despite high expectations.

												tl;dr scores and tips at the bottom of the review.Xcom 2 is not for everyone, but if you enjoy learning through failure similar to that of a rougelike, this game is more than likely your kind of game. Xcom 2 is a turn based strategy game with some mild rpg elements (earning promotions that increase stats such as "aim" "move" "hp" and gives you two perk options per level.) Xcom 2 requires good tactical knowledge oa how to use and how to use your options. The appeal to the game itself is the amount of viable items, class builds, and even build orders there are to the game to form your coherent strategy. (This is enhanced tenfold with the mod support and the Long War 2 mod.)Xcom 2 is not a kind game, having perma death similar to games like Fire Emblem. You can not only expect to lose soldiers, and even the occasional mission, but sometimes even have to sacrifice a soldier to complete an objective on time or draw fire from a vip. This is ok in a game like Xcom, as opposed to Fire Emblem, because you do not have set characters, and can instead get more and more soldiers to replace your losses, instead only losing the expirence and any items the person was holding. Although smart use of tactics, abilities, and items can minimize these risks (such as using a flashbang to "silence" an enemy from using their psychic or physical abilities.) There are many different types of consumables, ammo types, armors, status effects, skills, psionics and classes to minimize the risk of death or to turn a death into an injury, making for a very intense game. In the end though, death will always happen, and is not always preventable. (As of right now I would always recommend an item called Mimic Beacon, as this item when used correctly can act as a get out of jail free card for the whole combat turn.)The expansion to the original 2012 Xcom, Enemy Within, added an incentive to speed along missions and stop the prevelant and honestly overpowered strategy of constant "Overwatch Trapping" which is when you would alert an alien on their turn and finish them off with overwatches during their scatter. In this game they remove the incentive instead replacing it with a requirement to move faster. Not all missions are about killing all the aliens, instead having to do an objective in so many turns and then get out. The turn limit, while being criticized by some, pushes against this strategy and calls for more risks to be taken ("Do I alert another squad of aliens and ADVENT to my position so that I can for sure complete the objective on time? Or do I risk not being able to do the objective and reduce the amount of foes I have to deal with this turn?")The game, despite it's optimization issues, is wonderful, for even reasons I haven't mentioned such as steam workshop mod support. Overall here are my scores for the game:Music: 8/10 (Will fit the mood in game but outside of the game just listening to the soundtrack is lackluster in some songs)Story: 6.8/10 (The game has some interesting twists and has some weird honestly anime style cliches in it, but don't let the story dissuade you from the game as it's not the main focus, and for what it is it serves its purpose.)Gameplay: 9.7/10 (There are a few things that need to be addressed like melee falling off in usefulness after final tier of weaponry and the way hp values are shown, although these are already fixed in some mods. Don't worry, you can still easily miss a 97% shot.)Graphics: 8/10 (If the game runs smoothly it looks beautiful.)Severity of bugs: mainly visual (like breaking a window that has been broken already) and framerate.Overall: 9.3/10TIPS FOR NEWCOMERS TO THE SERIES:- Don't be surprised if you lose.- Have backup plans, a 97% shots can miss, and yes it is statistically possible to miss four 86% shots in a row.- Flashbangs silence enemies and reduce their aim.- Acid grenades are the best in the game at shredding armor.- You have to make choices and sacrifices in your build orders, such as rushing towards psionics and making connections in the resistance the cost of utility items and updating your armory.- Just because you have concealment doesn't mean you play the game like a stealth game, instead use it to wipe out the first squad you see. If you try to play it like a normal stealth game you will get surronded when you get detected.- You can set waypoints using CTRL+Right Click.- Disorient and Fire silence, Disorient and Poison reduce aim (20 percent and 35 percent respectivly.)- There are a couple of deceptively useful skills such as Blademaster and Volitile Mix (DoT from grenades also get the damage bonus.)- Don't get disheartened if you lose a soldier or the game. The game is balanced around casualties.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016



YouTube™ Video: XCOM 2 Walkthrough Part 1 - Introduction Tutorial and the New XCOM Base 

			Views: 170		

			XCOM was one of the hottest games of the year, and it was only supposed to be the first in a series of tactical shooters that never really took off.		

It was questionable as to whether or not they could make a game that is superior to the original.  The first game was really good and its expansion gave you more to do with the original game.  Without a doubt this game is... more of the same thing.  Which isn't necessarily bad.  It's different which allows you to play differently, but for the most part it's the same thing.Many of the enemies have had stats adjusted and have been reskinned, but for the most part all of the enemies are the same.  Some enemies can burrow now.  They've added stuns as a mechanic in the game.  They've removed some moves from some units and given some new ones to new ones.  The enemy unit composition although feels different, is roughly the same.Instead of having to worry about managing countries and slowly losing monetary support from countries you're instead building up a resistence network and can only lose support if you lose a defense mission for that area.  To keep you entertained there are 'pick ups' on the map that you can pick up over time while waiting for enemy attacks or waiting to progress down the rabbit hole of the game's storyline.I think if you've played XCOM before this game is worth picking up.  If you haven't played XCOM before you might want to just pick up XCOM instead and perhaps pick up this one after you're done with the first.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												Overall, I enjoyed XCOM 2. I plan to play a lot more of it when the performance issues have been (hopefully) fixed and when some more substantial mods are released.It should be noted that I played on Veteran difficulty. Commander might fix some of the issues I had.What I liked:+ FX+ Story (Plot, characters, missions, VO)+ Customisation+ Combat+ Stealth+ Loot became meaningless pretty fast but it was fun customising weapons.+ Classes+ AIMixed opinions:~ The randomly generated levels are hit or miss. Usually miss. I found myself fighting in streets and hiding behind chest-high walls and pylons most of the time. Everything that’s interesting in the level tends to not be in the B-line you have to make just to make it to the objective in time during a timed mission. ~ BLOOD FOR THE RNGODS. The RNG can get pretty crazy at times, which is both good and bad. Good when it’s funny and satisfying to hit a 30% shot + crit and bad when you miss two 94% shots then proceed hit a 43% shot.What I didn't like: - Overabundance of timed missions. Timed missions are too short to do any meaningful planning, recon, or strategy. You have to make a B-line for the objective. This was my biggest peeve and I’d say it hurt my experience the most. - OST. The tracks Lazarus and Out of the Ashes and the main battle theme are good. Everything else is pretty generic orchestral music and ultimately forgettable. I was really hoping for more heavy percussion and synth.- The setting isn’t interesting. I never found the ADVENT intimidating.- Atmosphere. I never felt one outside of the cutscenes.- The enemy variety isn’t great. A lot of the enemy types stopped being scary pretty quickly. The only ones to really be worried about are the ones with a lot of armour. Most of the time you just fight the MEC's from Enemy Within and ADVENT soldiers. I was really surprised at how I barely fought any Mutons. I only fought the Muton Berserker three times, one of those times being the final mission. - Performance issues. - Mission variety. There are only a handful of mission types. The most interesting and enjoyable ones like UFO capture and base defense only happened once each in my playthrough. Most of the time you're tasked with making a B-line to something you have to hack. I did enjoy the Avatar facility sabotage missions though.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2016
												First of all, I love the xcom series.I was having a lot of fun in XCOM 1 and wanted to finish it before buying XCOM2. The sound in XCOM stopped working for me so I decided to go ahead and buy XCOM2.Well so far the game seems pretty good but I couldn't say much about it because of all the game breaking bugs.During the tutorial there came a time when it wanted me to go into overwatch mode.  I tried, and no matter what I couldnt get into overwatch mode.  I use the steam controlller and it already is kinda weird controls so I tried on my mouse and keyboard, still couldnt.  So I had to quit.  This time I skipped tutorial because I don't have all day to play games and just wanted to play before my wife came home from work.  It was pretty good for about an hour or 2 until at a mission screen my ship starts on it's way to the mission and just stopped.  The game wasnt frozen it was just as if my ship didnt want to go to the mission anymore.  But it was on its way so the game wouldnt do anything else.  I just can't pujt the time into playing a game thats going to stop working all the time I am at a point in my life where I just want to be able to sit back on the couch and enjoy playing a game without thinking about it.   This is not able to be one of those games for me due to all the bugs.  :(Also as I mentioned earlier the steam controller works for it but the controls are bad to me (unless I just have not found out how to change them) but it requires you to click icons with the "mouse" for your moves instead of being able to use  the controller to cycle them with buttons.  Any time I'm forced to use the touchpad on the controller to navigate to tiny buttons is annoying,So maybe one day I'll be able to play this when it's polished more.  Until then it's been a waste of $50

content:
Posted: February 9
												It's got solid mechanics but for ♥♥♥♥ sake, it barely works. Constant glitches, some game breaking, or at the very least mission/campaign ruining. That you're completely at the mercy of dogshit coding for the entire game is an egregious fault that cannot be forgiven. Maybe in a more forgiving game this would be more acceptable, but I've had three very successful ironman campaigns killed at the last minute because some ridiculous bug got my best soldiers killed. And, on top of that, you might flawlessly and meticulously complete very long mission, only for the game to crash near the end or  afterward while it's loading the next screen, and now you've just wasted your time and effort. I can hardly believe they would even release this game in this state, let alone leave it largely unfixed even many months after the release.If they ever actually fix it, it's a great game, 8 or 9 out of 10. Until then though, avoid it.

It's the first game on the Unreal Engine for me with such troubles, I feel bad for Epic Games this game is so un-adverty for their technology:)

Posted: November 24, 2016
												Don't be fooled by the thumbs up - it should have a million asterisks next to it.While XCOM 2 is a definitive improvement compared to its predecessor in Gameplay, Audio/Visuals and Story, this game is very finnicky with AMD hardware and has the weirdest issues on that and some slower Intel CPU computers: explosion audio/visuals happen earlier than they should or are completely de-synchronized, model pop-in, texture pop-in, delays in output on very odd occasions, shots that appear to hit actually miss... None of these actually affect gameplay (especially since this is a turn-based game), but it is detrimental to the experience overall and inexcusable in this time and day - using Unreal 4, no less!Low-end/AMD owners, use extreme caution and make sure you're actually willing to pay for a game that WORKS and is REALLY FUN, but LOOKS broken as hell.the amd meme is real

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3
												An absolutely fun game. Worth every dollar. Combat is great (if you like turn based), the game feels relatively balanced within the difficulties, and the story is pretty cool. I had forgotton what playing a game and enjoying the story was like. You might not like the pacing of the game. This isn't like the original where you could build up and turtle for extended periods of time. X-COM 2 has mechanics built in that prod you to continue do story missions and to make you less cautious during missions. Some people don't like it. I honestly didn't think I would, but I feel it adds an extra element of sheer panic to the game. You can't just sit there, build up and get to the "steam roll" part then play the entire game. Overall: Really delightful.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2
												XCOM 2 is absolutely great, 10/10. But still there are some broken things and should be done I hope they'll fix on XCOM3. Giving a single example; Psi-op is broken, seriously. It requires long time to unlock psi-op's full potential but when you get it, its just indescribable. There should be 2-3 types of psi ops in my opinion because it's really stupid to accumilate all psi-op skills on a single operator which I managed to get 3 fully trained maguses; after 2.nd magus, I didn't even move my finger, they're waaaay better than other classes and so IMBA (not just for psi-op, game lacks of classes and there's an unnecessary class for example blademaster is unnecessary and useless late game), there are different bullet types, vests and weapon upgrades which are great and this time you strike enemy forces so that means you get lots of chances to ambush enemy pods, there are dark events which slows your progress and buffs enemy or AVATAR project, you should know that you're race against time because AVATAR project cannot be stopped, you can only make it delay. Mimic beacons are nice to draw attention, forcing enemies to come towards you, finally they removed spastic Floaters off and replaced them with Archons which is my favourite alien, not just Floaters even Sectoids has changed, only alien you'll be seeing in XCOM:2 is the Elders but even they have changed apperience. Gameplay is quick, but you probably want to play again maybe on a harder difficulty, after experiencing and knowing all things you may install a mod, there are lots of great mods and developers do support them like Long War 2 and mods numbers are increasing every day.So if you're looking for a tactical challenge you might consider buying XCOM 2.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2016
												The game is good (I guess) but the experience is just killed by critical technical issues. I played for about 20-25 minutes and honestly it was unpleasant. The game was released for 6 months and still there are a lot of bugs. After 25 minutes or so the game crashed. While I was playing I had 4 freezes which longs for about 30-40 sec each (no jokes, I've never encountered such *** before in my life). I mean, in the past I could play 640x480 Oblivion on Radeon 9600 essentially with graphics turned off with average 20 FPS and 2-5 FPS while you're looking it the direction of stables of Imperial City (no probs -- just look in other direction), but here 60 FPS suddenly becoming 0.03 FPS. It's not just annoying, it makes game unplayable. Maybe it will be fixed -- who knows? BTW, I'm playing on Linux, maybe Windows version is more ok. It's the first game on the Unreal Engine for me with such troubles, I feel bad for Epic Games this game is so un-adverty for their technology:)

content:
Posted: November 15, 2016
												Either everyone I know is astronomically unlucky or the game doesn't display odds correctly.Even if this game had odds relative to their display, it's still a wretched game. Extremely poor optimization, kamikaze AI, tacticless combat, unfair rookie/squaddie balancing for early game, AND less content with lower quality than their previous game. The story is laughable, considering Firaxis claimed to have a large focus on the story. All of the characters are very unlikeable, all talking over eachother with exhausting dialogues that have no relevance to anything. I'm guessing they'll also take the easy way out AGAIN and imply XCOM 2 was a string of failed missions to pamper their creative director's asses so they can reshah XCOM AGAIN and make another sequel.Look, I've never claimed to be lucky, but when you've pumped 55 hrs into a game, flawless it on commander, and literally lose the first three missions 50+ times on Legendary, I would consider someone mentally unstable if they DIDN'T despise this game.

The chances are either broken or they are not communicated cleary to the player. 3. Major performance issues although graphics don't look that demanding.

number of helpful: 57 of 110 people (52%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												My playtime is miniscule right now but let me give my piece  on it anyway. The game itself first and foremost caters to the XCOM: Enemy Within fan, it not only refines the mechanics seen in the previous games but it added new ones as well. The classes are distinct from one another and gives you the player greater tactical choice in your gameplay. But by far the best new item added is the concealment option which pretty much means that your team is invisible to all enemies until they are either detected via patrol or more often than not via an ambush you have setup. The story and atmosphere from what I have seen in sublime, the game pulls in no stops from telling you that you lost the previous war and that right now, XCOM are considered terrorists, this is a huge step up both thematically and mechanically as well since the aforementioned concealment mechanic makes so much sense. The mods will also bring in so much life to this game, as of writing this, there are 3 main mods that can easily be added to the game via Steam Workshop.If I have one gripe I would point to the performance, it's not gamebreaking but it is a hassle and it is obvious, I struggle to get a smooth 60FPS with many of the filters turned off, I run an I5 3570K with a GTX680, not the top of the line setup admittedly but it should have handled the game better than it did.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18
												In my humble opinion, I believe that Xcom 2 is one of the greatest Strategy games of the last 10 years, and surpasses its predecessor in scale, ambition, story and player emotion and connection.Without the DLCs, the base game is packed full of content and the content that you want and expect from an Xcom game as set by Xcom: Enemy Unknown.The DLC is somewhat lacking to Enemy Within, but it is still very accurate to Xcom 2, and very enjoyable. I would recommend playing through with no DLC first, and then doing a 2nd run wit all DLC enable.This was my top game of 2016, and probably my 5th favourite game of all time.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												So far an excellent successor to the X-COM series, and has learned a great deal from the previous itteration. The procedural maps are a godsend, and the new overworld map is a lot more fun/interesting to be involved in. The game is much more difficult in some areas, but much easier in others. Early on, there is a huge amount of instant-death for your squad, and that's not a bad thing.Currently there needs to be some optimization for graphics performance. There are a lot of visual problems for the title.And for those crying about "every mission having timers", this is a huge hyperbole. Huge. Half, if that, have very long and easily-worked-with timers if you don't slowly overwatch crawl to your objectives. Try actual tactics, and cycling through your soldiers mid-actions to orchestrate a kill, rather than waiting for the enemy to stumble on your 5+ overwatch snipers.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												Pretty good! Worthwhile sequel. Addresses virtually every criticism of the last one. Handful of issues though:- Performance is all over the place! Seems like lots of developers have added so many postprocessing effects to UE3 over the years that it's getting difficult to optimize well... and using a wrapper rather than doing OpenGL builds for OSX and Linux doesn't help. There's also hilarious bugs like the game thinking 12 PM is midnight and 12 AM is noon as far as your savefiles are concerned -- of course, _only_ C++ doesn't have a standard library to handle this for you, but that does suggest a minor lack of polish.- The base-building optimization puzzle is a little too solvable, but it's the sort of thing you'll inevitably get wrong the first time through. This carries through to a lot of the game's design, where you seem to be encouraged to savescum or fail on your first time through, with neither option being particularly satisfying. There's no reason this game couldn't have borrowed Invisible Inc's autosaving-with-a-fixed-number-of-rewinds mechanic as an alternative to Ironman mode, and it'd have been better for it.- Late game has a bit of Civ syndrome where once you've seen all of the tech it's a bit of a slog to push through to the very end.- Narrative comes on too strong at the start with all of the military stuff and the power fantasy of repeatedly addressing the player as "commander," though the mid-game scripted events are well-handled.- The starting swords are ridiculously anachronistic.This is already a good game, but I expect it will be much, much better in a year. It's probably fair to be frustrated by that in the meantime.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												So you have come to this page pondering if XCOM 2 is the game for you...If youre the type that tends to yell at your computer, dont buy it, unless you plan to drink gallons of stress relief teas and buy a 20 pack of pencils at the dollar store for the sole purpose of breaking them in half when your squad just got wiped out again all odds again.If you thought XCOM (+EU) was hard, definately DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. If you like a Dark Souls like challange, then go for it.While in XCOM you had to deal with thin men and sectoids that were one hit obstacles in XCOM, and you could develop advanced weaponry before enemys got too hard XCOM 2 doesn't give you a break like that. the sectoids have 8 hitpoints and can eventually mind control your units starting from mission one, aside from their other abilities.The plus side is, you too have some additional tricks up your sleeve, and especially the snipers and specialists are now more useful from the start while they felt like dead weight up to a point in old XCOM.Now you also have the "Avatar Project" instead of the "Doom Tracker" a mechanic that personally annoys me a lot more than the old one, where you felt generally more like it's related to your performance, while the Avatar thing just basically counts up constantly and you have to chip off some progress by doing certain things, which feels a lot more annoying in my opinion, especially because it feels odd with the story. The resistance has done resistancy things for 20 years while you were in a statis pod, and now all the the rush? Youre "Mr. Save The World" and are going to build a global resistance... I am sure there are more visceral ways to keep you on edge. Maybe its just me being reminded about work a lot when I see deadlines everywhere in the games.Oh yes another point, deadlines and racing around the clock in most missions, either for loot, mission objectives, the avatar project, enemy reinforcements...Another annoying part is the "Shaken" mechanic, while reversable contrary to the old "critically injured" it has one mayor flaw: You wont be told until the mission is over, so you cant reload and try again. And to get rid of it your twitchy Will=0, read: Every Psy ability will get them, and they will panic all the time, they need to kill an alien without being injured themselves...But aside from being really hard and often unfair and Deadline heavy, its a good game that really does a good job when it comes to the immersion part. You really feel like youre in charge of this ragtag band of resistance fighters, that you can customize to look like a bad♥♥♥♥♥version of your playground buddy or coworker.Would I recommend it? Yes, definately. Would I recommend to get a stress relief squishy ball along with the game purchase? YES DEFINATELY! *squeezes squishy ball and drinks some salvia tea*

content:
Posted: October 1, 2016
												Sheer brilliance.   This is the most accomplished version of the XCOM series yet. Some of the confusing game mechanics from the previous XCOM have been addressed. The DLC is nice enough, but it's a bit limited in scope and therefore not the greatest value for money.  The game had (past tense) some technical and gamplay glitches at first, most of those are gone and now only rear their head occasionally, which can  be annoying, but nothing insurmountable.  There's been many complaints about the performance - those issues are in the past. I play this on a 6 year old CPU (a i7-860 from 2009), paired with a GTX 660, it's very playable at 1080p if you tweak the graphics settings just right. Moving to a GTX 1060 (oc'd) gameplay is smooth with maxed out graphics setting at 1920x1200. Overall, a AAA title that delivers, with long-term replayability baked in.  I'm pretty sure I'll be playing this until XCOM 3 comes out.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Let me start by saying XCOM 2 is a triumph. XCOM EU and EW paid homage to UFO Defence's difficulty and fear factor by making sure the game was truly difficult, but in a mostly rewarding way. In some ways they compromised on those principles - having your best squad wiped a few weeks in and losing a critical mission was basically game over, so half the time losses felt frustrating rather than just punishing and reinvigorating. In my first XCOM 2 run, that I consider to have gone fairly well, I've lost upwards of 10 soldiers in a few months, and I failed my first attempt at a blacksite, but I can tell I'm that I'm not doomed. Notably, in EU, there were a lot of safety net abilities like Run and Gun, Rockets and various Sniper abilities like Double Tap though that made the game at times laughably easy - so long as you had restraint. XCOM 2's biggest change to the formula, outside of the total revamp of the strategic layer,  is the fact that there are almost no safety nets in the early game. Rockets are gone, replaced with grenade launchers, which while incredibly useful, cannot wipe out a pod of enemies in one shot every mission.  The new Ranger class, which is basically like the old Assault, doesn't get Run and Gun until midway through the ability tree. The sword they get has effectively enormous range, but can't be relied upon to singlehandedly kill enemies unless you get bladesman at corporal rank, which loses you an extremely useful concealment abiility.  Specialists are about as underwhelming as supports were early on, but get just as deadly in later ranks, while Sharp Shooters are heavily situational due to the fact that a lot of missions are timed, but can now do some very interesting stunts like fire off pistols a couple times a round at different targets, or chain sniper rifle shots together if each one is a kill. The fact the aliens are now more specialised, and their gimmicks are more frightening (e.g, the basic sectoid gets the mind control ability in the first few months)  means that without safety nets, they're far more fearsome and worth being worried about. This makes the game more difficult obviously, but also more enjoyable in the long run once you know how to handle each type of enemy - Sectoids are easily killed by swords, Stunlancers either need to die ASAP or you need a flashbang/overwatch to shut them down from charging. The Faceless, meanwhile, needs to be spotted well in advance of triggering it, because it can attack on activation.  The variation in alien types and the threat they present means that XCOM 2 encourages a lot more tactical, outside the box thinking. The visuals in this game are incredible. The unit design for the aliens and advent hybrids is superb, and really adds to the intimidation when they're breathing down your neck. The environmental design is also great - the procedural generation is by no means a half baked gimmick and makes every area look interesting and refreshing.  There are cobbled together outposts, futuristic cities, slums, surreal alien bases and facilities.  Customisation is top notch - there is as a lot of freedom and oppurtunity for making your own narrative in your head, and in general things that make your troops more memorable, like random extra abilities, the memorial/bar and personnel areas you can view all add to the attachment you get to them. I want to quickly mention the multiplayer. This is a mixed bag - the extremely points heavy advent robot units are extremely hard to kill and can one-shot most targets. The Sectopod, ludicrously, can even fire twice, doing 10-11 damage each time.  The costs on units are very weird, as is some of the internal balance. Advent Troopers at 200 points have 3 health and a mag rifle, but for 400 points you get an Officer with 12 health, better stats, a frag grenade and the ability to mark targets. Since matches total about 7500+ points, you can easily fit these guys in.  There is an issue with stuttering as well which I'll touch upon in a moment.In terms of technical quality, you can tell that the developers didn't put their effort towards making a game that was very free of bugs, or that ran extremely well. The game is stable - the amount of disruptive bugs that will ruin your experience or progress is very, very minimal and rare it seems. The problems arise with the fact that XCOM 2 just simply doesn't run as well as it should on high end PCs- there are frequent FPS drops in missions unless you turn some settings down.  This obvously doesn't matter that much, since the game is turn based, but it is irritating. Perhaps the most annoying bug is the fact that the game occassionally takes a few seconds to register a buff/debuff/critical effect, or upwards of 10-20 seconds to end a turn in multiplayer and pass control to the other player. This is something that is bound to be fixed eventually though. I whole-heartedly reccomend XCOM 2 to anyone who was a fan of XCOM EU, and would also say that anyone who has an interest in a challenging and interesting game but has not tried the games before this one should give it a go at least.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												70% rating? Come on, this game is fantastic. I've played 10 hours of this game so far, and I haven't enjoyed a game so much in this way since, well, XCOM EU.Let me explain what I mean: This game is terrifying. Every single mission is down to the wire. Every mission can and will go wrong. And the whole time, I'm sitting there thinking, "Don't miss don't miss don't miss Oh ****"And that's great. Seriously. That's awesome, and that's where XCOM shines. Risk/reward is a huge part of what makes the experience as satisfying or compelling as it is.So if someone complains that the game is too hard, they're missing the point. I mean, jeez guys. We're liberating the human race from technologically superior aliens. Why did you expect it to be easy?Anyways, half the fun of XCOM is when everything goes to hell and yet, somehow, you scrape together a victory.Disclaimer: this game is harder than EU. Yeah, seriously. And so if you're considering getting this game, don't expect it to be a walk in the park. It's war. But it's incredible.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Yeah, there are some crashes and bugs. Welcome to computers. So far I haven't run into anything that can't be solved by restarting the game.The mission timers take some adjustment and I've had to restart a few missions, but hey, new game new challenges. Figuring out how to use my team's abilities on the go has been fun - the same cautious tactics in every mission dominated in XCOM EU and now that's not optimal, thank god.The strategic layer creates a great sense of urgency and a real challenge to balance different research and development goals against maintaining your network and expanding to stop the alien plans before it's too late. If I lose, it won't be because my squad got killed and I didn't bother reloading; instead it will be because I didn't push fast enough to stop the alien master plan. Again, I like that caution is not rewarded: if I take forever building up my tech, the aliens will complete their doomsday project, The End.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Incredibly tough, even on just "Veteran" setting. Much more like classic XCOM in that you'll be churning through legions of rookies. Contrast this to XCOM:EU/EW, where the loss of anybody during a mission feels like preventable odds--in XCOM2, some missions will leave you thanking RNGesus you managed to evac with anybody.Note that the guerrilla themes apply beyond just the aesthetics. A lot of missions will be on tight timer limits, forcing you to scramble. Fighters will also be affected by PTSD, and Will reductions are more frequent than the previous installment. They're hammering home the fact that you're making do with civilian volunteers, rather than trained pros, but this adherence to thematic cohesion does often come across as a gameplay burden.Finally, in terms of performance: until Firaxis provides an optimization patch, expect a lot of lag. Turning off anti-aliasing can help, as does canceling cinematics, but there's going to be a lot of unavoidable stall-outs as the game processes combat results. Once spent a solid minute waiting for a single grenade result to register--between the odd angles, the burn damage, and everything else, the enemy unit ultimately clipped through a wall. Weird.Past the optimization problem, the game is very pretty, very deep, and VERY fun. I trust Firaxis to do what they need to do to make it shine. In the meantime, there's bug-eyed alien ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s to gun down.Good hunting, Commander.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												I waited till i finished the game before i wrote this review.When i had finished EU back in early 2013, i remember i craved for morecontent. And i got EW later that year, which was a good addon, and madethe original EU what is was suppose to be from the start.I was fairly addicted to EU, i simply could not put the game away. Andafter i finished EW, all i wanted for the next XCOM was more of everything.I wanted more content, more variation, more aliens, more story, bettergraphics, more customizations. More everything.And here we are finally. And Firaxis listened to the fans,What they have delivered is exactly what i wished for. A long detailedgame with a fantastic story, great music, great voice acting, awesomemaps... In short.. It has delivered everything!There are some dissapointments though, the game obviously havesome optimization issues at launch, i managed to fix those thoughby tweaking some settings, but others seem to not be able to playat all.The game also have some bugs here and there, but i never ran intogame breaking bugs.I finished the game in about 60 hours, I could have ended it earlierbut i decided to finish my PSI soldiers before i assaulted the lastfacilities. And the very last map was a blast, a map that took mealmost 2 hours to complete, with enemies off every sort in largequantities. Damn that was a fun ending.So what Firaxis has delivered is another great game, and this onecomes damn close to being a masterpiece. Some of the bugs areirritating, and brings the experience down a little bit. But as itstands, it is a great game with 50+ hours of fun.9/10 - Very good

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
												I want to like this game, I really do. I loved the "first" one. I played through the BS once when it first came out, and recently thought to myself, now that the dlc is out and they've had time to fix issues lets give it another go. But somehow its even worse off then before.What I'm talking about is performance and the regular crashes and freezes. The game just kinda skips along. Anytime anything happens on screen, any loading occurs, the frame rate is just.. disgusting. It drives me crazy, and nothing I do fixes the issue. I've dropped to the lowest settings, messed with every graphics option I could and am seeing the same issue. Do the drops in frame rate impact your ability to play? No, not really, its turn based after all. But it takes me right out of the game, makes me lose my train of thought and in a game where planing is key? that's very much an issue.And the freezing... I didn't have an issue with this the first time I played, but this time.. I just started this new game, not very far into it. I've already lost count of how many times I've had the game crash, even more so it's just frozen. Audio keeps playing fine but I can't do anything else. After a while it seems to have corrupted my save somehow. Eveytime I try to fire on an enemy the game just freezes, Bye bye my first iron man run.I looked past these problems at first and thought to give them time to fix things, sometimes unexpected issues pop up. It happens. But after all the DLC and 6 months? Not only are they not fixed but things have gotten worse.All I can really say is they took a great remake, a potential new life for an old series, and ruined it. Ruined it with garbage coding and worse still, ignoring the community's complaints.As it is, I cannot recommend this game. If they ever take the effort to actually fix this mess then I would absolutely love it. For when it dose work it's just fantastic fun. Unfortunately the fun is continually interrupted.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2016
												This game is just dice rolls with fixed dice, in the favor of the enemies. No matter how cautious you move or how good your cover is,you will always get shot, and half the time the enemies get crits while you always miss. People saying that "Oh, well it's a hard game so you have to get good, it's a fight against a way stronger force blah blah blah" No, there is a difference between difficulty and unfairness. Dark Souls, that's a notoriously difficult game that is balanced beautifully and feels rewarding and satisfying when you win, this game feels like you are constantly losing, and not in a fair way. You get a 70% chance to hit but always miss, enemies get crits on half of their shots, Sectoids with mind control are in the second mission. That isn't fun, it's just obnoxious. You can tell the devs are absolute garbage because people had to come in after the fact and fix major flaws of the game through mods on the workshop. This game is terrible, especially when comparing it to Enemy Unknown. Oh and lets not forget the ever present time limits. 4/10

content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												Definitely a step in the right direction for the XCOM series and certainly a very fun one.  If you enjoyed the first one then you will like this one even more, but I can understand where the negative reviews are coming from.  There are certian elements that are simply copied from XCOM with seemingly no attention given to them (e.g., the indoor camera; many of the human animations; a lot of the sound effects) and while these are on the whole a series of minor elements, altogether it does put a tarnish on what is otherwise a great game.  TLDR; fantastic game to jump into XCOM with; great game but a tad lazy in some areas for those coming back for round two.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												Pros:+Extremely detailed character and weapon models+Tactics are mixed up from XCOM 1 as now you can start out as the people hiding and the aliens are the ones defending+Improvements to the Geoscape and strategy within it as now you can choose different regions to expand to+Very detailed character customization and mods adding more and more each day+Cool new gadgets availible for research as well as "experimental" research. This can grant random armors, ammo, grenades, or utilities which is really neatCons:-Extremely obnoxious turn limit timers that sometimes make no sense. On one VIP mission I had 8 turns to get the hostage and leave, and there were about 15 aliens in the way to the exit and it also made no sense that the timer started ticking down before I was even discovered. I'm all for added dificulty, but not at the expense of reason, because there is no reason at all of why you would be limited in turns when the aliens already found you and reinforcements already arrived. You should be able to maybe fight off a huge invasion if you take too long, it shouldn't just end and not give you a chance.(There are mods to fix this problem however, as they increase turns)-On top of these turn timers, the Avatar project is constantly ticking away as well, though I haven't looked to see if there is a mod to slow it down, I am sure there is or will be one.Overall: 9.5/10 - Improved every aspect from XCOM 1 and there is in depth character customization for your characters that will probably be killed in a few turns.

Posted: October 9, 2016
												I thought the first game was great and I tried to like this second one but I can't get into the "limited turns" mission. I don't mind limited turns, for example the meld in the first game felt like I was rewarded for getting to the meld in time and losing out if I didnt, it was fair play but unfortunately in XCOM 2 the limit turn missions are most of the mission types and you will lose the mission if you dont achieve the objective in (usually) 8 turns.  I think in this case the limited turns take away too many options (and enjoyment) from the player and introduces frustration. In the end I became so frustrated with these missions and questioned why I was even bothering. I cant recommend XCOM 2, not even in a sale. Buying the game cheaper wont make it any less frustrating.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												Frustrating, repetitive, and tedious in the extreme.   I absolutely cannot recommend it unless it is very deeply discounted.1.  The developers need to learn some basic statistics.  When you are firing a weapon or hacking a terminal you are given a percentage chance that is always FAR higher than are the actual odds of success.  For example, I just did a trial (over several hours) of hacking a terminal where the odds were listed as 10% chance of success.  In 100 tries there were no successes (and each time it generated a different progress bar so it is not an issue of the outcome having been predetermined).  The odds of this is almost 1 in 38,000.  Why show the percent chance of success if it is so radically far off?2.  Too many times where enemies suddenly appear out of no where and shoot you through 4 walls and kill you.  Their shots almost never miss while yours usually do.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												"Xcom 2 is like that pretty girl in the bar who looks like a girl you really got on with but only hotter. Your thinking, shes fitter, and she must have the same personality. But does she ♥♥♥♥. Shes out for your Wallet and will leave you falling asleep after 15 minautes of ♥♥♥♥ all foreplay and playing dead the whole time""Xcom2 in my opinion, A Horrendous♥♥♥♥♥♥Picking♥♥♥♥♥Receptical."===========================================I recently mustered the courage to purchase this game despite cringing for my beloved yet light wallet. Ussually my purchases are very selective but I decided, having played Xcom 1 and adored many of the previous in the genre, this was a safe purchase. How wrong was I.My consensus playing this game leaves me lacking ANY form of excitement, I literally have to force myself to play it, let me break it down:Storyline: The story has completely failed to drag me in. Set in a world already conquered by aliens, It fails to establish any kind of emotional or empathetic connection with 'any' of the storyline characters and yourself. With no lack of attempts to drag you in, It just feels like they've attempted a mass effect/dragon ageish approach but completely ♥♥♥♥ed it up purely with a♥♥♥♥♥♥back story, no user customization/decisions making it linear and a one trick pony, then theres realism, your sat there thinking how the ♥♥♥♥ did all this happen, with little believable reason as to why. This theme that world has already been conquered and colonized leaves me feeling there is already no hope and humanity is ♥♥♥♥ed. Despite the fact there are already multiple Xcom storys flying from previous genres, they've reinvented the wheel yet spectacularly managed to make it the same as every title before. "get base, kill aliens, save the world" except in the EXACT SAME WAY AS ALL PREVIOUS TITLES. Jees, atleast have some forks in the road. -1Realism: None, there isnt any, the story is unrealistic, the setting, the tech, I know its a sci fi, but you need some realism factor in order for people to relate, and get pulled in. -1 Combat: Whilst vastly the same as previous Xcoms, has features implemented which frustrate my gameplay. UI has been reduced 'even more' like I didnt think that was possible before, with even less information on display allowing you to interpret the battlefield leaving you frustrated when your tactical decisions fail due to gameplay mechanics you simply werent aware of. The camera is god damned awful, with constant custscenes skipping in and increasing your wait time when all you really want to do is survey the battlefield, sure you can turn it off, but half of them still go on. Oh yeah surveying the battlefield, your camera is zoomed in only allowing you to see a short distance in your vicinity, to see further you have to mouse out, which gives what I'd consider a "normal" battlefield viewing distance, but once you release, it goes back to the previous camera. How the hell your supposed to think ahead tactically on this "middle mouse and remember" ethos is beyond me. It feels like this game has been dumbed down for console. Heavy modding will most definately be needed. -1Gameplay: The first couple of hours in this game, I felt like I had little or no influence over what was happening. No choices, just following a merry go round of "click OK to do this". It reminds me of a Web Based Strat where you spend weeks doing this♥♥♥♥♥♥only to get bored out of your ♥♥♥♥ing brain. The only choice I have are to click "ignore" then recieve a warning saying "♥♥♥♥♥♥YOU BETTER DO THIS OR HELL WILL BREAK LOOSE" and you feel like you'll miss something and succumb to fear mongering. -1Difficulty: The AI is a challenge, and the amount of options available to you in combat do present tactical freedom leaving you hanging on the edge of your seat. Gone are the "guy 1 shoots misses, guy 2 shoots, misses, guy 3 shoots misses". +1Graphics: Yeah great, but since when did looking at a nice picture captivate me for 60+ hours... That said, it feels like playing a frigging cartoon. Im giving it a +1 because it is beautiful in places, but its also getting a -1 because I think thats the reason im not dragged into this game, Its a fecking cartoon! +1 -1Experience: Whilst I enjoyed Xcom 1, it was already dumbed down as it was, and it was bearable, even fun, this didnt need to be dumbed down anymore. It needed more UI not less. More tactical options, not less. More User decision making not less. More Customization.... not... less..Conclusion: I really dont care for this game, its crap. Its a Cartoon graphicy console port.My Score: negs -5pos +2Overall, -3 Leaving Xcom2 in my opinion, A Horrendous♥♥♥♥♥♥Picking♥♥♥♥♥Receptical.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9
												XCOM no longer as government paramilitary organisation and instead being terrorist organisation fighting with government? That isn't same good 'ol XCOM - these were my thoughts when I first heard about changes made to the game. But when it was part of February 2017 humble monthly bundle, hell, why not? Turned out better than expected. This is a sequel to 2012s XCOM: Enemy Unknown. No matter what was outcome of the game, you have lost. World as you know it is gone. XCOM was dissolved and delegalised.20 years have passed. World's governments have been replaced by alien controled ADVENT Coalition. XCOM barely exists, Doctor Vahlen is missing, Doctor Shen is dead, Central Officer Bradford is alcoholic and depressed, whole resistance against alien rule is not coordinated, and former XCOM Commander is missing. All XCOM has is captured alien Aircraft as a base and few soldiers. That is, before resistance got a lead on Commanders whereabouts. Thats where you come in. You free yourself and take command over resistance. In gameplay, there are tiny changes, rendering this good 'ol XCOM. Turns out that shadowy Council member is still alive, so you have monthly ratings, you get money... i meant, supplies as they are known here every month as drops from the Resistance, there are heads of engineering (Lily Shen, daughter of late Dr. Shen) and scientific team (Dr. Tygan who used to work as a scientist for ADVENT), there are similar missions, for example Terror missions with saving civilians (here these are Retaliation missions, ADVENT attacking resistance safehouses). There are also changes, obviously. Enemies are similar to ones encountered. Government forces are mostly composed of human-like ADVENT Troops, Officers and so on. That means it will take a while untill you meet aliens. After 20 years, old alien types were enchanced using human genes, making them look slightly different than before, and have some new abilities. Some alien types are gone, other totally reworked, eg.: since aliens are now in charge, there is no need for infltration units, so Thin Men are only seen in retrospections. That being said, I wouldn't like to spoil the fun of meeting old enemies on the battlefield, so I will be quiet. Sadly, there is no option to capture alien specimens alive which I kinda miss. Soldiers can have one of 5 classes (4 regulars and Psionical unit): Ranger, equipped with words alongside with regular firearms, Specialists with their drones, hacking everything they can, Grenadiers with heavy weapons and sometimes useful snipers. In comparison to the old game, you have much more customisation options available, which is nice. Furthermore, on the missions enemy units can drop soldier enchancing items and weapon parts that can be given to soldiers. Very nice idea if you ask me. By the way, problem with attachments staying on old weapons after upgrading them has been solved: all if you unlock upgrade to the weapon, all weapons are upgraded, and modified guns stay modified. Engeenering and scientific research were slightly changed too. You have regular research and item building, but there are sidekicks: Shadow Chamber is one of the facilites available to build, and in it few of the research projects are conducted. Why make them there instead of lab, I have no idea (they definitely could, since SC researches stop regular ones). Similar problem exist with Item building and Proving Grounds facility for engineering. Two options with very similar results. One of the most altered parts of the game in my opinion is Geoscape. There are no countries that are funding XCOMs existence. Instead, you increase your income by making contact with resistance cells (there are total 16 of them) and building Radio relays to further increase your monthly income. Having contacted all cells on the continent and placing required amount of radio relays unlock bonuses, similar to ones gained on Enemy Unknown at the choice of base location: Experimental items finished instantly, weapons having more slots for parts ect. You can spend your time by collectiong random bonuses that appear on the map (require scanning over their location for set amount of days; you can get scientists, engineers, soldiers, supplies, allien alloys, elerium crytal or intel), destroying Avatar Project facilities (oh, yeah, since you cant lose countries funding, there is something different to make you try harder: AVATAR Project, for completion of which aliens need to finish Dark Events [they have additional effects like additional Chyssalid on each mission ect] and build research facilities. You can counter one event every month and decrease Avatar Project progress by destroying facilites and completing story missions). Also, to be able  sell your good, you need to find and unlock black market, and fly to in to trade. Okay, nothing is perfect. This principle also applies to this game. Most missions to counter Dark Events have timers: 8-12 turns to complete. Then you get 2-3 stong enemies on your way to the evac and it gets hard pretty fast. Some missions are unfair: had to defend relay from enemies, spawned on the other side of the map, while there was Gatekeeper (something like upgraded Cyberdisc from EU) spawned next to the relay. In 4 turns relay was gone. I had no chance to make it. Then there is Bradford and his notifications: useful at the beginning, but boring and annoying later in game (Commander, enemies scrambled interceptors, Firebrand wont be able to stay long, we need to hurry. I mean, i can see the remaining turns timer, no need for something like that). Proper Snipers are rarely fully used, since most of the missions require you to rush through the street with a VIP (Friendly or enemy) and escape, leaving no place for proper sniper usage, while their second skill tree focusing on pistols feels a bit too weak. Sure you can mix them but Jack of All Trades, Master of None, right? To be really honest, degree to which I enjoyed XCOM2 suprised me, given my lack of huge hopes regarding changes. Story works out, speeches of ADVENT Spokesman are amazing and these disadvantages dont break the enjoyment from the game. So if you enjoyed XCOM:EU and dont mind little changes here and there, you will like this one too.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21
												Before I start, SPOILER HEAVY REVIEW, although I feel I have good reasons for a negative review for a game I like.I will say that I enjoy XCOM, I have since the first one, and this kind of sadistic gameplay intrigues me. I love it, and I will spend many more hours in it, but there is a reason why I am not going to recommend it, especially over XCOM: Enemy Unknown.I am not going to focus on bugs/crashes/etc, since many of those can be system specific and not necessarily a general thing.1) TutorialThe tutorial is absolute garbage. It teaches you the base mechanics of the game BUT... Here comes a few points.    Point 1: It teaches you to not take cover while overwatching, also it teaches you to overwatch instead of engaging.    Point 2: It teaches you to go into positions where you have no cover.     Point 3: It only gives you a semblance of control, does not allow you to experiment with game mechanics, does not allow you to even try anything yourself, you are stuck on one specific path that will make any decent XCOM player grind their teeth from the decisions the game forces you to make. Probably one of the worst tutorials I have ever personally experienced (XCOM: Enemy Unknown had a tutorial that forced actions on you as well, but it did teach you about decent movement and didn't force you to do actions that were bad unless it got your trooper outright killed right away)2) ProgressionThe progression of enemies in this game is completely crazy, ESPECIALLY if you played the tutorial.If you played the tutorial you have very few decent troopers and you get dumped in to a mission where there will be a Sectoid. For new players being introduced to the game, they have barely finished a tutorial that didn't teach them anything, and they have to deal with a mechanic that can (without actually shooting a trooper) make a trooper inoperable for several rounds (panic), mind control them or make them near useless with a disorient buff... This is the ... "second" mission of the game, and if you did the tutorial you haven't even played one mission yet.Also a few enemies you encounter early on (within the first 6 missions), each having their own frustrating mechanic, especially if you haven't played XCOM before (and many of these mechanics are new to XCOM).ADVENT Stun Lancer: Can move incredibly long distances, which is in stark contrast to ANYTHING! you have encountered so far, rarely if ever shoots and deals an insane amount of damage early game which also has a chance to either stun your troopers (making them inoperable for X amount of actions) or outright knock them unconscious requiring you to carry them out of the mission if it is an evac mission. Despite them being this unique they don't stand out that heavily from ordinary ADVENT Troopers visually making them (especially for new players) harder to make out.Viper: These guys can PULL! your guys to them, and grapple them, making them inoperable until you shoot the Viper. It can BEYOND this shoot an AOE poison that will early game be able to almost kill your troopers. This is guaranteed damage and if you didn't bring a medkit, you are screwed because that is the only way to get rid of it (or finishing the mission)MEC: These guys are not as frustrating as the two others, but they severely limit your flanking abilities since they don't use cover as well as the fact they have 2 armor. The game has not taught you what armor is, or how armor works yet so some players may not have any idea how to deal with it (which will make these guys into bullet sponges early game) They also are the first AOE cover destroying enemies as well.This is within the first 6 missions, and 2 of these are earlier than that. All of these appear earlier than most of their (less frustrating) counterparts in XCOM: Enemy Unknown, screwing the progression of the game heavily.Just these things put together is one of the reasons I would probably never suggest XCOM 2 to a new player. Even more experienced players can get a lot of games ruined in the first couple of missions due to random frustrating control removing mechanics being introduced this early.3) Frustrating Mechanics / Enemy DesignThis ties a little into Progression but XCOM: Enemy Unknown in contrast to XCOM 2 did not introduce a lot of enemies that could outright take control away from you early game, while as I mentioned before this game introduces 2 of them within the first half hour to an hour of game experience. In a game already about RNG it speaks of the bad game design to have so many mechanics to take away the control of your characters (leaving you with less characters to deal with the threat) and some of these mechanics doesn't even have a real counter to them. Besides that I feel that they spent way to much time adding to many abilities on to their enemies due to them lore wise being an "upgrade" to the original troopers. Due to this addition of so many new mechanics to enemies, the enemies that were considered a threat (and didn't really receive an "update") in XCOM: Enemy Unknown are now incredible tame.These include:  Mutons: They are introduced so late into the game that their pitiful 8 health and 1 armor is laughable. A lot of your troops have more than that, and half your characters will be able to oneshot it.  Berserkers: Rarely if ever a true threat, due to it's "frenzy" mechanic. You just shoot it while it is far away, and it kills anything close by, including its own allies.   Avatar: These guys are... super... insanely... underwhelming... They are supposed to be the cool♥♥♥♥♥psionic dude you have to fear, but it gets introduced in a ridicolous manner because it comes out of the left field with no time to react. Despite this, the trooper itself has rather weak damage, the most annoying feature is every time it takes damage it teleports to a different location. This is easily countered with half decent positioning. When I encountered it the biggest threat on the field was a Gatekeeper, making these "bosses" extremely underwhelming.  The pacing of the progression is very very bad due to these guys.4) The Final "Boss"The final battle in general is super super underwhelming. Surprisingly few enemies, and the enemies you do get to fight you can basically ignore if you have the chance to kill the Avatars.Basically kill the first avatar, then you just kill the next two avatars as soon as they spawn. The fights prior to that, you ask? Well you get handed a new character "Commander Avatar" which has a massive AOE Void Rift that deals quite good damage, the ability to easily mind control any organic or dealing upwards of 14 damage in a line to enemies. This is beyond your first 6 troopers... So you have 6 really strong troopers and a 7th overpowered one... Yeah guys, totally tough final battle.I don't think a lot needed to be changed in this game to make it okay. Introduce Mutons earlier, introduce Sectoids and Vipers later, and focus more on the simpler enemies early game, the ones that just throw grenades and shoot at you, instead of the ones that grapple/pull/mind control/panic your troopers.Side Note: If anyone is going to tell me that the reason all of the above is okay because "This is XCOM"... Well, you may know how to play XCOM, you may know it can be frustrating and unfair at times, but that does not mean frustrating mechanics should be thrown at new players for the majority of the early game, which can easily feel uncounterable or straight up impossible to deal with. It is not an excuse for badly designed progression/game design.TL;DRIf you are a new player, I can not recommend you to stay further away from this game. XCOM: Enemy Unknown has a much superior progression and a hell of a lot better environment to experiment and learn about the game before it starts throwing insane mechanics in your face.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
												Not recommended for the full price. The set of game features considering what XCOM : EW added to the original game makes it look like a completely dumbed down version  of the first opus.Maybe wait until they add gene troopers, mechs , and the Long War Studios do all the work for them.Other than that, the only thing they ADDED to the game which actually good and fun is the stealth mechanic.So basically you would be paying 50€ for your copy of XCOM 1, with 20% of the gameplay features provided by EU + EW + Long War, only to get the stealth gameplay.Your choice, but basically it isn't worth it for me.I've got 450 hours in XCOM 1 btw, most of it on Long War. I've played this 60H so there is actual gameplay and value for the price. But I'm a huge xcom nerd. Nonetheless, honestly, buy on sale only. I'm fed up with devs removing half the content of the game in their sequels. Where are the MECHS, where are the gene troopers? Why do Psi soldier do not multiclass anymore? So many things you would have to mod to get back the gameplay you are used to. Otherwise nothing really fun is added. The tactical map is a nice idea poorly executed.Level design is perfect though.Basically I spent 60 kinda fun hours on it ( most of it fun, actually, but frustrated by so many poor choices of their part ) but won't be coming back to it. I want to play Long War but with the stealth of XCOM 2.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22, 2016
												Game as a software: This program does not perform well. I have a good gaming laptop but still frame drops constantly. The application sometimes crashes. I have encountered auto-saves that the game cannot load. Game in general: I wish the one calling the shots regarding what to put in the game have played the previous xcoms. The old xcom have more content, more things you can do, more research, more vehicles, more facilities. •	What happened to the archangel suit? •	No more mec trooper•	Missing the laser weapons•	Not enough depth to the normal weapon you use in the beginning•	No more bases across continents•	No more interceptors•	No more base defense (inside the base, where aliens can kill your engineers and scientists)I mean if you want to change some stuff at least replace it with something better. I feel this is a trim down version. And still if the plan is to really trim it down at least make the game kick-♥♥♥ in the sense that it is sleek. But the game as it is far from being sleek. Why do I have to see that useless hologram of the globe every time I want to move my base? And by the way, you keep showing us that but what we can interact with is a map…. So lame… Talking about moving the xcom base. We could assume that the ship would be a big ♥♥♥ ship but how come throughout the game it was only intercepted once, with no damage I tell you! What happened to the big ♥♥♥ ship the aliens have? Only saucers flying around. And even if you fly pass them they would not attack the freaking flying xcom base.I can still say a lot of negative things about this game but to summarize. There is nothing in the game that was impressive. It’s a trim down version of its predecessor. No effort to impress the players. If they say they worked on the graphics, well they currently suck with that frame rate drops. Nothing new, nothing exciting, nothing! I hope they earn a lot from this version so that they could do another one better. Come on guys, if you have to go back to the original game, please do so, there is a wealth of content there, you just need to use that as the base of your content and then improve some. (I still can’t forget that one time I sent an agent via motor bike to an alien site and “Rambo”ed the hell out of the aliens). I miss throwing those light stick to see the aliens… hayz…. Then *just thought of this now* you could have a research for night vision goggles so we don’t have to throw light stick so we can save mother earth while killing the aliens right?! I mean this game is supposed to be human vs aliens but this version doesn’t show enough human tech (if somebody will say because this version is in the future and alien tech is more advance then I would ask if we discarded our technology for alien tech then why does the resistance need to research alien tech again?). Anyway I digress, this is my first review here in steam and it is for a game that I love and played since the 90s and I am saying I feel there could be way more than what was given in this version. A very big room for improvement. Will I buy the next version of the game? hell yes :) but i might not pre-purchase anymore. I thought with the enemy within version being good this would be better but alas it is not, so next time I would not be as excited.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												I'm conflicted on this. I adored Enemy Unknown/Within, and XCOM 2 improves upon those games in many respects. The customization is great, and (fixable) optimization issues aside, it looks amazing. The new takes on old classes makes certain parts of me tingly, and much of the gameplay is sublime.So why the thumb down? Simple. Timers. God... damn... timers...Simply put, I play strategy games to (shock) strategize. If the occasional mission warrants I move fast (bomb diffusal), okay. I didn't mind it in EU/EW, but here it's every freakin' mission. You're constantly encouraged to avoid detection and set up ambushes, while simultaneously having Central yell at you that, unless you touch the magic objective RIGHT F***ING NOW, the world will end. You have one, maaaaybe two turns if you're lucky to set up, and then you gotta go H.A.M. to make it in time.And it continues into the strategic overview as well. You're constantly bombarded with things to do, while being forced to plow through the campaign or be subjected to more aliens than Texas.I can't understand how anyone thought this was going to be a good idea. Some say it was to curb Overwatch, but that could be done by tweaking overwatch range/accuracy/damage. There was no need to take a legitimate mechanic for bomb diffusal or hostage rescue, and impose it on the entire game.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												After having a great experience with XCOM EU/EW, I was eager to get my hands on XCOM 2. I can gladly say that it is a great improvement over its predecessor. Besides a few graphical issues and fps drops, the game itself is fantastic. I have seen people review it badly because of those sole flaws, however, let me assure you that the gameplay, is XCOM refined to greatness. If you liked XCOM EU/EW, prepare to have your soul crushed and prepare for one of the most satisfying games of your life. You should definitely buy it.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												Absolutely amazing game. Just completed the campaign and man it is so much harder than the previous game. If you love EU/EW you will love this sequel. Although it launched with varied performance issues, and some... 'interesting' bugs, the performance is pretty easiliy tweaked and the bugs are not so much game breaking as they are... weird. Mostly visual delays during the alien turn that leave you pondering what is going on until the turn ends and animation catches up and normalness resumes. Deeply rich campaign strategy and very very satisfying tactical combat. The turn counters add just enough pressure to make sure you're not quite comfortable while giving you the time for intelligent decisions and ultimately, victory. Even though about 75% of the missions had timers for me, the ones without the timer still kept me on my toes with the very difficult combat. Literally improved everything we loved about EU/EW and added new features and combat mechanics.Highly highly recommend this game to fans of the previous installment. Though the difficulty has gone up significantly! New players be warned! This is not a relaxing game but a stressful challenge to put your wits to the test! (brutally difficult but very winnable). And oh so satisfying when you obtain victory against overwhelming odds. Looking forward to many playthroughs. STRATEGY GOTY.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
												Almost one of the best games I\'ve ever played, hence why the let down for me is so bad. Like any XCOM game its got some really, too difficult enemies, thats all annoying, but its that horrible challenge that makes you want to keep coming back for more. Its brutal, its unforgiving, and its absolutely fantastic, with one of the most gripping stories I\'ve seen yet in a game.So you ask \'Why is it bad\'. Well, it seem Firaxis made a bit of an oversight. Towards the last couple of missions, the most important ones, it doesnt let you save the game, and there are no autosaves. This would be a good thing as it would force you to make every decision count. So why isnt it. The game crashed. I\'ve lost about 4 hours of gameplay, very important gameplay, that now I\'ll have to do over again. I dont even have a massive problem with the crashing, just the fact that they wouldnt even let me prepare for such an event by saving before hand.Really disappointing. Went from my best game of the year to my most disappointing in 10 minutes.
