content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Let's address the elephant before we push it out of the room.The sheer number of timed missions are a questionable design decision. I'm not entirely against them - it's new, takes some getting used to, and adds a sense of urgency to your missions. Despite how lovingly you remember it, creeping slowly across a map in full overwatch was boring in XCOM:EO. A simple fix would seem to be: start the time when concealment breaks. That way I can position my units accordingly and choose when to begin the countdown.Next is performance. I have a Core i7 and GTX 980 graphics card and the game runs abysmally on high settings. The nice thing about both of these complaints is that they can be patched and modded away.The game is otherwise fantastic. More of what you love about the XCOM series with some new additions. The procedurally-generated randomness is great and I enjoy that no two playthroughs will ever be the same. Looting upgrades and other items in the field is a wonderful touch. I look forward to finishing my first playthrough, and many more to come.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
												I waited until the first "performance patch" was released (it didn't help) to write this review.  I haven't tried any of the mods.tl;dr version: So many great ideas, but the execution and performance issues make XCOM2 unplayable.Good:- The aliens are incredibly interesting.  Most enemies are basically improvements from EU/EW.  Sectoids and Mutons receive massive upgrades from EU/EW, and there are several new enemies that make you really rack your brain on how you are going to combat them.- New twists on some buildings.  The proving ground is fun.  It's mostly a random grab bag of weapons and armor.  The advanced warfare center gives you some pleasant surprises every now and then.- Overwatch AI is improved.  No longer will 5 dudes on overwatch shoot at the dead alien the 1st guy killed.  All successful overwatch shots are useful.- Everything looks pretty good.  The animation is much less cartooney than EU/EW.  - Dodge/Graze mechanic.  Pretty cool when it's in your favor, but heart-breaking when it burns you.- Enemy reinforcements.  They will really screw up your game plan and make you recalculate.  Much improved over the drop-a-thin-man-in-there-and-put-him-on-overwatch paradigm from EU/EW.- Weapon upgrades add another level to squad make-up.  - Psi-warriors are a unique class.  They are bad♥♥♥♥♥..  and probably even overpowered.  No longer just necessary to "take one for the team" in the final cinematic.Neutral:- Stealth ambushes were a good idea.  Triggering enemies with several squad members in overwatch commences a Boondock Saints-esque cascade of bullets.  However, overwatch is much less effective than EU/EW, and I end up following a procedure for conducting ambushes. *yawn*- Lots of turn timers on mission.  They do add to the urgency and difficulty of missions, but generally force your hand most of the time.  - Mission types are basically the same as EU/EW.  Base assaults, terror missions, VIP rescue, destry the device.  A few new tricks, but they definitely took the don't-fix-what-ain't-broke approach.- The Black Market.  It's an evolution of the Grey Market from EU/EW.  The Black Market can be useful, but I just don't get excited about it and it doesn't help out as much as the Grey Market did.Bad:- Performance.  Prior to the recent patch, I should have been able to play on max settings/resolution (including 4k) on both of my rigs as they are waaayyyy beyond the recommended specs.  However, max settings made the framerate drop to gamebreaking levels.  I was able to tweak the settings to make the game playable, but it never looked all that great.  I did not experience crashes before the patch.  THEN THE PATCH WAS BORN.  Post-patch, I experienced 1-3 crashes per hour of play (The last one I suffered occurred on the plane ride home from a terror mission on which only one civilian was killed).  The real insult is that the developer added an "auto settings detector" to help us all play at acceptable framerates.  The auto-detect simply dumbed down settings on my machines AND the framerate was much lower than pre-patch.  Just plain unacceptable- Some missions seem pre-determined.  I loved the difficulty of Long War.  It was transparent and tactile.  You always knew why you were getting screwed, and were generally rewarded by living by the rules of XCOM.  But the rules of XCOM intermittently get flipped upside-down in XCOM2.  I have played several missions where there are a large number of improbable misses (> 85%) that lead me to fail the mission.  Even after save-scumming with an all-new approach, the overwhelming missed shots lead me to believe that the seed is choosing against me.  This leads to an unwanted side-effect of relying HEAVILY on 100% weapons (mainly grenades) and laughing when my guys miss three 90% shots in a row to end a turn.  It's insulting, and eliminates the fun of having a diverse squad.Verdict: There is so much to like, but I can't enjoy it because the few things I hate are so very bad.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21
												Before I start, SPOILER HEAVY REVIEW, although I feel I have good reasons for a negative review for a game I like.I will say that I enjoy XCOM, I have since the first one, and this kind of sadistic gameplay intrigues me. I love it, and I will spend many more hours in it, but there is a reason why I am not going to recommend it, especially over XCOM: Enemy Unknown.I am not going to focus on bugs/crashes/etc, since many of those can be system specific and not necessarily a general thing.1) TutorialThe tutorial is absolute garbage. It teaches you the base mechanics of the game BUT... Here comes a few points.    Point 1: It teaches you to not take cover while overwatching, also it teaches you to overwatch instead of engaging.    Point 2: It teaches you to go into positions where you have no cover.     Point 3: It only gives you a semblance of control, does not allow you to experiment with game mechanics, does not allow you to even try anything yourself, you are stuck on one specific path that will make any decent XCOM player grind their teeth from the decisions the game forces you to make. Probably one of the worst tutorials I have ever personally experienced (XCOM: Enemy Unknown had a tutorial that forced actions on you as well, but it did teach you about decent movement and didn't force you to do actions that were bad unless it got your trooper outright killed right away)2) ProgressionThe progression of enemies in this game is completely crazy, ESPECIALLY if you played the tutorial.If you played the tutorial you have very few decent troopers and you get dumped in to a mission where there will be a Sectoid. For new players being introduced to the game, they have barely finished a tutorial that didn't teach them anything, and they have to deal with a mechanic that can (without actually shooting a trooper) make a trooper inoperable for several rounds (panic), mind control them or make them near useless with a disorient buff... This is the ... "second" mission of the game, and if you did the tutorial you haven't even played one mission yet.Also a few enemies you encounter early on (within the first 6 missions), each having their own frustrating mechanic, especially if you haven't played XCOM before (and many of these mechanics are new to XCOM).ADVENT Stun Lancer: Can move incredibly long distances, which is in stark contrast to ANYTHING! you have encountered so far, rarely if ever shoots and deals an insane amount of damage early game which also has a chance to either stun your troopers (making them inoperable for X amount of actions) or outright knock them unconscious requiring you to carry them out of the mission if it is an evac mission. Despite them being this unique they don't stand out that heavily from ordinary ADVENT Troopers visually making them (especially for new players) harder to make out.Viper: These guys can PULL! your guys to them, and grapple them, making them inoperable until you shoot the Viper. It can BEYOND this shoot an AOE poison that will early game be able to almost kill your troopers. This is guaranteed damage and if you didn't bring a medkit, you are screwed because that is the only way to get rid of it (or finishing the mission)MEC: These guys are not as frustrating as the two others, but they severely limit your flanking abilities since they don't use cover as well as the fact they have 2 armor. The game has not taught you what armor is, or how armor works yet so some players may not have any idea how to deal with it (which will make these guys into bullet sponges early game) They also are the first AOE cover destroying enemies as well.This is within the first 6 missions, and 2 of these are earlier than that. All of these appear earlier than most of their (less frustrating) counterparts in XCOM: Enemy Unknown, screwing the progression of the game heavily.Just these things put together is one of the reasons I would probably never suggest XCOM 2 to a new player. Even more experienced players can get a lot of games ruined in the first couple of missions due to random frustrating control removing mechanics being introduced this early.3) Frustrating Mechanics / Enemy DesignThis ties a little into Progression but XCOM: Enemy Unknown in contrast to XCOM 2 did not introduce a lot of enemies that could outright take control away from you early game, while as I mentioned before this game introduces 2 of them within the first half hour to an hour of game experience. In a game already about RNG it speaks of the bad game design to have so many mechanics to take away the control of your characters (leaving you with less characters to deal with the threat) and some of these mechanics doesn't even have a real counter to them. Besides that I feel that they spent way to much time adding to many abilities on to their enemies due to them lore wise being an "upgrade" to the original troopers. Due to this addition of so many new mechanics to enemies, the enemies that were considered a threat (and didn't really receive an "update") in XCOM: Enemy Unknown are now incredible tame.These include:  Mutons: They are introduced so late into the game that their pitiful 8 health and 1 armor is laughable. A lot of your troops have more than that, and half your characters will be able to oneshot it.  Berserkers: Rarely if ever a true threat, due to it's "frenzy" mechanic. You just shoot it while it is far away, and it kills anything close by, including its own allies.   Avatar: These guys are... super... insanely... underwhelming... They are supposed to be the cool♥♥♥♥♥psionic dude you have to fear, but it gets introduced in a ridicolous manner because it comes out of the left field with no time to react. Despite this, the trooper itself has rather weak damage, the most annoying feature is every time it takes damage it teleports to a different location. This is easily countered with half decent positioning. When I encountered it the biggest threat on the field was a Gatekeeper, making these "bosses" extremely underwhelming.  The pacing of the progression is very very bad due to these guys.4) The Final "Boss"The final battle in general is super super underwhelming. Surprisingly few enemies, and the enemies you do get to fight you can basically ignore if you have the chance to kill the Avatars.Basically kill the first avatar, then you just kill the next two avatars as soon as they spawn. The fights prior to that, you ask? Well you get handed a new character "Commander Avatar" which has a massive AOE Void Rift that deals quite good damage, the ability to easily mind control any organic or dealing upwards of 14 damage in a line to enemies. This is beyond your first 6 troopers... So you have 6 really strong troopers and a 7th overpowered one... Yeah guys, totally tough final battle.I don't think a lot needed to be changed in this game to make it okay. Introduce Mutons earlier, introduce Sectoids and Vipers later, and focus more on the simpler enemies early game, the ones that just throw grenades and shoot at you, instead of the ones that grapple/pull/mind control/panic your troopers.Side Note: If anyone is going to tell me that the reason all of the above is okay because "This is XCOM"... Well, you may know how to play XCOM, you may know it can be frustrating and unfair at times, but that does not mean frustrating mechanics should be thrown at new players for the majority of the early game, which can easily feel uncounterable or straight up impossible to deal with. It is not an excuse for badly designed progression/game design.TL;DRIf you are a new player, I can not recommend you to stay further away from this game. XCOM: Enemy Unknown has a much superior progression and a hell of a lot better environment to experiment and learn about the game before it starts throwing insane mechanics in your face.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2016
												If you want to play XCom, just stick with the first game.  The second game has irritating bugs (you can be spotted when there is no red "spotted" tile), is filled with smoke and mirrors style difficulty (patrols know exactly where you are, so no matter how you approach a battlefield, they will "just happen" to walk in your direction), and just generally feels far more susceptible to random number generated nonsense, which limits actual tactics and preparedness.  XCom 1, meanwhile, had a much better balanced set of mechanics which allowed for tactical preparedness and limited the negative effects of RNG luck.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												I am a new player into the world of XCOM but having seen the hype thought I would give it a go. It looked good.Sadly the looks are where the fun start and end. My personal opinion is that this game is truly utterly awful. I bought it this morning, played 4 hours of it and have now requested a refund as i am stuck on a repeatable and unavoidable bug that completely prevents me from progressing beyond the first mission. I only racked up 4 hours gameplay as I was replaying the first mission to try and get past the bug. The point at which you are tasked with recruiting an engineer and excavating a part of the base results in a screen you cannot get past no matter what you click on and what buttons you press on your keyboard. My only option was to force close the game and try again.Despite this though the game is lacking in so many ways. The most ludicrous is the chance to hit mechanic. I appreciate this is something you develop as you progress in the game but having manouvered my character to point blank range and still only gain a 48% chance of hitting with rifle shots is utterly nonsensical. Time and again I would focus on troop movements to gain a good line of sight only to be presented with a 34% chance to hit or something equally stupid. RNG gone mad makes for missions you know will be successful based on a dice roll rather than your skills in playing. There is online gambling offering better rewards for that sort of uncertainty.I'm an old git and have been playing games for a long long long time - this ranks as one of the worst gaming experiences I have ever encountered. Unless you are a die hard XCOM fan I would avoid this one like the plague it will dissappoint and frustrate in equal measure and there are much cheaper games offering much more enjoyable playability than this.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												Firstly I want to start of by saying this game has worse balancing than the r8 revolver when it was first implemented in CSGO. This will probably cause controvesy as it has in other reviews and there will probably be some fu** wit who comments saying "lower the difficulty", to that fu**cker I want to say "youre a ♥♥♥♥ing idiot" and this is why:On the second "level" (level as in ground team mission) in the game theres an enemy (sectoid) with a mind control ability that lasts as long as its alive, a panic ability that causes you to lose a turn with a trooper and cause him to do stupid♥♥♥♥♥♥and an ability that lets it reanimate the dead. You honestly cant say that is balanced. It also has a lot of health and unless you score a crit youre looking at 2 - 3 hits to take it out. 2 or 3 hits that are hard enough to score since youre out numbered, youre under "staffed" because a troop has been mind controlled and its in cover. Even if you score 1 hit it will most likely move and then you have to regain ground again.The third level the enemy have "ADVENT stun lancers". Their job is too run at you from dash range(about as far as you can see. The max distance you can move at) and attack with melee. The melee has a chance too 1 shot if it doesnt 1 shot it has a chance to stun you for a turn. The melee attack can also go through walls and floors. Don't even bother about overwatch(An ability that lets your troop cover an area and engage any moving enemies there), when youre on your 3rd mission and your troopers are still basically cannon fodder when you overwatch 90% they will miss at a target at dash range. Its not a matter of difficulty its a matter of balance. I've beaten enemy within on impossible using smart tactics, this game however just seems more random than strategy. No matter how you position yourself youll get screwed over by a sectoids mind control or by a shock troop running in and killing or pacifying a trooper. Honestly I dont care enough to play the game far enough to see if it gets better. The mutons seem average enough and so do the snake people. The next thing I wanna go over is the timed missions. Some of the timed missions literally have just enough time for you to reach the objective even if you dash all the way. This means if you fight you keep your troopers alive but fail the mission or visa versa. I believe they will probably get patched. If not there are already a ton of mods on the workshop but it bothered me enough to mention. Some people are complaining at the amount of timed missions but I'm fine with that personally.I have around 400 games in my library but none of the ones I have played have this much imbalance. I enjoy a challenge but when its more difficult on rookie than enemy within was on impossible you know somethings up. I'm just going to bide my time until mods or patches come out.Pros:Graphics are niceNew concealment system is pretty neatNew hacking mechanicModding supportReplayabilityCampaign map is much better than enemy unknownCons:Optimization as of this date is pretty terrible (will be patched most likely).Really bad enemy balancingTurn timer missions/ not enough time on turn timersAiming angles are often reaaaally dumbBad difficulty settingsTL:DR Has some really cool new ideas to expand on from enemy unknown/ within but its let down by numerous factors mostly to do with balancing. Could be easily fixed, mods may save this game.If you want to tell me I'm a dumbass then comment and Ill tell you that you're wrong XD

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2016
												First things first!I am a huge fan of the xcom series! I loved the last game for reviving the series and giving you immense opportunities and ways to play the game. XCOM 2 is all that just better!Why the thumbs down?It is the constant time preassure and overwhelming enemy  presence especially in early game. I like the concept of not having tons of time in a mission. If it's behind enemy lines it is realitstic that you just have a short window before they send reinforcements. Just having ten turns for extracting a hostage (even if you manage to stay concealed until you free him) is just not enough. What I loved about the xcom series so far is you could carefully position your soldiers to engage the enemy and in firefights retreat to a tactically better position to flank.But with that turn limitations before the mission fails you are forced to take unnecessary risks and the enemy (sometimes 8-12 enemies) swarms you, flanks you through their numbers. Also very annoying are the sectoids which seem to have become bigger and easily panick or mind control your rookie soldiers. They also can revive their and your fallen soldiers as psy zombies.Combined with the low stats and equipment of your rookie soldiers, this makes it a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to play those missions.The game has improved in all other aspects, the story is amazing and it feels home on the computer. I would have wished for an option to deactivate some (not all) of the turn limitations in order to get the option to take some more turns to cope with the enemy.Very sad that they limit you so much and for me it adds a lot of difficulty in the early game that is just frustrating and unnecessary.I will keep playing and adapt my tactics but non the less it's a thumbs down for the game. :(

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												XCOM2 is an evolution of XCOM EU ideas, refining classes and abilities as well as adding a lot of new stuff.Nearly all abilities and items are usable in every mission, class builds are more versatile and fun, especially when boosted by the wide variety of items that are semi-blindly researched in Proving Grounds. To improve classes even more they have a random chance of getting the ability of another one when promoted thanks to Advanced Warfare Center - making some of your soldiers truly unique (and painful to lose).Maps are randomly generated this time, armor system is refined (not a bonus to HP but lowering damage instead, can be bypassed/shredded by grenades, psi powers and some weapons), soldiers can stay out of combat for weeks when wounded and even become shaken, being more susceptible to panic and enemy mind control - so you have to take care of them more than before.Weapons can be upgraded with gear bought from black market or dropped by aliens, soldier stats can be amplified by stims and various types of ammo and vests.XCOM2 also saw the addition of melee combat and concealment system granting you the ability to sneak up and ambush aliens. Aliens themselves are much more varied now, with more unique skills. Since you can mind control organic enemies and take control of robotic ones through hacking - combat becomes quite interesting.At the campaign level aliens have won and you are in charge of last remnants of XCOM organization fighting the occupation together with resistance. It's a race against time more so than before, with Doomsday clock ticking and you can only slow it down. This time there's truly never enough resources for everything so often you will find yourself literally running on fumes and will have to compromise.As a result some missions are timed now, which can be tough at first but becomes a lot more managable as your force becomes more skilled and on par with alien technology. This however rids the game of the infamous overwatch cheating that made the game easy in XCOM EU.And with all that said - there's a LOT more to see in this game that is impossible to mention here.

content:
Posted: February 29, 2016
A bug from the patch 2 weeks ago introduced a memory leak. It hasn't been patched since. I haven't been able to play the game.As of the most recent update, the game is now playable. I've even noticed an increase in performance! Wow! Still not optimal, but it doesn't really dip into single frames as often, and crashes are way less frequent. Others are reporting more performance issues though. YMMV.Game is pretty damn fun. XCOM 2 is more streamlined than Enemy Unknown: Stripped down base management, removal of aircraft, and there are no longer country-specific panic bars, but instead a single global one.That's not to say that they haven't added in anything new. Some missions will start you off in a stealth-based concealment status. Instead of groups of enemies gaining a turn as soon as you spot them, they'll only trigger once you enter their line of sight (which, once you spot them, will be displayed on the map when you move your mouse around. Unfortunately, this is currently bugged, and enemies may be able to spot you outside of the visible zone). I really like this concept, but generally the missions you start in this condition will have a lower turn counter. It makes sense for some missions, but it's a slap in the hand to give you this freedom and being unable to utilize it. On the bright side, there are some mods that change the way the timer works.And mods for just about everything else, actually. XCOM 2 is miles ahead of Enemy Unknown when it comes to mod support. If you go on to the Steam workshop (or elsewhere, if you prefer), and you'll find new classes, cosmetics, weapons, enemies, gameplay tweaks, the works. Making this game so mod friendly may be the best change to XCOM 2. Firaxis definitely deserves some praise for their improvements. The only downside is that if you decide you no longer want a mod during a campaign, you won't be able to use that save. On the bright side, there's a mod that lets you bypass that! (though your save may have issues or make your game crash). It's just such a damn shame how buggy this game is. There are situations like this where I feel like I should have a flank, but instead the game disagrees[i.imgur.com] and says the alien is in full cover. Here's one where I'm right beside this guy[i.imgur.com]. The inverse also seems to happen- flanks at absolutely incomprehensible angles. Happens to both me and the AI. Some bugs I feel guilty about is stuff like this. That target is behind 4 walls.[i.imgur.com] It's not usually that extreme, but it happens more often than you'd think.My first playthrough was on Veteran. The global crisis meter was one bar away from being filled because I was pretty dumb with my build order (PROTIP build a Resistance comms facility early in your base). I was able to completely erase it in about a month's time, and they never remotely recovered from it. It was pretty much a win state for the final two months: I was just waiting for more tech to develop and only a handful of missions popped up. Very anti-climatic compared to how hectic the early months can be.I really like this game. Should you get this game? Definitely. When the Game of the Year edition is released. The bugs are still present and they'll likely be focusing more effort on making DLC (because this is a 2K game, of there's a season pass). May as well get a cheaper, less buggy game at a later point in time with all the DLC included and better, refined mods from the community.I'll change my recommendation to a yes when I can honestly tell others to pick the game up. Until then, stay away.PS why the ♥♥♥♥ can Advent Officers move, use mark (increases enemy accuracy against one of your soldiers) and fire in the same ♥♥♥♥ing turn?PPS bring two grenadiers, get them Heavy Ordnance, Volatile Mix, and Salvo. Develop them heavy armor. Give one gas and the other acid grenades. Blow up every single wall, floor, and ceiling.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												XCOM2 is an evolution of XCOM EU ideas, refining classes and abilities as well as adding a lot of new stuff.Nearly all abilities and items are usable in every mission, class builds are more versatile and fun, especially when boosted by the wide variety of items that are semi-blindly researched in Proving Grounds. To improve classes even more they have a random chance of getting the ability of another one when promoted thanks to Advanced Warfare Center - making some of your soldiers truly unique (and painful to lose).Maps are randomly generated this time, armor system is refined (not a bonus to HP but lowering damage instead, can be bypassed/shredded by grenades, psi powers and some weapons), soldiers can stay out of combat for weeks when wounded and even become shaken, being more susceptible to panic and enemy mind control - so you have to take care of them more than before.Weapons can be upgraded with gear bought from black market or dropped by aliens, soldier stats can be amplified by stims and various types of ammo and vests.XCOM2 also saw the addition of melee combat and concealment system granting you the ability to sneak up and ambush aliens. Aliens themselves are much more varied now, with more unique skills. Since you can mind control organic enemies and take control of robotic ones through hacking - combat becomes quite interesting.At the campaign level aliens have won and you are in charge of last remnants of XCOM organization fighting the occupation together with resistance. It's a race against time more so than before, with Doomsday clock ticking and you can only slow it down. This time there's truly never enough resources for everything so often you will find yourself literally running on fumes and will have to compromise.As a result some missions are timed now, which can be tough at first but becomes a lot more managable as your force becomes more skilled and on par with alien technology. This however rids the game of the infamous overwatch cheating that made the game easy in XCOM EU.And with all that said - there's a LOT more to see in this game that is impossible to mention here.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
												I want to love this game.At it's core, the game is pretty good. Pretty solid base to work off of, it's pretty fun. Well what's the problem then?XCOM Enemy Within exists. Not even that, the Long War mod exists. The game feels like a step back from the first. There are less options, less enemies, and less depth. It feels like they took out a lot more then they actually added. Perhaps my biggest issue is that a good majority of the missions are timed in one way or another. Timed missions aren't bad, but too many of them is. It restricts tactics, which is not something you want to do for half the missions.I'll be interested to see what DLC adds, if it adds anything of interest. But when overall it feels like a step back from vanilla Enemy Within, and with the Long War mod in XCOM 1 which essentially transforms it into almost a new game, it just doesn't feel worth the price as is.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2016
												Terrible, frustrating, and unfair are the words that come to mind most when I think of XCOM 2. I loved XCOM Enemy Within and have several play throughs logged yetI loathe the sequel: XCOM 2. The game lacks the charm and novelty of the first. The premise that you are a Guerilla makes the Command Center portion of the game annoyingly tedious. The game literally won't let you finish doing anything in one go. It'll send you to a region to "investigate" and you won't even get to finish your investigation before it throws a time sensitive event at you.  You're going to be juggling a lot of♥♥♥♥♥♥instead of having a straight forward experience.Enemies are too powerful and have too many abilities. Mutliple enemies have the ability to perform several attacks in one go. Advent Stun Lancers can take out multiple soldiers by yielding them unconcious even though your troops have 3/4th health left. Tongues from Vipers literally travel through multiple walls to snag one of your soldiers away from your group. This is pure LAZINESS from the developer. Line of sight defintely affects your own hit chances but apparently does not effect the AI. Not to mention that hit chances for the most part are made much more predictably unpredictable. I've never missed so many 70% or more shots before, and this is a regular thing. You might miss these at crucial times and the FREQUENCY of missing these high percentage shots is incredibly high.  Also the route your soldier takes to get to an assigned destination is bizzare. For example your soldier could go around a building and up a ladder to get to a particular destination. Yet instead of using a logical route your soldier will smash through two glass windows, alert a group of enemies to reach that same destination.This game is literally the most frustrating thing ever. For the most part, I really enjoy challenging and tough games. Yet this game doesn't reward you AT ALL for your tactics, caution, or experience. I'm over 20 hours in and I've started a new play through with my new knowledge of the game. I've made no progress in improving my mission performance as the game doesn't reward you tactics. It's just a random pile of ♥♥♥♥ YOU. I wish I could get a refund and I don't recommend this game.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 18, 2016
												!!!SPOILER!!! This might be a good TBS, but to me it's not a good Xcom. On the one side, you have a surprisingly restrictive mission design which, unlike older Xcom titles, won't let you experiment with different tactics and strategies much. It's either "you're stealthy and have 10 turns to interact with some target" or "the enemy knows you're here, kill them". You can't do fun stuff anymore like mindcontrolling and disarming the entire alien force, drive them all together, let your noobiest soldier throw in a nuke and watch him getting a crapload of XP. And those base defense missions are just a joke. Why not give us missions INSIDE the base where you actually have to DEFEND!!!! It worked over 20 years ago?! Laziness? Savings? Also the terror missions: almost all the civilians got killed. Rating: excellent. What the...?! On the other side, you have a ridiculous amount of overpowered stun mechanics and crowd control, which allow you to cheese all the way through the game once you figure it out (at least on normal difficulty, couldn't find the motivation to try the harder modes). The Flashbang e.g. can be upgraded to the radius of a tactical nuke if you train heavy gunners accordingly (prepare for heavy lag tho), then there are smoke greandes, Gremlins, suppression mechanics, overwatch and of course psi (which you really don't need in Xcom2 since all the cheeper stuff is good enough and available earlier). If you're not braindead, most of the time the enemies won't even have a chance to shoot back. I lost 3 soldiers in the entire game, and that was on the first couple of missions, before I got flashbangs. There are aliens in this game which I don't even know what their abilities are because they never had the opportunity to show them. In older Xcoms, you had aliens snipe you out of the darkness all the way across the map before you could even see them and you had to use your brain to advance. In Xcom1+2, you will mostly find groups of 3 enemies, which first get aggro'd once you get close, do their little freak show intro and then run for cover before they can do anything at all... and before getting stunned. That's just ridiculous and gets old quite fast. You could at least make them do a funny dance every once in a while, to round up the circus clown experience... ;)Then there's the underwhelming graphics and performance. I really don't see why this game is so demanding, it doesn't look much better than the prequel which didn't have state of the art graphics to begin with, but at least it runs smoothly! In Xcom2, even the cutscenes can be laggy, and I have a well maintained, powerful gaming PC with a GTX 1080. Guess it's just another poorly optimized console port. That would explain the horrible user interface as well, but I won't even start on that...And last but not least, there's this generic story of shadow government, the end of humanity, rebellion network, guerilla war... "oh, and the prequel never happend, the aliens won, there's no terror from the deep. We wanted to do a new perspective.." - You started promising with the xcom 1 remake, 2k, but this is close to heresy. I think you're getting too cocky. Remember: The prequel was a success a for you because it was based on a legendary game and KIND OF convinced the old fans... when I buy Xcom, I accept anything less then Xcom! This is not Xcom enough. Sorry.Positive things: - nice soundtrack - reaper ability - bought it in a bundle with the excellent steam controller.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												There are enough reviews our there on the performance of the game and how dodgy it can be.  There are reviews detracting the pace of the game and the forced time limits in the missions.  For those users who complain about the time limits of the missions think on this.  You are the resistance, you are deep in enemy territory and they have the advantage.  The game does a great job on pushing that on to the player.  You get the strong feel of being the underdog more so then in the pervious titles.  That being said this is where I start to have a problem with the game and the developers and the course this game took.What do I mean by this well lets start with the fact the game is 20 years later.  The resistance has been fighting for years against Advent and the aliens.  So why in the name of all that is holy am I still starting the game off with your typical rifles?  WHY has nothing in the pervious war carried over?  In what universe would a 20 year resistance that had some advanced weapons at the end of the last game AND genetic modifications be reduced to the starting point of X-Com EW.Does anyone else feel this is just a slap to the player?  Where is the intense story?  I spent 20 minutes just trying to find out exactly what happened at the end of the last game and I have gotten nothing that actually makes any sense.  Advent took over the aliens attacked and took over.  Really so what the heck happened to X-Coms war against the aliens and the launch on their home planet?  Why are we stuck with nothing at the start? No Psionics no Gauss no nothing we are basically naked against a enemy that has evolved in 20 years and X-Com has not evolved?  I can not believe this as realistic. The game so far is good but I am feeling let down by this game.  Lets be honest X-Com the LW makes X-Com better than this.  As far as games go I give this a 7/10 for graphics and feel but I have to give it a thumbs down still.*Additional Note here that has me a little annoyed as a modder, programmer, and a gamer.  Upon reviewing the game files at length I noticed within the game code alot of notes and options laid out for development of the game.  Why are these not live, why are they sitting there unpolished?  Simple because the developers and company in general don't give a dang about the players.  They want others to finish the work for them like Long War Studios.  IF anyone cares to look carefully they will see long war published the mods in December of 2015 for this game.  So not only do they get the first jump on putting mods out there they have have had the game files for over a month, have completed some in game tweeks the dev team should have done and are well ahead of any modder who now looks to tackle an advanced mod for this game.  Way to go on the developers and publishers of this game.  As a customer and fan of this series you have lost my bussiness.  Simply because of the tactics played with this one game, and if this is the writing on the wall for the future of gaming well gaming will no longer be a secondary pastime but not a pasttime at all.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												To clarify recommendation, I'm on the fence.  If you're into Xcom.. Buy it.  If you're not. Don't.As far as a follow on goes, it's good.  Good idea, quite a basic storyline, but it's fairly involving.The missions after awhile become quite samey.  But they're fun to complete.The big let down for me is enforced gameplay and timed missions.   I prefer open non linear games.  Xcom 1 was non linear, sure you have to take out aliens, do missions etc but it wasn't forced on you.In Xcom2 You spend a few days gathering intel, then a few days picking up supplies(money) then you're given a mission, which you can't ignore doing so looses you the game. In fact you can't really ignore any of the missions or you'll either loose the game outright or you'll loose the county you've spent a week getting. Then there's the avatar project, which even if you hold every country in the world, can still be completed by the aliens.  Your hand is forced throughout the game and during missions via the timer, forcing you to make moves you'd never make without the timer.  Forcing you to rush and loose essentially.  The game world is excellent, the ai in general is very good, sure there's issues with line of sight and some cosmetic glitches but overall the "idea" of the game is superb.It is just let down by poor balancing, poor performance issues and mostly by poor design.I've beaten the game twice on veteran difficulty.  I lost maybe 2-3 soldiers in each game.  I don't mind loosing soldiers if I'm outplayed, but at times the game just seems to decide that you've lost, it's predetermined this and there is nothing to you can to stop it.Is it value for money? Sure.  I expect with time at least by summer, when the dlc's are introduced it'll be patched and updated.  Will I still be playing it then.. I doubt it.If xcom 1 had random maps, intelligent ambush and overwatching, the ability to carry wounded soldiers there would really have been no need to even release xcom 2.   It's really just the same game with added insult.Games aren't about being frustrated and bored they're about having fun and winning. Xcom 2 is about loosing, it's about not getting to do what you want to do when you want to do it.   The physical game is replayable, but do I want to play it again and again. Nope.  There's just too many annoying mechanics in the game.  Where there's a great idea, it's just poorly implimented or they clearly, just don't care.7/10 I really tried to like this game, but overall, after everything, I just can't.  Everytime I think of something good about it, I remember 5 bad things.*Edit*I hoped the dlc would add more to the game, but it hasn't.  Missions that should appear in mid or late game are appearing almost at the very start, pitting you against insanely powerful boss aliens and you just don't stand a chance.   Without some heavy modding of the dlc to reduce the hitpoints of these bosses, the dlc is worthless.  The added weapons rubbish.   Essentially it's a joke dlc, it's insulting.   Jake Soloman should be fired from firaxis for making this mess.

												I did not enjoy this game. Currently im submitting for a refund. This game is not BAD, it may not run well on all PC's but this is a game you need to KNOW that you want to play it. It isnt a game to go, "eh, idk, looks alright." then spend $60. (IMO) The NPC's kinda wander around and make no sense to why they go to certain places. The first two levels, i had multiple people die on me. Im probably just terrible at this game but the hit chance it says in game is completely inaccurate. if its not, then i had the WORST luck in this game. The game fails to ease you into this style of gameplay. it just throws you in and says deal with it. If you KNOW this is a game you will like and you have played others in the past then go ahead. Apparently, the base management is alot more streamlined making you be able to get to combat quicker. The graphics for the game on ultra are kind of sub-par. Honestly, mid combat looks better than some of the cinematics. Which isnt a bad thing, it just should speak for how bad some of the cinematics are. TL;DRDon't buy it unless you KNOW you will love it. If you aren't sure youll love it, get the older version. It wont be as much of a risk.Have a powerful PC if you wanna run it on high.

												i've been playing this game most of today and from what ive seen this is what i've collected:pros:- its an xcom game- introduces many new features such as the concealment system which allows for you to set up ambushes and such- plenty of new enemies we have never seen before (also as the game progresses the enemies you have already encountered change)- this xcom has a larger emphases on the story- TONS of character customization- the map is great and the travelling base is as well- dark events are a ton of fun (for those of you who dont know dark events are things that happen in the game that have negative affects on your operation like being pursued by a ufo or enemies raiding your supply lines)- this game (in my opinion) offers a greater challenge to players who just enjoy having their crap kicked out of themcons:- there are some graphical glitches that can occur, mostly when you are in buildings and it shows you the wrong floor- this game could use some more optimizationoverall: this game is great fun and offers plenty of challenges for strategy lovers like myself9/10

												This game is literally a ♥♥♥♥ing jokeProbability doesn't work the way it should. I should find a debug mode to check what the actual rolls are, because 70-80% is closer to 30-40% some of the time, and 50-60% most of the timeIt's not that I have a problem with risk management strategy. Like playing monopoly but with enemies almost never missingApart from sometimes when the enemies can't hit anything for a turn or two, even when flanking you at point blank... And also sometimes shots can never miss for you and your encounters run perfectly....? And now I have no idea what the hell is going on with the RNG. It's like playing monopoly on acidAND ALL THE MISSIONS BAR 4 TYPES OR SO ARE ON TURN TIMERSTHE CAMPAIGN IS ON A TIMERAND A FEW MISSIONS DON'T LET YOU LOOT ITEMS AND WHETHER YOU GET THOSE MISSIONS AS OPPOSED TO ONES YOU CAN LOOT IS ALSO ENTIRELY RANDOMTL;DR: The dice roller is broken and displays random values of what the probability of things happening actually is, though they did make some improvements on the base game....And also everything is on a timer

content:
Posted: October 22, 2016
												I have been an avid X Com fan since the 2d version. This one is absolutely great. The graphics are good and overall strategy to the game is great. My biggest gripe is that the Veteran/Normal difficulty is insanely hard compared to its predecessors. It's difficult in a way that makes it more luck than actual strategy. All the strategy in the world on the Veteran setting will not  aid you as it 95% luck and 5% strategy. The enemies will score critical hits and kills on you in no time on Veteran while on rookie you can get really lucky and stand out in the open and they will miss you. I think it's best to start on Veteran and play through as far as you can multiple times and then play on rookie once you decide to swallow your pride. I peronsally started over on Veteran 7 times before I finally just wanted to see the story. There is an awesome story to this game but you won't see it on Veteran unless you want to reload multiple times. All in all beside the luck variables it's a great game worth playing.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2016
												It's incredibly much like its predecessor, adding very little and mildly remixing or removing a lot of aspects that made Enemy Within such a balanced spread of fun and depth of strategy.  The ship's room-building strategy feels incomplete and profoundly unrewarding, basically a chore.  One room type seems to exist for the sake of a single mission (ship defense), without a clue that it's a one-off, so you can easily waste time and money building it in anticipation of a repeat which never comes.The story is PURE face-palm.  I was transfixed by the generic awfulness of the ending, I thought perhaps it was a parody of some kind, but the game takes itself far too seriously.Bugs also abound - enemies that do nothing except watch you shoot at them turn after turn until they're dead, and soldiers that sometimes can't move.  I'd swear one or two of the soldier advanced skills basically do nothing.Graphically it's mediocre and not much of a step up from its predecessor.  Outside of cutscenes, character lips don't move even if they're talking and looking right at you.  Creature designs are weak, partly being meh variations on its predecessor, partly being super-generic (sectopod!), and in one or two cases completely laughable (hi, breasty-snake!).Pick up Enemy Within for a cheaper, extremely similar but superior strategy experience.  Skip this one and wait for the inevitable XCOM 3.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												Hello.Xcom 2 is fun, there is no denying it and that is probably the only reason why it has achieved so many positive reviews. What the reviews all seem to ignore are the incredible number of bugs and general instability of the game. Please find below my systems specs, a list of bugs which i have encountered and the relative frequency at which they fudge up my experience.Windows 10Gtx Titan x SC editioni7 3770k @ 4.3ghz16gb ddr 31tb samsung evo ssd960gb sandisk ssd1. Game crashing to the point that my pc either restarts itself or I have to hard restart. The game crashes 90% of the time i play it, this is not an exaggeration.2. Very poor performance - the fps are all over the place, the game is way more demanding than it should be - relative to how it looks and the amount of action taking place at any given point.3. My soldiers or the enemy shooting each other through solid cover and other line of sight obscuring objects.4. Action cam showing bullets actually hitting the enemy and then registering as a miss.5. Sound bug where only the music remains and all other effects are not played or are very muted.6. Stuck animations, i.e. the constricted animation not ending after constriction has been released.When Batman AK and BF4 launched they both released in better shape than this game and were torn to pieces by the media and gamers alike, somehow it feels like Firaxis have gotten away with it and I have no idea why. It is incredibly disrespectful to your fanbase to expect payment for such a poor quality release; goodwill doesnt come easy and it feels like Firaxis need a reality check.Bottom line - avoid hours of frustration and dont buy it until they stop alpha testing their game and fix it.

Posted: January 30
												I believe that the somewhat lower reviews for this game, comparing with the previous one, are just fair. This is simply not as good as the previous XCOM. It has a lot of performance issues, incredible long loading times even on SSD, and that 720p resolution looks simply awful - don't buy unless you can play in Full HD. There were some gameplay changes that made no sense: why to remove the pistols (except for snipers) ?, while others were well done: overwatching shots are not all spend on the first target that moves, like in the first game. Same thing for history. It wasn't as interesting for me as the one from the first game, but yet, they deserve credit for introducing variety and not making an entire equal game. Now the aliens control Earth, and our base is a airship that moves around the planet, which obviously also affects gameplay and gives a refreshed strategy experience.Another big difference is the difficult level. The previous XCOM was difficult, but this one is even worse. I played the previous one in Ironmode, but this one I had to use a lot of save and load "cheat" just not to get crushed, and I'm not sure if I even want to try Ironmode. However, the special missions are easier on this one (didn't need to load and save on neither and no soldiers lost - not even close). The base defense one was a piece of cake (while on the previously one was VERY difficult), and the final mission was not very challenging. Normal missions were way more difficult.Oh, btw, timed missions suck.But overall, it's still a very good game, because it's still the XCOM formula, with great mechanics and great gameplay.

Posted: February 11, 2016
												I would say overall I recommend this game, calls back to the old games in many ways. Fun engaging, flexibility in manuvering your characters, as as well as specific and general skills associated with classes makes the engagements fun and interesting.  It is also a beautiful game.However; the game is a bit buggy, and suffers from framerate dips. I have a 4.2 ghz 5820k 16GB ddr4 2667mhz, 980GTX and i was getting sometimes 15-30 fps at times. That is inexcusable. Combine that with the occasional graphical glitch or black screen with the UI overlay "alien activity" with sound the only indicator the game did not crash.Would I recommend it? Yes and no. Yes in the fact that its a good successor to the other xcom games, fun, interesting and engaging, deep complex combat, skills, and characters, challenging depending on the setting you put it at(set it at verteran or above be prepared to reload the game lol). And then No, for the bugginess of the game. I would say if you are willing to put up with the bugs, errors, and performance issues; Go for it, you won't be sorry. It is a great purchase. But for me I got a refund and I will come back to it when a patch or 2 resolves the issues plaguing it right now.

content:
Posted: October 22, 2016
												I have been an avid X Com fan since the 2d version. This one is absolutely great. The graphics are good and overall strategy to the game is great. My biggest gripe is that the Veteran/Normal difficulty is insanely hard compared to its predecessors. It's difficult in a way that makes it more luck than actual strategy. All the strategy in the world on the Veteran setting will not  aid you as it 95% luck and 5% strategy. The enemies will score critical hits and kills on you in no time on Veteran while on rookie you can get really lucky and stand out in the open and they will miss you. I think it's best to start on Veteran and play through as far as you can multiple times and then play on rookie once you decide to swallow your pride. I peronsally started over on Veteran 7 times before I finally just wanted to see the story. There is an awesome story to this game but you won't see it on Veteran unless you want to reload multiple times. All in all beside the luck variables it's a great game worth playing.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												XCOM 2 is a great leap forward, bringing a classic franchise to par with all the new AAA titles coming out in 2016. Everything that was annoying in the first "new" XCOM was fixed or removed, and anything that was awesome was improved even further. From basic combat mechanics, through incredible character customisation (which made me actually care for my soldiers) and great range of both familiar and new enemies. The game is a gem to every turn-based strategy lover, and its graphical fidelity surpasses many mainstream first person shooters (and every console game in existence). With interesting (but not too deep) plot, and immersive gameplay XCOM drags you into a world dominated by so-called "Elders" - an acient alien race wandering through the galaxy, conquering countless worlds in pursuit of new spiecies to "cure". You ever get this "one more turn" feeling?Then prepare for the new "one more mission" complusive disorder, cause XCOM won't just let you leave.XCOM 2 is a must-have for any strategy fans, and DLCs add a little bit of content (not a huge lot, by no means neccessary to fully enjoy the game itself, but provide some re-play value).

content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												It pains me to write this, considering that I'm a very huge fan of Enemy Unknown. I confess that I have not played any of the other titles, but that's an irrevelant point. While the core mechanics and gameplay are solid, as well as nice visual, I cannot recommend the game in its current state. As noted, there are many instances of hiccups and awkward in-game delays. For example, after a unit is killed, there is a rather lengthy pause. I also experienced clipping/invisible enemies on the map. Some of these issues are not entirely gamebreaking though, but it is rather jarring. The pre-mission loading screen takes too long, and if you read the other reviews, you'll find out more issues. It also doesn't help that the chance to hit relies entirely on RNG. I'm not sure where to begin. But the aim/hit system is incredibly inconsistent. Throughout the majority of the game, I lost count how many "misses" I experienced on our end. My sharshooter has missed plenty of "90% hit" shots. I also notice that enemies such as Vipers (from across the map) have better firing on my team than vice versa. I'm also not sure how the "positioning/aiming" system actually works, but there were instances where I would come around a covering, only to find that I would have a less than 70% chance of killing an EXPOSED enemy a few tiles ahead of me. I also notice that the game really throws everything at you from the get-go. More often than not, you'll be stuck with rookie soldiers on your first playthrough. I love playing tactically, and spamming my Overwatch just to be sure, but these time-based missions force you to rush against the constant assault by the enemy. It wouldn't be so bad, but they throw in these Sectoids of whom have an extreme high range of panicking/mind controlling your squad. There is certainly an unforgiving pace, but only for the wrong reasons. The first game had a perfect balance and pace, but this just seems to really throw the nuke at you when you're not careful. If it weren't for the mods adding a support class and allowing benched soldiers XP, I probably wouldn't have gotten as far as I did. Not only does the game need a technical patch, they really need to reevaluate some of the balancing in the enemies and allow current players some breathing room. I pity the ironmen out there.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												First thing you need to know, combat mechanics are pretty much copied from part 1. Same infuriating, pre-calculated RNG, same LoS issues. I'm not sure if there is flying armor in this one, but I bet it will be just as horrible as i remember it from EU.Second thing, the game is stupidly hard right out of the gate. You are playing bunch of hobos fighting alien military (with borderline cheating skills sometimes), and it will make you want to throw the monitor out of the window. Once you manage to claw your way to better gear and ranks, things will get more enjoyable. You will still get horribly wiped, but at least you will be able to return the favour.Technical issues are present, but they don't affect the gameplay, and in general don't make me want to tear my eyes out. They will be patched anyway.Notorious timers, while annoying, aren't too stressful - you can easily finish them with 3-4 turns left if you play aggresively. Global map timer, while intimidating, for now behaves pretty much as panic levels in previous game (including reverts).With all those things said, game improved in pretty much every aspect. Economy is more interesting, soldier progression is hugely improved. Fighting is definetely more "interesting" as well, for better or worse. Most of problems are either temporary, or inherent to the series. Highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2016
												When I decided to write a review for this game, I had to decide wether to evaluate the quality of the game, or my experience of it. I decided to do both, but only write about my experience at the end (and not a lot of it). Because quality is less subjective than experience, I will go through the quality of the game first. I have roughly 1300 hours played on XCOM 2012, and perhaps 150 hours played on XCOM 2. I believe that should be enough to make a decent evaluation.The graphics are cartoony in its nature, with very basic shadow and modeling in general for a modern game. There are nice animations, though some are exaggerated (mostly rangers), and a lot of clipping issues. The air of the game is interesting, but very different from XCOM 2012, with a lot less creepy environments and a lot more clean shadowless surfaces.The game has an odd pacing build up, where the first parts of the game is much harder than the later parts. This was an issue in XCOM 2012, and it has not been addressed in this sequal. Quite the opposite, the game is even less forgiving now than it has ever been. Beside the odd pacing (which has no place in a modern game), some missions are badly built. As an example: there are missions where you are supposed to protect a certain device from being destroyed. In the early parts of the game, this device will last the onslaught of aliens for half a dozen rounds or more. In the latter parts of the game, you can end up being unable to reach the device in any way, before it's been destroyed. To be specific, these missions require you to move to the device, which may take several rounds, and the device may be destroyed in round 1, making the mission an autofail mission. That is simply bad game design. Fortunatley, there are mods in the workshp that takes care of such issues, but one has to observe that if players have to spend free time "fixing" a game, then the game was poorly made. These issues are accelerated by most missions being on a timer, giving you less time to make tactical choices that you prefer. Again: there are mods removing these constraints. But as I said, if a player made mod has to fix your game, then it was a bad game.LOS issues have not been addressed since XCOM 2012, and are in some cases worse in this iteration. Pods (groups) of aliens will spot you through concrete roofs, walls and floors, in spite of not having any abilities listed that would allow them to do so (humans will also spot you through roofs, walls and floors). There is a tool in the game, a small crosshair, which tells you if you can hit your opponent from a new vantage point. But the tool is also bugged and will give you false reports. Destruction of environment (such as razing a wall to the ground) may have the counter intuitive effect of making the target, who is now standing in the open, invisible to someone who previously had LOS. Aliens sometimes clip from one place to another, they fail to trigger overwatch shots even though they should. At times they are immune to grenades in spite of the in game tools telling you they were hit. Other times, your abilities will not function, or their effects will be ignored by the aliens, making it a curious gamble to use them.I could go on for some time, listing bugs. A quick google on "XCOM 2 bugs" will net you long lists of bugs, several which will ruin a mission (and on higher difficulties, a ruined mission may mean a ruined campaign) and none which are preventable by the game designers. Some features cannot be used properly. Example: The game features an ironman save, which means there is always just one save, and you have to own up to your mistakes. But the feature, much like in XCOM 2012, is unusable since the game is laced with so many bugs. If you are subject to a bug and the round ends, the game will save the results of the bug. The only way to prevent it is to force quit via task manager, which you as a player should not have to do.XCOM 2012 used a type of RNG called LCG, which is an obsolete and generally very bad type of RNG. The RNG produces bits of which some are more random, and some are less random. Both XCOM 2012 and XCOM 2 uses the least random bits. That means the game is prone to very long streaks of similar numbers. This in turn means that while a lot of rage towards XCOM is about cognitive bias... That is: the human mind having an easier time to remember failure compared to success, or assuming that previous results in an RNG effects the next result, which it does not. While this is certainly true, the game does in fact suck at creating random rolls. It will produce long streaks of similar numbers, and will do so on a regular basis. Over the course of a whole game, the hit chances will be correct. That is, 50% of all shots taken with 50% chance to hit, will hit. However, it will not have a random distribution of those hits, and they will streak often. That means one can expect the hits and misses to come in bursts, rather than distributed randomly.In XCOM 2012, just like in XCOM 2, game designers have decided to represent hit chances with percentages. This is in spite of many players not actually understanding how percentages work. There are numerous posts by people saying that it's odd that they missed a 90% shot. But it isn't. One in ten shots will miss, and you certainly tend to take at least ten if not more shots during a mission, never mind several missions. To represent hit chances in a way that many do not understand is also poor design, especially when the percentages lack an explanation. 85% chance to hit is roughly the same risk of missing as rolling a six on a normal die. Not at all uncommon, and certainly not a very likely shot when the soldiers life depends on it hitting.Now, as for my experience:Both XCOM 2012 and XCOM 2 give me the same pleasure. I am aware that the game may be very hard, and I am aware that I may fail. But the possibility of failure, and having to live down that failure, is the appeal for me. I like the game as long as I am challenged (I typically play until I have the best armor and weapons, then quit and start a new campaign), and I forsee this game (just as XCOM 2012) will provide me with a lot of fun.However. Do I recommend the game? I recommend the game to players who do not get provoked by bugs, and who accept failure when it comes with a sense of wish to push on. This is not a game for impatient players, or casual players in general. The game will demand your time and energy, and you will at times feel like the game is against you or that you are a bad player because you fail. But you're not. Losing that top tier sniper is part of the game, and a part of playing XCOM is to accept that there will be losses on your side. You may lose the entire game, and it might not be your fault (bad luck can end a whole campaign on higher difficulties).But a general recommendation? No. This is a poorly made game, with bad design choices, filled with bugs. This is not a game of quality, and certainly not of the quality one could expect in 2016. If I were to recommend it because I personally enjoy the game, I would be doing other players a disservice. I cannot in good conscience recommend a game which the developers have launched before it's been properly tested and fixed.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												Right now, I sadly can't recommend the game; there are simply too many bugs ,and a few design decisions, that make this game more frustrating than enjoyable. The random numbers are pre-generated whenever a new map is loaded. Meaning, sometimes your units WILL miss four times in a row. No matter how you position them, if it's overwatch or not, if the displayed chance to hit 100% or if the enemy is flanked, they will miss four times. So, if you use bad tactics and reload to try something different, you just wasting time because the outcome is already determined.And sometimes the aliens WILL hit, no matter what you do. Even through walls and floors, without them having seen your doomed units previously.Speaking of walls, it seems that they don't block the line of sight very reliable. It's very frustrating if you set up a nice ambush (in the rare case the map doesn't have a VERY tight turn limit), and the aliens notice your units through a wall or door, kill one or two, and poison the rest though the wall without even opening the door.Also, my first campaign save suddenly couldn't be loaded any more; it just crashed the game without any error.I hope Firaxis will fix them eventually, but until then you should better play something less frustrating.

content:
Posted: January 29
												Im hardcore Ufo: Enemy Unknown fan and i do not approve new reboot. Its too bright, too plastic, too rpg. Difficulty is broken in my opinion, when you do wrong things its hard, when you do right things its easy. Its hard to find middle ground and you play against the dice. But at least its better than XCOM 1 and i admit i enjoyed this game sometimes.More details:- i think that in game like that small squad is a mistake, when you add soldier levels to that it makes losing soldier a big tragedy. In XCOM 2 at least squad size makes sense coz you use gorilla tactics, you do not have big army. Anyway in original you could send 14 soldier to a mission from the beginning of the game. When you lost few soldiers or even half of them during mission you still had plenty. In XCOM 2 when you send 4 soldiers, lose one and other two panic its almost like game itself force you to load save. One way to cancel temptation is play in iron man.- difficulty is artificial in my opinion, when you fight one pack at the time its easy, but when you spot more packs its suddenly hard. Also when you shoot and throw grenades unspotted enemies are ok with that, but look at them, just look, they freak out and attack you :D that makes no sense. Concealment in this game is a joke. Initiative and order of actions is too important. Spoting enemy with first soldier or last soldier often make difference between win or lose. Time mission also just force you to make mistakes. - game have many minor issues in strategic view that makes some game features pointless. For example engineers, important only in the beggining. Scientist are almost useless coz research end very fast. Production of important things is random just to make it longer. Workshop or labolatory is almost pointles, and building slots have buffs that are not needed. Its just busy work. And im spent. Maybe in future I add few more points.

												After 5 hours I'm hooked. If you liked XCOM you'll like XCOM 2.Also I got to make Mr. T so I think it's a win.


I pity the fool. 
A Screenshot of XCOM 2
By: [KRAG] Batman




Edit: After winning a 40 hour game. I will never play XCOM 1 again. They fix so many things in XCOM 2 I don't know where to begin. Abilities in the old game that I would never pick have been buffed to be actually good. If you are losing missions you can scan for supplies and still be making progress. The feeling of the game is really good. At first you feel week but because you are working in the shadows everything seems to be going fine. After you start doing misstions Advent starts uping it's game and it starts to really feel hopeless (I'm guessing this is where many will lose). At the end you feel verying powerful and start having a hope of winning the war. The story is great and feeds into these feeling well. All the soldier classes feel great. There wasn't a single class (exept phsyonics which I never even reaserched and still won) that I felt was not worth bringing. Each choice you when leveling up you charecter is really hard. Only 20% of the time did I feel like one of the abilities I would never use.Concealment really makes the beginning of each mission fun. You feel safer and can get into the action faster. You also feel very powerful when you can take out an entire pod with an ambush. The mission timers really fix the game and add some depth to mission types. Not all missions have timers and not all timers running out mean you lose. The UFO for example will just call another pod to come and kill you if you don't shutdown the distress call in time. The overwatch cam is the best thing ever. The character creator really helps the game be more fun the second time. Make sure to get the mod that lets you start with characters from your pool. It's in my list of must have mods in the comments.There are way more mission types and each one is really fun and different. The procedural maps also add replayability and work really well.My only problems are long loading screens and the occasional bug. If XCOM 1 was a 8/10 XCOM 2 is a 10/10If you want to watch my video review you can do so here. Sorry the video cuts off from time to time. My computer can't handle both XCOM 2 and Twitch at the same time. 


YouTube™ Video: XCOM 2 Review with lag 

			Views: 39		

			I'm sorry for the lag spike and the video not keeping up with the audio. I would Recommend XCOM 2 to anyone who like XCOM 1 and and If you were only to get one XCOM game get XCOM 2.

content:

												Though it still retains some of Enemy Unknown's flaws, XCOM 2 is an improvement on its predecessor in almost every way.+ The tactical turn-based combat is as good as ever.+ Sometimes brutal difficulty keeps you on the edge of your seat even more so than the previous game.+ New enemies with new abilities create a threat that's more far diverse than before.+ semi-randomized maps means you won't be visiting the same battlefields over and over.+ Tuned-up graphics, animations and character customization make battles look great.- Planning movement across multiple vertical levels is still awkward and sometimes confusing.- AA options seem poorly optimised, cranking them up can give a huge performance hit.- Camera issues sometimes prevent you from seeing what's going on.
