content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												I feel that writing a review before finishing a game is wrong, but in this case I will make an exception.  I am currently running this game with the following specs: EVGA GTX  980RAM 16gbCPU i5 4670kWIN 7 premium 64 bitMechanical HDD     I am currently playing with everything maxed at 2560X1440, and I honestly don't see any performance issues that are game breaking in any way. I have been reading so many negative comments from people that are experiencing low or inconsistent FPS. Turn off what ever you are using to record the FPS, and stop concentrating on these numbers. This is the biggest way to ruin a game for you. It hurts even more when you have a banging game machine. I used to obsess about FPS, and would beat myself over the head trying to run a game to meet a steady 60 FPS. I had to stop. I realized I was spending too much time worried about FPS, and not enough time actually playing the game.      This game is awesome, and is such a huge improvement over EU, and EW.  There are so many personal stories waiting to be told within this game. I played for only 3 hours, and already experienced some awesome moments, I can't wait to dig deeper.      Firaxis hasn't wronged us. They haven't come to our homes, and kicked our dogs. They just released a game. If you feel ripped off, get a refund. Meanwhile, I'll be mu♥♥♥♥in' save-spamming, and killing sectoids. Peace.

number of helpful: 9 of 16 people (56%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												WARNING: SPOILERS AHEAD!The predecessor XCOM: Enemy Unknown might have been difficult to mod, but that's probably the worst thing that could be said about it. Once modded the gameplay was amazing. Especially with the Long War mod.Yes, there were still some things wrong with the predecessor, even after modding.But to call XCOM2 'weak' would really be a shame.Because that would waste the perfect application of the term 'abysmal' for this game.Why?1) The actual premise of shooting down UFOs (that's were the series came from, guys, it was originally called "UFO: Enemy Unknown") was totally and completely removed from the game.No more figher planes, no more interceptors, nothing. Simply gone.That's like taking city building out of Civilization. Stupid. Game breaking for me.2) The premise of a small resistance group being able to do what it does in the game is totally ludicruous.But hey, it's sci-fi, it doesn't have to follow logic, right?Wrong. For something that has turned into a terribly stupid economy- and turn-based-combat simulator the game logic is utterly ludicrous again.EVERYONE on the combat map suddenly becomes visible if even ONE soldier is spotted makes for some totally immersion-breaking moments EACH AND EVERY COMBAT MISSION. Why would I keep someone back from the frontlines only to have him suddenly become a target when somebody else who is nearly a mile away is spotted is beyond me.Because now there is NO CHANCE WHATSOEVER of leading the enemies on a wild goose chase by fleeing (visibly) with one soldier and dragging them behind me while the rest of the stealthed team moves in on the mission target. No chance for this basic maneuver. Due to some total balloney BS of a game logic.Strategic map:Yeah, ADVENT is in control of the world, we get it.We don't know anyone around the world who opposes them except our own little group. But we were the greatest force to oppose the aliens 20 years ago. Now we are nothing but a powerless group of gimps trying to get a F'ING HUGE ALIEN SHIP to fly again. Yeah, great logic.While we, as the resistance group on the 'strategic map' (hah, what is strategic about it, can anyone tell me?!?) can't simply broadcast on short-wave radio across the globe to simultaneously reach ALL resistance groups at once. Especially with a damn f'ing huge alien ship (where did it come from, anyway?) can't do a little radio building of our own. Naaah, too logical. Nah, can't be done.Sorry. Stupid logic does not trump sci-fi based logic.This list could go on for quite a few pages.3) A random number generator that generates a new roll every time the game is reloaded but still (and I checked) fails to come up with a number below 43% (which at that time was my chance to hack a heavy advent mec) after 50 (FIFTY) attempts is not a random number generator. Something is fixed there.Or my four failed attempts to successfully apply a dead-eye shot with a final adjusted to-hit percentage of 94% with my plasma sniper rifle, a superior scope, the aiming PCS, and tracer rounds. Yeah, very very likely, that chance.Nuff said, otherwise I'm gonna go random on some developer's a$$.4) A tech tree that is so shallow that you can have it finished after a mere two months game time?Merely three weapon groups (basic, magnetic, plasma). No more laser, no more REASON to have different weapons. Once you reach plasma the end is reached. No more advancement, not even the slightest increment after that. No matter how many scientists you have. No chance to apply your possibly dozens of scientists to upgrading the clip sizes, or the ranges, or the damage, or... or... or...Nothing.Especially the ludicrous game logic of loading electorinic warfare bluescreen BULLETS into a PLASMA rifle. Shouldn't the PLASMA rifle fire PLASMA? Which is a super-heated stated of atomic nuclei stripped of their electrons (therefore being UNABLE TO BE A BULLET ANYMORE BECAUSE THERE IS NO MORE MOLECULAR COHESION?)Still only ONE grenade for every soldier except the grenadier who can (hold your breath) carry at best FOUR grenades.WOW! Now that is one hell of a grenadier, right? Especially as he carries an ancient ONE-SHOT grenade launcher design from around the 1940's. Wow, now that is really modern tech, isn't it?Still only ONE ammo type for each soldier. No choices of changing ammo during the mission.No mecs, no cyber-units. Upgrading of specified soldiers abilities of totally boring two choices each level.No adjustability AFTER the fact. Once you pick, you are stuck with it, even when the choice you made turned out to be totally useless (and trust me, there are quite a few really useless abilities in the game, such as all pistol skills for the snipers.)No useful avenger upgrades except those 16 few vertical slots. Again, a flat side-view.Scientists and engineers with as much personality as an Excel spreadsheet.Who would have thought that the original UFO: Enemy Unknown would still have a better base building technique than a game 20 years younger? Not better graphics, no, butter a much more intersting premise.Anyone still remember the 3d- building slots that allowed you to lay out your own base in the original game?With defensive stations that actually did something useful instead of simply upgrading your theoretical defenses. Especially because after the first UFO was evaded in this game I never ever saw another UFO again during my whole game. So what do I need those stupid defense stations for?Boooooring. Snooze-fest!5) A ranged game that has absolutely useless ranges for their weapons.Many weapons have the problem of being barely able to clear a street -across, not lengthwise.Sometimes you have problems of shooting across a room, as that already seems to be beyond the acceptable range for some weapons BECAUSE YOU ALREADY GAIN RANGE PENALTIES FOR IT!Even the sniper rifle is barely able to shoot along a street, much less along a street block of three houses.Come on, my slingshot at home has a greater range (and probably damage) than that stupid sniper rifle.Dito for other classes.The Ranger class that has amazing cinematographics for the first few times they strike down an enemy. After that the enemies become far too tough for that stupid useless toothpick of even the most advanced swordtype to do squat against virtually any enemy except the weakest. And the Ranger's shotgun requires the Ranger to be almost on top of the enemy. Yeaaaah, great. Why not give me a spear and a sling with stones. Maybe I would actually get a better range with that than with my shotgun.Psionic soldiers, errr operatives, that require a clear view of the enemy AND also nearly have to be up close and personal. Blaargh.Nah, don't make me go into more detail.The ranges and even the best upgrades in the tech tree totally suck.6) Bugs and balancing issues still riddle this crash fest of a game.I don't know how often the game crashed during my one play-thru. But I lost count at around 30.When did Firaxis subscribe to the current gaming industry standard of releasing seriously unfinished and untested product?7) And finally, an ending that was so anti-climactic that it nearly put me to sleep.Oh boy, are you guys gonna be surprised the first time you see it.It probably was one of the worst endings in the full UFO series I have ever seen.Nah, not worth it.Forget about this game. Maybe when, or rather IF, some of the Long War modders have finalized a full game overhaul of the complete logic then you might consider this game.But only once this game has landed in the bargain bin of Steam.Cause I wouldn't pay $10 for it in its currents state.But even the most amazing mod won't bring interceptors back again.Sad, sad state of afairs for the gaming industry.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2016
												How should I put it in the simplest of terms...? X-COM 2 really likes to slap the player over his stupid face. If you are a little confused by what I mean, please understand that these words are not to be taken as a complaint or a sign of dissapproval from my part. I actually thoroughly enjoyed X-COM 2. It is – without exaggeration – one of the best, if not THE best turn-based strategy I played in this decade. It is thematically refreshing, cinematic where it needs to be and tactically demanding. And by 'tactically demanding', I mean hard as ♥♥♥♥. Yes, you heard me correctly; so if you consider yourself to be a rather casual player of strategy games, you should sit this one out. This game is cruel and unforgiving; I had to restart my campaign after 14 hours of gameplay just because I had made so many tiny mistakes along the way that, when accumulated, they created a scenario that was unwinnable. Nevertheless, if you take your time, learn from your past mistakes and never cease to improve your tactics, you will, eventually, experience one of the greatest feelings – beating the game for the first time. And for a while, you shall feel truly unvincible... I mean, until you try the Ironman mode and get your♥♥♥♥♥handed to you all over again. TO SUM UP: If you love great strategy games with brilliant micro-management, complex systemics and you don't mind turn-based combat and a difficulty setting that will never give you a break, don't you dare waste another minute and go buy this master piece of modern gaming.

number of helpful: 9 of 16 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												Ok 30 hours of gaming later, I have one finished campaign. Overall opinion? Holy hell this is a GREAT sequel!!!What you WON'T get... Fighters, Skyranger Upgrades, UFO Intercepts, Gene tweaked soldiers, Tanks/Vehicles, MEC Troopers, EXALT, or The same 6 maps over and over and over again.What WILL you get? PLOT! XCOM 2 actually has a story to the campaign, the mechanics of it can make some elements frustrating, but overall this is a VAST improvement. Did you hate Meld timers in EW? Well brace yourself, XCOM 2 makes a LOT of use of timers, albeit much more generous ones. Aside from the elements mentioned, almost everything else traditional about "XCOM" and similar titles is here, and generally improved upon. Soldier customization, for example, goes beyond what most MMOs will allow you to do with your character. The game creates all the maps you play on right before loading so you will never see the exact same map twice. While awesome, this feature seems to result in load times that are just a hair on the longish side for modern games. Maps still generally take less than 1 minute to load and, imo, its WELL worth it to have different maps EACH mission. Which brings me to the next "issue" with XCOM 2, if you want to nitpick, this thing pushes your cpu cores and gpu FAR FAR harder than its predecessor ever dreamt of. I don't know if this is due to sloppy optimization or just that they crammed that much more under the hood, but my GTX 650ti still handled the game rather well, if on some seriously low end settings. Interestingly, the game still looks better than the previous title even on these lower settings. One thing I am on the fence about is that, in this title, you are pushed to move. Your enemy is working on its ultimate 'I win' project and it cannot be stopped by you during game play, only delayed. This removes the option to go everywhere, do all the side missions, and finish the "Alien Menace" at your whim. While, at times, it can seem that the enemy will finish long before you are prepared, 2K was very good about balancing out pacing, and your ability to reduce their progress. For example: At one point they were nearly 3/4 the way finished before I did several major missions back to back and pushed them back to zero. As normal, once you begin the endgame you no longer have access to most of the game features and you have to make do with your soldiers as they are with whatever gear you have in your inventory. On the upside, if you are REALLY short handed for some reason, critical missions will allow you to bring wounded soldiers. Construction order is a bit trickier in this title than others in the same vein, I nearly screwed myself by ignoring the radio room while pursuing psionic tech and soldiers. You WILL spend a lot more time thinking out the consequences of what to build and when. The developers did a fabulous job of simulating the difference between XCOM as a super-black op with funding from around the globe versus XCOM as a barely existent guerrilla force only marginally better equipped than a militia. There are tons and tons of little things in this game that make it an absolutely fantastic TBS, and entry into the XCOM franchise. The addition of a story and some very RPG elements bring the game to the next level, especially when combined with the amazingly robust modding tools 2K provided. The possibilities are mind blowing, and if the mod authors embrace this title, its one we will still be playing 10 years from now and enjoying new stories and user made content. Obviously this also lends itself to giving 2K a huge opportunity for tons of DLC which can help keep the game fresh, interesting and new for years to come.  This one is definitely a "must own" for fans of TBS or XCOM.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												I really didn't like this game. There's a lot of new things, and some stream lining elements that make some things outside of combat better. But at the heart is the tactical combat gameplay, and that's really gone another direction from the previous XCOM. I personally do not enjoy the timed mission element on every single mission. I know other people do and that's fine. While this change is different compared to the first XCOM, it becomes a pain when every mission is timed. You have to throw caution to the wind to complete the objective, and the game punishes you for that. And if you fail, then game punishes you just as severly in a different way.There's no slow and steady in this game, that tactic is gone. It's now balls to the wall rushing into bad cover and getting nailed. But don't forget to flank! Oh wait, you now can miss quite easily while flanking. Get used to missing even with good shots. I don't think there is even much point to flanking, as you easily get out flanked when flanking. So the risk vs reward isn't there at all. But it seems the AI doesn't have any issue hitting your troops and they will hammer you even when you're in full cover. This game is quite different to the first XCOM, and I honestly don't like XCOM 2 at all. I'm going back to the original which had the right amount of risk vs reward to it.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2016
												TL;DR at the bottomIm gonna be totally honest, im giving this game a positive review because there isnt an "its ok" rating.  I absolutely loved XCOM: EU and I'm a huge fan of tactial combat and strategy games. Not only did i sink quite a bit of time into XCOM: EU, but i actually bought the iOS version so i could play it when im away from my computer. Like a lot of other fans of XCOM, when i saw XCOM 2 announced and i saw all the trailers for how the game looked and how much more stuff there was going to be in XCOM 2, I almost♥♥♥♥♥♥my pants in excitement. I preordered the game and I was so ♥♥♥♥ing ready to play this game. You can imagine how upset i was when the game launched and was practically unplayable because it ran like♥♥♥♥♥♥for so many people. I was willing to wait however, because i knew this game was going to be great. Promptly after the Launch Day issues were resolved, a lot of people were saying that the game was unplayable, and to an extent, it still is. XCOM 2 is arguably one of the most difficult and punishing squad-based tactical combat strategy games on the market today. When the game first launched and everyone was talking about XCOM 2, i heard a lot of statements that followed the general idea of "XCOM 2 is the Dark Souls of combat strategy games".  THIS IS ABSOLUTELY 100% TRUE. Much like dark souls, XCOM 2 does not give a♥♥♥♥♥♥about your precious little feelings. "Im sorry to hear that you missed with a 99% chance to hit, but you're still going to die here"  Clearly, there is a lot of XCOM:EU still reminiscent in XCOM 2, but there also isn't. This is why i feel so torn about giving this game a positive review, because i cant give it a neutral review, but i don't think it deserves a negative review. Let me run through the pros and cons real quick.Pros:+Excellent turn-based strategy that you know from XCOM:EU +Abundant customization options (who wouldn't want to slice sectiods in half while wearing a top-hat and monocle?)+DIVERSITY (good lord are there a lot of different enemy types in XCOM 2, which is something that i wish XCOM:EU had. I get that there are elite type enemies in XCOM:EU, but in the end theyre pretty much the same enemies, but stronger. XCOM 2 has a large variety of completely different enemies that have their own seperate abilities, armors, weapons, hopes, dreams, etc.)+MELEE COMBAT (why wasn't this is the vanilla XCOM:EU?)+Mod Support (idk about you guys, but if you arent saving the world as Guy Fieri, Shrek, John Cena, and Hatsune Miku, i think youre playing this game wrong)~Unbalanced Gameplay (I love an uphill battle, and i totally understand that an uphill battle is exactly what the devs were going for when they made the game. After all, youre the resistance. You dont have military-grade stuff, so naturally the enemy will have better weapons and equipment. I put this as an iffy kind of thing as many people might be upset about the steep difficulty curve.)~Lack of customization options (?) (honestly im not sure if this is the right way to put this, but i wish there were more basic styles for faces and hair. I kept getting recruits with the same faces, and i like to think that the resistance were only recruiting people from the same bloodline, but since those people kept dying, i dont think their bloodline would have lasted very long.)Cons:-HOLY♥♥♥♥♥♥THIS GAME IS HARD (I like an uphill battle, but this game is unfairly difficult. There's the obvious 99% chance to hit situation, but there has been more than one time where i was directly adjacent to an enemy and i had a 35% chance to hit with a melee attack. Not a ranged attack, a MELEE attack. Honestly, the swords would do better to just be a decorative piece than an actual weapon.)-Unoptimized (don't expect to be able to run this on any computer that could just barely run XCOM:EU)-Unoriginal Story line (I really do want to like the story of XCOM 2, but i would have greatly prefered a situation where we did defend earth, but they came back in greater numbers, like the new independence day movie.)-Less than (inter)Stellar voice acting (I didnt find Tygan or Lily to be super interesting characters. Like, i understand that  XCOM:EU's Dr.Shen would have taken a major stand against the alien forces and died doing such, but I find it a little odd that his daughter, who apparently would have been a little girl during the events of XCOM:EU, grew up to do the exact same thing as her father, with the exact same, if not more, skill as her father. Also, where the hell did Dr.Vahlen go? RIP(?))I feel like a lot of the points I've made about the game's difficulty could be best sumarrized by the Best Friends Play XCOM 2 series. I believe there are 7 parts to the series, but im probably wrong about that. They do a great job of going into greater depth about a lot of the topics i've covered here, but then again, theyre considerably bigger losers than i am. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rpAdhLcuSjkTL;DRIn the end i have to give this game a 7.5/10If you like games with a 90 degree difficulty curve, smashing keyboards out of anger, and beating your head against a brick wall until you or the wall falls, then you will love this game.Also it helps if youre a fan boy of XCOM:EU and Dark Souls like I am.

number of helpful: 10 of 18 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Alright, roughly 14 hours in, I'm going to go ahead and throw in my two cents.First, everything you've heard about perfomance issues? It's true, mostly. XCOM 2 cannot maintain a stable framerate to save its life. Many of the bugs and other issues with visuals return from X:EW. This is true even on the highest end hardware, and its really dissapointing to see a dedicated PC game suffer so much right out the door.If you can get past these issues however, XCOM 2 is an absolute blast to play. The new setting and excelent evolution of the mechanics already established in Enemy Unkown and Within, as well as new featues like concealment and a robust melee system, and use them to form an all-you-can-eat buffet of turn based tactics. Yet despite the fantastic new abilites of your soliders and the rival aliens, none of it feels too unfair. The RNG is still merciless, but more options for garunteed damage and ways to get the maximum efficency out of your turn mean that you have to contend with it far less often. At the same time, it still definitelty retains the "That's XCOM baby!" feeling of having the odds suddenly flip for or against you in a single bold move.The only complaint I see some people having is the turn limit placed on some missions. And while it doesn't bother me personally, I can see some people who enjoy taking their time on missions struggling against it.Thankfully, XCOM 2 gives nigh-unrivaled access to its inner workings, thanks to direct access to the same tools used to build the game, downloadable for free with purchase of the game. Even without these, you have ready acess to easily manipulated INI setting, allowing you to change many aspects of the game with little to no experience necessary. And that's just day one. In a few weeks or months, people will probably be able to customize every aspect of their XCOM 2 experience.As such, I highly reccomend it to anyone who enjoys turn based strategy games. If you're worried about performance however, it may be worth your while to hold back a while. After all, the game can only get better from here.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Its got some issues, the optimisation is shocking it runs terribly, i personaly had to edit the .ini files to get a resolution over 1200X800 , certainly more work should of gone into it before release. how much you hold it against the game is up to you.Myself i give it a pass, why? well its been out for 36 hours and ive spent 24 of them in game, so more of a first impressions that a full deep review.The combats better, clearer , more cunstimisation , more gear choices the skills have been ramped up , height bonus got doubled, supression imposes a wopping -50 now over double its previous value. add in armour and all the skills the enemy uses and you end up with a much richer deeper tactical combat.The Geoscape is now a valid tactical level with real choices to make, sure there are time sensitive missions that need to be done as they pop up but between those your free to invest your time as you see fit, generating troops or resources to increase either your economy or to fight back, and a balance needs to be struck, be too aggressive and stall out , be too passive and the aliens can simply win. The base building options are at the same time smaller but also a bit more impactful. you actually have choice rather than being a slave to the satelite nexus spam. whats your first priority? get a guerilla school and some of the old officer training unlocks such as squad size , xp bonus and more loot, go for an advanced warfare facility (how you heal fast) so your troopers are unlocking bonus skills as they level? or maybe you want to push and get a psionics lab out early and get some psychers on the field. Timers! big bone of contention and there is a veritable hurricane of♥♥♥♥♥♥on the forums about it. myself i like them mostly , id like a round or two longer to do my guerilla ops and the defend teh civilian missions are a bit vulnerable to spawn rng. but with over 20 hours in i havent actually lost a mission to them, i have left a trooper behind just couldnt get everyone to da chopper in time.they certainlymake sense thematically , you are an insurgency now after all , take to long and the legions of the enemy will descend on you and swamp you. and they certainly address the issue of overwatch crawling so many relied on. dp you like this design choice? well its personal opinion and im sure there will be ods to remove them if there isnt already, but myself i like thier addition.its a much more agressive game , between the timers and the aliens actively winning the game infront of you and it might not be for everyone. but for me its a glorious breath of fresh air. the new faster pace really forces you to make the most of your troops and to push.im a big fan of 4x and turn based strategy games and i really like this new cranked up xcom. a strong contender for game of the year for me , but i love the genre and have adored the franchise since the release of the original i played back on my amiga , your mileage may vary, if in doubt watch some lets plays and see oh and dont skip the tutorial its full of story and feels!Welcome back commander its good to see you

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												*I HAVE NOT FINISHED THE GAME SO THIS REVIEW IS SUBJECT TO CHANGE CURRENTLY*Im conflicted on whether to say this is worth picking up at the moment. Several patches can easily fix issues that are gameplay related. Optimisation wise, there is somethings to be decided. So lets jump into the good, the bad and the ugly.The game picks up in a future where xcom lost in EW (roughly around the 3 month mark from memory). The story is intriguing and the lore is interesting. Some nice throw backs to EW, but nothing super necessary.Graphics -The game looks nice, has a nice 'feel' to it. Things look on point. Enemy pod reveals are cool, the camera can be a little clunky but does give a satisfying feeling most of the time.  Textures are appealing and soliders look cool. Alien designs vary but Xcom 2 does a great job of the models imo.Sound -The soundtrack on this game is stellar. The music gets you right into the spirit of whats going on, the tension exists. Sounds are all nice, game does a great job using audio to its advantage.Gameplay -This is where things get shaky. Starting with difficulty. The game itself is not 'Impossible' and this is very apparent on veteran and lower difficulty. I found commander was a fair challenge. Legend has me ripping my hair out, but thats what you sign up for. The issue is apparent in veteran and lower where the game is disgustingly easy until it spikes.Xcom 2 introduces constant mission timers. I found several issues with this. It seems very divided by players if its good or bad, it creates tension but I found timers were sometimes stupidly short and were too unforgiving. This is reinforced by procuderal generated maps. I have had missions come up where it is not viable for me to reach the objective or vip and get out in time due to the map generation. This is when I have a issue. There is nothing worse than coming into a mission and straight up accepting its a failure because you cannot reach a point in time. MODS CAN ADDRESS THIS ISSUE AND EXTEND TIMERS/TRUE CONCEALMENT.Most of the aliens seem to be implemented well, with the exception of the faceless who punishes the player for doing what the game forces you to rush. Not a great system, but with time you can get strategy to get around these issues.Geoscape wise. Building is more streamlined, unfortunatley the early game is very forceful and you have to take a pretty forced build order. You have to manage time more effectively. Issues arise again from the avatar project and how quickly it can accelerate in comparison to how long it takes you to do things. Optimization -Yeah no. Its not optimized well and that impacts the game significantly. High performance rigs can struggle to pull decent frames when it is not something that appears to be all that demanding. Hopefully the game can be optimized and this fixed.Should you buy it?If you have played EU/EW you have a semi idea of whats going on. The game is a fun TBS with a cool premise and interesting elements.However, do not buy this game if you do not enjoy getting punished constantly. You can extend timers through mods or remove them entirely so dont fear them. I am enjoying the game a lot and am having a lot of fun. The game is in a state where its playable, but some fine tuning could really polish this to be easily game of the year.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Named and customized a Soldier, spent an hour making sure every detail was correct, even got him on the first mission - one shot by sectoid.Will customize again. 5/7 Perfect Score ;) (Imgurians will get it)-----Real Review You Say? Okay.If you enjoyed the latest reboot of XCOM, you will find more of the same in XCOM 2 - the difference being that they actually improved on the reboots original formula. The Overwatch is slightly more intelligent, the enemies more diverse, the strategies you can employ change a bit as well (especially with the "Concealment" factor) - there's new mechanics such as the "hacking" system which can give varied bonuses, and the new soldier classes are definitely more interesting (even introducing the first melee class in the Ranger) - they definitely feel much more interesting to play with.This game however does move even further away from the base building focus, simplifying it even further from the first game - whether this is a pro or con really depends on your personal opinion of that aspect of the game (I enjoyed the classic XCOM's base building and invasion mechanics, the reboot's base building mechanics felt a bit tacked on, and XCOM2's feel like a 'refined necessary evil' approach has been used - they're nice, but may be too simple)I like the direction they went with the storyline as well, making failure "canon" is an interesting leap very few games go with (Halflife being another big one) - that also leads to a lot of interesting story opportunities. It is also a nice play on the fact that XCOM is notorious for its difficulty (this game is a lot more fair than the original XCOM or its Reboot though, at some points could be considered a pinch too easy by some)Overall, if you enjoyed the original XCOM, this game is worth the asking price - if you just enjoy tactics games, I would probably wait for it to go on sale ( possibly 15-25% off ) - as it is still a very solid performer in that regard.

Posted: March 2, 2016
												I loved XCOM and XCOM EU; but the fact is that those games were significantly more fun to play, even on high difficulties and ironman.  The mechanics have been shifted past the point of 'frustratingly difficult' to simply 'unfun'.  The randomness generated is not balanced around Ironman or higher difficulties, much less both.  This can lead to, say, your third mission blasting you with three or four Vipers; opponents who stunlock your team one at a time.  When you encounter three opponents who can stunlock you in one pack, and you haven't gotten past a 4 man squad, you immediately lose.This isn't a roguelike where I have some option of variety in the first few levels.  RNG can just wipe out twenty hours.  The game is buggy, but more than that; it's just unfun.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												In 2012, an old strategy franchise returned from the dead and showed the gaming community just what real difficulty and real pain is. That game was XCOM: Enemy Unknown, rebooted from a series once known as X-COM and it went on to win not just the pleasure of old fans but gain new fans as well.XCOM 2 is the sequel to Enemy Unknown. Storywise, everything that happened in Enemy Unknown was a fake. The Commander was really a prisoner to the alien invaders and Earth has been conquered and ruled by the aliens with a faction of apparent human symphatizers called ADVENT. As the Commander, you're freed at the beginning of the game and once again, it's up to you to lead the forces of Earth against the aliens, only this time you'll be the attacker.From a gameplay perspective, XCOM 2 is mostly the same. You try your best to keep your soldiers in the best cover you can find and launch attacks on your enemies. What changes is that this time, you start out in Concealment mode. The enemy won't know where you are until you attack or get spotted by them, so this is where strategy comes in as you'll have to pick a perfect opportunity to ambush the enemy. Sounds simple? Well, it wouldn't be XCOM if it was simple now, wouldn't it? This time, certain missions also feature a turn timer which shows how many turns you can take before you fail the mission. With that in mind, you have to get to an objective as quickly as you can while also keeping an eye on the timer. While it may seem like a rush, the timer is mostly fair. You do have enough time to get to an objective, you just need to make the most of Concealment mode. Another new element to the game is the more destructible environment. Putting all of your soldiers on top of a building may not always be such a good idea.And stopping you from reaching those objectives would be the aliens now bolstered by ranks of so-called human volunteers. Some aliens make a return like the Sectoid and Muton but even the ones that returned have completely evolved or have been upgraded. Sectoids are no longer cannon fodder, Floaters have been upgraded to the angelic-looking Archons and the dreaded Sectopods return in a slimmer yet more powerful design. One way or another, the aliens are going to ruin your day, each of them with their own unique way.All is not lost however. Your soldiers may be outnumbered and outgunned, but they're no pushovers. The classes are both similar and different from Enemy Unknown. Snipers now known as Sharpshooters not only make use of Sniper rifles but can learn to use pistols like a gunslinger from the Old West. A new class called the Ranger employs a high-risk, high reward combat style to slash the enemy with swords in melee combat. With the destructible environments, the Grenadier basically becomes the most powerful and valuable class you can have in your squad as you can blow enemies off buildings or those hiding behind cars and other explosive objects. Most importantly, you also can blow up walls and obstacles so that you can reach a objective faster. Rest assured, you're going to have a lot of fun doing that.While XCOM 2 doesn't disappoint in its gameplay, it does in it's optimization. You'd think that having it as a PC-exclusive would make it easier for Firaxis to release a more polished game but nope, that didn't happen. The game is buggy like hell, at least it's mostly visual bugs  but still it can ruin the experience a little bit, especially for the last mission. There's also other weird problems like the aliens' turn taking too long, sudden framerate drops and the like but most players didn't experience anything game-breaking. Hopefully, Firaxis fixes the game soon.All in all, XCOM 2 is a fantastic game and is a textbook example of what devs should do when making a sequel (not the bugs though). If you're one for great turn-based combat and you can stand the pain of watching your men and women die horribly in combat, then you'll love XCOM 2. Just remember when you miss a 95% shot, that's XCOM, baby.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
												This game is more buggy than XCOM: Enemy Within.Despite that, I feel that it is absolutely a superior game, especially when it comes to playing on the highest difficulty.PROS (compared to XCOM:EU)- Steam Workshop support- Procedurally generated maps- More varied mission objectives- Missions are not an Overwatch-fest- More opportunities to recover from setbacks, allowing for more risk-taking- Each soldier class has at least three builds useful for various purposes on Legendary, as opposed to XCOM:EU's one or maybe two. More builds become viable as the AWC endows soldiers with out-of-class skills. Except for psionic soldiers -- and I haven't fully explored the new SPARK class yet.- No useless options in strategic layer, which is more than I can say for XCOM:EU- Better strategic layer BY FAR despite what other reviewers are saying. Enemy Unknown definitely had a formula for the most optimal choices and was completely predictable from game to game. Impossible difficulty pretty much meant, "always choose engineers, probably give up South America to the aliens." In XCOM 2, even on Legendary, I may take completely different research paths depending on what resources I find, what AWC does for my soldiers, the distribution of alien facilities, whether or not my hacks pick up Insight or Enemy Protocol or reduced Scanning Times, where the power cores are located in the Avenger, what's available from HQ or Black Market on a given month, what Dark Events I have to contend with.... etc.- Game music better fits the tone and narrative. I also like how it cross-fades between an "XCOM" and "Alien" track.- More interesting and likeable characters with better-written dialogue and better delivery on the voice acting- Did they take out "moving at the speed of death" from Run and Gun? I think they did. Gah that was such a cringe-worthy line.CONS (compared to XCOM:EU)- Bugs, largely aesthetic. (Programmer-speak: I think when they pre-calculate the outcome of an action, they load stuff up into asynchronous queues that may get out of order, and the engine gets confused as they are dequeued. This leads to the world as the player sees it having incongruities, like windows or terrain being destroyed without any apparent cause.)- I cringe a little when soldiers say, "What's over there?" Haderp!- The music is better, but unlike XCOM:EU none of it gives me visions of my soldiers competing in a roller derby :((( lol- Was released at a point in life where I have less time for games ;_;

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												tl;dr If you're a fan of XCOM or tactical strategy games, you'll probably enjoy this. The difficulty is steep but for those who like hard games this may be part of the appeal. Performance concerns addressed below(zero spoilers) - For the record my rig is running a Radeon 380 GPU and FX6300 CPU, so nothing too fancy. Upper mid level at best. Now then...Little more in depth(NO SPOILERS): XCOM 2 goes the opposite direction of the first game in terms of plot. Rather than defending the Earth or, as Sid Meier put it, "playing not to lose", XCOM 2 puts you in the role of the resistance fighters after the aliens won 20 years prior. Some old characters return, with a cast of new ones as well, and the roster of enemies to kill has increased by quite a bit. Graphically the game looks pretty great. I had lag when I first booted up at the main menu but it was because the game defaulted to maxed out settings. Although my GPU isn't at the very top of the line, it is now running the game quite splendidly with all of the settings maxed except Anti-Aliasing. For some reason that's the only setting that seems to be giving my rig trouble. But it still looks pretty good with that turned down.Sound-wise, it's pretty standard fare. Dramatic music when the xenos spot you, triumphant orchestras when outfitting your squad. It does its work, sounds high quality, and is pleasant to hear but isn't spectacular. But not every studio can afford to hire Jeremy Soule. Performance(CPU) could be better. Considering this is day 1 of release I'm not surprised that the optimization is what it is. Loading screens sometimes lag, turns take maybe a second or two longer than you feel that they should, but overall it's not dreadful. I haven't had any freezing in game at all. Compared to some releases, XCOM 2 feels pretty smooth. My old FX6300 doesn't have any trouble with it, and that's a lower-mid AMD chip. Gameplay is what you would expect from XCOM. Fans of the last game will be able to pretty much jump right into the action. Start off with rookies and no special equipment, promote them as they gain experience and skills, cry when your favorite soldier gets killed by a rogue laser... good stuff. The chance to hit with each attack is percentile based, so bare that in mind. Some players may not enjoy that aspect. Difficulty can be adjusted however so if the game feels too hardcore you may still find a level you enjoy.Graphics - 9/10Sound - 8.5/10Gameplay - 9/10

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												I have never written a steam review before but feel compelled due to the wave of negativity I have noticed and due to my experience so far!I have put around 14 hours into the game at the time of writing and am having an absolute blast, I love the game, XCOM EU/EW has been the game I have played the most over the last few years and I believe this game has impoved upon that in every way so far!A lot of negativity I have seen is about performance, I obviously can't speak for everyone and I am not a 'hardcore' PC gamer by any means, I bought an Alienware X51 3ish years ago and have not upgraded it in any way and would not know where to start if I had to, my PC is between minimum and recommended specs, i5 processor, NVIDIA GTX 660, 8GB RAM and the game runs fine for me.  I should say I have never looked at FPS counters in games and would only complain if the game was stuttering and impeding my ability to play the game and it isn't, I have noticed some stuttering in the cut scenes and a few times the camera pauses for a few seconds too long but that's it so far - I should also say I have not touched the graphics options so far and am just playing on what the game recommended for my PC on launch so I could probably improve the performance more so if needed.People have also complained about turn timers, I was unsure at first but really like them now, great feeling when you extract your squad with only 1 turn to go!  Makes the game more interesting for me - I used to camp and try to draw the enemy to me in the first game which artificually lengthened missions and did bore me occasionally, I cannot do that any more, at least on the majority of missions and I love it.  The timers also fit the 'guerrilla' theme of the game which I love.  I have noticed there are already mods available to remove and tweak the turn timers as well so this could help people who cannot learn to love the mechanic.Also, the fact modding is intergrated through the steam workshop is brilliant as it makes it more accesilbe to people like me and will only go onto enhance the game and increase it's longevity - which will be good anyway as this games is made to be replayed!Anyway, as I said, for me, I love the game and it is running fine on my PC. I would recommended you give this game a try and if bought via steam directly you can always get a refund if you cannot play!

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												Welcome to X-COM 2! Good Guy Terrorist Edition!In X-COM 2, you'll be freeing humanity from the clutches of our new alien overlords of 20 years! You play as the commander of the previous game, and with your track record of losing the planet to aliens, you were the first man they spent 2 decades to hire. God help us.But they probably recognise it wasn't your fault, since even the best tactician in the world can't win a fight with sub-standard troops. Which brings us onto 'Rookies'. Rookies are the mystical genetic blend of a stormtrooper's one night stand with a red shirt. Rookies could aim to breathe, miss, and then panic at someone doing it correctly as they are clearly a threat to their existence. Having a squad of rookies is asking for trouble, one panicky little♥♥♥♥♥♥can start a tantrum spiral that would make Dwarf Fortress revel in glee.But in all seriousness, X-COM 2 has been a solid improvement to EU/EW. Even with day 1 bugs it felt solid to play, has a lot of interesting lore and new mechanics, but retains the original X-COM charm of having troops miss stunned enemies at point blank range only to get mindraped by sectoids. Recommended!

number of helpful: 12 of 22 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												XCOM® 2 is a 3D-but-isometric-tactical-shoot-them-aliens-up game. The plot boils down to this: extraterrestrial beings have taken over the world and it's your job to take it back. You need to dissect aliens and research their technology in order to find out more about them and come up with ways of defeating them. Positive:The game plays extremely similar to XCOM: Enemy Unknown. Taking cover, shooting, researching, upgrading your base and many other things feel very similar. There are, however, new features that are all built upon that rock solid base that we, or I, know and love. My personal favourite and in my opinion biggest feature is a stealth mode. You can't Metal Gear Solid the game up by silently taking down enemies, but you can now avoid them, sneak around them to set up ambushes and create massive tactical advantages. The game also features a load of new enemies. Most old enemies from XCOM: Enemy Unknown have been genetically modified using human DNA, making for more powerful enemies than ever before, because YES, this game is HARD. I recommend people who aren't familiar with XCOM play XCOM: Enemy Unknown before picking this up.Something XCOM: Enemy Unknown was, in my opinion, already good at got massively improved: character customization! The higher the level of your character, the more you can unlock and the more unique your characters will become. I am a massive fan of extensive character customization and I absolutely love playing around with the customizer in this game. It has a load of options and features something for everyone's taste: wacky, tactical or whatever's inbetween, it's in there somewhere.Negative:I don't have many problems with this game, except for it's framerate. I recommend you watch out with this if your PC has low specifications, because I run it at 30 to 40 FPS, even though this PC can easily handle GTA V on some of the highest settings and still run it at a smooth 60 FPS. My verdict:A solid 8.5/10

content:
Posted: April 11, 2016
												I have some experience with older Command and Conquer games, Final Fantasy Tactics: Advance, and Fire Emblem, but this is the first and only XCOM game I'll ever play. I absolutely hate this game, and wish I hadn't thrown away $60 on such an unpolished mess.My main problems with XCOM 2 are (in no order):The game does a very poor job of informing the player about vital mechanics.I hate all four characters: Tygan, Shen, the pilot, and Mass Effect's The Elusive Man after about 80 more years of heavy chainsmoking.The game is way too difficult during the first third, especially for a first-time player.Enemy abilities are never explained. Unless you know beforehand, you have to risk your pawns' very important lives just to know how to fight enemies you've canonically seen before in some form.Attack range is never explicitly shown. FF Tactics: Advance managed to do this beautifully 13 years ago on the GBA.To manually path around hazards, you have to waste a move rather than the game having a competent pathing system.There are too many things happening at any time on the overworld. I have like 6 things to scan, 3 dark events going on, a resistance raid, Avatar Project targets, monthly reports, and research all overlapping each other.The game never tells you that a sniper can't fire his rifle after moving.For some reason, a soldier will be gravely wounded after taking only 4 damage out of 17 health, and I've healed it with a medkit.Supplies are too scarce for the first third of the game. By the final third, I contantly had over 2000 that I couldn't spend on anything.Unless you've already played through XCOM 2, you will not properly lay out the additional rooms you can add to your ship unless you spend even more time and supplies fixing it.After you beat it, it plays some cutscenes, and that's it. No New Game + or anything.Soldiers' voices will often glitch, and play in a language, sometimes even gender, other than what's selected.It's often far too difficult to click on specific tiles when targeting abilities like melee attacks and grenades.It seems like Vipers can grab you from literally across the map.You can have your engineers build "experimental" armor, weapons, grenades, and ammunition. This actually means that you throw away at least one elerium core and wait 7-30 days for a random item in that category that you may already have.

Final view If you are a fan, you already bought this game. If you are new to xcom, I would start off with enemy unkown to get a feel for this game.

number of helpful: 13 of 24 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
												If you enjoy any kind of Turn-Based strategy games, or you've played Enemy Unknown. This is everything you expect and 100x more.Difficulty is up to 10, but not to the point where you get frustrated, but to the the point where you feel so motivated to complete the mission.The addition of time pressure to the game overall, as the Alien's secret weapon is in construction, time is of the essence, every second and every move you make in the World Map is crucial, don't waste time or you will feel the consequences. The graphics themselves are wonderful, nothing to write home about, but a definite improvement.The newly added character customisation also adds a whole new experience as you can create your own units or even escort units. The customistation is quite developed for a game like this.Overwatch ability can also create some wonderful moments which can either make you full of pride, as you witness your units totally wreck the opponent or leave you out in the open for attacks.But as always, games like these arent perfect. The whole chance to hit system still feels ♥♥♥♥ed, but not as bad as before. The whole 'you're next to a guy but you have 60% chance to hit' can be aggrevating. But for me atleast it didn't happen too often. Everyone's game experiences varies in how badly ♥♥♥♥ed they can get because of it. The story is a unique one, normally we're defending earth, but now we are trying to take it back from the aliens. It's loosely attached to Enemy Unknown, so if you havent played that you can still play this without knowing what happened before.

number of helpful: 14 of 26 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
 JOIN US OR BECOME THEM  EDIT: Lack of optimization. The game is very poorly optimized. very. a lot. not good. I think I need to say this first, the game is awesome, but its optimization not. I press the "automatically detect hardware recommendation" the game set all the options on ultra... but the menus run with an important lag (10-15fps), when the "action camera" join the scene the fps experience a considerable decrease, about 20fps (but for example explosions or smoke looks perfectly during the game at 60 fps) so the game is poorly optimized at this point. I can run Wild Hunt for example on ultra on 60fps so... Think about it.This is XCOM Enemy Unknown ultra enhanced edition. This is more and better. This is pure XCOM turn-based strategy. XCOM 2 is all the good things the original had (as well as the bad things too) with a lot of new stuff.Now you are behind the enemies lines, XCOM becomes the underdog, acting furtively, in the shadows, they are now an organization declared criminal by the new order...  The time has come to reclaim our world. Now they are not fighting an invasion force, the XCOM project are now against a greater more organised force, with power and resources. And they are really♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off with you. The new concepts, guerrilla tactics, the implementation of stealth, new enemies, a good variety of mission types, the customization of the weapons (you can add ons like scopes, lanterns, silencers,  enhanced ammunition... modify many aspects), of your soldiers (now you'll miss 'em when they die, if the moment comes... and trust me, surely come), can modify their aspect in a very deep way (but all the male faces are ugly as hell) there's a high level of customization. Your headquarter is really badass now. The maps are open now, you can move about the map freely, until you either stumble into range of an enemy or decide open fire on them, so, this is the guerrilla aspect of the game, you can now prepare an ambush, seek for the better positions before a gunfire or even almost end a fight before the enemies can react at your presence. but the situations can become in a different, very bad for you, scenario in a heartbeat, so you need a plan B, always.  The combat feel so agil and natural. The game is very more dynamic this time. Fights are brutal, raw and complex. The game is really challenging and tough, doesn't forgive a mistake.The environments are procedural battlefields, high-quality procedurally generated maps, there is slums, city centres, forest, suburban spaces, all interesting, richly detailed, destroyable (explosions can start fires that propagate, for example), interactives... (at this point maybe you got your suspicions... the game is amazing in every aspect!)XCOM has a real evocative history now for the first time, with cutscenes, and remarkable characters with a backstory and its own opinions. People you want to save.There are now Dark Events, and will change the game in unpredictable ways. Dark events are "counter-operations" undertaken by Advent against XCOM.It's the more exciting turn-based tactical game ever made.Of course it has its minor flaws, soldiers firing the same enemy during overwatch, missing high chance shots with an average of 87.3%... but we're here to suffer, weapons through walls, some glitches, "weird walls" when you enter in a building... but nothing really remarkable.The graphics aren't spectacular neither the animations.It's true that the game needs much better optimization, quite. I can run The Division beta or The Witcher 3 on ultra and 60fps but XCOM barely runs, on menus (yeah weird), about 20fps, in battle runs fine.About mods and steam workshop. XCOM 2 has Steam Workshop support, this will improve the game in many ways and make it probably endless. Long War Studios (the team behind XCOM: Enemy Unknown's Long War overhaul) has already produced three mods for XCOM 2, all of which are playable from launch, highly welcome move! This feels like a free DLC because Long War Studios teamed up with developer Firaxis Games, and they've been working together!! so this mods perfectly fit with the core of the game, without problems or complications.Take earth back, commander.

content:
Posted: March 19
												First of all, I loved the first XCOM, but this one is much of the same, though it seems as though they push you into expert mode from the beginning. (even if you set it to rookie) They pen you against enemies that are way too strong for the units you have available, and your units can't hit crap, (even when it is like 80% chance) I go so frustrated by the constant misses and mission losses due to the misses, that i just gave up on the game. The balancing on this game was poorly done, almost to the point that it is like 80% enemy against your 20%. again, i played and finished the first XCOM on higher difficulty levels, and yet this one is hard to get past first few missions without loosing all your troops.(edit) - I played a bit more, and some of the missions are impossible, and i have only covered four slots in asia, and im supposed to get more in all the planet. There is this countdown to doomsday which is almost impossible to stop since you keep loosing troops because they suck at shooting, and the enemy seems to get every shot dead on the money. (mind i set it to rookie, the easiest level possible.) -The game lags when loading missions, and freezes up on characters when they are captured by the enemy snake dudes. Not sure why it loads so slow since i have the game on a 2TB SSD drive, and I have 64gb of RAM. Honestly this game is crap as it is, and im surprised the devs never repaired the issues with the game.  -The game feels like one of those games that the devs DID want to finish, but the distributor didn't want to spend any more time on the game, so they released it early. We all know potentially awesome games have been ruined because of some suit in an office decided to get the quick buck instead of waiting to make the game right. It plays like a early access game, only there aren't any updates from what I have seen.Im really disappointed, because I loved the old game, and wanted something to fill the void.  Sadly this game is just too buggy and unbalanced to get a thumbs up, and I would give it more thumbs down if I could. Thanks 2k for ruining a franchise.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												 An absolutely awesome game that continues the great qualities of the first. Although in XCOM 2 the desperation is palpable, all of EARTH is occupied by the Alien menace that now uses human/alien hybrids called the "Advent". Right away the action is reminiscent of the original, which is a good thing! Each action looks like a short film, the firing of the rifles is absolutely beautiful, only multiplied by a rib crunching strike against an enemy trooper. XCOM 2 also puts alot of emphasis on the psychic and psionic threat of the aliens. While you may be safe at a distance from being turned into purple jelly by a plasma ray, an advanced alien might use a technique to make you panic, running maniacally into the enemy only to be slaughtered at close range.  Ive notice some people had complaints about lag, the only times I noticed the lag issues where in the pod before a mission, and I am hoping 2k can quickly solve this problem. Also the loading between each members turn can take awhile. This game has a much more "Guerilla" feel, you are trying to create a resistance team to finally crush the alien race. Did I mention Lore? Lore Lore Lore, especially if you were a fan of the last game this one will have you drooling at the mouth. 9/10 Great Job!

Posted: February 15
												Twas a pree fun game while it lasted. But, if i must be perfectly honest, the first XCOM was much better., and ill point out why.  In the 1rst game, the aliens invade the planet, and they have aliens dressed as humans, and there scouting and gathering information. In the 2nd game... somehow the humans are "semi" co-existing togheter, the aliens supply the police force known as ADVENT. For me,  XCOM 2 has a much weaker story, and way of a dire importance to missions you do. In the first XCOM, right off the bat, you get to pick which country you play, which gives you a specific perk through-out the entire game,  you get to slowly but surely gear up your weak soldiers, and you really felt there was a progression when you finaly beat a mission that would unlock various alien technologies that you would need for future combat. In XCOM2, altho fun, did not captivate me as much as the 1rst one. The researches were boring, weapons were mundane, and whenever i would research and get something "amazing" as they would make it to be, like a armor that makes you run through wall, i was already 3/4 done with the game, and i didnt really care about all the fancy new gadgets XCOM2 has over the 1rst game. Ill give this game a thumbs up, altho no bad, there is no sideways thumb for a 50/50. If you wana get into Xcom, just buy the 1rst game. You WILL be happy with it.6/10 eNjoY =^-^=

number of helpful: 22 of 42 people (52%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 6
												Pretty tired of an 81% chance to hit actually being a 0% chance to hit.I have 175 hours into XCOM Enemy Unknown/Within.  I got a lot of play out of that one.  And I preordered the big special edition of this expecting that this one would surpass that.  Well, it didn't.  I finished my first playthrough of the game in about 24 hours and it was very frustrating.  This was before any of the content packs went live (as they were not at launch when I got the game).After seeing all the DLC had been released I loaded it up again eager to try out the new stuff.  But the new stuff, it really isn't that interesting at all.  With Enemy Within there were huge additions to the game.  Mechanized soldiers or bio enhanced ones added new depth to your strategies.  The ones for X2 here mostly added aesthetics, a few interesting but overall useless weapons, and robot soldiers, which is just a retread of the exact same robot soldiers from XCOM  Enemy Within.Here I sit at about 59 hours in a love hate relationship with this game, I actually want to play it again but then I remember all the frustrating things about it.One of the things XCOM2 does is have more urgent missions, which is fun in a way.  You can't overwatch creep through maps, you have to move quickly and you have to take risks.  Unfortunately those risks often end in really bad results.This is a puzzle game.  The puzzle is loading multiple times to get the correct execution so you don't lose any one of your soldiers.  I want to write them off, I really do, but I can't.  For one, I get attached to them since I can custom make my own roster, which is neat.  Jack Bauer, Bear Grylls, Duke Nukem, Lara Croft, it's a dream team.  But it takes so much to level guys up.  And they only advance on getting kills, not participating in a mission.  Support Units, guys with drones that are meant to buff and heal the party, they can't advance if they aren't killing aliens.  Doesn't matter how many missions they run, how many lives they save, if they don't get their kill quota they stay useless.So it takes so long to level up your squad, which means when you lose a guy, it hurts, it hurts a lot.  So you don't want to lose anyone, because there's so many things that put pressure on in the game.  In both playthroughs I could never get the Avatar Countdown to drop below 2 empty squares and ultimately fell apart in my second one. Losing good troops means losing the ability to mitigate the countdown.  And wounding times are so long.  Even when I try to bring along a couple of rookies to make sure I'm padding out my advancement, it's a battle with luck, since they need kills to advance.Some fights keeping a guy alive is all but impossible.  It's a puzzle game.  You keep reloading until you find the right combination of moves and attacks that keeps your squad alive.  And it doesn't help that the game pregens random numbers, meaning you will see the exact same result every time.  Which I find odd there was no option to change the random seed which iirc was added in Xcom (also exists in Civ 5 another Firaxis game).And I wish the devs addressed that, the need to constantly reload, because you have to keep your good guys alive, you can't lose them.  You can't run the end game with a field of rookies and survive without constant reloading.  And the load times are soooo loooonnng.After almost 60 hours, I'm done.  The new content just isn't enough to keep me playing, it's a waste of money.I've been gaming since my dad bought my fam a Commodore 64 in the mid 80's, so maybe I'm just too old.  The kids these days play their Dark Souls and talk about how awesome it is to die all the time and never make it past level 2.I like a challenge, but I don't like frustration.  And there's a fine line.  And I'm going to get a whole bunch of thumbs down because it isn't about whether a review is 'helpful' here, it's about whether or not you agree with someone's opinion.  And old gaming codgers like me are in the minority these days.

												Developers missed the balance between fun and frustrating by adding timers to missions. That one simple decision is what turned this game from fun to frustratingly unfun. Outside of the missions with timers, the difficulty is ramped up to a very fun pace due to mind control, swords, and unkown enemies  Quote from top negative review... Which I couldnt have said better. My review for Xcom Within & Uknown was an "A+" But this one is tuff for me to love...1.Commander level is like impossible2.Lengendary is like Impossible for sure...I have started over and over again trying to get pass the stage where my troops have some decent gear to surive the onslaught of opponents the ai throws at you and that damn timer clock...(yeah that F-timer clock lol). I even went to normal level vet. and ok I hit more often but cant seem to get over that steep unbalance the game throws at your ill-equpied troops. Yes I understand the human race has lost to the aliens but its still a game that needs some balance for fun. Most youtube vids Ive watched leading up to launch show game crits with ramped up gear and skills...which say once you obtain the game's AI gets kinda steamed rolled but thats not fun either. ;/ Hell I even tried the strategy guides to how to... and ive succeeded to the point I got some decent gear but my troops seem to run into those damn time clock missions and the death con to avatar goes higher do to failure to complete them because most of my squad are wounded from other missions...To sum up I do like the game but I wonder if the developers played this themselves for balance rather than handing out game crtitics skilled and geared up squads to test there game...I find Xcom2 unbalanced in its present state...I shouldnt have to keep fluxing game difficulty level to get passed certain missions...Would love constructive feed back on my review because despite my negative review I keep at it like an Abused Lover trying to make it work....lolEDIT: I have recently aquired some player mods. bellow thanks to "Commander Cool" in the comments section of my review and I believe this will turn my frown upside down on the game...I encourage the reader to check out these links...(hell if this works I might even change my negative review! ;)

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												Will update this once I get home from work, review mostly written for old xcom players.+ The combat has been improved a lot because of small things that makes the game have a much better pacing. As an example they've added the ability to actually see if you have a line of sight on the enemies so that you wont have to worry about it when moving around.+ The new system in which you spawn invisible to the enemies makes the first part of every map more enjoyable because it means you're setting up ambushes instead of hoping for good rng with the pod openings.+ I for one like the new base building system even if it at first glance might look dumbed down. It feels like you wont have to play a certain way IE follow a certain building line that was always the same no matter what.+ So far the enemies have been fun and rewarding to face, and I'm eager to see what they will throw at me for the rest of the game.* Some graphical glitches like weapons or enemies clipping trough walls, pretty much the same as the previous game. It doesn't affect game play unless you really care about graphics.* Difficulty has been scaled down and it feels like if you would play on a difficulty level under commander(classic) it would probably be really easy compared to the previous game.- The AI has a habit of some times running into really stupid positions. As an example I've had two occasions now where AI ran into cars that exploded the next round, instantly killing them. Not sure if intented but I doubt it.- Terrible optimization makes the menu, cutscenes and base almost unplayable. I don't know if this is a common issue but my rig should easily be able to handle this on even the highest graphics. Luckily since it's a turn based game it doesn't affect game play that much.Easily recommend the game for now!

number of helpful: 74 of 145 people (51%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												This isn't turn based strategy, it's time management.Every mission has an objective on the other side of the map, that you'll have to retrieve/hack/destroy/etc. Standing in between you and that objective, is a large number of aliens. Sounds fun, right? Good news, it is!That is, until you realize that you're basically not allowed to strategize, due to the comically small time limit you're given to complete these missions. You have a very small amount of turns, to not only achieve your objective, but in some cases, kill off all the remaining enemies on the map. What does this mean? It means rather than sneaking around and being careful in order to achieve a successful attack (aka "strategy"), you will be making a suicidal dive towards the objective in hopes of getting out in time. This makes gameplay extremely linear, and leads to the inevitable and needless death of countless squad members. Sadly, the time limit that plagues individual missions, plagues the entire campaign as well. I don't want to spoil it for those who plan on getting this, but there is also a very small window to achieve certain events, and failure to do so means campaign over. I also found the side quests overwhelming and not fun at all. They bombard you with a million things all at once, all timed, with zero explanation. Failure to do these things will put you behind in resources, which in turn makes you less prepared on the battlefield. And let's face it, you're gonna get fisted out there on a good day. This game has a lot of potential, but it's poisoned by the fact that you're constantly being shoved from behind, rather than being allowed to enjoy what is otherwise, a beautiful game. If a patch or mod comes along, that fixes this ridiculous time mechanic, then I highly reccommend you pick it up. If not, save your money, because as of now it's Diner Dash with guns.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												30~ hours, and a completed game later.I'm very sad to report that XCOM 2 is just not worth the hassle as the games state is right now, below this little essay i will list observations that i've made that will be useful to know prior to purchase.First and foremost I'm a fan of the series and both XCOM ORI and XCOM EW, but this one has, not captured the same fun elements of seemingly unending and important research, interresting buildings and the general planing between the team, the engineers and the scientists.Engineering and the building of facilities is extremely boring, no depth or intruiguing or important bonuses to adjacent rooms. Scientists are just exponentielly decreasing, yet flat, science speed upgrades with names. (Yes somewhat similair to XCOM EWs, I just personally expected more)The worst however is the boring absence of pre-planing required to be successful, and by the time you get anywhere with a plan, some random, un-ignorable, mission interrupts your work + plan.Worst of all though, is the extreme amount of animation time you will be wasting watching an AI doing nothing, before and after it has done anything, for no visible reason, as if it went afk to fix a lamp mid fight.Below here is a list of observations, one or two could be considered spoilers, but they're rather important. Also they're obvious.*Locked 30~ Fps? Odd decision since the game runs like excremation from a donkey.*Only outtro cinematic is 60fps, intro menu 1-48 fps (wtf?)*Numerous performence issues, mainly removing all lighting features and filtering will fix the fps from 16 to 30, sometimes.*Crashes upon launch, crashes upon certain actions in certain areas (shotgunning an avatar on the last mission), crashes randomly, crashes upon reloading certain load files (curropts all related MISSION autosaves and quicksaves).Unreliable movement control, misinformative movement in certain circumstances (VIPs for instance block paths, but aren't shown to do so), On higher difficulty my own statistics show that the aim your soldiers pretend they have, is somewhere around 37% worse than it says, multiplicative.*Artificial difficulty – over the board.*Information needed from the f1 function in xcom Eu/EW surprisingly missing.*General sudden missing imformation.*Boring streamlining of stats in classes, boring abilities.*Annoying mission interruption (constant interruptions).*Research and building boring and linear.*Overused Cliché “you’re the hero” ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ (with a character looking directly at ‘you’ saying “you’re the one”).*Too short (<- more of a personal thing)*All the other "minor" glitches and buggs from XCOM EW, such as wallhacking units, glitching and shooting through them.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												Woohoo! More alien killing! Time to go after their UFO landings, shoot up everything that comes out of them, and eventually go find some weird aliens with strange psionic powers.Wait... I lost the war? WHAT DO YOU MEAN I LOST THE WAR? I HAVE 100% COMPLETION IN XCOM ENEMY UNKNOWN ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥!Anyway XCOM 2 is both similar and different to it's predecessor. Similar because much of the gameplay mechanics are the same. You build and research stuff at yer home back, go out to beat up aliens on turn-based tactical maps, then return to yer base to look at all the alien goodies you captures and see if you can learn to make fancier toys to use against them. Different because, well, you lost the last war somehow and the aliens now rule the world, so now you get to be a GORILLA instead of the leader of a multinational special forces unit.The change in circumstances is shown quite nicely. Since you are the "attacker" this time, you always have targets to go after and places to go in order to help improve your resistance network. However, it also feels like you are pretty much always starved for resources and forced to make do with whatever you can scrounge together. Eventually this means, of course, that you will scrounge together some power armor and plasma weeapons, but that felt earned after dozens of battles where the technological odds were heavily stacked against me and I had to overcome the foe with superior strategy... or just legging it for the escape area if it was one of those kinds of missions. XDI'm going to play this game some more because there are achievements to unlock and more aliens to shoot and blow up. Also because, well, I had lots of funs doing it. Yes, it's very similar to it's precessor, but enough is different that it feels like a different game with a new experience, rather than just a remake of a proven success.Also you can decorate your characters to look completely silly. That's a nice bonus and even adds to the "guerilla" feel of the war you are fighting. Not everyone is going to be dressed up the same like it was some regular army, after all. Therefore, it is perfectly ok to lead your armies into battle under command of the moustached fellow with  a pink hat, purple clothes, and a yellow assault rifle! :PHave funs! Kill all the aliens! o_o

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												Since the release of Xcom (which wasn't actually the first x-com), many games have tried to copy the turnbased gameplay that these guys did so brilliantly. Some were ok, some were just terrible, but none compared, let alone did any better, than Xcom.Now it's back again with the much anticipated new version with the turn based combat style.Instead of just doing another cookie cutter version though, it seems like they have looked at the tactics and added/changed some things so that players have a slightly new experience with the new tactics. Which imo is great.It has an updated version of that great artstyle and graphics from previously. But it does seem to want some quite high pc specs for a game engine that doesn't seem like it should require them. On my pc it seems to run ok but kind of does stutter/stall a little when switching from birdseye to aiming view just for a second, then goes back to good fps again (30+). Hopefully a patch or driver will help this in the future.So far all up I'd say a 9/10 should be pretty justified, with the slight performance issue stopping it from being 10/10, BUT I won't really know how justified until the end really. So fingers crossed it stays as good as it seems so far and that a driver or game patch helps with that very quick and slight yet noticable stutter/stall at certain times.update- I have noticed lowering some settings has helped with performance a little and it still looks really nice imo. 7 Hours in and oooohhhhhh man this is going to be addicitive for me LOL. Don't you just love digital crack? :P

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												Finished XCOM 2 today and can't recommend the game enough to those who enjoyed XCOM:Enemy Unknown/Within, or turn-based strategy.Like the previous XCOM, the start of the game can be quite brutal and unforgiving if you don't keep pace with the aliens. I've only just recently played the previous XCOM, so i'd learnt from my mistakes in that game that you have to upgrade weapons/armour ASAP - otherwise you'll just be roasted. Because of that, I didn't have much of a problem on the normal (vertern) difficulty. If you do, don't be afraid to just restart the game and optimise your research/builds/combos better. Once you get past that initial hurdle and have a solid rotation of soldiers, the game feels like it goes down in difficulty. I didn't have any problems past the first 2 or 3 hours until the final level - which is challenging/completely insane IMO. I thought I had got better at turn-based strategy, but that mission just sat me in a corner and explained that this wasn't the case.I finished the game after 43 hours. I'm sure you can do it in less time, and replayability is definitely there. I'm also looking forward to seeing what mods/updates come out for this! Definitely worth the purchase, even at full price IMO.
