In a month or two once it’s fully functioning properly.  That’s my review and I’m out!P.S Firaxis if you read this I think the whole Xcom 2 community should get a new piece of DLC for free. Make something else up since I already own the deluxe version.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												So now that I've seen some improved performance through the most recent mods such as "Stop Wasting my Time" the game has vastly improved to where I now can recommend it. The reason it was a not recommended wasn't because of the gameplay reasons such as timers but due to all the buggy issues with the game.XCOM 2 is the next step in the Firaxis XCOM franchise. The game does a neat job of switching the roles where we are the invaders and some of these features really felt missing in the first XCOM. Concealmeant is without a doubt my favorite system in the game but I also love fighting against the high tier enemies. The thing about fighting a sectopod or a gatekeeper is that when you defeat one of those enemies, it feels great. There are some enemies that are very annoying that I think should've been scrapped and reworked (Stun Lancer for example) because they aren't fun to fight against early on. The story is a strategy game story, it's not supposed to have a Bioshock Infinite level of plot twists. There are a couple of references to the X-COM franchise (Terror From the Deep) but whether or not Firaxis will actually make a TFD I don't know.At $60 the game is currently enjoyable for XCOM fans but not so much for anyone else. The new player experience is pretty bad because they do not give you enough of an introduction to show you all the neat little things about the game. This will make it very hard for newcomers to actually play the game. Of course they can watch a tutorial which is what I would do but the game doesn't teach you how to play that much.Mods will also keep this game alive for a long time. I bet in about a year or so, we will see a Total Conversion Mod where the Rebels fight the Empire in XCOM Empire at War.

												Despite what the negitive reviews say, this isn't a half bad game. The only problems are the turn timers and lag but I am 100% sure a patch will fix the lag (Plus the game is moddable anyways so you could always make a mod to fix the frame rate.) and the turn timers make the game much harder which I personally like (However they should be higher on lower difficulties).Pros:Great Concept.Great Gameplay that improves on EU/EW.Much more at stake when playing it (No more sit and stay overwatch bait)Love the base building in this one.The aliens are much much cooler and tougher.Amazing Character Pool and Customization. "Cons":Huge FPS problems that will be fixed in a few days.Something that makes the game tough. (Again, no more "I could move up, or I could overwatch for 5 turns and turtle")Overall:I feel bad for Jake Solomon... Every bad review is either ♥♥♥♥♥ing about bad optimization (For crying out loud large amounts of games on release are like this, but they get fixed.) or saying that the turn timers "take the skill out of the game and you just have to mad dash for the objective".The turn timer isn't that bad for ♥♥♥♥s sakes!!!! Look at most of the YTers playing this, they keep their cool and ususally get to the objective with time to spare. You can mod the turn timers out if you really are that lame and just want to spam overwatch for years.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												XCOM 2 is an excellent follow-up to XCOM : Ennemy Unknown and XCOM : Ennemy Within. The game is tense and heavy while also giving you a realm of possibilities when it comes to killing aliens. This time around, your soldiers are on the offensive, and as such, the way you start a mission and set-up an initial ambush on your ennemies can change the odds of a mission. Fortunately or not, things do not always go as planned and the RNG makes for an entertaining but sometimes frustrating game. Ennemies are varied and all troublesome in their own, special way, but your soldiers also feel more resourceful and powerful then ever. The relatively easy to procure Psi Operative Class is so versatile and potentially devastating that you'll always want to have one in your squad. The game can be a little rough around the edges and the mission timers can be a big source of stress, but with the possibility to mod the game to suit your style of gameplay, this point is almost moot. With a few updates from Firaxis and an ongoing mod support, this game could easily be remembered as a classic of PC gaming in the years to come.

This isn't a criticism, I'm loving every minute, I agonise about every build decision and every mission I choose.Plus it's nice to have a PC exclusive of this quality occasionaly.Absolutely love this game, (although it seems to enjoy making me suffer).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												Now it says I've only got 21 hours as of 09/02/2016 but if not for kids and a Job I would have likely had over double that since Thursday's 11pm release...Alien AI:The Aliens seem a lot more aggressive this time round, they will push for that flanking position not just hide in high cover taking pot shots. more melee chars and high HP of the soldiers (in the mid game) make choosing targets wisely the difference between a wounded squad, a depleted one or a dead one.The actual patrolling (Yes the aliens walk around the map when you are concealed not teleport) and reinforcements give extra flavour to the missions.Alien upgrades & Dark Events:These can give missions more much flavour. In EU/EW a sectoid always had 4 or 3 HP (Imp/Class) normal Advent troopers (The lowliest enemy) now have 8 hp when they start off at 4, gives the feeling that the aliens aren't just resting on their laurels while you bleed them.The Dark events are pretty nice too depending on which one you counter (You usually get the option to counter 1 a month) they can give the Aliens higher detection radius when you are concealed, give their troopers poison ammo or insert faceless ones into the civilians in normal maps not just terror sites plus many more that I really don't have the time to sit here and type up :)Customisations:Oh god yes, the basic amount you get for a rookie/squaddie already is more than EU/EW but they all unlock at Sgt level some people don't like this but me personally I only get invested in a soldier once its got a few upgrades and proven itself in battle so 4th rank seems like a fair point... Like I said though if you are one of those people that like customising your soldiers you already get more options for rookies than all the options in EU/EWMap Manipulation(Hacking and Destruction):The hacking is a pretty good mini "game" yes its chance based like firing a weapon but it can give a minor change to that map, like disorientating the enemy for 2 turns or it can raise your income on the continent you are fighting on permanently, it can also backfire and make enemy soldiers stronger too or alert all the aliens on the map to your position.Remember the invulnerable floors and ceilings from EU/EW that you wanted to make your soldiers armour out of! They are no more! You can happily waste your heavy ordinance on to bring them down... Pro tip, this is a good way to get rid of enemy turrets if you aren't going to hack them.I've read a few reviews now - just something to settle my itch for Xcom 2 between busy periods at work - and I seem to think people are playing an entirely different game to me.*Removed countering other peoples gripes as there is no point, other than fps issues, l2p*TL;DRProsAlien AI improvement over EU/EWDark EventsAlien UpgradesCustomisationsWeapon Mods Workshop Mods (This is a big one, don't like the timers in missions? Mod it. Don't like the lack of supplies early game? Mod it...)Increase in Difficulty over EU/EW ConsFPS DropsMinor Graphical/Animation GlitchesMission timers in 8/10 missions (Can be fixed with workshop mods!)Would be a solid 9/10 without the FPS drops & Load times which although don't affect gameplay that often are really annoying, but they are highly likely to be patched I couldn't not recommend this game based on drops in fps *At Times!* (Some people make out like its all the time, its not) and the "long" load times when entering/leaving missions (Its about 30 seconds)

content:

												Some may not like the turn based style. Some may not like the action point system. Some may not like the game mechanics  at all. I agree that the action point system could be better. I agree that some gamemechanics could be better.But none the less I like it.I like it because of the stories. No not the main plot though it is good. I mean the stories you and your soldiers forge in the heat of battle. I'm talking about the Heroes that give thir lives for the mission. the friend ships they form in your mind the bon chilling moments when your troops can see the end for their comrades and you know that they went home thinking about how they could have saved them.The game may not keep track of these things but you do. You know which squad members work best together not because of complimenting skills but because somewhere in the RNG they are a team and being there with each other gives them strength.Some of you may see this as mindless ramblings but others know exactly what I speak of. They know the joy, the pain, the anger, and sadness that these soldiers can experience in their journy to protect their families and liberate the world.So I salute these virtual heroes whose lives we lead straight into the gates of hell. May the fallen be remembered forever.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												If you played X-Com enemy unknown then you know what you are getting into.Similar gameplay as EU, some more customization options, more crazy aliens, etc.A lot of people seem to be complaining about the timer missions, but tbh it seems to be about half the missions have a timer, which is fine by me. You can't just take two steps and overwatch your way through every map (what some may call "tactics") and I enjoy the sense of urgency. People acting like Xcom is some detailed tactical simulator cracks me up, the only tactics in the game is cover and flanking. They're still there. Have fun!p.s. you probably heard performance sucks at launch. it's true. actual gameplay is fine, but lots of stuttering in cut scenes on a GTX 970.

												Xcom is back and it's baaaaaad. Ok mostly baaaaaad with some bad. Apart from the optimization issues which are varied, your mileage may vary, this game rocks. Apart from performance issues, weird camera angles and riding that mass effect elevator. I've only had one crash to desktop. With regard to the game itself, my only one real criticism is that the game has a small design, pacing issue. It throws everything and the kitchen sink at you. Can't go past a couple of hours on in-game time without some notice popping off. That needs is small fix. Life is stressful enough, no need to butter your customers with more stress. We get it, defending the earth is hard. Missions are tougher than ever and it's thoroughly enjoyable. Timers shooting off? Missing at 97% with a minute on the clock? This game is one stressed round after stress round.9/10 you lose one point for making me look at a butt while skull jacking an advent officer.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												So now that I've seen some improved performance through the most recent mods such as "Stop Wasting my Time" the game has vastly improved to where I now can recommend it. The reason it was a not recommended wasn't because of the gameplay reasons such as timers but due to all the buggy issues with the game.XCOM 2 is the next step in the Firaxis XCOM franchise. The game does a neat job of switching the roles where we are the invaders and some of these features really felt missing in the first XCOM. Concealmeant is without a doubt my favorite system in the game but I also love fighting against the high tier enemies. The thing about fighting a sectopod or a gatekeeper is that when you defeat one of those enemies, it feels great. There are some enemies that are very annoying that I think should've been scrapped and reworked (Stun Lancer for example) because they aren't fun to fight against early on. The story is a strategy game story, it's not supposed to have a Bioshock Infinite level of plot twists. There are a couple of references to the X-COM franchise (Terror From the Deep) but whether or not Firaxis will actually make a TFD I don't know.At $60 the game is currently enjoyable for XCOM fans but not so much for anyone else. The new player experience is pretty bad because they do not give you enough of an introduction to show you all the neat little things about the game. This will make it very hard for newcomers to actually play the game. Of course they can watch a tutorial which is what I would do but the game doesn't teach you how to play that much.Mods will also keep this game alive for a long time. I bet in about a year or so, we will see a Total Conversion Mod where the Rebels fight the Empire in XCOM Empire at War.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												Xcom 2 is an awesome game and raises the bar in squad tactical combat genre.The game has a great story line leading you deeper into the plot as you progress learning new things about the aliens and why they have come to earth.What is unique about Xcom 2 is that your every decision has an impact on your progress to rid the aliens from earth. You will often find yourself making many value judgements of which is the greater evil or most needed benefit of multiple choices of actions. For example when you counter dark events, do you choose the dark event based on the need for what the reward offers you or do you counter the dark event based on stopping the aliens from acquiring a benefit that will make them stronger. Sometimes you get lucky and you get both. When you embark on taking down the dark event are you bringing the right combination of soldiers, experience and equipment to get the job done?Another unique quality about the game is you get an emotional attachment to your soldiers and you find yourself picking favorites. You find some soldiers survive many missions and become powerful veterans while others look like they will last a long time only to see them killed in action. When you experience a loss you feel it in the game and emotionally.  For example, seeing your psi-op solider who just trained for a good month or more get wacked within three missions. You are not paying attention to how many turns your extraction window is and you have soldiers going missing in action. Or how about that unstoppable ranger or that long range sharpshooter who has been dealing death mission after mission and one day his number is up. This is something you must accept when playing Xcom 2 that your soldiers will fall in battle and when they fall you got to pick yourself up and move on without them toward victory.Another unique quality Xcom 2 offers is a constant sense of urgency. You are constantly under pressure. I find myself cursing at the operations guy whenever he opens his mouth telling me the obvious. For example, you may be on a retaliation mission to save a resistance camp. On this type of mission you have to weigh the balance between speed to cover ground quickly (in order to rescue civilians which will easily expose your soldiers to enemy fire) and moving cautiously putting your soldiers in over watch as you hear alien gunfire taking down civilians during a turn. If you move too fast your soldiers may become isolated without over watch support. If you move too slowly you may have over watch support but the civilians are getting massacred. Another pressure mission are the ones I call the “8 turn wonder missions”. You have 8 turns to hack a terminal, escort a vip to an extraction point or to destroy a data relay and all hell stands between you and the objective. Meanwhile as the firefight ensues back and forth, the ops guy pops in reminding you the short window of extraction is getting narrow. These are very challenging missions which can be accomplished but you feel pressure mounting as each turn your soldiers miss their shots, get injured and remain in the same vicinity exchanging gunfire as opposed to moving toward the extraction point.Then there is the pressure of the avatar project. The aliens move very quickly to build the avatar project and if they are successful, then you lose and its game over. Your first assaults on the avatar facilities will be based on your efforts to make contact with local resistance groups in order to land there and blow it up. However there are only so many facilities that are found via making contact and the rest of them you have find via skulljacking advent soldiers. Skulljacking is a daunting task especially when it comes time to jack a codex. Making contact and finding these facilities Is not as easy it looks because you have to manage your intel and your supply between either:  1) improving your soldier’s weapons and gear, 2) improving the avenger or 3) expanding over world finding contacts. While you are busy hustling to gather up intel and supplies the aliens are stacking up the avatar progress quickly.  Then there are those glorious moments during the game when ambushes execute flawlessly. Your soldiers are in the right place with over watch hitting their targets. The terrain feels natural as you watch your sharpshooters take down targets at long range perching from building or hilltops. Your rangers evade enemy overwatch slicing and killing their targets on one hit. Your specialist hack those towers to gain an immediate benefit or you take control of mech unit. Your psy-op soldier takes control of an archon who then lays waste to a group of advent troops. Your skulljack attempts don’t end up costing you soldier or killing target with over watch fire as your ranger stuffs that piece of metal into an advent soldier’s skull.Xcom  2 is a great game. If you like squad tactics using different soldiers with a variety of skills and abilities to take down enemies on many different terrains and environments with all kinds of weapons, ammo, explosives, armor and gear, then Xcom 2 is a must have game. I highly recommend it.

												This is a very good addition to the XCOM collection. There are a few nods to previous XCOM games, including a few to the sequel to the original. If you are not a fan of XCOM, you are not likely to think much of this. If you wanted to have more power, you are likely to be disappointed. In general, you are a bit weaker than you were in the previous games in terms of raw firepower, though you have some advantages not afforded to you as wel. It is not an entirely new game, but it is enough of a departure from XCOM Enemy Unknown/Enemy Within to satisfy those who want a good, novel version of XCOM.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												Now it says I've only got 21 hours as of 09/02/2016 but if not for kids and a Job I would have likely had over double that since Thursday's 11pm release...Alien AI:The Aliens seem a lot more aggressive this time round, they will push for that flanking position not just hide in high cover taking pot shots. more melee chars and high HP of the soldiers (in the mid game) make choosing targets wisely the difference between a wounded squad, a depleted one or a dead one.The actual patrolling (Yes the aliens walk around the map when you are concealed not teleport) and reinforcements give extra flavour to the missions.Alien upgrades & Dark Events:These can give missions more much flavour. In EU/EW a sectoid always had 4 or 3 HP (Imp/Class) normal Advent troopers (The lowliest enemy) now have 8 hp when they start off at 4, gives the feeling that the aliens aren't just resting on their laurels while you bleed them.The Dark events are pretty nice too depending on which one you counter (You usually get the option to counter 1 a month) they can give the Aliens higher detection radius when you are concealed, give their troopers poison ammo or insert faceless ones into the civilians in normal maps not just terror sites plus many more that I really don't have the time to sit here and type up :)Customisations:Oh god yes, the basic amount you get for a rookie/squaddie already is more than EU/EW but they all unlock at Sgt level some people don't like this but me personally I only get invested in a soldier once its got a few upgrades and proven itself in battle so 4th rank seems like a fair point... Like I said though if you are one of those people that like customising your soldiers you already get more options for rookies than all the options in EU/EWMap Manipulation(Hacking and Destruction):The hacking is a pretty good mini "game" yes its chance based like firing a weapon but it can give a minor change to that map, like disorientating the enemy for 2 turns or it can raise your income on the continent you are fighting on permanently, it can also backfire and make enemy soldiers stronger too or alert all the aliens on the map to your position.Remember the invulnerable floors and ceilings from EU/EW that you wanted to make your soldiers armour out of! They are no more! You can happily waste your heavy ordinance on to bring them down... Pro tip, this is a good way to get rid of enemy turrets if you aren't going to hack them.I've read a few reviews now - just something to settle my itch for Xcom 2 between busy periods at work - and I seem to think people are playing an entirely different game to me.*Removed countering other peoples gripes as there is no point, other than fps issues, l2p*TL;DRProsAlien AI improvement over EU/EWDark EventsAlien UpgradesCustomisationsWeapon Mods Workshop Mods (This is a big one, don't like the timers in missions? Mod it. Don't like the lack of supplies early game? Mod it...)Increase in Difficulty over EU/EW ConsFPS DropsMinor Graphical/Animation GlitchesMission timers in 8/10 missions (Can be fixed with workshop mods!)Would be a solid 9/10 without the FPS drops & Load times which although don't affect gameplay that often are really annoying, but they are highly likely to be patched I couldn't not recommend this game based on drops in fps *At Times!* (Some people make out like its all the time, its not) and the "long" load times when entering/leaving missions (Its about 30 seconds)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												34 hours in, playing on Commander "Classic" difficulty.  I highly recommend this game.This is a great game, but you need to go into it like playing poker.  You are going to make bets.  A good player makes good bets but understands that sometimes you can lose even when making the "right call."  This is why good players do not simply know who is more likely to "win" in a binary sense, but what is an appropriate amount to bet.  Along these lines, you must know when to raise, when to go all in, and when to fold.  Preserve your chips for when the odds are highly in your favor, risk little when they favor your opponents.This is one of the only games I have ever played that actually has an organic concept of a "phyrric victory," where you can literally lose the campaign by winning badly a couple times in a row.  A lot of people are complaining about the "mission turn counter," but I would tell you not to listen to these people.  Tight turn limits are an essential element in forcing a very interesting decision of how much you want to risk to achieve victory, and at what cost.For example, I suspect many players (including me) immediatly go for all the "output damage" talents on their soldiers in all cases.  However, later in the game accidentally pulling multiple packs is a deadly mistake.  Using scouting talents or soldiers allows you to push quickly toward an objective while reducing the risk of engaging in an unintended large fight.  And if that fight does, unfortunately, happen (as it sometimes will), you have a choice to make: pull the squad out immediatly, or win the fight with heavy wounds?  This is not a game where just winning is enough.  How you win matters, and the tactical level is intimately tied to the strategic level in this regard.There are some annoying technical issues, but they have not impacted my play experience.  YMMV.This game is hard, but it is fair.  Furthermore, it is a game where the computer AI is a worthy opponent and doesn't cheat, which is IMO a huge accomplishment for a turn based strategy game.  If you are the kind of player who loves turn based games for their slower, "thinking man" style but is frustrated by the lack of fair challenge out there, you are in for a treat with this one.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												I've been playing the X-com series since the origional was a demo back in the 90's, and couldn't wait to lace up my alien stompin' boots and save the Earth all over again.  I have to say I am very happy with the results.  From the new story line, to art direction, character customization and of course the workshop modding community, this is a worthy new chapter for the franchise.Until you experience the delicious joy of the Rube-Golbergesque chain of events following a perfectly executed (or horribly botched) ambush you can't even comprehend what you are missing.  Explosions!  Fires!  Collapsing buildings!  Alien Bewbs!  This game has it all.  As of writing this the game has been out for nine days, and this is the earliest I've been able to rip myself away from it long enough to write a review.  As with all X-com titles expect an inexhaustible level of replayability.  Saving the world from alien invasion is not the kind of thing anyone wants to do just once.  It begs to be played over and over again in ever stranger variations of play style.  Make a team of kill crazy explosive experts, or all snipers and one covert scout.  Maybe a team of unarmed psychics.  The world's your oyster, go crazy.This game is not without its detractors for sure.  Many are claiming to have problems with running the game on their systems, but aside from the Skyranger travelling to and from a mission in what seems to be real time, I can't complain on performance.  I beleive the delay is due to the computer building an entirely new randomly constructed map for the mission, so I find it hard to complain over something so cool.  Plus the delay isn't experienced if I load a save game mid mission, just on generation of the map, so small annoyance.  Keep a novel on hand, or take time to do those annoying human requirements like eating and visiting the little commander's room during these times.  Maybe you'd also like creating dialogue for the operatives as they sit on the long flight to and from battle.  If you are confident about your computer's performance specs you will probably be fine.  If you have any doubts about your setup there is a very real chance you will end up disatisfied until the inevitable patch release.  Personally I couldn't have waited any longer for this game to come out.  If I had to wait another month for full optimazion to be completed I might have gone insane.  For me any reservations I had were gone the first time I launched a tox-grenade into an unsuspectiong squad of Advent Troopers.  Oh sheer joy.

content:
Posted: April 4
												This is XCOM:EU but a lot better. They took the "if it aint broken don't fixt it" route but changed enough things to make the game feel fresh. The most interesting design decision in my opinion is that they made the combat mechanics more complex but at the same time they didn't overload the player with dozens of equipment choices. For every new piece of equipment that they added they removed an old one that wasn't that fun or balanced to use. This way the player doesn't feel like he is overburdened with choices and the game retains it's tactical but also calm gameplay that I love. On the techincal department, I didn't come across game breaking bugs but I did come across some slight performance issues (when using certain abilities that leveled buildings) but nothing too serious, I may be lucky.

content:
Posted: January 11
												I'll start this off by saying that I've not experienced any gamebreaking bugs or crashes while playing on this machine.  Performance is wierdly inconsistent but is playable.  I can't speak to the experience that others will have.With that out of the way, this is not a good XCOM game, it's a great game, truly fantastic, but it's not a good XCOM game.  That's okay though, the original UFO defense is one of, if not my favorite games of all time.  I own it on multiple platforms and play Openxcom to this day.Where UFO defense was heavily minimalistic mechanically, with most actions following the same set of rules, XCOM 2 has a great variety of additional features.  This gives this game many more areas in which it can fail or seem unpolished, the complexity and volume of unique mechanics being staggering. This isn't always a bad thing, although balancing certain things equally becomes difficult.  This gives you a greater degree of control and customization as regards units, equipment, and tactics.  Your XCOM is very much your XCOM.  In UFO defense your XCOM had very much a mind of its own, soldiers wouldn't advance how you would like, the missions were unfair as♥♥♥♥♥♥ and the main objectives seemed to consciously evade you.XCOM2 does not have that personality, but as a game it is far more "playable" than UFO Defense.  You don't need a master's degree in patience and risk management to finish it, and some degree of randomness is removed.  XCOM2 is a handcrafted experience, like a fine Oak table, whereas the original is like a very nice tree that decides to grow through your living room.It is an excellent tactics and management game, perhaps the best of this generation.  I feel that it is almost a disservice to both games, UFO defense being the other, to link them.  This game is unique, well crafted, challenging, and playable.  I very much recommend it.

												ivey waited over half a year for this game and now that i have it.... im honestly disapointed, to start out with the game was 80$ and took up 25 gbs of storage, i thought that must mean the that the game was about 2 and a half enemy withins.... but the game was short and the levels didnt have that much varieity, i can look at this game and say that i dont see an 80$ game needing 25gbs of storage, i see a 8-10gbf game costing at most 50$, im still trying to figure out where the other 15gbs are in this game, another tjhing i didnt like was that you had to always play be the games time, in enemy within there were several points where you could do as you please and continue when you were ready, and dont worry about the roumers they are all true and i hate that, i mean its nice but unrealistic, there are also fewer enemies and fewer recearch to do, im pretty sure you can beat this game in under a day if you rushed, the psi operitives is also a bad touch because, personally i prefered it when it was an add on and not its own class because to fully train them it takes forever, this dosent mean i hate the game, it means that if i had to choose i would pick enemy within, with this game i expected about 7 classes, around 11 new alien spicies fighting alongside the original ammont, more unique soldiers, more unique missions, and more combat mechs at your disposial and an evil campaign where you play as the aliens, they dilivered almost none of that, in the end i say if they added more missions, got rid of the avatar project or at least have more build up to it and better ways to combat it, got rid of the constant timer, added new aliens, added an evil campaign and added more classes then the stock options then it would be a great game, but what was dilivered was a game that gose right between decent and good, nothing more, nothing less, if there was a neutral option id use it but im stuck with saying that its good.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												I must admit I was a little cautious about the new canon for this game coming from Xcom:EU but now it looks like a stroke of genius.  You get to stay rooted in earth based tech at the beginning and the path of discovery that is the core of the game is still intact but with new gear and new takes on familiar enemies.Apart from quality of life changes such as the LoS indicator when previewing move positions, buttons to make gear and weapons available when equipping soldiers pre-mission etc, there are also new mechanics such as the concealment system allowing you to start a mission on your terms (usually).  The soldier customisation is back and extensively expanded along with upgraded stylised graphics that really bring you into the dystopian version of earth in the not too distant future.The mission timers that most missions have are not to everyone's tastes but you can mod them out if wanted.  Personally I think they really do add to the game as they are carefully balanced to give you enough time but not too much, assuming you play in an agressive fashion.  If you try to spend your turns doing overwatch creep to try and spring the perfect ambush, yes, you're going to run out of time and pay the price.  Don't do that.  Watch Beaglerush on twitch or youtube to see the sort of approach you need to be taking.There are still some glitches left, but nothing that I've found to be game breaking so far even on Ironman.  Overall this is a legendary game and well worth your time, unless you really hate turn based games.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												Finished XCOM 2 today and can't recommend the game enough to those who enjoyed XCOM:Enemy Unknown/Within, or turn-based strategy.Like the previous XCOM, the start of the game can be quite brutal and unforgiving if you don't keep pace with the aliens. I've only just recently played the previous XCOM, so i'd learnt from my mistakes in that game that you have to upgrade weapons/armour ASAP - otherwise you'll just be roasted. Because of that, I didn't have much of a problem on the normal (vertern) difficulty. If you do, don't be afraid to just restart the game and optimise your research/builds/combos better. Once you get past that initial hurdle and have a solid rotation of soldiers, the game feels like it goes down in difficulty. I didn't have any problems past the first 2 or 3 hours until the final level - which is challenging/completely insane IMO. I thought I had got better at turn-based strategy, but that mission just sat me in a corner and explained that this wasn't the case.I finished the game after 43 hours. I'm sure you can do it in less time, and replayability is definitely there. I'm also looking forward to seeing what mods/updates come out for this! Definitely worth the purchase, even at full price IMO.

Posted: February 14, 2016
												XCOM 2 does everything that XCOM 1 did correctly.The problem with the game is that it doesn't do much else.The new classes are fun and intuitive. I enjoy the new mechanics. The story, as far as XCOM games go, is good. Better than the first in that regard.The issue is it just. doesn't. do. very many new things. It feels a lot like the first game. Which is fine, because the first game was great, and honestly I'm not sure what else they could have done.Overall, yes, it's worth the price of admission. You'll find yourself wanting to play this one over and over again, just like the first. I can only assume that once the DLC is online, we'll be getting a game that surpasses XCOM and it's expansion.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												Since it seems to be peoples main issue with this game, id like to say IM RUNNING A BUDGET PC AND HAVE HAD NO PROBLEMS. The only thing that isnt 4 years old is the graphics card. I've got an i3 3.2 ghz, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ motherboard, 4 gb DDR3 and then a GTX 960 and SSD. The game did not crash a single time in my play through and the few times a weird situation came up that caused the animations to get confused, the game would time it out and recover beautifully. Back to the main review.XCOM EU/EW was probably my favorite game. The sequel didn't dissapoint in any way. That's a hell of a tall order. Intense and satisfying gameplay and story. It also manages to pull a half-life two and paint a picture of a fascinating new world after the world changing events in the first game. Most series just try and sweep those enormous events under the rug but XCOM 2 embraces them and does so very well.If I try hard i can come up with a few complaints. I miss shooting down and attacking UFOs, through the whole game I was only able to attack 2 but it was like christmas each time. It's a little hard on my 4 year old budget processor so the load screens take a little while. And every now and then a unit animation goes wonky (but then completely recovers every time). It's a beautiful game though, and it's turn-based nature means that it's pretty on even moderate hardware. I'm not sure that I could have come up with less consequential complaints. Maybe the fact that I wasn't a big fan of a main characters hair style. Or the fact that this one important alien suit has these weird mittens that bug me for no reason.I can't think of a game I'd recommend more than this one.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												If you have played Xcom: Enemy Unknown and enjoyed it then be prepared for a lot of the same intense fun with the old alian apocalypse. I personally haven't completed the game, but I feel as though I have seen enough to tell you folks that this game is surely worth the buy if you enjoy tactical games such as Fire Emblem, Final Fantasy Tactics, and/or Chess.It is very deliberate with its ironman mode like fire emblem; it has percentage calculating "to hit" measures based off many variable factors like final fantasy tactics; and has great strategical appeal that rivals Chess. The pieces are mostly the same, but position and timing are everything. If you like the difficulty like that of dark souls, you can find it here. The only thing this game really needs now though is for the modding community to completely overhaul it to the terminator theme, just for added appeal. In Xcom2 it would really work. John Connor defeating the machines and all.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Entery date: February 18, 2016I felt this needed to be added. If you buy this game, be aware that the legendary "to hit" calculations are very false. Over the course of 20 games I calculated the probability of missing shots 50% or above. I found that on average I was missing shots at a 50% hit rate nearly 6 times in a row on a constant basis on the first mission sometimes happening twice in one play through. I was playing ironman and every game was a fresh start because the system requires that work around. The resulting probability of it occuring twice in the same game is roughly 10000 to 1. now keep in mind that these are misses 50% and above being calculated at exactly 50% so the probabilities of these kinds of misses are infact much much lower... Anyway, missing 6 times in a row was a common occurance but, before the odds become astronomically slim like my results are showing ill tell you the probability of missing 6 shots consecuitively on 4 different occassions: 99999947/53... That's next to a nill chance... however, this had occured a grand total of 15 times. So, either I'm the unluckiest person in the world or this system is completely broken and false at the legendary level.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												I am a big fan of the XCOM seires. From the origional with the TU, to the remake with AP.GAMEPLAY:XCOM2 is a refinement on the 2012 remakes origional intentions. The biggest change is that eveything has been rethemed with the idea that XCOM is now a rouge faction with limited support.This minor change makes most of the unpopular changes from the origional really cool. Enemy pods, limited mission selection, and smaller squads, make a whole lot more sense now. Not to mention that the stealth system got a complete overhaul.STORY:I also really did not like how the 2012 remake ended. This Game retcons a lot of that in some pretty cool ways.For the most part you are going to be creating your own stories. War stories.Overall a really solid game if you are a fan of turn based squad tactics.There are some bugs, but most of them are visual and dont affect gameplay.

Posted: February 14, 2016
												I'm gonna write two reviews, one for those who already played XCom-enemy unknown and one for all new players who have never heard about Xcom and want to jump in right into xcom2.For those who have already played Xcom1:The game is great! Gameplay speaking it's a wider, better XcomEU. There are a lot more game mechanics, finally the overwatch isn't broken and it's basically the same formula but with more breadth. If you loved Xcom1 you will love Xcom2. I admit the story is not as engagin as the first xcom, probably because it lost a lot of the "mistery" sorrounding the abductions and the discovery of your enemy. But you should absolutely get this game.For those who never played Xcom1:go play Xcom1, it's a great game, there is no point in jumping in Xcom2 if you never plaied Xcom1. Do yourself a favour and play Xcom1 first!Overall:- great game- a few bugs here and there but nothing game breaking- a lot of hours of gameplay10 out of 10, must buy!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												If you enjoyed over watching your way to victory in Xcom Enemy Unknown then Xcom 2 will be something of a culture shock.  You really cannot afford to rest on your laurels when the resident alien force outnumbers and outguns you severely in the early stages. I found it surprisingly punishing on normal difficulty compared to its predecessor.The tactical game play remains intact; there’s better mission variety, a more involving narrative, better soldier customization, randomly generated maps, a wide variety of aliens and weapons and on the whole it’s shinier, prettier and more difficult. There’s already a substantial number of mods available on the Steam workshop so if you’re not keen on those timed objective missions (of which there were a lot) or fancy a new hat  your needs will be met.A word of caution however because the game really would benefit from some bug fixing and better optimization. No-one likes crashing to desktop Firaxis; not even the aliens.

												I have played the original UFO: Enemy Unknown, and love that game. I also have XCom: Enemy Unknown and have sunk many hours into that game too, and found it very enjoyable. content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												Played through the campaign on commander difficulty in about 40 hours, very few reloads. Aside from some graphical glitches, I only encountered one bug: the chrysalid save game breaking bug (fixed in the first patch). Ive heard a lot about performance issues, but have not had any trouble. The game runs smoothly on my 2 year old game PC.I like most of the changes and new features. Missions with limited turns force you to adapt your playstyle (slightly) and the new classes are quite nice for this. The avatar project bar in the world map may seem threatening, but in reality, it's pretty easy to keep under control. The dark events, however, can have a big impact, which is pretty cool.

												If you have played any of the classic X-Com games, or XCOM: Enemy Unknown, give this game a try.  It is, in this players humble opinion, a worthy entry into the franchise.  I haven't played it with the Paid DLC, but have installed the mods from Long War Studio, which adds value but I'm starting to feel some of the mods dilute the experience. content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												I loved playing this game, even with it's numerous glitches and performance issues. (i7 and 970 GTX, 16gb of ram and still struggled) It was a vast improvement over Enemy Unknown which I loved also, but there's one issue that is keeping me from writing out a long and glowing review. Hopefully it's fixed ASAP, because it was just a crushing turn of events for me. I get to the final mission, it's pretty late at night so I decide to save and go to bed, continuing my ironman campaign the next day. Wrong, I go to load the game this morning and it crashes every time I load the game. As this is Ironman mode I have no other saves, and I literally have to restart the game to finish it. Not sure what causes the issue, but to people that do buy it, be wary of saving on the last mission especially if you're on Ironman.EDIT 2/17/2016: First big patch was released today for the game, it fixed the glitch I had and my game was loadable! I had since moved on and started a new game, accepting it, but it's great to see Firaxis hard at work. My FPS seems to maintain at a steady 60 now as well on High settings due to the numerous performance fixes they deployed. 9/10 would recommend now that the gamebreaking bug is fixed.

												If you have played any of the classic X-Com games, or XCOM: Enemy Unknown, give this game a try.  It is, in this players humble opinion, a worthy entry into the franchise.  I haven't played it with the Paid DLC, but have installed the mods from Long War Studio, which adds value but I'm starting to feel some of the mods dilute the experience.  Since I haven't actually completed the game yet (I move too slow on the critical campaign objectives,) my personal recommendation would be to avoid too many mods until you have finished a playthrough without them. All is well now :)

												Played through the campaign on commander difficulty in about 40 hours, very few reloads. Aside from some graphical glitches, I only encountered one bug: the chrysalid save game breaking bug (fixed in the first patch). Ive heard a lot about performance issues, but have not had any trouble. The game runs smoothly on my 2 year old game PC.I like most of the changes and new features. The avatar project bar in the world map may seem threatening, but in reality, it's pretty easy to keep under control. The dark events, however, can have a big impact, which is pretty cool.

content:
Posted: April 4
												This is XCOM:EU but a lot better. They took the "if it aint broken don't fixt it" route but changed enough things to make the game feel fresh. The most interesting design decision in my opinion is that they made the combat mechanics more complex but at the same time they didn't overload the player with dozens of equipment choices. For every new piece of equipment that they added they removed an old one that wasn't that fun or balanced to use. This way the player doesn't feel like he is overburdened with choices and the game retains it's tactical but also calm gameplay that I love. On the techincal department, I didn't come across game breaking bugs but I did come across some slight performance issues (when using certain abilities that leveled buildings) but nothing too serious, I may be lucky.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												34 hours in, playing on Commander "Classic" difficulty.  I highly recommend this game.This is a great game, but you need to go into it like playing poker.  You are going to make bets.  A good player makes good bets but understands that sometimes you can lose even when making the "right call."  This is why good players do not simply know who is more likely to "win" in a binary sense, but what is an appropriate amount to bet.  Along these lines, you must know when to raise, when to go all in, and when to fold.  Preserve your chips for when the odds are highly in your favor, risk little when they favor your opponents.This is one of the only games I have ever played that actually has an organic concept of a "phyrric victory," where you can literally lose the campaign by winning badly a couple times in a row.  A lot of people are complaining about the "mission turn counter," but I would tell you not to listen to these people.  Tight turn limits are an essential element in forcing a very interesting decision of how much you want to risk to achieve victory, and at what cost.For example, I suspect many players (including me) immediatly go for all the "output damage" talents on their soldiers in all cases.  However, later in the game accidentally pulling multiple packs is a deadly mistake.  Using scouting talents or soldiers allows you to push quickly toward an objective while reducing the risk of engaging in an unintended large fight.  And if that fight does, unfortunately, happen (as it sometimes will), you have a choice to make: pull the squad out immediatly, or win the fight with heavy wounds?  This is not a game where just winning is enough.  How you win matters, and the tactical level is intimately tied to the strategic level in this regard.There are some annoying technical issues, but they have not impacted my play experience.  YMMV.This game is hard, but it is fair.  Furthermore, it is a game where the computer AI is a worthy opponent and doesn't cheat, which is IMO a huge accomplishment for a turn based strategy game.  If you are the kind of player who loves turn based games for their slower, "thinking man" style but is frustrated by the lack of fair challenge out there, you are in for a treat with this one.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												I've been playing the X-com series since the origional was a demo back in the 90's, and couldn't wait to lace up my alien stompin' boots and save the Earth all over again.  I have to say I am very happy with the results.  From the new story line, to art direction, character customization and of course the workshop modding community, this is a worthy new chapter for the franchise.Until you experience the delicious joy of the Rube-Golbergesque chain of events following a perfectly executed (or horribly botched) ambush you can't even comprehend what you are missing.  Explosions!  Fires!  Collapsing buildings!  Alien Bewbs!  This game has it all.  As of writing this the game has been out for nine days, and this is the earliest I've been able to rip myself away from it long enough to write a review.  As with all X-com titles expect an inexhaustible level of replayability.  Saving the world from alien invasion is not the kind of thing anyone wants to do just once.  It begs to be played over and over again in ever stranger variations of play style.  Make a team of kill crazy explosive experts, or all snipers and one covert scout.  Maybe a team of unarmed psychics.  The world's your oyster, go crazy.This game is not without its detractors for sure.  Many are claiming to have problems with running the game on their systems, but aside from the Skyranger travelling to and from a mission in what seems to be real time, I can't complain on performance.  I beleive the delay is due to the computer building an entirely new randomly constructed map for the mission, so I find it hard to complain over something so cool.  Plus the delay isn't experienced if I load a save game mid mission, just on generation of the map, so small annoyance.  Keep a novel on hand, or take time to do those annoying human requirements like eating and visiting the little commander's room during these times.  Maybe you'd also like creating dialogue for the operatives as they sit on the long flight to and from battle.  If you are confident about your computer's performance specs you will probably be fine.  If you have any doubts about your setup there is a very real chance you will end up disatisfied until the inevitable patch release.  Personally I couldn't have waited any longer for this game to come out.  If I had to wait another month for full optimazion to be completed I might have gone insane.  For me any reservations I had were gone the first time I launched a tox-grenade into an unsuspectiong squad of Advent Troopers.  Oh sheer joy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												Had a ton of fun playing through this game, the kind of game I was itching to keep playing and progress in. The XCOM games are highly unique in the way they make every decision absolutely crucial, which in turn makes it incredibly exciting. It's likely that the chance aspect of the game will tick you off at times, but after a while you'll learn how to keep the odds in your favor, and with a dozen missions under your belt, and wisely using the available equipment, you'll be killing aliens left and right without them even touching you.I recommend not abusing saves. This will substantially increase your immersion and enjoyment of the game, making you feel like your decisions are that more important. Stick with your decisions and your mistakes unless it's too devastating. For me personally, I only retried one mission twice, near the beginning, where my whole squad was either killed or MIA. Other than that I suffered through bad decisions, killed soldiers and unecessary injuries, when they occurred.I'm hearing a lot about technical issues with this game.. poor performance, bugs, glitches. When it comes to performance I frankly didn't expect much from my aging rig, with a GTX 660. So with the game running as well as it did, I was more than satisfied. This is also a game that doesn't need a high framerate, giving how it's played. Bugs, glitches or technical issues I hardly noticed, except for once, when there were so much happening on screen it brought my computer to its knees. Maybe I just got lucky, or the worst issues were patched before I started playing.All in all, I can't recommend this game enough. A really unique experience that keeps you on the edge of your seat, caring about keeping your soldiers alive like no other game does. For me it doesn't have much replayability right now, but the close to 50 hours I got out of it was a blast. I'll definitely be back if this game gets a significant expansion, the way Enemy Within was for the previous XCOM.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												There is nothing like a game where humanity must work together to survive some kind of apocalypse. In this xase its a small group of resistance fighters which most of you probably know as XCOM. This game greatly builds off XCOM: Enemy unkown, giving you much more options for customizing your squad, you can choose from a plethora of colors and camo's, the new classes are well designed and alot of fun to play. One of my favorite things about this game though is that i have been playing for 47 hours and i still havent seen the same map twice. Im sure this is due to the randomly generated maps. One more thing to love is the day one mods, which was released along with the game. XCOM 2 has your expected story and does it much better then any of the other games, with great cutscenes that are fun to watch.Some things i feel this game could improve on though, something thats not extremely bother but more of a nuisance is the loading times for some missions seems to take a bit. Then you have the problem with the extremely bad lag when playing multiplayer, you will end your turn and the next person will have to wait almost 30 second more before actually taking theirs. And one last thing i have noticed about this game is a audio bug that happens often enough to warrant a fix.All in all I have 47 hours in this game and with the few drawback i stated it dosent take away from the game enough to not pick it up. I expect to have many many more hours of great fun on this game. If your if about it and liked the older games this is definitely something your going to wanna get.

												Basically a slightly better version of X-com EU/EW (which is already a phenomenal game) with a few new mechanics and a new story, and a lot harder across the board (I was only a few short days away from losing the game at one point).  If you haven't played EU/EW then play that first, but if you liked EU/EW, this is a must have.Some people have complained about framerate problems: I'm running it at max settings on a GTX 980 and I am having some small framerate issues, mainly during cinematics, but the game is completly playable.My biggest con is that there are no truely new classes, they just renamed the ones from EU and give them one or two new abilities. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												X-Com 2 hits all the right notes for a sequel to 2012's X-Com Enemy Unknown. It improves the combat, adds a ton of customization and the story is much more interesting.There were a bevy of bugs during my first playthrough though, including: Enemies just stop attacking until I restarted the game (even after going on to another mission), enemies shooting me through the floor and other LOS issues, and squad abilities not working correctly (the sniper's cone of fire ability just didn't work sometimes). Also, despite having a beefy computer, I ran into various performance issues at 1440p. What X-Com 2 does right, it does wonderfully. Tons of customization, improved combat, better classes with more defined (and varied!) roles, and a sense of foreboding provided by the story which ties the experience together.My first playthrough had a sense of desperation to it, I was barely holding everything together when  the Avenger defense mission happened. I lost a lot of soldiers, but it actually helped my rookies level-up, which became a turning point for me. I really can't wait to see what DLC they release, and I am even more excited for what the modding community has in store.

												Fantastic - a further improvement on the previous XCOM's wonderful tactical combat engine combined with a geoscape strategy perfectly hybridizing Terror from the Deep's alien base hunting and UFO: Aftershock's networkbuilding (and flying base!) There are still bugs that need to be ironed out (though I only had two in 50hrs of gameplay), and I'm hoping for a new set of Second Wave difficulty/gameplay customization options, but it's tuly great game.In fact, my only negative reaction is to the title! There are easily a dozen other UFO games, none of which have a number - shouldn't this one really be called XCOM: ADVENT or XCOM: AVENGERS?

												My first impressions of this game were mostly frustration given the countdown clocks on missions and the avatar meta-game timer. It drove me crazy. A must buy for any fan of turn-based action strategy games

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												This game has good basic gameplay that can keep you entertained for quite some time. For anyone who played XCOM enemy unknown this is the same thing with only smaller changes. The changes that has been made however are not for the better. They have for example this turn-timer (you have a certain amount of turns to finish the mission). This takes away a lot of the tactics of going in slow to make a perfect surprise attack. It forces you to run and gun a lot. They’ve also made sure that you have to hurry with the story missions as well or you’re doomed. This makes the psi-soldiers nonexistent. I made only one and never used her. I saw when I finished the game that the overall amount of psi-warriors for a playthrough is 1. ONE! The game is too short and rushed to make you feel a good change (a big difference) in gameplay from beginning to end. It’s more or less the same throughout but with more grenades and more hits towards the end. The character creation has been developed a lot. Sadly it’s only cosmetic. They’ve stuck to professions instead of letting every character be unique with their own mix of abilities and weapons. Also, why not more fun abilities? Even if you want to keep the professions they should of made more of them.I will keep this short. Do you want a solid turn based tactics game and you’ve already finished enemy unknown, then this game is for you. It’s fun. Do however not expect a better or even equal experience as enemy unknown. PS: It works on Linux!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												If you enjoyed Enemy Uknown/Within, you're going to like this. It's more of the same but tweaked and changed so it keeps the best while improving on weakness and trimming the fat. It also introduces new elements into the old formula to spice it up, so being experienced with EU/EW is a false sense of security. It took me 58 hours and 3 failed games to finally win on normal difficulty.Familiar enemies have progressed and improved in the wake of the alien victory, presenting new challenges. World/base management has also stepped up consideradbly- where EU/EW boiled down to "bum rush your satellite production, win game", here you are more engaged by active counters, lurking UFOs and a doomsday countdown that will WRECK you until you've learned from your failures (more on that in a bit)Character customization and generation is more in depth than ever, so you'll feel even more aguish when your soldiers get critted by some jack-off Muton WHICH IS ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T BTWSo in my personal experience, I would reccomend it. BUT SOME THINGS TO CONSIDER:------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  I find the new soundtrack somewhat lacking. It's not that it's bad,  I just think it lost some of the personality that Michael McCann (guy who did the Deus Ex HR soundtrack) brought to EU/EW. Mods can and will remedy this though.- The game can be buggy. For me it's mostly been inexplicable pauses that slow the pace, but some people report some serious issues with LOS. Your mileage may vary. - If you hate time limits...I got some bad news for you. Mods will remove these if they transcend 'challenging' and wind up just ruining the game for you, though.- BEWARE THE "ALIEN HUNTERS" DLC. This is my only objective complaint. This DLC is nonsense that at best will put a new player against an even more uphill battle, and at worst will render your game unplayable through game crashes. Save your 10$, you've been warned. -----------------------------------------------------------DEATH TO AYY LMAOS

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2016
												Can I recommend this game YES, can i highly recommend it YES.I wrote a negative review last time, but after about 10+ month of waiting for a patch that fix the shooting/looking though walls bug, then it seem like after latest patch that the game now play much better.Well If read this, then you properbly already know Xcom series and how to play this turnbased strategy game.But be aware this game work in a little different way.On the big world map you now have a flying base from start-end in the game. You fly from country to country setting up radio towers to earn funds for your operation of xcom. What is pretty cool is that everytime you start a new game then everything is random so the replay value is fantastic, also the battles never play out excactly like last time, since the enemys are also random selected depending on your tech level and how far you are in the campaign.You will without a doubt encounter enemys you already know from the series, but there are also some new ones that you love or hate.  ( properbly hate since they kill your men he he )All in all you will fly arround the map all the time completing random missions that variate from capture vip, to protect resistance HQ against enemy raid..  Sometimes you also get special missions that can alter the course of the campaign. Example you get 3 missions to choose from that all effect what you get out of it different.Example do you want a scientist in reward, you want money, or maybe you want that a hidden event will not happen.Be aware the game take a little time to understand how the new features work and how you move arround on the tactical world map, but once you learn the rules of the game and so on then it is actual pretty good if not excellent.The game AI i think is pretty good and is indeed a challenge. They will assult/run away or maybe flank you.The shooting animation and detail of the graphics are excellent as well.As you know the game is all about research and getting better gear to combat the aliens, and well you are in for a long journey.. There are allot of tech, and in this new xcom game you can even put extra gadjets on your weapons so they become more powerfull or precise.. Why not give you soldiers some armour that if enemy try to thouch you set them on fire... quite handy when one of the anoying snake aliens want to cuddle with you.I recommend that your first campaign will be the most easy level, even if you are experienced.. The game is quite tough, and there it take a little time to learn how the new game work.Well what are you waiting for, BUY IT..... 10/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
												It is the final days of the resistance. Advent forces have discovered the location of the Avenger and have launched a full frontal assault. All XCOM operators defending the ramp have had their weapons disabled by a Codex. However, the resistance was not going down without a fight. They engaged the hostile forces with honor and dignity.Miraculously, the resistance managed to defeat Advent at the Battle for the Avenger without the loss of a single life. But there was still one more problem, the Avatar Project was nearing completion, and they had not made contact with the area where an Advent research facility was located, which would have to be destroyed in order to delay the project.Resistance Comms was constructed, supplies were received from a supply drop, and contact was made with Western Europe, the location of the research facility. But the aliens completed the Avatar Project, and the countdown to the end of humanity began. There was no more time to prepare, the Resistance had to act now.An elite squad of XCOM operatives, led by Colonel Lukas "Junior" Bekker, launched a covert operation with 1 objective; destroy the research facility. The squad of 6 soldiers deployed into the woods surrounding the facility, fought their way through Advent forces, and reduced the facility to rubble. Not one XCOM operative was lost that day. The destruction of the research facility dealt a major blow to the Avatar Project, which bought more time for XCOM to make contact with more regions to destroy more facilities. Will the resistance succeed in defeating the aliens? Probably not. But like they did in the Battle for the Avenger, they can hope.In XCOM 2, the real story comes from your own gameplay experiences. and everyone's will be different.

content:
Posted: February 24
												The second XCOM remake, while keeping with the themes and general setting of the originals, still manages to stand on its own with the increased depth of its tactical gameplay and considerably more fleshed-out story and characters. Not to mention the visuals alone make it a first-class title. There's definitely a lot more customization options now, and skill trees are a little less linear, with substantially more game-changing skills available per class: XCOM 2 is no longer the war of attrition of its predecessors, and to me that was very refreshing.All this being said, experience with the first remake or previous XCOM titles is recommended to appreciate the genre better and watch the progression of story and foes (indeed, you might be in for a surprise if you fight certain enemies without understanding of their previous forms, such as Viper, Crysshalid, or Sectopod), but is not required, as characters, reports, and general story progression synopse all the major plot points of Enemy Unknown.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11
												I'll start this off by saying that I've not experienced any gamebreaking bugs or crashes while playing on this machine.  Performance is wierdly inconsistent but is playable.  I can't speak to the experience that others will have.With that out of the way, this is not a good XCOM game, it's a great game, truly fantastic, but it's not a good XCOM game.  That's okay though, the original UFO defense is one of, if not my favorite games of all time.  I own it on multiple platforms and play Openxcom to this day.Where UFO defense was heavily minimalistic mechanically, with most actions following the same set of rules, XCOM 2 has a great variety of additional features.  This gives this game many more areas in which it can fail or seem unpolished, the complexity and volume of unique mechanics being staggering. This isn't always a bad thing, although balancing certain things equally becomes difficult.  This gives you a greater degree of control and customization as regards units, equipment, and tactics.  Your XCOM is very much your XCOM.  In UFO defense your XCOM had very much a mind of its own, soldiers wouldn't advance how you would like, the missions were unfair as♥♥♥♥♥♥ and the main objectives seemed to consciously evade you.XCOM2 does not have that personality, but as a game it is far more "playable" than UFO Defense.  You don't need a master's degree in patience and risk management to finish it, and some degree of randomness is removed.  XCOM2 is a handcrafted experience, like a fine Oak table, whereas the original is like a very nice tree that decides to grow through your living room.It is an excellent tactics and management game, perhaps the best of this generation.  I feel that it is almost a disservice to both games, UFO defense being the other, to link them.  This game is unique, well crafted, challenging, and playable.  I very much recommend it.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												Had a ton of fun playing through this game, the kind of game I was itching to keep playing and progress in. The XCOM games are highly unique in the way they make every decision absolutely crucial, which in turn makes it incredibly exciting. It's likely that the chance aspect of the game will tick you off at times, but after a while you'll learn how to keep the odds in your favor, and with a dozen missions under your belt, and wisely using the available equipment, you'll be killing aliens left and right without them even touching you.I recommend not abusing saves. This will substantially increase your immersion and enjoyment of the game, making you feel like your decisions are that more important. Stick with your decisions and your mistakes unless it's too devastating. For me personally, I only retried one mission twice, near the beginning, where my whole squad was either killed or MIA. Other than that I suffered through bad decisions, killed soldiers and unecessary injuries, when they occurred.I'm hearing a lot about technical issues with this game.. poor performance, bugs, glitches. When it comes to performance I frankly didn't expect much from my aging rig, with a GTX 660. So with the game running as well as it did, I was more than satisfied. This is also a game that doesn't need a high framerate, giving how it's played. Bugs, glitches or technical issues I hardly noticed, except for once, when there were so much happening on screen it brought my computer to its knees. Maybe I just got lucky, or the worst issues were patched before I started playing.All in all, I can't recommend this game enough. A really unique experience that keeps you on the edge of your seat, caring about keeping your soldiers alive like no other game does. For me it doesn't have much replayability right now, but the close to 50 hours I got out of it was a blast. I'll definitely be back if this game gets a significant expansion, the way Enemy Within was for the previous XCOM.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												There is nothing like a game where humanity must work together to survive some kind of apocalypse. In this xase its a small group of resistance fighters which most of you probably know as XCOM. This game greatly builds off XCOM: Enemy unkown, giving you much more options for customizing your squad, you can choose from a plethora of colors and camo's, the new classes are well designed and alot of fun to play. One of my favorite things about this game though is that i have been playing for 47 hours and i still havent seen the same map twice. Im sure this is due to the randomly generated maps. One more thing to love is the day one mods, which was released along with the game. XCOM 2 has your expected story and does it much better then any of the other games, with great cutscenes that are fun to watch.Some things i feel this game could improve on though, something thats not extremely bother but more of a nuisance is the loading times for some missions seems to take a bit. Then you have the problem with the extremely bad lag when playing multiplayer, you will end your turn and the next person will have to wait almost 30 second more before actually taking theirs. And one last thing i have noticed about this game is a audio bug that happens often enough to warrant a fix.All in all I have 47 hours in this game and with the few drawback i stated it dosent take away from the game enough to not pick it up. I expect to have many many more hours of great fun on this game. If your if about it and liked the older games this is definitely something your going to wanna get.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												Since it seems to be peoples main issue with this game, id like to say IM RUNNING A BUDGET PC AND HAVE HAD NO PROBLEMS. The only thing that isnt 4 years old is the graphics card. I've got an i3 3.2 ghz, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ motherboard, 4 gb DDR3 and then a GTX 960 and SSD. The game did not crash a single time in my play through and the few times a weird situation came up that caused the animations to get confused, the game would time it out and recover beautifully. Back to the main review.XCOM EU/EW was probably my favorite game. The sequel didn't dissapoint in any way. That's a hell of a tall order. Intense and satisfying gameplay and story. It also manages to pull a half-life two and paint a picture of a fascinating new world after the world changing events in the first game. Most series just try and sweep those enormous events under the rug but XCOM 2 embraces them and does so very well.If I try hard i can come up with a few complaints. I miss shooting down and attacking UFOs, through the whole game I was only able to attack 2 but it was like christmas each time. It's a little hard on my 4 year old budget processor so the load screens take a little while. And every now and then a unit animation goes wonky (but then completely recovers every time). It's a beautiful game though, and it's turn-based nature means that it's pretty on even moderate hardware. I'm not sure that I could have come up with less consequential complaints. Maybe the fact that I wasn't a big fan of a main characters hair style. Or the fact that this one important alien suit has these weird mittens that bug me for no reason.I can't think of a game I'd recommend more than this one.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												I am a big fan of the XCOM seires. From the origional with the TU, to the remake with AP.GAMEPLAY:XCOM2 is a refinement on the 2012 remakes origional intentions. The biggest change is that eveything has been rethemed with the idea that XCOM is now a rouge faction with limited support.This minor change makes most of the unpopular changes from the origional really cool. Enemy pods, limited mission selection, and smaller squads, make a whole lot more sense now. Not to mention that the stealth system got a complete overhaul.STORY:I also really did not like how the 2012 remake ended. This Game retcons a lot of that in some pretty cool ways.For the most part you are going to be creating your own stories. War stories.Overall a really solid game if you are a fan of turn based squad tactics.There are some bugs, but most of them are visual and dont affect gameplay.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												If you enjoyed over watching your way to victory in Xcom Enemy Unknown then Xcom 2 will be something of a culture shock.  You really cannot afford to rest on your laurels when the resident alien force outnumbers and outguns you severely in the early stages. I found it surprisingly punishing on normal difficulty compared to its predecessor.The tactical game play remains intact; there’s better mission variety, a more involving narrative, better soldier customization, randomly generated maps, a wide variety of aliens and weapons and on the whole it’s shinier, prettier and more difficult. There’s already a substantial number of mods available on the Steam workshop so if you’re not keen on those timed objective missions (of which there were a lot) or fancy a new hat  your needs will be met.A word of caution however because the game really would benefit from some bug fixing and better optimization. No-one likes crashing to desktop Firaxis; not even the aliens.

												Xcom: enemy unknown was honestly the game that made turn-based games fun for me. I have a solid 200 hours of JUST campaigning, most of it on impossible. I was honestly very surprised about how jazzed up the combat was on xcom2. It's much much different, the game forces you out of turtling and start running for dem objectives. Which i honestly don't mind, just gotta adapt abit. Xcom2 is also changed into a combat based game. Base management is less important but provides bonuses and fun stuff to play with. The game has alot of bugs, i feel they rushed the release abit. Gremlins fly underground, occasional frozen enemy turns. The worst bit honestly the intro and the outro for me the video was delayed and the voice appeared before the video :SIt needs a bit of modding tbh. WHICH IS GREAT BECAUSE IT HAS MODDING SUPPORT! Which is honestly one of the highlights.MODDERS: Please make Anime faces, naked person decals, Asain language (Why doesn't this exist?) and sky combat. It's bound to happen so just be first :P Overall: I enjoyed it, it's pretty brutal good for dem xcom vets. As for new people, not too sure, maybe take off mission timers? (Which a mod is already made.) Game seems pretty bare bones with some pretty nice features. Seems like there's lots of room to improve upon, hope we get some fine♥♥♥♥♥modders on the case and they flesh it out. Would give solid 8/10
