												XCOM 2 is a great game-having just finished it I have yet to decide whether or not I like it more than its predecessor, EU/EW. Honestly, if you are new to the franchise, go back to the original (from Firaxis) and give that a try: the games are awfully similar, and the EU is less expensive. Also, since XCOM has a pretty dedicated fan base, it will provide a good basis for questions and forums. Just like any other game, there are pros and cons. Fortunately, most of the cons are mostly bugs and will likely be addressed and fixed very soon. ProsMost of the pros are based of of EUa) enemy will have a crosshair if your soldier moves into targeting range, indicating whether you can attack from a specific locationb) more dynamicc) definitely more map variety-however, some of the missions do still seem pretty similard)good strategy level too-not just tacticale)good replayability-choices are always difficult and making different choices will lead to different resultsConsbuggya) small things that are also found in the EU like poor slowmo shotsb) larger issues like not being able to see another floor or move somewhere on the mapc) mediocre story lined) FPS drops and lag. e) long load times

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												Unlike XCOM1, where you had a fighting chance, to beat this game requires save scumming (or modding). While Bentley will insist you need to 'review your tactics' at the end of a failed mission, no amount of tactical play will stop the aliens from one shotting your troops through cover. This is complicated by a buggy UI that will indicate one thing, but then something else happens. Like getting hit with status effects (running through fire, acid, poison) and being spotted are not always indicated. Also, a genade's damage radius can be often misrepresented causing you to destroy a mission objective. I've had a hack objective get destroyed because I threw a grenade over it. Camera transarency glitches and other things that cause your troops to move to locations you did not intend further this issue.The game seems to let you know from the very start that you should expect casualties. OK, Firaxis. If that's the case then why can't I get more troops? I start with 9, early in the game you can get recruits for free(I got 2). A few missions later (2 died to one-shot crits through cover, 1 died to burning that the game didn't tell me I would get when I moved, 1 got one-shot by an exploding car). Now I've got 7 total, with 4 wounded. Can't even field a full squad anymore and I'm only 5 missions into the game. The game is filled with design contradictions like this. Expect to lose troops, but don't have any good means of replacing them (50 supplies is a lot for a recruit, and more than you have to spare). Time the missions, but moving quickly almost always results in an unfavorable situation. Fail a mission? Now you get reduced income from the resistance in that area. Complete a mission? I hope it was worth the bodies you had to sacrifice. As you progress, the game just stacks the negative consequences against you repeatedly until you can just forget about even playing. Because now you don't have enough troops, don't have gooed enough weapons, and don't have troops leveled sufficiently.Parts of the game are tedious and time wasters. Bentley will constanly tell you what's blatantly obvious. The camera will constantly hover over the objective when you get near it (even though it's marked from the beginning). It's just dumb how much time is wasted and how irritating it is to have to listen to and watch pointless stuff when you just want to take your turn.I have also found that the game forces you to play a certain way. In XCOM1, you spammed satellites. Now, you have to spam communications upgrades. If you don't, you will end up unable to get to mission areas and losing. Also, certain classes are much better than others. I would put specialist as the weakest in combat (but they can provide nice bonuses). Snipers are versatile if you go the pistol route, but otherwise can slow you down. Grenadiers are epic and can do some great AOE. Try dropping an acid grenade on a flare before reinforcements arrive and watch the aliens stand in place for 3 rounds as they don't want to get the debuff for moving through those tiles. Rangers seem to do the highest single target damage and can be essential to take down high hp targets. I've heard that snipers can do really well with high ground.Yes it seems to be poorly optimized (disable bloom, SSAO and AA helps). I have yet to crash, though. I can live with some minor graphical glitches and a some performance slowdowns for reaction shots. The camera can act up as well, but that's just another annoyance. The thing that is frustrating is the incosistent manner in which some tactical notifications are given. The detection while stealthed for example, can incorrectly show a spot as being safe to move to (even though you can see the alien that spots you before you make the move). The notification icons for burning, poison can decide not to show up. I've had aliens be invisible on the map, even though troops can target them (also more irritating than game-breaking).Bottom Line: wait for some mods to come out that fix game balance a bit (I like the one where you get to start with 1 engineer and 1 scientist), wait for a bug fix patch, and then get it on sale.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												XCOM 2 is the successor of XCOM Enemy Unknown / Enemy Within, a reboot of the original X-COM game. XCOM EU/EW suffered from a few problems. In short, the game was too easy and too repetative. This was fixed by a mod called The Long War. With XCOM 2, the developer has listened to the community, they even hired mod developers. This game is exactly what you would want to expect from an XCOM game!Pro's:  + Random generated maps  + Wider variety and more complex mission strategies  + In-depth game strategy  + Great graphics and soundtrack  + Full customizable characters that can be saved, exported and imported. Make your friends and have them killed on the battlefield  + Highly moddable. Within a week of release over 200 mods were available. Mods do not disable achievements.Neutral  o High learning curve and high entry level. This is what is expected from an XCOM game (learning by trial and failure), and any hard-core turn-based strategy gamer (like me) likes it that way. But if you are more of a casual gamer, you may find the lack of information on how to play the game, and failing many missions, frustating.  o A lot of missions are based on a turn timer, i.e. finish the game within a limited number of turns. Not everyone may like it. If you don't like a turn-timer, you can disable it using one of the mods. Con's  - Poor game optimization. For best performance, turn of anti-aliasing, lower shadow quality and turn of action camera.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												It's XCOM2 !   If you liked XCOM EW you will like XCOM2.Graphically it is a much enhanced game.  Maps are more open, colorful, and varied with lots of sparkly effects. Some groups of enemies have patrol routes, which makes for a more interesting tactical experience. Timed objectives occur more often - though not with the frequency those complaining about them would have you believe.New soldier skills have been added, and some modified to liven up combat.  Rangers carry a blade for close combat and sharpshooters are now the only pistol carriers.  Both these classes acquire specialized skills for these weapons.Altering soldiers' visual appearance and history has reached a new high.  You can write their bio, change their country of origin, and accessorize - with more options opening up as they level.   You can even color and name their weapons.  On the down side, the base physical features of each race seem more homogenized and less country specific. Lots of attention to small graphical details has been taken throughout the game.   Soldiers have grim, tense expressions flying to a mission, and cheerful, relieved expressions flying back.  The intro loading screen will pick a soldier on your roster ( in their current gear ) and show them spying on an Advent position. You can give your soldiers cigars and cigarettes, earrings, scars and tattoos.  The downside of all this graphical goodness is that it comes at a price.  If you've been nursing along an older computer system with infusions of RAM and a slightly better graphics card,  you may not be satisfied with how the game runs. There are a lot of options in the graphics setup, so it is possible to find a setting that is bearable on an older system,  but it won't be pretty and frame rates will stutter on some weapon effects.Before XCOM2 i've been playing XCOM EW with the Long War mod.  While XCOM2 is definitely an improvement over the base XCOM EW, I have mixed feelings on how it compares to the Long War modded version.  Graphics aside, more different than better. ProsGraphically improved.More varied maps and missionsNew soldier skillsInvolving storyConsHefty system requirementsNot fully optimized for performance.If you liked XCOM EW  and your computer can handle the system requirements, definitely give XCOM2 a go.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												I've beaten the game. Awesome!  I love it.....but I am a fan of x-com since the original Ufo: Enemy unknown in the 90's came out.Let me be absolutelly straight with you. If you're a new to X-com, this will be a brutal experience. You will likely lose your first campaign, or three. And I'm not talking legendary difficulty. You'll get your♥♥♥♥♥handed over to you on normal. You will watch your soldiers die and missions fail.But that is the point. This is the dark souls of the strategy games. It is a challenge. A true gauntlet testing your will, resilience, ingenuity and ability to learn. It is always an uphill battle. You will never be in comfortable position of power. Enemy has more troops, stronger units and economy.This game will not pamper you as they are trying to tell you straight in the tutorial sequence. I will reccommend the game but the final decision is yours - do you have what it takes to save humanity?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												XCOM 2 is actually a terrific game, I at first was not sure if I was going to enjoy it or not, the timers being part of it, and the lack of individual targeting areas, and the different if not also similiar format. After playing the game for several hours, I realized that I did in fact love the game, the combat is enjoyable, the upgrades are fun, the story is exciting, and to be quite honest, I actually like the timers now that I have played with them on. Rather then taking things slow, becoming incredibly risk adverse, and loading up on medkits like I did in XCOM: Enemy Unkown, I've had to change my playstyle up.Now every single person has some sort of explosive, with my specialists using their gremlin heals, Snipers, being almost the worst class in the first XCOM of this decade, have made a come back with some really amazing abilities and tactics, and every class has a use now that can't be replaced in this very aggressive and high-risk high reward combat style that I have been forced to adopt.XCOM 2 is an amazing game because of what it is on it's own. The game itself is different enough from XCOM that it doesn't feel anything like an expansion, yet nearly everything in the details has a comparable element in XCOM, the gameplay, even though it's based on the same concept and same rules, is entirely different, yet it is still so fun that I personally can't stop playing the game.Performance wise the game runs well for me, and it runs on max settings for me with only minor framerate losses in various cinematic parts. I heavily reccomend this game to anyone who enjoys XCOM style gameplay, as long as they are open enough to understand that just like in real life, tactics have to change with time and the situation.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												In comparsion to its predecessor this game is for me clearly an improvment, with a few drawbacks.I restarted the campaign 2 times, because I made some early mistakes. But now I am pretty late game, fighting against monstrous Sectopods and Gatekeepers with an almost fully equiped Squad (altough i do hope i did not reach the end of the research  tree, with one research left). The good things:For me each time a new enemy appeared was like a new challenge (besides the avatar that one was strangely easy).Each with their own strenght and weaknesses.This games rewards Tactics. Ive read that some ppl complain about timers. And i do agree the first time I saw those timers i rushed and almost lost my entire squad. Now I take some time in the beginning (obvious not too much) for a good positioning and a good engage which gives you enough time to finish the rest of the mission leisurely. Now i almost always have 2-3 sometimes even 4-5 rounds left before finishing those missions. Lots of customization, not just looks but gameplay changeing. Want a heavy front line ranger with heal? Get those heal armor with a w.a.r suit bladestorm and untouchable. Or a more stealthy approch with Wraith Suit its crappling hook and Phantom?  Change weapons parts for extra shots bigger mags higher aim and so on.Psi. I love psi. and its OP. Mindcontroll those heavy Gatekeepers? check.And i love those new Specialists. In my opinion one of the biggest changes to xcom. Ranged heal and hacking.Heavy Sectopod killing your squad? Hack it!Ranged heal allows for a more spreaded approch without being in risk that your frontline warrior cant be healed.Great replayability. Each playthrough will have other missions/strarting place so you need to adapt to what you get.The not so good:Lack of freedom. I would love to have really easy and really hard missions from the beginning. Right now Enemy strenght evolves with your own, which doesnt make sense for me. It would be much better if there would be lightly guarded remote post to attack. Or those big Strongholds with many guards and advanced Defenses and the player would have the choice when to attack which place.Now i have my standard squad and if one gets hurt 2-4 reserve Soldiers to swap out, greatly reducing my power, You could say thats my fault because I focuesed too much on my squad. but on the other hand, i knew each mission will be harder and i picked the best for it. If i would have the choice to attack an place that isnt that much of a problem i could use some rookies to give them expirience. And not to forget you cant really decide were to attack. Mostly you get 3 choices from which you can choose one and thats it. And mostly you choose those mission because of their reward. And late game you most likely will pick Supplies because thats what you need most.No optional fights. Ok you could say you dont need to fight each mission but not doing one is in general a really bad idea. Loosing supplies/scientists/engineers/intel no exp gain and so on. And if you cant do mission because all you soldiers are hurt i would strongly suggest you restart the game.

												I've beaten the game. Awesome!  I love it.....but I am a fan of x-com since the original Ufo: Enemy unknown in the 90's came out.Let me be absolutelly straight with you. If you're a new to X-com, this will be a brutal experience. You will likely lose your first campaign, or three. And I'm not talking legendary difficulty. You'll get your♥♥♥♥♥handed over to you on normal. You will watch your soldiers die and missions fail.But that is the point. This is the dark souls of the strategy games. It is a challenge. A true gauntlet testing your will, resilience, ingenuity and ability to learn. It is always an uphill battle. You will never be in comfortable position of power. Enemy has more troops, stronger units and economy.This game will not pamper you as they are trying to tell you straight in the tutorial sequence. I will reccommend the game but the final decision is yours - do you have what it takes to save humanity?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												It's XCOM2 !   If you liked XCOM EW you will like XCOM2.Graphically it is a much enhanced game.  Maps are more open, colorful, and varied with lots of sparkly effects. Some groups of enemies have patrol routes, which makes for a more interesting tactical experience. Timed objectives occur more often - though not with the frequency those complaining about them would have you believe.New soldier skills have been added, and some modified to liven up combat.  Rangers carry a blade for close combat and sharpshooters are now the only pistol carriers.  Both these classes acquire specialized skills for these weapons.Altering soldiers' visual appearance and history has reached a new high.  You can write their bio, change their country of origin, and accessorize - with more options opening up as they level.   You can even color and name their weapons.  On the down side, the base physical features of each race seem more homogenized and less country specific. Lots of attention to small graphical details has been taken throughout the game.   Soldiers have grim, tense expressions flying to a mission, and cheerful, relieved expressions flying back.  The intro loading screen will pick a soldier on your roster ( in their current gear ) and show them spying on an Advent position. You can give your soldiers cigars and cigarettes, earrings, scars and tattoos.  The downside of all this graphical goodness is that it comes at a price.  If you've been nursing along an older computer system with infusions of RAM and a slightly better graphics card,  you may not be satisfied with how the game runs. There are a lot of options in the graphics setup, so it is possible to find a setting that is bearable on an older system,  but it won't be pretty and frame rates will stutter on some weapon effects.Before XCOM2 i've been playing XCOM EW with the Long War mod.  While XCOM2 is definitely an improvement over the base XCOM EW, I have mixed feelings on how it compares to the Long War modded version.  Graphics aside, more different than better. ProsGraphically improved.More varied maps and missionsNew soldier skillsInvolving storyConsHefty system requirementsNot fully optimized for performance.If you liked XCOM EW  and your computer can handle the system requirements, definitely give XCOM2 a go.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												If you've played a X-Com game on anything above easy or normal, keep in mind that the difficulty is increased for X-Com2. The difficulty on Veteran level is closer to Classic. If you liked Long War, you'll find the combat to be more challenging. The four initial classes are diversified based on soldier perks to more resemble the eight class system of the long war system. This is a refined mechanic that allows you to customize your soldiers greatly.Performance wise, on two year old built computer, the game ran smoothly with no hiccups.The shooting through walls animation issues have been greatly reduced between 1 and 2. Tactically, you have far more options than X-COM EW or EU. Waypoints are essential for sucess. You can use them to avoid many situations that would otherwise break your squad.Overwatch is still a key mechanic but there are many times you will take the risky option to get to the objective and you will fail. Every shot will miss, beause of the order you took them in. This is okay, the war is not over yet.There will be the one time everybody makes the shot against incredible odds and you go home with a everyone alive. Treasure it.This game will make you sob when your squad gets wiped out in one turn because you misjudged pod locations and triggered four of them. But your small squad of soldiers will go down fighting, and the war against the aliens will go on.Your small band of soldiers is doing their best to save the planet and there will be casualties along the way.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23
												Story20 years have passed since the events in XCOM: Enemy Unknown and humanity has fallen under alien control. The once supportive council nations have sided with the new alien government during the height of their invasion. Using an administration known as Advent to become a disposable source of manpower, the aliens make an aggressive campaign to earn obedience and loyalty with earth's population. Harsh crowd control tactics and an abundance of Advent propaganda are utilized to invoke fear across the globe. With immense government funding they are a force to be reckoned with, in regards to both manpower and military equipment.XCOM has become an almost forgotten remnant of the past, leaving many to wonder what the future holds for the human race. However, Resistance forces have burrowed themselves into small pockets of the world, working tirelessly to overthrow Advent and fight for what was once their's. With little resources and time, a small squad of resistance forces act on newly provided Intel. This lead suggests a possible location for a tremendously important figure that is being held in an Advent facility, the Commander. Once rescued and revived from a medically induced cryo-sleep, the player (taking on the role of The Commander) is briefed on the current state of Earth. With a shell of what XCOM once was, you must gather resources and individuals loyal to the cause and restore XCOM to it's former glory. Technological advancements and utilizing your soldiers abilities to the fullest are the foundation for success, but strategic planning and careful military tactics are what it's built on. Expand the reach of the Resistance by aiding smaller Resistance forces, and set back Advent's development of a mysterious weapon known as the Avatar Project by completing important assignments and destroying key Advent facilities.GameplayXCOM 2 is a turn-based tactical strategy game that is in a league of it's own. Never before have I played a game that has bestowed so much weight in every decision you make. On masterfully designed multi-level maps that are almost entirely destructible, soldiers are controlled like chess pieces with a limit to how many actions they may perform, or tiles they can move. With limited vision of your surroundings, every enemy encounter can be in the players favor through already established defenses, or brutally devastating by enemy flanking maneuvers and abilities. The presence of perma-death only adds to the tension of enemy engagements, and ending your turn pits your tactics against an intelligent and equally lucky AI.Concealment is the latest and greatest feature, allowing you to enter missions undetected and grants you the ability to ambush your enemies. Solid defensive placement and foreknowledge can be the difference between a devastating blow to Advent forces or a fatal backfire. In addition, a multitude of weapons, armor, and utility items are at your disposal, assuming you researched the necessary criteria and had the required supplies. As well as new and useful abilities that give your soldiers a major advantage on the battlefield, granted you use them correctly.What flaws are to be found in XCOM 2 however are incessantly apparent. (For Enemy Unknown veterans they may come at no surprise.) These include shots and abilities making contact through walls and objects, hanging animations in certain circumstances following Overwatch shots or soldier placement, numerous instances of clipping, and obscure lines of sight that are both infuriating and laughable. Now these are not game-breaking by any nature but they are certainly a nuisance. Furthermore, they work both ways so while you may be victim to some quite frankly BS shots, you too may find yourself with the same unfair advantage.User interface and camera controls work well throughout the majority of the game, in small instances though they can be incredibly temperamental. One wrong click can mean the difference between short or high cover, spotted or concealed, dead or alive, so it's aggravating when action keys are click-through if a friendly soldier is nearby or when travel routes get finicky when rotating the map.When not in combat, time is of the essence as Advent will make slow but steady progress to completing their Avatar Project. If they do, you have a short amount of time to attack a facility or complete specific objectives that stagger it's construction. A great deal of missions are time sensitive as well, requiring the player to make aggressive advancements and react accordingly to enemy reinforcements. Even without a turn/time limit, every action and choice comes with a reward or consequence and XCOM 2 does a great job at making you aware of the result. Tense combat situations, challenging AI and enemy variants, and an immense amount of player freedom and customization. SoundXCOM 2 offers as much depth in the sounds and music as it does in it's gameplay. Music is triumphant in success and shattering in defeat. Sound effects are appropriately fitting to each circumstance whether it's gunfire and explosions or destruction and animations. Aliens come to life with intimidating battle-cry's and soldiers express their panicked state or wounded cries in disconcerting fashion. Dialogue and voice acting is dramatic but not over the top. A satisfying blend of military criticality  as well helpless emotions when things take a turn for the worse. Cinematic scenes are enjoyable both visually and aurally, however (and maybe this was a bug) facial animations noticeably lacked movement when soldiers communicated their understanding of each order.GraphicsFor a game that doesn't need to be graphically beautiful to attract strategy enthusiasts, XCOM 2 is stunning. The amount of detail in the environments, models, armor and weapons, visual effects and lighting are astounding. In what's simply an isometric plane comprised of tiles and levels, it is filled with so much character and tone that it comes to life the moment you touch down. Combat animations resemble movies in the re-positioning camera and the surroundings crumble and shatter from forceful explosions or enemy movement. Unfortunately, detail like this comes at a price. My gameplay experience maintained solid framerates for the majority of the play-through. Key word majority, guess-timating that atleast 30% of my time was spent wtaching frames drop to as low as 24FPS and then right back up to 60. These occurrences were almost always during cinematic moments, whether it was in or out of combat didn't matter. Destructible environments make for a great gameplay mechanic but when it's framerate teeters back and forth regardless, more ground clutter and visual effects only hurt performance more. Luckily these instances don't take away much from the gameplay itself, but become immersion breaking with frequency. (Ultra on 2560x1080 - i7 6700k / GTX 980 ti)Replay ValueArguably infinite, nearly pattern-less. While most missions follow a similar formula for enemy locations and objective markers, the breadth of possibilities is so vast that you're never experiencing the same fight twice. On a global scale and even inside combat enemies behave intelligently and pose a threat to your entire Resistance. (And existence!) Procedural map generation and spurts of luck make for endless possibilities both good and bad. The options for squad loadouts and soldier variety can be the difference between a flawless victory or crushing defeat.Wrapping UpA must play. XCOM 2 delivers a challenging experience that leaves you tugging your hair when things go South and exhaling massive sighs of relief when they go right. Despite it's buggy nature and clunky performance, solid strategic gameplay kicks it into sixth gear to overshadow it's imperfections. In a genre polishing checkers, XCOM 2 is reinventing chess.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2
												Upfront TL;DR: I recommend XCOM2 to anyone who is remotely interested in strategy/tactical rpg games and does not mind a few hiccups in optimization.It is like a sci-fi Fire Emblem without anime cutscenes and support convos (all that waifu♥♥♥♥♥♥ and adds good graphics and destructible environments. XCOM2's plot is the classic Good vs. Evil with some philosophical drops of "we are becoming what we set out to destroy".The real story, however, is the success and failure of XCOM agents under your command. BTW If you can't play a game without your precious waifus then download a voice pack for them and add them to your character pool. Pretty sure there are a bunch of neptunia heads and voice packs in the workshop. See, everyone's happy. Introduction:     This review is tailored for those who have not played any iteration of XCOM, so that it better informs those interested in trying the game out. Before continuing, I want to say that mods are a double edged sword in this game. They enhance play and decrease performance at the same time (subscribed to 300 atm). I cannot deny the fantastic additions graced to XCOM2 by the modding community, but I hope to review the ideas and concepts that the vanilla version succeeded/failed to accomplish on its own.Specs: i7-6700K @ 4.00GHz (4.36GHz)16 GB RAMGTX 1070 Pros: +The ability to extensively customize your soliders contributes a sense of attachment to  soldiers you are ordering around, something most games cannot emulate. +Map generation is very well designed/balanced so that the same tileset/area can offer many different avenues of play. +Configurable settings via the xcom ini can further modify play, leading to more replayability. For example, you can change the base stats of every character/item in the game if you wanted.+There is some base management, but it is not too extensive and does not feel tacked on just because "every other game has some form of it" (the original XCOM had this too).+Combat is interesting and offers different approaches to problems through the soldier class system, plethora of researchable gear, and destructible environments. +The emphasis on limited time (in combat and on a macro scale) to rebel against Earth's alien overlords provides a sense of urgency that many games strive for yet miss. +Your soldiers and the aliens become stronger as the game goes on, which creates a sense of each side trying its hardest to defeat the other. +Countless workshop mods offer something new and exciting to experience through multiple playthroughs.  +There is an ironman mode (Only one save state) for tryhards. Variable difficulty as well, which is good for new players. +A game that discourages facerolling over every button on your keyboard. Cons:-You have to realize this game has its optimization issues.  -Loading screens can be long, depending on your settings and how many mods you decide to download. I think the base game does not have this problem as much as a heavily modified one. -Frame rate drops slightly when discovering enemies, unloading from your transport, and initializing props to customize your soldiers with. These frame rate issues, however, can be easily ignored since they only occur at specific points in the game and do little to hinder the gameplay itself.-Do not play at max settings, even the best rigs will have trouble stabilizing at that golden 60fps.-Due to the nature of XCOM2, it being quite a long game, these problems seem to be more apparent later on when there are simply more characters in a given mission (larger squad size, more enemies, etc.). -There are not many gameplay elements that I feel XCOM2 failed to deliver on, but indeed there are many annoyances within the vanilla version that have either been patched already or allieviated by the free mods inside the workshop. Conclusion:     So if you do buy the game and see something that is offputting, check out the workshop to see if a solution has already been distributed.More than likely if you see something as a problem, someone else has too.      This concludes my review of XCOM 2. If you made it this far, then congratulations on either scrolling fast or reading.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2016
												In the beginning, this game and me had...issues. Now we've sorted it out though, and...well, I have other games.Anyway, this one differs from the first game in the sense that here you're gonna be under time preassue for some of the missions. Move with haste and you're all good. This game also plays out on the assumption the aliens pulled off their invasion of earth, and now it's time for "Le resistance" (say it out loud with a french accent).Come the higher difficulty levels, you have to realize you have to beat the game. Relying on 90% hit chances to save your day (or night) won't work, what it'll do is give you an actual headache instead. When things come together though it's beautiful, Once you manage to sort that out, your beefy operatives will slice through aliens as there was nothing to it, and this is one of the true joys of this game:It starts out tough, just like you'd imagine it would be to start a resistance movement, but once you've gained momentum, you really get the sensation you have them on the run. You put them on their heels, you're at their rear nagging, and just waiting for them to shout out the all familiar "E.T. phone home" in dispair.On top of that, it's very nicely made, a beauty to watch. I strongly recommend this game, and urge you to give it some time. Don't worry, it won't mind you having other games on the side.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												In the desert of a year filled with misleading marketing, broken releases, and disappointing games, XCOM 2 is an oasis.  When people look back on 2016, most of its titles, inde and AAA alike, will have been forgotten either for their mediocrity or out of the shame for having purchased them.  But not this one.Those who enjoyed XCOM: Enemy Unknown will find XCOM 2 well worth their money, time, and attention.  If 2K can continue to do work this good with the series, then it will take its place among the best franchises of gaming.  They really have done that well with it.The continued story remains true to the franchise, the objectives structure is familiar yet novel enough to entertain, the worst of the bugs and awkwardness from the last title are gone, the expanded mechanics and features are flawless.  It is a rare treat to get to play a game like this, and an absolute pleasure to praise work of such high quality.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2016
												XCOM 2 is a good turn-based game -  I recommend it!GameplayYou race around a map in a very massive aircraft, collecting resources, and taking on missions.  These missions involve shooting aliens.  A large number of missions have timers (which adds a level of difficulty).  If your dudes and dudettes survive, they get more beastly.  You spend lots of time researching and building gear for your soldiers and watching them mend in the hospital after they got shot up in the last mission.  In said missions, Sometimes your soldiers really suck and you get so incredibly furious.  Other times, they totally rock and you well with pride.  There is also a big timer that works against you all game, but I found it pretty lax.  The Proving Ground (a buildable facility) throws an element of randomness into the game by never knowing what the heck those engineers will actually come up with for you (special ammo, grenades, body armour, etc). SquadI really got attached to the squad members in this game. I loved customizing them, changing voice sets, nationality, gender's, etc, to make the right set of killer dolls.  The number of reloads due to key team members biting the bullet was high.  I like the classes available for squad members, of which there are five, each with two skill options to decide between on level up.  The psionic class (unlockable by building a facility), has a nice feeling of power and can really rock the alien's world when fully trained.DifficultyI have played all the XCOM's to date and feel that perhaps XCOM UFO Defense (the oldest) was harder, but not by much (and my memory may be failing me, that was a while ago).  I played it through on normal, but had to turn it down to easy on two missions (which felt like cheating, but it was easier!).  Good on ya if you can play it on harder modes, although I didn't try them.BugsIt certainly has a few bugs, but none prevented me from accomplishing anything and at worst made me reload a save.  Mostly, they ocurred in the form of odd misclicks with the UI, a team member not getting off the dropship at mission start, terrain issues, squad members looking but not acting alive when they had been nuked by an alien, etc.  Nothing too important.Time to WreckI took my time, but it was around 35 hours or so from start to finish.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 5
												XCOM 2 has a soft space in my heart. I've tried the first XCOM, I mean, the REAL first XCOM. As much as the die-hard fans rave like rabid dogs about how amazing it is, my simple, casual, millennial mind simply can't sit down and grasp how it works or how to put up with god awful graphics (and trust me, I've played stuff like Populous, so I've got some resistance compared to my generation.)When I first found XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Within, I had literally no idea what I was in for. What I found was a great "Dress up these people and make them fight aliens" strategy game I immediately fell in love with. Making everyone look like celebrities was my best choice, and having secret agent Ben Affleck kick doors down whilst Jeremy Renner did wierd magic stuff was just hilarious.So, I was stoked for XCOM 2. Despite my usually harsh view on the videogame industry, I even pre-ordered a couple of weeks early, I was so damn excited.On launch day, I was... satisfied?XCOM 2 is buggy, feels somewhat unfinished in some areas, with some oversights included and overall loses a couple of elements of strategic depth for more "Pfft, that's XCOM"-ness I was growing somewhat tired of. That being said, I still adore this game. The graphical upgrade is immense, and my soldiers look sillier than ever thanks to the impressive range of mods available for this game. Even in vanilla, this game still entertains me. XCOM 2's take on top-down strategy gets me immediately feeling like a strategic genius when I manage to get a grenade thrown through a wall to tear down cover for someone else to take a shot. Despite it's bugs, flaws, and it mistakenly thinking that everyone who plays it will spend six hours on every mission like some sort of chess grandmaster, playing on a lower difficulty to get to grips with the game and just having some fun with the characters makes XCOM 2 a worthy sequel to it's predecessor, building on the lore and gameplay of the first, elevating the stakes and making you feel that much smarter when grenadier Michael Bay blaster launchers an entire house to dust.MICHAEL BAY!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												Unlike XCOM1, where you had a fighting chance, to beat this game requires save scumming (or modding). While Bentley will insist you need to 'review your tactics' at the end of a failed mission, no amount of tactical play will stop the aliens from one shotting your troops through cover. This is complicated by a buggy UI that will indicate one thing, but then something else happens. Like getting hit with status effects (running through fire, acid, poison) and being spotted are not always indicated. Also, a genade's damage radius can be often misrepresented causing you to destroy a mission objective. I've had a hack objective get destroyed because I threw a grenade over it. Camera transarency glitches and other things that cause your troops to move to locations you did not intend further this issue.The game seems to let you know from the very start that you should expect casualties. OK, Firaxis. If that's the case then why can't I get more troops? I start with 9, early in the game you can get recruits for free(I got 2). A few missions later (2 died to one-shot crits through cover, 1 died to burning that the game didn't tell me I would get when I moved, 1 got one-shot by an exploding car). Now I've got 7 total, with 4 wounded. Can't even field a full squad anymore and I'm only 5 missions into the game. The game is filled with design contradictions like this. Expect to lose troops, but don't have any good means of replacing them (50 supplies is a lot for a recruit, and more than you have to spare). Time the missions, but moving quickly almost always results in an unfavorable situation. Fail a mission? Now you get reduced income from the resistance in that area. Complete a mission? I hope it was worth the bodies you had to sacrifice. As you progress, the game just stacks the negative consequences against you repeatedly until you can just forget about even playing. Because now you don't have enough troops, don't have gooed enough weapons, and don't have troops leveled sufficiently.Parts of the game are tedious and time wasters. Bentley will constanly tell you what's blatantly obvious. The camera will constantly hover over the objective when you get near it (even though it's marked from the beginning). It's just dumb how much time is wasted and how irritating it is to have to listen to and watch pointless stuff when you just want to take your turn.I have also found that the game forces you to play a certain way. In XCOM1, you spammed satellites. Now, you have to spam communications upgrades. If you don't, you will end up unable to get to mission areas and losing. Also, certain classes are much better than others. I would put specialist as the weakest in combat (but they can provide nice bonuses). Snipers are versatile if you go the pistol route, but otherwise can slow you down. Grenadiers are epic and can do some great AOE. Try dropping an acid grenade on a flare before reinforcements arrive and watch the aliens stand in place for 3 rounds as they don't want to get the debuff for moving through those tiles. Rangers seem to do the highest single target damage and can be essential to take down high hp targets. I've heard that snipers can do really well with high ground.Yes it seems to be poorly optimized (disable bloom, SSAO and AA helps). I have yet to crash, though. I can live with some minor graphical glitches and a some performance slowdowns for reaction shots. The camera can act up as well, but that's just another annoyance. The thing that is frustrating is the incosistent manner in which some tactical notifications are given. The detection while stealthed for example, can incorrectly show a spot as being safe to move to (even though you can see the alien that spots you before you make the move). The notification icons for burning, poison can decide not to show up. I've had aliens be invisible on the map, even though troops can target them (also more irritating than game-breaking).Bottom Line: wait for some mods to come out that fix game balance a bit (I like the one where you get to start with 1 engineer and 1 scientist), wait for a bug fix patch, and then get it on sale.

content:
Posted: March 29
Pros:Engaging turn-based combat. It's easy to pick up but you quickly realize how important every single action is. One wrong move could easily result in a dead soldier. There's also a good variety of classes (4 base classes, 1 unlocked via a ship upgrade, and another is part of Shen's Last Gift DLC.)Layers of strategy: I really like the tension the game maintains. Having to choose between squad or ship upgrades, or what continent you should help first. The game has a surprising amount of depth to it.Mod support: This game has a wonderful modding community behind it. There is a huge selection of content: character customization props, addition terrain pieces, quality of life fixes, additional classes, and campaign overhauls. (On a side note: avoid any character props/races that have "empty" face placeholders. I.e. they only have eyes, teeth, and hair. The game will still use those for randomly generated NPCs, engineers, and scientists. That♥♥♥♥♥♥is nightmare fuel.)Character customization: Honestly, I think I spent 8 hours just making characters. There is a pretty decent selection just in the vanilla game. Add mods that allow for additional layering and more pieces and you can do pretty much anything.Replayability: Very high. Trying out different mods, different play-styles, randomly generated events and battlefields, and different upgrade priorities. No two games will be the same.Graphics & sound: The game has respectable AAA graphics and sound. Plenty of options, and runs smoothly. While the game does look good, it probably won't blow anyone away.Neutral:Story: It won't blow your mind by any measure, but the story maintains a good focus and the cut-scenes, characters, and voice acting are all well executed and maintain a good production quality.Environmental destruction: Walls, trees, and clutter items are all destructible, I just wish buildings had more dynamic destruction. Like if you took out some support beams the whole building would go down.Difficulty curve: The game goes from "walk-in-the-park" to "this game is horse♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; difficulty real quick. Though, once you kind of know what your doing it's not so bad.Cons:Line of sight issues: even with mods that provide some additional feature and bug fixes, this is probably the most frustrating part of the game. Nothing will generate rage like getting one-shot through the floorboards when on your turn your character couldn't even see them.The game is still pretty buggy. On a totally vanilla game I've ran into bugs like: enemies don't take actions, and SPARK units don't end turn after using overdrive, and all their actions. Hacking mechanic: Rewards are sometimes nonsensical, and usually don't warrant the risk/reward until you get a higher level technician. I just didn't find the mechanic fun.Computer Specs: Intel i7 5930k, EVGA GTX 1080ti FE, LG 34UM95 (3440x1440, 60hz), 500GB Samsung 850 Pro SSD.

When it comes to the story, i found it a nice change from the usual defend the earth from invasion and rather take back earth from them. and i can say for sure, every time i start a new playthrough, its always a different experience , as nothing is the same when it comes to the map layouts. with a +100 hours into this game and hopefully more into the future , i would totally recommend this game if you like strategy turn-based games ,  with a lot of customization options for your soldiers and many repeatable playthroughs.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2016
												This game is amazing, heartbreaking, rage inducing and euphoric. It will have you by the edge of your seat the entire time; and it's turn action based. The difficulty is punishing. Make a wrong move and it could mess up the entire mission. So you have to be very strategic, and difficult as it may be, sometimes you just have to make some sacrifices. Do you go for the missions objective even if you could loose your best guy? Do you risk carrying out a wounded brother in arms -or just saving your own hide fleeing?Who will be the hero? Who will crumble under pressure, leaving the the team exposed? X-COM 2 is one hell of a game, well worth the coin. Maybe it has some issues with bugs, but on the whole I have no critique. The learning curve might be a little steep, and as such it might discourage new player.The way to play is to use your wits and intellect to outmaneuver the brawn of the aliens. This means that this game is not for the casual gamers looking for something to pick up and play.  If you like these types of games, this is the one for you. Look no further.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2016
												I played XCOM: EU and EW on PS3 a few years ago, and was enthralled immediately. The stories, the connections you make with your soldiers, it was all so organic and it was phenomenal. The game had a handful of issues that were annoying, but were minor enough that I'd give the game an 8/10. (Enemy Within, however,is such an improvement it's a 9/10.) Now, after logging in more than a few hours into the sequel, I'd say it's as good as Enemy Within. The feeling of being a guerilla force fighting from the bottom is a great change and the timer on some missions, while occasionally annoying, ramps up the intensity. Seriously, if you're coming from a different genre and are unsure how you'll like turn based tactics, give it a try. It's more intense than almost any FPS or fighting game there is in spite of it's slow pace. 9/10

content:
Posted: December 13, 2016
												It's overall better than XCOM:Enemy Within. Maintains the general design, but refines it a lot and addresses a big chunk of the criticism. Plus it's moddable! There's quite a few interesting mods out there.It's less stable, still has quite a few bugs, but mostly related to animations and the interface. I haven't encountered anything game breaking.It's a lot more balanced, with difficulty that is coming from the high amount of alien types and their special abilities, as opposed to being able to one-shot your guys like in the previous installment. The game feels challenging, but fair, on a Veteran playthrough (difficulty 2 of 4). For comparison, the original XCOM difficulty 2 of 4 was very easy, while 3 of 4 had a very big difficulty spike due to aliens one-shotting XCOM soldiers easily in the first one third of the campaign.In my oppinion it's the best squad-focused turn-based tactical strategy game out there at the moment.My only complaint is that the end game is pretty short and you don't get that much of a chance to use the shiney last tier equipment or the most powerful abilities at your soldier's disposal. But there's a long war mod for that :P (the Partisan War mod).EDIT: A Long War 2 mod made by the original team behind the XCOM1 LW mod and backed officially by Firaxis has been launched. It's really good, brings a lot of new content (missions, research tree options, utility items, 2 whole new weapon tiers, maps, aliens, etc.) and an overhaul of the strategic (geoscape) layer. Two thumbs up for XCOM2 just because of this mod - it increases the replay value of the game hugely.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2016
Product received for free
												Whilst I long for a faithful recreation of the original XCOM or UFO from the 90's, with its seemingly endless campaigns, huge tech trees, full environmental damage and sprawling bases, this will more than do.The world is under alien occupation and, as the resistance, it is your job to quell the alien threat.The game has two halves. Firstly, there is the planet-wide base building and mission finder, where you plan your global strategy, build up your base, choose missions, find resources and research new technologies. Secondly, there is the strategic combat element, which occurs when you send the troops in on missions and focuses on moving individual soldiers around a finite area. This works a bit like a game of chess - albeit over multiple levels and scenarios, with various targets or objectives and, of course, aliens to seek and destroy or humans to find and protect.One negative for me is the timers on missions; some are quite strict. I understand they are there to induce a sense of threat - which works if you like that - but I prefer to play slowly and methodically, coving all corners and such. With such strict turn time limits, you can't play like this as you are up against the clock! But the timer can be patched out with a mod if you so choose.With that minor gripe out the way - this is strategic and unforgiving. Just the way it should be.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22
												Since release I checked in on the critical and user reviews across the webz about this game many times. I could not help but notice its retail price had not dropped in like.. a year (how long has it been since launch?). Crappy games don't do that - the price goes down usually and fast. So i picked it up. Man oh man I have not enjoyed XCOM this much in a long time. It is not the same formula as the old XCOM so don't come in expecting that. Don't pick it up unless you have a gaming rig because it is demanding. As a point of reference, with some tweaks I am running comfortably on High and it looks and runs great. 3-year old MSI mid-range gaming laptop with a 970m gtx card - hardly groundbreaking there, and was only considered mid-high-end when it came out, awhile ago. The quality of the port is top notch. All the settings you'd expect are there, the menus are execellent, everything is bindable, no mention of a controller, no changes require a restart or reload, no crashes or technical issues at all. The atmosphere, music, sense of urgency and the gravity of each mission is awesome. I find myself actually caring about the outcome and having something actually at stake. The VIP rescue mission that you'd think I would hate actually resulted in an awesome emergent drama of sorts, a tough decision, and a major risk that paid off in full. Satisfaction, and it easily could have gone the other way. But it didn't, because I'm baf. I am playing on normal, with ironman mode (constant save, no undoing anything) and for me the ironman mode is essential, I recommend that because the stakes are 'real' and things matter more. There are more great things I could say about it such as solider progression and how that already feels so satisfying and I instantly got attached to one of them that I'm now trying to keep alive, but that covers the essentials for now..

It's like they looked at every single aspect of the game and improved upon it. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29
												strategic challenges have never been more present than in XCOM 2 - perhaps more so, with a constantly see-sawing balance of power and time restraints that often force you into desperate action. This isn’t a game where the heroes always win - it even assumes a canon; that you, XCOM’s Commander, failed to defend Earth in the last game.XCOM 2 is set two decades after the aliens quashed mankind. With Earth now under alien rule, Your choices matter - from what research you tell your scientists to develop, to what facility you ask you engineers to build. It is this sense of agency that makes even micromanaging your base, or deciding where to send the Avenger next, truly exciting.Most missions have a limited amount of turns in which to accomplish them, meaning a slow and careful advance is generally out of the question. It is a clever, cruel way of coaxing you into misjudgment, eking out risks when you should be patient. Sometimes you’ll be forced to send a soldier sprinting into the Fog of War just to get a grasp of the procedurally generated battlefields, but be that at your peril - they may end up toe-to-toe with an entire enemy squad and all out of moves.That being said the game is very poorly optimized and i had to do a plethera of .Ini file changes in order to get a stable 60fps, While i did manage this the task was certainly time consuming. TL/DR  Xcom-2 was an amazing purchase i got it for £10 from a humble bundle, I would not recommend paying full price but on a deep discount it certainly will net you a good few hours, I may be slighty biased being a veteran of this genre of games Xcom-2 has a vast learning curve and a immese difficulty spike, But never the less the game is endlessly enjoyable, That and with the addition of online multiplayer and steam workshop support you cannot go wrong. I give Xcom-2 an 8/10 - Definitely Worth Buying

content:

												Xcom 2 is a great follower to Xcom Enemy Unknown. And with the whole workshop intergration everything is nice to enable and disable when it comes to mods. The game also offers great replay abilities as every mission is different in it's own way due to the ammount of maps the game comes with (You can even find map expansions on the workshop if you do get bored of the current ones) Along with the mods the 2 last DLC's have been really great and added lots of fun to the game when it introduced back the Mech class. And the other added more dangerous aliens that makes the game more challenging just when you think you got the hands on things.There are ofcourse a few flaws as there are with many games. Nothing too major in my opinion. Most comes down to gear sometimes not loading proberly when changing it. I don't know if that is just me having that issue though. The alien turns or player turns sometimes take a long pause before switching to the next turn for some odd reason. Other than that there are few issues i am not gonna adress as they are not game breaking in any way i have noticed.I will gladly recommend this game to people! It is a great game and there are as said many possibilities whitin it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												There is so much that this game has going on for itself.It is a successful remake of a magnificent game series. Granted the original xcom was a true tactical and strategic game, that required hours upon hours of micromanagement to actually get ahead of the aliens. But that was then and this is now. Granted this game is not a "true to heart" remake of the original. But they got the original idea of the alien invasion and created a game from scratch, with a breath of new ideas coupled with stunning graphics.The only downside I can find is the technical problems that arise. However, they have a dedicated support that tries to solve issues and a little online search can fix most issues.Added on top of that a thriving workshop and modding community and you got hours of replayability.I can't but recommend that game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2016
												Well, Firstly I say that this game is not for the faint of heart. You will see your dreams crushed, and your men and women under your command shot, burnt, panicked and generally trying not to die in spite of your bad decisions. I still havn't beaten the game and I will likely try again here very soon. There is a nice collection of mods avaliable here for you to choose from to fit your fancy. The story behind this game is pretty solid, I have enjoyed it so far. One of the cons is the additional DLCs but I coughed up the money and was pleased by the results.I am now daring to try the Long War 2 mod for XCOM2! I will be updating this review as the tale of the war continues.The Second Long War has been lost. Shen was lost in a final desperate battle trying to take down the final sectopod in a desperate gamble to begin adding new SPARK combat robots to my flagging combat teams. The start of the war was marked by desparate skirmishes against superior forces, while XCOM was forced to fight on the move. In the process losing good men and women to mind control, explosions and bullets. The only bright spot in a grim and dark war was Delta Squad, lead by the commando "Boss", with Sev, Fixer and Scorch. Delta Squad was 100% successful with no fatalities among the four of them. At each battle the going was worthy of a epic poem. If you needed to slip in undetected break out a VIP and scoot before ADVENT knew what hit them, Delta was the answer. The Roughneck Moccasins were completely wiped out on thier first mission. The Avengers managed to survive thier first mission, but at the cost of 85% casualties. On the Avengers second mission they were destroyed to a man by the new viper units being deplyed by advent across africa and india. The Black Night's Watch faired better at first, three successful mission in a row with under 65% casualties each mission was still a grim fair, but at least they got the job done. With the fateful mission comeing to my attention I decided to run with the Black Night's Watch. I regret that decision. We went in with a full complement of six soldiers. No one came out... With Shen lost, the XCOM project could not continue and humanity was doomed. Final ReviewXCOM2  - 4 of 5LongWar2  - 5 of 5 Mod Support  - 5 of 5In a few words: Gritty, Rewarding, Captivating, Hellacious. I would do it again.

												First of all you should watch the Youtube video titled "XCOM (Honest Game Trailers)" which tells the truth: "One commander will rise and lead humans to victory by - constantly reloading a save file" :DThis pretty much sums it up. Game is really interesting and if you like original X-Com series, Xenonauts, the previous X-Com, you will also like this game. It´s in many ways better than the previous title and the only real complaint is the fact sometimes the game is just too unfair with the odds and your whole team is wiped out in critical spot of the scenario. If you play Ironman mode this easily means you will have to restart the whole game.Some people might enjoy this but rest of us will use this ultimate tool called "Load previous Save" and try again. I would recommend X-Com developers try out a great game called Hard West which has replaced the traditional probability system with a "Luck of the Draw" combat mechanism which turns the previously random events into actions where player can influence the odds.... just an idea

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Sent Bob Ross to fight a war against aliens that look like Shrek and the cast of the teletubbies.-10/10 Skyrim with lazersGood:-Great Gameplay, still as good as Xcom but with more detail and new things to do.-Great Steam Workshop-Immersive Story, follows  up the events of Xcom but it can still be played without any previous knowledge.-Amazing Character Customization, not only that but there are several great skins in the Workshop, which brings us to the next point.-Massive Workshop, from everything to new maps, guns and skins to making your soldiers look and sound like Bob Ross.-Challenging, however there are some BS moments in this game this game is hard because it takes good planning and execution for every mission, not only that you need to learn how to properly manage your base and how you spend your time, time in this game is precious as there is a limited ammount of time in between missions where you can decide to research new technologies which will help you on your road to victory.-Much Longer than the last game, it took me 40 hours to finish my first playthrough of Xcom, im 42 hours in and im still not halfay through the story.-Just plain good fun, there is nothing more satisfying than perfectly executing a mission (that is after you reload 12 times)Bad:-Can be Frustrating, If you easily rage quit because of minor things this is not a game for you, you will find yourself reloading previous saves due to some BS like missing a crucial 99% chance shot and then gettin instantly killed from the other side of the map.-The DLC is not great, dont get me wrong it does adds a couple of new things and more gameplay but the alien rulers DLC is just bad, the "Rulers" are stupid overpowered to the point that it makes the game unplayable in the early stages, not difficult, just bad, if you start the dlc in the late game it is pretty cool and you wont have too much trouble getting through it. The other DLC however is just more character customization stuff but you can get better in the workshop for free. Shens last gift however is a pretty cool dlc which adds the option of sending robots instead of troop to missions just like in the previous Xcom.Overall i would really recomend this game to hardcore Xcom fans and people who haven't played Xcom before, it is a great challenging experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22
												The following is my experience after a few hours of playing Long War 2 (the XCOM 2 Total Conversion), and the reason I remembered XCOM 1 as a better game than XCOM 2 felt at release. Long War 2 is simply the way the game must be played:"It looks like the game I remember xcom1 being, and the reason why I didn't really play much xcom2, it felt too easy and less like a war and more like a series of little skirmishes. In war, people die, often.So, I went into LW2 feeling pretty confident with my skills. Of course I lost 2 soldiers on gatecrasher and had to restart. After that I found out about the infiltration thingy, and looked it up. Pretty simple, and anyone who does not understand it, simply look for 100%+ infiltration, if it is not possible then simply avoid that mission.Had 3 squads of about 8-10 soldiers with 2 casualties after about 12 missions, thought I was doing really good. Then, Mutons and Vipers (and their new variant) started appearing, as well as MECs. Had to abort a guerilla op which in turn gave the enemy a UFO looking for me.Got hit around australia and the next scenario is a total nightmare. I sent my less leveled team, thinking I would get reinforcements if I lost people and thinking that I WOULD get hit really hard. But I was extremely underestimating the enemy.Holding the line became something like an inverse D-day for a couple of turns, hitting the enemy and them dropping like flies. Then it started to go to hell, my soldiers dropping left and right, stun lancers and vipers picking off soldiers. mecs dropping misiles on my positions, and I couldn't even leave the ramp to look for the disruptor.After about 10 turns of madness a gap appeared and I sent a shinobi to go kamikaze on the disruptor while what was left held the line. The battle was 36/42 for the aliens and I lost 6 soldiers KIA and 6 WIA (3 left behind)With a squad crippled, Advent now attacked a Haven. Barely held the line with 3 more casualties and 2 wounded.In just 2 missions, the game told me to sit down and cry as I only have 1 squad left (of badass soldiers from all 3 squads) and about 6 guys wounded and no replacements at all. Loving it."

content:
Posted: April 11
												The sequel of the best acclaimed Turn Based Strategy Game and I hope... really hope we are gonna get XCOM 3 :)This game is good... not as good as previous XCOM IMO... Having played them side by side...The camera is a bit weird... LOS is broken in some places...The difficulty scaling is better but the end games enemy is just annoying and/or broken rather than challenging... Having played this the moment I finished XCOM 1... At first this game is not as good as it's predecessor... and gonna feel like a bad game at first... but the longer you play it... the more you are gonna appreciate it that it is actually a sequel and a good XCOM game...The stealth mechanic is broken... literally... the longer u stay undetected is actually better for the enemy... so guns blazing all the way...Avatar time is just not good... It kills the diversity of how u want to play the game your own way... the timer on the mission is not that bad thoughThe mod... Oh the mod... XCOM 2 make the mod actually legal from the get go... and there is so much QOL mod you really want to install into the game without breaking it...IMO the mod make a good XCOM game into great XCOM game...If u already finished it... or if you want a challenge or want to play this game in a different and good way... I recommend the long war 2 mod... It makes a 8/10 game into 9/10 game... Very nice mod to hav

												Save your money on this one, even at half off. After downloading the game and waiting for the launcher to apply all the patches, I was very dissappointed when I clicked "Play" and was presented with an error message. I tried a couple more times with the same results. I Googled the error and found many other posts of others having the same problem. I applied for a refund but somehow, between the Launcher's patching and the troubleshooting I've done, Steam says I've "played" for over 5 hours. I tried a second time explaining I've not "played" the game once but apparently time sitting in the Launcher counts as "playing". Yeah, I really enjoyed that "play" time. Shame on you Steam!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												In the desert of a year filled with misleading marketing, broken releases, and disappointing games, XCOM 2 is an oasis.  When people look back on 2016, most of its titles, inde and AAA alike, will have been forgotten either for their mediocrity or out of the shame for having purchased them.  But not this one.Those who enjoyed XCOM: Enemy Unknown will find XCOM 2 well worth their money, time, and attention.  If 2K can continue to do work this good with the series, then it will take its place among the best franchises of gaming.  They really have done that well with it.The continued story remains true to the franchise, the objectives structure is familiar yet novel enough to entertain, the worst of the bugs and awkwardness from the last title are gone, the expanded mechanics and features are flawless.  It is a rare treat to get to play a game like this, and an absolute pleasure to praise work of such high quality.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												It's XCOM2 !   If you liked XCOM EW you will like XCOM2.Graphically it is a much enhanced game.  Maps are more open, colorful, and varied with lots of sparkly effects. Some groups of enemies have patrol routes, which makes for a more interesting tactical experience. Timed objectives occur more often - though not with the frequency those complaining about them would have you believe.New soldier skills have been added, and some modified to liven up combat.  Rangers carry a blade for close combat and sharpshooters are now the only pistol carriers.  Both these classes acquire specialized skills for these weapons.Altering soldiers' visual appearance and history has reached a new high.  You can write their bio, change their country of origin, and accessorize - with more options opening up as they level.   You can even color and name their weapons.  On the down side, the base physical features of each race seem more homogenized and less country specific. Lots of attention to small graphical details has been taken throughout the game.   Soldiers have grim, tense expressions flying to a mission, and cheerful, relieved expressions flying back.  The intro loading screen will pick a soldier on your roster ( in their current gear ) and show them spying on an Advent position. You can give your soldiers cigars and cigarettes, earrings, scars and tattoos.  The downside of all this graphical goodness is that it comes at a price.  If you've been nursing along an older computer system with infusions of RAM and a slightly better graphics card,  you may not be satisfied with how the game runs. There are a lot of options in the graphics setup, so it is possible to find a setting that is bearable on an older system,  but it won't be pretty and frame rates will stutter on some weapon effects.Before XCOM2 i've been playing XCOM EW with the Long War mod.  While XCOM2 is definitely an improvement over the base XCOM EW, I have mixed feelings on how it compares to the Long War modded version.  Graphics aside, more different than better. ProsGraphically improved.More varied maps and missionsNew soldier skillsInvolving storyConsHefty system requirementsNot fully optimized for performance.If you liked XCOM EW  and your computer can handle the system requirements, definitely give XCOM2 a go.

												I've beaten the game. Awesome!  I love it.....but I am a fan of x-com since the original Ufo: Enemy unknown in the 90's came out.Let me be absolutelly straight with you. If you're a new to X-com, this will be a brutal experience. You will likely lose your first campaign, or three. And I'm not talking legendary difficulty. You'll get your♥♥♥♥♥handed over to you on normal. You will watch your soldiers die and missions fail.But that is the point. This is the dark souls of the strategy games. It is a challenge. A true gauntlet testing your will, resilience, ingenuity and ability to learn. It is always an uphill battle. You will never be in comfortable position of power. Enemy has more troops, stronger units and economy.This game will not pamper you as they are trying to tell you straight in the tutorial sequence. I will reccommend the game but the final decision is yours - do you have what it takes to save humanity?

												This game is set in present day Madagascar and you play the role of a middle aged, quick witted roguish like character (whos devilishly handsome by the way). Nolan North's voice acting once again stuns as his quick wit and impeccable delivery coupled with his masterful acting ability. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												In comparsion to its predecessor this game is for me clearly an improvment, with a few drawbacks.I restarted the campaign 2 times, because I made some early mistakes. But now I am pretty late game, fighting against monstrous Sectopods and Gatekeepers with an almost fully equiped Squad (altough i do hope i did not reach the end of the research  tree, with one research left). The good things:For me each time a new enemy appeared was like a new challenge (besides the avatar that one was strangely easy).Each with their own strenght and weaknesses.This games rewards Tactics. Ive read that some ppl complain about timers. And i do agree the first time I saw those timers i rushed and almost lost my entire squad. Now I take some time in the beginning (obvious not too much) for a good positioning and a good engage which gives you enough time to finish the rest of the mission leisurely. Now i almost always have 2-3 sometimes even 4-5 rounds left before finishing those missions. Lots of customization, not just looks but gameplay changeing. Want a heavy front line ranger with heal? Get those heal armor with a w.a.r suit bladestorm and untouchable. Or a more stealthy approch with Wraith Suit its crappling hook and Phantom?  Change weapons parts for extra shots bigger mags higher aim and so on.Psi. I love psi. and its OP. Mindcontroll those heavy Gatekeepers? check.And i love those new Specialists. In my opinion one of the biggest changes to xcom. Ranged heal and hacking.Heavy Sectopod killing your squad? Hack it!Ranged heal allows for a more spreaded approch without being in risk that your frontline warrior cant be healed.Great replayability. Each playthrough will have other missions/strarting place so you need to adapt to what you get.The not so good:Lack of freedom. I would love to have really easy and really hard missions from the beginning. Right now Enemy strenght evolves with your own, which doesnt make sense for me. It would be much better if there would be lightly guarded remote post to attack. Or those big Strongholds with many guards and advanced Defenses and the player would have the choice when to attack which place.Now i have my standard squad and if one gets hurt 2-4 reserve Soldiers to swap out, greatly reducing my power, You could say thats my fault because I focuesed too much on my squad. but on the other hand, i knew each mission will be harder and i picked the best for it. If i would have the choice to attack an place that isnt that much of a problem i could use some rookies to give them expirience. And not to forget you cant really decide were to attack. Mostly you get 3 choices from which you can choose one and thats it. And mostly you choose those mission because of their reward. And late game you most likely will pick Supplies because thats what you need most.No optional fights. Ok you could say you dont need to fight each mission but not doing one is in general a really bad idea. Loosing supplies/scientists/engineers/intel no exp gain and so on. And if you cant do mission because all you soldiers are hurt i would strongly suggest you restart the game.

I'm pretty annoyed with the game and it's unpredictability.The only way you can keep your squad alive is by inching your way forward - and even then you suddenly get 2 poeple poisoned by a viper through a solid wall...The hang after mission completion is especially annoying and the known bugs and support pages are pretty much a joke.The last patch was a quarter year ago, but the dev does not really seem to be interested in actually supporting the product.Whether you like the design is up to taste, of course, I happen to disagree with the 'chunky' and clumsy feel of the combat dynamics and the camera always doing stuff on its own to zoom at some event for ages during combat.It rarely is where you want it to be and gets ripped out of your control for seconds befor you get it back.Enemies gratuitously gesticulate around while the camera is glued to them - in the middle of a heated battle. I always feel that I don't have any significant decisions I can even make - it's all so closely constrained that it feels pretty limited and therefore boring.This is a real pity, because I quite liked several aspects, but they get smothered in above mentioned problems.
