content:
Posted: December 13, 2016
												Xcom: Enemy Unknown was my first turn based strategy game that I really put any time into. I thoroughly enjoyed the first one which was a surprise since I'm usually not too fond of turn based anything. So to keep it short, if you liked the first one you will definitely enjoy the second. If you haven't played the first one I'd highly recommend it, it will make your experience with xcom 2 a whooooole lot less frustrating. There's a lot of innovative enhancements to the original gameplay to keep it fresh and interesting but still has the core Xcom feel. I really like the new skills they added and the more in depth class system. Also the character customization is awesome, I thought I wouldn't give a damn about character appearance in a game like this but there's a lot of options and it makes you that much more inclined to try and keep your favorite soldiers alive. Another thing, I've seen quite a few reviews complaining about bugs and glitches interfering with gameplay. There are definitely some AI bug issues, but in my case nothing interfered with my gameplay other than the occasional pause because the game gets stuck on the enemy turn for a few seconds. The rest were pretty small and easily ignorable bugs. (Again, this was my personal experience) I don't have too much negative feedback to give on this game other than certain missions feeling way too hard for your current progress and some lag and pauses during the enemy turn. NOTE TO NEW PLAYERS: PERSONAL SUGGESTION, DON'T DO IRON MAN ON YOUR FIRST PLAY THROUGH. I WOULD HAVE SMASHED MY WHOLE COMPUTER TO PIECES.The good:-great new skills-MOST of the time the difficulty feels balanced as you progress-in depth customization-longer story, more hours of fun gameplay-great for players new to strategy games. Easy to learn, but it keeps you challenged-story is more interesting than the first-looks goodThe bad:-painfully frustrating at times. Some might consider this a good thing for a strategy game, but a lot of those times I felt like I had been cheated instead of outplayed-shot percentages feel like they are always way less than what they say (60% feels like 40%) maybe I'm just a ♥♥♥♥♥-some of the countdown missions feel way too rushed and next to impossible to come out with a success and a full crew. Then again that may have been the intention. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.-Small bugs and glitches-long loading screens8/10

content:

												Morbo says,"THIS GAME IS LOTS OF FUN, EXCEPT WHEN MORBO'S FRIENDS DIE!  I WILL DESTROY YOU!"But seriously, this game is excellent.  I've always been an X-Com fanboy (so read everything I say with suspicion), but they've done the series a service with both this and the XCOM (1) games.  I can't wait for the next game.What's great:The combat system has been seriously upgraded in my eyes, even from the first XCOM game.  The addition of new classes and their own special skills has really changed how you play...in a good way.  The battles are more fluid and I think they're more difficult than they've ever been.  The difficulty is offset by capability, however.There's no management of the mundane.  No, I don't have to reload ammo on my troops.  No, I don't have recruit hundreds of scientists and allocate them all to different labs.  No, I don't have to waste time.The storyline is excellent.  I love the continuation of the original storyline and the way it plays into the story of this game.What's not so great:Little bugs here and there with my system and the graphics.  Nothing that's caused the game to crash yet, so this is really not a big deal.All in all, this is an excellent continuation of the XCOM series and might be my favorite yet.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2
												Upfront TL;DR: I recommend XCOM2 to anyone who is remotely interested in strategy/tactical rpg games and does not mind a few hiccups in optimization.It is like a sci-fi Fire Emblem without anime cutscenes and support convos (all that waifu♥♥♥♥♥♥ and adds good graphics and destructible environments. XCOM2's plot is the classic Good vs. Evil with some philosophical drops of "we are becoming what we set out to destroy".The real story, however, is the success and failure of XCOM agents under your command. BTW If you can't play a game without your precious waifus then download a voice pack for them and add them to your character pool. Pretty sure there are a bunch of neptunia heads and voice packs in the workshop. See, everyone's happy. Introduction:     This review is tailored for those who have not played any iteration of XCOM, so that it better informs those interested in trying the game out. Before continuing, I want to say that mods are a double edged sword in this game. They enhance play and decrease performance at the same time (subscribed to 300 atm). I cannot deny the fantastic additions graced to XCOM2 by the modding community, but I hope to review the ideas and concepts that the vanilla version succeeded/failed to accomplish on its own.Specs: i7-6700K @ 4.00GHz (4.36GHz)16 GB RAMGTX 1070 Pros: +The ability to extensively customize your soliders contributes a sense of attachment to  soldiers you are ordering around, something most games cannot emulate. +Map generation is very well designed/balanced so that the same tileset/area can offer many different avenues of play. +Configurable settings via the xcom ini can further modify play, leading to more replayability. For example, you can change the base stats of every character/item in the game if you wanted.+There is some base management, but it is not too extensive and does not feel tacked on just because "every other game has some form of it" (the original XCOM had this too).+Combat is interesting and offers different approaches to problems through the soldier class system, plethora of researchable gear, and destructible environments. +The emphasis on limited time (in combat and on a macro scale) to rebel against Earth's alien overlords provides a sense of urgency that many games strive for yet miss. +Your soldiers and the aliens become stronger as the game goes on, which creates a sense of each side trying its hardest to defeat the other. +Countless workshop mods offer something new and exciting to experience through multiple playthroughs.  +There is an ironman mode (Only one save state) for tryhards. Variable difficulty as well, which is good for new players. +A game that discourages facerolling over every button on your keyboard. Cons:-You have to realize this game has its optimization issues.  -Loading screens can be long, depending on your settings and how many mods you decide to download. I think the base game does not have this problem as much as a heavily modified one. -Frame rate drops slightly when discovering enemies, unloading from your transport, and initializing props to customize your soldiers with. These frame rate issues, however, can be easily ignored since they only occur at specific points in the game and do little to hinder the gameplay itself.-Do not play at max settings, even the best rigs will have trouble stabilizing at that golden 60fps.-Due to the nature of XCOM2, it being quite a long game, these problems seem to be more apparent later on when there are simply more characters in a given mission (larger squad size, more enemies, etc.). -There are not many gameplay elements that I feel XCOM2 failed to deliver on, but indeed there are many annoyances within the vanilla version that have either been patched already or allieviated by the free mods inside the workshop. Conclusion:     So if you do buy the game and see something that is offputting, check out the workshop to see if a solution has already been distributed.More than likely if you see something as a problem, someone else has too.      This concludes my review of XCOM 2. If you made it this far, then congratulations on either scrolling fast or reading.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												XCOM returns, and it is back with a resounding bang. I won't give away any plot details, but X2 offers a deeper look into the various supporting characters (not your soldiers) than its predecessor; while  maintaining the general overall feel of Enemy Unknown/Within. With improved game mechanics and animations, X2 truly feels like the next step in the franchise.However, there are some performance problems with the game at launch (especially on lower-end machines); including various memory issues and slow-down as the game progresses and more enemy units start to flood the screen. At the time of this posting, 2K has stated they will be addressing these issues in forthcoming patches so be assured that the problems are temporary. A big boon is that XCOM 2 is mod-friendly. This is fantastic because, for me, there are a few glaring negatives that can be "ModFixed". The default camera control is terrible and can be utterly frustrating- especially if you want to see from floor to floor of a building or get an over the shoulder view of your soldier without having to spend far too long fiddling with the controls. Another negative, (or positive to some) is the mission timers. IMO, most instances of their use are out of place and rehashed in order to create a sense of urgency. But thankfully, there are mods out there to add either a set number to these timers, randomize the time to keep things interesting, remove them all together- or my favorite; have the timers not start until your group is revealed from concealment. Go Go Mod Community.In the end, XCOM 2 is a great game with high replayability and is worth every dollar per hour for the purchase price. If you love Sci-Fi and strategic/tactical combat buy this game; you won't regret it.9/10 ... 10/10 Modded.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												First thing, the difficultly level, for me, is fine at the default. Perhaps I just suck.  ;) I love how many of the old systems from the last Xcom have been carried over but in some cases improved. Having reload of your weapon not end your turn for example.Somethings, I'm not sure about.The will loss (from taking damage?) that recovers from doing well at a future mission is annoying. Thankfully panic is much less of a mission ender. The aliens start with some pretty powerful abilities from the get go this time. One thing that I didn't like, is the early mind control. When you have a squad of 4 it's a big deal. You hardly ever resist it. It can even end your mission if your entire squad is mind controlled. The only saving grace is that the aliens won't damage mind controlled teammates, so sometimes it actually saves you. (when a surprised flanked unit gets taken for example) edit: actually, they will target mind controled units if they have nothing else to shot at.My biggest beef with the game is how the timed missions with random maps work. You will have X amount of time to do something and get to a certain point. However, because the maps are random, sometimes that point can be so hard to get to that even if you ignored the aliens and dashed right for it your cutting it close. I don't mind the rush effect sometimes, but I like to take my time and do things systematically. They need to have at least one more turn added to them across the board. Moving units to different levels is STILL a pain. I have had units run to the wrong point because it's hard to tell exactly what level your selecting your space on. A couple of pods activated through walls too.It's overall a good game. It needs to be tweaked somewhat however. Thankfully it's supposed to be super mod friendly, so we will see. I suggest to anyone who loved the last XCOM, to get this one. It is good game overall.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23
												Story20 years have passed since the events in XCOM: Enemy Unknown and humanity has fallen under alien control. The once supportive council nations have sided with the new alien government during the height of their invasion. Using an administration known as Advent to become a disposable source of manpower, the aliens make an aggressive campaign to earn obedience and loyalty with earth's population. Harsh crowd control tactics and an abundance of Advent propaganda are utilized to invoke fear across the globe. With immense government funding they are a force to be reckoned with, in regards to both manpower and military equipment.XCOM has become an almost forgotten remnant of the past, leaving many to wonder what the future holds for the human race. However, Resistance forces have burrowed themselves into small pockets of the world, working tirelessly to overthrow Advent and fight for what was once their's. With little resources and time, a small squad of resistance forces act on newly provided Intel. This lead suggests a possible location for a tremendously important figure that is being held in an Advent facility, the Commander. Once rescued and revived from a medically induced cryo-sleep, the player (taking on the role of The Commander) is briefed on the current state of Earth. With a shell of what XCOM once was, you must gather resources and individuals loyal to the cause and restore XCOM to it's former glory. Technological advancements and utilizing your soldiers abilities to the fullest are the foundation for success, but strategic planning and careful military tactics are what it's built on. Expand the reach of the Resistance by aiding smaller Resistance forces, and set back Advent's development of a mysterious weapon known as the Avatar Project by completing important assignments and destroying key Advent facilities.GameplayXCOM 2 is a turn-based tactical strategy game that is in a league of it's own. Never before have I played a game that has bestowed so much weight in every decision you make. On masterfully designed multi-level maps that are almost entirely destructible, soldiers are controlled like chess pieces with a limit to how many actions they may perform, or tiles they can move. With limited vision of your surroundings, every enemy encounter can be in the players favor through already established defenses, or brutally devastating by enemy flanking maneuvers and abilities. The presence of perma-death only adds to the tension of enemy engagements, and ending your turn pits your tactics against an intelligent and equally lucky AI.Concealment is the latest and greatest feature, allowing you to enter missions undetected and grants you the ability to ambush your enemies. Solid defensive placement and foreknowledge can be the difference between a devastating blow to Advent forces or a fatal backfire. In addition, a multitude of weapons, armor, and utility items are at your disposal, assuming you researched the necessary criteria and had the required supplies. As well as new and useful abilities that give your soldiers a major advantage on the battlefield, granted you use them correctly.What flaws are to be found in XCOM 2 however are incessantly apparent. (For Enemy Unknown veterans they may come at no surprise.) These include shots and abilities making contact through walls and objects, hanging animations in certain circumstances following Overwatch shots or soldier placement, numerous instances of clipping, and obscure lines of sight that are both infuriating and laughable. Now these are not game-breaking by any nature but they are certainly a nuisance. Furthermore, they work both ways so while you may be victim to some quite frankly BS shots, you too may find yourself with the same unfair advantage.User interface and camera controls work well throughout the majority of the game, in small instances though they can be incredibly temperamental. One wrong click can mean the difference between short or high cover, spotted or concealed, dead or alive, so it's aggravating when action keys are click-through if a friendly soldier is nearby or when travel routes get finicky when rotating the map.When not in combat, time is of the essence as Advent will make slow but steady progress to completing their Avatar Project. If they do, you have a short amount of time to attack a facility or complete specific objectives that stagger it's construction. A great deal of missions are time sensitive as well, requiring the player to make aggressive advancements and react accordingly to enemy reinforcements. Even without a turn/time limit, every action and choice comes with a reward or consequence and XCOM 2 does a great job at making you aware of the result. Tense combat situations, challenging AI and enemy variants, and an immense amount of player freedom and customization. SoundXCOM 2 offers as much depth in the sounds and music as it does in it's gameplay. Music is triumphant in success and shattering in defeat. Sound effects are appropriately fitting to each circumstance whether it's gunfire and explosions or destruction and animations. Aliens come to life with intimidating battle-cry's and soldiers express their panicked state or wounded cries in disconcerting fashion. Dialogue and voice acting is dramatic but not over the top. A satisfying blend of military criticality  as well helpless emotions when things take a turn for the worse. Cinematic scenes are enjoyable both visually and aurally, however (and maybe this was a bug) facial animations noticeably lacked movement when soldiers communicated their understanding of each order.GraphicsFor a game that doesn't need to be graphically beautiful to attract strategy enthusiasts, XCOM 2 is stunning. The amount of detail in the environments, models, armor and weapons, visual effects and lighting are astounding. In what's simply an isometric plane comprised of tiles and levels, it is filled with so much character and tone that it comes to life the moment you touch down. Combat animations resemble movies in the re-positioning camera and the surroundings crumble and shatter from forceful explosions or enemy movement. Unfortunately, detail like this comes at a price. My gameplay experience maintained solid framerates for the majority of the play-through. Key word majority, guess-timating that atleast 30% of my time was spent wtaching frames drop to as low as 24FPS and then right back up to 60. These occurrences were almost always during cinematic moments, whether it was in or out of combat didn't matter. Destructible environments make for a great gameplay mechanic but when it's framerate teeters back and forth regardless, more ground clutter and visual effects only hurt performance more. Luckily these instances don't take away much from the gameplay itself, but become immersion breaking with frequency. (Ultra on 2560x1080 - i7 6700k / GTX 980 ti)Replay ValueArguably infinite, nearly pattern-less. While most missions follow a similar formula for enemy locations and objective markers, the breadth of possibilities is so vast that you're never experiencing the same fight twice. On a global scale and even inside combat enemies behave intelligently and pose a threat to your entire Resistance. (And existence!) Procedural map generation and spurts of luck make for endless possibilities both good and bad. The options for squad loadouts and soldier variety can be the difference between a flawless victory or crushing defeat.Wrapping UpA must play. XCOM 2 delivers a challenging experience that leaves you tugging your hair when things go South and exhaling massive sighs of relief when they go right. Despite it's buggy nature and clunky performance, solid strategic gameplay kicks it into sixth gear to overshadow it's imperfections. In a genre polishing checkers, XCOM 2 is reinventing chess.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2
												Upfront TL;DR: I recommend XCOM2 to anyone who is remotely interested in strategy/tactical rpg games and does not mind a few hiccups in optimization.It is like a sci-fi Fire Emblem without anime cutscenes and support convos (all that waifu♥♥♥♥♥♥ and adds good graphics and destructible environments. XCOM2's plot is the classic Good vs. Evil with some philosophical drops of "we are becoming what we set out to destroy".The real story, however, is the success and failure of XCOM agents under your command. BTW If you can't play a game without your precious waifus then download a voice pack for them and add them to your character pool. Pretty sure there are a bunch of neptunia heads and voice packs in the workshop. See, everyone's happy. Introduction:     This review is tailored for those who have not played any iteration of XCOM, so that it better informs those interested in trying the game out. Before continuing, I want to say that mods are a double edged sword in this game. They enhance play and decrease performance at the same time (subscribed to 300 atm). I cannot deny the fantastic additions graced to XCOM2 by the modding community, but I hope to review the ideas and concepts that the vanilla version succeeded/failed to accomplish on its own.Specs: i7-6700K @ 4.00GHz (4.36GHz)16 GB RAMGTX 1070 Pros: +The ability to extensively customize your soliders contributes a sense of attachment to  soldiers you are ordering around, something most games cannot emulate. +Map generation is very well designed/balanced so that the same tileset/area can offer many different avenues of play. +Configurable settings via the xcom ini can further modify play, leading to more replayability. For example, you can change the base stats of every character/item in the game if you wanted.+There is some base management, but it is not too extensive and does not feel tacked on just because "every other game has some form of it" (the original XCOM had this too).+Combat is interesting and offers different approaches to problems through the soldier class system, plethora of researchable gear, and destructible environments. +The emphasis on limited time (in combat and on a macro scale) to rebel against Earth's alien overlords provides a sense of urgency that many games strive for yet miss. +Your soldiers and the aliens become stronger as the game goes on, which creates a sense of each side trying its hardest to defeat the other. +Countless workshop mods offer something new and exciting to experience through multiple playthroughs.  +There is an ironman mode (Only one save state) for tryhards. Variable difficulty as well, which is good for new players. +A game that discourages facerolling over every button on your keyboard. Cons:-You have to realize this game has its optimization issues.  -Loading screens can be long, depending on your settings and how many mods you decide to download. I think the base game does not have this problem as much as a heavily modified one. -Frame rate drops slightly when discovering enemies, unloading from your transport, and initializing props to customize your soldiers with. These frame rate issues, however, can be easily ignored since they only occur at specific points in the game and do little to hinder the gameplay itself.-Do not play at max settings, even the best rigs will have trouble stabilizing at that golden 60fps.-Due to the nature of XCOM2, it being quite a long game, these problems seem to be more apparent later on when there are simply more characters in a given mission (larger squad size, more enemies, etc.). -There are not many gameplay elements that I feel XCOM2 failed to deliver on, but indeed there are many annoyances within the vanilla version that have either been patched already or allieviated by the free mods inside the workshop. Conclusion:     So if you do buy the game and see something that is offputting, check out the workshop to see if a solution has already been distributed.More than likely if you see something as a problem, someone else has too.      This concludes my review of XCOM 2. If you made it this far, then congratulations on either scrolling fast or reading.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2016
												I've never been into turn based games, the format couyld never get me to invest or get excited about what was happening. Somehow, by some strange witchcraft that I blame aliens for, Xcom has changed that. Although it is currently the only exception to the rule, it is fun and exciting. I started playing and the next thing I knew it was three days later.There's a child in me who loves the idea of kitting out my squad. Chuck Norris, The Terminator, John Rambo and Snake, then sending them off to shoot aliens and save the world (again). You can't help but become invested in the charcters, and when one of them eventually dies there is a real loss, both for the character you watched go from raw recruit to seasoned alien hunter and in the game as losing a skilled character can be a serious set back.So even as the Terminator was dismantled, and Snake bleeding out, Iron Man and Lara Croft were waiting in the wings for their chance to leave their mark on the genetically enhanced faces of the Aliens.Great game, loading times can be a bit long but to be honest that's the only real complaint I have. Even if you have never played a turn based strategy game, give it a try, it will surprise you.Squad honourable mentions: Obi-Wan Kenobi, Conan the Barbarian, RoboCop, Robin Hood, Ghost Rider, Alice, James T Kirk, Neo, King Leonidus, John McClane, Bruce Lee, Achilles, Boba Fett, Bane, General Zod and Selene.Good huntin'

content:
Posted: February 5
												Fighting on your heels!XCOM 2 is a master stroke in the reboot of the series that started with it's fantastic predecessor. Whereas the first game worked to recreate what made the original XCOM so beloved, the sequel set out to stand on its own, and in that it succeeds brilliantly. As the story goes, we lost the war in the first XCOM. The Aliens have taken over Earth which has become a dystopian, assimilate or be destroyed hell of oppression. You, The Commander, have been put in charge of the remnants of what used to be the world supported UFO defense force. The once global operation has become a small, unorganized resistance against the alien occupiers. The first handful of hours absolutely captures this element brilliantly. You have to choose your strikes carefully, find where you'll do the most good while slowly building your struggling resistance. The feeling you get as you begin to turn the tide in the war is unlike anything i've experienced in a game before, you can't help but cheer. Graphics: Beautifully done, action camera angles and features from the previous game return, and are made better. Sound: Also top knotch, every weapon and creature sounds unique and varied. You can also flip a switch and have your squaddies actually speak the language of the country they're from, a really nice touch that helps you become attached to your precious resistance fighters. Challenge: Tough but rewarding. You will literally spend the first half of this game on your heels, barely surviving your engagements and looking eagerly for your next supply drop. You will hit a point where you can start to breathe a bit easier, but that's when the game ratchets up the Avatar Project, and the clock starts ticking. Overall: Get this game if you enjoyed the previous one, XCOM 2 is even better. When you've played through the game and won the campaign, I HIGHLY recommend The Long War 2 mod. It's free, a total conversion and adds a TON of content to what was already a brilliant game. I do not recommend the mod until you've beaten the main campaign and understand and are comfortable with XCOM 2's pacing, because TLW2 kicks that up to 11 with a resistance management layer. Brilliant game, logged tons of hours into it, and i recommend it to all fans of the series.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2016
												Amazing experience. Became one of my personal classics.I've felt like i was commander. I weeped for my fallen soldiers, I cherished with them when we've done a flawless mission. This game really makes you care about your soldiers with massive amount of customization from armor to their biography. I've seen some people who played only 40 hr-20 hr, saying this game is not an awesome game or worse; "it's a bad game". Let me tell something to you. This is not a game where you can spent 50 hours and decide whether it's good or not. Because you have to spend time with the customization, you have to do different things, try to look from different angles. Learning it's combat mechanics and properly using them may take some time as well. And also finishing the game and seeing it's suprises (they are really good). Doing those in my opinion takes at least 70-80 hours if you rush it if not you have a safe 120 hours of gameplay. I may rushed it a bit. 106 hours.I like playing strategy games. I thought i liked them because i could play them in a relaxed mood. But XCOM 2 proved otherwise. I was always on my toes. I felt the pressure of those soldiers and the earth's survival. And there is never a dull moment. There is always something going on around the world forcing you into an important decisions. And all decisions matter something. You feel like all your decisions combined got you where you are. Bad or Good.And there are hidden mechanics which i will not spoil them to you. Even after 100 hours you can be suprised. And realise you still haven't seen the whole game.Difficulty can be really frustrating for a people who rush their decisions and are new to the game. But once you die couple of times and you specify your mistakes or figure out how enemy react to those actions, you'll know how it works, you'll feel like you are an experienced commander. Game is challenging but yet it is immensely compelling. And after everything works as you intended and game rewards you for it, that moment you'll know how 'flawless' XCOM 2 is Commander.  FOR THE RESISTANCE!

content:
Posted: October 21, 2016
Love it!If you enjoyed EU and EW then you will most definitely enjoy XCOM 2. The soldier customization is so in depth this time around, I wish there were more customization options available out of the gate but the mod community is part of what helps keep things fresh. I'm glad that Firaxis added mod support this time around.There's nothing like having a soldier survive 20 plus missions only to have him/her mind controlled by a sectoid and giving his squad mates no other choice but to shoot him/her down cause he or she is on the verge of killing another squad member. Then there are those moments where you set up the perfect ambush with all soldiers on overwatch and your recon set with Killzone and a superior extended clip. Then there are those moments where your squad is overwhelemed and caught off guard which lead to the most intense moments.Some of my favoirite missions are the retaliation missions, the base defense missions and assasinate/capture missions cause they truly test your skill; during some of these missions you may need to complete them with a certain amount of moves, if you fail then your soldiers end up being captured. I have yet to deal with any of my soldiers being captured so I am not sure if we can rescue them down the road but these are the missions that will put your skills to the test.Visually the game looks more appealing than the previous entries, as for frame rates, I get the drop every now and then but never too bad. load times are what I dislike the most and I've noticed that the more mods you have active then the longer it'll take for the game to load.Either way I highly recommend the game... DLC may be a bit overpriced but it is still worth it in my opinion.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												This game has good basic gameplay that can keep you entertained for quite some time. For anyone who played XCOM enemy unknown this is the same thing with only smaller changes. The changes that has been made however are not for the better. They have for example this turn-timer (you have a certain amount of turns to finish the mission). This takes away a lot of the tactics of going in slow to make a perfect surprise attack. It forces you to run and gun a lot. They’ve also made sure that you have to hurry with the story missions as well or you’re doomed. This makes the psi-soldiers nonexistent. I made only one and never used her. I saw when I finished the game that the overall amount of psi-warriors for a playthrough is 1. ONE! The game is too short and rushed to make you feel a good change (a big difference) in gameplay from beginning to end. It’s more or less the same throughout but with more grenades and more hits towards the end. The character creation has been developed a lot. Sadly it’s only cosmetic. They’ve stuck to professions instead of letting every character be unique with their own mix of abilities and weapons. Also, why not more fun abilities? Even if you want to keep the professions they should of made more of them.I will keep this short. Do you want a solid turn based tactics game and you’ve already finished enemy unknown, then this game is for you. It’s fun. Do however not expect a better or even equal experience as enemy unknown. PS: It works on Linux!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												If you enjoyed Enemy Uknown/Within, you're going to like this. It's more of the same but tweaked and changed so it keeps the best while improving on weakness and trimming the fat. It also introduces new elements into the old formula to spice it up, so being experienced with EU/EW is a false sense of security. It took me 58 hours and 3 failed games to finally win on normal difficulty.Familiar enemies have progressed and improved in the wake of the alien victory, presenting new challenges. World/base management has also stepped up consideradbly- where EU/EW boiled down to "bum rush your satellite production, win game", here you are more engaged by active counters, lurking UFOs and a doomsday countdown that will WRECK you until you've learned from your failures (more on that in a bit)Character customization and generation is more in depth than ever, so you'll feel even more aguish when your soldiers get critted by some jack-off Muton WHICH IS ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T BTWSo in my personal experience, I would reccomend it. BUT SOME THINGS TO CONSIDER:------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  I find the new soundtrack somewhat lacking. It's not that it's bad,  I just think it lost some of the personality that Michael McCann (guy who did the Deus Ex HR soundtrack) brought to EU/EW. Mods can and will remedy this though.- The game can be buggy. For me it's mostly been inexplicable pauses that slow the pace, but some people report some serious issues with LOS. Your mileage may vary. - If you hate time limits...I got some bad news for you. Mods will remove these if they transcend 'challenging' and wind up just ruining the game for you, though.- BEWARE THE "ALIEN HUNTERS" DLC. This is my only objective complaint. This DLC is nonsense that at best will put a new player against an even more uphill battle, and at worst will render your game unplayable through game crashes. Save your 10$, you've been warned. -----------------------------------------------------------DEATH TO AYY LMAOS

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2016
												Can I recommend this game YES, can i highly recommend it YES.I wrote a negative review last time, but after about 10+ month of waiting for a patch that fix the shooting/looking though walls bug, then it seem like after latest patch that the game now play much better.Well If read this, then you properbly already know Xcom series and how to play this turnbased strategy game.But be aware this game work in a little different way.On the big world map you now have a flying base from start-end in the game. You fly from country to country setting up radio towers to earn funds for your operation of xcom. What is pretty cool is that everytime you start a new game then everything is random so the replay value is fantastic, also the battles never play out excactly like last time, since the enemys are also random selected depending on your tech level and how far you are in the campaign.You will without a doubt encounter enemys you already know from the series, but there are also some new ones that you love or hate.  ( properbly hate since they kill your men he he )All in all you will fly arround the map all the time completing random missions that variate from capture vip, to protect resistance HQ against enemy raid..  Sometimes you also get special missions that can alter the course of the campaign. Example you get 3 missions to choose from that all effect what you get out of it different.Example do you want a scientist in reward, you want money, or maybe you want that a hidden event will not happen.Be aware the game take a little time to understand how the new features work and how you move arround on the tactical world map, but once you learn the rules of the game and so on then it is actual pretty good if not excellent.The game AI i think is pretty good and is indeed a challenge. They will assult/run away or maybe flank you.The shooting animation and detail of the graphics are excellent as well.As you know the game is all about research and getting better gear to combat the aliens, and well you are in for a long journey.. There are allot of tech, and in this new xcom game you can even put extra gadjets on your weapons so they become more powerfull or precise.. Why not give you soldiers some armour that if enemy try to thouch you set them on fire... quite handy when one of the anoying snake aliens want to cuddle with you.I recommend that your first campaign will be the most easy level, even if you are experienced.. The game is quite tough, and there it take a little time to learn how the new game work.Well what are you waiting for, BUY IT..... 10/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
												It is the final days of the resistance. Advent forces have discovered the location of the Avenger and have launched a full frontal assault. All XCOM operators defending the ramp have had their weapons disabled by a Codex. However, the resistance was not going down without a fight. They engaged the hostile forces with honor and dignity.Miraculously, the resistance managed to defeat Advent at the Battle for the Avenger without the loss of a single life. But there was still one more problem, the Avatar Project was nearing completion, and they had not made contact with the area where an Advent research facility was located, which would have to be destroyed in order to delay the project.Resistance Comms was constructed, supplies were received from a supply drop, and contact was made with Western Europe, the location of the research facility. But the aliens completed the Avatar Project, and the countdown to the end of humanity began. There was no more time to prepare, the Resistance had to act now.An elite squad of XCOM operatives, led by Colonel Lukas "Junior" Bekker, launched a covert operation with 1 objective; destroy the research facility. The squad of 6 soldiers deployed into the woods surrounding the facility, fought their way through Advent forces, and reduced the facility to rubble. Not one XCOM operative was lost that day. The destruction of the research facility dealt a major blow to the Avatar Project, which bought more time for XCOM to make contact with more regions to destroy more facilities. Will the resistance succeed in defeating the aliens? Probably not. But like they did in the Battle for the Avenger, they can hope.In XCOM 2, the real story comes from your own gameplay experiences. and everyone's will be different.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2016
												Lots of great changes from EW/EU.  XCOM Project is more detailed and challenging to manage, specialist class is great, soldier upgrading/equipping are managed more easily, and the storyline is compelling.The only downfall is that comat almost always feels rushed.  XCOM 2 puts a time limit on practically every mission in one way or another (either by limiting turns or looping enemy spawns until the party is extracted).  If you played EW/EU in a slow, methodical way, you're gonna have to change your style significantly.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2016
												This game gets better and better.  I'm inspired to write a positive review.SummaryXCOM2 has very good to amazing graphics, an excellent story and very good character development with a deep variety of strategically complex skills that keep me coming back for hours on end to try different play styles.GraphicsThe board itself, the trees, the water, the destructible environment are beautiful.  The animations, partially due to their small scale, are almost lifelike.  Kills are awesome.StoryThe story is interesting, makes sense and lends itself well to the variety of missions available.  The only downside (if you can call it that) is having to hear Bradford say "we're losing people left and right".  The voice acting is very good.  Every time I hear him say that I want to ♥♥♥♥ing strangle him.  What's interesting and true is that those negative emotions contribute to my interest.  The anger, the challenge, that element is critical to how much I like this game.GameplayI imagine this is what chess with real people would feel like.  The different skill sets and character development options are what keep me returning.  I like snipers.  Developed snipers are worth the initial agony.  The agony comes from missing.  ...missing.  The horror.  ..luckily my desk is made of hardwood.  Surviving in spite of missing, surviving in spite of the relentless onslaught of missions, surviving in spite of losing your entire squad, another challenge that makes this game great.  And once you're more savvy to using your team strategically you're free to experiment.  How would I fare with a team of all concealed rangers?  All PSI Ops?This is where I am now.  Starting over again and again.  Trying different styles and building my base slower/differently.  I anticipate many more hours of this.I eagerly anticipate the next generation of XCOM.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2016
												Bought in Dec 2016 for Mac Pro (2014 model). Worked fine. Didnt find any performance issue people have complained about. Its a bit CPU heavy though. There were a few glitches, once a muton went outside the playable area and I couldnt kill it and had to do premature evac to continue. The objectives were partially completed but the mission showed failed status. A couple of times the keys would freeze and wouldnt jump to the next character on pressing tab or esc wouldnt work. An exit and restart solved it. Overall a very good sucessor with many WTF moments as new alien units drop on you for the first time with little warning or awareness of their weakness/strengths. You soon learn to butcher them though :) Starts a bit slow and you are always on the backfoot at first but you get OP at the end. The end mission is pretty interesting and doesnt disappoint like EU. However would have liked a chrysaild like tense mission from enemy unknown. overall 8/10

content:
Posted: September 10, 2016
												I`m a long time fan of the series, have been playing them since the first entry. About Xcom 2:PROS:- fresh take on the x com's formula - Nice colorful graphics- fun and varied missions- MODS available on Steam Workshop (some of them are REALLY important, like the one that let`s you see the health bars into numbers)- Reasonably difficult, but without all the punish from some of the early games (you may think that as a CON, but I think it worked well)CONS:- some minor glitches (as it`s always been with xcoms)- field of view bugs, in overwatch commands for example (as it`s always been with xcoms)- some missions may seem unfairly difficult, but if you're familiar with Xcom, that shouldn't be a problemThere are a lot of new aditions and differences from the previous games, but those may be good or bad, depending on your opinion. For me, it all seemed like a good, solid, and fun Xcom game.

												I invested in the Deluxe Version of this game and it was well worth it.  New customization options and new units are available; as well as new armor, missions and a few new enemies.  There is a timer mechanic but instead of making things annoying, it keeps them moving and intense.  You can push back the timer with certain missions as well, which is nice.  The turn limited missions can get somewhat annoying in the way that it pushes you to the objective but it makes sense with the premise of this game.Upon beating the vanilla version of this game, I was left satisfied but curious.  The ending was akin to a movie ending with room for a sequel.  Easily one of my favorite games, even beating out the previous games; of which I adored.  Overall, excellent game.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												While I'm not generally drawn to turn-based tactical games, during the last Steam sale I noticed the price drop and upon a recommendation from a close friend I decided to drop the 30 bucks and have barely regretted it since. I've never played the first XCOM, so I couldn't make any comparisions there. First impressions: Hard. Very hard. Why is everyone dying? Why do I keep missing?But now, I'm a firm convert for XCOM 2.         This game is an absolute blast to play. Once I got the hang of the tactical combat I really began to enjoy every battle, the suspense you get after signalling and ambush and praying for the destruction of the enemy.But, there are some points I don't like. For one, the stragey aspects that come with the Avenger are pretty hard. True, it does recreate the feeling of fighting an entire alien force with limited resources and time, but all the same, it makes the game real ♥♥♥♥ing annoying when you have to turn down major (time sensitive) missions because everyone except your lowly recruits are wounded. And once you get behind the AVATAR project bar it's almost impossible to catch up again.All in all though, a good 7/10.

There is absolutely no freaking way the developers sat down and played their own game and didn't see these.  I bought this on sale for $40 and I regret it. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2016
												This game could have been awesome.It does not give nearly enough time to complete anything without failing critical missions. If you do focus on critical missions and skip most upgrades and research, you will be vastly outnumbered and far from powerful enough. I do not have a whole lot of turn-based strategy gaming experience, but even on the EASIEST setting (which is suggested in-game for non-experienced players), the difficulty scales way too fast with your progress and quickly becomes impossible. The tutorial gave hardly any hints and tips, leaving the player to figure everything out on their own whilst getting their butt kicked. There are also strategy-critical BUGS throughout the game that tilt to the enemies advantage (for example, enemies shooting through two walls before they are destroyed, or enemies slashing your squad members from below you). A 4-man squad is absolutely ridiculous when you have many more soldiers to spare, especially when going up against 10+ enemy units. The Dark Events are also relentless and make the enemy much too powerful. It is also frustrating that there is no way to take the time to counter all the Dark Events. In fact, you can't "take the time" to do much at all. The entire game rushes the player through everything, interupting progress with side missions that are far too detrimental to lose. There are also several aspects that don't make sense and uselessly inhibiting of a good game experience. Now that I've got that off my chest, here's what I find amazing about this game. The platform is easy to use. Graphics, landscape, splash art, the alien concepts, these are all beautiful and very attractive. This game has a unique blend of action and story progression, which I find very enjoyable. The aliens themselves are decently authentic and fun to discover and fight. All of this alone ALMOST makes up for the rest of my frustrating experience. Conclusion:This game was a complete joy to learn about and explore for several hours, but became a complete mess of failure and frustration rather quickly. I have a bit of regret paying $60 for this. I'm sure there is a very specific way to play this game and do quite well, but it is not obvious at all. I do not enjoy having to go research how to actually play to feel as though my purchase is worth (which I will do now) and would much rather be able to learn and explore everything myself with a successfully challenging experience. Perhaps my review will change once I do some digging.4/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
												I have the same problem with this game, as I had with the first one.  Once you figure out your base build order, the game becomes 100% RNG.  Nothing the player does, no strategy or tactic you can employ, has any real meaning in the game.  Fights are absolutely determined by the RNG.  This is made worse in the second installment, because you are always under the effect of a timer pushing you to hurry.  At least in the first game, you could set up a kill zone and try and pull aliens into it, or split them up.  There was at least the pretense of strategy.Sadly, the game is best played on the easiest setting, as it has the least amount of RNG destroying your party.I'll give you a perfect example.  One mob left with 3 hit points, my entire party has at least 60% to hit, my sniper has 93% to hit, EVERYONE misses....mob of course one shots one of my soldiers that's in full cover on the next round.  Uninstall.The real problem is, especially early on in the game, you don't have enough hit points, to offset lousy runs of RNG.  Given that it's *very* easy for your soldiers to be one shot, especially early on, and it's a rage inducing formula if you're playing on any of the higher difficulty levels, or ironman.At the end of the day, the worst design descision was the timer on every mission.  It strips the game of any kind of tactics, and makes every single thing you do at the mercy of the RNG.  Why this game gets so much praise I'll never understand, to me, it's shallow, and frustrating.

content:
Posted: April 5
												XCOM 2 has a soft space in my heart. I've tried the first XCOM, I mean, the REAL first XCOM. As much as the die-hard fans rave like rabid dogs about how amazing it is, my simple, casual, millennial mind simply can't sit down and grasp how it works or how to put up with god awful graphics (and trust me, I've played stuff like Populous, so I've got some resistance compared to my generation.)When I first found XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Within, I had literally no idea what I was in for. What I found was a great "Dress up these people and make them fight aliens" strategy game I immediately fell in love with. Making everyone look like celebrities was my best choice, and having secret agent Ben Affleck kick doors down whilst Jeremy Renner did wierd magic stuff was just hilarious.So, I was stoked for XCOM 2. Despite my usually harsh view on the videogame industry, I even pre-ordered a couple of weeks early, I was so damn excited.On launch day, I was... satisfied?XCOM 2 is buggy, feels somewhat unfinished in some areas, with some oversights included and overall loses a couple of elements of strategic depth for more "Pfft, that's XCOM"-ness I was growing somewhat tired of. That being said, I still adore this game. The graphical upgrade is immense, and my soldiers look sillier than ever thanks to the impressive range of mods available for this game. Even in vanilla, this game still entertains me. XCOM 2's take on top-down strategy gets me immediately feeling like a strategic genius when I manage to get a grenade thrown through a wall to tear down cover for someone else to take a shot. Despite it's bugs, flaws, and it mistakenly thinking that everyone who plays it will spend six hours on every mission like some sort of chess grandmaster, playing on a lower difficulty to get to grips with the game and just having some fun with the characters makes XCOM 2 a worthy sequel to it's predecessor, building on the lore and gameplay of the first, elevating the stakes and making you feel that much smarter when grenadier Michael Bay blaster launchers an entire house to dust.MICHAEL BAY!

When it comes to the story, i found it a nice change from the usual defend the earth from invasion and rather take back earth from them. and i can say for sure, every time i start a new playthrough, its always a different experience , as nothing is the same when it comes to the map layouts. with a +100 hours into this game and hopefully more into the future , i would totally recommend this game if you like strategy turn-based games ,  with a lot of customization options for your soldiers and many repeatable playthroughs.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												If you enjoyed Enemy Uknown/Within, you're going to like this. It's more of the same but tweaked and changed so it keeps the best while improving on weakness and trimming the fat. It also introduces new elements into the old formula to spice it up, so being experienced with EU/EW is a false sense of security. It took me 58 hours and 3 failed games to finally win on normal difficulty.Familiar enemies have progressed and improved in the wake of the alien victory, presenting new challenges. World/base management has also stepped up consideradbly- where EU/EW boiled down to "bum rush your satellite production, win game", here you are more engaged by active counters, lurking UFOs and a doomsday countdown that will WRECK you until you've learned from your failures (more on that in a bit)Character customization and generation is more in depth than ever, so you'll feel even more aguish when your soldiers get critted by some jack-off Muton WHICH IS ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T BTWSo in my personal experience, I would reccomend it. BUT SOME THINGS TO CONSIDER:------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  I find the new soundtrack somewhat lacking. It's not that it's bad,  I just think it lost some of the personality that Michael McCann (guy who did the Deus Ex HR soundtrack) brought to EU/EW. Mods can and will remedy this though.- The game can be buggy. For me it's mostly been inexplicable pauses that slow the pace, but some people report some serious issues with LOS. Your mileage may vary. - If you hate time limits...I got some bad news for you. Mods will remove these if they transcend 'challenging' and wind up just ruining the game for you, though.- BEWARE THE "ALIEN HUNTERS" DLC. This is my only objective complaint. This DLC is nonsense that at best will put a new player against an even more uphill battle, and at worst will render your game unplayable through game crashes. Save your 10$, you've been warned. -----------------------------------------------------------DEATH TO AYY LMAOS

content:
Posted: December 16, 2016
												Can I recommend this game YES, can i highly recommend it YES.I wrote a negative review last time, but after about 10+ month of waiting for a patch that fix the shooting/looking though walls bug, then it seem like after latest patch that the game now play much better.Well If read this, then you properbly already know Xcom series and how to play this turnbased strategy game.But be aware this game work in a little different way.On the big world map you now have a flying base from start-end in the game. You fly from country to country setting up radio towers to earn funds for your operation of xcom. What is pretty cool is that everytime you start a new game then everything is random so the replay value is fantastic, also the battles never play out excactly like last time, since the enemys are also random selected depending on your tech level and how far you are in the campaign.You will without a doubt encounter enemys you already know from the series, but there are also some new ones that you love or hate.  ( properbly hate since they kill your men he he )All in all you will fly arround the map all the time completing random missions that variate from capture vip, to protect resistance HQ against enemy raid..  Sometimes you also get special missions that can alter the course of the campaign. Example you get 3 missions to choose from that all effect what you get out of it different.Example do you want a scientist in reward, you want money, or maybe you want that a hidden event will not happen.Be aware the game take a little time to understand how the new features work and how you move arround on the tactical world map, but once you learn the rules of the game and so on then it is actual pretty good if not excellent.The game AI i think is pretty good and is indeed a challenge. They will assult/run away or maybe flank you.The shooting animation and detail of the graphics are excellent as well.As you know the game is all about research and getting better gear to combat the aliens, and well you are in for a long journey.. There are allot of tech, and in this new xcom game you can even put extra gadjets on your weapons so they become more powerfull or precise.. Why not give you soldiers some armour that if enemy try to thouch you set them on fire... quite handy when one of the anoying snake aliens want to cuddle with you.I recommend that your first campaign will be the most easy level, even if you are experienced.. The game is quite tough, and there it take a little time to learn how the new game work.Well what are you waiting for, BUY IT..... 10/10.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
												It is the final days of the resistance. Advent forces have discovered the location of the Avenger and have launched a full frontal assault. All XCOM operators defending the ramp have had their weapons disabled by a Codex. However, the resistance was not going down without a fight. They engaged the hostile forces with honor and dignity.Miraculously, the resistance managed to defeat Advent at the Battle for the Avenger without the loss of a single life. But there was still one more problem, the Avatar Project was nearing completion, and they had not made contact with the area where an Advent research facility was located, which would have to be destroyed in order to delay the project.Resistance Comms was constructed, supplies were received from a supply drop, and contact was made with Western Europe, the location of the research facility. But the aliens completed the Avatar Project, and the countdown to the end of humanity began. There was no more time to prepare, the Resistance had to act now.An elite squad of XCOM operatives, led by Colonel Lukas "Junior" Bekker, launched a covert operation with 1 objective; destroy the research facility. The squad of 6 soldiers deployed into the woods surrounding the facility, fought their way through Advent forces, and reduced the facility to rubble. Not one XCOM operative was lost that day. The destruction of the research facility dealt a major blow to the Avatar Project, which bought more time for XCOM to make contact with more regions to destroy more facilities. Will the resistance succeed in defeating the aliens? Probably not. But like they did in the Battle for the Avenger, they can hope.In XCOM 2, the real story comes from your own gameplay experiences. and everyone's will be different.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2016
												This game gets better and better.  I'm inspired to write a positive review.SummaryXCOM2 has very good to amazing graphics, an excellent story and very good character development with a deep variety of strategically complex skills that keep me coming back for hours on end to try different play styles.GraphicsThe board itself, the trees, the water, the destructible environment are beautiful.  The animations, partially due to their small scale, are almost lifelike.  Kills are awesome.StoryThe story is interesting, makes sense and lends itself well to the variety of missions available.  The only downside (if you can call it that) is having to hear Bradford say "we're losing people left and right".  The voice acting is very good.  Every time I hear him say that I want to ♥♥♥♥ing strangle him.  What's interesting and true is that those negative emotions contribute to my interest.  The anger, the challenge, that element is critical to how much I like this game.GameplayI imagine this is what chess with real people would feel like.  The different skill sets and character development options are what keep me returning.  I like snipers.  Developed snipers are worth the initial agony.  The agony comes from missing.  ...missing.  The horror.  ..luckily my desk is made of hardwood.  Surviving in spite of missing, surviving in spite of the relentless onslaught of missions, surviving in spite of losing your entire squad, another challenge that makes this game great.  And once you're more savvy to using your team strategically you're free to experiment.  How would I fare with a team of all concealed rangers?  All PSI Ops?This is where I am now.  Starting over again and again.  Trying different styles and building my base slower/differently.  I anticipate many more hours of this.I eagerly anticipate the next generation of XCOM.

You soon learn to butcher them though :) Starts a bit slow and you are always on the backfoot at first but you get OP at the end. The end mission is pretty interesting and doesnt disappoint like EU. However would have liked a chrysaild like tense mission from enemy unknown. overall 8/10

content:
Posted: November 7, 2016
												XCOM 2 Is very 50/50 for me. I love it, but I also hate it.Pros: - Very dedicated and talented workshop creators- Challenging and fun combat system- Good soldier customization for those like me who love just creating badass looking soldiers- Can be pretty immersive- Decent replayability to the game since workshop mods can change everything.Cons:- Mods always have a huge chance of just breaking your game, it's inevitable- Very pricey DLC for a VERY pricey game.- The story of the game is not interesting at all, don't play this game for the story. - The RNG in this game will make you cry yourself to sleep- Developer support is barely there. The only content you're getting is DLC, no patches, no bug fixes.- Noone plays the multiplayer, don't even try- The game has a crash dump and bug finder built into the game, but it really doesn't help at all- This game is just being kept alive by the workshop.Summary: Xcom 2 is a wonderful game that could be enjoyed forever. A very amazing collection of awesome workshop mods make this pretty stale and bland game into something pretty fun.If you plan on buying this game, I will give you a list of mods that I definetly reccomend checking out. The game is hard to manage with over 10 mods installed, so keep that in mind. Mods:Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare Remastered Weapon Pack  This mod features about 33 new weapons you can use in the game that all have different functions. Why buy a $5 for a few guns when you could get 33. Please note these weapons are SEPERATE in the workshop. There isnt one big pack.A Better Advent 1 & 2 These mods give you dozens of new enemies to battle against, making missions more interesting Music Modding System A mod that allows you to add custom music the game. My personal favorite is the Halo 3 Music pack. 10/10 More Maps Pack Gives you more maps of course. WHO DOESNT WANT NEW MAPS!?!? Capnbubs Accessories Pack Some really cool looking accessories for your soldiers, very well done and detailed. Additional Mission Types Self Explanatory Military Camouflage Patterns Definetly one of the Top 5 best mods on the workshop, this mod gives you what I think is 60 new military camoflage patterns for your soldiers and their weapons. More Cities Adds more cities to fight in. Yup More armor colors Self Explantory x2 Expanded Mission Names Just a mod that makes sure its unlikely to get a name of a mission repeated. Adds immersion.  Uniforms Manager Great for people like me that like to organize their soldiers in one specific uniform.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												First thing, the difficultly level, for me, is fine at the default. Perhaps I just suck.  ;) I love how many of the old systems from the last Xcom have been carried over but in some cases improved. Having reload of your weapon not end your turn for example.Somethings, I'm not sure about.The will loss (from taking damage?) that recovers from doing well at a future mission is annoying. Thankfully panic is much less of a mission ender. The aliens start with some pretty powerful abilities from the get go this time. One thing that I didn't like, is the early mind control. When you have a squad of 4 it's a big deal. You hardly ever resist it. It can even end your mission if your entire squad is mind controlled. The only saving grace is that the aliens won't damage mind controlled teammates, so sometimes it actually saves you. (when a surprised flanked unit gets taken for example) edit: actually, they will target mind controled units if they have nothing else to shot at.My biggest beef with the game is how the timed missions with random maps work. You will have X amount of time to do something and get to a certain point. However, because the maps are random, sometimes that point can be so hard to get to that even if you ignored the aliens and dashed right for it your cutting it close. I don't mind the rush effect sometimes, but I like to take my time and do things systematically. They need to have at least one more turn added to them across the board. Moving units to different levels is STILL a pain. I have had units run to the wrong point because it's hard to tell exactly what level your selecting your space on. A couple of pods activated through walls too.It's overall a good game. It needs to be tweaked somewhat however. Thankfully it's supposed to be super mod friendly, so we will see. I suggest to anyone who loved the last XCOM, to get this one. It is good game overall.

content:
Posted: March 29
												I absolutely loved the first game, Enemy Unknown/ Enemy Within and I love this one too. Of course there's some different mechanics that can be debated but it's basically a very solid continuation from the first game, although it doesn't really add anything other than nostalgia if you've played the previous one. Gameplay: 8/10Could have been more but some minor annoyances and mechanics brought it down a bit. First, the mechanics are pretty much the same as Enemy Within. Obviously some additions like specialized unique armor and some extra soldier customization. Just about when I felt the missions started getting really repetitive and annoying the game was really close to the finale, which is almost perfect for me. Some things like stupid camera movements during solder actions and the ability to save and load whenever you want brought this score down as well as a weird bug that crashed the game whenever I made a certain action within a mission. The mechanic of losing took a while to get used to and I had to reload near the beginning, but it's nothing complicated. If you liked the mechanics of Enemy Within, you'll like this game and probably its new additions too. (WARNING RANTING AHEAD)One mechanic I really didn't like was the Kings/rulers. Although I managed to defeat them without major repurcussions, I had to cheat the system by saving and loading between actions to ensure nobody died, which nullified the feeling of victory. Basically there are 3 special super mutants of different alien species that appear randomly after a certain mission. When you fight them, they get a free action whenever any of your soldiers makes ANY action, including movement. Certain abilities that don't count as an action won't activate this (thankfully). Meaning it's pretty much impossible to kill one of these things without someone getting major damage, unless you have multiple locking techiniques like freezing or stun and you have everyone positioned to hit them without moving once spotted. Luckily, they made them easier by making them retreat at about half health despite repearing randomly later on. Story: 6/10Granted, these games were never really about the world in which it takes place in. It's solid enough to introduce new players and you don't really have to pay attention to it to enjoy the game. For people coming from Enemy Within, this is set in an alternate universe where the XCOM project didn't actually succeed. It's an interesting premise, but the core mechanics remain the same regardless. There's a bunch of background text involved with every single research you complete, but of course that's not necessary and I never read any of them. The overall storyline is also decent. Not complex and kinda cliche, but it fits the bill. I personally really liked how the characters actually talk directly to you and that you can personally participate in the last mission.Peformance: 9/10Like I mentioned before, the camera can get real weird during soldier actions like running and shooting. There's some consistent minor visual glitches, but I didnt encounter anything that affected the actual game. Overall, I can recommend this game. Although maybe not for the full price, i would definitely wait for a sale in order to get the DLCs as well.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												I'd like to start by one of the main-points of TotalBiscuits review: "If you didn't like the first remake of Xcom by Firaxis, you won't like this one either". However... if you liked that first one, you might love this one.It very obviously is a follow-up, and a tiny bit of "more of the same", but the devs really managed to improve quite a few things and added some new mechanics. Graphics and performanceWhile graphics might not be as essential in a strategy game, it surely doesn't hurt if the game looks nice, and this one does. The chars don't look as beautiful and detailed as, say, in W3, but the game does look really nice, and you get to see quite a lot of the details you put in when you create your characters.Performance-wise, this might need a patch or two to improve stability. It didn't crash, but there are some framerate-drops, and some laggy moments, where, at the end of a turn, there is a weird delay, or sometimes, the game "stops" on the "fly to mission loading screen". Again, no crashes.Gameplay (mostly about the changes compared to the previous game)It works pretty much like the first Xcom. Turn-based, overwatch, etc, all the stuff is still there. However, Firaxis added quite a few new abilities, some of them really helping to turn the tide in an intense encounter. I really wasn't excited about melee, seeing alien-hunters swinging swords. I thought it was pretty silly, not making sense. However, the rangers are great for stealthy approaches, their attacks can be very powerful, and with some upgrades, you can move them out of harms way once you have slain an alien. The game is set in the future, a few years after the first game, so it makes sense that you get new gear, new abilities and tech. Some of the new suits and special abilities (like items that create mirages of your guys, which will draw the enemies attention) are pretty dang cool.However, the aliens did do some research too and did get some upgrades. The thin men now have a new look and abilities, and there are some all new heavy units which will give you quite a fight (I especially hate the AT-AT-like ones...gosh, those are tough).Some people have commented that the game is a bit more balanced, as in no more unfair and pretty much impossible moves by the aliens. However, I didn't notice too much of that in the first Xcom, even though I played that a lot, too. So there is no "god powers" for the aliens, they also miss shots quite often, and there is some room for error. If you do mess up or are too bold, you might just survive without losing a soldier... or you will get annihilated.Some cool new abilities, like hacking (even mobs, disabling them for a while or even mind-controlling them), the drones that specialists use are cool etc. One thing I love is "serial", a sniper ability. If you activate it and then manage to kill an enemy with your snipe-ability, you don't lose action points. So you can eg. weaken some mobs with a grenade on one guy, and when it's your snipers turn, you can kill them one by one in just one turn.The game does feel a bit tougher than the first one, yet not to the point where it is frustrating (I heard though that the final mission is VERY VERY tough, you will probably lose a bunch of your guys). Just like in the previous game, losing one of your soldiers, especially those you might have named after a rl-person, hurts, especially if they have reached a high rank.You decide how you progress. There is a doomsday-clock-device, adding some urgency, but you have choices... pick up more supplies, research a lot of new technology, focus on doing everything to slow down that Avatar-project? Yes, you eventually have to do certain missions and you better try to expand your network, but there is quite some choice here.What people seem to dislike, and one thing I am not fond of, is the amount of timed missions, with a limited amount of turns. There were some in part 1, and that was ok,... it was a nice change of pace, was a challenge, and made sense. However, having TOO many of them is... not always fun. Sure, it can be a blast to beat those, but if you really like to approach stuff tactically, try to keep your guys safe, set up perfect ambushes etc, well those timers will make that tough.You may wanna consider download a mod from the workshop which will extend those timers.I enjoy this a LOT. Wasnt sure whether I'd like the even more futuristic setting and look and the sword-class, but it turns out that this is a carefully crafted, improved take on the first remake. If you liked that one, definitely check this one out!Pros: - Looks great- Fun new updates and tech and abilities for both you and the aliens- Said techniques and abilities allow some all new strategies- Some nice new missions and progression/choice system (world map)- Challenging- Apparently, more variety in the maps you play on and the way things are set up- High replayability (had to start over twice, once to make up for mistakes I had made and apply stuff I had learned, and the second time because of a savegame broken by a mod that was removed from the workshop, and I didn't mind restarting at all!)- SOme weaknesses of Xcom were removed- Workshop enabled, with mods on day 1- ChoicesCons:- Some performance issues (my system: i4790, 16 gb ram, GTX 960 with 4 gb, W7)- Too many timed missions, ymmv

												I got this game in the recent steam weekend sale for £19.99 and can honestly I would have been happy paying full price for it.First of all I am not a guy who plays a lot of strategy games however the notion of fighting back against alien occupiers appealed to be greatly. When I finally jumped in I was met with a great story and amazing gameplay mechanics which keeps me coming back. content:
Posted: March 19
												All the claims of turn based strategy go out the window when 2/3 of your missions are auto fails in 6 turns or less.  If you dont risk sprinting across the map you'll fail, of course if you pull a group of aliens you also fail as your time runs out before you can deal with them and reach the objective. The percentage chances of shots are meaningless because no matter  how high a chance you have to hit its still 50/50. I missed 17 85% chance to hit shots IN A ROW.  Also poor camera angles when your troops act out your orders. Great view of the inside wall while my soldiers take their overwatch shots. This game feels rushed even though its been out for quite sometime as I write this review. Camera issues and graphic stutters really ruin the immersion.

												The game crashed while trying to play the tutorial, so I dont recommend this game...After a while of playing I can say this game makes me sad. I LOVED the original Xcom and after years of technological advances and a huge increase in computer capibilities, they manageed to make a game with less features and options than a game made in the 90's. Its as if the designers had a picture ("picture" as in a single literal picture) of a tactical combat game then built the game backwards. Then its as if after a couple years of development someone told the designers, "Hey there is this old game called Xcom made in 1994. You guys should make your game like that one."** Edit #1 ** Crashed again while loading a save. Even after the game "shutdown", Steam still thought it was running. The game had a file running in the background and Steam wouldnt budge  until I manually closed that program the game still had running (it was crash dump something exe).
