number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Why have I not written a review for this game yet? Eh. Here goes my usual wording of 'OMG GLORIOUS GAME'.So! XCOM 2 makes the assumption you f*cked up XCOM: Enemy Unknown and the world is now under the rule of the 'ADVENT Coalition' who are a puppet of the ethereal from Enemy Unknown. The game kicks off with as it usually does: A tutorial where people die! (At least it's none of your precious soldiers you've made!) But anyways!Once that’s done this is where you begin to create your own soldiers! (*Squeal of delight! *) Or be boring and do the game with the pre-generated soldiers. But if you bother to turn your best friends and yourself into operators you will get SO much more attached to them as you go through the campaign! Just imagine your best friend being under fire from several aliens while you: The glorious sniper of the crew has only one shot to save him! It's up to you to take that risk of 55% to kill one of the units trying to flank him to end his life.Now the missions in this can be a little repetitive (Shoot aliens, Grab item, evac and such forth) But the environments you fight in will feel oddly different when you do (Random map generation is glorious :D) And doing the monthly Op's can add a decent bit of variety. However, this game REALLY puts you under pressure with the turn limits, which I personally think is complete BS compared to the last game. I've had many scenarios where I've just wanted to wait the enemy out and sneak to the objective but NOPE! Three turns left on the clock so I gotta grenade and run my ranger up to the objective!And that brings me to something else: Classes! There are 5 types of specialisations/classes/operators and they are as follows:Ranger.Grenadier.Specialist.Sharpshooter.Psi Operative(6 if you include the SPARK from Shen's last gift DLC)Each of these operators was in XCOM: Enemy Unknown but under a different name and now they have received a major overhaul in skills, balances and abilities. (The ranger has a ♥♥♥♥ing sword! I'm not complaining!) The Psi operative is no longer a special person with 'The gift' it's now a trained-from-rookie unit, I don't like this myself but the masses of new abilities is awesome!I'd spoil the story and go into more detail but I have one last thing to say before I conclude this the graphics in this game... Beautiful... I honestly love the look of this game.But anyways: Get this game if you loved XCOM: Enemy Unknown and yes! I did diverge from some points but anyways! So, what are you waiting for?

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												4 Turns Left to Evac     My sniper is badly wounded, my Drone Rigger is keeping pace, two rookies are holding their own, and we have a scientist in tow that was busted out of an ADVENT prison cell. The problem is there isn't enough time to get to the evac. A sectoid and trooper are in the room with us. We have to make a decision. We blow up the wall nearest the evac. The civilians run.3 Turns Left to Evac     We barely survived the onslaught, we are legging it into the opening, we can taste freedom, but it's still too far. The sectoid chases, the advent chases, the scientist runs, everyone is running.2 Turns Left to Evac     We're almost there, the evac zone is in sight. A line of park benches provide cover for us to run. We've made it. We've made it. We just need to get to the LZ and we'll have survived. The scientist runs, everyone runs... the Sectoid mindspins.1 Turn to Evac     The Scientist makes it to the evac, the rookies make it barely alive, but still hanging on. The sniper limps there, barely avoiding a plasma round in the back of his skill. The rigger sits there. He is filled with fear, the invader in his mind. We leave him behind. The Skyranger runs.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												There are very few games I've come back to seeking that vicious cycle of: glory, hubris, pain, regret, dread, and glory again and again. I don't see myself as a masochist, but since XCOM: Enemy Unknown, I've found myself hungering for games that remind I'm not that I'm king of the world, but still make me feel like it whenever I conquer it's mounting challenges. Even after Enemy Unknown's initial launch in 2012, I found myself playing it again and again even after beating it the first time, not to mention with the equally exciting Enemy Within expansion in 2013. I didn't think another game would give me that same sense of accomplishment and make me fight to attain it, but I was wrong.In 2016, XCOM 2 reminds me again and again why I love this franchise.XCOM 2 is not XCOM: Enemy Unknown. Sure, it cover-based shooting and powerful alien weaponry mixed with dice rolls and failed 96% shots, but this game more than Enemy Unknown keeps you constantly wishing you were everywhere at once. XCOM 2 doesn't run you through every single system like EU, and some systems won't be as apparent the first time around, but failure and learning are one and the same here. I died a little when I realized the plate armor upgrade carried over to my entire personnel after several hours of playing and several more casualties had already transpired. But I realized how deftly X2 ripped off the training wheels when I couldn't simply sell off my wares to the Gray Market right before a crucially timed mission across the continent. That being said, some additions to the game make combating the alien-infested earth a much more attainable task. I was unsure of how much the concealment mechanic would change my playstyle, or if I would take advantage of it at all. But there is almost nothing more satisfying than setting up an overwatch ambush and seeing the aliens drop from your well placed death-nest of sniper shots and cannon fire.I can ramble on and on about this game, and once I have finished the game I'll be able to confirm if my mad ravings are more than just a fanatical sales-pitch or rose-tinted ad libs. Until then, it's good to be back. I for one will be playing this game for a very long time, and enjoying the regretful deaths and mistakes every step of the way.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												Recently finished the game on Commander.I like it a lot and see it overall as a big improvement.Short summary:-Big Step up from Enemy Unknown in difficulty, a lot of people are going to have trouble with it because Enemy Unknown was a cake walk in comparison. It's not as hard as the Long War mod for the original, but its definately up there, just less mindless grinding than long war had is the greatest difference.-Poor preformance issues all round, I turned down the big killer AA, but otherwise had everything else on high. I have a medium-high end rig, nothing amazing. I had around 40 fps constant, but sometimes it dipped pretty far. Annoying, but will probably be patched. Some people can't play at all which obviously needs to be fixed. The min specs are way below what they should have been given though.-Much more action packed and tactical than Enemy Unknown, people hate the timers, theres a mod that removes it or gives you four more rounds. Personally I didn't have a problem with it, made me seriously tactically consider things far more than the orginal. I lost three people to timers, holding the line while my squad escaped. Love it. Some people will hate it becuase they want to go 100+ rounds spamming overwatch, doesnt work anymore I'm afraid.-There are bugs, most definately. And then there are "bugs". The glass window two tiles over from your evac zone breaks due to ambient destruction and your evac point gets moved accross the map causing you to lose the mission. Thats a bug. The Vipers pulling you through walls but they can logically 'target' you and you them is not a bug people, get over it, you positioned poorly. Knocked out units been uncarriable so you lose them in evac is another big bug, happens fairly rarely though in my experience.Overall I think its a huge leap forward and I really enjoyed it. A few patches for performance and bug fixing and it will be extremely solid. They could 'perhaps' tweak the difficulty on lower settings but I found Commander competitive and hope Legendary will be even more fun.I'd give it a 8.5/10, 9/10 with a few performance patches.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												Short review ITS AWESOMEReal review WHAT IS X-COME 2 ?X-com 2 is a stratagy game that has 2 layers (and a bit now). 1 layer is the levels / battles where you control a squad of your troops too ambush and defeat alain troops and compleat objectives all in a turn based stratagy setting. The other witch is your base / antfarm where you perform research, staff parts of your base, train/ upgrade and equped your troops, upgrade your wepons and armour and finally manage resources like space suplies and energy. The bit is the map where you chose where to travel what leads to follow missions to undertake and so mutch more. Something else to add is the custimisation for troops i could spend all day makeing up there storey lines tweaking how the look and it really brings the universe to life.COMPARED TO 1X-com 2 is a step forward for the series. Now dont get me wrong with about 140 hours between console and the pc vertion of x-com 1 i really loved it but it had a few things that became anoying. X-com 2 fixed all that for me. Also if you don't have x-com 1 i really advise getting it whenever its on sail as i doubt you regret it. After 1 playthrough of x-com 1 you pretty much know what you need to do to win and ever campaign plays out the same. In e-xom 2 i am constantly altering my plans and reacting and improveing on them the 3 campaings i am in the middle of are all very different. you never need to change your stratagy or plan (Ant farm part of the game). In x-com 2 there is no go to stratagy and you have alot more intarations with the staff really makeing your base feel even more alive that it was before.On the blue map of the world in e-com 1 you just sat there in scanned and waited now in x-com 2 there is even stratagy to be had here .... do i want to go follow that info i got on some reasources over here in canada or do i want to add the rebels in this area to my resistance. Do i stop the alians unlocking this or that ?Troop development in excom 1 had a right way to do it and a wrong way..... for example squad sight on a sniper and snipers in genrall where so op compared to other classes and could even finish the games finale boss for you on there own in 1 turn before the alians could even think of hitting you back. In X-com 2 there is no go to skills and each trooper can be leveld differntly and still be good / competative and all classes have there place.There was a large pool of maps in x-com 1 but you quickly start to see the same ones over and over again (think i must have seen that small one with the fast food joing about 400 times) in x-com 2 its allmost imposable to get the same map 2 times it is genarated and put together by parts like a jigsaw every time you play a leveljust one last time i want to say x-com 1 was an awesome game it just had the few things above that stoped it being a masterpeice in my opinion...... x-com 2 IS a masterpeice.ok enough of compareing it to x-com 1  PERFORMANCEThe game is very well optimised with good frames at least in my experiance on both my pc rig and my laptop ... not quite perfect but quite good. ROUND UPI love this game. I love how the cannon is we failed x-com 1 the storeys between games makes so mutch more sence than the standard and they lived hap..... oh wait the bad guys are back. You can really get attached to the characters like central or shen and the troops you design yourself. content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												Overall, a fantastic addition to the XCOM/X-Com family.Pros:- Customizable troops- Enhanced tactical game responsiveness (aiming equipment, grenades are now useful, etc)- "Interesting choices" (i.e. it matters what you choose cause you can't get everything) on the Geoscape- Good story with cutscenes that don't beg to be skipped- Very difficult "special" enemies- Deep base management- Intel; this new resource is one of the primary methods of making choices on the geoscape matter- Improved Psi training and skill tree- Timed missions add some pressure and interest to tactical gameCons:- LONG load times- (at the time of this writing) Buggy soldier "cutscenes" in tactical combat- Overuse of timed missions; would have liked to have seen more fully tactical missions that start stealthed- Still didn't fix the wonky difficulty curve: early game is much more difficult than endgameOverall I would rate this game 8/10

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												As a huge fan of XCOM: Enemy Unknown, my expectations for the sequel were astronomical.They did not disappoint. Its the classic sequal route, more but better.The game is about as hard as playing chess against a six-armed bear with the brain of Bobby Fischer while balancing a plate of hollow eggs on your head at gunpoint.The workshop is shaping up to be pretty great, and will keep me coming back for more.Even all the things the aspect that everyone is up in arms about, the unceasing timers and turn limits, are pretty good design. They force you out of your comfort zone and make you think about everything you do, making you experiment with new strategies.The one downside is the abhorrent optimization. Like, its really terrible. 25 fps while im on the avenger? On a PC exclusive game? What? Luckily with a few tweaks you can have it up and running at an enjoyable framerate, and its not like the game is reflex based so its not really that big of an issue to begin with.UPDATE: Wow, my save games got corrupted out of nowhere, so I guess thats a restart for me. Seriously, how did this game launch in this state?!2nd UPDATE: Incredible. I cant run the final mission. Crash to desktop everytime. Unbelievable. I know I already said it, but how does a game launch like this? This is unfathomable. Crash every time, and I cant seem to fix it. Firaxis, we need a patch. Now.3rd Update: Most of the bugs are now ironed out, the workshop is flourishing, and while the DLC is a bit weak, its a fun game nontheless. Lots of replay value, similar to Enemy Unknown. Thumbs up from me!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												I am longwar fans (600+ h ),  I've been played this game for 20+ h. And sorry for my bad english.Suggestion: Do not start with Legendary + ironman, it's a new game, and they change the gameplay style in every aspect (tactic strategy, research tree, and research-gear relation, etc)So far I am pretty satisfied with all those IMPROVEMENTs. The reseaon I call it IMPROVEMENT rather than change are the following:1. Strategy: which is the most complaints about. However, to me, is not. Someone complain, there is always a timer for most of the games (maybe 7 out of 10). If you play longwar or vanilla, you spend a lot of time on searching the enemy, which is pretty boring. This may be is why they put a timer and decrease the map size, meanwhile increase the complexity. In this way, you just focus on "what the hell, How could I get out of here safely?" when you've done this, together with some LOOT, you will gain a lot of fun and sastisfactory. Every mission last for 20-30mins average. Some mission will last for 1 h. The game strategy rely more on your understanding of the following: a) Enviroment, not just cover and destroy cover, sometimes, a Perfects gernade will change everything (4+4 damage is possible!), especially in the start. there are many examples for you to discover. b) your understanding of the class builds, and every item(all of them are pretty useful), and each of the class plays its role in the gameplay. (compare with vanilla within, super hero-"sniper") c)Playstyle is various, Overwatch is not always the best way to kill the enemy, so does ranger. you will always have more and better choices, there is not a unique pattern to follow. And this is also why I suggest not choose ironman at first, you can discover many strategies. 2. DifficultyPersonally, I suggest longwar verterans starts with commander, famillar with  and gain some knowledge about the game(especially the research tree and mission choise). Because xcom 2 wiki is now under development, it's almost impossible to beat the legendary ironman. The Auto Save and Load design is pretty good, especially for those who rely on S/Ls. I mean, you never focus on when should I save? (S/L gurantee hits is a bad habit, xcom 2 will help you get rid of this) Find the diff level most suitable for you which also means minimize the S/L times. Be preparing for the final xcom experience ironman. (when xcom 2 wiki is complete, I will start Leg+ ironman)What do you think about Legendary Diff? I think it is suitable, but it's not for the beginners, seriously. If you are interested in that diff, you can search youtube, like Mr. Odd's(recommended), or some twitch channals. 3. Research + "New Foundry"-Proving Ground + Loot/Gear System.The new gear systems is pretty fun. the relation between those 3 is very neat. (I am pretty sure they gain the idea from LONGWAR). But I should say, there are still more space to improve.  Just enjoy it. 4. Missions: Becareful about the choices, especially in Commander and Legendary Difficult.It's not just as easy as "rush satallites" in within. Someone complains about the design, think, I've been already super frustrated about the tactic strategy, can you give me some "non-frustration" time? Maybe this is a point for those modder and developer to think about. Currently the game design is: "You will not have anytime to take a deep breath, aleins have already take control the world." You must stop this, although it is "IMPOSSIBLE".5. Bugs: A Lot of bugs...crushes is pretty common. Some bugs are funny, like, sometimes the enemy are "stunned", you name it...So may be it's not  the time to start the "Ultimate Xcom Experience: Ironman" LAST, I believe after some patches and mods, this game will become a "must buy".   Besides, there will be a LONGWAR mod to make it Legendary.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												Hit a bug where enemies will stare at you in pity instead of fight you for a few missions.Though I was doing pretty bad, only playing on baby (normal) difficulty. They probably felt sorry for all the save scumming I had to do to complete some prior missions. Or scumming and choosing a different, hopefully easier, RNG'd mission altogether.It aint a bad game. It runs well for me, loading times are good. Just feels a little too spiteful. Hard/full cover seems to mean about the same as soft/low cover. Same with elevation. And the to hit % is a lie i think. Tries to give you a little hope or something. It feels like a 98% chance to hit is the same as an 11%. I just take every shot now. No matter how many yards/walls/squaddies and floors I have to shoot through.I used to think I liked challenging games. Where you could find ways to nudge the odds in your favor. And see it was making a noticable impact. I like Darksouls. Darkest Dungeon. PVP games. XCOM EU/EW. But XCOM2 is kinda seeming to be too challenging. Or not rewarding enough. Or too stressful. Too much out of my control. Beating a tough mission isnt that great of a feeling usually. Always end up with wounded units that are out of action for weeks on end missing out on missions and not advancing. Throwing new recruits in instead who get chewed up or wounded and put in the infirmary too. And dont forget that doomsday clock is really ticking up, and we are out of power, and we havent got enough engineers, and the missions are jumping up in difficulty rapidly. Just throw more rookies and corporals at them! Until you run out of supplies cause you were dumb and didnt counter the recruitment dark event and countered the doomsday clock ticking up instead. Dumb♥♥♥♥♥Just not what I hoped it would be. And that Punished Bradford is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ Guess ill try ultra babymode (rookie) and see if my appreciation for this game improves.

content:
Posted: March 19
												All the claims of turn based strategy go out the window when 2/3 of your missions are auto fails in 6 turns or less.  If you dont risk sprinting across the map you'll fail, of course if you pull a group of aliens you also fail as your time runs out before you can deal with them and reach the objective. The percentage chances of shots are meaningless because no matter  how high a chance you have to hit its still 50/50. I missed 17 85% chance to hit shots IN A ROW.  Also poor camera angles when your troops act out your orders. Great view of the inside wall while my soldiers take their overwatch shots. This game feels rushed even though its been out for quite sometime as I write this review. Camera issues and graphic stutters really ruin the immersion.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												This is a Review of the game after my first play through.I liked the game but feel like its another rush job from FIRAXIS/Y2K. Don't buy untill this game is optimised and finished. At the moment it feels like Early Access Beta.Tactical game in XCOM 2 is excellent, the strategic layer/story is a bit of a let down. A lot of Base management doesn’t make sense. (Why are scientists essentially useless and engineers do all science jobs?)Overall game feels a bit rushed and unfinished. This is a shame because there is an excellent tactical game in here.All the budget was spent on fancy hats for your troops..Pros+Fun and addictive tactical missions+Environmental destructibility (open the door or just blow up the wall/ceiling)+Random Maps+Lots of tactical options in missionsCons-Game wastes a lot of your time with pointless unskippable transition animations-Terrible use of the Unreal engine. I have no idea how they have managed to make this game run so horribly. It feels like it's barely holding holding together.-No support/patches/acknowledgement from the developer for the game's technical issues-Story is serviceable at best, with a cliffhanger ending because of course it will not have a satisfying ending (must set up DLC/xcom 3)-Final battle is just lame-Seems to be always-online (that is probably the cause of some of its performance issues)-At the end of the campaign it doesn't even show proper stats (world stats are missing)-No way to turn off annoying unskippable animations (eg hacking)-Camera controls are terrible, no options to customise anything. game takes control of the camera even if you don’t want it too-Unskippable in mission dialog (unable to perform actions)-DLC feels like ideas that  were cut from the game-No mission variety-No way of choosing your own actions/missions (have to wait for them to pop up)-No free mode (can’t turn off story mode)

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												Good game, but (very) disappointing.The fact that it was potspone for a few months made me believe it was for an actual good reason, to release it into a somewhat "perfect" state. I heard "Let's not make the same mistake of failing the release, like so many else".Obviously, I misheard.The game itself.The "2", for me, stands up for "more".And for customisation, that's true. It is a huge step up in looks, weapons, tools, passive traits, and unique skills. Somewhat perfect. (Well, almost, when the gloomy character you made in the pool will show with an idiotic smile instead, you may feel a bit let down,  their attitude is randomized, immersion lost).And, that's it.Everything else seems "more less" (DLCs pattern).The worldmap.Oh man, I was so kicked by it on the teasers.. By the looks of it, It may be like Aftershock, maybe even more, like the one in Afterlight..Well, it is not.It is an empty land with pop-ups. Where you are urged to slow the "Avatar Project" by Captain Obvious every 2 minutes, actually by wasting this so precious time, moving and locking your camera and controls away for the time he repeats the same phrase over and over again. (In order to show you a spot where you can only interact with on the very last mission).I understood the stakes here the very first time Bradford, please believe me.Of course this so had to happen while in missions too.Can feel like Internet without ad-blockers. Old days.The resistance.After contacting them, well, they will write you a check after the end of each month. That's about it.And they get passively slaughtered on retaliation missions ('cause aliens don't like them for writing you checks), as Bradford will unavoidably never fail to mention.A resistance that doesn't actually resists. Strange concept. (To be fair, they may not carry wepons, but they will manage to take down some UFO's for you, to remind you the name of the original title).The Base.You build what you can, when you can. Thats's about it, with a bit of management. Feels better than the last one, can't compare to the originals (was more like mini-SimCity). Still, rather good I might say.Discussions between staff can be muted, if not, they don't freeze your screen when talking (wich is something someone could have learnt from his comrades).Research.It is deeply simplified, for the second time (so long old-timers) : Research Tier 2 weapons & armor, research Tier 3 weapons & armor. Autopsies unlock new tools, and they made the option to instantly research those after some "breakthrough" on the next Tier.So, do you want to research x for 3 days, y for 4, then next Tier for 10 ? Or next Tier for 10 and instant x & y ? Tough choice.Let me break your expectations, there are bullets, laser, plasma. Yes, those are the same (more straightforward). And no, there's no MEC.If you haven't played the precedent game, won't be a problem though.Overall progression.Fine by your troops, slow and steady, each skill, every bit of scrap seem to matter. Very well done.The way ennemies are introduced every two missions is not. It soon feels like a freak show, and utterly destroys the low profile Aliens are supposed to have (Sure Bradford, they don't have to hide, but frightening the population doesn't seem great either). More coherence would have been nice, like maybe only Advents troops in cities, other species represented in the "wild", or in Resistance lands, maybe common/rare types, etc.Some are underused and replaced, other overused. "Codex" is a perfect example, so great ennemy, brillant design, until it becomes absolutely common in every mission, therefore losing all of its aura.The combat.The system still works, stealth mecanic is also a fine addition.But it lacks coherence. Why the ennemy would blow up his precious installation without him knowing we're here ? Why is all squad revealed when only one member is detected ?Just to justify the turn-limit and the one scout class, who will be better at never actually fighting. Not enough for me. It limits the way you play more than it opens it, not so good for tactics.The turn-limit system and very small maps resume gameplay to :1) Take a direct shot at 30%.2) Make a flanking move (with a 70% to trigger new ennemies).3) Blow up cover with explosives and shot after.Answer is 3) until you have to make 2) due to the turn limit, wich is now a bad move. I think the precedent system of ennemy triggering and their free move & turn should have been arranged to better fit this new layout.Normal difficulty is more permissive strategically wise, higher ones and the fact that the game is currently crippled with bugs will only lead to an irritating experience.Last but not least, in its current state, all of this will be darkened by the fact that you will be detected for no reason, sometimes even shot at the very same moment, melee & shot through walls, moving on another tile than the one you clicked, performance issues, etc.Replay value is kinda limited in a way, you will have researched everything when you beat the game the first time, "screen locking" will still be there and it doesn't grow more pleasant, no second wave options (not even unlocking customisation at beginning), and Ironman seems avoidable with gameplay bugs.Oh, and a special mention to the "Final Mission" and its idiotic moment.. Worst concept ever, and Hack'n Shoot'n Slash parody. "Or when Aliens do recall they could summon infinite troops instantly". Brillant.What should have been the most epic moment of the game chose to be the most depressing last note ever. I think underwhelming good reviews state what the game will/might be, and in this case I might agree with them, but certainly not what it currently is.I'm pretty sure it will be a better game than its predecessor, but releasing in this state can't be supported as it is literally asking for this kind of pratice.(As for an example, not much, but clearly shows a lot, in french, some voices have the same number, and the country of origin is repeated again at the end of each biography. Meaning, not even a single person took a single look at it before launching the game.)If you haven't already bought the game, spare yourself the disappointment now and buy it when the actual release comes out, wich is programmed for the second half of 2016.+Another XCOM+We can play before release !-Shouldn't have been released yet.-Way too oftenly Bradforded

content:
Posted: March 18
												The game crashed while trying to play the tutorial, so I dont recommend this game...After a while of playing I can say this game makes me sad. I LOVED the original Xcom and after years of technological advances and a huge increase in computer capibilities, they manageed to make a game with less features and options than a game made in the 90's. Its as if the designers had a picture ("picture" as in a single literal picture) of a tactical combat game then built the game backwards. Then its as if after a couple years of development someone told the designers, "Hey there is this old game called Xcom made in 1994. You guys should make your game like that one."** Edit #1 ** Crashed again while loading a save. Even after the game "shutdown", Steam still thought it was running. The game had a file running in the background and Steam wouldnt budge  until I manually closed that program the game still had running (it was crash dump something exe).

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25
												First and foremost let me say I've always been an Xcom fan.  I've played since the 90's.  I'm not bad at the game either and I love the difficulty.  Losing troops, failing missions, and the tension that permadeath brings is fantastic.  The previous Xcom game was amazing.  This game has some poorly executed gameplay ideas and extremely frustrating bugs.  I've got about 40 hours into this game and maybe 15 of it are replaying game sections because I got screwed over by a bug.  Line of sight in this game is busted.  You will get shot through solid walls, floors, and even the map itself.  Hit %'s don't represent the actual percentage as their are metrics and abilities not factored in (dodge for example).  Sometimes abilities flat out don't work.  I've had every enemy on the map turn invisible and slaughter me.  The last straw for me was when one of my squaddies just said screw it and laid down.  Half health, concious, and alive they just laid in the street.  I couldn't pick them up.  I couldn't revive them because they were not bleeding or unconcious.    Like a toddler they just said, "I'm done doing this."  I thought to myself, "Me too squaddie, me too."  I want to love this game, I really do.  I'm sad to give it a negative review and I hope after several patches these things work out.  I'll revisit it once its worked through.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												Didn't have a crash once, saw no glitches, other than the delays in turns, which a mod fixed like day 4, Customization is insanely awesome, i was a person who believed it would add nothing to the game. I was totally wrong, the introduction of the character pool, which allows you to create soldiers and then import them to your game or show up as rookie recruits is amazing. The game is an improvement on the previous xcom games in LITERALLY ALL WAYS. The base building lets you have freedom and choice now, no more limitations such as forced to build Uplinks asap. The new enemy variation is astounding, new enemies show up constantly keeping you on your toes, constantly wondering what the game may throw at you next.  The Viper enemies are probablly the worst alien to see, they take whatever plan you had and make you throw it out the window quickly so you can try to come up with a way to save your soldiers. (they do pathetic dmg though hardly a threat on their own)The loot dropping mechanics and weapon upgrade system, are awesome, really giving you the feeling that you are working with what resources you are given, replacing Meld, with the detonating loot. BRILLIANT. The story was quite thin in Enemy unknown but it served its purpose, the story here is more fleshed out, and you could tell they wanted to give you a good reason to push throught the trials, to save humanity from the Avatar project. The Woudned system works differently you can have lightly wounded, wounded, or gravely wounded soldiers. If someone is gravely wounded they are healing for around 15 in game days, and if the aliens retaliate with your best troops wounded it can seem terrifying. (still beatable)       This new system teaches you to be safe with your soldiers, sometimes causing you to be too safe and screw up evacuation missions, but thats what Xcom2 is about. The Classes have been given much more attention, both trees are very appealing in their own ways and both are viable in every class.Psionic troopers are available earlier in the game!!!!! However they are only available early if you take the sacrifices of not building your Guerilla building, or your workshop. You can take a chance at fighting the aliens with only 4 troops, or have your 6 troops, but be behind on your psionics research and training.Psionic troopers take FOREVER TO TRAIN (literally around 2 MONTHS in game time. But that is to have a completly trained soldier, with literally all psionic abilities.  However this is not a negative, they become precious troops, whom will actually force you to play the game better, and that is only because of the new injury system, without it they would just feel like overpowered troops with no downside. The new "failure state" comes when you allow the Aliens' Avatar project to go unchecked, you were either busy training psi soldiers (like me in my first game) or busy trying to get a bunch of supplies. This failure state is far more satisfying than the countries leaving the Xcom project. You feel like you actually have a tangible thing to fight against rather than just HOPING that the next Abduction mission does't happen to your highest panic countries. .If you fail, it was your fault. not just because rng decided to make it so.TLDR-An improvment in all ways over previous xcom games, -EXTREMELY varied enemy pool.-Varied customization.-Sticks to the solid gameplay Enemy unknown made us all love-Concealment is super satisfying and getting the jump on aliens is glorious. -Weapon upgrade system helps add more flavor to your already flavorful troops-Base building is way less constrictive, and because of this actually leads to more choices, and therefore more varied replays of the game.-Story is given more love-Classes are now quite balanced giving you more choice when you rank up. -Mod Support on Day 1, that basically fixed anything the dev's didn't think of, or didn't have time for.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												Dear god, this game. And I mean that in a good way.I just played through the game from day of release to tonight, non-stop, and never have I felt such a boiling pot of emotions from a game in my entire life. This game hurt me, this game made me feel stressed, and this game made me feel stupid. But at the same time, this game encouraged me, this game made me feel good about myself, this game made me think, and rewarded my when I took time to do so.There are tons of improvements over the original XCOM, namely ones relating to armor and weapon upgrades, along with resource acquisition and base management. It all just felt a lot more smooth and made much more sense to me. Instead of spending hundreds on a single gun, you spent it to upgrade your entire force's arsenal. When making the incredibly high-tier end-game armors, you had to manufacture them in the proving grounds over a course of several days (depending on your engineer count) but not having that armmor was never really a death sentence. My favorite improvement through is the level of customization added to this XCOM title. Every soldier feels that much more special after you spend upwards of hours messing around with their armor, guns, props, faces, attitudes, voices, etc to make one that just works for you (Look at my playtime; at least 1/10th of that was spent in the character creator/editor alone.) It feels easier to get attached to squad members in this game as such, making it hurt that much more when your favorite dies, or make you get that much more on edge when they're in danger.Of course, this game is FAR from perfect. It's plagued with some major artificial difficulty in certain aspeects, such as many enemies having a large amount of health, armor and damage relative to your abilities to take them down at that point in time. Another thing people have been complaining about: Mission timers. These were added to reduce the likelihood for players to overwatch crawl through every mission, and many say that they're just too much. I agree, AND disagree with that. The timers add urgency to the game, and make every move count much more than it did in Enemy Unknown/Within.  While, at the same, the timers DO feel rather... Short, at times. If they were closer to 10 and 14 instead of 8 and 12 for missions respectively, my guess is there wouldn't be as many people upset about them as there are now.Overall, I'd say the game is most definitely worth picking up if you enjoyed Enemy Unknown IMO. If you're new to the franchise though, I'd say going for EU & EW together, or the original, classic XCOM for a more cheap intro to the series. XCOM 2 and Enemy Unknown aren't DRASTICALLY different, so if you find you like that one, I whole-heartedly recomend this one.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												Playing this game in ironman mode is frustrating because of the bugs.-Line of sight issues (aliens can shoot you through floors and walls, when they shouldn't be able to see you). This makes high ground unreliable, since the enemy can enter the building and shoot you from underneath.-Cover and flanking are not reliable. It rarely happens, but sometimes a flanked enemy will not be labelled as flanked, and sometimes a soldier under cover will be labelled as flanked. It's rare but it'll ruin an ironman game if it happens.-Sometimes a game does not save properly, and your ironman run will disappear and become unrecoverable.-Grenades are the biggest tactical advantage in early game, and their explosion radius is unreliable. The HUD does not highlight the radius correctly. Throwing a grenade with a 1-tile space from cover may or may not blow it up. Even if it isn't highlighted by the HUD, it may still blow up. Basically an early grenade has a 3x3 radius of guaranteed cover damage, and a 5x5 radius of MAYBE cover damage that isn't shown.Some non-bug issues:-During concealment phase, the enemy knows your exact location and will walk towards you, forcing engagement. This happens if you sneak close to the target, which will force an engagement with 2 or 3 pods. This makes sneaking to the target impractical.RNG already makes the game unpredictable, but with unpredictable bugs it becomes hard to enjoy the tactical part of the game.**EDIT**Played even more, some more game-breaking bugs:-Sometimes can't open door to rescue VIP, results in failed mission.-A failed cerebral mine has bug that will kill specialist over time during the mission. -Rushing research does not work properly on Legend difficulty. Causes -Killing Andromedon in the first-contact phase on overwatch will magically allow the andromedon to attack (usually aliens will run to cover).I was given the suggestion to just play without ironman, and only reload if a bug happens. The problem with this is that all the moves made leading up to the bug are no longer a surprise, which is what makes ironman fun to play in the first place.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												EDIT - There are already mods on the Workshop to disable timers, which is the basis for a huge number of negative reviews here. So, y'know, keep that in mind.Pros- Punishing; you WILL lose soldiers you WILL NOT win every mission or campaign.- Wonderful model and texture work, with nice lighting and shading.- Feels different enough to justify a new game imo.- Enemy patrols are a game changer, forcing you to pick your battles and make the most of your advantages.- Large array of character customization, letting you create and become attached to digital representations of your friends so you can watch helplessly as they are torn apart by aliens. With Workshop support, there is almost endless possibilities for new cosmetic options.- Extremely open modding, to the point where some core mechanics are essentially .ini value tweaks.- 42GB of development content in the SDK to work and create new content with. Seriously awesome.Cons- Others report performance issues, though I have not experienced them aside from slight stuttering during the insertion cinematic animations. (i74790k, 32gb RAM, TitanX, Win10, installed on SSD).- Strange pauses once in a while before or after actions, though I haven't found it as annoying as others appear to have.Notes- It's not EU or EW with better graphics, it's a different game. Most missions have turn timers which force you to think and play aggressively and take risks, rather than turtle your favorite soldiers up 1 square at a time. Some people hate this, they say it isn't "fair" or "too hard". Personally I really enjoy it for the reasons I listed here.

												HUGE amounts of bugs and gameplay issues that make it impossible to play. I love XCOM, see how many hours I have on XCOM 1, and was so excited about XCOM 2But the game is frankly an unfinished, buggy mess. Some examples - My solider is on the ground floor, inside a building.  I can see, shoot and kill an enemy through THREE intervening ceilings without actual line of sight. The same happens with the AI in reverse.Then we have situations where a player runs up to cover but instead of hiding behind it, switches to walk up the side of it like spiderman - or in some cases, walks up thin air so he is at a 90 degree angle to the rest of the map. Or gets stuck trapped inside a wall.  OR simply disappears when the move is finished.Coupled with all manner of other impossible shooting & moving issues, colossally stupid AI (I even tried the improvement mod), and absolutely shocking graphics performance on high end kit I'm gutted. Hugely disappointed.I can only show my dissatisfaction in one meaningful way, and that is to get my money back.If they ever fix it, I'll think about coming back.But right now it's horrible.  And that's very sad.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
												UPDATE, after installing once again, hoping that they fixed stuff by now:- still runs like♥♥♥♥♥ even on absolute minimal settings; waiting for the flashy menu transitions (basically every time you click something in the strategy layer) probably accounts for half my play time. I know my system is getting old, but I don't have this issue with other games that have similar graphical quality. XCOM:EU ran flawlessly on max, XCOM2 chugs along on minimal.- iron man is still a succession of frustrations with inconsistent line of sight, extraction zones that get moved to the other side of the map with 1 turn left (because one tile got damaged!), unpredictable environmental damage, etc.- oh great, turns out I got a completely useless set of continental bonuses, thanks RNG! Should I replay the entire first month of the campaign if I want a set of fun ones?- having played the game a while, I realized the maps being random just means every single one of them is forgettable. Would much rather have had a good selection of well designed static maps. You know, with interesting choke points, etc.- a few mods provide improvement on a few design choices, but most of them are just collections of shiny helmets and weapons from other pop culture franchises. It's cool, but it doesn't save the game from being underwhelming.ORIGINAL REVIEW:If you want to play this on ironman, it's probably better to hold off on purchasing for a couple of months. Too many bugs and inconsistencies mean it's a rather frustrating affair.The good:- modding support- animations/ragdoll physics- more customization of soldiers and weapons (both functional and aesthetic)The bad:- very poor performance on all graphic settings- lots of waiting for animations to finish- unintuitive and cumbersome UI- strategic choices are largely illusory, you're kind of forced into a certain path of action if you don't want to lose- lots of bugs dealing with line of sight- overreliance on RNG to simulate diversity, screwing you over in ways that are beyond "that's XCOM baby"- not a very interesting difficulty curveI'm halfway during my second campaign (on 2nd highest difficulty) and I simply can't be arsed to start up the game anymore, since it feels like a chore to have to sit through all the bad in order to get to the good parts.I really wanted to like this more, but I can't really recommend XCOM2, based on my experiences so far and the price they're asking. I'm probably going to play very little until they either patch the hell out of this, or some genius modders do.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2016
												I love the XCOM series. Having played XCOM since 1994, I was really nervous when XCOM: Enemy Unknown came out in 2012, but it was an enjoyable reboot. It had its flaws and limitations but all in all was a fun game to play. I was blown away with XCOM 2, it is everything I wanted in a sequel. Not only is this game worth paying full price for, it is also worth the inevitable hardware upgrade you're probably going to have to do to fully enjoy the game. I have an older gaming system, hardware is about 7 years old. I only had to upgrade system RAM from 4GB to 8GB and my video card from a GeForce GTX 260 to a GeForce GTX 750Ti 2GB, in order to run DirectX 11. All in all only about a $180 upgrade but it runs the game perfectly. XCOM 2 take place a few decades after XCOM: Enemy Unknown (EU), but with a twist. Without having any spoilers for anyone who hasn't played XCOM: EU or XCOM 2 yet, the end of one does not match up completely with the beginning of the other. XCOM 2 is unlike most every other sci-fi sequel out there, and is much more enjoyable in my opinion.PROS:-Original Storyline.-Fully Customizable Squad (ALL Squad specialties are useful, unlike previous Xcoms).-Amazing Graphics.-Tons of replay value.-Computer AI is well done, unpredictable and fully uses the environment and weapon systems against you.-Stays true to the core principles of XCOM.CONS:-Requires A LOT of hard drive space 45GB for basic install.-Graphics Glitches that sometimes effects gameplay.**-Smaller map size, not a lot of huge buildings to clear like XCOM: TFTD.-Can have slow load times.-Average game length.**= Ghosting sometimes occurs and during graphics intensive segments (like catastrophic explosions) characters sometimes display incorrect actions afterward. (Like constant crouching or constriction after 'bladestorm' etc)Probably my favorite turn-based strategy game of the last decade, and a must-have for any XCOM fan!

content:

												Fantastic sequel to Xcom: EU. It succeeded in fixing nearly every gripe I had with the first game. Also perhaps more importantly, it managed to keep the same feel of progression as in the first game, despite having to research nearly the same technologies and weaponry all over again. Highly reccomend.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												If you liked the 1990's originals or Xcom: EU/EW, this game has something for you. Play on the second difficulty level if you're used to playing EU/EW on classic, as that's about the same kind of difficulty. This game is tough, but fair. The strategic global layer is deeper than last time, and the gameplay is similar but significantly different to the first game, so that people good at the first game will find this one tough too. There are some bugs, but nothing major and we're still awaiting the first patch so that's fine.I highly recommend this to people who liked EU/EW. If you didn't play them, play them before you buy this since they're some of the best games released in the last few years. This game, however, is better. This might be the game of the year for me.

												I played the first XCOM, haven't tried the XCOM: Enemy Within DLC, have no idea about XCOM 2 until it release date but XCOM 2 really got me hooked. Aside from the game feels alittle bit rush (Spoiler: project Avatar will make your life a living hell if you fail to delay it) and the aliens can be d*cks sometimes with godly aim. To sum up, game is awesome. In addition, the game is really well optimized i can play it just fine with my crappy laptop (Core i5-4200U 1.6GHz, Nvidia GT720m 2GB, 8GB DDR3 L Memory Ram.) Overwatch is kinda overrated in this game but the stealth mechanic is really cool (for setting up ambushes, rush objective,) also this time you can actually save your fallen beloved soldiers from the battlefield which is super since iam kinda attached to some of my toons. In conclusion this game is worth 59.99$ for what it is giving the players, i do recommend you to get it if it is on sale or full price if you can :3 9/10 - Superb.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												Xccom 2 has incredible graphics thanks to the unreal world builder and great artistic work by those who deserve credit. That is the only good thing I have to say about Xcom 2.So far in my commander difficulty game I have not enjoyed any of it. Every single mission is the same. You are on rails the entire game. Every map is your squad walking straight across the map, no exploration, you walk directly from point a to point b, every single time. No exploration, you know without question where the enemies are. It's not tactical at all. Every mission has the same enemies and the same ammount of them. Nothing fun about this game and to top that off the dialog is unforgivable. Jake solomon is hands down the worst thing that has ever happened to Xcom. Constant misuse of words in dialog, with no intelligent flow from subject to subject. Just as if Sarah Palin wrote the scripts and then they paid some voice over to read each word of the script. However they only record each word one at a time and paste all the words together so you get the MOST akward dialog at times where you know for a fact that the sentence was spliced together by seperate audio clips. So lazy for a 60dollar game especially a well established game company thats been in business for years, you would expect much more than this.A lot of people complain about performance, I have no issues with performance, but I must note that at times enemy death can take upto 10 seconds. You're just sitting waiting, the death only took 2 of the 10 seconds but you just sit there waiting for the game. It might seem like lag but you can see the soldiers idle animations and frame rate isn't dropped or locked at all. Music mouse ect work just fine but it's as though there is wait time programmed into so much of the animation sequences that the game plays like a poker game where one person is in the other room ALL THE TIME.The worst part about this game is that it's only an intellectual property license which means you can't get a refund for the game and you can't take a literal♥♥♥♥♥♥on it. Because there are only two things that this game would be good for, pooping on it, and returning it for a refund.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												Sequels that are just retreads/reskins of the previous title are all too common nowadays.  XCOM 2 is everything that a sequel should be.  It takes the game play of the original and improves upon it in every way.  All of the player classes are reworked and improved.  All of the returning enemy types have been remade and there are several new enemy types.  Levels are now randomly generated instead of being the same dozen maps over and over.  The geoscape has been completely redone.  The game has mod support with Steam Workshop at launch.  The new concealment system adds many new tactical optionsSeveral outspoken people have complained that the mission timers and Geoscape timer have "ruined the game" but I will disagree and say that these 2 additions are the two best improvements from the previous game.  In the previous XCOM, it was all too easy to turtle with overwatch and completely minimize any risk.  Many missions in XCOM 2 have a turn limit that require you to complete the mission, or a mission objective with in X number of turns.  This forces you to be less conservative with your actions and keeps you moving forward.  This makes gameplay much more interesting and dynamic. Sometimes you will loose missions and some times you might have to sacrifice some of your soldiers to save others.On the Geoscape, some times you will end up in a situation where you have to take a dark site mission or some other mission related to the Geoscape timer at the expense of ignoring some other mission.  This forces you to make decisions that can impact your game.A lot of people do not seem to understand that a game you always win isn't fun.  Fun is feeling like you accomplished something and you can only feel a sense of accomplishment if there is a real challenge.  XCOM 2 does provide a challenge and is fun.
